column8: Bought the game early access way back when and was at first happy with my purchase. However the game was abandoned before reaching any kind of completed state. I am only leaving this review because I am surprised to see that it is still for sale.   Double Fine does not support this game in the least and left it up to the community to finish it. They should be ashamed of themselves to leave this on the store for customers to purchase without clearly labeling it as unfinished.

column8:
[h3]If you look up the definition of broken and mediocre games, this game should be front and center...[/h3]
Abandoned and gutted before its time. I got this in a bundle of Double Fine games and felt that I at least had to try it out to see if the overwhelmingly negative score was corrected, and yea, it totally deserves it.. Ironically enough, Tim Schafer has some absolute bangers in his hall of fame with Monkey Island, Psychonauts and Day of the Tentacle to name some of the most prolific, and then there are the likes of Hack N Slash and Spacebase DF-9. Sure, this is the work of Double Fine which one could argue is a whole different company from his earlier works, but still, one starts to wonder how it could go so completely sideways. 

This game is centered around building and building a spacebase (no surprise there) while gathering an oddball crew of workers to populate it and raid mysterious space hulks in the vicinity. This sounds great on paper, but the game is janky, broken and most importantly unfinished and if it were not for the great work of the community putting out patch after patch to polish it up to a decent standard this would be a complete waste of space in my library. 

[b]Conclusion:[/b]Avoid and do not bother, there are far better games out there for this price. The fact that this game is still available to buy for 10â‚¬ is a scam, in my humble opinion. Somewhere in its DNA is the glimmer of a great game that never manifested itself, and instead we get an infested scrapcode filled with the broken dreams of all those who were left behind..

column8: I wanted to dislike this game so bad, but I gave it a fair shake: I used the unofficial 1.09 patch and got playing. I did have to try multiple times to create a successful base, mainly due to bugs still left in and having to figure out how the game likes to be played without turning into a broken mess... but after plenty of swearing, restarting, and monkeying with the LUA scripts in order to alleviate some (many) infuriating aspects, I found myself actually enjoying it. Sure, it's in no way, shape or form a game that should be recommended to anyone nowadays, especially considering that it looks like something out of the late 90s and that I needed to apply source edits on top of the mod, but 100+ hours don't lie.

column8: My play time is real, this is the best game I own when it works! Build a space station, manage your crew and rehabilitate raiders which make the best security guards. Its like Prison Architect meets rimworld and does stuff Space Haven wishes it could.... When it works, sometimes fires just start and people start fighting and die, and theres always alien bugs popping out of peoples chests so morale gets real low real fast and people start failing to thrive... My best playthrough I had a crack team of Raider security specialists, all the best professions, and all the resources I could ask for, but I still died because raiders got to my power generator and oxygen recyclers went down. Its the best game ever but it isn't finished and sometimes you get really commited to a colony build just to have a fire bug and eat all the oxygen forever untill everyone suffocates.

column8: I really enjoyed this game when it came out.  Yes, there were a lot of bugs, but the concept was nice.  To find out later that the developer abandoned this game and laid off the team that was working on it was a gut punch.  The stupidity of the decision makers for this was so surprising in one way, but on the other hand, not so much.  When this game was put into early release and added on Steam, you truly expect the developer to do their best to make sure that the product is up to snuff for a commercial release.  What Double Fine Productions did was rush out an unfinished product because they did not see the sales number in early release that they were expecting.  The condition that they put this game in for early release was not very good and there were a lot of bugs.  If this is just some prototype that they came up with in a brainstorm, what they called Amnesia Fortnight, then it should have stayed in Alpha and finished more before releasing it into early access on Steam.  What Double Fine should have done was refund everyone their money back because they did not release the product that they were promising.  After this debacle, management should have been let go.  Since the release of this game, I have never and will never by a game that this company has developed or published.  I also cannot believe that this game is still up for sale on Steam and that is has not been taken down yet.  Unfinished commercial releases should be against the Steam ToS, but everyone will keep trying to rake in some money, even from unfinished crap.

column8:
Although I'm not recommending it, this is an interesting concept of a game. If you are very adept at base builders and love to micromanage, this would be a game for you.

HOWEVER;
Don't go into it thinking it'll be a cosy 'sit back and watch them work' type of game because the difficulty ramping is not balanced. 
There are still bugs that mean your colonists are perpetually sad. And it doesn't make it easy to find what they were sad about to begin with.
Security detail is near useless
Shelves cost the same resources as an oxygen scrubber

And it's not like any of these bugs will be patched as it got stuck in dev limbo when the original indie-devs dropped it. And now even their website can't be reached so the fabled 'Patch' I've heard of can't even help.

TLDR: Could have been good, but no point in buying it.
column9:
Although I'm not recommending it, this is an interesting concept of a game. If you are very adept at base builders and love to micromanage, this would be a game for you.

HOWEVER;
Don't go into it thinking it'll be a cosy 'sit back and watch them work' type of game because the difficulty ramping is not balanced. 
There are still bugs that mean your colonists are perpetually sad. And it doesn't make it easy to find what they were sad about to begin with.
Security detail is near useless
Shelves cost the same resources as an oxygen scrubber

And it's not like any of these bugs will be patched as it got stuck in dev limbo when the original indie-devs dropped it. And now even their website can't be reached so the fabled 'Patch' I've heard of can't even help.

TLDR: Could have been good, but no point in buying it.

column9:
[h1]Spacebase DF-9 Review: What Happened Here, Guys?[/h1]

[h2]Summary[/h2]
Welcome to my review of Spacebase DF-9, the game that promised to take you to the stars but left you floating in the void. It's like buying a ticket for a space cruise and ending up on an inflatable boat with a hole in it.

[h2]Important and Interesting Aspects[/h2]
The highlight of Spacebase DF-9 is the premise of building and managing your own space station. Great, right? Sounds like every sci-fi fan's dream, until you realize that dream comes with a price tag of not-so-pleasant realities.

[h2]Aspects for Improvement[/h2]
Oh, friends, the list is long. From resource management that makes you feel more like a struggling accountant, to an interface that looks like it was designed by aliens (and not the intelligent ones). Plus, occupant AI is like talking to a wall. Sometimes literally.

[h2]Scoreboard[/h2]
[table]
[tr][th]Category[/th][th]Score[/th][th]Comments[/th][/tr]
[tr][td]Gameplay[/td][td]3[/td][td]Just like trying to build an IKEA space station without a manual[/td][/tr]
[tr][td]Difficulty / AI[/td][td]2[/td][td]AI makes less sense than a flying fish in space[/td][/tr]
[tr][td]Content[/td][td]5[/td][td]They promised a universe, they delivered an asteroid[/td][/tr]
[tr][td]Video / Graphics[/td][td]6[/td][td]Not bad, but it's not a trip through the Hubble either[/td][/tr]
[tr][td]Story[/td][td]2[/td][td]Story? What story?[/td][/tr]
[tr][td]Setting[/td][td]7[/td][td]The most decent part of the game, you really feel like you're in space (alone)[/td][/tr]
[tr][td]Effects[/td][td]4[/td][td]Noticeable effects, but where's the atmosphere? [/td][/tr]
[tr][td]Music[/td][td]5[/td][td]Adequate, but don't expect it to transport you to another galaxy[/td][/tr]
[tr][td]Vocals[/td][td]2[/td][td]Play on mute, your ears will thank you[/td][/tr]
[tr][td]Diversity[/td][td]5[/td][td]An attempt that doesn't take off[/td][/n][/tr]
[tr][td]Total scores[/td][33][td]It's not even an alien sum that works out[/td][/tr]
[/table]

[h3]Final Evaluation[/h3]
If your total scores are less than [b]50[/b]: [i]Don't buy it[/i].

There you have it, Spacebase DF-9, the game that's more of a challenge to your patience than your skill as a player. My suggestion? Spend that money on something more rewarding, like a large pizza to enjoy while you choose another game.

column8:
They shat the bed with this one. Abandoned and incomplete. So much promise - which made the choice to bail on this all the more disappointing. This could have been a really great game - but it's nowhere near ready and was dumped on the store as a finished product rather than scrapped as it should have been (presumably to avoid needing to give refunds).

The good news is you can pick up Space Haven and it will go quite some way to scratching the itch DF-9 should have.

column8:
I bought this in 2013 and played it a bit then. It looked like it could be something, but I guess a few years later (2015) they killed off the game. The good news is they released the source code and the community fixed the bugs and have been patching it. It appears the last patch and final to be coming out was released a year ago (early 2023). 

It is sad to see this go like it did since this could've been a lot more. But at least we got the source code and the community could fix the game and bring it to a point worth while. 
I can never recommend a game like this where they killed it off in such a way it literally caused Steam to change it's policy on EA games on them not using this as their only source of income. And even more, them charging you $10 for others (the community) doing 90% of the work fixing and you having to jump through massive hoops to find the fix and install it. I mean one of the people from the community worked on the patches for almost 10 years for free.

column9:
I'm voting to raise the disastrous stats a bit.

I played this game many years ago, and so I noticed the annoying bugs back then, like corpses that weren't recycled and would float by the hundreds around the base at the end of the game.

BUT! With the latest patch provided by Derelict Games (v1.09 at the time of writing), almost all the bugs have been fixed, and the game is what it should have been when it was released.

So if you like the genre, don't hesitate; it's very fun.

column8:
[quote][b]Warning: Broken Game![/b]
This game has design/implementation defects that will render this unplayable for many gamers.  The game was abandoned by Double Fine in an incomplete state, yet, unethically, they continue to try scam gamers into buying a product they know is defective, unfinished and unplayable..[/quote]

Spacebase DF-9 is an extremely promising looking sci-fi base building/strategy game... and there's a huge market for such games if done right, which this isn't.  In fact this is a cautionary tale about not judging a book by it's cover... and while the traditional meaning of that is we shouldn't dismiss a book just because it looks bad, when it comes to video games, it's the opposite.  Some video games may look really fantastic but turn out to be duds... especially when they're not even complete games.

How did it come to this?

The core problem here is that this isn't a sincerely made, professional game, it's a Game Jam/demo project.  Game Jam and other student/project games are not made for gamers, they're made for the benefit of stroking the ego of developers.  It's obviously not possible for a game slapped together over a few days to be of the same quality as a properly, sincerely made game from a full development team with a full budget who take the right amount of time and put in genuine hard work to create a product for gamers.  Sure, it is possible to slap together a game in such a manner, unprofessionally.  This is a lot like driving a car using only your feet.  Just because it can be done, doesn't mean it's a good idea, and often ends up in disaster.

After the game jam, Double Fine made a commitment to finish the game... then didn't bother, they just abandoned it.  They took all the money from gamers based on this promise, abandoned the game, and kept all the cash they scammed out of gamers.  Completely reprehensible. 

Reviewing SteamDB to check how popular this game was with players reveals a surprise... there's a very healthy spike in player counts for the game.  How is this possible, if the game is incomplete and unplayable?  This only happened once, around the same time that trading cards were applied to the game... so this is just card idlers getting their cards and moving on.  A closer look at the numbers shows the game just has a couple of players every week running up the game and idling it for cards, then deleting it.  We must ask how it benefits gamers for there to be so many games like this, with no merit as a serious game, that only generate sales from people idling and selling the trading cards.

The developer is deliberately and unethically trying to scam gamers into paying them the greedy, cash grab price of $10 USD for a game they know is broken.  Don't give it to them.  This is also competing with over 9,000 free games available on Steam, many of them far better than this paid product.

column8:
This game is made by doublefine. Why is that important? Well the leader of that company (Or former leader if he's already been fired by now, I have no idea) is a man named Tim Schafer. Apparently he was there when games like monkey island and grim fandango were made. I've heard they are great and were absolute classics.
So what is the issue then and why have I brought this up in the first place?

Well the studio he was in charge of by the name of "Doublefine" had a period I like to call the "Indie phase" where they hosted game jams and picked the best games out of the ones on display to be made into fully fledged games. One of the games they picked came out somewhat half baked. It was called "Broken age" and was forced to launch with only half of the game playable, so the studio could make enough money off the sales to create the second half of the game and add that. 
This might not seem so bad until you realise that the company had made a kickstarter for that game and promised the backers a full and ready game if they backed it. So understandably many backers were upset about this.

But Broken age wasn't the game that got the rawest deal. That was this game Spacebase DF-9. While I didn't back it on its kickstarter (Yes there was a kickstarter for this game too) I did buy it in early access. Now thankfully the game is playable.
Its a quirky yet fun space colony management sim where you get to make choices that effect your colony now and then.

But there is a glaring flaw here and it is the reason I cannot recommend the game. Because the whole project was dropped like a hot potato, there is a point in the game where the progression and content grinds to a halt. And I don't mean you get drip fed more content, I'm talking about walking into a fully fledged brick wall.

Your colonies/bases will be doomed eventually because of this. They may thrive, they might become sprawling megacentres that act as a refuge for humanity. But eventually they will wither and die due to enough natural space born disasters popping up and screwing the place over. I also encountered a game breaking scripting error once.
I was constantly choosing a dialogue option that sent attacking forces of pirate raiders away, and all of a sudden, something gave way in the code. 

Every single pirate raider I had convinced to leave my colony alone came swarming in like a bunch of army ants. That save file stood no chance. Everyone died horribly. 
In the end I'm sorry if my review made you upset, because to be honest I was getting upset while writing this. This game could have been great, but its been left behind.


Please, don't buy this game. Its not worth it in the end. 
Also for my final note I wouldn't recommend buying anything else from double fine either considering their track record. Except psychonaughts 2. I heard that is a really good game.

Anyway, that is everything I had to say.

column8:
I got this way early, and back when it went on steam, it was during a time when this genre was dead. It had pedigree, it had promise. None of that came to fruition. This was some game-jam demo that got a half hearted dev cycle, and it was cancelled the second it didn't do big numbers. It's abandonware. It was okay in its current state, as a work in progress. There may be mods that make this playable, but it isn't worth it. There's not enough under the hood to sustain more than a couple of hours of play.

One of the sadder outcomes in game development, but don't fucking buy this.

column8:
Houston, we had a problem... and that problem was Spacebase DF-9. This game had all the potential to be an interstellar masterpiece, but alas, it got abandoned faster than an astronaut's lunch in zero gravity â€“ and that's saying something!

I mean, seriously, it's like they planned to launch this game to the moon but forgot to pack the rocket fuel. I was eagerly waiting for the 1.0 release, but it's as elusive as spotting a comet in the daytime sky. And yet, here they are, still trying to sell it, like trying to convince me that Tang is still the official drink of space.

So, if you ever feel like taking a one-way ticket to disappointment, Spacebase DF-9 might be just the game for you. It's the cosmic equivalent of finding out your spaceship runs on cosmic fumes and duct tape. Someone get these developers a telescope so they can see where they went wrong!

column8:
Spacebase DF-9 is an indie game of the simulation genre that invites players to build and manage a space station. The gameplay is very interesting and appealing to fans of simulation games and the game has many strengths. However, there are also some disadvantages, which I will summarise below:

1. boring gameplay elements: some gameplay elements can become repetitive and monotonous, which makes the game boring.

2. lack of depth: the game does not offer much depth when it comes to long-term strategic decisions, which can make the game monotonous and superficial.

3. incomplete gameplay: the game still has many bugs and missing features, which is understandable especially for an early access game, but can still frustrate.

4. weak AI: The AI of our crew members is sometimes illogical and difficult to predict, which affects the gameplay and can lead to frustration.

In summary, Spacebase DF-9 certainly has potential and will appeal to fans of simulation games. But the lack of depth and the presence of bugs can frustrate the gameplay.

column8: I got this game as a gift and immediately interested in playing it. Definitely my kind of game, it looks fun and easy and overall cute. BUT NOPE! THIS GAME IS FRUSTRATING. I tried many times making new base, trying different combination of places that would be good enough to enjoy it but also occasionally engage in combat. This game doesn't have the same balance of any game in this genre. It really doesn't have a breathing space for you to ACTUALLY BUILD your base. The hostiles just keep popping up every few minutes and by the time it takes your crew to rebuild and fix everything, yet another group of hostiles come on their merry way to fuck you up even more. I honestly tried again and again, building new base because I had hope and see the potential of this game as it is quite fun while it lasted. But it really just kick you in the butt on every turn. Your crew died and depleted so fast it doesn't even contribute anything even if you put them all on one task only to fix the base faster. It either caught on fire or your crew died in combat or asphyxiation just to name a few of causes. It is so hard to maintain the prosperity of your crew and build the base when you can't even do basically anything. And I mean, anything. You can't get things done because you keep getting shot and raided or horrible virus monster eating you alive. So disappointing and just plain infuriating over time to play this game. Such a missed opportunity as this is such a fun game while it lasted. But yeah, don't waste your money over this game. Not worth it at all.

column8:
[h1] ğ”¸ğ•¨, â„ğ”¼ğ•ƒğ•ƒ â„•ğ•†! [/h1]

Well, humble bundle... I wanted to help out the victims of the Syrian and Turkish earthquake... but not on the expense of my sanity.

This game... man... For those who actually bought it; I feel bad for you! Really, I do! I'll tell you a bit about the premise, if you're still interested in the worst game ever on Steam lol
You're on a spaceship, and simulating a situation where you're supposed to survive! You get settlers in the ship, that can build, do multiple mundane activities but not all at once! You gotta select them individually and put them to a task... Now, the game starts off by saying that "your settlers will die without an Oxygen tank, set one of them to build it", so after telling you absolutly nothing in the tutorial, you actually find the Oxygen Tank and you build it... Keeping up with the tutorial's checklist, doing what is asked of you... and you think you're getting somewhere; so you speed up time to get stuff done faster, your settlers start now moving and working at a reasonable pace... Two minutes in, and then they all get seizures and die Hahaha! I actually laughed at that, really hard. They just are like "Nope, enough work, I amma just die now". The failure message states that "Your ship has ran out of Oxygen"... Umm, Okay! So I decide to give it another go and go slow this time... The settlers all die again at the exact time all at once and the message persists despite my monitor displaying that I've got 72% Oxygen on that crappy shit.

Figures the game doesn't want to be played... So I shut it off, put it down softly and wrote this review. The rating? For the first time ever: THIS IS a [b]0/10[/b] game. Thank you Humble Bundle!!!
column9:
[h1] ğ”¸ğ•¨, â„ğ”¼ğ•ƒğ•ƒ â„•ğ•†! [/h1]

Well, humble bundle... I wanted to help out the victims of the Syrian and Turkish earthquake... but not on the expense of my sanity.

This game... man... For those who actually bought it; I feel bad for you! Really, I do! I'll tell you a bit about the premise, if you're still interested in the worst game ever on Steam lol
You're on a spaceship, and simulating a situation where you're supposed to survive! You get settlers in the ship, that can build, do multiple mundane activities but not all at once! You gotta select them individually and put them to a task... Now, the game starts off by saying that "your settlers will die without an Oxygen tank, set one of them to build it", so after telling you absolutly nothing in the tutorial, you actually find the Oxygen Tank and you build it... Keeping up with the tutorial's checklist, doing what is asked of you... and you think you're getting somewhere; so you speed up time to get stuff done faster, your settlers start now moving and working at a reasonable pace... Two minutes in, and then they all get seizures and die Hahaha! I actually laughed at that, really hard. They just are like "Nope, enough work, I amma just die now". The failure message states that "Your ship has ran out of Oxygen"... Umm, Okay! So I decide to give it another go and go slow this time... The settlers all die again at the exact time all at once and the message persists despite my monitor displaying that I've got 72% Oxygen on that crappy shit.

Figures the game doesn't want to be played... So I shut it off, put it down softly and wrote this review. The rating? For the first time ever: THIS IS a [b]0/10[/b] game. Thank you Humble Bundle!!!

column8: I played this game very briefly years ago, when I got it as part of a bundle. I recall really liking the concept and the feel, but quickly realising that it was currently in a completely unplayable state. As such, I left it, and decided to come back to it when it was finished. Fast forward to now, and I'm immensely saddened to see that this game was completely abandoned by the devs. I've seen that some of the playerbase have taken it upon themselves to mod and fix the game, but I have yet to test it to see what it's like. That being said, if you like the look of the game, maybe download the unofficial fixes and give it a go. Although only if you already own the game, because having to pay for the game in its current state may as well be theft.

column8:
A fun tech demo, but it lacks content and is balanced in such a way that making progress is basically impossible.

My main issue is that even on low threat systems which are close to warp gates (basically how often you get new units), there are so many raider spawns and your civilians are so stupid that it becomes impossible to build up a large enough workforce. As an example I had 2 raiders spawn in my canteen. I sent my security which consisted of three units to stop them. However my security decided to go in one at a time, allowing the raiders to focus fire them. The raiders them proceeded to camp in the canteen and kill another 3 civs who decided to go in because they were hungry before finally leaving the room and immediately getting mowed down by my turrets. In theory I had the upperhand, but due to elements I could not control I ended up loosing 1/3rd of my population to one engagement.

Questo gioco Ã¨ un prodotto incompleto. Anche se all'inizio sembra tutto rosa e fiori, dopo poche ore di sviluppo della base i bug e le meccaniche claudicanti non permettono di avanzare.

Scrivo questa recensione a distanza di anni dalla mia ultima e unica partita perchÃ© ho visto questo gioco nuovamente in vendita in un pacchetto di Humble Bundle. Non mi capacito del motivo per cui sia ancora in vendita a prezzo pieno e Double Fine lo riproponga ciclicamente.

A chiunque stia valutando l'acquisto di questo titolo: ci sono tanti alti giochi con lo stesso tema e meccaniche simili, ed Ã¨ lo stesso motivo per cui lo sviluppatore ha deciso di abbandonare questo progetto; per cui, rivolgi la tua attenzione altrove.
column9:
This game is an incomplete product. While it seems all rosy at first, after just a few hours of basic development, bugs and lame mechanics prevent you from progressing.

I'm writing this review years after my last and only playthrough because I saw this game back for sale in a Humble Bundle package. I can't understand why it's still on sale at full price and Double Fine keeps reissuing it.

To anyone considering purchasing this title: there are many other games with the same theme and similar mechanics, and that's the same reason the developer decided to abandon this project; so look elsewhere.

column8:
[b] Trying everything on the Steam Deck # 9 [/b]

Tim Schafer talked about the nearly two years of development time this game got, dumping more than what they could make from the game, it was scuffed after the first year, towards the end they just torpedoed it off Early Access and right into the store.

It was fun for an hour or so but it just became a total mess once the base gets larger. It's really only about 30% of a full game, so many things are missing. Only get this on sale or free with a bundle because for $10 bucks, I just cant recommend.

However ! Since Double Fine came through on their promise and made it Open Source so the community can work on it, I'll give them a thumbs up.

Note For The Deck: Runs great, trackpads are great for mouse movement, though as the base gets bigger, zooming in/out begins to get cumbersome.

-  We always had hope we weren't going to end it, until the end. 3/10

column8:
Sorry to say but this game just isn't finished and never will be. The beginning half of the game feels great but as you play you encounter more and more issues that make it impossible to play. Combat is the most broken, impossible system I have ever seen in any simulation game, ever. Let's talk about some issues:

-Derelicts (ships that spawn with loot / enemies) if you explore them, you're almost guaranteed to have a crewmate get stuck there and slowly suffocate and starve. Since you can't directly control anyone, the only way to save them to to build a path from the derelict to your ship. Also, it is functionally impossible to order your crew to fully explore a Derelict. They just won't do it.
-Incapacited crew/raiders can stay that way for so long that they'll literally starve to death. Additionally, enemies can just stand up and be completely fine afterward and go on a rampage, so if a raider goes down but doesn't die, you have to deploy security for them for weeks at a time.
-You can get pop-ups for events / problems that have been solved. These pop-ups never go away and will eventually open back up no matter what.
-I've lost several new games simply because my crew won't go inside and refill their oxygen. This has a risk of happening with every new game.
-Raiders can be ridiculously strong, able to kill (with only one raider) over 15 crew without being downed. Even if your entire crew is security you'll probably die to what is effectively a bad rng roll.
-Corpses never go away. The community patch fixes this but parasite corpses aren't removed.
-If one of your crew dies on a derelict, your crew will all automatically go to try to loot their body. If the derelict isn't empty of enemies, this means that your entire crew will eventually die trying to get loot. There is no way to stop them from doing this. 
-There's not prioritization of tasks. Even if your crew is literally dying and need to act immediately, they'll still stop to chat and ask people their favorite bands.
-Wounded crewmates will continue doing harmful tasks even to certain death. You can order them to go to the infirmary, but they don't listen and will die anyway.
-In the community patch, meteors will hit parts of your station. You get a warning and opportunity to avoid it, but you can't order your crew to move away so it's really just a random 'these crew members die' event. The game is FULL of these.
-Music just sometimes stops playing completely until you go into the menu and turn it up.
-Practically speaking, it's near impossible to catch illnesses and there's literally nothing you can do to change the result besides employing more doctors, so this event also serves as a 'these crew members die' random pop-up. The base game also has way too many random diseases to look out for, and each of them needs to be researched to effectively stop them, and research takes nearly 10 hours of real time per disease. This is faster with more researchers but everyone in this game just dies randomly with no ability to stop it.


Basically, this game is an embarrassment and is not really a game in its current state. It is an RNG button with some slight amount of interactivity but gives you so little control and has so little content that appears so often that functionally, the only thing you actually control in this game is heavily repeated dialogue that determines how many crew members you hire once every 2-5 minutes. Since your entire crew is likely to die about every 5 minutes, really these dialogues don't represent a choice at all, since you have to hire more to keep playing the game. In other words, this is a management sim where in reality, you are a passive participant that is watching events as they transpire.

This isn't a finished product, it's barely a game. It shouldn't be on sale at this point.

column8: I'm not too sure how this company is still in business. Just saw a new game called Gang Beasts by the same people, and I'm like.... hang on. Go back and finish the game I already bought before I give you any more money. This game had so much promise, and it's basically playable. They just up and finished the early-access alpha and dumped that on the unsuspecting public, with no budget for developing it from a beta. That's what this is. An untested beta with balance problems; the scenario which triggers events has no mercy. I think it's a simple timer with no conditions at all, and there's no time to research everything, get enough crew to handle the bad dudes who attack, or build up much of a base. You might think you have a big sprawling base, but it's definitely not well defended.

Ships spawn on asteroids 
If more than 1 ship hails you, you cannot open the 2nd dialogue.
Would like a priority setting for technicians 

...and so many more.

It is just not a complete game.
column9:
I reopened this years later and I remember why I stopped.  It is just not a complete game.  It is at best a glorified sandbox with not true purpose.  Too many glitches and broken AI.

Oxygen can be produced for non-attached segments.
Raiders just roam the halls and don't seem to need food.
Ships spawn on asteroids 
If more than 1 ship hails you, you cannot open the 2nd dialogue.
Would like a priority setting for technicians 

...and so many more.

It is just not a complete game.

column8:
A sad failure of the Early Access system. A space station manager game that emphasized character needs. A bit like the Sims, really.

The game wasn't bad, per se, just unfinished, and it had potential. But the money dried up and so did the game. I enjoyed it while it lasted, but it must suck for people who paid for a game they expected to be finished but never was.

column9:
Spaceship Game

Expand your spaceship, recruit new crew members, and survive enemy invasions.

You start with only a basic engine and three crew members.

You build floors, walls, and oxygen generators for basic survival.

You then install chute racks and special doors to allow access to outer space.

Once your spaceship is fully developed, you can assign your crew members to various occupations.

Constructionists build and place buildings and furniture as instructed.

Miners gather ores from space.

Guardians defend against enemy invasions and doctors treat the wounded and the dead.

Furthermore, there are occupations that develop technology, farm, and handle food and beverages.

Each occupation has its own preferences, and the longer you play, the more proficiency you gain in that occupation.

After constructing a room, the items installed in it determine its characteristics. It can be designated as an energy room, or a place to process ore, exercise, or sleep.
If you want to change this room's characteristics, you can remove the installed items and change it to Unspecified or another characteristic.

Occasionally, people will come looking for new recruits. If you have enough oxygen generators left, you can welcome them and gradually expand your spaceship.
Of course, it's not always safe. Space thieves can invade your spaceship, attacking the crew and destroying furniture.
Also, dangerous situations like alien lifeforms or falling meteors can occur.
With proper defenses, these can be easily prevented, but without...

Disappointing Points
- Not very convenient
- Not many items can be installed
- Based on reviews, the battle record seems quite impressive (though it's not bad for a quick kill, so I recommend it)
- Nothing much to do other than build and assign a job.

column8: This game is just broken. I'm prepared to weather some glitches with Double Fine games because their many positives so outweigh their issues. But this game just doesn't work, at all.  Doors will fail to open, characters will asphyxiate in  oxygen rich rooms. Steam wouldn't allow a developer to sell something so dysfunctional as early alpha, I don't know why they allows this to be sold as a completed game.

column8:
This is one game that was never finished. If you look at the news, you will see that it was in Alpha testing for 1 year, then went straight to release. It skipped the Beta testing. The last news from the 1.0 release was 1 month after it was released. The fact that they are still charging $10 for this 7+ years later is ridiculous. If this game was finished it might be worth $10 today, but at its current level of completion, it might be worth $1 today. If you buy this game, you are paying $10 for a game demo that was released as a full game. Go buy an actual game with your $10 instead.

The worst gameplay mechanic that other games got right 17+ years before this game was in Alpha is people assignments. Here you have to assign each person to a job. The bigger the base, the more people and jobs. The game doesn't tell you if a job needs filled, you have to search for one.

The rate of decay on equipment is intolerable. If this was real life, most equipment takes over a year to breakdown through constant use. In the game, things breakdown within 2 game days. This wouldn't be so bad if people didn't have to sleep for a good portion of that time. If you line the outside of a small-medium base with turrets every 5 blocks, by the time 2-3 mechanics get around to all of them for repairs, it's time to do it again.

column8:
This game was abandoned by Double Fine while in Early Access. It is a simulator with barely any depth, and will quickly bore you. Do not let the Double Fine logo fool you. They took early access money, realized the game wasn't profitable, slapped a 1.0 label on the game and walked away. 

Double FIne's history is riddled with bad project management, with Spacebase DF-9 being the ultimate example. It is amazing that after so many years they still ask money for this. This game would work as a free smartphone game, but for now it stands as a testament to their own incompetence.

Buyer beware.

column8:
This game feels more like a proof of concept than an actual game. It's got the basics, but things are horribly unbalanced and there's significant bugs. Earning any resources (mining, research) takes forever, while you can loose resources very quickly, like if a raiders attack or even just AI stupidity, since you can give direct commands to your people, and they're stupid, so they'll do things like hold a conversation in the airlock while one of your crew is starting to suffocate because they can't get in. :/ As you start to build up you need people on certain roles full time, but since you start off with so few people and the only way to get more is pure luck, you'll constantly be understaffed. Probably the biggest problem is that when you start you start with nothing but a seed pod you have to build a station around, which makes things really hard and doesn't make any sense since you just came here by spaceship? It should give you the ability to start with your choice of ship design (several of the deleric ships you can come across are well designed, so they could have easily used those).
I'm honestly surprised DoubleFine even released this, it feels like a game still in Beta and I'd expect better from them. But if you want to play a space survival game, I'd recommend go playing FTL instead

column8: This game is just way too buggy, even with the unofficial patch that's supposed to fix a lot of things. I'm continually stuck in crisis mode, trying to get a functional base, while people die of things they need, but won't build them, or the airlock gets stuck randomly and decides it's not an airlock anymore so I have to build a second airlock in order to build a room for oxygen in order to prevent my people from suffocating. Then raiders attack and kill my workers who won't work anyway. It might be a fun game if it worked as expected, but due to its buggy nature and terrible UI I wouldn't recommend anyone even starting to try it.

column8:
I don't think the title is as bad as the rating suggests, but I can't recommend it at the end of the day for most people either. 

If you like space-base building I thought it was a fun couple hours seeing what it has to offer. But it could certainly use some polish. I could see this an enticing 1.0.0. release into early access, but given that this is the end result it is rather disappointing given the lack of polish. 
- no way to monitor power production
- role swapping for dealing with raids is tedious
- Turrets dont' seem to be too effective as a defense system
- The building system is a bit chunky for something with so few items. 

So overall, fun for a certain crowd, but not well developed enough to warrant a suggestion to most opeople.

column8:
I bought this game a few years ago, it worked and was good fun playing it.
Then it stopped and had all the usual problems everyone else found.
New PC, Win11, better GPU, SSD, reinstalled it then pressed play and it loads up in exactly the same as it was, broken! So, at least we know cloud saves work!
Disable save to cloud, 'escape' key from the still same everyone dead no walls screen, Menu screen, click Start New Base, select place accept to launch, aaaaaaaaannnnnnddddddd.....................................

..............BLACK SCREEN.

Oh there's an unofficial update v1.09 nice, but then that gets auto removed by antivirus for being unsafe.

F this game, don't waste time messing about, get something else.

column8:
Spacebase DF-9 is a game where you control a space crew and you survive in space.

The game really doesn't set anything up for you in terms of a story, so that's about all I have for the first line above. You pick a spot in the galaxy, which have different environmental clauses that'll affect what'll happen around you and that's where you'll place your base. You will learn the game as you go as the game will give you notices as to what you need to do. So, naturally, the first thing you need to do is to build the base, which will include the essentials being a power supply, air supply, airlock door room for entering and exiting space, and many other life and resource necessities.

Overall, it's sub-par to other games I'd presume only because I've played minimal games like this, but it doesn't seem to do too well. I've had my space crew keep roaming outside only to kill themselves through asphyxiation as well as I've seen enemy AI do the same when both could've easily boarded the ship to live. The crew don't always act immediately on the actions that I tell them to do (build a room, mine some asteroids, etc.), so it was delaying my gameplay.

The visuals are rather simplistic, but not very appealing. The sound effects and music get repetitive.

I don't see a lot in this game, so this is a no for me.

column8:
I decided to start going through some old games in my inventory and see how they are.  This was a game that I really enjoyed while it was in development. A non-ascii Space Dwarf Fortress?  Sounded good, and adding that DF suggested if not outright promised a deep and compelling world unfolding as you played.  

I looked at the store, it was $10 and mostly negative due to being released unfinished and abandoned.  Double Fine allowed feature creep and ambitions to overwhelm them and decided instead of pretending they would work on a project that had grown larger then they felt they would ever be able to do, they would instead release it as is and stop support for the game.  This plan was (I suspect) so they as a newer studio would be able to move on to other games and not be bogged down on an endless development cycle with a single game.  

How is this game?  It is (imo) 100% an unfinished Spacebase Startopoia.  It has a very similar feel and honestly doesn't look that old.  As it stands you will get overwhelmed with people just moving into your base and chewing up resources until everyone dies.  You'll get endless waves of pirates and derelicts until everyone dies, and you'll have builders brick themselves off into rooms and suffocate if you don't watch their every step.  

The game is compelling before everything goes to awry.  And that chaos that unfolds can be fun trying to get on top of it to start with, but it is never ending and dooms most playthroughs to failure.  It isn't that it is too hard, it is just unfinished with ideas implemented before they were worked into actual mechanics.  

I doubt it will as most everyone pretends this game never existed, but should it ever find its way to a sale of 50% or more it is worth $5 to see how long you can hold of the forces of chaos!

column9:
[h1] A game with very bad reviews, which I wouldn't hesitate to recommend [/h1]

A rather interesting concept, and unfortunately, a game that's been abandoned.

You can spend about ten hours playing it and building your own colony, but unfortunately, there's not much else to do.

[b] If you find it in a bundle with other Double Fine games, or if it's on sale for about 50 rubles, it's worth picking up and trying. Otherwise, I don't recommend it. The game is dead and no one will resurrect it.[/b]

[h1]Join the [url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/KPSAVMNI] Steam group[/url].
And subscribe to the [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/36010948/] curator[/url]. 
It's worth it! [/h1]

column8:
I like games from Double Fine Productions.
And I just enjoyed pretty much all of them.
But: Spacebase DF-9 is really disappointing.
It's an early access title sold as a full game.
There's plenty of unfixed bugs everywhere.
Last update happened in 2014, that is sad.
And yeah, it pretty much feels like a scam.
Charging money for this is quite 'scummy'.
Unfinished product for 9,99â‚¬, full of bugs.
It's playable with the fan made mods, tho.
Mods can actually improve this gem a lot.
But as it stands: It's not worth your cash.
This should not be sold in the first place.
And I have to give it my negative review.

column8:
Spacebase DF-9 is an incredibly fun base building/colony sim. Until your toons build themselves into a room and suffocate. Or dismantle a floor and eject themselves into space. Or decide to take a nap in the doorway to the inner airlock suffocating all toons in their space suits.

All things which happen FAR more frequently than you would like. All things which were not terribly surprising when I bought this as an early access game. 

Except it's no longer early access. Doublefine did some great initial work but then instead of completing the game they simply walked away from it.

This game is broken, shame on you doublefine.

Wow ich sehe gerade, dass dieses Spiel tatsÃ¤chlich immer noch verkauft wird. Unglaublich frech, da es nie in einen spielbaren Zustand fertigentwickelt wurde. GehÃ¶rt nicht in "Simulation" sondern in "kaputt und verlassen" , warum gibt es eigentlich eine solche Kategorie nicht frage ich mich.

column9:
Wow, I just saw that this game is actually still being sold. Incredibly cheeky, considering it was never fully developed into a playable state. It doesn't belong in the "simulation" category, but rather in the "broken and abandoned" category. Why isn't there a category like that, I wonder?

I had high hopes for the title back then, but that was a long time ago.

column8:
Purchased this years ago. It's a rimworld clone with the following exceptions:

* lower performance compute

* characters have one job rather than prioritizing an array of jobs

* no tech tree

* events are totally randomized and uncontrollable

* no game goal

* less than five minutes of music audio

* worse graphics

* no development in years

If I could get my money back, I would. If I could spend those dollars on a gofundme to give butt cancer to the publisher for accepting monies for this scam title it wouldn't bother me to drop the cash right in that project. This is as close to cash rake and tax avoision I've ever seen (yes, it's a word). It's worthy of criminal investigation for fraud

column8: This would have been a fantastic game.....except that it was abandoned mid development.  It's buggy, especially with the AI.  The AI makes this game nearly unplayable, and it completely lacks tools to mitigate that.  Citizens randomly abandon tasks for minutes on end, pick the most asinine tasks to complete first, leaving critical issues for later.  Raiders attack far too often and you can't send security to them, you just have to hope that security wanders in before too much damage is done.  It seems to be impossible to make citizens happy.  Just terrible AI and job management systems.  Shame that it wasn't fixed up before full launch.  Hard pass.

column9:
Well, clearly, this game wasn't fully developed... :( The basics were good, but there always comes a time when everything goes to hell and there's nothing you can do about it.
The AI â€‹â€‹is completely messed up, and after the first few deaths, there's no way to alleviate the depression that sets in among the crew. Too bad :(
Almost 100 hours of gameplay - it's still a bit distracting, not everything is completely ruined - but it's the type of game where I'm doing other things at the same time (TV, chatting, even the accounts...). If you're looking for a good space management game, move on!

column8:
In all fairness this game was fantastic while it was still be developed. I dumped a ton of hours into it, and it had so much promise. For what's there, it's still fun to be honest.

However I can not recommend supporting this game. After being forced to 1.0 and abandoned without finishing development, this game has literally given me Early Access trauma. I'm making this review because I'm appaled they have emoticons and backgrounds in the new Steam Point shop when they disappointed their entire fan base that was following production of this game.

A couple other people in the reviews have mentioned Space Haven, I would 2nd that recommendation. Go give Bugbyte your money cause they actually support their products.

column8:
This game used to be unplayable (crashes and stupid situation where you cannot progress anymore), until I found about the community patch (available here: https://www.spacebasehub.net).
Not everything is polished and perfect, but I am on 8 hour long game and so far enjoying it.

Sometimes the AI goes a bit stupid (with reaction to fires, or lack of oxygen, ..) but it stays manageable and I did not get stuck in a situation I could not get out of.

Before the community patch, the game would crash occasionally and sometimes the AI/characters would be stuck. No more with the community patch.

Thank you Derelict Games for patching this game and make it enjoyable.

With the community patch, this is definitely worth buying when on sale !

column8:
Spacebase DF-9â€¦ oh boy, what a backstory this game hasâ€¦ It started as a humble pitch in Amnesia Fortnight 2012, and the idea got enough votes to be made into a playable prototype in just 14 days. Not only that, it even got greenlighted to be made into a full game. So far so good. The game went into Steam Early Access, which is something I am always skeptical about, but as long as the game eventually gets fully released, I donâ€™t really mind. But suddenly, the developers pulled the plug, and magically the game was finished and out of Early Access. What sorcery was this? Obviously, the game was still unfinished, with some crap responses from the publisher. To make matters worse, they released the source code, a middle finger saying that the community can and should finish the job.
Now, to be fair, itâ€™s a sad story, but in the end what matters is the game itself right? Well, itâ€™s a space management title, a genre Iâ€™m not really a fan of. But alright. The game starts with you picking a location to build a base, which basically acts as a difficulty select screen. Ok. It even has a special one designed to be a tutorial. Ok. Letâ€™s try the tutorial then. I managed to complete it, and immediately saw how clunky it is to play. Navigation between menus is a mess and time consuming. After the tutorial things get worse. Plenty of times the crew members just ignore your orders or take forever to do anything. At this point I almost gave up on the game, but there is an unofficial community patch that essentially fixes a lot of bugs and adds some more features.
That patch is the supposed community salvation for the game, but even that one seems abandoned. Still, props for the people that spent time trying to fix and finish this mess of a game. Truth be said that patch really improves the overall experience, and I managed to play some playthroughs for a few hours this time. Unfortunately, the crappy foundation is still there, and itâ€™s just a meh game. In the end, I just cannot recommend this: official release is unfinished, crappy publisher decision and PR, and even the community canâ€™t save this disaster. While it is playable with the unofficial patch, I still didnâ€™t like Spacebase DF-9. Itâ€™s just an average space management title, and there are way better titles in the genre that deserve more of your time and money.

column8:
Great 2D space base builder game that you will have some fun with at first but then you realise the game has a number of flaws that need fixed as the AI can be a little buggy most of the time and this can cause you to lose the game a no fault of your own, also it could do with some extra features, such as more research options, spaceport, trade centre, games room, command centre, cloning centre to make your own crew and even a school to help sculpt your crews abilities etc just to allow you to do more in the game.

Characters in the game appear amusing and the game has a lot of potential for fun but sadly just as you get into it some crazed mad max of space redneck comes along and ravages your space port. That and the buggy AI where crew will just start acting with no priorities or just the opposite of what you expect them to do.

Game also needs better ways to defend against asteroids and raiders as found I could be playing and suddenly been hit with 3 raider ships, only to just beat them off to be left with minimal crew who them decide to loose the will to live and then some asteroid impacts the base and you cannot repair anything in time to be raided again with another raider attack and each level will usually end the exact same way each time.

column8:
--I got this game from a Humble Bundle and played it without knowing anything about the game. It is NOT worth the~ 8â‚¬ they are currently asking for in the shop. --

I had a few hours of fun with it. It tries to capture the charme of a game made 30 years ago and in some parts this works very well. There are enough little details and animations so the space station feels alive. Events like appearing spaceships and raiders are a fun at first but become repetitive after just 5h of gameplay. 

Sadly you can tell the game was never finished. I thought i was playing another Gamejam project and i thought wow this is quite impressive :). 

For example even the most basic stuff like building a room can be quite annoying and complicated. Citizens don't react to enemy fire while in space and the needed defensive turrets can only be placed facing north and east while the attack came from south. Sometimes weird and fun stuff happens but no gamebreaking bugs yet...

column8:
Good lord, I just don't even. In the beginning it seems like a really nice looking game with a supposed slick manner of progressing the game.
Then you realize how dumb people are. How impossible it is to bother with raiders, and even fires. Why can't one of the dumb af crew just grab a fire extinguisher from the other room? Why can't I prioritize fighting raiders? Why is there so little control in a colony game?
If I'd have made this game I'd be deadly embarrassed. What an awful game.
On top of that, it's been abandoned. A good reminder why Double Fine studios should pack their bags and leave the gaming world permanently. How dare they still spread this game.

column8:
Appeared in my steam library after redeeming a different game from DF's Humble Bundle (did not use the code I was given, this just showed up out of nowhere). Decided to try it despite the negative reviews, and my partial dislike of management games. Immediately saw why it had negative reviews.
Never even got past the damn tutorial. UI is a bit confusing to me but I can partially blame myself tbh; I have a bit of a smooth brain :P
The music is alright though, I'll give it that. There's a dozen different space management building games out there, buy one of those instead of this one.
Overall 1/5. Not DF's greatest work tbf.

column8:
Ah Double Fine, company of "how do we manage consistently getting more money than almost any other indie dev only to squander it" Seriously, they make some good stuff here and there but holy shit they just do not care sometimes, and this is the best example of that. They took advantage of Early Access and dumped it by the way side as soon as profits slowed from this game. They knew full well this game couldn't be remotely considered done, and they left it anyway. Cause that's what they do, make a good game, then make a few mediocre ones, then just unfininished schlock. Then they get money from everybody to start the cycle over, with increasingly high costs for increasingly low quality.

It speaks volumes that they did a bad enough job that I decided on a lark after playing a different game of their's to finally review this, and *BOOM*, suddenly paragraph of vitriol over a game I haven't cared about in years.

column8:
At first I thought the game looked fun and It was for a while, gave me a feeling kind of like FTL and it was pretty good. 
My problems with it are that it can go from doing really good to all your guys are dead in about a minute. A random raider attack with 5 raiders all with lazer guns and your security team dies almost instantly. You can't edit or upgrade what weapons your guys have without researching new weapons and researching takes forever especially while you are trying to keep more than 5 people alive at a time. If you have more than 1 thing set to build at a time, you can't tell your builders to focus on one project over another. My builders would 1/2 build a room and then go off to do something else when I just want to get my medic room finished to heal my sick and injured characters, that's when they decide to build my cabinets or have a lunch break. FINISH THE DAMN WALL!!!! 
I think the most civilians I had were 13 but, they had illnesses, some getting killed by a parasite and then right after a raider attack killed the rest all within about 3 minutes. 
As many others have said the game is unfinished and forgotten about by Doublefine. I thought I was just stuck in the tutorial forever but, it seems that's the whole game. the game could have been really cool, too bad Doublefine saw something newer and shinier to pay more attention to...

column8:
Space Base DF-9 is probably one if the worst scams on steam. The game was never finished and it still is shitty in its current form. 

After choosing a location on the map your 3 crewmen spawn near your pod, the game doesn't try at all to tell you what to do and your oxygen is slowly decreasing over time. If you somehow figure out what your doing and somehow build an airlock and a life support, your might run into a problem like I had where one of my crewmen refused to get into the station. 

This game has probably the worst camera angle ever. It becomes hard to place objects smartly when everything is covered up by something else. A basebuilding game shouldn't have the same camera as fallout 1 and 2.  

After your colony gets started you will start to get messages from NPCs asking to join your colony, While other basebuilding games like rimworld and ONI will allow to look at the traits of a colonist before they join you, Space Base just lets you see that NPC's gross face. 

Sometimes a derelict ship will appear some where on the map. If you send a security team to explore the ship and there is a hostile alien on board, most of the time the security team will not do anything and just stand there as they get killed. This is as far I've gotten in this shit game. 

In conclusion Spacebase DF-9 is a hyper shitty game and a waste of $10, It is probably smarter to get 10 copies of save Jesus, because then you might get some enjoyment out of your friends reactions when they see a gift of save Jesus.

column8:
!!! SCAM - FRAUD - DON'T BUY - REPORT !!!

This game isn't finished even when they wanted to suggest you this. Development was simply canceled and instead of taking the project down they said it's finished and patched it out of Eearly Access so they still can generate money with it! Don't support this behaviour and report the title for other innocent users, thinking about buying this. Steam shouldn't allow this actions and Double Fine Productions should receive a warning for these action!

==========

Was soll man sagen... Double Fine ist eigentlich ein Studio mit guten Ruf bei mir aber dieses Spiel zu verkaufen, grenzt wort wÃ¶rtlich an Betrug. Ich meine, ein Blick in die Reviews genÃ¼gt, um zu sehen das hier etwas nicht stimmen kann. Wie kann ich einen Early Access Titel kommerziell vertreiben und dann einfach sagen 

"Sorry Jungs und MÃ¤dels, wir haben keinen Bock mehr aber schÃ¶n das wir eure Kohle bekommen haben! Wir machen jetzt lieber was anderes!"

Was mich aber noch viel mehr daran stÃ¶rt, ist die Tatsache, daÃŸ dieses "Spiel" bis heute im Store von Steam gelistet wird und weiterhin Geld abwirft fÃ¼r den Entwickler. Ich kann nur jedem Empfehlen die Report-Funktion zu verwenden und dieses Game als Betrug zu melden wegen dem eingestellten Support in einem desolaten Zustand.

Double Fine Productions ist damit offiziell auf meiner schwarzen Liste fÃ¼r Publisher gelandet und ich werde zumindest legal keine weitere Software dieser BetrÃ¼ger mehr erwerben. Schade aber "bescheiÃŸ mich einmal, Schande Ã¼ber dich - bescheiÃŸ mich zweimal, Schande Ã¼ber mich". Mein Motto und ich gebe so einer Firma bestimmt keine weitere Gelegenheit mehr, fÃ¼r so eine Aktion mein hart verdientes Bares abzugreifen.
column9:
!!! SCAM - FRAUD - DON'T BUY - REPORT !!!

This game isn't finished even when they wanted to suggest this to you. Development was simply canceled, and instead of taking the project down, they said it's finished and patched it out of Early Access so they can still generate money with it! Don't support this behavior and report the title to other innocent users thinking about buying this. Steam shouldn't allow these actions, and Double Fine Productions should receive a warning for these actions!

==========

What can I say... Double Fine is actually a studio with a good reputation in my opinion, but selling this game literally borders on fraud. I mean, one look at the reviews is enough to see that something can't be right here. How can I distribute an Early Access title commercially and then just say

"Sorry, guys and girls, we're fed up, but we're glad we got your money! We'd rather do something else!"

What bothers me even more, however, is the fact that this "game" is still listed in the Steam store today and continues to generate revenue for the developer. I can only recommend everyone to use the report function and report this game as a scam due to the discontinued support in such a desolate state.

Double Fine Productions has officially landed on my publisher blacklist, and I will, at least legally, no longer purchase any more software from these scammers. It's a shame, but "scam me once, shame on you - scam me twice, shame on me." That's my motto, and I will definitely not give such a company another opportunity to take my hard-earned cash for such a scheme.

column9:
It's a great game.
I don't understand why it's so hated. The game's main drawback is the price (for me, it's worth the five bucks). And yes, there are a lot of flaws, as most would say, but not me. I should clarify that it's more a lack of foolproofing than flaws, and most of the game's problems stem from your own actions.
Having read many reviews, I see that most people are upset because the game didn't live up to their expectations (in fact, I didn't see any lists of expectations from those same reviewers). Prejudice and expectation... the two main vices of humanity.
Putting aside this nonsense, you'll have a wonderful time exploring the game with its gorgeous soundtrack and pleasing graphics.

column8:
I must preface this with the fact that I do like the game. It is a cute little sim. However, the game is clearly unfinished. It is rather buggy which makes it difficult to play. There are no clear directions. The controls aren't user friendly. Sometimes you just gotta guess what's wrong. Most of the time it's not something you can fix and you just have to watch everyone on your base suffocate because the game decided you don't have air anymore, or despite knowing how to fix the problem none of your citizens respond to your directions anymore so you just gotta restart.

I love most of Double Fine's other games. I wish they would just finish this one.

column8: It's a cute looking game, but the difficulty of constantly fighting with a behind-the-scenes AI is just too much to be enjoyable. Half the game is just a guessing game. Losing so much time to setting everyone to Security then back to their proper jobs and then five seconds later doing it all over again. Being stuck on derelict ships because they refuse to leave while they suffocate or burn to death. A single Raider climbing on your ship and three-shotting all your generators. Turrets blowing holes in your own walls and the resulting Builder running into the room and being sucked out into space. A whole roster of Technicians not being able to repair everything so you have to just dismantle and rebuild anything that gets too damaged. Crew members fighting even though they're Very Happy. Even when you pick a region that should have the lowest difficulty, it feels a lot like trying to do a Zergling rush in StarCraft II but you go to attack and Terran already have upgraded tanks. It's an interesting base-building game that borrows a lot from Sims, Dwarf Fortress, and Rogue-likes, but falls flat on its face with poor control, glitches, hidden mechanics, and terrible balance.
column9: It's a cute looking game, but the difficulty of constantly fighting with a behind-the-scenes AI is just too much to be enjoyable. Half the game is just a guessing game. Losing so much time to setting everyone to Security then back to their proper jobs and then five seconds later doing it all over again. Being stuck on derelict ships because they refuse to leave while they suffocate or burn to death. A single Raider climbing on your ship and three-shotting all your generators. Turrets blowing holes in your own walls and the resulting Builder running into the room and being sucked out into space. A whole roster of Technicians not being able to repair everything so you have to just dismantle and rebuild anything that gets too damaged. Crew members fighting even though they're Very Happy. Even when you pick a region that should have the lowest difficulty, it feels a lot like trying to do a Zergling rush in StarCraft II but you go to attack and Terran already have upgraded tanks. It's an interesting base-building game that borrows a lot from Sims, Dwarf Fortress, and Rogue-likes, but falls flat on its face with poor control, glitches, hidden mechanics, and terrible balance.

column9:
I've been trying this seemingly cute game for a while now, just as a general pastime.
You build your base and watch the "humanoid lifeforms" socialize.

As a game, I see potential, although it gets a bit monotonous after a while. Once you get to about 20-30 lifeforms inside, the challenge begins: keeping them from dying in various ways, from being burned in a fire to being phased by an external attack (raid), thus losing all your hard work.

Lately, I've been trying an unofficial MOD, 1.08.1, and I've noticed some problems. When a derelict appears, the lifeforms move around for no reason, and if there's a hostile crew, practically all of them die. The best part is that, as usual in the best movies, if you create a defense team, they attack one at a time, panicking and dying pointlessly. 10 against 1, of course, one always wins, armed with nail clippers!

There are some research items for the crew to complete in the basic version, but they aren't very many, and some aren't very useful. The problem is that when you reach a certain number of life forms, oxygen is simply not enough, even by increasing the various oxygen producers. I found it useful to increase the size of the room, but at a certain point, having a 60x60 room is just to avoid running out of oxygen immediately. There's no research on this, only a larger producer to have more crew.

In the unofficial version, they've added a jukebox for the pub, research for extra oxygen, puppets to increase the happiness of the humanoids, various plants, and a few tweaks to improve the look of the game, but as I repeat, the military section suffers a bit.

As far as I'm concerned, I don't dislike the game, even if it's not well-followed and updated.
I wouldn't recommend it as a primary everyday game, but as a pastime.
Between its strengths and weaknesses, the weaknesses outweigh the strengths, so for now, it's a no.

But I always leave the choice to you to buy it, perhaps encouraging the developers to update and improve this new gaming experience.

column8:
It's abandonned and glitchy, has a steep learning curve and isn't actually finished.
Avoid it, unless you hardcore need something new to play. Pay as little as you can for it, if so.
There ARE some user patches after 1.06 at spacebasehub.net, but I just installed them now to try them, I don't know what effect they have on gameplay yet, but I highly doubt they solve everything. For the average person, this game will only be an excersize in frustration. Too slow paced for the content to keep you interested, and too fast paced for you to figure out what's going before you just die.

*edit* ok so I'm running the usermade unnofficial patch 1.08.1 It DOES help with quite a few things, namely a lack of content, but also some major glitches. HOWEVER things are handled a bit differently, particularly in the security area. And there's a game crashing glitch with the way it's done, so be careful how you manage your security. There is apparently a 1.09 coming eventually, which will likely address this, but it's not a hurry and will be the last. I understand why. I still don't recommend this for any one looking for a casual game, it's just not... all there. and it won't hold your hand until you figure it out. You're going to fail, a lot. If you're willing to zerg your way to success, you'll enjoy this, and only if you spent less than $3 on it.

Edit: 1.09 is out and solves a lot. It's still a little glitchy but the save system is upgraded and most of the issues are minor. None CTD anymore. It's playable and enjoyable in its current state, Not perfect, but fun.

column8: Learning curve can be STEEP! Too easy to click on the "Learn to Play" option and have it totally wipe your base and put you into a tutorial base. You can be going strong, huge base, well-trained people, and then ONE raider can walk in with a phazer rifle and mow down half of your crew, damage your reactors and send the survivors into a panic state. START RESEARCHING EARLY!!! Despite all this, I found it incredibly hard to stop playing. Needs a better save system though and a more handy "how to" referral guide, rather than a hotlink to a tutorial mission that wipes out your progress.

column8:
I bought this game back around 2015-ish and logged a lot of offline hours.  

Understanding that the Dev team has abandoned the project, I never had any expectations for future releases or features and just played the game as it was.  This game is by no means a great example of a colony sim, and there are dozens of better games that have released in the past few years that make this game obsolete. (Rimworld, Prison Architect, Oxygen not Included, etc...). 

However, for the current price of $10, given the years of hard work that has been put into developing this game (and that is still being put into this game) by a group of independent modders that go by "Derelict Games", I think you should still consider grabbing a copy if you find yourself in need of a game to fill that colony sim itch.  I've personally always enjoyed playing the game.

I bought this game when it came out, and had high hopes for it. It was chugging along just fine for a while, updates were happening, then suddenly, NOTHING.

No explanation, just abandonment.

I had expected more from this company than total silence and abandonment.

Since then, I have never bought a Double Fine game and I urge everyone else to boycott this company that treats its customers like garbage. I also took note of the devs and have nothing to do with them if they go to, or found new companies.

EDIT: Reason for posting in 2019, going through my entire library and writing reviews for exceptionally bad or good games.

column8: The game was barely playable when it came out, and the updates were so sparse that it had no chance of improving and gathering a greater audience. DoubleFine wanted a pop indie game where they replaced the "independent developer" with "some cash" and when that idea inevitably collapsed in on itself they pulled the plug. Tim Shaffer himself used the failure to endorse the game's now grotesquely incomplete 1.0 version, which they continue to sell, before he scurried back into the scat-stained crags of Southern California.

Tim Shaffer himself used the failure to endorse the game's now grotesquely incomplete 1.0 version, which they continue to sell, before he scurried back into the scat-stained crags of Southern California.

column9:
It's in early access mode.
There are many issues that make it difficult to play, such as freezes and bugs,
and it's been several years since I bought it, but there have been no fixes or updates.

Because it's unfinished and hasn't been updated, I can't recommend it, even on sale.

I also don't purchase titles from developer Double Fine Productions and publisher Double Fine Productions.

column8:
Wikipedia Sums it up well.

After the release of v1.0 on November 21, 2014, twelve employees were laid off including the programmer and project lead JP LeBreton. On December 16, 2014 Greg Rice posted on the official technical support forums stating that there were no further plans for patches and there was no team assigned to the project. Double Fine officially ended support for Spacebase and abandoned the game in May 2015.
column9:
Wikipedia Sums it up well.

After the release of v1.0 on November 21, 2014, twelve employees were laid off including the programmer and project lead JP LeBreton. On December 16, 2014 Greg Rice posted on the official technical support forums stating that there were no further plans for patches and there was no team assigned to the project. Double Fine officially ended support for Spacebase and abandoned the game in May 2015.

column9:
Not very attractive, antediluvian ergonomics.
Crashes already after 20 minutes in the tutorial... & reloading the save makes the game crash the same way...
Even with patch 1.07, it's still an alpha game that crashes every 2 minutes or even less than 30 seconds... (For a management/construction game, it quickly becomes complicated, especially when the save is corrupted...)
In short, it's simply unplayable!

column8:
DoubleFine released this as an early access game. Then they decided that they didn't want to finish it and "released it", running off with the money. The current state of the game is very early alpha and unplayable.

If they were a small start-up games company that failed, then it'd be kinda understandable. Either way, as an established and supposedly successful company DoubleFine shouldn't have been relying on early access to fund their game (it's also worth noting that they had won funding from The Indie Fund - even though they couldn't really be described as indie devs).

In other words, DoubleFine took funding from Indie devs and money from early access buyers, and in return gave.. Nothing.
