column9:
Spacebase DF-9 is an abandoned "early access" version of a potentially good space base construction tycoon. Its developers lost funding mid-development, so the project was shelved and released as-is on Steam for $6.99.

Or rather, the developers themselves might have wanted to release it for free. However, everything indicates that the backers at Double Fine Productions decided that too much money had already been spent on the project and that they needed to somehow recoup that money, even at the cost of their reputation. Incidentally, if you have SDF-9 in your game library, you most likely got it in a bundle with other Double Fine gamesâ€”at the time of writing this review, the game has "extremely negative" ratings on Steam, so few people will be willing to buy it separately now.

The SDF-9 concept was perfectly feasible: tough tycoons aren't being released in large numbers these days, so a game about surviving in space with a constant shortage of oxygen, money, and manpower could be a hit. At the start of the game, we have a very small crew, and it's replenished extremely irregularly (from the occasional arrival of ships drifting through space, whose lonely inhabitants wish to settle on the station). However, the same crew members are tasked with various tasks depending on the situationâ€”from construction, resource mining, and medical work to gardening, tending the bar, or defending the base (different characters have different work preferences and skill levelsâ€”these factors can often conflict with each other).

The crew requires air, food, rest, and entertainment, which are provided by air purification systems, gardens, a recreation room, a gym, and a bar; these require a certain number of generators to function. To build all this, you need money, which is earned by refining the space rocks mined by spacecraftâ€”meaning you also need a refiner to handle the refining. And for miners to enter space, you need a separate room with spacesuits and special doors that pump out the air. And if you don't install a couple of turrets at the base, a couple of bandits from the first pirate ship they come across could destroy it, for some reason killing off your entire crew. This would be all well and good, but the version currently available on Steam has three key flaws that could have been fixed in the later stages of development, had it continued.

The first flaw is the lack of a coherent tutorial. The existing one was clearly rushed: the player has to figure out most of the gameplay mechanics themselves, through trial and error and starting over. This is especially noticeable when trying to launch a new game outside of the "tutorial mode" (where you're given a base consisting of a few rooms with the most important buildings from the start), but from scratch (where you're stuck in outer space with three astronauts with an oxygen supply for eight in-game minutes, a base "core," and 2,000 coins, which run out too quickly in the first dozen tries, forcing you to hit restart again and again).

The second problem is the raw balance, which clearly wasn't tested by the test team before release. There's either a constant shortage of coins or nothing to spend them on. At first, there are too many people, then inappropriately few (new ones seem to arrive on drifting ships completely randomly, and it's impossible to "order" manpower from Earth to your base). Builders construct new rooms incredibly slowly (the developers themselves seem to have realized this when they built a system to "speed up" in-game time, but even it doesn't help stave off boredom). Some buildings are either useless or have an unclear effect on the crew's condition (in particular, they seem to have no need for a "rest room," nor for a doctor's office). There are also simply strange game design decisions that unnecessarily complicate an already challenging gameplay: for example, once you place a building of a certain type in a room, you can no longer place buildings of a different type there (since that building "paints" the entire floor surface beneath it, not separated by walls). So, if you built a huge room, placed a bar counter (an item of the "bar" category) in it, and then decided to split the room into two by placing a wall in the center, it won't work: the floor is already painted blue, so you'll end up with two "bars" separated by a wall (one with a bar counter, the other empty). The gameplay mechanic of powering buildings with generators works equally strangely: some reviewers claim that this mechanic was cut from SDF-9 and that generators are completely useless. However, in my case, some buildings still complained about insufficient power. After I ordered my builders to dismantle them and create new ones, the "insufficient power" problem actually disappeared.

The third, most noticeable problem is a clear lack of content. Upon opening the building menu for the first time, the player may be surprised by the large number of building categories, but it quickly becomes clear that most categories contain only one type of object. And this isn't because the game has just begun, but because the developers simply haven't had time to implement other types of objects. There's one type of reactor, one type of refiner, one type of air purification system, one type of sapling (though the plant models are different), one bed, and one gym machine. Potential new team members arriving on ships are given maybe a dozen welcome messages and quickly become repetitive. Your base is threatened by external factors from space, but they come in a few varieties: diseases, asteroid impacts, and space pirate attacks (sometimes singly, sometimes in pairs). Problems are solved in the same monotonous way: assign doctors, put out fires, hang turrets along the corridors. The game continues, monotonous situations recur more and more frequently, and after a couple of hours of base development, the player realizes they have nowhereâ€”and, more importantly, no reasonâ€”to grow. The player has no ultimate goal, but the map (despite random generation) always has strict boundaries and a limited number of resources. That is, there will inevitably come a point when the base either has no room or nothing to grow onâ€”but the game won't end until you press Escape and start over. So, in its current state, SDF-9 isn't a tycoon, but rather a sandbox, a rather monotonous one at that, with few available actions.

Verdict: clearly an unfinished version of a potentially good game, killed by a lack of funding. Perhaps at $0.90 it would have been quite tolerable, but the anger of players who bought it for $6.99 is completely understandable. If SDF-9 "seemingly free" came to your library with a Double Fine game bundle, it might even offer a couple of hours of interesting gameplayâ€”until it becomes predictable and tediously monotonous. I don't recommend it at full price, or even at a discount.

P.S.: After a flurry of player outcry, the publisher released the SDF-9 code open source and announced that it welcomed any contributions from modders. This, however, didn't save the project, as the game clearly lacked the resources to achieve cult status, and there were almost no volunteers willing to work for free to save a development that had already foundered.

column8:
I wish I hadn't ignored the bad reviews and bought this game purely because it was on sale very cheaply. There's a lot of potential here, but it's all just that - potential, completely unrealised. Literally nothing about this game is satisfying or fun. Even with the community patches the game still doesn't function properly. I restarted over and over, trying to learn how to get the best start, until I finally got a good starter base going with all my colonists fairly well satisfied...only for one of them to arbitrarily go insane and start wrecking everything. Builders float mindlessly in space ignoring tasks until they die, or just mooch around the base playing handheld games while you wait forever for an important construction job to get done. Technicians wander around ignoring broken machinery, or if you're lucky, happen by and repair it in tiny increments of 5% or less before wandering off again. Miners stand in corridors staring at walls while you run out of resources to build with. Security guards stand idly in adjacent rooms while raiders kill your colonists.

Not worth the frustration.

It's sad that the game is in the same state some years ago. I played at a friends pc and now i bought that game to support the devs.
But there are no new objects or items.

Furthermore even the "easy" maps with "very low" threads are just killing you.
You get 3x 2 Raiders in a row within 10 seconds. One time i got 5 vessels together in the same time.

In another game i got raided and lost 25 people because of 2 raiders (i changed ALL of my citizens to security after they killed 6). The balancing is very nice. When you want to get frustrated even on easy maps to learn: You're right here

column8:
I'll be honest, this game had a LOT of potential, but ended up as one of the poster children for how early access goes wrong. 

People bought this game as an early access because Double Fine had a great reputation (at the time, anyway) and were promising the moon with it. Unfortunately, development went over-time and over-budget. Eventually, Double Fine just called the current release the final release and released it from the Early Access program, even though it was full of game-breaking bugs and more than half the promised game functions weren't developed yet. 

The devs then had the gall to tell players that it was absolutely fine and to quit their complaining. 

This game is why I will never give a cent to Tim Schafer or Double Fine again. 

Do not buy this game.

column8:
This game blows. When you're doing well, you never get to fight anyone because no one comes into your base. When you're down on your luck, they send ships full of marauders every few seconds which makes it so you can't possibly keep up, let alone put out the fires and busted stuff they cause. Oh, and in case you're wondering, I chose to set up my base in a place where the threat level was "Extremely Low" so I could avoid these issues while I get good at the game.

No wonder it's only $1.50 to get a copy, not to mention that it's only version 1.0 and people were talking about it back in 2014... (5 years ago)

column8: A lesser appreciated title, a challenging game for sure. Once you get started, you have to be fairly attentive with different things. Always keep an eye on new arrivals, sometimes they aren't fresh friendlies. If you see a derelict, salvage it. If everyone dies, try again. Needs work to its core, but I still play it from time to time.

Da habe ich doch mal ein ganz unglÃ¼cklichen Kauf von 2013, aus den tiefen meiner Bibliothek herausgeholt, um auch mal eine negative Review zu schreiben, was nicht wirklich oft vorkommt. Es geht dabei nicht einmal um das Spiel direkt, denn das Spiel kann nicht dafÃ¼r, das seine Entwickler auf einmal ihre Arbeit einstellten und es seinem Schicksal Ã¼berlassen wÃ¼rden.  
Der Ansatz eine Raumstation zu bauen und zu verwalten ist eigentlich hochinteressant und hÃ¤tte sicherlich immer noch ziemliches potenzial. Warum es sowas bisher, meines wissend nach, nicht mehr gibt, verstehe ich gar nicht. Leider konnte dieses Spiel nie seine vollen MÃ¶glichkeiten entfalten. 
Es gibt wohl noch Fans, die versuchen aus dem, immerhin zur VerfÃ¼gung gestellten Quell-Code, noch etwas zu machen aber das Ã¤ndert nichts daran, das hier ein typisches Negativbeispiel fÃ¼r das Early-Access Programm vorliegt: Der Kauf eines nicht fertigen Spiels, birgt immer ein gewisses Risiko.  

Zum GlÃ¼ck gibt es bei weiten genug positive Beispiele als ausgleich.
column9:
I've dug a rather unfortunate 2013 purchase out of the depths of my library to write a negative review, which doesn't happen very often. This isn't even about the game itself, because the game can't be blamed for its developers suddenly stopping their work and leaving it to its fate.

The concept of building and managing a space station is actually very interesting and certainly still has considerable potential. Why, as far as I know, something like this doesn't exist anymore, I don't understand. Unfortunately, this game never reached its full potential.

There are probably still fans trying to make something out of the source code, which is at least made available, but that doesn't change the fact that this is a typical negative example of the Early Access program: Buying an unfinished game always carries a certain amount of risk.

Fortunately, there are more than enough positive examples to compensate.

column8: Okay so lets be real up front.. Double Fine dumped this game and ran with the cash. Now that being said this is a pretty fun game. I keep coming back to it. It's quite relaxing. I wish they would of polished it more before they abandoned it, however,  for me its paid for itself several times over.

I've played it for a few hours now, had to restart multiple times as I finally learn something that wasn't really explained. I'm still trying to figure out a lot of it. Unfortunently, I don't think I can really recommend the game in its current state. Maybe if it was only a couple bucks, or free. It's a good concept, and it was diverting for a few hours. But with it being abandoned, I just don't think it's worth the cash for it. I'm honestly not sure where I got it, I don't remember buying it, it probably came in a humble bundle or something. If you really like building and planning, it's ok. But there are far better games than this that fit that niche in my opinion.

If the dev's ever come back to it and actually do something with it (unlikely) then I might re-evaluate. For now... meh...

column8:
While the game has been abandoned, which means no more patches. I find myself loving this game. It's sortva like X-com, but with a lot more chances for things to get you killed, which is what makes it fun. You WILL loss people, that is 100% certain, but they I rarely found myself on the actual loosing side of the game. Sadly you cannot save without quitting, which tbh hasn't affected the experience that much for me. If you ignore the fact it was abandoned and give a shot, you will realize it's actually a good game that just had a bad fate. 
+X-com-like experience
+Hours of randomly generated fun
- Can be quite punishing at times, depends on your luck and how well-made your base is.
-Must quit to save
Final: 7/10 Give it a shot.

column8:
When I backed this, I had no idea that Double Fine's Tim Schafer had such a record in the industry for chronic mismanagement. I also had no idea that his development plan was *entirely contingent* on the absurdly optimistic presumption that this game would equal the financial backing of Prison Architect, one of the most successful projects ever to be released through Steam's Early Access program (by a studio which, it must also be said, allocated funds cautiously and responsibly, rather than haemorrhaging cash with nothing to show for it).

The fact that they splurged all their funding without coming close to completing the game would be bad enough, but the insult of slapping a 1.0 on an unfinished project (and the ludicrous claim by Schafer that he actually considers the game complete) is a kick in the teeth. Make no mistake - this is a deeply unsatisfying, barely playable mess, and to sell it under the pretence of having finished development is as shameless as it is reprehensible. More galling, there was clear potential for an excellent game here, so abandoning development wasn't merely an act of utter disregard for those of us who supported it, but also a foolish lost opportunity.

Not only should you *not even consider* buying this, but you shouldn't buy *anything* from a studio that treats its customers with such contempt.

Als Teil eines 50% Rabatt BÃ¼ndels mit 12 (jetzt 13) weiteren gut bewerteten und teils top Titeln kann ich diese kleine SÃ¼nde verschmerzen, empfinde es dennoch als unethische GeschÃ¤ftspraktik, solche unfertigen Spiele zu vermarkten.
column9:
âœ¯âœ¯

Spacebase DF-9 was part of the Double Fine Bundle and received very poor reviews.
It's now part of my library, and I don't recommend it either. The game was once an "Early Access" title, but development was halted prematurely.

Even though I recognized its potential, the gameplay was unbalanced, the menu navigation was not well thought out, and I simply wasn't having fun.
There's a patch created by the community that smoothed the game's entry. This allowed me to build a functioning and growing space station, which I enjoyed for a short while, until the game's bugs and monotony finally made me tired of it.

As part of a 50% discount bundle with 12 (now 13) other well-reviewed and partly top-notch titles, I can overlook this small sin, but I still consider it an unethical business practice to market such unfinished games.

column8:
It's a shame, because I actually enjoyed this a lot when I played it a couple of years ago, as everyone else has said though it's been completely abandonned (for a long time), so I wouldn't recommend buying it. 

That said, if you own it anyway, it can be fun to mess around with for an afternoon if you have nothing better to do. 

This is one of those games I do genuinely wish they'd come back and fix. 

If they'd allow someone to take over and continuing making it (for all future profits), and someone does, then I'd also really like it. Sadly that will never happen.

column8:
I know I'm late to the party, but I just got around to try this.
While there is some sort of fun to be had for periods of time, that never lasts long.
After dying relatively quickly the first four times, I had at least developed some sense of what was supposed to be what and thus managed to hold out for a while, expanding my base.
But after that (not too long) while it became apparent that there was not much content left to explore.
Shortly afterwards a horde of 45 Raiders came by to eradicate my 17 fledgling space-pioneers, with no way to get around it.

In short:
Hard to figure out, boring once you figured, frustrating overall.
Really don't buy.

column8: A buggy, unfulfilling experience; The bare bones of a space station building game with pretty much nothing beyond basic management. Characters do not develop or become interesting. Mechanics are unclear and unexplained; and Management tools are non-existant, so good luck working out what is going wrong when something does go wrong. And something will go wrong (because of pathing, collision detection, the base having invisible holes). A few hours of base setup game, that will ultimately leave you wondering where the other three quarters of the game are. Not worth the price tag unless your time is worthless.

column8:
I owned this game since it was in EA (I got it on sale) and never installed it, after it was cancelled I forgot about it. Then I ran across it in my library again so decided to install it. After giving it 13 hours here is my assessment.

Pro:
1- Functional but buggy, Its a decent time waster if you install the unofficial patches.
2- Rogue-like (ish) (if you like that sort of thing) its not specifically marketed that way but it has the unforgiving hallmarks of said genre, things can cascade from "No Problem" to "Your Last Colonist was just sucked out into space" becuase of battle damage leaving a hole in your station that you cant seal off and cant repair becuase there are raiders rampaging in your base, your airlocks are all broke and the doors leading to the hole have all been wrecked by the 7th or 8th raider team. This doesnt appear to be due to a bug but its hard to tell
3- I got my money's worth, I tend to have a $1 per 1hr of entertainment rule on purchases, im at 13 hours and I got it for $5 so even at full price it would have met my standards
4- Has some interesting elements and random events but you get pretty good at figuring out which are the good and which are the bad and how to avoid them

The Cons:
1-Buggy, security wont always explore derelicts properly, They will sometimes continue to target an incapacitated crewmate who you had them knock out while they were rampaging and many many others I cant even list them all here
2- Abandonware/Cancelled at this point even the team that was putting out the unofficial patches and upates has abandoned it. It is what it is and it will never change. 
3- gives you a look at what might have been with proper support and development which leaves it feeling unsatisfying


TL;DR if you are looking to waste an afternoon watching station after station get destroyed after you spent hours building it up, if you are the kind who enjoys walling sims up and letting them die, you can do that here too, you can even vent the oxygen from the room if you want. If all that appeals to you AND You get it on sale, it will scratch an itch for at most one afternoon

I cannot recommend it due to the fact that its utterly abandoned and has been for several years. I can see what it might have been with proper support however and it would have been fun.

column8:
To understand why this game is so widely panned, it's important to know that it was originally sold as early access and was unexpectedly cancelled. I don't blame Double Fine for this - they were self-funding the project and were hemorrhaging money - but it alienated a lot of fans, from the game and from the studio. And nowadays Spacebase DF-9 is held up as one of the great failures of early access as a funding model.

With all of that said, the situation today has changed somewhat: it's a $10 game on Steam, and what you buy is what you get. And is it $10 worth of game? Absolutely! It's a fun and addictive little diversion. Like everyone else, I'm disappointed that it didn't grow to become the $40 game we knew it could be, but the game that is there is charming and memorable.

And next time you buy an early access game, remember that all you're buying is the game as it stands today. If you're not happy with the asking price for the amount of game currently available, there are plenty of other places to spend your money.

column8:
I really want to like this game. Really. But it's got serious issues with play balance. It doesn't seem to matter what "threat level" the area has, Raiders appear with great regularity. Your people die very easily. Construction takes a lot of time, with no way to prioritize what gets built first. Cosmic events (space debris and such) occur quite often. 
If the devs work out the bugs, I'll annotate my review with the upgrades. Until then, I have to go thumbs down.

column9:
In my opinion, one of the most underrated games.
The abundance of negative reviews and the lack of localization scared off a significant portion of Russian-speaking players. I admit, I fell for it myself. But then, I bought the game on sale. I launched it with a feeling of having wasted money. And... I liked it! Spacebase DF-9 is an indirect control strategy game. Interesting astronaut animations. Fun graphics. You can choose the game's difficulty by setting the coordinates for the landing site of the primary capsule with three astronauts. The music is unobtrusive, and when the camera zooms in, you can hear various sounds around the station.
At first, a Russian localization was sorely missed. It was distracting when you constantly had to search Google for a translation. But now there is a translation. The game's humor is perfectly captured. It's much more enjoyable to play.
And most complaints about so-called "bugs," in my opinion, are due to users' misunderstanding of the game mechanics.
I had a similar experience. A punishment cell was urgently needed for a raging medic. I think he drank something alcoholic back in his medical station. An empty compartment with a food dispenser came to hand. I quickly renamed it "shutting cell," shoved the medic in there, and forgot about the whole episode... But for some reason, the astronauts refused to go to the punishment cell for food, even fainting from hunger. One even fainted in the airlock, which stopped the airlock from opening. And while the second doctor was taking the poor guy's pulse, making a diagnosis, and bringing him back to his senses... the airlock wasn't working. Well, strangers shouldn't be in the airlock area. Meanwhile, a miner, his oxygen supply running low, was trying to get into the base. The worker nearly died of suffocation, but just seconds before the airlock shut off, he finally made it into the base. I realized the cause of all this chaos later, when I analyzed the events.
I lost track of the oxygen again. The number of people exceeded the permissible limit. But while I was delaying building new oxygen generators, panic was growing at the base. No one wanted to build new reactors; they just ran around with bulging eyes and shaking hands. And then... Everyone died. Only one miner survived, who was flying to the asteroid for ore at the time. I can imagine what he went through when he returned to the base :). But the station was still restored after that.
Overall, it's a good, fun game. Don't be fooled by the bad reviews until you try it for yourself.
P.S. I'm currently playing on version 1.06. But enthusiasts haven't abandoned the game. Unofficial patches are being released. I think it's worth a try.

column8:
Abandoned game.

I bought it on Early Access, and I'm here to advise you not to. 
Do not reward developers or publishers for such nonsense.

edit:
I should note that it's less of an abandoned game and more of an abandoned WIP.
Would've been alright if they more-or-less finished it before moving on, but it's very unfinished.

It has its moments, but save your money for a complete game from a dev who deserves your support.

column8: DO not buy this game! It is overwhelmingly negative for a reason. The game has been all but abandoned, wasted potential. What is actually in the game is very shallow. Once you get a working base (usually through pure luck) you just end up losing anyway to raiders who kill everyone. The game's save system is also very strange, you can only have one playthrough at a time, and have to erase your last one if you want to start a new one.

column8:
TLDR:  Out of early access in name only, this game is abandoned by the developer unfinished and full of bugs.  You shoudnâ€™t buy it.

I still think thereâ€™s a lot of potential here, but Double Fine walked away instead of finishing it.  If this were still in early access and still being developed it would be worth checking out, but unfortunately itâ€™s neither of those things.  I bought it in early access and knew there was a possibility of it never getting finished, but I certainly didnâ€™t expect that to happen with Double Fine.  Iâ€™m amazed theyâ€™re still selling it.

Here's some obvious missing things (there are probably more):
- Overviews of things like moods, productivity, disease spread, food supplies, facility utilization, etc.
- Cleaning up blood / etc from the floors
- Ways to draw playerâ€™s attention to things like broken walls or that there are X raiders and Y killbots in the base and where exactly they are (it tells you when they enter but that notification stays even if turrets take care of them at the door)
- Specify higher priority for certain build or repair jobs (sometimes you really need another oxygen recycler but your builders are more interested in tearing down the derelict vessel)
- Selecting the next thing to research without needing to find your research lab and click on the empty floor or wall space

As is you can sort of get a space base started, but the game quickly reveals how unfinished it is.

Esta no es la forma en que un estudio decente saca algo a Early Acces; Ellos mismos deberian saber que lo de Early Access es sÃ³lo una patraÃ±a para sacar dinero con la que ACABAR de financiar un proyecto y ver cuanto dinero merece la pena usar en dar retoques.

En mi opiniÃ³n, en vez de pagar salarios astronomicos a Jefes de DiseÃ±o, Jefes de ProgramaciÃ³n, Jefes de RPy Jefes de Jefes, podrian haberle decidido los derechos a algun estudio indie para que lo siguiese desarollando hasta estar bien hecho y compartir beneficios.
column9:
I recommend it to video game developers who don't mind spending a couple of euros on sale to see how you shouldn't release a game into Early Access.

It could have been fine if they had bothered to make the game at all.
It's shocking that the heads of this production, having worked on epic titles in the world of video games, have allowed this half-finished product to be released, and it's considered finished.

This isn't how a decent studio releases something into Early Access; they themselves should know that Early Access is just a ploy to raise money to FINISH funding a project and see how much money is worth spending on tweaking it.

That's not what happened here; They released a half-baked game (one that part-time indie developers could have ready in 8-12 months), with absolutely no polish (I imagine they were hoping the community would explain how to polish it...), and then they realized there weren't enough people buying it to pay their salaries.

This is the market, folks. Release something that's almost finished, not a half-baked product that looks like an abandoned indie game from a beginner.

In my opinion, instead of paying astronomical salaries to Heads of Design, Heads of Programming, Heads of PR, and Heads of Heads, they could have given the rights to an indie studio so they could continue developing it until it was well done and share the profits.

column8:
Great little colony game! When you start a new game (I'll call it a mission), you get to pick a point in the solar system with 4 variables:
Warp Gate proximity determines how often ships and visitors appear.
Magnetic Fields determine the presence of derelect ships to investigate.
Debris is how many asteroids are to mine, and how often you're hit with them. (not often)
Hostilities is of course, how many bad guys show up.
There aren't really any specific points per say, it's more for RP.

You can't research anything.. but there are in-game Goals, and the graphics fit very well. AI can be fairly stupid at times, like boarding a derelict craft and getting murdered as soon as they pass the airlock.. I lost 8 staff this way, until a couple of builders managed to deconstruct their airlock! I then cut little holes in each room's wall to suffocate the occupants! BWAHAHA. You can have doors on the outer wall that are sealed, then lock intruders in their rooms and manually open them.. many ways to play.

As I said, you cannot research your armor or better weapons.. but for 300 materials you can mount a laser turret into the airlock and around your base to vaporize any intruder in a couple of hits :D.

Another fine feature is that you start the game with 1,000 power but if you save & exit, then load again it drops to 500. I almost lost everybody to a station-wide systems failure but here's what I did:
Space suits provide 8 minutes of O2 so first I put everyone into space suits by giving them the 'Builder' job, and built a 6x6 room with a Fusion Reactor in it for a total of ~300 materials, which I had already. In a gamer point of view, this seems like a terrible job at programming but imagine if in the real world, your station suddenly lost all power for no dicernable reason! In that regard, the bugs give the mission more unpredicabilities to work around :).

Currently around 5.00 would be an adequate average for the amount of time you may spend on it (I've been playing about 5.5 hours today!) and how you RP the scenarios. There's a user in the Discussions who is trying to fix the game through patches (modding). v1.08 is available at the time of this review, but v1.09 has haken 6 months already. Hopefully we can research soon, then it would be worth the $10-15 mark ;).

Hostilities is of course, how many bad guys show up.
There aren't really any specific points per say, it's more for RP.

You can't research anything.. but there are in-game Goals, and the graphics fit very well. AI can be fairly stupid at times, like boarding a derelict craft and getting murdered as soon as they pass the airlock.. I lost 8 staff this way, until a couple of builders managed to deconstruct their airlock! I then cut little holes in each room's wall to suffocate the occupants! BWAHAHA. You can have doors on the outer wall that are sealed, then lock intruders in their rooms and manually open them.. many ways to play.

As I said, you cannot research your armor or better weapons.. but for 300 materials you can mount a laser turret into the airlock and around your base to vaporize any intruder in a couple of hits :D.

Another fine feature is that you start the game with 1,000 power but if you save & exit, then load again it drops to 500. I almost lost everybody to a station-wide systems failure but here's what I did:
Space suits provide 8 minutes of O2 so first I put everyone into space suits by giving them the 'Builder' job, and built a 6x6 room with a Fusion Reactor in it for a total of ~300 materials, which I had already. In a gamer point of view, this seems like a terrible job at programming but imagine if in the real world, your station suddenly lost all power for no dicernable reason! In that regard, the bugs give the mission more unpredicabilities to work around :).

Currently around 5.00 would be an adequate average for the amount of time you may spend on it (I've been playing about 5.5 hours today!) and how you RP the scenarios. There's a user in the Discussions who is trying to fix the game through patches (modding). v1.08 is available at the time of this review, but v1.09 has haken 6 months already. Hopefully we can research soon, then it would be worth the $10-15 mark ;).

column8:
Well, here is an actual review of the game. Not all those silly little kids who've played only in-development and early-build games demanding updates. The game is actually pretty good, better than 99% of the stuff out there, which nowadays is not such a hard thing to do.
 
On the plus:
+High-level of polish
+Nice music & sound effects
+Intuitive menus & controls 
+Price tag gets -85% when on discount.  

On the negative, it is more of nit-picking and quality-of-life that exists in top polish games.
-Tutorial being on the short side; if you skip the tutorial you may miss why you need certain things
-Lack of description of objects purpose; 
-Short notifications; Raiders are coming ! Where ? They are already killing your crew!
-Attacks and events seem unbalanced by player development? First run a derelict flew by, scouted it with 3x 3* security. All died by killer bot. 
-Lack of numerical representatio; Pawns are "healthy" ...ok, what does that mean to me if a weapon does 10 damage or 99?
-Defense turrets are nearly useless
-Some bugs that I caused myself by being stupid
-Being used to Rim World, didn't like that pawns can do only one thing at a time

All in all, good game, enjoyed it, recomended.

Est-ce que je recommande ce jeu? Oui, Ã  moins de deux euros... (et encore)
En fait, je fais une critique positive pour trancher avec toutes les autres et Ã©ventuellement attirer l'attention.
Mais ne vous y trompez pas, ce n'est pas la meilleure simulation spatiale loin de lÃ !
Le plus gros soucis Ã©tant principalement l'IA. Tant qu'il ne se passe rien de spÃ©cial, qu'il n'y a pas de situations compliquÃ©es comme un feu, etc... Et bien l'IA se comportera Ã  peu prÃ¨s normalement.
Mais dÃ¨s que c'est un peu le foutoir, vos compagnons interstellaires se comportent comme des idiots notoires et vous enragerez sur certaines situations.
Par exemple, il y a un feu et plus d'oxygÃ¨ne dans un compartiment et bien certains idiots ne vont mÃªme pas avoir Ã  l'esprit de fuir et tenter de s'Ã©chapper mais vont paniquer comme des dÃ©biles jusqu'Ã  en crever!
VoilÃ  Ã  quoi vous attendre! Heureusement il y a des patchs non officiels qui semblent intÃ©ressants mais ils ont tendance Ã  faire planter le jeu j'ai remarquÃ©.
Donc, vous me direz avec ces critiques quel intÃ©rÃªt d'investir quelques piÃ©cettes dans ce jeu???
Et bien, je ne sais comment l'expliquer mais ce jeu a un cÃ´tÃ© agrÃ©able et hypnotique!
On prend du plaisir Ã  construire et voir utiliser votre personnel les sas pour aller dans l'espace, se battre avec des envahisseurs (raiders), aller chercher du minerai... Bref, tout ceci est plaisant.
Mais ne vous attendez pas et n'espÃ©rez pas des miracles de ce jeu, on est loin d'une simulation spatiale pointue mais juste plaisante qui peut vous dÃ©tendre un certain temps.
column9:
Do I recommend this game? Yes, for less than two euros... (and even then)
Actually, I'm writing a positive review to stand out from all the others and possibly attract attention.
But make no mistake, this isn't the best space simulation, far from it!
The biggest problem is mainly the AI. As long as nothing special happens, as long as there aren't complicated situations like a fire, etc., the AI â€‹â€‹will behave more or less normally.
But as soon as things get a bit messy, your interstellar companions behave like notorious idiots, and you'll get furious over certain situations.
For example, if there's a fire and there's no oxygen in a compartment, some idiots won't even think about fleeing and trying to escape, but will panic like idiots until they die!
That's what you can expect! Fortunately, there are unofficial patches that seem interesting, but I've noticed they tend to crash the game.
So, with these reviews, you'll tell me what's the point of investing a few coins in this game???
Well, I don't know how to explain it, but this game has a pleasant and hypnotic quality!
It's fun building and watching your crew use the airlocks to go into space, fight invaders (raiders), search for ore... In short, it's all enjoyable.
But don't expect or hope for miracles from this game; it's far from a sophisticated space simulation, but simply a pleasant one that can relax you for a while.

This AI is to stupid to live, with the crew, excerzising in air locks, charging towards enamies, trying to repair stuff while being shot at, waiting to change before fighting back and more. The game soon becomes a endless Raider attack even on low threat, where if you are not dumping every mineral you have to turning your station into a pin cusion of guns your entire crew will get killed.

And dont forget once people get killed people get sad and try to kill everyone else, so pretty soon you are a ship full of sad sociopaths trying to die at the hands of endless stream of raiders. Fuck this game and Fuck DoubleFine for abadoning it in this state.

column9: The game's idea is very good, but in my opinion, it has too many negative reviews. It can be difficult to get the hang of, but once you get into the game and understand the mechanics, it becomes very fun and exciting. For the price and quality, it's a very good choice. If I had had a demo, I wouldn't have hesitated to buy it. I hesitated because of the reviews, but I don't regret the money I spent. I even gave it to a friend.

column8:
Great concept, but unfortunately it was very poorly executed.The tutorial jumps you straight into managing some basic aspects, but doesn't explain important features that you'll need to know when actually playing the game proper. 
The AI of the inhabitants seems almost suicidal too. Often my base would run low on oxygen, so I would place some oxygen converters for construction only for my builders to continually float around doing nothing until everyone was dead. If there was a solution to this it was never pointed out or made clear within the game and after a shory while and numerous restarts I found the game unplayable.

column8:
This game is a bloody joke, I can't tell you the amount of games I've started and restarted because of my crew being dumb and making stupid mistakes which costs me the game, if I fail at a game fine by me, I deserve to restart it but when I fail because your game is blatently broken from the get go it's so annoying.
Spacebase is a game in which you establish your own base with the use of initially a 3 man crew and can accept more in but have to balance oxygen consumption as well as various other micromanaging aspects which indeed sounds fun but here's my issue, the AI is blantently broken, I've had times where I've assigned 2 crew members to be miners out of 4 and sent them out to excavate debris for materials, but the idiots stop and idle half way through and do nothing but stare blankly at the bloody rocks as they use up their oxygen and eventually sufficate and because this is early game I have no hospital to send them to so they die of lack of oxygen which is dumb as hell since it wasn't my fault the idiots died staring at rocks and forgot to breathe. The game starts off quite difficult and leaves you pressed for time which I actually like as it pressures you into keeping your crew alive, unfortunately I can't tell you about the late game cause I can't get there cause half my crew die looking at rocks, then another few die at a random event that sucks them out of the airlock or they simply get killed by pirates. Another thing that's dumb is you'd have crew members doing excercise in the base, right fair enough, but they do it in the airlock so when someone comes in that crew member without a suit gets sucked into space and dies. This game is broken and the devs have long since abandoned it which is a shame since I've heard great things about double fine but this is the first and last game I shall ever get from them due to how bad the quality of this game is. What's a real shame is the gameplay is solid and I enjoy, semi clunky but if they stuck at it they could've refined it but they stuck this out here and expect people to buy it. If you saw this on the likes of NerdCubed's channel like I did and expect it not to be as bad as the reviews said it would be like I did, take this as your warning, this game is a peice of shit and doesn't deserve your money, go buy Planetbase which is an infinetely better game and actually works for one and doesn't have an bs involved.

column8: You know? I actually was having fun with this game. Then raider attacks happened so often even in a low threat area that it was impossible to do anything. Security is absolutely terrible and the A.I. is so bad they can't defend themselves from raiders at all, so you just die. There is no way around it. You will always lose at least 1 or 2 people during a raider attack even if it is just one raider. Eventually, you will just be wittled down or have 6 raiders attack at the same time and kill everyone. Terrible game and unbalanced. I get it if they wanted to make some hardcore or difficult game, but this is just unfair

column8: Bought this for maybe $2.00 a while back in a sale and I still feel ripped off. As other reviews stated, this game had an incredibly promising concept but was abandoned by developers. I appreciate the isometric graphics and most of the simulation, but to put it simply, the game isn't worth buying in its current state unless it goes down to 99 cents or so and you like modding. I've heard there is a promising modding community. This is irrelevant. Modders shouldn't have to finish an unfinished game the developers left us with. The game is fun at first, actually. It's fun for about 30 minutes, when the content and new gameplay that you are presented with just... stops. There is nothing past that point. Just disappointment.
column9: Bought this for maybe $2.00 a while back in a sale and I still feel ripped off. As other reviews stated, this game had an incredibly promising concept but was abandoned by developers. I appreciate the isometric graphics and most of the simulation, but to put it simply, the game isn't worth buying in its current state unless it goes down to 99 cents or so and you like modding. I've heard there is a promising modding community. This is irrelevant. Modders shouldn't have to finish an unfinished game the developers left us with. The game is fun at first, actually. It's fun for about 30 minutes, when the content and new gameplay that you are presented with just... stops. There is nothing past that point. Just disappointment.

column8:
I received this as a "present" for buying Hack 'n Slash.

After playing for a bit there's only one thing that really stood out for me: It really feels like an unfinished game.
Everything just feels clunky and unpolished, and isn't really fun to play.

If you are looking for some kind of simulation/management game, then something like Rimworld or Prison Architect would be a better choice than this.

column9:
This is the first game I've seen rated "Extremely Negative."

I'm just wondering, even though it's four years later, don't the devs mind having such a lousy rating?
Well, I mean, even after so much time, if they'd get a little more work done, they could finish it. They have millions, and just by hiring one or two developers, no more, these guys could improve the game in a few months (I have to say, it would be hard to do worse, so they wouldn't risk much).

So I'm going to do what everyone else does, because in any case, the game doesn't deserve anything better than a negative review, but I hope that one day, they'll be touched by grace and get back to it a little because the foundation is very good, as is the idea.

Maybe in 2 or 3 years if they're in a good mood and make you want to change the rating =D

Happy gaming, everyone!

column8: In the beginning I hated this game. I felt it was too comfusing and unplayable for such a simplistic game. It has a simplistic feel to it, but only after you learn how to play it. I haven't played it for months because I couldn't get how to play it even with the tutorial. After coming back I did the tutorial again (sucessfully this time) and rather enjoy it. It does not seem like this game will ever be "updated" or "completed" so don't expect that to happen, if you want the game, get it for what it is right now.

column8:
[June, 2020]
You may be curious of why this game has so many negative reviews thats probably why you click on the store page of this game. This game and its developer is the reason why early access can never be fully trusted, Barely polished and abandoned we all saw potential for a spaceship crew management game.

IN SHORT... If you could rent a goat for $10 and pet it just for a day. You wouldn't regret the goat and be proud you didn't spend you $10 on one of Steams Early Access Unfinished Failures. 

*You may think the playtime I put into this game is not enough to justify my review but trust me as a consumer and someone that loves video-games I've purchased games I don't even get the chance to play (e.g Nether, Survival).


- You don't have to read this part - 
An Early Access game I do not regret purchasing years back is Rust, as I put an amount of playtime into the game when the game was in alpha and looked like an unfinished Unity asset game. I thought that Rust would've been another bad purchase on my, but if you look at Rust now in its 7-8 year development cycle (which is hella long). The game is still flourishing and the developers are still committed, updating the game occasionally keeping the game alive and its community on board. 

As I digress, early access is not such a bad investment specially when the asking price for an unfinished game is affordable. If you are interested in a small or indie company developing an impressive game please do some research before throwing your hard earned simoleans ($) on a game that has barely been worked hard on by its developer.   
 
 
OLD REVIEW [March, 2018]
If I had a chance to go back in time and choose between either spending $10 on this game or paying a farmer $10 to pet his goat for 1.1 hours...

I'd choose the goat.

P.S - Don't buy.

column8:
Seeing another developer taking a crack at something like this (Starmancer, being published by Chucklefish) reminded me just how infuriating it was to have bought this only for Double Fine to abandon it because Tim Schafer is a condescending blowhard who can't properly run a project to save his life, with a large portion of his history in game development amounting to "wastes other peoples' money." Before the questionable fine print in Fig's terms of service, before the inability to finish Broken Age in a reasonable length of time (and showing it,) there was Spacebase DF-9 and it's transition from a low-numbered alpha build to 1.0 with with a thunderously awkward shrug.

Avoid.

While this game has its many bugs, you can see that it has potential. Well, it would have potential if it had not been abandoned a few years ago. Luckily there's an unofficial patch for this game which fixes many bugs and adds a lot of new content which actuallly fits the game's original content.

Still, the game is fun. It is one of the few games that makes me feel like I care about my people, it reminds me of Rimworld in a way. If this game is ever on sale for 2 bucks it might be worth picking up, otherwise it is a waste of money.

column8:
This was a very fun space builder for a few hours until I really started to get into it and noticed that there was very little control and almost no depth to the game. You build a base and then the game has its way with it.

I began building in a region with extremely low danger but after about an hour of cultivating a smoothly running spacebase I started getting raider attacks. At first it was within a few minutes of each other so I built some turrets and beefed up security. Then it became constant so I sealed off entire areas and cut life support to suffocate the raiders. But then it turned into simulatenous attacks from multiple locations, in addition to the incoming debris and other problems. What kind of ridiculous progression in an "extremely safe" zone is this? Everything was decimated and I was forced to give up. They just kept coming...

It might not have been so bad, but the NPCs are morons. Builders have no sense of priority, leaving gaping holes in walls or avoiding installing doors in favour of other tasks, leaving entire areas uninhabitable until they get around to it. Miners are so desperate to drop off materials that they'll do suicide runs right through enemy gunfire. Technicians will attempt to force their way into hostile zones to fix sabotaged equipment even though a door is locked because there's a group of raiders on the other side. Even if they do fix something, they have no sense of priority- opting to patch up gym equipment rather than the reactor. I don't think scientists actually do anything because they're never at the research console and in three hours they haven't accomplished anything noticeable. Doctors will leave bodies lying around for days. And Security, the one group you should be able to micromanage, can't even be split up to deal with multiple raiders. You can send a certain number of security staff to a location or enemy, but the remainder will just loiter.

If this game was being regularly patched and updated then I could see the potential and maybe recommend it if it goes on sale. But as that isn't the case, just stay away.

column9:
As already mentioned, the idea is very good! The execution has very interesting aspects and would be great if the character AI weren't so dumb and the gameplay weren't so slow.

I basically wasted 10 hours trying to get through the "tutorial" alone, thinking I'd made some noobish mistake and would get it right next time. It turns out the tutorial doesn't explain anything, and the environment is very dark and confusing (there's no option to increase brightness! In fact, the adjustment options are practically nonexistent). Furthermore, enemies constantly appear, and the characters are always very sad, even if you have them do a job they enjoy and provide entertainment and things that would make them happy at the base. Okay, there's that whole dilemma of being alone in space and the bonus of people dying all the time that would make anyone sad, but no matter what you do, it seems like the tendency is to get sadder and sadder, and then have a psychotic break (which is literally what happens) and start destroying the base. You handcuff the individual and have them admitted to the infirmary, but no one takes them, so the only option is to kill them.
Anyway, everything ends up being very scarce, and since you have no control over the characters and they're stupid, nothing gets done at the base, and you're left stagnant (not to mention, if someone attacks a character when they're not set to safety, they freak out and die, and they don't deviate when there's danger, and you can't warn them, meaning they die very easily).

All of this makes the game very slow. Maybe if I had the patience, I could finish the first level, but the game gives me a headache because it's so slow (speed 3, the maximum, sometimes feels like normal).

It's a huge shame because I really liked the premise, and other than that, the execution is very good, but these things make the game extremely frustrating and waste a lot of your time for nothing. Now I really want to play a game like this, with the same idea, but with the correct execution.

column8:
Game is way too buggy and annoying. Research is poor, it sometimes work and and sometimes doesn't. A single raider can and will wipe out your entire sercurity, then the rest of your colony. Your colonist are too stupid, they would rather suffocate in space then return back to base. There is no save so you can't go back and try again once one of these bugs kick in.
Played some more, colonist would rather die of starvation than eat replicator food, even though there are stacks of food in the fridge, and the gardens are producing more.
Everyone is sad or really sad all the time. Finally everyone lost the will to lived and killed each other. Raider came and got destroyed by my defense turrets then the turrets stopped working due to lack of maintenance. You can still carry on once everyone is dead because more shipps will stop and ask to join the colony.

column8:
Si hay algo que me gusta son las buenas historias y el explorar. El juego estÃ¡ bueno los primeros momentos pero luego es repetitivo en mi opiniÃ³n. AquÃ­ les enlisto lo que no me gustÃ³:

Puntos en contra:
1- El tutorial no explica bien ciertas cosas.
2-Solo se puede tener 1 partida activa con 1 solo punto de guardado. (Ãºnica partida que vas a tener o empiezas de 0, nada de volver atras)
3- Las llamadas de "aliados/piradas" son iguales, no hay variedad. He jugado 4 horas y sÃ³lo he visto 3 o 4 con el mismo texto de "ayuda/amenaza".
4- A veces se bugea; leÃ­ en otros comentarios eso pero no pensÃ© que me iba a pasar. En una parte se me volviÃ³ loca la maquina de defenza y mato a todos (estaba en modo protecciÃ³n). Aunque los bugs se arreglan reiniciando.
5-De vez en cuando viene otra nave a estar cerca  (decides si la invades con tu seguridad y la reclamas o no) pero todas las invasiones son modelos muy similares con 2 o 1 tripulante.
6-Lo mÃ¡s "exitante" fue cuando me invadieron de a 6 naves aprox...
7- Luego de una buena administraciÃ³n ya no hay nada que hacer, tus mismos tripulantes apagan el fuego, reestablecen las cosas. Lo Ãºnico que queda hacer es seleccionar minas y reparar paredes que se hayan roto por asteroides.
8- Por ahÃ­ se mueren de guerra o asfixiados en el espacio pero no se pueden reciclar los cuerpos o sacarlos...quedan ahÃ­ indefinidamente.
9- El fondo es siempre del mismo planeta, no cambia y tampoco te mueves como mencionÃ© anteriormente.
10- Hay cosas que uno no puede contruir como las maquinas para transladarse (sÃ­, querÃ­a moverme muucho por el espacio)
11- No hay variedad de objetos; cada habitaciÃ³n que construyas tiene 1 o 2 tipos de objetos (sacando los 10 objetos que se pueden poner en todas las zonas).
12- Las zonas seleccionadas son solamente para una cosa.
13-Literalmente la primera vez vas a morir asfixiado porque no es automatico el tutorial y tampoco te explica como empezar.

Puntos a favor:
1-Me gusta la variedad de razas y cÃ³mo estan hechas, desde los hombres pollo hasta pajaros o parasitos. 
2-Te da "tips" de las cosas que se pueden mejorar o si pasa algo en tu base.
3-Cada ser tiene "necesidades" asÃ­ que no siempre hacen todo automaticamente, a veces primero, comen y duermen lo cuÃ¡l lo hace mÃ¡s realista y te hace pensar en que cosas hacer primero.

Se veÃ­a "bonito" y prometedor el juego, es una lÃ¡stima que no lo desarrollen mÃ¡s Â¡TenÃ­a mucho potencial!, yo me imaginaba en un futuro agregar mÃ¡s objetos, seres y hasta un online pero luego vÃ­ que los desarrolladores ya no ven este juego y los mismos usuarios lo ven como abandonado, una lÃ¡stima Â¡Espero que les sirva mi comentario! Â¡Un abrazo y descansa en paz buen jueguito!
column9:
If there's one thing I like, it's good stories and exploration. The game is good at first, but later on, it gets repetitive, in my opinion. Here's a list of what I didn't like:

Cons:
1- The tutorial doesn't explain certain things well.
2- You can only have one active game with one save point. (You'll only have one save point, or you'll start from scratch, no going back.)
3- The calls for "allies/crazy people" are the same; there's no variety. I've played for four hours and only seen three or four with the same "help/threat" text.
4- It sometimes bugs; I read about this in other reviews, but I didn't think it would happen to me. At one point, my defense system went crazy and killed everyone (I was in protection mode). Although the bugs can be fixed by restarting.
5- Occasionally, another ship comes nearby (you decide whether to invade it with your security and claim it or not), but all the invasions are very similar, with only one or two crew members.
6- The most "exciting" was when I was invaded by approximately six ships...
7- After a good administration, there's nothing left to do; your own crew members put out the fire and restore things. The only thing left to do is select mines and repair walls that have been broken by asteroids.
8- Some people die from war or suffocate in space, but you can't recycle or remove the bodies... they stay there indefinitely.
9- The background is always the same planet; it doesn't change, and you don't move around, as I mentioned before.
10- There are things you can't build, like the machines for moving around (yes, I really wanted to move around in space).
11- There's no variety of objects; Each room you build has one or two types of objects (excluding the 10 objects that can be placed in all areas).
12. Selected areas are only for one purpose.
13. You'll literally suffocate to death the first time because the tutorial isn't automatic and doesn't explain how to start.

Pros:
1. I like the variety of races and how they're made, from chicken men to birds and parasites.
2. It gives you tips on things that can be improved or if something happens in your base.
3. Each creature has "needs," so they don't always do everything automatically. Sometimes they eat and sleep first, which makes it more realistic and makes you think about what to do first.

The game looked "nice" and promising, it's a shame they don't develop it more. It had a lot of potential! I imagined adding more objects, beings and even an online experience in the future, but then I saw that the developers no longer see this game and the users themselves see it as abandoned. What a shame. I hope my comment helps! A hug and rest in peace. Have a good game!

column8:
Base management games already aren't for everyone.  Even for those who like the genre, Spacebase DF-9 can be difficult to enjoy.

Right from the get-go, Spacebase-DF9 doesn't do much to "wow" you.  There are no cinematics or anything, and aside from possibly wanting to change Options, you'll quickly find yourself at a map of the galaxy, to choose where to start your base.  Depending on which coordinates you choose, relevant factors to your gameplay can differ - Stellar Density, which affects both how many resources there are and how frequently asteroids will hit your base - Warpgate Proximity, which affects how frequently you'll get visitors, wanted and otherwise - Threat Factor, which determines the frequency of Raider attacks - and Magnetic Interference, which determines the frequency of derelict vessels appearing.

Even at the first screen of "actual" gameplay, I have three issues with the game.  One, that your typical "difficulty" settings are pretty much thrown out the window.  You'd think that "low threat" would just be easy mode, but the threats still increase exponentially - I'll go into greater detail below.  Two, that there are a few different variables with which to basically "seed" your corner of the galaxy, but rather than let the player outright pick them, if you have particular settings you want, you have to scour the galaxy, pixel by pixel (okay, each area is maybe like 3 pixels wide, but it's still a huge area), until you find a spot you like.  If you want to force the player to try something new with each new game (which I'd be okay with, especially since this isn't exactly a "difficulty" setting), then just make it random, but it shouldn't be such a tedious process.  Third, why not tie Threat to Magnetic Frequency?  Raiders and derelict ships should go hand-in-hand, whether the ships are derelict due to Raider attacks, or the Raiders are there to loot the ships.  This would better fit the double-edge-sword nature of the other variables.

Something I mentioned above, and only becomes more prevalent the more you start to actually play the game, is that there is no story.  There are no cinematics, no voice acting, no plot, no progression from one stage to another.  You just survive in your base until you can no longer survive.  Many story-light games will still give you hints of backstory with item descriptions, and some of the dialogue.  In DF-9, just about all of the dialogue is tongue-in-cheek, but it succeeds more at confusing the player as to what the character is trying to do than being entertaining, and makes no discernible attempt to flesh out the galaxy.  The same goes for item descriptions, though they can, on occasion, at least give you a little more useful information than the dialogue does.  Character designs are interesting (sometimes), but since alien races don't line up with dialogue or have any impact on a colonist's abilities (just their name) it feels incredibly pointless, and more like the variety is just there because it's what everyone does in sci-fi.

Once you manage to forgive those issues, and actually start playing the game in earnest, you'll get your starting 3 residents.  You build your first handful of rooms of base by assigning them relevant jobs - namely Builder at the start.  Before long, you've got the whole "oxygen" problem under wraps (for the moment anyway), and have enough opportunity to "breathe" to start worrying about and make use of the two major "stat" pages for your residents.  The first, which is much easier to understand the ramifications for, is the Job screen.

When you view all the Jobs for your Base, it's shown as a spreadsheet comparing each resident to each job.  (I find it far more useful than simply viewing one resident and a list of each job.)  There, you get to see which jobs residents like or dislike doing - and how strongly - represented by an emoticon, and how skilled they are at each job, represented by a number of stars.  It's a bit strange that there's very little correlation between skills and likes - real people tend not to loathe things they're really good at, nor remain inept at their greatest passion.  But compared to the other issues in the game, this is pretty easy to forgive.  And frankly, this screen does its job just fine.  It's the second "stat" page for citizens, Personal Needs, that can cause nightmares.

At first glance, it's perfectly reasonable.  Sort of like The Sims, each resident has needs that must be met, and they will automatically go about meeting needs, especially if they're far from satisfied.  So if they're Hungry, they'll go to the Food Replicator and acquire some fabricated sustenance, or if they're not feeling sufficiently Social, they'll go chat in the Pub.  But there at the Pub, you'll find a problem that only gets worse the more you learn about it.  Sometimes, your citizens will get into a fight.  In my experience, this always left a citizen knocked out on the ground, though I felt like if I could just get a citizen in Security to respond fast enough, they could break up the fight before anyone gets badly injured.  Anyway, this can give you a considerable setback, as not only does it hurt Morale (which means they're less likely to work), it means the loser/victim will be out of commission for a while, their recovery will take work from your Doctor(s), and you'll need to have sufficient space in the Medbay.

As you grow your base's population to accomodate its continued expansion, fights will break out in greater frequency, naturally causing you to investigate why they do, and how you can prevent them.  So you take a closer look at the citizens' Needs.  And sure, you find that there's usually a correlation between low Morale and fights.  So you keep the food in the Pub better stocked.  You install more Monitors in the base so the citizens can more easily entertain themselves.  Some citizens weren't having their Duty needs met, but it's because you felt a bit of a crunch, and you had citizens doing Jobs just because it's what they were good at, but not what they liked doing.  So you spend an extra ten minutes at the Jobs screen, to make sure everyone's doing a job they at least like doing, if not love, even if it means some jobs will get done a bit slower while they hone their skills.  And things are good for a while; fewer fights, more productivity, means a happy player.  Maybe at this point you're starting to struggle with the increased frequency of Raider attacks, but for the sake of completing this thought before talking about that one, let's say everything's actually starting to go well.  It's going well, that is, until the citizens start fighting again.

You check the Morale of everyone involved in the fight, and it's doing alright.  The fight may have caused the victim/loser to take a dip in theirs, but it's certainly not what caused it.  Each of the needs is pretty well satisfied.  But then you take a closer look at the aggressor's Needs.  He's been at a job he loves for a while now, and his Duty is well satisfied - fully satisfied, actually.  Everything looks great.  But then you look at his personal job rating - egotistical.  That's right, if you make your citizens too happy, they'll overinflate their egos, and fight each other anyway!  It was at this point I had to put the game down for good.  But this came after I had been struggling with Raiders for many playthroughs.

Apparently I need to keep it short due to review length limits.  Basically, they wind up getting extremely hard as time goes on, seemingly increasing in difficulty faster than you can hope to develop defenses.  There seems to be a sort of "final wave" of Raiders but I was never able to fend them off, even with a dozen point defense lasers shooting down most of their ships.

In summary, think long and hard before deciding to buy Spacebase DF-9.  It's not just not for everyone, it's only for a very niche, forgiving group of gamers.

Yes, the game has been largely forgotten for a long time, but it's still supported by its community. There's a website with player-to-player patches.
Many of the game's bugs are gone, but the dumb AI still gets to you sometimes.
I recommend picking it up; it'll keep you hooked for a very long time.

column8:
Do not purchase this game.

It's been dropped in development, barely qualifies as an early beta build, and really is a depressing view of where Double Fine is headed.  I'm thoroughly disappointed, and waiting for Psychonauts 2 is becoming harder and harder to justify.

Edit:
I'm rather fed up with Doublefine.  They've rereleased old games, which run about 95% of the time.  They put this piece of garbage on the store, where the community patch is the only thing that makes it mildly viable.  Most importantly, they kickstart content, but go back on that very low bar.  

I'm done.  Psychonauts 2 was put on hold for a VR game and Broken Age.  Both games profoundly miss the mark, and highlight how Psychonauts was the last point where this company was firing on all cylinders.  This game should be enough of a failure to have sent Doublefine into financial ruins, but we haven't had the mercy of that yet.

Congrats; I now place Doublefine with MS, Peter Molyneux, EA, and Rockstar.  This is the short list of developers whose products I will not buy, given that they seem to show active disdain for their gaming consumers.  It's too bad WIndows 10 is the only option for gaming.

column9:
Back when the game was first acquired, it was interesting, something unusual, reminiscent of the old Space Colony, with regular updates, but then... The project was abandoned at 45-55% of its potential. For players capable of creating mods and add-ons, there were NO tools, no feedback. It was a huge disappointment with EarlyAccess.
Concept - 8 out of 10
Execution - 5 out of 10

column8:
Ich mag das Konzept des Spiels wirklich sehr, nur leider ist mit diesem Konzept bis auf den Rohbau nichts gemacht worden. 
Das Spiel hat seit nun Ã¼ber 2 Jahren keine Updates mehr bekommen und wird wohl auch nie wieder welche kriegen. Es ist unfertig und das merkt man leider an jeder Ecke. 
Die Bewohner kÃ¶nnen verschiedene "Berufe" annehmen und die dementsprechende TÃ¤tigkeiten ausfÃ¼hren. Jeder Charakter hat verschiedene FÃ¤higkeiten in den Berufsfeldern und wird mit der Zeit im zugeteilten Beruf besser. Leider fÃ¼hlt sich fast alles extrem holprig an, von Bauen Ã¼ber Ausbauen zu "KÃ¤mpfen". 
Das KÃ¤mpfen steht nich ohne Grund in AnfÃ¼hrungszeichen: Man kann Bewohnern quasi die Rolle einer Polzei zuteilen, doch dummerweise stellen sich jene ohne Berufserfahrung Ã¤uÃŸerst dumm an. Wenn Gegner kommen laufen sie hÃ¤ufig dorthin und machen exakt gar nichts.
Es gibt wenige RÃ¤ume mit noch weniger Ausstattung und eine groÃŸe Basis bietet (nach meine GefÃ¼hl zumindest) mehr Nach- als Vorteile. Man bekommt sehr langsam neue Bewohner dazu. Dennoch muss die Basis der groÃŸer werdenden Besatzung ausreichend RÃ¤umlichkeiten bieten. Trotzdem hat man im Endeffekt selbst in den leichten Karten nie genug Personal um alles in Sinnvoller Menge zu besetzen.
Ein leider aufgegebenes Spiel mit gutem Konzept. Sehr schade.
column9:
I really like the game's concept, but unfortunately, nothing has been done with it beyond the basics.
The game hasn't received any updates for over two years and probably never will again. It's unfinished, and you can see that at every turn.
Dwellers can take on various "professions" and perform the corresponding tasks. Each character has different skills in these professions and improves over time in their assigned profession. Unfortunately, almost everything feels extremely clunky, from building to expanding to "fighting."
The combat is in quotation marks for a reason: You can essentially assign residents the role of police, but unfortunately, those without professional experience act extremely stupidly. When enemies come, they often run there and do absolutely nothing.
There are few rooms with even less equipment, and a large base offers (at least in my opinion) more disadvantages than advantages. You gain new residents very slowly. Nevertheless, the base must offer sufficient space for the growing crew. Nevertheless, even on the easy maps, you ultimately never have enough personnel to staff everything in a reasonable number.
A sadly abandoned game with a good concept. A real shame.

I reccomend this game. Does it have faults, yes, is it bad, to a degree, is it good, to a degree. But you cant have the good without the bad and evil. Every game has it's own faults, even this one, but instead of whining and saying how bad this game is, how about people take matters into they're own hands. Start anew or mod it, if you think the game could be better, then start a community that is willing to put forth the effort to make what they believe to be it's potential.

Stop waiting for someone else to do it, if you want something done you gotta do it yourself.

column8:
The game had potential. Loved the concept, Loved the Genra.......That's basically were the props end though. I don't know what it was but the DEV team could not handle this game. Something happened and I have not looked into why but this game is basically done for. And in it's current state it's not worth playing. 

Well that's sometimes the risk. But I can't recommened anyone buying this. I should have made this review sooner but my friend recently reviewed the game so I should as well to steer people off of this game. 

From what I understand fans of the game have made unoffical updates? My hat goes off to those people but I can't play this anymore. If you are one of the fans patching this game. Check out a game called Rimworld. It has an amazing modding community and the game itself is not going to be abandoned. If you check out Rimworld and like it come to the Ludeon forums and help build a great game.  

Now I have not said much about Spacebase DF-9 besides don't buy it... And that the game is abandoned. The truth is I forget nearly everything about the game. It has been a long time since I played. I was waiting for many updates and bug patches that never came. It's your avereage colony sim but in space... If it was developed better it would be amazing.

column8:
A buggy, but Playable Game.

Sadly it is abandoned by the developers. I think the game has some major promise, but needed some more time and attention.

Twice in 1 hour I had People die due to suffocation because of stupid AI. And in the end, for some unknown reason, my builders removed all the O2 generators. Which set off a panic, and the Game would not allow me to build any more. Even in empty rooms. So if you enjoy watching all your work go up in smoke due to bad AI, This is the game for you.

The game has a lot going for it, and I want to like it. But it's just not done.

column8:
The epitome of why Early Access can go wrong. The potential of this game was overwhelming, and it belonged in a marketplace where there are few space building games. And the choice of bringing back the Isometric was good too.

However the choice to cancel, due to a lack of Early Access purchases, is a lesson all must learn in why you don't make a game and place all your hopes solely on your Early Access success, especially when the company that falls foul of this blunder is none other than Double Fine Productions, run by the revered Tim Schafer (Day of the Tentacle, The Secret of Monkey Island, Full Throttle).

If you already own this, hope for the future or for mods. If you don't own this, do not bother. This game is now officially abandoned indefinately.

column8:
Dear public saying this game is good, it is, you are right. But, there is one detail, in fact, not one, but two, not two but three and many more actually... 

1 - Double Unfine
Double Fine finishes a 0.6 game, jumping it straight to 1.0. This is ridiculous. They left a game that was CLEARLY unfinished abandoned! For a 0.6 game it was fine. But it ISN'T fine when you just say "WELP, SCREW THAT SHIT I AIN'T FINISHING THAT!". It's wrong! They stole ALL the money from the innocent players that tought it would be a good idea to waste their money in this, apparently good, game. I feel for them, for i am one of them.

2 - Double Fuck You
Good god Double Fine, at least state your reason for doing this! At least do something, just something to symbolize you care a little, just a tad. Just assume you do this... Well, i shouldn't speak to much about double fine... THEY CAN CLOSE THE COMMENTS, CAN'T THEY? Infact, i think im safe, for they care shit about us!

3 - The game 
Good as a Work In Progress, terrible as a finished product, bugs and more bugs, repetitive gameplay that gets boring after  5 playthroughs or so and, of course not very good graphics, but it would all be accepted if it was a WIP, but Double Fine, or rather, Double Fuck Our Clients, refuses to care about us. Please, just... State a reason, im furious by that. If you want to just steal our money, fine, Paradox does that always and still earns lot's o' money... But they at least try to maintain their lies! They at least say "Welp, sooorrrryyyy we gotta increase prices!" but for god's sake, Double Fuck, at least try! Show that you care for us just 1%, it's all i need.

4- Recommendation
If you don't care about corrupt people stealing your money, sure, go ahead. If you want to change that, please, leave. This game is good for base builders, quite fun, I would not recommend it for people with little patience or that like action, as it has little to no action (Only action there is is the Final Raid and some other minor raids that get boring and OP as time goes by, not action, just a excuse to say the game is not the same thing over and over again). 

Angrily, Anders.

column8:
I would have said i'd reccomend this game if doublefine had continued development of it to a much more realistic state to call a full launched title, at best its in EA status still. i bought this well before the " launch " and i will say its my fault for jumping on it a bit early, but at the time of my purchase of this in EA, i had many doublefine titles going into my library and most had been at worst, not half bad, at best, really fun. but this just completely baffled me, If i could get a refund, i Would. but it was way too late when they told us " too bad, so sad " still to this day, i refuse to buy doublefine games now, in fears of the same thing as what happened to Spacebase DF-9 to other titles, and they should not expect my money to be wasted to a dev i cant trust wont finish a game, this is almost as insulting to me to see in my library as it is to see Planetary Annihalation/Titans.

Side Note: I only made this to keep people away that are looking for a good finished game, this is Not a good finished game.

column8:
Maybe it's because I went into this with such low expectations, a whopping 19% of reviews for this game being positive, but I actually somehow managed to sink like 8 hours into this doing a few plays and even then i'm tempted to go back to try and do better. 

It's not the level of abanoned I was expecting, that's for sure. These kind of sims games I imagine take a lot of work and I was expecting this to be far less functional for the feedback it's gotten. It actually works okay, I managed to keep a base running for quite a while. I would of gotten a lot more engrossed in it too if I had actually built some proper defences.

As much as I didn't expect to say this, I had fun. It's an alright way to kill a bit of time.

With that said though I wouldn't encourage people to actually buy this unless it's in a bundle or insanely cheap or something. You can get a bit of entertainment out of it, but it is still disapointing on Double Fine's part to even still have an abandoned game up for sale. It's a real shame because there is a lot of potential here.

Seeing as there is no neutral option for reviews, and people probably pick out the positive ones to actually read, i'll mark it as positive, but again, I don't encourage you to actually pay Â£6.99 for this.


TL;DR : I expected a lot worse to be honest
