column8:
I don't have record amounts of time on this game, but I have enough to get the full experience of it. 

I will say this game is very fun also very challenging. 
You can choose the type of "space" you'd like to play in. The space will have different densities of resources and different frequencies of enemies and random events.

But I have found this game to boil down to a scalable tragedy event. You can start off in the easiest of space zones and spend enough time there and some horrible things will start happening that become impoosibly difficult to control.

My games typically end by a blitz of pirates that kill most of my crew or diable my systems and let my crew suffocate to death.

The game is still very fun to play and the base building great fun.

Add my negative review on the pile.

Bought as Early Access and I played it up to "launch". This could have been a good game, but instead it's a black mark on Double Fine who dropped it half-baked when it became fiscally inexpedient to support their customers.

I know, this is years after the fact, so why bother? 
Because Steam (for some reason) is still selling it.

Car ya des cadavres des raid...... mais les mÃ©decins s'en occupe pas, il reste juste a l'infirmerie pour se touchÃ© la nouille (cliquez sur "seal oxygen" comme sa il seront bloquÃ© et s'occuperont enfin des cadavres). Au passage les IA sont conne, "je me fais attaquÃ©, je vais mourrire si je m'enfuie pas, si j'allais parlÃ©e avec un garde en train de me dÃ©fendre pour qu'on meureut tout les deux ?". 

Bon, c'est quand mÃ¨me sympas d'y jouÃ©e, d'autant que je l'ai chopÃ©e sur Humble Bundle a 0.99â‚¬ donc j'ai rien perdue.

column9:
A nice little game... but with its fair share of bugs and rage! You won't be able to evolve your colonies infinitely, why? Simply because morale is constantly dropping! Because there are corpses from raids... but the medics don't take care of them, they just stay in the infirmary to touch their noodle (click on "seal oxygen" so they'll be blocked and finally take care of the corpses). By the way, the AI â€‹â€‹is stupid, "I'm being attacked, I'll die if I don't run away, what if I go and talk to a guard defending me so we both die?"

Well, it's still fun to play, especially since I got it on Humble Bundle for â‚¬0.99, so I haven't lost anything.
This game could have been good if the devs had tried to address the bugs and listened to the community. Especially in terms of graphics... well, for a 2014 game, eh! Let's be clear.

column8:
Tags: Tycoon&Simulator&Sim&City
Additional Tags: Delete Local Content & Remove from Library

TLDR: Infamous abandonned kickstarter early access rushed out incomplete.

Tried playing, interactivity was limited, placing tiles and creating rooms felt clunky. Seems like they were mostly interested in ripping off dwarf fortress's lazy newb pack UI and system for crew management. Sim-aspect between teammates or actual in-station behaviors did not seem implemented. Pathfinding was rudimentary. Ensuring life support system's connection to station power and extending the grid was a tedious confusing process.

column8: I do enjoy this game as it is but (and this is a massive but) the game is incomplete and that is what hurts with this game.  There is so much missing from this game and you know it when playing it especially once you have done the research and the rooms are constructed. But in the games defense it is a fun little game that throws the occasional curve ball at you to keep you on your toes and with a few mods in addition it turns into a good game. I'm checked I would recommend because you have to but I neither recommend and don't as my own feelings are still mixed

column8:
Played for a while, thought I was doing okay. Game is painfully slow and the AI pathfinding is terrible, but things were decent.

Got attacked by Raiders for about the 20th time in half an hour (I picked an area that supposedly had a 'Very Low' risk of being attacked by raiders), no issue. They'd come before, I'd taken them out easily.

Single raider wiped out my entire security team. Wasn't even far enough in the game to have researched better weapons yet (because if you don't build fucking shelves everywhere your little people will whine) And he then proceeded to kill everyone else (after taking out the oxygen supply).

Nevermind that Raiders are fucking pointless anyway, because the ships they come in don't wait for them to be done, they just fuck off.

So it's painfully slow, not particularly compelling, and it takes about 10 seconds to get fucked up the ass.

column8:
I am well aware of Tim Schafer's Molyneux-esque decline from a position of respected industry veteran to corporate slime-ball.  I am also well aware of Spacebase DF-9's troubled development and reputation as the quintessential example of a consumer-unfriendly kickstarter failure.

So why did I pick up this game?  It was dirt cheap on sale and, in theory, it contains many elements of a game that I should enjoy.  Base construction, resource and personnel management, quirky characters to enlist or engage- all wrapped up in a sci-fi setting.  I was expecting that it would be an incomplete experience good for a couple of hours of play with no worthwhile end-game.

"Incomplete" doesn't even begin to describe this disaster of a game.  The UI is unintuitive.  The AI is incompetent.  The QA is nonexistent.  Each of these elements adds a layer of frustration to the experience that, had I known existed, I would not have bothered to play even if you payed me the price of the game to do so.  Every element is broken on some level.  Had the developers an ounce of integrity, they could have easily invested the time (for which they had been paid in advance) to bring it to a servicable level, but this is nothing more than an embarrassment for which they should be ashamed.

Do not buy this game.  Do not buy games from this developer... unless it's Psychonauts.  Buy that instead.

column8:
Hello there fellow gamers!
If you liked this game, or you would bother pursaching it but you won't because of the bad reviews, I have great news for you! An unkown team from the internet made unofficial patches and bugfixes (what DoubleFine did not do) for the game. I have been playing for hours now with that patch, and it's extremelly great!
They fixed:
-when people at your base stay sad all time
-technicians not repairing stuff
-and more!
I can recommend you this game 100% if you are willing to install the patch, otherwise only if you get it for free.
Link for the patch: http://www.spacebasehub.net/

column9:
An interesting concept, interesting execution. At the time of its release, there was virtually no competition in this genre, but for some reason, the developer discontinued the project. However, the game hasn't gotten any worse for it; yes, there are bugs and flaws, but if you install the "official" (unofficial) patches, the game is transformed.

I don't recommend buying it; there are other ways to enjoy it; information about patches can be found on the community pages.

column8:
I know I checked "no" on recommendation, but I still loved this game!  Bottom line is, it's about 90% complete and has some holes that will drive you a bit crazy, but the 90% that is done is excellent, fun, challenging, creative, etc.  I logged about 24 hrs total play time and will likely not play it again, because I did everything you can in the game.  I wish the developer would take another crack at it, fix some of the bugs, and finish some of the features that never showed up.  This game could have been a staple of excellent indie games.  

Super fun, good multi-hour entertainment, but yes, it's got some gaps/glitches/issues that keep you from coming back after a while.

column8: Its simple with not a lot of content, but that in no way mean its short. My longest game was about 12 hours long, theres not a lot of different things to work with so you can just keep expanding what you already have. Hundreds of fully furnished bedrooms, dozens of bars, hallways, farms, pubs etc. You can literally create a large scale city. After a while i have so much resouyrces that my whole base is surrounded by turrets so im not in danger from raiders. Dont hate the game for the lack of content; love the game for the big things you could make it into

The concept of this game is genius and should therefore have a lot of potential â€“ but after a relative short period, the game gets impossible to play. The workers in the game rather talk to each other than doing there duties - and this means of course, that your whole base just die in front of your eyes, even you try desperate your best to organize the base-crew  - but when only a very few will follow your orders, of course it must end bad â€¦ and in every game!  

I do have understandings for the fact, that is not an easy thing to do, to program a game â€“ but this game has been for sale on Steam now for ages, and even so, the programmers of this game, still wonâ€™t lift a finger to fix the errors â€“ so, shame on them, and shame on Steam for selling this game full of errors â€¦ it is so sad that the gaming industry is so greedy and obscene!

column9:
Let's get started
-------------------------------------

Good:

Acceptable graphics
Many troops and units
Base or base customization
Complex
Realistic "Outside of space, NPCs suffocate if you don't have both decompression doors up and oxygen on."
Quite a few battles, even your own NPCs get into arguments.
When you're disconnected, the game continues until you return.
Hours of real gameplay and complexity.

The Bad:
Bug
Sometimes laggy
Many constant attacks
Extremely difficult, "quite a challenge."

-------------------------------------
It's a game that needs perfecting, but it still has its time and special features, such as modular base building, among other strategic qualities.

column8:
Played it for 2 hours and it really was fun. But once you have build every room it stops being fun (there are about 10 differen rooms).

After 2 hours it's boring. It's not worth 9.99 â‚¬ but I bought it via the Double Fine Bundle and it's a nice addition.
Whilst I love the idea ant the early game seems polished it just stops there. There pretty much is no mid or end game because once you got al rooms there is no more to see.

Also the combat is not rewarding. One cannot gain anything from it but the risk of losing a guy is really high so i always kept away from combat situations. Also the combat is pretty boring since one can only tell the minions a rough direction which they capture and defend themself.

Never figured out how to do science even tho I had the room, the machines and a scientist. Ugh.
One never really needs the science anyway since everything can be archieved using the lvl 1 machinery that one can build from the start. Mostly i never needed to build a second lvl 1 machine for my needs.

It's really annoying that one cannot command the minions themself. It's annoying when they are carring out a deadly policing command or just standing somewhere in the danger zone. It would really help if one could commandeer them.

Also there is no priorititzing system which means that a mid-size base becomes unmanageable.

If you seek a fun base building game I recommand Dungeon Keeper 2 or Prison Architect.

column8:
How the hell did I buy this?!
It is so un-polished that makes me feel that even the concept is broken.
Have played a few terrible games thanks to steam summer sale madness, but this takes the ice-cake top.

So whats annoying other than the clumsy user interface and lack of anything fun?
Guys are running around like idiots while raiders are shooting them dead is one of the prime examples.
And bugs like messages with font size 72 stuck on your screen forever.

Did I mention that there is no content in the game? Yes, there is nothing really.

Edit: Got it for Â£0.69, but I can't recommend this game at any price.

column8:
I got this game in a sale for next to nothing and had some hope for it as a space base management sim. Unfortunately the AI is awful and the mechanics for raiders and derelict ships are awful. The first time I played I managed to get 2 rooms made, an airlock constructed and everything needed for people to survive only for the first person to enter the airlock and glitch out, meaning that everyone else couldn't get inside and they all died. Great (sarcasm).

The second time I played I used the tutorial and got a lot farther, even setting up defensive turrets at my airlock to repel boarders. They don't use the airlock apparently and just cut a hole through the floor of ANY room and enter. Great again. Then people assigned jobs, don't do their needed tasks and get stuck talking to someone, doctors don't clear up corpses or attend people in airlocks, stopping everyone from entering or exiting. Their's no way to urge someone to do a specific task other than assign them a vocation and hope they know what to do. The security team kept going to a derelict with an alien enemy on board that kept killing them even though I'd cancelled the security tag and not claimed any areas. Then the doctor went over there to get the corpses..... It didn't end well.

All in all, this game is a frustrating mess, half the time you're just sat watching people trying to do a task that you have no power over but you know how to solve it and what dangers are there. The other half you're trying to assign people jobs that won't make them throw a tantrum and trash the only airlock while raiders are entering your base through the bedroom and killing people while they sleep. 

Don't buy it, look somewhere else for your gaming needs.

column8:
I can still remember when this had updates! When there were hopes and dreams, the promise of a finished game were just over the horizon! When Men were Men, Women were true Women! When Alien Parrots really were aliens and not the sad, mutant ones you get in pet shops these days.

Why again is this still being sold on the Steam market? The creators have abandoned it. As of writing it's on sale for $0.99 and I'm not sure I'd pay even that for it. Expect bugs that will never be fixed and gameplay that will never be added. This is the reason why people shy away from Early Access games; they even had the gall to remove the EA label even though it's unfinished.

If you're really that desperate to be rid of a dollar, I'd recommend you just throw it at Toady One and go back to the source of the river (Dwarf Fortress). Or buy RimWorld instead. At least with both you're getting more content and work towards completion.

no vale la pena. al principio  space base parece interesante  y la idea buena. pero despues de jugar unos minutos te das cuenta que le faltan cosas los controles se sienten mal. por ejemplo en mi primer base mis astronautas se murieron asfixiados a los 8 minutos porque por alguna razon las  puertas de cierre se buggearon.
tambien es un pain in the ass que no puedas mover la camara mientras estas en modo construccion.

en fin...       por 10 pesos Mexicanos...   no le hace nada mal a nadie.. pero a precio normal 109 pesos si es un desperdicio de dinero
column9:
It's not worth it. At first, Space Base seems interesting and the idea is good. But after playing for a few minutes, you realize it's missing some things, and the controls feel awkward. For example, in my first Space Base, my astronauts suffocated to death after 8 minutes because for some reason the closing doors were buggy.
It's also a pain in the ass that you can't move the camera while in construction mode.

Anyway... for 10 Mexican pesos... it doesn't hurt anyone at all... but at the regular price of 109 pesos, it's a waste of money.

column8:
I have played this game for several hours. I'm a pretty tolerant kind of guy.
I knew there were some bugs in the game. But that did not stop be from trying this game.

After playing for hours I can only conclude that the game is unplayable because of the many bugs.
I even tried path 1.07 and 1.08, but I could not see any improvement.
I liked playing the game, but I'm very sad that because of the bugs I cannot progress in the game.

The idea and gameplay of this game are awesome.
It's something I miss in the gaming community, there are only a few games like this.
If all the bugs were fixed, this game would match all those before it.

Some bugs I encountered:
- AI stuck in air lock (to fix this restart the game)
- New crew keeps floating in space until they run out of air (restarting the game doesn't help)
- In 1.08 the security teams do not follow orders

Also the events in the game are pretty random, like in FTL.
I choose a location with very low chance of raiders. At one time my base was devastated. Took some time to fix a lot of things. Then 3 raider ships showed up simultaniously, finishing the rest of my base.

I also did not like that most of the crew were not attending their duties.
Instead they chat, exercise, sleep or just idle (maybe a bug).

Because of all of the above, the base is not making much progress. My base usually gets destroyed by raiders.
My crew usually dies because of the suffocation bug or are killed by raiders

Things I miss in the game:
- turn off raiders option
- save slots
- difficulty setting

If you like this game and are trying to find others like it, take a look at these:
- Theme Hospital
- Dungeon Keeper (2)
- Dungeons 2
- Startopia
- Evil Genius
- Space Station Alpha
- Planetbase
- Astrobase Command

If you know a great game that could be on this list, please let me know!

Unfinished broken pile of buggy crap.  Tim Schafer takes kickstarter money and cranks out pure garbage these days, laughing all the way to the bank.

Oh, and on top of all that, it was coded in LUA?  Gimme a break.

Just listen to this jerk try to spin excuses.:

https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2014/09/22/tim-schafer-spacebase-df-9/

"We have stumbled awkwardly through some new territory with this game, and in terms of early access communication we fell short." - Schafer

aka "I've been making games my entire life and somehow I let this project spiral out of control and for the life of me don't know what the hell went wrong because I'm a lazy incompetent douchebag."

column8:
[h1]For the sake of brevity..[/h1]
[list]
[*][b]Genre tags:[/b] Simulation, Base Building, Space, Management 
[*][b]Value Proposition:[/b] dashed dreams, righteous solemnity in fortitude of unfounded hope
[*][b]BSERC[/b] - (Borderline Sardonic and Extremely Reductive Comparison): Garbage version of Startopia
[/list]
[h1]Concomitant Exposition and Summation[/h1]

[b]Spacebase DF-9[/b] is a base building game in space. But it's totally broken.. In fact the very simple realization that its isometric and the workers build on a flat pane IN THE MIDDLE OF SPACE should send chills down your spine. 

Now, I purchased this in early access. So, that's likely where the 11 hours I played came from. Consistently convincing myself that, in time, it would get better, more complete, and overall a product worth purchasing. I say that because this game even after â€œbeing completedâ€ aka abandoned, is actually in a perpetual state of disrepair. Almost at every moment, you'll find yourself saying â€œwow, this game as some neat ideas. I'm looking forward to when they start working on it.â€ Alas, my fellow compatriot.. that day will never come. Everything feels if it was implemented on a whim rather than thought about and made with any intent of it working.. It's almost as if they treated it like a clipboard of various ideas. Relying on the name sake of the developer. Granted, Tim Schafer's renown stems from classics like Grim Fandango published back in the LucasArts days. The adventure genre being his forte. Certainly not simulation base building, even with a comedic twist. 

This game was so poor Double Fine gave away a copy of [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/246070/Hack_n_Slash/]Hack N Slash[/url]. Another extremely mediocre game. Certainly not enough to make up for my lost hope. 

I really enjoyed Psychonauts and Costume Quest so seeing things like this, especially the way it was handled has made me very weary of all things Double Fine. 

[b][i]THE GIST
Never forget what this game could have been. What it [i]should[/i] have been. Double Fine is so sporadic with their games now: If you weren't apprehensive about pre-orders/early access before. Let this stand as a shining example.[/i][/b]

[quote]More here â€” [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/28295405/]Station Argus[/url][/quote]

[i]I recently was having a discussion and this game came up and I decided to write something in a slightly more official capacity to warn of its failings.[/i]

column9:
[h1]Description:[/h1]
A failed early access product that was released unfinished. So, what we have here is a kind of "Sims" in outer space. We choose a location in the galaxy, each with its own set of factors, and set out to build a base and survive. Initially, we have only a few builders and dwindling oxygen, but by constructing objects, we can create conditions for survival. However, problems will never cease: something at the base will constantly run out and break, and the threat from outer space will be knocking on the door every minute. Add to this the stupid AI of the characters, who will make decisions that are not always logical, and sometimes downright absurd. There is no plot in the game, nor is there an end goal... We build, survive, and start over. It's boring to spend time in an unfinished game that is presented as a fully-fledged product. I do not recommend it.

[h1]Rating: 2/10[/h1]

[h1]Afterword:[/h1]
If you liked this review, welcome to the group
http://steamcommunity.com/groups/uojer - here you can see my recommended games, other reviews, and just chat in good company.

column8: Let me state that I believe this to be a great game concept with a good start. However, the game has a high amount of issues for a game released in 2014. Hopeful is the best I can be at this point, the game remains broken, when so many problems are so obvious. Some are visible once you complete the tutorial. Steam has an obligation to the people that buy the Early Access games but they are not holding up their end of the bargain. The game is not complete and no refunds will be honored, so we are stuck with this mess. I will not be paying for any more games released this way and suggest that you all follow my example. A cheap game is still suppose to be a complete game.

column8:
I've played Spacebase DF-9 a fair amount, and I've always enjoyed it for the most part. The problem with this game is that it is FULL of game breaking bugs and half finished features. To top it all off, the devs gave up on it long ago. 

This isn't a finished game. If you buy it, get it super cheap and appreciate it for the kooky game it is, but don't expect a smooth ride.

Abandonware always gets a thumbs down, though I really wish I could give this game a thumbs up.

Alas bought the game during early access (thought well its Double Fine, so it will be safe). But alas they dropped it before it was finished and then "released" it in a non finished state. I write this as I see its on sale via the Double Fine Memorial Sale....keep away.

Seen smaller Devs (some single band), and smaller producers manage early access releases on a much smaller budget and release a fine product. Don't let Double Fines pedegree fool you (although they were not the devs), on this one :(

column8: Unfertig seit Jahren. Gutes Konzept was aber leider nie zu Ende gefÃ¼hrt wurde. Bugs, fehlende Features und nach dem Early Access 2014 einfach als "fertiges" Game auf den Markt zum vergammeln geworfen. Schade, denn das Spiel hat bzw hatte ein echt gutes Potential. Wenn sich nicht doch noch was tut, seh ich schwarz und sag nur "Abandon Ware" dazu.
column9: Unfinished for years. A good concept that was unfortunately never fully realized. Bugs, missing features, and after Early Access in 2014, it was simply dumped on the market as a "finished" game to rot. It's a shame, because the game has, or had, really good potential. If nothing happens, I'm pessimistic and will call it "abandoned ware."

column8: I would for one just like to say i dont understand all the toxicity on this game right now ive played this game long enough to know this game deservs way more credit then it was given yes it does suck that it was abandoned so early and i think thats all people are pissed about i see comments about how the AI is brain dead well ive played long enough to take notice that when your people live together they have conversations together and you can somewhat read how they went if you look into a charecters stats and ive realized that if those same people meet again and they didnt start off to great then they tend to break out into fights more often so i will for one say the AI is not brain dead and this game has enough to work with to be considered more then functional derelict ships pop in and out of my area as time goes by normally i have someone svaenging on that hince my way of surviving if i start to get low on asteroids there is a real feel and sensation to this game, and i feel that those people with 1-2 hours of gameplay dont know what they were talking about the game was probably to hard for them and there brain dead pissed about it. i personally do not run into to many bugs there are bugs yes i wont say this game is perfect like i said it sucks that this game was abandoned because it has so much more potential

column8:
The fact that this game was one of the "Early Access Cons" by PC gamers, should say all you need to know. The developers abandoned development of the game, and there is just a buggy mess. I mean, if you hit escape too many times while trying to close menu's ingame, it'll actually exit the game altogether, losing all your progress since the last (manual) save. It's honestly just frustrating to play, and definitely not enjoyable.

If you really, REALLY, want to buy this game, wait for it to be on special. Anything over 50c is not worth it, in my opinion.

Double Fine is great but this game is a joke at best... you could even call it a scam.
Its not even finished its full of gamebreaking bugs, the AI is braindead and theres just nothing to do after a while (1 or 2 hours). But this game was simply not ready to go out of early access and they released it anyway. possibly because it was not throwing out enough money. Either way. Don't buy this game in any case whatsoever unless you get it for 1$ or below(i'd say its worth that much). Its just bug ridden and does not offer much content. But i do like the concept.

I don't recommend buying this game at all.
It showed a lot of potential, but unfortunately, it was abandoned by the developers.
This is a complete blunder by Double Fine, as they're not just any company in the industry that came here to steal money from customers. I would never have expected this from them.
The game is fun, but it's definitely not worth 10% of what they charge.
=/=
PS: At least I'm glad I got it via the humble bundle. At least the money I gave went to a charity, instead of funding something that would never be finished.

column8:
This game is the reason why some people hate early access.

This game is completely unfinished. It has several bugs and no endgame. It was left for dead on the side of the road by Double Fine. It is still somewhat interesting, and I do play it occasionally. If someone ever decided to make something similar enough, I would probably never play this again. If it's on sale I might consider it but...

Here's the story:
Many years ago (~2014), Double Fine made Spacebase DF-9 available for early access and promised to make it into a complete game. There were many high hopes for the game at the time, but at some point in the development, it was decided to stop development. Double Fine made a tutorial and adding mod support, but then it completely stopped supporting the game in any way. There were some attempts to finish the game with modding, but there was never any large effort to my knowledge. After the developers abandoned it, so did many of the community.

The fact that Double Fine decided to charge full price for this game absolutely shocks me. However, since Microsoft acquired Double Fine, I doubt many people even realize this still exists on Steam.
If you've come here looking for a game, you won't find one. If it's available on sale for extremely cheap, it might be worth picking up, otherwise don't touch this game.

column8:
I will start by saying what there is of the game is good! The graphics, the music, the gameplay it's all good. The problem is that there's so very little of it after Double Fine abandonned it mid-production. This is a dreadul thing because when playing you will probably enjoy what's there. It could have been great if it had been finished.

It baffles me that a company like Double Fine, who have had a sterling record before now, could have done this. Frankly I don't even think there's a good reason for abandonning it since it seems to have been sold better than a lot of other games out there. It's like they were expecting get the biggest selling game of all time and nothing short of that would do.

This kind of behaviour should not be supported and for that reason I cannot recommend this title.

column8:
Spacebase DF9 is a space management simulator where a small pod of astronauts set out to create a new space colony. You have to manage oxygen, food, jobs and the happiness of your intergalactic residents. As you progress, you will need to continue expanding to make space for new residents. The game had the potential to become an enjoyable simulator, but fell short in so many ways. 

PROS: 
The graphics are decent. 
The sound is fitting for the game. 
Most of the astronauts are not human, they are alien, making for more interesting looking characters. 

CONS: 
The game is very repetitive. After only an hour of gameplay, all the messages are the same, all your residents are saying the same things, everyone behaves the same etc. The game is severely lacking in variety. 
The A.I. is brutally stupid. Your colony can die because your mechanic is to depressed to fix the oxygen generators, killing everyone. 
There is quite a limited amount of things to build. Once you build each type of room, all you can do is keep making the same things as more astronauts arrive. No matter what, the gameplay is boring after the first hour or so. 
There is a lot of waiting, even when you speed things up. 
When you encounter problems, there is a fixed solution to deal with them. It gets even more boring and repetitive when you are forced to do the same steps continuously as the game progresses. 

It all comes down to is repetitiveness and a loss of interest. The game could be so much better if there were more scenarios and problems and multiple unique strategies to use. Unfortunately, this game is not worth the price when there are so many better alternatives available.

column8:
I bought this game a few years ago for $30 when it was still in early access. Thirty dollars might as well have been burned. Don't get me wrong, I like this game, and I think it could have been so much more than what it is. 

In terms of gameplay, it's decent. There's lots of options for zoning, wacky randomly generated names, and a unique art style. But it's obvious that the game's been abandoned by double fine. There hasn't been a major update (or even an update at all, correct me if I'm wrong) in who knows how long. 

Then there's balance. When I first played this, I was extremely frustrated with the raiding and pirating system. There was really no correlation between base level and defense systems and the difficulty of any enemies. Seriously, you know no effort has been put into balance when you have 2 entirely unrelated raider boarding parties entering your base when you're barely 10 minutes into the game.

In terms of replay value, I struggle to find any.

In conclusion, I think this game is a bit of a lost cause. It had potential, but it was thwarted by bugs, balance, and lazy devs. It's a shame, really. I recommend taking a look at Prison Architect if you still want a game similar to this, but far more in depth and absolutely worth the price.

Video: (Speed up version of above, coming soon)

Review:
Double Fine has the capacity and the know how to make this game better, but because of the overwhelming amount of bad reviews, they won't be ever coming back to it.  This is unfortunate, because I rather like the game and think it could be improved a lot, especially if I can get ahold of the developers who were tasked with this specific game and give them my detailed unbaised input on things.  Having talked to several other game devs in my time, I've learnt several things about the development scene so I know how to work around certain issues with development to help make a game better.  However, it seems thathis game is abandoned.

In its current state, it "works", but you have to be real lucky to get a good base going and you need to place lots of turrets everywhere and rapidly expand as fast as you possibly can.  I guarentee you're going to lose, a lot.

column8:
"Spacebase DF-9" ist ein Raumstations-Aufbau und Crew-Management Spiel. Und eines, das mitten in der Entwicklung einfach abgebrochen wurde.

Ein richtig spannendes Konzept: eine Raumstation auf- und ausbauen, die aus Humanoiden und Aliens bestehende Crew bei Laune halten, Aufgaben zuweisen, Vorlieben berÃ¼cksichtigen, sie bei Laune halten, Kontakt mit vorbeifliegenden Schiffen herstellen, Verteidigungsanlagen einrichten. Klingt alles sehr spannend, komplex und spaÃŸig.

Der Aufbau beginnt mit dem Planen von RÃ¤umen und GÃ¤ngen. In diese werden dann lebensnotwendige GerÃ¤tschaften wie Generatoren oder Sauerstoffumwandler gesetzt, Betten und Regale fÃ¼r die CrewrÃ¤ume, Luftschleusen, Nahrungsspender, GÃ¤rten oder auch FitnessgerÃ¤te.

Das groÃŸe Problem: dem Game fehlt es nicht nur an Feinschliff, es ist schlichtweg nicht fertig. Bugs sind an der Tagesordnung. Rasch bemerkt man, daÃŸ der Content nicht gerade umfangreich zu nennen ist, das Gameplay wird schnell repetetiv und ermÃ¼dend. 

Schon im Tutorial tauchen absurde Fehler auf. Auch wenn man gefordertes gebaut hat, bleibt die Meldung, die einen zum Bau auffordert, noch vorhanden und das in ganzer Bildschirmbreite: Oder die Crew baut in RaumanzÃ¼gen den Boden eines Raumes fertig und findet dann den Weg zurÃ¼ck in die Luftschleuse nicht mehr. Absurd unfertig, Gamebraker an jeder Ecke, selbst als Alpha wÃ¤re es nicht akzeptabel. Und Double Fine erklÃ¤rt so etwas einfach als fertig und verkauft diesen Gamestumpf immer noch zum ansehnlichen Preis.

Es gibt inzwischen zwar von den Usern erstellte Fixes, die zumindest die Ã¼belsten Fehler beheben, das sollte aber die Aufgabe der Firma sein und bleiben, die dieses unfertige Etwas auf den Markt geworfen hat.

[h1]Wertung:[/h1]
6/10 AtmosphÃ¤re
2/10 Story
6/10 Grafik
5/10 Sound
5/10 Spielmechanik
0/10 Balancing
0/10 Spielspass

[h1]Fazit:[/h1]
Spacewaste Did not Finish-9

[h1][b]DNF/10 Gesamtwertung
column9:
"Spacebase DF-9" is a space station construction and crew management game. And one that was simply canceled mid-development.

A truly exciting concept: building and expanding a space station, keeping the crew, consisting of humanoids and aliens, happy, assigning tasks, taking their preferences into account, maintaining contact with passing ships, and setting up defense systems. It all sounds very exciting, complex, and fun.

The construction begins with the planning of rooms and corridors. Vital equipment such as generators or oxygen converters, beds and shelves for the crew quarters, airlocks, food dispensers, gardens, and even fitness equipment are then placed in these.

The big problem: the game not only lacks polish, it's simply not finished. Bugs are commonplace. You quickly notice that the content isn't exactly extensive, and the gameplay quickly becomes repetitive and tedious.

Even in the tutorial, absurd errors appear. Even after you've built what's required, the message prompting you to build remains, stretching across the entire screen. Or the crew, in spacesuits, finishes building the floor of a room and then can't find their way back to the airlock. Absurdly unfinished, with game breakers everywhere; even as an alpha, it wouldn't be acceptable. And Double Fine simply declares something like this finished and still sells this game stump at a respectable price.

While there are now user-created fixes that at least address the worst bugs, that should be and remain the responsibility of the company that released this unfinished thing.

[h1]Rating:[/h1]
6/10 Atmosphere
2/10 Story
6/10 Graphics
5/10 Sound
5/10 Gameplay
0/10 Balancing
0/10 Fun

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
Spacewaste Did Not Finish - 9

[h1][b]DNF/10 Overall Rating

column8: Its shit

Obviously there is no shortage of hatred on this game. And it is not undeserved by any means. Double Fine betrayed all of the supporters of this game by making many promises, delivering very few, and eventually completely abandoning this game. I've owned it for quite some time, as I purchased it very shortly after it was greenlit. I'm not here to White Knight in any way for the Dev(Double Fine). [b] Screw. Those. Douchebags. [/b] I will never purchase anything from them ever again.

However... There is yet, a glimmer of hope. Now, it's no secret that this game is riddled with bugs, and malfunctioning features. But due to the hard work of a dedicated group of gamers, coders, and modders, an unofficial patch has been released for the game. It fixes -many- of the game-breaking bullsh!t that plagued the game, and even adds some additional features. It's easy to find via the game's forum page, for any who are interested.

So in my opinion, with that patch, the game is worth a try. Don't like it? Refund it. I find it extremely fun, with some very unique mechanics and concepts that I've never seen elsewhere. The promise that this game had was immense. It's very obvious that, before they decided to run away with the cash, the Devs were being extremely creative when making this game.

[b] TL/DR: [/b] The game deserves a shot, as long as you use the unofficial patch.

column8:
Stay away from this game!

I purchased it when it was in Early Access and thought it showed promise.  I would revisit it ever 6 months to a year to see if anything had been updated.  For the first year or so there were updates to mechanics but not many bug fixes.  After that progress started to slow and I held off on playing till they got more of the major playability issues taken care of.  I downloaded it again recently only to find that the developers had put a rush patch out a couple years ago and called the game done.  The game by no means is done.  It is in almost the same state as when I purchased it years and years ago.  Their website and Wiki are the only pages left up as well.  The Blog and Wiki seem to have been deleted entirely which suggests Double Fine are trying to bury this.  The sad thing is they still have my money.

column8: I dont write reviews often, but I feel like I have to with this one. I'm an avid Early Access participant and enjoy supporting games in developement. When I bought this game 3 years ago, I thought I would be participating in helping out won of my former favorite developers Double Fine, the makers of greats such as Psychonauts and Costume Quest. I wanted to love this game when it came out, and it showed alot of promise. But unfortunatly it has been abandoned, and the developers have released games since. I never expected a kick in the balls like this from Double Fine, honestly makes me sad.

Sur le papier, le jeu peut plaire : construction, gestion de ressources, le tout dans l'espace, il y a de quoi Ãªtre demandeur. 
Dans la rÃ©alitÃ©, l'IA du jeu fera tout pour rÃ©veiller en vous un sentiment de frustration constante. Vos citoyens passeront le plus gros de leur temps Ã  tourner en rond, essayer de construire le mÃªme mur jusqu'Ã  la mort, courir dans les flammes... Ils n'ont pour ainsi dire aucune autonomie.  

J'ai jouÃ© aux premiÃ¨res versions du jeu et reprenant le jeu rÃ©cemment, je ne vois aucune diffÃ©rence, aucune nouveautÃ©, aucun bug corrigÃ©... Autant dire aucune Ã©volution entre le dÃ©but et la version soi-disant "finale".

Bref totalement dÃ©Ã§u de ce que Double Fine a fait de ce jeu bien qu'ils nous aient habituÃ© Ã  mieux. Il existe d'autre jeu de gestion plus intÃ©ressant et plus poussÃ© et je vous conseille d'aller voir ailleurs pour ne pas perdre votre temps.
column9:
Spacebase DF-9, a game that never left alpha.

On paper, the game sounds appealing: construction, resource management, all set in space, there's plenty to be excited about.
In reality, the game's AI will do everything it can to stir up a feeling of constant frustration. Your citizens will spend most of their time running around in circles, trying to build the same wall until they die, running into flames... They have virtually no autonomy.

I played the early versions of the game, and having recently picked it up again, I see no difference, no new features, no bug fixes... In other words, no progress between the beginning and the so-called "final" version.

In short, I'm totally disappointed with what Double Fine has done with this game, even though they've accustomed us to better. There are other, more interesting and advanced management games out there, and I recommend looking elsewhere to avoid wasting your time.

Wer hier negative Bewertungen schreibt, kann ich nicht nach vollziehen. Klare Kaufempfehlung
column9: SpaceBse DF9 is a popular space base game. It was discontinued through crowdfunding, but despite that, it's very playable, and it's fun to build your base. There's an unofficial patch, as well as a translation patch for German texts. I can't understand anyone writing negative reviews here. A clear recommendation to buy.

column8:
[h1] Overview [/h1] 

Spacebase DF-9 is a survival game in the wide-reaching void of, you guessed it, space. Your mission is work with a trio of astronauts and build the most sophisticated, comprehensive and long-lasting space station anyone has ever seen. That sounds amazing on paper, and being developed from the veterans over at Double Fine Productions, youâ€™d almost be assured a great game. However, the product falls short and development has long since died for this title, leaving an ugly mess in its wake. In space, nobody can hear you complain.

The game opens up with an interesting concept at first â€“ a map laid out with all the locations in the galaxy, letting you pick where you want to start and factoring in variables like meteor showers, derelict ships, traffic for earning more crew members [good and bad] and resources. Once your base is selected, youâ€™re launched into space with three crew members, a space pod for power and oddly, no spaceship; the game starts you out in the dead of space with limited oxygen, limited supplies and a very short time span before your whole crew perishes from asphyxiation. From a logical standpoint, the start of the game makes absolutely no sense and it only gets worse from there.

You must quickly build a functioning center with enough life support for your crew. Youâ€™ll gather material from nearby asteroids that oddly resemble play-doh, which you will ingeniously craft into oxygen recyclers and stations for power with nothing but a blowtorch and your wits. As the base grows, youâ€™re able to expand, making different rooms that can be retrofitted into housing, laboratories, pubs, infirmaries and more. 

I like the aspect of building a base to my own liking, but Double Fine really chokes the life out of personalizing it as you see fit: limited items to use, each room can only use furniture from one list of items [I.E. only residential furniture in a residence] which forces you to build a lot of unnecessary rooms for no reason at all. However, my biggest complaint is being in space and not being able to build along the Z axis; you can only build outward, not vertically, which seems like a huge oversight since youâ€™re not hindered by the laws of gravity.

As you continue playing, youâ€™ll encounter hazards that you must overcome, such as illness, resource management [marginally], machine repairs, raiders [space pirates] and meteor showers. Most obstacles arenâ€™t all that exciting: meteor showers are not impressive and barely noticeable if the game didnâ€™t tell you it was happening, space pirates have terrible AI capabilities and can easily be killed with a few well-placed defense turrets and most ailments can be cured by simply sending them to the doctor, curing them nearly instantly. Oddly, some of the ailments have auto-cures, such as when I was afflicted with â€œSpace Blindnessâ€, which I was promptly told there was already a cure so I didnâ€™t have to do anything.

The real gem to this travesty is the writing, or the lack of a proper writer. Hereâ€™s an example of the type of â€œcommunicationsâ€ youâ€™ll received while in space:

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=834694128

I felt secondhand embarrassment just reading it. The writing is dreadful, out of place and just downright terrible. Couple that with other gems like my dead astronaut having a â€œkinda happyâ€ job satisfaction while simultaneously being dead, but the real winner is that her location is â€œspaceâ€:

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=834702535

Yes, everything in this game has "space" attached to it. Your location, beds are called "space beds" and even rugs are called "space rugs" because your typical Ikea rug is not suitable for the vacuum of space apparently.

I could go on and on with all the issues with this game, but in the end it has been abandoned completely by Double Fine and is left at the hands of 3rd party modders if they feel like investing their time in such a project. Much like my crew member Nashira Corrino, this game is dead, asphyxiated by its own mediocrity. 

[h1] Pros [/h1] 

[list]
[*] There are none.
[/list]

[h1] Cons [/h1] 

[list] 
[*] The entire game is a con. There are too many to list. The game has been abandoned. Stay away.
[/list]


Overall, Spacebase DF-9 is an absolute mess with broken AI, poor graphics, terrible UI and even worse sound effects. There is literally no reason for you to play this unless youâ€™re punishing yourself and even less reason to buy it unless youâ€™re sending it to someone in hopes of terminating a friendship.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=834694128

I felt secondhand embarrassment just reading it. The writing is dreadful, out of place and just downright terrible. Couple that with other gems like my dead astronaut having a â€œkinda happyâ€ job satisfaction while simultaneously being dead, but the real winner is that her location is â€œspaceâ€:

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=834702535

Yes, everything in this game has "space" attached to it. Your location, beds are called "space beds" and even rugs are called "space rugs" because your typical Ikea rug is not suitable for the vacuum of space apparently.

I could go on and on with all the issues with this game, but in the end it has been abandoned completely by Double Fine and is left at the hands of 3rd party modders if they feel like investing their time in such a project. Much like my crew member Nashira Corrino, this game is dead, asphyxiated by its own mediocrity. 

[h1] Pros [/h1] 

[list]
[*] There are none.
[/list]

[h1] Cons [/h1] 

[list] 
[*] The entire game is a con. There are too many to list. The game has been abandoned. Stay away.
[/list]


Overall, Spacebase DF-9 is an absolute mess with broken AI, poor graphics, terrible UI and even worse sound effects. There is literally no reason for you to play this unless youâ€™re punishing yourself and even less reason to buy it unless youâ€™re sending it to someone in hopes of terminating a friendship.

column8:
[h1]It is very sad to see that authors decided to forfeit further development of the game. [/h1]
[b][u]It is not yet finished and should NOT be considered as a full release. [/u][/b]

It was a [b]good attempt at "[i]space dwarf fortress[/i]"[/b], but I guess as soon as money came in & people who actually care about the product came in, the devs decided that it's time to move on onto another money-making project (that will, most likely, not be finished either).

[b]Do I recommend?[/b]

[list]
[*] [b]if you're a connoisseur[/b] you might get some joy in playing it through. It should last for two evenings, not more. [b][u]I still would consider just checking YouTube videos of the product instead of buying it, as paying developers for their unfinished and abandoned work (in such a disgraceful way) would be a shot in the leg.[/u][/b]

[*] [b]if you're looking for another simulation / survival / base building title but in space (aka [u]dwar fortress in space[/u]) you should consider another title.[/b] This one is bugged and not ready to be played, and will get you (sad / depressed /-r money wasted).
[/list]

Do not waste your money on this developer. Tim Shafer is a bloody twit who cannot manage finances properly, and basically left this game barely even out of alpha, despite being a kickstarted game.

The game literally went from something like Version 0.3 to 1.0 overnight, and then he basically said "We can't afford this, modders can do the rest."

Yeah, let modders make 85% of the game, that's a good way to get the community together, innit? It did get the community together, as nobody supports this game at all, and neither should you throw your money at it.

Buy something else, because even buying a wet fart is worth more than this game.

column8:
DO NOT BUY THIS GAME FOR ANY MONEY. Just read all the reviews others have given it.

This game, given another year in development, could have been good. But the alpha version you get here is really frustrating to play:

- Only one saved game at a time, and auto save only. So if anything goes wrong, that's all your time wasted.

- Quite often when raiding a derelict (which should be a fun thing to do), oxygen levels will drop for no reason and kill all your guys.

- A single raider can easily kill way too many of your experienced guys. Even in areas that are meant to have low threat levels and even when your guys are firing back (and because of AI bugs, sometimes they don't).

- I've not noticed any difference in the threat level of the main map, because I can get raided once in an hour in a high area, and almost once a minute in a low area. It makes no sense and feels like the map rating wasn't connected to anything.

- The AI has serious flaws, the most irritating of which is where your security team WILL JUST STAND there and get killed. Even 10 highly trained guys will stand right next to a raider and let themselves all be killed. There is also a bug where they get confused and refused to enter the base to regain oxygen, eventually dying.

- You can't tell your guys to leave an area, which means that once you own a derelict it becomes a magnate for guys and raiders which is no end of trouble. For instance, When raiders retake a derelict, technicians and doctors will all float over and get killed. I know an emergency switch is used for this, but derelicts don't come with any.

- You can't pan when in the building menu, which means you have to start all over again if the camera isn't perfect.

- You can view oxygen levels, but not power levels, and is seems power units need to be close enough to power things. So you have to guess where power is going.

- Oxygen leaks are impossible to spot sometimes if a ****ing raider blows out a wall that's not in an obvious spot. The O2 overlay needs to show leak spots.

- Sometime when building a new base, oxygen recyclers don't work.

There's enough game here that would be worth checking out if it were free. BUT, because this isn't on early access I can't recommend spending any money on it. There's just WAY too many game breaking flaws that end up ruining your time. 

The fact Double Fine thought it was OK to continue to charge money for such a broken game, and with no plans to fix any of it, they get a BIG F.U from me. Seriously, I would never trust anything from them ever again (especially their kick starters).

column8:
This game gets an 8/10 from me. It's a really relaxing game when taken for what it is. I am reviewing it as version 1.06 Mac OSX no mods installed. I had a free version for months before finding it on steam for 99Â¢ and just had to buy it to encourage the developers just a little bit with my tiny contribution. I would easily pay $5 bucks for it.

You're basically thrown into space, given 3 guys and very little resources to start building your space base. In the beginning you need to start as small as possible, building just the bare necessities. Once you have a small (3x3) airlock room, another room just large enough to hold 3 oxygen recyclers, and a room just large enough for a matter refinery, the rest is a piece of cake.

The game is 90% relaxing, mining and building, welcoming new (weird & silly) inhabitants, and pretty much trying to keep everyone fed, breathing, and happy - or as happy as one can be in a fragile domicile in space. You need to begin early considering how to protect your base from bad guys that pop in periodically, and asteroid impact damages.

Aside from the few (easy) dangers, it's just a relaxing sandbox style building game where you can be creative in making a space base to be proud of. The interface is pretty much well organized, which is an aspect that many games like this get wrong. I enjoy the weird types of characters/aliens and their thoughts and interactions.

Many people complain about the AI being retarded, but you have to pay attention to what each character is good or bad at and by what degree they would suck at a job. You have to assign them to duties they are good at and actually enjoy doing. Some are good at a job, but hate doing it, so yeah, they'll stand around playing games on their pads instead of doing any work, unless you assign them to a duty they enjoy. I find this aspect completely adorable, as it really adds to the immersion and how you feel or care for each individual. I also love the names - imagining how an alien would pronounce his name written as "Uneekly (nicely)" - that sorta thing.

It's currently (for the past several months) been my favorite game for when I just want to relax and make a creative little space base. The few, easy dangers add just enough of that random aspect to keep you on your toes and influence the shape and direction your base takes. Have lots of good tech guys and your base will run smoothly - put lotsa gun turrets all around the outside walls and you'll be safe enough to survive a large attack that eventually happens. And just have fun building and watching how your inhabitants get along.

My only complaint is - once you get a VERY LARGE base, things go bad fast. Machines start failing, catching on fire, destroying themselves everywhere, no matter how many techs you have to fix them. But I guess this is just a sign that I've gone way too far with this base and should just start a new one, haha.

Lotsa people be hatin' on it, but it's been one of my favorite, relaxing games that I keep going back to.

column8: To me, somewhat enjoyable I play it from time to time when I am extremely bored. However there are lots of fustrating issues with it. Prioritization of work is non-existant (ex. running out of air, so I put plans on building more air recyclers, but builders instead were chatting, eating, and sleeping and did not get to it for a LONG time). Combat/action pretty boring and worthless, takes security like 10 shots (mostly missing) to kill a raider. Bugs everywhere. Base location unbalanced (basically, some locations have lots of matter to harvest, or barely anything. Nonstop citizen ships/raiders practically everywhere. Just a few examples). AI pretty pathetic. Basically, a lot more Cons than Pros. I wish that the devs would improve on these issues to make a more enjoyable and exciting game, but it seems that they washed their hands on this product. This could be an amazing game if they get updating and fixing it.

column8:
Look, I love this game, it's very unique, and I'm still giving it a thumbs down, here's why;

1. AI occasionally breaks, leaves the game unplayable
2. Buggy
3. There is only like 20-30 placables from start, and to unlock more you have to research which takes forever, and can be expensive
4. When citizens die they drop stuff on the ground, and that stuff, almost never disappears or is picked up.
5. Devastating to lose everything (Just save A LOT to avoid this.)

So there ya have it. Those are my top five reasons I'm leaving this dislike, I love this game. Love it. It will always have a special place in my heart, BUT unless you're willing to put up with these, like I was,  then this is a no buy. Or if its on sale, its a great buy to play for a couple of hour, but I don't think I'll ever reach 48+ hours on this game.

column8:
Lets see, the first time i loaded up the game i decided to run the tutorial. I was greated by roughly 100 frames of intro (please keep in mind these 100 frames were spread over 20 seconds or so). So i turn my graphics setting all the way down, ditch the second monitor and lower my screen resolution as low and the game allows. Well I can now move fairly unhindered. Go through the tutorial up until I have to fight 10 ish enemies. imediately my frames drop to 10 or so. I have a mid range PC that runs pretty much every game i have in at least a playable fashion (IE ARK and Squad), however this unoptomized POS can barely pull 10 frames?

F**K it, me and some friends already have bought and installed the POS so lets try it out. After about 15 minutes of loading screens were finally into the game, well 3 out of the 4 of us. So another 10 minutes go by while they restart and load into our game. 

Alright lets rock n roll! To be fair the gameplay is pretty decent and it definitely is what i was expecting. That being said there's a solid chance your gonna get dropped from the game mid session, or want to play with some weapons that were in the beta but removed from the actual release for umm idk a reason i guess. The game has so many glitches i can't even recall them all. Our favorite of which is when you interface with a door and afterwards cant use any of your buttons besides movement. This can be solved by running(you know without actually running cause the sprint button doesn't work) over to a door and interacting with it again. Some times it seemed to just happen randomly. Once we were running two auto Cannons and both just happen to get glitched for no apparent reason what so ever. Pretty legit.

All in all not that bad if you enjoy 5 frames, of unoptomized graphics from the 90's, a second while not being able to use your weapons after spending 15-20 minutes of time in loadings screens. But hey its a 40k game!

The emporer protect anyone who buys this.
column9:
Lets see, the first time i loaded up the game i decided to run the tutorial. I was greated by roughly 100 frames of intro (please keep in mind these 100 frames were spread over 20 seconds or so). So i turn my graphics setting all the way down, ditch the second monitor and lower my screen resolution as low and the game allows. Well I can now move fairly unhindered. Go through the tutorial up until I have to fight 10 ish enemies. imediately my frames drop to 10 or so. I have a mid range PC that runs pretty much every game i have in at least a playable fashion (IE ARK and Squad), however this unoptomized POS can barely pull 10 frames?

F**K it, me and some friends already have bought and installed the POS so lets try it out. After about 15 minutes of loading screens were finally into the game, well 3 out of the 4 of us. So another 10 minutes go by while they restart and load into our game. 

Alright lets rock n roll! To be fair the gameplay is pretty decent and it definitely is what i was expecting. That being said there's a solid chance your gonna get dropped from the game mid session, or want to play with some weapons that were in the beta but removed from the actual release for umm idk a reason i guess. The game has so many glitches i can't even recall them all. Our favorite of which is when you interface with a door and afterwards cant use any of your buttons besides movement. This can be solved by running(you know without actually running cause the sprint button doesn't work) over to a door and interacting with it again. Some times it seemed to just happen randomly. Once we were running two auto Cannons and both just happen to get glitched for no apparent reason what so ever. Pretty legit.

All in all not that bad if you enjoy 5 frames, of unoptomized graphics from the 90's, a second while not being able to use your weapons after spending 15-20 minutes of time in loadings screens. But hey its a 40k game!

The emporer protect anyone who buys this.

column8:
I have mix feelings with this game, i really enjoy it, i've spend a lot of time playing it, and I feel that if the devolperers have not abandoned it could turn out to be the best space base management sim ever.... it's too sad it's basically abandonware.

Imagine theme hospital, one of my favorite games as a child, but in a space setting.... you build the base, gather resources from asteroids, set defenses against space pirates.... it's so fun in so many ways. 

BUT.... 

Keep in mind before buying this game, that this is an alpha.... a really good alpha, but the game is never going to be finished, so actually there's no campain missions, no goals, no achievements, and lot of features not in game, the random "encounters" get repetitive after a while....  in the end you'll end with a big well armed base, and nothing to do but let the time fastfoward till the next "event" .... it makes me angry cause the core of the gameplay it's wonderful.

yes there's a "user-made" update, that fix some things, adds a thing or two (like the happy bot) and also adds bugs (example.. update adds the squad mode for your security personel, cool.... game crashed if you disband a squad, not cool), in the end,  still feels like an alpha, so if you think that the user made path will make the game complete... it's not gonna happen. So be wary.

ThatÂ´s really sad because what is done here...  it's done in a beautiful way, so much potential wasted...

And thatÂ´s the risk and problem with Double Fine, on one hand they make wonderful out-of-the-box ideas, games with a lot of charm, funny, different from anything else on the market ... on the other.... they have failed the customer more than once before (Broken Age anyone?)

Ill update this review if the User-made path is updated and the game gets better.

column8:
I like this game, simple, dumb.  It lacks a lot of items, randomized events, and it's most likely when you really need an action taken like saving an incapacitated crew member, or fight back against enemies you are going to lose.  That is pretty much it, three things you have to deal with.  Bad A.I. that are stupid and the events of ships coming and going being either new crew or raiders, that's all.

This is, sort of worth the price but sort of not, since it still plays like alphaware (even fan-patched, you want to do that) If it's on sale like $4.99 (or free/bundled cheap/$1) I think it's worth just a few hours of play if you want a really dumb space simulator that is pretty much rogue-lite if you don't absolutely micro like a mo-fo against any early first 15 minute rage quits.  I followed all the hype and bad blood and finally sitting down with it, (had it for awhile) I really like it.  If there was one thing I'd like added it would be abit more control with your crew, rather then somewhat bad hit/miss pathfinding and que actions. Like at least make one crew promoted to Captain and you at least can do everything on your own seperately and remotely while everyone else just does their business.

Like I said, it's a more unforgiving repetitive rogue-lite experience with either very bland gameplay or very frenetic broken attacks and your crew just being dumb.  It won't be this sim that is easy or, hey build a base with hundreds of items beautiful space life thing.  The gameplay is somewhat vapid, and a bit weak in a few areas but to me it was okay for what it is, regardless of any pie in the sky promises.  I've certainly played far worse games that cost more and games that truly are shovelware/abandonware.  It isn't going to be evil genius, or dwarves, or even rimworld.  It's okay for an unfinished game.  Believe me, there are much much worse out there.  Out of 5 I'd give this game a 3.  Out of 10, I'd give it a 5.  Out of 3 I'd give it a 1.5

You send a guy to a derilict and he dies, go send a builder to vape a few walls and kill everything inside.  You got miners/builders outside about to be attacked, switch to guards.  Use the alarms/beacons.  Put sentry guns everywhere, build air/power and research.  Then build.  That's about it, build another base layout, then another base layout. Most of all, get this game as cheap as possible.  Not more then $4.99 and certainly $1 is a bargain for you to waste an hour or 2 just to see how rediculous your crew will act.  They will leave crew to die on the floor with broken knees no matter how many doctors you have, they will fly around outside and do like one action and return with 7 mins of oxygen.  When the crew does work it makes you happy, when they all leap out the airlock to die like lemmings... well... ya, it pisses you off.

column9:
The game came in a bundle, so I have no complaints, as it was practically free.
The idea of â€‹â€‹creating a small space base and expanding it over time by receiving space travelers is pretty cool.
I understand that the studio didn't finish it and left a lot of people high and dry, but I can say that I had a lot of fun and concluded that the game would have had great potential if it had received the attention it deserved from the developers.
Since it's single-player, it could have had a story, better ways to manage crew stress, warships, and other means of base defense.

column8:
Spacebase DF-9 was broken when I first began to play it...crashing within the first ten minutes. I was bummed out 'cuz it looked like a cool space station builder. THEN...I don't know what happened....maybe an update (maybe the last one), but now it runs reliably and I can't remember the last time it crashed. I have had immense fun with this game. It does have quirks that will be unacceptable to some people, many have been covered by other reviewers. I just, for some reason, really enjoy building building outposts in space and don't take my "crew" too seriously if they asphyxiate themselves because, after awhile, my space stations tend to get big and busy....starting over and rebuilding is what I enjoy about this game. I've not run out of ideas for construction of the ideal station, yet. That's what I like about this game...the building and crew management and watching something I've created actually function...until aliens board, or a new crew member's mental illness comes to the fore with disasterous results! Or someone leaves a door open..yeah, this game reminds me of Planetbase...I get to build things my way, but in the end, a billion miles from nowhere, I can only forestall eventual doom.
I am glad I bought it.
Frankly, I would give Spacebase a 8.5/10 for concept.......umm, I don't know what I would give it for execution, I just know I pick it up when I'm in the mood  for making things in space..."It scratches an itch very well"...7.5/10

column8:
I bought this game on sale, and, I reasonably enjoyed it, but, it has some major problems. The primary of which, a time limit. After a set period you're inundated by enemies that you basically can't recover from, and even if you let them destroy you and try rebuilding, they'll just come back in overwhelming force. I even tried cheating to build, and rebuild quickly, but the game still became unplayable after a certain point.

That being said, and even though I'm giving it a negative recommendation, if mods become available, or it's patched, or it's on sale for cheep, pick it up, it's worth a couple of plays.

column8:
Game is abandonware, so be careful. It is a fairly fun game, but suffers serious balance issues. You will get raided ... CONSTANTLY, no matter what settings you use. Diseases and illness are rampant. Your base will not so much be a colony as it will be a friggin meat grinder. Be sure to have lots of doctors, because it seems they are the only ones qualified enough to pick up corpses and toss them into a trash compactor. 
The AI is so bad I have started to consider it a game mechanic. Eventually your crew will be killed when they all march onto a derelict ship one by one trying to pick up a coffee mug.  Forget reparing or building ... the dudes will drop everything and beeline onto that hostile derelict vessel because they GOT to get that coffee mug. Nothing you do can stop them.

The source code has been released and some guys have created an unofficial patch. I tried it out and uninstalled it after half a game ... their vision for this game was to add more diseases .... a LOT more.  Seriously, if you install the unofficial patch like every other crewmen will spontaneously get a disease.

I still play the game a little, but I wouldn't recommend it to anyone. I got it for like $0.75 in a bundle and still think I overpaid.  Just stay away.

column8: Stay far away from this game. It is totally unfinished and was just named 1.0 to gather a few more sales. It didnt make enough money and thus was abandoned by Double Fine. This is especially "great" after they expressively stated that they are "not some kind of fly-by-night developer" who would just abandon a game in early access. Well this is exactly what they did. The game itself is quite buggy and unfinished. DF relased the sourcecode and just left it up to the fans to fix it. Don't support this kind of behaviour with a purchase!

column8:
If this game was ever finished, it would be fantastic. It promised to fill the StarTopia-shaped hole in my heart that wanted a space station construction/management citybuilder.

Unfortunately, the game has been completely abandoned and will never be finished, and I wish I hadn't spent the money on it in Early Access.

As I write this review, the game is on sale for $0.99. Get it at that price if you feel like it -- I easily got that much entertainment out of it.  But if you do purchase the game, know that it is broken and unfinished and you will eventually get bored or too frustrated to continue.

Given that it is abandonware and really should be on sale at superdiscount ALL the time, or better yet not on sale at all, I can't recommend this game, even though it had a lot of potential.

Broken, unfinished, shallow crap. They went into early access to grab some cash, did virtually no work on the game to develop it then dumped it as "finished" and ran away with the money, Tim Schafer is a scammer with a long track record of financial mismanagement and failure to deliver.

The AI is non functional.
The content can be fully experienced in an hour.
Everything (not exaggerating) is bugged to hell and back.

The most basic of tasks become nightmarish due to the bugs and clunky brokenness of this "game".

Here's how dishonest Tim Schafer (the guy in charge of Doublefine) is - His steam profile listed Spacebase as his favourite Steam game and he had about 1 hour of playtime on it. LOL!
column9:

The content can be fully experienced in an hour.

column9:
A sandbox game is great. But a game where you're only sold the sandbox and promised that the sand would arrive is pointless.
So when, in the end, they tell you, "You'll laugh, but we can't deliver your sand, but look over there, there's a big rock: together, you'll be able to turn it into sand, and it'll be even funnier," you tell yourself that you'll never be fooled again, and you'll never buy a double-fine game again.

column8:
November 2016: Now that the game is not so buggy and it is unoficially supported by the comunity, it is good and I really liked the time I had playing it.

The major problem is the one-unique save-upon-exit (but there is a bypass for it). Permadeath is not a bad idea, since a careful strategist can beat the game and build the 'perfect' base farely easy. BUT the game still has some minor bags (once my 5 guards squad was stuck running on a wall wile 1 intruder was destroying my life support systems, another time the guard with low oxigen in his spaceswit didnt want to follow my waypoint to safty and prefered to suffocate etc). If i had only one save, I would had abandon the game in the obavo acations, writing a rage review.

BUT: I reguraly exit the game and copy-paste the two save files at another folder, so I can paste-overwrite them agan later, to properly handle buggy or annoying situations. That, made the game a really nice experience: A more casual Rimworld type of base building.

I strongly recoment if you go on with SPacebase, to get the unoficial patch 1.08. It adds things in the game and helps for better control of the guards (really useful).

So, I recomment the game, but since the publisher is not supporting it any more and community/freelances do the job instead, I am a bit sceptic about the 10 euro pricing... Check on some gamply videos and comunity feedback, and then deside if you would prefer to wait for a high discount before purchasing this actually good game.

(ps. Rimworld has also still many minor bugs, but the save system is there to make me forget about them...)

Yes, the game is abandoned, but Double Fine was smart enough (?) to make the game's source code available.

column8:
Purchased during Early Access/Beta period as I'm a fan of Double Fine/Tim Schafer and this looked set to be a promising (but not genre-defining) Sims-y colony management game, with a chunky, retro Theme Hospital aesthetic.

I wasn't after a lot, just a bit of a casual management game to pass the time when I'm not in the mood for something with a little more meat on it's bones.

Entertaining to start off, but gets quite boring, quite quickly once you're fully established; resources and food no longer become a problem. It could, at this point; open up into a Sims-style social management game rather than a resource-gathering and base building game, a switch of pace would have been an interesting way to remove the monotony.

However, the devs just up and left the project.

It's nowhere near finished. It's an intro to a game that could have been, an early alpha concept piece.

Avoid like the Space Plague - unless you're planning on making a video on abandoned games or something, as it really ain't worth it.

column8:
Not really much to say on this one.

I picked this game up when it was still in early access, spending what little money I had free to use on video games at the time, excited about all the plans the devs had. What was already there was a solid base game to build on, and I figured with a studio like Double Fine behind it there would be a lot to look forward to.

The joke was on me, I suppose.

Double Fine bailed after they decided the game wasn't as successful as they wanted, and left everyone who supported them with the very beginning of a game and nothing else. What's there may be stable, but there's just no content. I wouldn't even call it a beta; it's not complete enough. It's fun for all of an hour or so at most, and then there's nothing left to do. Starting over doesn't really change anything, either. There's nothing to really do differently, so there's virtually no replay value.

To this day Spacebase DF-9 continues to be one of the most infamous cautionary tales of early access, and for good reason. Not sure I'll be doing any further business with Double Fine either, but only time will tell.

column8:
I can understand completely why this game has such poor reviews. Two years after its release, it remains littered with bugs that devastate its playability. I am reccommending it because for what it costs, I think you're getting your money's worth.

This game is very screwy. You've been sent deep into the galaxy to help seed the remnants of human civilization throughout space after the fall of Earth. You're not alone, you get help from nearby strangers in similar situations. You never get to actually take control of anything though, the people do whatever they want and all you can do it provide some guidance. More often than not, succeeding involves less strategy and skill, but simply getting lucky.

With that said, I've been having fun with it. There isn't a whole lot to the game. I really wish they would finish it, or perhaps publish it open source so we could develope it further, because it has enormous potential to be an exceptionally entertaining experience.

If you get it, you're going to notice a few problems right away. There are almost no settings. I think you can basically turn the sound on or off and that's it. The game's artwork is quite simplistic and usually runs smoothly, but the HUD menues are overloaded with special effects and animations that will make your framerate drop to crap any time they open. Once you've done the tutorial level and are ready to actually play the game, you may spend more time just looking for a decent place on the galaxy map to build your base than the time you spend actually getting to play. The whole game then gets quite confounded by the mood mechanics. While there are things you can do to help people be happier, and I've had lots of happy folks in some of my bases, they all inevitably gravitate towards depression and then stop working and everything goes to crap and the oxygen runs out and they all suffocate.

Once you get to that point, you discover that there is no way to actually loose the game! Even with everyone dead and your base in ruins, you can still get new people on random chance and continue playing, even though they are almost certainly doomed.

The whole game is wacky that way. It makes a whole lot of no sense. But, still, it's fun, somehow. As long as you don't think abut it too hard or take it too seriously, building one base after another while being hounded by pirates and metoeor showers and ocasionally having some suicidal idiot walk out the wrong door and drift away into space can be pleasantly amusing. This is a game you can just relax with and generally expect to fail at every time you play.
