column9:
So, I bought this game in Early Access â€“ it was fun, but I recently decided to give it a serious go, thanks to my vacation. It's a tough game. After nine hours of playing and progressing, a raider got into my base, entered through an unprotected gateway, and wiped out all my equipment and the base. I decided to start over, but this time my villagers were sad, and one guy went berserk. While they were catching him, raiders entered my base through a brand new gateway, where they hadn't yet installed a turret, and I was back to the same ending with half the base wiped out. My experience with "Dwarf Fortress" told me that a base's story always serves as a lulz, so this time I chose a low-threat sector and checked the game's reviews. They were mostly negative, and my review would have been negative if not for my thirst for adventure. One huge downside I noticed was that not everything the developers promised made it into the game, and that made me very sad.
However, the game is a complex base simulator. Why is it complex? It's because it's unfinished! I haven't quite figured out how, other than professions, bars, gyms, and shelves, I can improve people's moods. This is practically the most important thing, since, say, a friend gets killed, and yes, that person gets the "sad" status. Besides a Rooster, there's practically no way to brighten their sadness, and ultimately, it's either raiders or a madman in the base. There's little choice; even parasites are easier to kill than raiders. I'm thinking of trying a couple more times, and this time I'll put turrets on the base so I can continue the game instead of watching someone destroy your base. And did I mention parasites? Here, they can be as big as in the movie Alien, meaning you're nurturing and cherishing a villager, and then a parasite appears!

On the enjoyment scale, this game still earned a positive review from me, although there are many flaws in this game.

I bought this game for many reasons and at first was very excited about what could of been done with it, so i waited, and waited, and waited and much like the buggy AI I asfixiated while waiting for something great to be built... it was a massive disapointment to see a game shapping up and then for the development team to rush out of the 'alpha' stage and straight to a 'release'

So they walked away with my cash, handed out a half finished product and now im left with a worse taste in my mouth than fart cupcake....

Double fine will HAVE to change to attract new customers, but as for me, i trust them as much as i trust a pervy looking balding man sweating in a playground.

column9:
Well, what can one say about this game?
As far as I understand, it's not being publicly developed. However, there are also websites in the community where there are unofficial patches.
A lot of work still needs to be done to get it working properly.

What I mean more specifically is:

The route guidance (my colonists regularly build themselves, take paths I don't understand to airlocks that are far from the target, or stubbornly walk/float to their doom)

The ability to block off areas (this corresponds to the point above). I've lost countless colonists because they thought they had to climb a derelict to collect items. If it isn't cleared of enemies yet, they get shot down. Or so many arrive after a battle that they run out of air, panic, and the airlock stops working. Those were VERY frustrating moments.

Graphical issues caused by flickering and lighting failures made the rooms indistinguishable from their color schemes.

And yet, I spent many hours fending off attacks, examining brain parasites, and growing my station. It's a nice change of pace for an evening, and you should keep an eye on the modders and unofficial developers.

column8:
I bought this game so long ago. It looked promising, giving us barebone functions to make sure we can grasp how the game works, and how stupid the colonists are. I was definitely hoping the game would be published to its fullest potential because, despites its numerous bugs and AI mishaps, it was a fun ride.

But then Double-Fine decided to say "F--- You" to everyone and stopped working on it.

So, basically, here is what you have, in clever bulletpoints:
-Buggy AI akin to the Sims without the instinct for survival. Your colonists could very well die of asphyxiation if you forget to stop them from doing whatever they were doing
-a faction-based territory system that barely works, where you could very well f--- up the enemy base if you just dismantle a wall or a door while they attempt to invade you. This causes strange bugs all around.
-Limited space and resources, you mostly end up relying on the so-called enemy invasions to dismantle their clutter so you can have anything, at a later point in the game.

It's an interesting micromanagement survival game, and a challenging one at that, but it became so buggy and out of control that I couldn't see myself play any longer each session. Plus it seems Double Fine deemed this game a dud, and stopped working on it. Wrong move, guys. Finish your games before calling it quits.

column8:
I picked this game up for 1 euro and you shouldn't ever pay more than that. It's a cute game, but deeply flawed. Using the unofficial patch helps. but I think the flaws in the game go to deep. The developer apparently abondoned the game, which may have been foolish as the die hard fans show there really was a good idea here. 

The AI is horrible for one thing. Trying to keep a base running seems to be impossible. It's not just a matter of planning, you injured citizens will starve and die while your doctor is lifiting waits and complaining about being bored.

You like this genre, pick this up if its on the cheap. It will entertain for a few hours, and for 1 euro that's worth it.

column9:
After more than a year of not playing, this game hasn't changed for the better.
There's still no German translation, so I still find it difficult to distinguish between raider and "benevolent" access points.
To research, you still have to click into the room. So, on the floor in the research room. Instead of using the research tab in the top left, as is usual.

I'm missing a construction priority list; for large construction projects, things are tinkered with here and there.

I'm also still missing an active energy indicator; I don't want to be informed visually when I'm over capacity.

I'll check back in a year to see if anything has improved.

column8:
This game has few minor problems:
#1 There is no game. You know, like goal, quests, storyline, anything!
#2 Unbelievable number of bugs. Tutorial didn't register that I build airlock (characters were going outside ok), at second game I build oxigen "something", but game didn't noticed and still was acting like I had no oxygen (characters were breathing ok), than station was raided and my turret killed some poor raider. All characters were stuck at "panic mode" and didn't return to work.
#3 Idiotic UI that would be completely unbearable for game with any actual content.

I got it for free and i am still feeling it was little bit too pricey.

column8:
Unfortunatly, even with the aid of Derelict Games and the support of many modders this is game does not have the content nor the stability for any mid-late game enjoyment as you will more then likely die, asphyiate, run out of resources or run out of managable space more so from the randomness of the game then your inability to play.

I think my biggest gripe with Spacebase DF-9 is the amount of constant events that pop up that will either give citizens, matter or hostiles and some of these you have no choice but to accept. With these though it runs into the problem of keeping these new citizens alive and happy as your Oxygen Generators can only sustain a certain amount of people and you may only have enough facilities to sustain what you've built for.

The game will constantly try to push you to a higher population cap, it becomes more of a race to keep up then a relaxing experience, even worse the game will punish you if you try to "control" the population by stressing all of your citizens out and pushing them closer to brawling and killing each other. It all tries to reach critical mass and as soon as your last citizen drops it's game over.

column8: Spacebace DF-9 has a very steep learning curve, and tuturial system is barely any help. After restarting worlds more times than I cared to count, I finally got past the initial 8 minutes of oxygen. Now that I've got a start the fun actually starts. Layin out the base and assigning my folks to their duties is straight forward. The interface needs some adjusting, because it's not very intuitive, I was constantly click or hitting the wrong button.

People in the reccommended section will talk about the patch that has been made for this game, and how it fixes many of the problems that the game has. Given that so many people complain about the base game, I'm reviewing the patched version.

Its not great. The UI is clunky, its difficult to figure out what you need to do in the tutorial level to a certain degree. I lost a guy in a derelict spaceship cause one of the survivors stole his space suit.

So sorry mod makers, I'm sure the mod fixes many of the game's problems, but if something is that bad to begin with, you're not gonna be able to fix it that easily.

column8:
BrÃ¼tal Legend was the last good thing that came out of Double Fine's production. And that was 7 years ago.
Space Base DF-9 is not only an abandoned game, but devs won't even apologize for this fuck-up. 
And look what are they after now? A remastered remakes of old quests like Day Of the Tentacle and Grim Fandango. 
Looking at how things are going for Double Fine I wonder if Tim Schafer has anything to to with previous games success at all. Looks like the brain and soul of games we liked was staying in shadow.

column8:
This game has about 1-2 hours of content. Build some items and that's that. 
There is next to nothing to actually build, no progress tree whatsoever and to counter the lack of content they have just increased the rate of events. Raids or aid arrives basically all the damn time and there is nothing to actually do at all beyond building a few turrets so you're immune to raids. Almost nothing to achieve at all, so you will built at least one of each item the game contains within half an hour. 

The research is useless, you will be fed up with the game by the time you have researched two or three items, which you cannot even manufacture, they just "are". 

Complete vaporware, do not touch. It looks fancy and has a lot of potential, but don't spend a penny on this until they've actually made a real game out of it. I've played demos that have more content than this. Hell, sneak peeks have more content than this.

column8:
Everybody's dead, Jim.
My merry crew found a dilapidated space freighter. It was populated with a single Killer Robot. One by one, my crew, of their own accord, walked into the airlock and died, some shooting, others fleeing into the wall, only to find sweet sweet respite amidst the cauterizing laser burns. 

We pause for a moment of silent reverence for oooXiixoo, Jill 034192, and don't forget Jabujo_bujo, the merry miner who hated his job and his friends, who all died too.

RIP

(Trying the patch from the brilliant folks at Derelict Games this week, will update rating accordingly.)

column8:
An abandonware scam, essentially. Double fine stopped work on the game when the money from the initial rush stopped rolling in. Heaven forbid they learn to manage their finances more prudently and move out of ultra-expensive San Francisco offices. Like a financial black hole devouring money vastly out of proportion to the reasonable requirements of a project, it has become apparent that no amount of funding short of a bottomless AAA corporate money pit is too great for Schafer and his gang to squander. No, clearly the better decision is to make bait-and-switch scams like this in between making quirky over-hyped and obscenely over-budgeted hipster adventure games with A-list geek-chic voice talent. 

For me, this is the last double fine title I'll ever spend money on. Not that they'll ever learn with so many other people begging to throw money at Schafer for whatever poorly conceived swindle he's got lined up next. "Remember my Lucasarts adventure games and Psychonauts? Good, now shovel money in my general direction to feed my SF hipster pub crawling habit." As with the pathological liar Molyneux, enough is enough.

An abandonware scam, essentially. Double fine stopped work on the game when the money from the initial rush stopped rolling in. Heaven forbid they learn to manage their finances more prudently and move out of ultra-expensive San Francisco offices. Like a financial black hole devouring money vastly out of proportion to the reasonable requirements of a project, it has become apparent that no amount of funding short of a bottomless AAA corporate money pit is too great for Schafer and his gang to squander. No, clearly the better decision is to make bait-and-switch scams like this in between making quirky over-hyped and obscenely over-budgeted hipster adventure games with A-list geek-chic voice talent. 

For me, this is the last double fine title I'll ever spend money on. Not that they'll ever learn with so many other people begging to throw money at Schafer for whatever poorly conceived swindle he's got lined up next. "Remember my Lucasarts adventure games and Psychonauts? Good, now shovel money in my general direction to feed my SF hipster pub crawling habit." As with the pathological liar Molyneux, enough is enough.

column8: Simply put: there is no intent for the developer to finish this game, given the lack of updates. Definitely one to avoid until this changes.

column8: The chorus of overwhelmingly negative reviews resounds, a clarion call echoing the mismanagement that has left this game languishing in an unfinished state, a mere specter of what it could have been. Abandoned, it sits, a forlorn relic, while the community, undeterred by the shadows of neglect, has taken up the mantle, continuing the work unofficially, breathing life into the remnants of a dream forsaken. In this act of reclamation, the spirit of collaboration shines forth, a testament to the passion of those who refuse to let the embers of potential fade into oblivion.

column8:
Unfinished, buggy, and crew members are too lazy to keep themselves alive. 

Crew would rather work for 1 hour and goof off for the other 23, before complaining about how nothing gets done and how they are "...the only one who does anything..."

Mid-late game is stupid hard. Security is basically zero, and those who you'd think would be good fighters still die extremely easilly. 

Didn I mention this game is unfinished and buggy? I thought it would be going somewhere with the updates, but then the updates stopped, and then did my interest in the game. I haven't played it in a long time, but figured I'd give another warning to anyone who is currently thinking about buying this game. 

If you do, put it in your pile of games to give to someone you don't like.

column8:
I really wanted to like this game, I really did. 
The sci-fi setting and base building mechanics looked promising at first, but after about 10 hours of play time, I can confidently say this game is incredibly disappointing and saddening. 
It had great potential and if the developers had really seized that, it could have turned into something great, I'm sure of it. Instead it turned out to be a shoddy half finished and unstable game. 

Spend your money elsewhere, folks. This is sadly not worth buying.

column8:
I quite loved the potential for this game, but in practise it is horribly disapponting!

My first playthrough went fine, pretty basic management fare but then a raider showed up and I discovered that the 'security' crew assignments I'd made meant people couldn't last two seconds against the lone raider..
Alright then, it was the first go and in tutorial so I can accept an hours play lost and decided to start a new game.

First realisation, there was no "this will erase your data" or "do you want to save" warning. Surprising and not great, but as said, I hadn't planned to anyway so I went ahead with a new real start.

My hopes for the game returned, I enjoyed starting anew and building up the base and this time I had a plan for raiders!
My plan... reassign every crewmen to security and overwhelm in numbers! XD
Not great I know.. but it worked, though highly tiresome to have to remember and reassign everyone back to their old jobs as you can't assign saved positions to default back to.
Then of course, things went bad again...

I find a derelict ship, so badly laid out it could've been a rushed post-battle vessel from Galaxy Truckers.
So of course, I decide to tear everything out as salvage materials.
Unknown to me, one crew decided to remove the ships oxegen generator and then the door of another room from the inside.. leaving him stuck and likely gormless, as there was no notification of him being stuck.

I'll admit a possibly mistake on my part: Not painstakingly watching and assigning each item removed one at a time, but when I tried that previously the crew had a habit of just heading off to bed or returning to my base for a minute to build some shelves I'd requested another builder to build, before coming back.. which is why this time I just left them to it.

Anyway, I found Mr.Gormless and got him to let himself out of the room but before he got any further the oxegen in the ship got too low and it turns out people panic when they realise the oxegen is low (fair enough I'm sure).
Unfortunately, this panic was apparently too much to allow the builder to obey my orders to rebuild an oxegen generator.
Close to frustration I see my second builder heading over in a space suit to save the day..

Unfortunately, Gormlessness is clearly contagious as our superhero stepped out of the airlock, went into a panic himself, rushed back into the airlock and flushed himself into space...

So yea, there you have it. My adventures in Spacebase DF-9. I advise you against having any of your own.

column8:
I'm sure everyone knows this, but I must include it on my review. This game has been abandoned by the developers.

The developers are also expecting modders to finish the game for them...but didn't make a workshop compatability...*facepalm*. Seriously devs? so at the moment, there are very few mods out there and they are scattered all over the internet, and google search is no help. 

However, there is a new mod called "unoffical patch" to fix some bugs and add some features. I recommend you download that mod or be greeted with bugs apocalypse. 

Now lets talk gameplay.

I don't know what they normally call them, settlers? austronaut? pawn? I'll just name it "people".
Unfortunately, you can't move your people, which can be very annoying when raiders are on sight.
You can assign them up to 9 jobs, some people are more skilled on certain job and also enjoy/hate certain job.
The jobs are;
Builder: self explanatory 
Technician: maintain and fixes objects
Miner: self explanatory
Security: shoot hostile enemy, and follow security beacon that you can set.
Bartender: Tends the bar which increase happiness.
Botanist: tends the garden.
Scientist: Make researches to unlock things.
Doctor: Heal and cure diseases/illness
Janitor: Clean corpses
Unassigned: default

People have needs, and they can go up and down shown on a graph. I don't know what most of these does to the person.
Duty, Social, Morale, Stuff, Energy, Hunger, Fun. Those are the 7 needs of a person.

People also have "thoughts" that you can read. Some of them are about friends and enemy they made, an object they built, or even a certain doom they are about to encounter. Thoughts really define them and I enjoy pausing the game and reading them. 
They also have a nice hand drawn avatar so you know what they look like and perks, if they have low self esteem or they are anxious, etc.

Each person really is different from the rest and it's amazing how much detail they have. It's ashamed this game is abandoned.

Now let's talk about building.
There are 13 rooms you can build, and they are;
Airlock: In and out of the space station
Life Support: For placing Oxygen machine 
Reactor: for powering the entire space station
Refinery: smelting rocks into matter (money)
Residence: Build beds to increase population limit
Pub: increase happiness
Garden: Grow food
Fitness: gym
Research: build research table for scientist
Infirmary: Hospital
Brig: prison
Command: Threat monitoring
Unzoned: plain old room 
Each of these rooms have certain objects that can only be placed on that room. All objects (and wall/floor) cost matter to build.
Matter can be obtained by mining rocks and smelting it on a refinery machine. 

To build a room, you need to inclosed it with walls and floors. If a wall or a floor is destroyed, and a person is in that room, they will be sucked into the vacume of space and die.
Walls/floors and objects can be destroyed from astroids and raiders. 

There are random encounter in the game.
There are people that you can communicate with that randomly pops up (when they are near you).
If you respond to their message, then you can either gain a person or be targeted by raiders.
This is the risk you need to think about before accepting their calls.
There are also an actual spaceship that shows in your game. You can either send your security (via security beacon) or leave it alone until it leaves the game. 

Spacebase DF9 had potentials, but its been abandon before it can even fly. I really wish someone would make a similar game. SOMEONE PLEASE! 

That being said, would I recommend this game? Not on full price. Buy this game when it's 90% on sale.

column8:
First up, I will say that I have personally enjoyed playing it overall, despite the many gripes I have. However, the sheer quantity of gripes means I simply cannot in good conscience recommend the game to others.

To put it simply, the game is really, really hard, because the AI is awful and the game hardly gives you a chance to recover from one raider attack to the next. I literally end up with 10s of bodies littered around the inside and outside of the space-station because the medical staff (who are supposed to clean these bodies up) do so at a slower rate than new bodies are generated. Your station crew love attacking eachother due to unhappiness, with no obvious way of resolving their unhappiness. Your non-security personnel love to run directly into the line of fire of the raider boarding party, whilst your actual security personnel will slowly amble over from the other end of the base, even though you put down a beacon more than 30 seconds ago. 

However, the fact the game is hard due to the rubbish AI is, I think, what makes me enjoy it. I can build a successful space-station despite the crew being my worst enemy.

The game also, in general, feels unfinished - which is probably not surprising because, despite what Double Fine Productions may tell you, it simply isn't. They basically cancelled the game and released a Version "1.0" which did tidy up some loose ends but by no means all of them, nor did it add any sorely-needed late-game content.

I can see what they say , their friends, enemies, what kind of music they like and their food. You can see them arguing, chatting exercising, and see their dialogues. They seem to me â€œrealâ€ people 
Several types of:  
	 rooms (restrooms, infirmary, research, airlock etc) 
	items to put inside (beds, closets, shelfs etc etc ) 
	races
	events that makes you smile and wonder what could happen ifâ€¦.

           .- Anna invited me open the door!...
 
	    .-Hey We dont have any  Anna!!

All that offers a wide variety of gameplay.  and replay value.
It seems developer used too much money and time to make it work and profit was not good. so he decided to release the code for this game so someone could improve and patch it if they like to do it)
It seems he loved so much his game that he made some  poor financial decisions and have to abandon it at the end, not without any pain.(like a divorce of someone you love so much but that is unsustainable and it is better to set it free.) 
This game is a treasure and there are some new unofficial patches that fix some gameplay balance issues but the game works well and I will be testing it this days.  Having the code of this game on my hands seems like a real treasure for someone with coding abilities or someone who wants to learn.( Many thing done on LUA so they are very easy to change.)

http://spacebasehub.net/ for patches, and see the development roadmap and the team that is developing this game. it is not an abandoned game. there is a new patch I will test it...

column8:
Dissapointing....  Back when the game was in early development I fell victim to its "appeal".  I saw a game with potential and I was all and all hopeful.  In those ealier days the game was riddled with bugs and glitches, and when I found out they were dropping the game and rushing development, I was hopeful they would eliminate those bugs and glitches in the game.  So as a review of the official release of version 1.06 here is the breakdown.  I'll have a simple review and more in depth... or in this game... anger driven review...

----- Simple ----

The game is crap... It had so much potential but since it got the axe and a speedy release... it has so many issues.  I honestly tried to play the game again... but yet I wasn't able to play longer than 10 minues.  I would not recommend this game to anybody unless it's less than a dollar or given to you free.  It's buggy... rough to control, and just honestly crap.

----- Angered Version -----

Graphics:
As this is not a "Highly graphical" game I wouls say they are acceptable.  The sprites perform actions that is befiting, and nothing to standoutish.  However in aspect of gameplay the "isometric" angle makes the game difficult to know exactly what is going on.  In the typical fashion the walls disappear in a way to allow you to see in the rooms, however being able to roatate the camera would be nice.

Gameplay:
This is where the game loses me.  Although the controls aren't "hard" they are difficult in there own way.  I've played many builder games, and most games play similarily with minor adjustments to the controls.  In more recent terms since the era of shooter games almost every game depends upon the W-A-S-D model.  This game doesn't stray too far fram that idea and it feels comfortable... at least until you start building.  At that point the game takes a turn for the worst.  Edge scrolling doesn't feel like it's in existence, so your dependant upon the WASD model, but once you open the construction menu, foul language fills the mouth as when you click with your mouse to select the item and press "D" to move your contruction item changes.  As soon as that construction menu comes up the game shifts from a comfortable WASD model to a point and click model.  This wouldn't be a problem if they didn't establish you could use the WASD in the first place....   So that is annoying.  Then it gets worse.  As you play you decide to speed up the game, and most games using some button near the WASD (tab, 123, something) changes the game speed, but in comes the mouse model, and you have to click the speed options.  Now I wouldn't have an issue with this, if it wasn't for the fact that when any ship arrived or any notification appears the game switches back to speed 1.... and DOES NOT RETURN.....I find it quite annoying because I'll be in the middle of waiting for my characters to build a room... then all the sudden a message... then the question, "Why are my guys moving so slow"... then oh gotta click that speed... then the game goes NOPE... and another message.  It just continually pesteres you until you get so angry that you give up.

AI:
I don't normally judge AI as it's always an issue with all games.  It is always about finding that right balance between what the computer needs to process and what the character prioritizes.... unfortunately it appears that this game said, "F*$k it... have the guys do whatever."  And like loyal programs they do whatever.  You have absolutely no control over the individual character, so when your trying to finish that bed... your have to wait until the game decides... "know what I think I should build that bed."  But at that point your characters are now falling over because they are so tired... that they have no energy... then get depressed and not want to work... so now that bed will never get done.... it annoying the bleeping crap out of me as I was just trying to enjoy the game.

Glitches and Bugs:
Yes I'm bringing it up... as a "fully" released game you would expect most of the bugs and glitches to be taken care of... in fact thats what most of the follow up forums established... but know what.... turns out that your characters get stuck (dumb AI) and because you can't do that they sufficate.... yeah... so just started finished the basic build... airlock... air... and such... but oh no... two of my guys just sat there... doing... NOTHING... could it be AI? probably... but to me that's a bug.   But it's not the worst oh no... in my honest to goodness no opinion try I got "invaded" another ship attached itself to me, and I was assulted.  After killing the AI I noticed, Hey there is a gun outside...  Then I slowly watched one of my security guards go out to take care of it.... two shots later dead.... ok..... so what does the AI do?  "Well he's dead... probably should take care of that... but naa...."  Guess where my miners had to go to get resources?  Right in the line of fire.... so there goes two of my miners...  Well maybe I can control a security... oh wait can't control the guys so whoops... maybe set a security point for them.... nope... dead... dead and dead.....  I'm happy they incorperated the guns for defences... but when a gun is established as enemy and even if you took over everything it appears that that guns still acts hostile....  My frustrations knows no bounds.

Overall the game is fine.... just fine.... not great... not good... just fine.... if you want something new to distract you for 10 minutes... here is the perfect game for you... but don't buy unless it's on uber sale.... and by uber sale like... I dunno $0.99 per copy... or heck maybe if the company pays you to play... becuase honestly this game isn't worth anything more.

column8:
Is this still abandoned? Yes.
Have I bought any Double Fine games since? No.

Pros: The artwork is pretty okay. It had strong potential as a base-building game. Uh... The price hasn't gone up or anything? I guess that's a pro, but maybe the reverse should be a con instead.

Cons: A whole lot of other stuff. Paid for but never delivered. You might even say that there's a certain "artistry" to the cons, if you take my meaning. I mean, you "might say that," although I would never say that, lest someone take it for slander. No, sir.

Don't buy this. Even if it's your mission to own every Steam game, just skip it.

column8:
[h1] I want to rate this game well I really do but I simply can't at the moment [/h1] 
I have had it before where I have made a great base and all has ended well and that feels great but its getting to that point that makes me want to scream in frustration. The AI in this game to put it simply is suicidal. In my latest playthrough a raider has calmly floated outside my base and shot my miners. I think wait I put a beacon on him why did my security force do nothing? They got stuck in the airlock. They were in there so long I had to build a second airlock in order to save a small building team I had working outside. On numerous occasions I have had builders who were working on unfinished rooms in space simply take off their space suit and die from a lack of oxygen. Normally in a game like this I think well its an early access game give it the benefit of the doubt it will be fixed it may even turn out to be as good a prison architect [i] 'Double Fine Productions is releasing a final version of Spacebase DF-9 next month, the studio announced last week. The decision brings an end to the studio's plan to continuously expand the game over a few years' [/i]Yep the devs at Double Fine abandoned it. The concept seems really cool to me its just so frustrating I can't recommend it

This game was utterly a complete disappointment. Had they just continued updating and working on the game, I'm sure I would have eventually recommended this game but alas, this company took our money and said fuck you. But that is the gamble we all take with early-access games, you pay for an incomplete version of the game with no guarentee that they finish it. This game had potential, this game had promise...but this game did not have a good developer.

I would not recommend buying this game nor any game from this company.

column9:
To make sure our adorable little Frenchies don't waste their money buying this game (the term "game" is quite far from reality), I'm taking the trouble to write this review to warn you:

This product isn't finished, never will be, and the current content is clearly not enough to want to play it even if it were free (which it isn't).

The bugs are numerous, and the AI â€‹â€‹(let's include everything related to NPC behavior) borders on the appalling, spoiling the little content available.

The forums are also heavily censored; there's no point wasting your time reading what's there.

TL;DR: move on.

Playtime: An hour or two, if it doesn't bug out.
Gameplay: 4 / 10
Graphics: 5 / 10
Overall: 1 / 10

Spacebase DF-9 held such promise, but with continued bugs after release and a sudden abandonment from the devs, I can only conclude this is one of the reasons Steam added the "recent" reviews section. I seem to have more playtime than most, because this was exactly my kind of game, but now I have not played it in months.

A purchase that left a bad taste for future pre-releases.

The game had great potential. Much had been accomplished, but much was missing. In fact, the previous review was positive. But at some point, the studio simply said, "We don't have the money to develop the project," called what was the "Final Version," and ended support for the project.
In essence, it's a beta version of a game that will never be released.

column8:
The game has a cool concept but it simply is not a complete game, it has been abandoned by its creators and left it to rot in the corner.

A group of moders took on the games source code and improved it, but even with their 1.08 version is buggy as hell and just makes the game not fun. The AI and pathing really suck, making you frustrated as you try and make your people do things.

My advice skip this, and look for a better space station building sim.

column8:
SDF9 is not very amazing at all. In the past I've held Double Fine in somewhat of a high regard, but this game just isn't very good at all, for a multitude of reasons.

Namely, it is unfinished. It is abandonware. And yet DF have the gall to keep selling it. On top of this, there are people making mods in order to fix the game. This should not be necessary, and sends red flags from the get go.

Playing some of the game you immediately see that it has a very unfinished feel:

The controls are rather clunky, and there are quite a few problems with the graphics. I can't find out how to rotate the display, which means [as it's in an isometric view], lots of stuff are hidden and can't be easily accessed. Many of the elements end up 'overlaying' themselves on each other, evidence of problems in the graphics engine itself.

The gameplay is rather boring, frankly, and the game lacks flow. You're just dropped in without any real explanation of what the point is. Every now an then a passer by might interact with you with some, well, 'odd' dialogue is probably the nicest way to put it.

The sound design in this game is probably the best part, honestly. It has some nice background music.

Just to TL;DR, Don't buy it, its a shambles.

column8:
My review will look similar to what most other people have probably written, but at any rate the developers for this do not deserve your money.

I bought the game when it was still in Early Access. It had some cool functions to it, was fairly simple, and felt almost like a simplified, more accessible Dwarf Fortress in space. I wasn't too concerned with the lack of available features or amount of glitches, as most of what I wanted was to be released anyway through updates leading up to the final release.

Well, as you probably already know, the developers essentially shredded up their list of short/medium/long term goals in one night, and suddenly the game "went gold". 

It was a very disappointing turn of events, to see a title with such promise basically wind up as a hollow shell of what it could have been (and should have been, based on what was promised the gamer base by the makers of the game originally). 

Basically, don't waste your money - you'll get maybe a couple short, bugged-out playthroughs of the game but it's just lacking any amount of depth to really get you playing up to even half your money's worth.

column8:
Started playing this game, having startopia and other similar games in mindâ€¦ it could have been a great game but it somehow misses the motivational part. If you enjoy building something next to an angry toddler who destroys all your work randomlyâ€¦ then this mightbe a game for you. I've played it some hours now and found it quite frustrating. Even in the supposedly easier parts of the galaxy you can barely construct a base, at one point the game starts to throws masive waves of raiders - way more than the population of your base - against you. Just after you barely survived a couple of killerbots arrive. This might be something to handle and to enjoy if the games worked as intended. But you only have one "security" beacon (but probably about 6 differend intrusin locations) and if you are lucky the citizens respect the emergency alarms and the security comes to the beacon. one by one. to get slaughtered. But about half of the time they don't do anything when they arrive at the beacon. There are construction bugs and fire extinguishing things as well.
After all, it is hard to actually have fun playing this game.

column8:
It's been ages since the last update, and it seems that the developers have effectively abandone their game mid-development with no promise of refunds. If you do decide to buy this game, be wary you will have to rely on modders for bug fixes, content, etc. The developers are no longer working on this game.

To be fair, the game was fairly fun (if you ignore the bugs, lack of content, etc.) and had great potential, but when it became clear that the developers didn't want to work on the game anymore, it kinda broke my heart. Ages later, they still aren't working on the game, and there is no way to get a refund. We have to rely on modders to finish the game, instead.

column8:
Actually i was contemplating whether to give this a yes or a no, simply because.. it's just a normal game.
I bought this as a bundle with Hack 'n' Slash, which is on a discount which makes me only spending less than 1 cent for this game.

This game started as a good game, with a great concept and all, about building your own spacebase. You have no limitations, and there are a lot of things to construct while keeping balance with residents' needs. However, this game is very confusing at a start, with so few tutorial (and it has a more detailed, although still not cover most of it, in a separate section on the main menu, which makes it worse). The actual game is actually like an endless mode, which give you everything you need to build at the start and a few resident to start with.

Honestly, i hardly can come up with a good and a bad aspect with this game. This game is actually an okay game if you have understand on how to play it, but there isn't anything appealing to it. There are some "goals" to be accomplished, but i don't really think it's that important, or maybe the game doesn't really show it as important.

Pros:
- Lots of items and room variations to build
- You can assign your resident to do various jobs and raise their experience

Cons:
- Assigning a bed to each person one by one can be very tiring, especially if you have a lot of residents.
- No "undo" button after doing a construction "blueprint"
- No rotate button

Should you buy this game?
If you like this type of game, this game can be very cheap when it's on sale, which is good. But if you don't, just skip it.

However, this game is very confusing at a start, with so few tutorial (and it has a more detailed, although still not cover most of it, in a separate section on the main menu, which makes it worse). The actual game is actually like an endless mode, which give you everything you need to build at the start and a few resident to start with.

Honestly, i hardly can come up with a good and a bad aspect with this game. This game is actually an okay game if you have understand on how to play it, but there isn't anything appealing to it. There are some "goals" to be accomplished, but i don't really think it's that important, or maybe the game doesn't really show it as important.

Pros:
- Lots of items and room variations to build
- You can assign your resident to do various jobs and raise their experience

Cons:
- Assigning a bed to each person one by one can be very tiring, especially if you have a lot of residents.
- No "undo" button after doing a construction "blueprint"
- No rotate button

Should you buy this game?
If you like this type of game, this game can be very cheap when it's on sale, which is good. But if you don't, just skip it.

A game that has been abandoned by it's devs very early into development and in a completely unfinished state. It severely lacks content and has some major UI and pathing issues. While it likely had much potential, it's 'absolutely not worth it in it's final version, not even on sale.


If you like the genre, take a look at planetbase instead.

Okay, yes, the game in its base state is awful and buggy and unplayable and Doublefine did a terrible thing ragequitting from it.

HOWEVER. Now there is an unofficial patch that is really making this game worth the money. It's damn glorious too, and they're still working on it. It rarely crashes, and there are few glitches. Yes your citizens are still...kiiind of stupid but you tend to expect that in a basebuilder game.

Seriously, if you love basebuilders, look no further than this.

Just get the unofficial patch once you do. I'll link it here.
http://spacebasehub.net/

*BUYER BEWARE*

Game has been abandoned before many of the promised mechanics/components of the game were included. Developers claim the budget for the game ran out. column9: I bought the game back in 2014. It had great potential, to say the least. Incidentally, for those who don't know, DF is a reference to Dwarf Fortress. It was fascinating to imagine what the game would become in the future. Ultimately, the game is still unfinished. It's yet another product, of which there are countless now, that has "sold" those (myself included) who bought it in the alpha stage. Let me speculate a bit, if you'll allow me. The fact is, the gaming industry doesn't allow for the full range of genres it once did. It's hard to imagine a submarine simulator, for example, being commercially successful. Game production is becoming increasingly expensive, so it makes sense to release only CoD every yearâ€”a product aimed at the largest possible player base. And then, of course, keep enticing players with paid DLC. That's why we have what we have. That's why players grab interesting games, even if they're still in development, hoping for the best. Verdict: don't buy them under any circumstances.

column8:
This one's a little tough, because I really wanted to like this game. I'm a fan of survival games and sims (both with and without capital-S). Spacebase DF9 has a nice idea and a rather decent realisation. The gameplay is all right, and the design, particularly of the inhabitants of the space station, is pretty cool. BUT. The game has been abandoned by the devs and currently relies on community patches to work. Don't expect any fixes for the bugs that are still in the game.

What is there is the groundwork for the Sims in space. Sort of. You're starting out with three astronauts and a small amount of resources, just enough to build a closed space to shelter your little aliens from, well, actual space. From there, you mine resources, add to your space station room by room, and slowly develop a complex microcosmos that has you manage life-sustaining installations like reactors and oxygen generators, necessities like food dispensers, a medical bay and bedrooms, and luxuries like a bar and a fitness room. Additional challenges include raids and abandoned drifting space stations to discover and loot to your heart's content.

But that's where the content ends. It's a very bare-bones game that gets repetitive fast. The AI is borderline stupid as soon as something goes wrong, with people running around screaming at the tiniest fire instead of using the extinguishers and subsequently letting the entire station burn, others starving to death because the food dispenser was too far away (in the next room), and the doctor preferring to eat five times in a row at said food dispenser instead of incinerating the bodies of those who died in the last pirate raid - who have only died because security idled at the opposite end of the station until I specifically directed them to fight the raiders. You have to micromanage everything, because you can't trust the AI. Even after you assign jobs to people, they will sometimes refuse to do them, even if it's their preferred occupation. Security officers will not intervene unless you tell them to, and then one at a time, getting killed by absurdly overpowered raiders.
Who will always show up as soon as your station hits a certain number of people (ridiculously low, six, if I remember right), and will start out super-strong. Contrary to what the "map" selection suggests, there is no way to adjust the difficulty unless you change the game files manually, and even then it often doesn't work. The area of space that you pick has no tangible impact on how hard the game is; the number of raiders and meteor strikes seems consistent across the board, the only thing that changes is how often empty stations drift by yours.
It's crazy hard to survive after hitting the threshold after which raiders spawn, and borderline impossible once you've reached ten and higher because the game keeps spawning higher and higher numbers of enemies, forcing you to assign around half of your inhabitants to security. That, in turn, prevents you from playing a lot of the other features, like botany, which you need for the bar, or science, which you need for almost all upgrades. The balance is shoddy, and Double Fine did not bother to fix it, instead abandoning the game.
Fans have stepped in and created one (to my knowledge, so far) patch to fix a few of these bugs, but there is no guarantee it'll work with your game. And it shouldn't have to, if DF didn't stop working on games once it becomes too much work. It seems like the game didn't sell as many copies as they anticipated, and they decided it wasn't worth the effort, instead starting another crowdfunding campaign for a new game. That looks like a really shady business practice, like you'd find on the seedier side of Greenlight and Early Access, and one I can't support.

Shame. This would have been a fun space sim, but as it is, I can't recommend it.

Security officers will not intervene unless you tell them to, and then one at a time, getting killed by absurdly overpowered raiders.
Who will always show up as soon as your station hits a certain number of people (ridiculously low, six, if I remember right), and will start out super-strong. Contrary to what the "map" selection suggests, there is no way to adjust the difficulty unless you change the game files manually, and even then it often doesn't work. The area of space that you pick has no tangible impact on how hard the game is; the number of raiders and meteor strikes seems consistent across the board, the only thing that changes is how often empty stations drift by yours.
It's crazy hard to survive after hitting the threshold after which raiders spawn, and borderline impossible once you've reached ten and higher because the game keeps spawning higher and higher numbers of enemies, forcing you to assign around half of your inhabitants to security. That, in turn, prevents you from playing a lot of the other features, like botany, which you need for the bar, or science, which you need for almost all upgrades. The balance is shoddy, and Double Fine did not bother to fix it, instead abandoning the game.
Fans have stepped in and created one (to my knowledge, so far) patch to fix a few of these bugs, but there is no guarantee it'll work with your game. And it shouldn't have to, if DF didn't stop working on games once it becomes too much work. It seems like the game didn't sell as many copies as they anticipated, and they decided it wasn't worth the effort, instead starting another crowdfunding campaign for a new game. That looks like a really shady business practice, like you'd find on the seedier side of Greenlight and Early Access, and one I can't support.

Shame. This would have been a fun space sim, but as it is, I can't recommend it.

column9: Spacebase DF-9 is a rare case where the game was better in the early stages of development. Each new patch added unfinished elements that were promised but ultimately remained unfinished. The end result is a playable product, but barely. I spent all 27.5 hours playing the older versions. I could have recommended the game back then; it was engaging and challenging enough to keep you busy for multiple playthroughs. Now, I don't recommend it.

column8:
Honestly I love this game From the building to the micromanigning people and there needs fears and likes.

I think the feel of the game is a combination of age of empires in space + sims aspects, the reason why I say this is becasue  the building and advancing feels a bit like age of empires 2 but with aspects of sims.
As in the people have there own will and do and act to there will as much as you're commands and you need to micromanage the jobs and flow of mass and keep building to acomadate all these people.

I find this game quite challanging because of the constant fear of raiders diseases and parasite's oooh those damn bastards.
this will always keep you on you're toes and usually I try to keep the starting 3 people alive as long a posible and get a like and dislike in people and try to make them happy and thats challaging to keep them happy and alive with all those treaths.

The building is also quite fun becasue you can basicly do wathever you want how you want it and it's always a good plan to build efficient and smart to ensure safty and easy access to you're rooms wich is also essential.

Even tho the developer gave up on it people that liked the game just like me starded to update it !
unofficial but they are improving the game nothing the less and working on it making it better and doing a great job on it. shout out to them amazing job people keep it up !

my final Judgment The game is great if you like a age of empire in space with a personal toch I rate 8/10.
Becasue the atmosphere freedom in building, managing all you're people and the sound track is great and I like it.
you can play it alot and not get tired of it atleast I can haha.

I will keep playing it because I find a lot enjoyment in this game but thats just my opinion.

column9:
A game about building and managing a space colony.
To what end? There's no such goal whatsoever.
As it stands, it's nothing more than a sandbox with no story or anything.

All you do is gather resources from nearby asteroids, prepare for the occasional pirate attack, and endure the rain of debris.

And even after just a little play, there are obvious glitches.
The reviews are full of complaints that the developers abandoned development midway, which is quite a problem.

But as the saying goes, "where there's a dev, there's a pick-up," and volunteers are continuing to update (see the community hub), and it seems to be working properly now.
There are still many features that need to be implemented, but this is very much appreciated.

The game's basic concept is well-thought-out, so if it were on sale at a significant discount, you might not be disappointed, but honestly, there's no reason to buy it now.

column8:
Being a fan of the old â€œTycoonâ€ games and â€œTheme Hospitalâ€ I was really excited about Space Base DF-9. I thought for sure reviewers were being too hard on it, so as soon as I saw it pop up in a Humble Bundle I was ecstaticâ€¦ But, all of my excitement was for naught. Almost 6 hours wasted and I can pretty well guarantee I will never touch this title again.

[b][u]TL;DR [/u][/b]
There is a ton of promise here. When the game is running smooth thereâ€™s not a lot to complain about (except maybe lack of construction options), but eventually that smooth ride will be over and youâ€™ll realize nothing works like it should, if at all. So while playable youâ€™ll hit a point where the effort to advance isnâ€™t worth it. If you still think you want to punish yourself by playing this game make sure you check out http://www.spacebasehub.net/ for the unofficial patch, the mechanics are still broken but everything else has been improved.

[b][u]In-depth Review[/u][/b]
[b]Overall Gameplay: [/b]
The basic construction and management section of the game is fairly well done. Itâ€™s very similar to â€œTheme Hospitalâ€, but with a slightly improved interface. Thatâ€™s where the positives end. So many things are broken that it becomes unnecessarily difficult, and not in a fun, challenging way but in a â€œoh thereâ€™s another thing that doesnâ€™t work rightâ€ kind of way. 
Here are just a few examples of things youâ€™ll see characters do:
- Die of suffocation despite being surrounded by rooms with oxygen and having access to an airlock with space suits, 
- Become incapacitated (not dead, just lying around uselessly) indefinitely. If theyâ€™re Raiders they actually might be back up and start killing people!
- Be marked for the brig or infirmary but never go there
- Scientists not researching (despite being assigned research and having a research station).
- Ignore the 3 fire extinguishers near the fire, and instead stomp on it until they catch on fire, then run around the base being ignored by everyone else until they burn to deathâ€¦ Actually that mightâ€™ve been the most entertaining part of the game!

[b]Presentation:[/b] 
The user interface is easy to navigate but overly simple. You only have 1 save slot and the game auto saves by default, so if youâ€™re not careful itâ€™s quite easy to erase a save game by clicking on the wrong thing and not exiting before it overwrites your game.

The graphics are fine. Theyâ€™re quite obviously a throwback to â€œTheme Hospitalâ€ (how many times can I name dop?). It works well for the genre, and theyâ€™re fairly sharp. 

The sound is outright boring, the music is nothing impressive and off the top of my head I honestly donâ€™t remember any sounds other than that and the chirping alarm if you zoom in far enough.


[b][u]Summary:[/u][/b]
This game could be so good, but as in so many cases now it looks like the developer took their money and ran. In my love/hate relationship with Early Access this is why the hate portion exists. Iâ€™d give it a 3/10, itâ€™s playable and as long as things work right itâ€™s quite enjoyable, but the unpredictable and frustrating broken mechanics make it another EA Trash title. Pick it up in a bundle with some good games or for $1 or less and get a couple hours of funâ€¦ But DO NOT, under any circumstances pay any more for it than that. Especially when you could get the vastly superior Theme Hospital and forget this all together.

column8: Despite all the negative comments and outcries over double fine not finishing this game and abandoning it even without any mods installed i actually REALLY enjoy this game and can spend hour upon hour fine tuneing my base and colonists. i don't understand why people think this is so unplayable, it's actually VERY playable once you figure out how everything works, the Big "ending" scenario is not even remotely hard if you're setup right before hand. the biggest problem i can see having is expanding too far too fast take your time pace yourself and don't expand or accept new people unless you're absolutely ready for them or are recovering from loss.

column8: bought this game long time ago with loads of bugd was hoping developers will fix it (well few years later the game is still crappy with bugs and issues not to mention that there is very little to the game, when originally they promised more content to come I was hoping they will add more things but instead they added few things and went on to another development. Yes I got their new game for free (or on a discount can't really remember now) but I'd say it like I feel it, If you promise to make a game and after many years you can't deliver it, well don't be surprised if whenever I see your companies name I will be skeptical about buying a game from you.

column8:
I've logged a lot of time into this game, and pick it up every now and then and play it for stretches at a time. You'd THINK that would lead me to recommend it, but no. I don't recommend this game to purchase.

I started playing the prototype that released with the Double Fine prototype bundle, and I really, really enjoyed it. I was so thrilled when the game hit Steam, and couldn't wait to see where it went. Well, it did add features to the prototype game, which I was playing regularly, so in that sense I'm still enjoying it. However, the game is extremely unfinished and buggy. Asking $10 for it is a slap in the face to consumers; they should ask no more than $1 or so for an unfinished game, if that. Basically, I've played more completed games from Pyweek, and that's folks slapping together games in a week -_- 

All that said, I do like playing this game; I enjoy the space sim aspect, and since I've never really gotten a successful, self-maintaining base running it's sort of a perpetual challenge. But I can't recommend it to others because it's so broken. I'm surprised Double Fine has the balls to keep it in the Steam store at $10.

column8:
+ It's fun for a few hours: Construct your base (you'll need to use tricks so the idiot AI doesn't lock itself in or out)
- Pretty soon, deaths occur just because the AI sucks balls: 
-- Miners suffocating on the way back from asteroids
-- Miners dying in front of the airlock because the airlock is waiting for another character
+ Once you've got all the rooms, it's fun to watch stuff going on
+ Your guys learn skills
-- until pirates appear and shoot all your best buys who cannot fight back because the enemy is under your base and not targetable
-- or they shoot up all your guys who're currently demolishing some structures
-- or your guys decide to hang out in an area you've dsigned to be removed, so they suffocate as soon as a miner removes the wall

This was abandoned by the devs in a Completely unfinished state. It could've been great, which adds to the frustration of seeing things go so stupidly wrong.

column8:
I can't get anywhere in this game. I chose a low hostile area for my first base, so that I'd be able to learn the game before having to learn how to fight. No such luck.

I can barely get four areas built before the first invation. No one ever reacts to the invaders unless they happen to be in that room. In fact, even after setting EVERYONE to security, most just kept about their old jobs while others got killed/injured by invaders. FINALLY I handled the first wave of invaders. I go to build my infermary to heal the injured, only it takes the builders FOREVER to finish anything and by the time it gets done I'm being invaded again... and again... and again. About four seperate attacks happened in the span of five minutes (in LOW hostility territory) and I watched as everyone was killed and my game, thus, completely lost.

This is not fun. The tutorial sucks and the learning curve is too steep or the A.I. is just too dumb for the hostility the game throws at you. I have restarted this game 10 times already because I can get nowhere in it. I'm done.

DO NO BUY THIS GAME. IT'S NOT WORTH THE FRUSTRATION!

column9:
Spacebase DF-9 is a pretty good project with great potential, which, unfortunately, was squandered by the developers.

This project was conceived as a kind of alternative to the famous Sid Meier's Civilization series, but unfortunately, things didn't quite go as planned.

So, we're faced with the task of founding a colony in space. Creating a base is fairly simple; in the first hour of the game, it's fairly easy (despite constant pirate attacks and meteor showers), but after the second hour, you start wondering, "What next?" And the answer is shockingly simple: "NOTHING!"

Unfortunately, this game remains in Early Access, despite its great potential. After all, it would have been possible to develop one base, say, in a single "solar" system, while simultaneously establishing a second base with even greater potential (like Civilization, except the battle would be for a specific part of the galaxy, not just a single planet). Or, after successfully establishing yourself in space, you could colonize a nearby planet, and then it would be a real fight for survival. But, as I already said, my dreams were not destined to come true.

Overall, the game turned out very well, but as mentioned earlier, it's simply unfinished. A lot of glitches in the game are quite normal, at least for a beta test. The sound is quite decent. Regarding the graphics, I'd say that if you're looking for a game with good, and most importantly, high-quality visuals, you definitely shouldn't try this project. The graphics, for a standard strategy simulator, are pretty good; at least they don't turn the player off.

Finally, I'd like to list the pros and cons of this project.

Pros:
+ Very interesting concept
+ The game's graphics are quite good
+ Sound
+ Gameplay (though simple, is very convenient)
+ Addictive (but, unfortunately, not for long)

Cons:
- Bugs
- Few items to build
- The project remains unfinished (meaning the game remains just an idea)

My rating for Spacebase DF-9 is 6/10. A good game... If only...

[b][i][url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/11769719/]More reviews in our curator group: Dreams of Genesis [/url]

column8:
It can not even be considered a Pre-Alpha-Release, but it comes with a full price tag nonetheless. Double Fine decided to rob all early access supporters by pretenting development by making cosmetic changes to their tech-preview for a while until they finally drop the whole project all together, like they already did with Broken Age, Hack'n'Slash and other titles. In my opinion this can only be called an bold example of customer fraud, so don't even consider to install it even if it might be for free one day, since it's in a non playable state and therefor a total waste of time.

Keep away from any Double Fine game at all costs, since it follows a undeniable pattern of overexaggerating and under-delivering. It would fit in if they would hire Molyneux.

column8: I really wanted to like this game, but the AI is absolutely horrendous, one negative thing hits your base and it's over. I had a base with 45 people, one killbot came in, despite me having 12 people on security with phaser rifles and better armor and turrets in every room, the killbot alone murdered my entire base that I had spent 3-4 hours building, on top of that, most of the people on your base will randomly go on a rampage and kill / destroy everything, it's ridiculous, unfinished, and really disappointing, bought in pre-release hoping they'd finish it, but never happened. Will make sure to boycott any other games they try to sell and spread the word of how shitty of a company they are.

column8:
This game is fun for the 30 - 45 minutes you can play.  Bugs still exist.

Great concept and gameplay.  The problem is, even when in an "extremely low-risk" portion of the galaxy, you are faced with raider after raider after raider.  With 12 citizens and FOUR of the being 4-star "security"... ONE raider wiped out all but two citizens. Ridiculous.

15 minutes later I had built back up to 5 citizens.  Three raiders wipe EVERYONE out.

No way to save a game and return to it as far as I can tell.  You may "quit and save" then return later to where you left off....  But once catastrophe happens, you can't back up and try again.

Start over?  I've done that plenty.  Tired of it.  This game sux and is the biggest waste of money I've ever experienced on Steam.



As I said, good premise, fun game.  But no saves and wave after wave of intruders in the "significantly low risk" portion of the galaxy.  Ridiculous.

Continuous message that my base is out of power yet it is NOT.

column9:
I've been playing the game for a while now, and I don't know which game has managed to make me so angry...
Either the population is bashing each other's skulls in, civilians are running stupidly into combat zones and into the crossfire, or damn Armageddon breaks out in the form of debris blasts, massive invasions, and stupid, do-nothing security forces that just stand by and watch, and usually it all happens at once. I rarely get angry about games, but this game was once a great idea, but it's damn near unplayable!

Conclusion:
You want a game that makes you angry? Spacebase DF-9
You want anarchy? Spacebase DF-9
You want one or more worst-case scenarios? SPACEBASE DF fucking 9 >:(

column8:
This review doesn't account for the fact that DoubleFine essentially gave up on it. 

I rather enjoy playing this game, and often think back on it in consideration of playing it more. 
I have rarely, if ever, encountered most of the complaints that I've seen about the game; even after essentially 'beating' it. 

The community guides for the game are very helpful - especially in handling savegames. RNG can really kick your butt in Spacebase DF-9, and managing your saves is the key to making the game enjoyable. 

All that said, I really do wish that there were more content... the game, in my opinion, is much more fun than FTL.

column8:
I'm writing a positive review to this game only for 1 reason - current fanpatch(v1.08.1) made this game quite playable - when you`ve figured out this game at least(i made a little guide for the game anyway - "Nova-class fortress").

As game in raw - you are building a space base populated by lazy idiots. They dont do what they must, fight for no reason and die for that reason. 10/10 simulator of why idiots must not be around base. Ppl jump off airlocks, fight fire with bare hands - that's raw spacebase.

Anyway, you're building yourself a spacebase. From scratch. You need to get Air recyclers, beds, medical care, food and later - garden-made food. For all of that you use matter mined out of asteroid chuncks. Ppl have different skills and job preferences. Sometimes you gonna get raiders, sometimes - derelicts with raide/parasites/killbots. You also need to research new stuff in order to survive. And in the end - fight off massive raider attack.

For great idea this game had, it's a shame that the game was never finished, but with fanpatch and other stuff game is quite funny and can test your wits and nerves. Also, bought game with discount - so it's worth it's price for me. 
Shame no achievements evne though game has goals(things like achievements).

column8: An unfinished, buggy piece of abandonware marketed as a early access game in constant development which was tossed out along with the source code and sold in spite of being a finished, functional game when the funding dried up.  Instead of a game, this is an example of the worst and most intolerable abuses of early access.  That this was done by Double Fine only makes the jab that much more painful.  There isn't enough content in this "game" to be worthy of the title or even to be judged as such and the sequence of events leading up to now make this more of an artifact to be remembered about how bad things can possibly get and a reminder of how you should never trust a single word published by a developer and judge the product in your hands as is.

column8:
TL:DR - Dont buy it. Great potential, shame was never finished.

A awesome game - or it could have been. Great ideas, really had alot of us excited, "This is the game I have been wanting to play for 14 years, and finally someone's making it!! Startopia x Dwarf Fortress!!" But unfortunately, the decision was made to pull the plug by DoubleFine. The game is unfinished. The AI is awful, It's crashy  it's buggy and while they claim they covered the list of things they were going to include, the full list (that they tried to delete and replace with an abridged version) was considerably bigger, and you can feel from the game alot of the "Completed" items could have had several layers, or further sophistication, but instead were there as a superficial "tick the box so we can say we delivered". 

I cant even compare this to the MOO3's in terms of promises that failed to deliver (Maybe Outpost comes close?) although the "let the modding community save us" is VERY MOO3. I am VERY interested to see what the modding community can do with the game, but I can only echo the others here to say DONT BUY IT!! Get a friend to share it or torrent it first, or wait till it's $3 in a Steam sale - in it's current state it is only good of an evenings entertainment. 

The thing that makes me FURIOUS instead of dissapointed is several other groups (i counted at least 3) were looking to make a similar "Build your Spacestation x resource management x roguelike" games around this time, but the graphics for SB-DF9 made all of them say "Nope! All right, junk that and try the next idea". They had games that looked good (in 2D) and were focused on gameplay and game mechanics and also had huge potential, but were scared out f the market. Damn you DoubleFine. . . . that is all.

column8:
Theme Hospital meets FTL.
It's a roguelike space station building game. You start with three astronauts and some supplies. 
After you've got the basic stuff laid out - everyone needs air and food - you're free to start kicking back and just...building a base. Positioning sleeping quarters, infirmary, dropping plants, opening a pub.
Challenge comes in the form of enemy attacks. Sometimes enemy ships will close on your station and invade, other times you'll come across a derelict wreck which you can explore, though in doing so you'll generally have to fight stuff.

And why are so many negative reviews around?
Fan base doesn't like the way this game came from an early access to a full release, so the most of them changed their reviews to negative ones.
Nevertheless the game is really good and definitely worth trying!

column8:
A.I. IS DUMB LIKE SHIT AND YOU CANT TELL THEM WHERE TO GO!

The game is very nice and had potential, but i want to give you just some little examples of gameplay:

Everything worked fine for 2 hours, but then suddenly 3 raiders came and killed half of the crew....

Later on some idiot went crazy, damaged a turret, that killed 90% of the Crew... The last guy died after a sudden fire accident, that would have been no problem if it wasn't just at the infirmary.... 3 hours gameplay lost. 


NO CHANCE TO SAVE! JUST THIS DUMB-PSEUDO-WE-WANT-A-INDIE-SAVEGAME-SHIT-THING will make anybody mad playing this game for later than a few hours. 
Sometimes you cant even do anything, just watch anything what you had built up in this game for hours die and burn. 
But people who love this, should buy it....

column8:
Unfortunately, besides being an unfinished abandoned product it's not even fun to play. It seems to be more of an alpha demo with lots of ideas crammed together than anything else.

What I felt it crippled the fun the most was that the crew spent 50% of the time sleeping, 25% eating, 15% chatting and 10% working so everything moves extremely slow, besides that sleep time even on super fast speed takes forever (like at least 5 times longer than the sleep time in the sims with low end beds, or about 5 minutes real time). And I'm not even commenting on the characters dying of diseases even though they were "healthy" and/or quite early in the game and when they are unconscious on the floor the medics or anyone else does nothing to help them out even if you have a free bed in the infirmary, or that even on the more secure zones you can be attacked at the very beginning when you haven't even begun to mine asteroids for resources.

The GUI is quite a mess as well with features all over the place and filled with so many things you don't know what do with yet lacking of important information of what does each object/room do and just throws you into lots of trial and error.
