column8: This needs to be marked as an abandoned early access. There's obvious potential but it is completely unreasonable to charge for this.
column9: This needs to be marked as an abandoned early access. There's obvious potential but it is completely unreasonable to charge for this.

column8:
Spacebase DF-9 lets you create your own space station, managing crew and resources all while staving off pirates and taking hails. It sounds like a lot of fun for anyone that was into Star Trek or even games like Dungeon Keeper 2, but it turns into all of the management and none of the fun. The big issues that I have with the game is that its tough to survive the first few moments of a normal game and beyond that, its just a dull game that forces you to assimilate all metal to keep growing your station to accommodate more crew.

Your objective is to keep your crew alive against first asphyxiation and later raiders. Even when your crew dies and the game tells you start a new game, it still continues. It is a game over without being concrete or giving you a final score before you have to start a new game.

To start with, there's an optional easy how to play tutorial level that will guide you through the basics without feeling forced upon you. The tutorial makes it easy to get up and running. Assign crew to the roster of jobs. Builders build when you construct rooms or objects. Miners will mine ore to be refined to get more matter to construct with. Technicians fix things and that's about as far as the tutorial gets.

You'll need a few things to get a space base operational. The first is power that comes in the form of reactors or a seed to start with. The second is the base itself which can be a giant room. You'll need an oxygen recycler since you are in space after all. After your space base has O2, an enclosed room and power, there's another matter and that's getting in. To do this you need to setup an air lock with two airlock doors one to the interior and the other to the exterior. This room also needs to have a locker for space suits.

Outside of the tutorial the giant problem that I have with the game is the level of difficulty when you're even getting started. The tutorial is nice and setup and it does let you continue on playing which is perhaps the best method. Consider that easy mode. You get to select your location and the game tells you how rich in ore and the frequency of attacks. Its a nice choice of difficulty without being a blunt difficulty slider.

In normal play, the game starts you with a seed for power and three crew in space suits with limited oxygen. There is so much that can go wrong. Running out of matter before your crew is in oxygen will doom you. So you need to budget building a small room to house the seed, a recycler, food dispenser, and a second for the air lock. Then you need to wait for the station to fill with oxygen and even for the air lock to cycle air in and out. Your spacemen can die in their suits when waiting for an air lock to pressurize. Oh but there is another nail to get caught on and that's the fact ore needs to be converted into matter, so it requires a matter refinery. This getting started kicks off the game and it will scare people away.

On paper, interesting things do happen. Derelict space stations will come into your area for you to explore and spaceships will dock with you. From there you have a choice, send your security over to investigate them or ignore them. The spaceships become part of your base where then you need to claim each room, which can be tedious and cumbersome since many small rooms are just tough to click on.

People can come aboard infected with a disease and then your science station will be put to work finding the cure. To do so, click whatever science room you've setup and select whatever they should research. There are a number of diseases to cure and upgrades to unlock. Upgrades include things like body armor and heavier doors.

You will get attacked from time to time. Raiders will float out in space and either try to shoot your miners as they pass by or they will board your station. Other times vessels will dock with your station and you'll be invaded. The catch is, unless you're watching a mining operation, its easy to spot and prepare for. You can have your security waiting for them, unless they're busy putting out a fire. It seems like more of an annoyance than a fun or cool challenge. You can also purchase wall mounted defense turrets.

Normal crew will still engage the enemy if they're in the same room, but to send crew in to fight hostiles, you'll need to assign crew to the security. From there you can make a security beacon that draws them to the area. It feels like an extra step and even marking the point and calling off security seems like it could be streamlined. A lot of the game needs to be streamlined.

Once attackers are incapacitated you can act to cuff, uncuff or execute them. In fact you can chose to execute or cuff any of your crew. Its just a little odd. Sometimes they will even chose to join your crew. Once resources become scarce, its just easier to execute them and dump them into the refiners to make matter.

Sometimes there is an issue where a firefight in an airlock can down the only crew inside the station. So anyone outside the station is forced to suffocate over time because the air lock refuses to open when someone is in there without a suit. It gets more hilarious because in smaller stations, crew will just stand in the air lock when its too crowded everywhere else. Spacebase DF-9 is an amazing game to watch because of its logic.

Speaking of logic, I managed to glitch the game into thinking there was no airlock. Those outside the station would die of asphyxiation and those inside the station would stay in there. Even crew joining would stay outside until they died. Destroying the airlock doors and rebuilding had no effect. Yet I could manually keep a door open so the spacemen could float into my base still in their suits. They would still suffer the same fate with no oxygen. The only way I was able to get people in and out was to build a new airlock.

In terms of crew management, when it comes to the roster everyone has an emotion to specific jobs no matter what their skill level is. You can have someone great at botany, yet hates doing it. Crew member you're the best doctor we have! Yeah but they get sad while doing it. Its a realistic and offers a level of micro management. Once you get to a point where you have crew of every class it gets easier since you no longer have people flip jobs such as having a miner one day and builder the next.

You get constant hails to answer and decide if you want them to join. It feels like a chore so I opt to avoid the calls. Sometimes the hails are to lull you into security so they can get "in your base, killing your dudes." Their transmissions all seems sketchy. There is no one that sounds like a clear cut good or bad choice. They all sound like they're trying to be funny and questionable, because that's what people like in their games, humor and charm. Well both fall flat and it feels forced.

Its also annoying having to press the faster speed setting, because the game will drop to normal speed whenever a yellow notice appears. It could be worse by being a popup box that you have to click like in so many other games. These warnings are things such as a crew member is starving or running out of oxygen. These warnings are color coated. Green means an overall hint on what's needed in your station such as more self space. Yellow and brown seem to be specific crew have achieved something or need something. Major warnings like crew being attacked or raiders about to board are in yellow so they blend in. A lot of times I realize we've been attacked after I see the number of crew go down. Raiders look similar to your own crew.

Spacebase DF-9 is just a tough game to love when it feels like a tough start followed by dull and uninspired management. It does feel like a fleshed out game with a lot of annoyances. I think scenarios would help extend my interest, but within a few hours I feel like I've seen everything there is to see. With all of that said, it is still worth the one dollar I paid for it.

column8:
Don't buy this game unless it's on sale. It was abandoned in development and while playable in the early stages quickly becomes a nightmare somewhere around the 10 hour mark. I didn't realize this game had been out for a while and kept waitng for updates and fixes that never came. So, I was screwed out of about 14 bucks around a year and a half ago.

 If you just can't resist go for it now while the whole (unfinished) thing is under 2 bucks.

column8:
Could have been a very fun game that could be played for hours. However, the game is buggy, very limited gameplay and no end goals or objects. And what content is in the game lacks depth.

It's not worth the money even on the holiday sale

column8: I really like this game.  It's simple and difficult to develop all the tecnologies and keep the population happy.  A very challenging and time consuming game.
column9: I really like this game.  It's simple and difficult to develop all the tecnologies and keep the population happy.  A very challenging and time consuming game.

column8:
Glitches / stupid crew actions ruin this game. I really wanted to like it. It's a good idea. It should be fun but it just makes you angry. The challenges like raiders, space monsters and diseases are nothing in comparison to your own crews death wish and ineptitude.
Suffocation seems to be the suicide of choice for your crew. Half your crew will move from a perfectly life sustaining base with everything they need to a tiny base with nothing, panic about oxygen then asphyxiate. For no reason!
Your crew will "chat" inside an air lock while their friends suffocate outside. Alternatively crew will open airlock doors flushing their unsuited friends into space.
You security crew will ignore alerts and "patrol" the room next to the sleeping quarters where every one inside is being slaughtered by raiders.
Your security crew can't tell the difference between a raider inside the base and a raider outside, so while all your miners are being shot they will run round inside instead of putting on space suites.
Crew will starve to death stood next to a food dispenser.
Finally your crew will refuse to go to the infirmary (status says they will, but by now you know they are  lying) and die of diseases you have the cure for.

column8:
Spacebase est mieux que planetbase.

Spacebase contien la galaxie en map et en plus c'est au hasard, il y a des vaisseaux qui nous abordent, et pour le reste c'est assez similaire Ã  Planetbase.
Sauf que Planetbase est vite limitÃ©.
0.99 ca vaut le coup !!
column9:
Spacebase is better than Planetbase.

Spacebase contains the entire galaxy map, and what's more, it's random. There are ships that approach us, and otherwise, it's pretty similar to Planetbase.
Except that Planetbase quickly becomes limited.
0.99 is worth it!

column8: You're killin' me, DoubleFine.  I was such a Tim Schaefer-ite, I loved everything he and DoubleFine put out for a long time, and then they started making awful business decisions and completely screwing their customers.  What's worse is that SpaceBase REALLY scratches that itch of well-designed, funny and tight gameplay I have been searching for - until all the bugs show up and I read the reviews and find out that DoubleFine literally stopped supporting the game.  Left for the wasteland of vaporware, this game could have been amazing.  I know there's a cadre of programmers trying to take up the mantle that DoubleFine left behind to fix it via patches and mods, but the bottom line?  They shouldn't have to.  Spacebase could have been something amazing, and it was the final nail in the coffin; I will never buy another DoubleFine product. :\

column9:
The game is incomplete (see other user reviews from users who are more knowledgeable than me) but above all, it's abominably random.
Meaning, you can spend almost an hour without any problems, then, in less than 20 seconds, you'll experience a meteor shower, two raider attacks, and a fire...

column8:
This game has made it finally from early Alpha to final release version. I played this game while it was in early alpha and beta later on. Long after it has been released as final I picled up again.
Gameplay: You start off building your own little spacebase after picking a suitable place. Getting into the basics is quite easy and there is quite fun attached to that. Building up you base is spiced with raider attacks and impacts from space debris. Some other gameplay elements (artefacts, research, etc.) make it interesting for some longer play.
I found this game entertaining for about 10h, afterwards it got repetetive and dull.
After the developers dropped this game completely there will be no future content added (besides community developed content). I certainly learned my lessons concerning early alpha content.
=> You may have some fun with this game for a short/medium amount of time, but I cannot really recommend buying it.

column8:
I am really upset this game turned out the way it did.
Talk a walk a year or two back, and you'll find Double Fine announcing a cool new sci-fi space station management game. Why, it looks amazing. Many of us buy in, including myself, and fork over loads of cash to get this game going. And for a long time, it went. It developed and developed and developed, and then all the coal of the development train was dumped out into the engineers' pockets, and they ran off, leaving us passengers screwed over on a train that was stopped halfway to its destination.
The engineers reach the nearest town, and, without changing their names or the name of their train company, start advertising a brand new train ride.

column8:
In its current form the game is worth less than $1

Unfortunately it may never be improved beyond that state. If you want to buy it for $1 (on sale) and hope that several years from now the player base mod team actually turns this into a working game, go for it.

But don't say you weren't warned. I bought this for a $1 knowing what I was getting into and I can't say I'm disappointed simply because I wanted to poke around and see what all the negative hype has been about. And the reality is, this game can not be recommended with a good conscience.

All the potential for a good game is here and than you realize your content ends shortly after figuring out how the controls work. There's no campaign, the tutorial is laughably poor at even explaining the basics and the sandbox play (which is pretty much all that exists) is laughably short before it becomes an endless loop.

You start with a random team of 3 with random skills in a random zone of space with random resources and (almost) random difficulty. You have some minor influence over how to skew the randomness (by choosing different zones of space); but in the end the only real choice you have is:
pick a dangerous area or pick a non dangerous area (or rather: pick an area where you cant play because you die instantly or pick an area where nothing happens until later and than goes into an endless loop of the same easily defeated enemies)

I don't know, I had some silly fun poking around with it for about an hour but there's just not much here and while I applaud the player base mod team for making an effort at improving the game I know full well that it could take years before there's enough fixes and content additions to make this game playable. 

I'll probably replay it for a few minutes every year or so just to see if they ever do anything with it.

EDIT 1: And I fell asleep listening to the music while playing, which is the only reason it looks like I have some hours of play time. Content was over in less than an hour. The rest of the listed play time was watching the spacebase like a fishbowl or sleeping with the music from the game playing.

EDIT 2 (years later):
Just to note it appears the mod team that wanted to fix this game no longer seem to be active, no real progress has been made or is currently available to the public.

On a brighter note the original Startopia is getting a spiritual successor in Spacebase Startopia.

Note: Spacebase Startopia is not made by either company that had anything to do with either Spacebase DF9 or Startopia, it's just borrowing the names from each, but the game play is clearly inspired by Startopia more so than Spacebase DF9. Anyway for those who may have been even curious about Spacebase DF9 I think either the original Startopia or its spiritual child Spacebase Startopia are both at least worth looking at:
https://store.steampowered.com/app/243040/Startopia/

https://store.steampowered.com/app/840390/Spacebase_Startopia/
---

[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/38232109/]While you are here, would you consider following my curator page?[/url]

[url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/kunovega/recommended/]Want to read all of my reviews and not just the curated ones?[/url]

column9: In French: Strong potential, but Spacebase DF-9 is clearly not finished. Even at less than a euro, it's not worth it: after the first few minutes of building your space base (an aspect that has its good points), you'll run into numerous bugs, serious AI problems, and a lack of content. You have to subscribe to the game, or rather this prototype game. I downloaded an unofficial patch made by developers (see comments), but it still crashes and there's a lot of work to be done before finishing this game... instead of the developers. Seriously, I don't understand how an unfinished game can be sold, even on Steam at a low price.

column8:
[b][i]Spacebase DF-9[/i][/b] is a casual building sim-tycoon game. You are put in charge of a few colonists to build, maintain and protect your own space station.

[b]Pros[/b]: The game is easy to pick up on: you start with a power source, minerals and a handful of colonists whose first priority is to build a modest space station with oxygen supplies, and expand to a small variety of room types while mining and refining minerals. As your crew grows and time passes, additional needs will surface, needs that you must address or risk your crew to lose its temper. Derelict ships and additional travelers will want to join, some whether you like it or not, and you must deal with meteor showers, raiders and other threats, all the while researching better equipment.

[b]Cons[/b]: There is a severe lack of variety in every way: Only a couple of room types with very little content or options, while general furniture offers a scarce selection. Travelers will often discard your rejection, and you quickly become over-populated. You barely have any control over crew morale. The game become repetitive as you are constantly facing the same issues: need more resource or oxygen/power, raiders come over to kill some of your crew, crew member goes berserk, rinse & repeat. Even tech research is rather limited.

[b]Verdict[/b]: â˜…â˜…â˜†â˜†â˜† - Forget it

[i]Spacebase DF-9[/I] drops the ball. While not a bad game, it had the potential of being the next [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/297920/][i]Space Colony[/i][/url], but doesn't come even close. Games of this genre require variety to make it interesting to build and grow, and this game doesn't have what it takes to give it the replay value it would need.

[quote][b]P.S.:[/b] I do not recommend this game as it is offered on Steam. There is, however, a dedicated team of developers at [url]http://spacebasehub.net[/url] who have taken it upon themselves to enhance the game and its content. There is still a long way to go, but should the game's potential actually come to fruition, my opinion of the game could change.[/quote]

â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”
[i][b]This was just my opinion.[/b]

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up, and feel free to check out more of my (purely opinionated) [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/CJsOpinions/]reviews[/url].[/i]

column8:
Do yourself a favour and do not buy Spacebase DF-9. I bought it some years ago, early in development and it was a great concept. But as the "development" went on it started to get less and less substantial, until they just stopped. Double Fine might say it is finished. Nothing of the sort. It is empty, buggy and mediocre. They filled it with features that would look good on a list, but gameplay-wise are useless. If you already have it like me, get rid of your misfortune and download the unoffcial 1.7 patch from Derelict Games (community). 

Double Fine is anything but fine. They might have other great games, but they are not getting a penny's worth of my time and money again. To do this, and in such an underhanded way, it is unforgibable.
column9:
Do yourself a favour and do not buy Spacebase DF-9. I bought it some years ago, early in development and it was a great concept. But as the "development" went on it started to get less and less substantial, until they just stopped. Double Fine might say it is finished. Nothing of the sort. It is empty, buggy and mediocre. They filled it with features that would look good on a list, but gameplay-wise are useless. If you already have it like me, get rid of your misfortune and download the unoffcial 1.7 patch from Derelict Games (community). 

Double Fine is anything but fine. They might have other great games, but they are not getting a penny's worth of my time and money again. To do this, and in such an underhanded way, it is unforgibable.

column8:

The object/build menu - Meh. 
Build walls for new rooms - Meh.

Your Guard will mostly fail to go into there.

I tested one mod to see "will it fixed?" and the game crashed, so for me it was no solution.
(Played with Win7 64bit)

column8:
This game is just a failed experiment I suppose? Basic playability is barely functional.
At a base level in games, you generally want to know what you can and can't do, and a certain amount of intuitiveness is necessary in UI elements. 

You cannot place objects on walls if they face ne/nw (Isometric view). You cannot rotate a camera despite the 3D models, I spent about five minutes confused thinking no surely you must be able to make it face the other way? Considering objects are NECESSARY in one room, to go into another, (Two spacesuits in a room, with an airlock, to move out) the only answer is making gigantic rooms or a ton of small rooms. The tutorial doesn't really tell you to do this, and while you can then retry, and do it "right", it sets the tone for the game. You won't be using your intellect or planning skills, you will learn that the game isn't capable of some things, and how to work around it. There is no space efficiency, which is one of the key "fun" things to do in a base building game. 

Learning is of course a key part of games and design, but they should be learning mechanics not limitations. 
In ten minutes I ran into several of these little "Oh. You can't do that? Or am I doing it wrong?".

I bought it because it was DoubleFine and it DID NOT say it was early access. I checked if there would be updates, and it says sure there will be one more, and then development is done. Unfortunately I think this is a kind of cool game that will never come to fruition, like  many in this harsh industry.

column8:
Summary:  Don't buy this game.  Not worth playing, even if it was free.


Review:

It will take about 30 minutes to get a simple base together.  Then you will be under constant attack with everything you build getting destroyed faster than it can be rebuilt.

There is no way to turn down the frequency of attack.  I've even changed the config files with no difference.

Resources are clunky to manage.

Tons of "fun" negative events include various types of raider events, meteor strikes, fires, fights, killbots, etc.
ZERO helpful events.

No balance.

column8:
TL;DR Don't bother, it doesn't follow it's own rules.

What a steaming load.  I bought this for 99 cents and I still fell ripped off. sure, it looks okay, sure, it has it's atmosphere but the game doesn't understand what a "low chance of being raided" means. I played one game for ~4 hours today and I was actually starting to have fun. theeeen raider after raider after raider, waves of the scrublords killed my workers, so I had to assign people who were not workers.. they were murdered, eventually my security was killed off and everything fell to pot. This isn't a strategy game, this is an exercise in futility and it desperately needs fixing. (but its not being  developed any more, ohnooes) And if you think I'm just being salty over this, I moused over the galaxy and found the most ideal spot I could. (which is near the galactic center) I was looking for the easiest of easy modes to get my feet  wet before I tried any of the other areas. And it was decently easy! uuuntil the game decided to start throwing raiders at me like they were party favors. seriously, I couldn't even keep up with  the info box because it was all "hey, raiders. look, raiders. oh hey, guess what? raiders!" Maybe there's some sort of infinite loop, maybe there's some sort of size threshold that this happens at but I never even got my population to 40. On top of all of this I was unable to do any research, medical or tech related. I couldn't assign anyone to do anything like that even though I had a huge research bay with 16 or so research tables and at the peak, 4 scientists.  

And can we talk about unhappiness? nothing  I did seemed to help them, they'd just go off and sulk and get into fights n stuff. All in all,  not as bad as Kirk Cameron's Saving Xmas, nor is it anywhere as awful as Depression Quest, but it has some serious coding and feature-related issues that really need to be looked at (if not by DF, then by allowing 3rd party patches to fix it.)

column8: I don't think the game is bad, it just sort of very quickly becomes repetitive where you set it on highest speed, sit back, and wait. I think maybe the game needs some sort of campaign or level progression to make it more enjoyable (maybe there is one? I didn't find it).

column9: The game reveals all its meager potential in the first hour; after that, it's pure despondency. Games after the first were practically identical. The only bright spot is the occasionally amusing dialogue, but even that gets repetitive every second playthrough. Avoid this game like the plague; it's not even worth your time.

column8:
this game has a few too many problems for me.

1: no one ever does their jobs. the builders and the miners do their jobs, though when you tell the builders to take appart a derelict they go inside, take off their space suites, and drill a hole in the hull and kill themselves.

i got attacked by raiders and they got into my life support room and got killed, but then the room was full of dead bodies so no one wanted to go into the room to fix the oxygen recyclers. how do you get rid of dead bodies? well, the doctors are meant to come in and take them away, but whenever they enter the room they get upset by all the dead bodies and leave. THIS IS YOUR JOB! not to mention that they leave all these unconcious and injured people all over the base.

then there's the science team, there was a disease i needed them to reaserch so i assigned them to it and checked back on them about sixty minutes later and they had done NOTHING. i had a special room and everything, i double checked and they had just been standing in the hallway chatting the whole time. eventually they got to work, but people were sick and going to DIE!

the security job is nearly pointless, and what they actually do can hardly be considered security. people assigned to security patrol a small area around a single security beacon, and the only real use for this is to have them explor derelicts. i just ended up building defense turrets everywhere, but they have limited view.
 
1.5: you can't tell anyone what to do, so even though this room is on fire no one knows and your fusion reactors are going to burn down.

2: given how little you're actually able to do as a player, the game asks way too much of you. every five minutes it's telling you there's a new disease that needs to be researched, when instead you want to research new technology (because apparently the scientists who research dark matter also research medicine, and not the doctors), raiders seem to attack more and more frequently untill you're perpetually under attack, and the game is always telling you that, even though you have 30 reactors and twice as many oxygen recyclers than you need for your population, you don't have enough power or oxygen.

3: the AI is stupid. outside of not doing their jobs, when i got attacked by raiders the AI does nothing to avoid them. when they walk into a room and see a raider, most of them just stop and hold up their hands in fear before being shot. raiders aren't even that smart, one broke into my pub and started punching my fridge.

4: i'm not listing all the problems, i'm glad this game was so cheap when i baught it, because it's too late to get a refund.

column9:
I've seen a lot of negative reviews about this game. I honestly don't understand it; people say it's unfinished. It's true that it could have been more, but it seems like a pretty complete game.

Personally, I'm enjoying it, Theme Hospital-style. Don't expect a captivating story or outright action, but the game is quite entertaining. I also bought it for a ridiculously low price.

It's a good game and doesn't deserve the negative rating it has.

column8:
Unless this has a serious discount, don't buy it. It has a lot of things wrong with it, and the devs dumped it before finishing the game. BUT some modders have taken up the challenge of releasing patches for the game anyway using its source code, and so far they've been consistent in their releases.

The most annoying thing about the game by far is how your station residents are incredibly sluggish when it comes to doing anything. I've had two starts where everyone suffocated in their space suits because they took a million years to actually get around to building oxygen recyclers when ordered, and another where everyone suffocated because they refused to build an airlock to actually get into the mini-station they'd just built. When you order a squad of security officers to move to an area with raiders in, it's a coin flip whether or not all of them will actually go there. I lost one citizen and one of my two officers to a raider attack when one of the officers decided to - I shit you not - stand around playing a handheld game instead of actually doing his job and shooting the raider that just killed someone.

It's quite frustrating sometimes, but worth the whole 69p I paid for it. I wouldn't pay much more than that for this game in its current state, though - if you do want to pick it up, I would advise you to not pay anything more than Â£1.50 or so for it.

Been a while since I looked at the progress of the game. Looks like there is a team now working again on getting the game fixed and updated.

column9:
It all starts off quite optimistically: low system requirements, pleasant graphics and music.
We build, extract the only resource, build some more, conduct research...

The artificial idiot is delightful: the players are incredibly stupid, doing anything but their duties, starting fights, destroying equipment, cramming ten of them into a tiny room, sniffing out all the oxygen, throwing open both airlock doors... Even Sims are smarter: at least you can give them direct orders.

The regularly arriving raiders are also distinguished by their intelligence and resourcefulness: the only thing that drives them is "Hulk, smash!", no matter how fatal it ends for them. At the same time, they manage to single-handedly wipe out the entire station's personnel, emerging victorious from clashes with a dozen highly-powered guardsâ€”yeah, their armor and weapons have been researched, but the point... Apparently, someone kindly provided the pirates with cheat guns to compensate for their lack of brains.

The low system requirements were also compensated for by poor optimization. From time to time, the game, having consumed the remaining RAM, begins to mercilessly slow down.

Conclusions:
- It's worth buying only on sale and with a good discount (which, fortunately, I did).
- The game might appeal to those who like tormenting NPCs: after 17 hours of play, I discovered that they know dozens of ways to die, and they never tire of inventing new ones.
- A heat-resistant plate for the chair is a must.

column8:
Fun diversionary game.  If you get it for a few dollars, it is worth a purchase but don't pay full price since there just isn't enough content.   The tutorial is decent.  I haven't found the Lua modding community for this game that the developers were hoping would expand their content.  

For a lower price and some DLC, or more content at its full price, this game would have been a great afternoon or light weekend game. 

Helpful Observations
Installed turrents in quantity seem to be the best bet for security but lack the ability to investigate the derilict ships.  
Watch the lights on the airlock doors (they go from full lights when pressurized to no lights when depressurized).  The airlock will only handle as many characters at a time as there are spacesuit lockers and space for.

column8:
WTF is this...? I guess i should have read the reviews before spending 99ct on it, but being a huge scifi fan i was blinded by the promising screenshots and i bought it anyway. I regret every single of the 99cts. It just sucks. My crew keeps dying constantly without any logical reasons (especially popular: asphyxiation due to blocked air locks that other crewmembers refuse to leave or generally refusing to leave depressurized areas), i get raided all the time despite living in a VERY LOW threat sector, the build menu is awful to use and the game sometimes refuses to follow build orders due to already demolished structures that nonetheless block the construction of new ones.

Don't make the same mistake i made. Do not buy this game.

column8:
It occurred to me that I should actually write something after the couple of years I've had this game. For those who weren't aware, this is an unfinished game that went from Alpha to Finished virtually overnight after Double Fine got all the money they thought they were going to get from it. It's buggy, it's extremely barebones in features, and if you buy it now you'll "miss out" on the Hack/Slash consolation gift they offered to us paying customers who got royally screwed by Tim of Legend. There is a modding team attempting to do (for free) the job Double Fine Entertainment couldn't be bothered to do, but buying this game will give those welchers yet more money that they can roll into their new Early Access project, which they're totally going to finish this time, honest guys. My advice: avoid.

I can't say the $20 I spent on this game was a complete waste, though. It taught me two valuable life lessons: never buy a game for the promise that it'll be awesome later, and never buy any more Double Fine products for as long as I live.

Leider unfertig mit haufenweise spielzerstÃ¶renden Bugs. 
Hier eine kleine Auswahl:
- Wird ein Charakter an der Luftschleuse verwundet, schlieÃŸt diese nicht mehr. Und er kann auch nicht von Ã„rzten behandelt werden. LÃ¶sung: Exekutieren!:(

Leider herrscht dort Sauerstoffmangel, weshalb sie in Panik geraten und ihre AnzÃ¼ge nicht mehr anziehen. Plopp, ganze Truppe hops. Besonders Ã¤rgerlich, weil das Skillen von Sicherheitsleuten aufwÃ¤ndig ist.

column9:
A really nice concept.
Unfortunately unfinished with tons of game-breaking bugs.
Here's a small selection:
- If a character is wounded at the airlock, it won't close. And they can't be treated by doctors either. Solution: Execute! :(
- If you investigate a wreck with enemies, your own soldiers take off their spacesuits and search the ship. Unfortunately, there's a lack of oxygen there, which is why they panic and don't put their suits back on. Plop, the whole squad goes down. This is particularly annoying because leveling up security guards is time-consuming.
- Repair priorities seem to be determined solely by condition and not by distance. If things go badly, the technicians just walk and don't repair.
- People starve to death next to food distributors that supply everyone else.

In its current form (end of November 2015), it's only playable with great frustration.

column8:
Starts off sweet but quickly becomes sour.

As far as abandon titles go, this one seems like it is close to being complete. However, two big elements are missing. 

First, there is gameplay balance. The game starts off feeling like you can do anything in it, if you just put the time and effort into it. And for the first 20 or 30 minutes this feels true.  You expand your base, explore ships, and manage your people to get the most out of them.  But then the raiders, and meteor strikes happen. And this is where the missing gameplay balance is most obvious.  Negative events are important to any game, if things were always good, than there wouldn't be any challenge. But the speed, and frequency of the negative events needs to be balance out against what the play can and cannot do, so that they can overcome them, and not just suffer.  I found that during the few games that I played, that I would get close to having a decent base going, only to have ruin by constant attacks, to the point where I was losing a lot more people than I was generating. Which resulted in me having a large empty base that I had no chance of defending or using.

The second element is content. There isn't much in this game... 

Overall, this is not a game that you should spend money or time in.

column8:
I liked the concept of this game, but ultimately it proves so frustrating to play.

Everything from the UI to the AI slowly starts to grate on you. Take when the player has to first build the room for power and life support and an airlock - even though I did it fine each time, a bunch of times the little crew members would refuse to go inside and instead ran out of air while floating and wandering around outside while marvelling at their craftsmanship.

Send your virtual minions to collect rocks so that you can build more areas for them to live in and shelves for their..tentacle monsters and sooner or later you will encounter... SPACE PIRATES! Okay, it is not nearly that dramatic, it becomes such a casual occurrence (so much so you get invasions right after each other, yaay..), the problem is these visits throw stuff into chaos. Security team, arm phazers, set them to stun or kill, I don't know, just get rid of these guys! Mr Wol--, what the... So even if you go to the security tab and tell your security team to defend a breach point a lot of the time they will stand idle and just be cut down one after another and the SPACE PIRATES will go on their merry way butchering your whole crew.
How to prevent this? Set EVERYBODY to security since that is the only way people defend themselves properly, afterwards you can try to figure out who does what job. CHAOS, Chaos everywhere, send in space marines to purge all this chaos.

After learning that my security were completely incompetent I instead put turrets, over there, outside, in that room there.. EVERYWHERE! Turrets are far more effective than actual people, you don't need to worry about losing something that took ages to level up and they kill raiders near instantly. <3 Turrets.

Base is defended - rockin'! Crap, tons of dead bodies in the base, mostly raiders but also my own people sometimes too, but they are making the crew depressed. No worries, the doctors will clear these bodies and recycle the matter, or at least they should. Doctor doctor, emergency paging dr. Beat, corpse rotting in life support room, whole station being flooded with smell of rot and bacteria! DOCTOR! I stare at my doctors and notice two standing in the infirmary playing videogames (curse you videogames!) and another one in the pub getting drunk and brawling. I sigh and decide that if they want to look at them so bad then sure, they can keep their cadaver friends.

Despite my doctors being either drunken masters or videogame addicts, I don't have any huge illnesses or parasitic worms devouring the crew lately. Still no work is getting done, so I change all the bartenders to other stuff hoping this abolition will get people to work.

I have miners and builders getting picked off by raiders and kill bots because the AI does not avoid danger and there is no way I saw to tell them to stop and go home. I stop caring if my crew die, it is worse than herding sheep because at least sheep run away from danger, crew numbers drop, bodies piling up, nobody cares and just drinks away their sorrows on Spacebase. 
I decide to quit playing the game before the chaos and stupid mechanics get to me and I become as apathetic as the crew, right before I quit - I notice that a doctor is finally removing all the dead bodies on the ship. 

Double Fine, could have done better. The game had potential, but abandoning it rather than fixing stuff was much easier for them.
column9:
I liked the concept of this game, but ultimately it proves so frustrating to play.

Everything from the UI to the AI slowly starts to grate on you. Take when the player has to first build the room for power and life support and an airlock - even though I did it fine each time, a bunch of times the little crew members would refuse to go inside and instead ran out of air while floating and wandering around outside while marvelling at their craftsmanship.

Send your virtual minions to collect rocks so that you can build more areas for them to live in and shelves for their..tentacle monsters and sooner or later you will encounter... SPACE PIRATES! Okay, it is not nearly that dramatic, it becomes such a casual occurrence (so much so you get invasions right after each other, yaay..), the problem is these visits throw stuff into chaos. Security team, arm phazers, set them to stun or kill, I don't know, just get rid of these guys! Mr Wol--, what the... So even if you go to the security tab and tell your security team to defend a breach point a lot of the time they will stand idle and just be cut down one after another and the SPACE PIRATES will go on their merry way butchering your whole crew.
How to prevent this? Set EVERYBODY to security since that is the only way people defend themselves properly, afterwards you can try to figure out who does what job. CHAOS, Chaos everywhere, send in space marines to purge all this chaos.

After learning that my security were completely incompetent I instead put turrets, over there, outside, in that room there.. EVERYWHERE! Turrets are far more effective than actual people, you don't need to worry about losing something that took ages to level up and they kill raiders near instantly. <3 Turrets.

Base is defended - rockin'! Crap, tons of dead bodies in the base, mostly raiders but also my own people sometimes too, but they are making the crew depressed. No worries, the doctors will clear these bodies and recycle the matter, or at least they should. Doctor doctor, emergency paging dr. Beat, corpse rotting in life support room, whole station being flooded with smell of rot and bacteria! DOCTOR! I stare at my doctors and notice two standing in the infirmary playing videogames (curse you videogames!) and another one in the pub getting drunk and brawling. I sigh and decide that if they want to look at them so bad then sure, they can keep their cadaver friends.

Despite my doctors being either drunken masters or videogame addicts, I don't have any huge illnesses or parasitic worms devouring the crew lately. Still no work is getting done, so I change all the bartenders to other stuff hoping this abolition will get people to work.

I have miners and builders getting picked off by raiders and kill bots because the AI does not avoid danger and there is no way I saw to tell them to stop and go home. I stop caring if my crew die, it is worse than herding sheep because at least sheep run away from danger, crew numbers drop, bodies piling up, nobody cares and just drinks away their sorrows on Spacebase. 
I decide to quit playing the game before the chaos and stupid mechanics get to me and I become as apathetic as the crew, right before I quit - I notice that a doctor is finally removing all the dead bodies on the ship. 

Double Fine, could have done better. The game had potential, but abandoning it rather than fixing stuff was much easier for them.

column9:
Despite the large number of negative reviews and its low rating, after playing it for a couple of hours, I have no choice but to give it a positive vote.

From what I've read, the devs left the game half-finished and released it for sale, but a group of programmers later fixed it.

Steam gave me the game after purchasing another game, and after the overwhelming number of negative votes, I thought it would be a real piece of crap. Nothing could be further from the truth; the game is quite decent for what it aims to offer: creation and management of a space base: obtaining resources, recruiting new tenants, combating sudden attacks, repairing damaged machinery, research, botany, food, oxygen, mining, defense turrets, etc. From the start, you can place your base in different parts of the galaxy, each location with specific conditions: a greater or lesser number of asteroids for obtaining minerals, greater or lesser passage of friendly or enemy ships, etc. I recommend completing the tutorial because starting from scratch can be a bit confusing, especially since the game isn't translated into Spanish. Even so, a high level of English isn't required.

In short, a kind of space Sims with simple yet colorful graphics. The only drawback is that it's in English; otherwise, it does what it's supposed to offer.

column8:
This game is fun, and as a space-themed strategy game about building a base in the middle of nowhere.  That part is fine.  What is not fine however, is how the devs abandoned this game part way through development.  Good thing I bought this on a really great sale when it was around the first few versions.  I cannot recommend this game unfortunately, even though I do actually like the game itself.  Wait for a sale if you want to buy it.  Anyway, here are some pros and cons.

Pros:

+ The game is fun, if you are patient.
+ The community for this game is releasing unofficial updates to the game.
+ Can actually present an occasional challenge.

Cons:

-The devs abandoned this at the side of the road like an unwanted child.
- Might be a bit TOO challenging at times
- $9.99 is a bit steep of a tag for a game that was abandoned in alpha.

Summary:  Buy this game if you like space strategy games, and dear god, please don't buy it at full price, wait for a sale.

column8: Ok let me start by saying I love this game. The best way to describe it is that it is kind of like SimCity and also the Sims but it is in space. You have to build a space colony from scratch and take care of your people. You build things for you colony to aid in research, life support, things to do for your crew and so on. You have to mine materials and manage resources in order to last a while. You must make sure you keep an eye out for raiders and derilect ships. This game is like a Sims game on steroids. If you don't like games like the Sims or SimCity you may want to pass this by but if you do enjoy games like that then this is a must have. The neat thing is that all of this happens in a sci-fi setting and the game can be addictive as you want to do the best you can for your crew and protect them from raiders. Make sure you get the The Officially Unofficial v1.08 Patch! Now with Brainworms! to make the game even more enjoyable. Trust me.

column8: Game is incomplete and devs ditched it. They wanted to do the Minecraft-style development where they keep improving the game and people keep buying it as they add more and more, but they had a barely-functioning skeleton of the game, not enough people bought it to justify them continuing, so they shut it down. That's just pathetic behaviour. Small indie studios get crucified for that kind of thing, let alone a bigger established studio like DoubleFine. As a bonus they put it on a big steam sale a week before announcing the end of development, just so new buyers felt extra shafted. They tried to buy some goodwill back by giving purchasers a free copy of Hack n Slash, as well as by putting out tools for modders and asking the community to finish the game for them(!), but buyer beware. This game was halted a brief way into development and never even remotely came close to being a releasable product. If Broken Age's double-kickstarter shenanigans weren't enough, this is proof that DF cannot be trusted with early access. Just stay well away.

column8:
Game showed such promise. I enjoyed what the game was shaping up to be. Loved the premise and enjoyed it and watching it grow.

Unfortunately, the game is now ABANDONWARE. I do not recommend purchasing this game unless you can accept the game in an unfinished 40% state the game is in. It is fun, but there is little content, the AI is crap, and will wear out on it fast due to odd bugs and little content.

While I do understand when games have to be abandoned, with the new Early Access system, this is one many people got burned, and burned bad with. What was supposed to occur with the game, and what actually happened, were narrow. They released the game from Early Access and called that that. Did a few fast patches to shut people up about the big items and continued on their way. The dollar signs weren't big in front of Doublefine's eyes apparently, and took what they had and ran. I wish Steam would have forced their hands in this situation, but didn't, and Doublefine continues along its way like nothing happened.

I'm even more disappointed with Doublefine that they put it on sale right before they terminated development (And I can't imagine them NOT knowing they were going to can it a couple weeks before they did) and continue to sell it with no disclaimer anywhere on the Steam page that it is abandonware and no longer being worked on, AND have also put it for sale as if it's still being acknowledged.

I will not purchase another Doublefine title (or anyone who is part of their team if they move on again) in prerelease, and I am GREATLY nervous about buying a title from them ever again.

column8:
I guess this game has gotten such bad reviews because the previous developer dropped it after people had already bought it.  Well now it seems like it's finished.  Great UI, great concept, lots of fun.  Reminds me a lot of the old Outpost series, but with a greater focus on your people/birdmen/chickenmen/frogmen etc. 

I really like that you can plan out the design of a room before confiming it and having your builders build the objects, but wish that you could do the same thing when laying out the room initially.  Something like a building simulation mode where you can place the walls and then place the objects to make sure that you have the room dimensions correct.  I've built a few rooms where I've discovered that the walls need to come out another tile and then had to send my builder back outside again to fix it... If the devs did this I think it would be the first sim that I've played with this feature, design first then build.  Then I wouldn't need to keep drawing my rooms first on grid paper... haha.

column8:
Ok, so this game.  Great concept.  Great idea, and it is done really well.  Except for one main thing.  The game constantly throws stuff at you, and sometimes there isn't actually a good answer.  Let me explain.  You are building a big section of your base.  Things are going well.  You then see a message appear on the side of the screen saying how one of your builder's space suit oxygen is running low.  Sometimes they quickly make their own way back to the airlock, stopping them from dieing.  Sometimes they just carry on working and then die.  You can try to avoid this by sending them to the infirmary (which is obviously inside) manually.  But sometimes they don't bother to listen and still die.

  Another example of this game throwing rubbish into your face would be those raiders who have high tech weaponry.  It takes one of them to take out tonnes of vital parts to your station as well as many many people with inferior weaponry, and thats it.  Your space base is broken and/or on fire and half your population dead.  Yay.

The random space debris causing major fires and ruptures within your base can easily kill a room full of sleeping people, again almost half your bases population. 

But the main thing that gets me is that for a game that is meant to be a mix between economy and fighting, all the fighting is unfair (see the first paragraph) and the economy lacks whats really needed.  The AI don't know when to prioritise fixing vital oxygen recyclers over fixing an unused door.  They also don't know when it is useful to take a break - many will take a break and not perform tasks during critical points in gameplay, causing negative effects (most prominently the players mood).  

In conclusion this game has a lot of potential.  A lot.  But it doesn't have basic concepts like manual prioritization and decent AI.  The whole game needs a huge amount of balancing, and until this happens I recommend you simply follow this game, rather than get it.  If and when the devs make the changes necessary this game will definately worth the money.  But for now, I recommend you spend it elsewhere.

And one other thing.  I can't for the life of me find out a way of keeping the people happy.  It may just be my incompetance, or this too may need balancing...

I can't think of anything to describe this game.

In short:
-The things you can build are almost impossible to count.
-The AI â€‹â€‹is extremely stupid, mostly just a leisure activity, or, for example, even 5 security guards are afraid of 1 raider.

I hate to see the bad in this game but there's no way I could recommend it as it's basically an incomplete game. Development halted and although the game is functional it is hardly a thrilling and inviting game.

If you wish to learn more before buying simply do a good search for SpaceBase DF9 and you'll get all the history on the reasons for halting development and the reactions from the fans.

Another cautionary tail for gamers with early access and Kickstarters.

Buy at your own discretion.

column9:
Unfortunately, this is typical for many Early Access games. They take money and then stop development.
As a full-time software developer myself, I have to say that this is a disgrace for our entire profession.
I actually consider Early Access a promise â€“ a promise to support users and deliver a continuously improving product that also meets customer expectations.

Imagine if car manufacturers promised you a 300-hp car that would consume only 1 liter per 1,000 km if you just ordered it now. Then you buy the thing and get a car that consumes more fuel than standard cars, and on top of that, it constantly stalls or can only turn left. Then we would clearly be talking about fraud.

As I said: I am a full-time software developer myself and know the ins and outs of software development â€“ â€‹â€‹before someone comes up with the argument "those poor software developers" again...

I think this is a complete disgrace.

column8:
ONLY BUY THIS ON SALE!!!!!!!!!!
Admittedly at first with this game I bought it in early access, I ranted and raved about it and it had amazing potential to be an extraordinary game. The game itself offers good game play and a decent UI, the tutorial is standard, does the job. The only thing that annoys me about this game is that although the features the game has are damn cool and entertaining (at least for 37 hourish ahaa) it had the potentially to become one of the best but sadly double-fine as per usual started as being active with the alpha community but did the inevitable thing they almost always seem to do and screwed everyone by being half arsed and essentially slapping a for sale sign on an alpha despite many things 'in the pipeline' so they claimed (including workshop compatibility which would have only made this game even more fun to play, more features, more control, more events and ultimately a better game). So i will still recommended this game, but however please ONLY BUY THIS ON SALE!!!!!!!!!! I only say this as double-fine seem to developing quite a habit of not fully developing their games that they release early access and shafting what is always an active community of fans to 'work on other projects'.... In other words they wants to see the $Â£$Â£$.... like a street hooker who starts buy giving you some amazing head and then bolting down the street leaving you to realise they've provided an albeit enjoyed but unfinished and overall crappy service while stealing your money and running onto the next chump.... (I use that analogy as it actually happened to a friend of mine once, hardest I've ever laughed)....
 Despite all of that however I cannot find it in my heart to not recommended this game as I thoroughly enjoy it....

column8:
This is not so much game as a loose conglomeration of bugs held together by an idea of a game. Bought it when it was still in development, after a few false starts murdered by game breaking bugs I realised it's not even marked as "In development" anymore. If that was an option - I'd demand my time back, let alone the money.

Pros:
Er... It was a nice idea, I guess?
There were a couple of lines that made me chuckle
Cons:
Bugs
Simple and soon annoying soundtrack
Behavioral bugs
Pathfinding bugs
Lousy implementation
Graphic glitches
Gamebreaking bugs
Other kind of bugs
More bugs.
Did I mention bugs?

column8:
Garbage, unfinished piece of crap that I originally paid Â£15 for. The absolute poster child of why early access sucks 99% of the time. Double Fine studios raw dogged everyone with this ship-jumping money-grabbing half-arsed excuse for a space sim.

If this were any industry but gaming they would be taken to court by the customers and sued for breach of contract, having to give all customers the option of a refund. They sold the game with the promise that it was a work in progress and they would evolve it, only to bin it as soon as they harvested all the early sales. To add insult to injury the game is awful too.

Disgusting, I shall not be buying another Double Fine game.

column8:
It's a shame to say, but unfortunately, this is just an incomplete game. That's really the best way to describe it. With bugs and glitches abound, and an astounding lack of ability to implement even the most basic mechanics without running into huge balancing issues between AI abilities (which are stunted by a bad AI setup) and the horrifically timed Raider events, it really just reeks of Double Fine saying "we need to get something that at least looks half decent if you close one eye and squint real hard".

Don't waste any of your money on this. I got this as a gift copy, and I still feel offended for the person that was kind enough to gift it to me. This is one of the few games which makes me genuinely angry to play, and is a blight in anyone's game library without some future huge rewrite by an independent coder of some kind.

column8: This game had so much potential. Go ahead and watch Scott Manly play this game on youtube. It was early access and it was shaping up to be a pretty decent Dwarf Fortress style game, but in space. Progress was made, bugs were clipped, and features added on a fairly regular basis, it had every indication that it was an early access game being developed in good faith for your investment. For whatever reason it got frozen, and released, unfinished, warts and all for the world. That's why you see so many negative reviews. This game isn't done, it makes no pretensions to being done, don't buy it unless you are fully aware what it is you are getting, and you don't have any lighters around to burn 10 bucks.

En effet, le jeu est complexe... mais trop complexe. Les ressources ne sont pas forcement lÃ  pour amÃ©liorer votre base, les mineurs ne faisant pas forcement correctement leur boulot, les attaques de pirates sont frÃ©quentes et rÃ©duisent vite votre station Ã  une base fantÃ´me, et vos astronautes sont de vrais enfoirÃ©s qui prÃ©fÃ¨rent aller boire un verre au bar que de faire leur boulot. Il faut l'avouer, on s'attendait Ã  mieux de la part du jeu, mais ce n'est pas atteinds.

Note : 4/10

column9:
Life in space is a passion for many people. Being able to create your own space station would be a dream come true for many! And Spacebase DF-9 makes us realize that's not happening anytime soon. Indeed, the game is complex... too complex. Resources aren't necessarily there to improve your base, miners don't necessarily do their jobs properly, pirate attacks are frequent and quickly reduce your station to a ghost base, and your astronauts are real assholes who'd rather go for a drink at the bar than do their jobs. Admittedly, we expected better from the game, but it falls short.

Rating: 4/10
Pros: Clear tutorial, base management is simple and enjoyable.
Cons: Difficulty obtaining resources, managing base personnel is overly complex, and the graphics leave something to be desired.

column8: This game had a lot of potential, but it's left very unfinished.  A lack of settings makes the game difficult to customize, and many of the event are haphazardly thrown in.  I'm very disappointed to see this as an example of an early access game gone wrong.  It's sad that they just dropped it like they did, and with very little info on what happened.

column8:
I really wanted to like this game but its just way too broken to enjoy. The potential for a great space station sim is there but the bugs make it unplayable. I'm hoping for mods but Spacebase needs an overhaul.

Pros: 
- great idea
- fun when you fool yourself that everything will actually work this time

Cons:
- Only playable if you can mod or work around the various bugs and brain dead AI
- Overall unpolished and ugly
- unbalanced enemies and unintersting battle system
- feels like more of a fish bowl than a game at times.

column8:
The gameplay itself is fairly fun, but I cannot recommend it for a simple reason:

Double Fines poor approach towards the game. Rather than finish implementing promised features, they cancelled any further development with no warning and crapped the game out of Early Access.

Why such a formerly loved developer would make such a colossally bad business decision, I'll never know.

column8:
Don't buy this game.

Here's why:
-Incomplete. They stopped working on it while it was in alpha. Then said it was complete.

-Unbalanced. Most things end up broken or killing you.

-Broken AI. The AI does idiotic things that end up being worse for them and everyone else. And you have zero control over them.

-Tutorial. It's terrible.

-Events. The events are just awful. No one wants any of the events to happen. They never end up being fun. Bandits are OP.

-Features. The bare minimum was put into this game. Seriously, they added only what the game needed to be playable not fun.

-Mods. There are none because the game isn't even worth it.

-Developers. They don't help much and obviously don't care for this game. Which begs the question: "Why did you make it?"

column8:
I don't understand why this game has so many negative reviews. Don't get me wrong, to have it bought and then find out that the devs would cease development, I would probably be angry too...but it's no longer early access, and for 2,45 I have to say that it has all I want. The music is nice, the scenery is nice, and the gameplay is good. I mean...you build habitats in space!!!
It relaxes me VERY much and I can't do anything else but recomend it. Maybe it's not worth 9,99, but having bought it on sale I have no regrets!

column8:
I love the concept of this game, but for me there are too many flaws. 

Raiding parties too early in the game with higher tech weaponry when you haven't got enough time to build your base to defend yourself.
The time it takes to switch jobs for characters. I had a builder and needed security quickly, my base was overrun with raiders and my builder/security just carried on building in his security suit.
The rate my citizens get peeved or bored. How do I get these ratings back up??
The lack of scenic items to raise the morale of the citizens

I'll probably keep at this game, playing it and trying out different techniques, but I can't see the level of difficulty changing in relation to raiding parties. I even placed my base in an area where it was ridiculously low for threats, but in three different games got attacked within an hour of setting up a base. I could be playing the game totally wrong, but if that's the case the tutorials need to be more informative.

column9:
First of all, the volume is too small.

If you look at the residence tab in Construction, you'll only find a bed and a rug, a lab with one research machine, and a gym with one exercise machine.

If you fast-forward, you could probably build a building in an hour or two.

And the only events that occur in between are a pirate attack, an investigation of an unidentified airship (which basically raises your resident level), and a resident asking to be accepted.

The game itself is enjoyable to watch and build, but that's about it.

It's a shame they didn't make more.

If you're hoping for updates that occasionally add buildings and increase events, that's another story. But as it stands now, it's a game you can see everything in a day or two.

column8: I didn't really "get" this when it was in Early Access; now that it's nominally in final release, I think Double Fine owes each of its owners a copy of Psychonauts 2.
column9: I didn't really "get" this when it was in Early Access; now that it's nominally in final release, I think Double Fine owes each of its owners a copy of Psychonauts 2.

column8:
This started out as a good looking project from a respected maker of novel games.  Then apparently Double fine's collective brains fell out and they decided that since people had already payed for their game in early access they didn't actually need to bother to finish it.
The release version of the game is fundamentally broken, and cannot even claim to be a working beta.  It's a half finished alpha they just dumped with zero consideration for their customers.  Most of the features promissed don't exist, or if they do are not functioning correctly.

Issules include but ar not limited to:

Spotty AI of both crew and hostile mobs.

Exploring wrecks is almost pointless since the risk of loosing crew because they refuse to come back to the station after checking it is usually greater than any benefits you may get from it.  Plus the mining reources always run out far too early leaving gutting wrecks for matter the only way to keep a base running.

Station power supply only works sometimes.

The only way to satisfy the entertainment need of station crew is to put at least 2 televisions in EVERY room of the base (including airlocks) since nothing else was ever added for entertainment.

The shield tech to stop asteroids punching holes in the base was never added, so you tend to spend half your time patching holes.

Don't even THINK of buying this game, and if you want my advice, stay clear of anything else from this developer as they do not deserve to exist.

column8:
I bought this game really early on and i still had a ton of fun with the limited things to do, now that ive played the full release, i can see theyve done alot of work, theyve fixed a huge amount of bugs and glitches that i used to see. The game goes pretty well now. I see people complain about the raiders, well you can build turrets to repel the ships before they even arrive, its all a learning process honestly, youll need to try a few new games before you find a nice balance.

Now I will say that there are still a few glitches but nothing gamebreaking. And I think the power system needs reworked because my base is covered in reactors but im somehow still need power. I also would think that there is alot more they could add to the game (rooms, objects, defences, other customizations) to have more things to do, but Im happy with its current state and id deffinately say this game is worth $10

column8:
This is a very high potential game, but still in alpha state. Double Fine Production didn't finish it and released it after alpha 6. It's a great game and so much fun to start with. But it's incomplete, not balanced and buggy which leads to a frustrating gaming experience.

I can not recommend it in the current (sadly final) state.

I started out loving this game, really, really loving it. Then slowly but surely all it's issues crept up and started ruining it for me.. AI does not work, causing ridiculous losses from raiders and essentially just making you angry rather than thinking "damn, next time that won't happen, I'll totally be ready".
If this game was still in early access and under development, I'd be willing to give it another chance. However, this is all it's getting, so I likely won't be playing again.

The game didn't live up to its promise and is definitely not finished.
I've never seen such an empty management game.
Don't you dare play early access games, especially when they're labeled Double Fine?
I've played 9 hours, and to be honest, in 2 hours you've done it, but well, it's more than enough.
After 9 hours, this thing deserves a good uninstall and a negative rating.
GAMERS ARE NOT BANK CARDS ON LEGS. DOUBLE CHIASSE (uh, sorry...). Double Fine.
You're no better than ubichiottes. (Ubisoft) and Actipognons (Activision)
We're tired of being taken for idiots.

column9:
4/10

The game itself isn't that bad. I read some reviews, and it feels like they've improved the game since those reviews. I didn't see any serious bugs or crashes, and the inhabitants of my godforsaken station weren't oblivious to their primary responsibilities. They did procrastinate a bit, but that's more of a simulation of reality. :) So, the answer to the main questionâ€”is it worth getting the game? Yes, if you get it for free in a bundle with other Double Fine games (like me), or at a crazy discount during a sale. The first five hours of playing it are quite interesting. How much are you willing to pay for five hours of play?

Amazing.
I've always dreamed of finding the strength to properly tackle Dwarf Fortress. It's a challenge to my abilities, imagination, and patience. This game is a great first step in that direction. Essentially, the gameplay and concept are completely consistent. But in this case, it's simpler, leaner, and less rigorous. You'll master the basic principles of what to do and what not to do in games of this type. Practice.

Pros:
- A good old-fashioned construction game, building the space base of your dreams.

Cons:
- There's not enough content, events, variations, or starting conditions (even the pros and cons in this review), which in turn leads to quick boredom.

Overall, as mentioned above, this game isn't so much valuable in itself as it is a pre-game trainer for children. Buy it, play around a bit, and that's it. Therefore, I can't recommend it.

column8:
I'll keep this review short and sweet.

I got this back in Early Access as I liked the idea. Pretty solid progress was made along the way and while it was nowhere near what I'd class as "Complete", it was showing lots of potential.

Then suddenly it got released as version 1.0 and that was that.

What's there is relatively stable and it's fun for a few hours. But it's easy to see it's incomplete whether it's some missing tool tips, room zones where there isn't much to do, etc. There's no reason to keep playing after you've built anything in your base and enjoyed the inhabitants for a while unless you really enjoy aiming for the "Goals" which just seems like grinding numbers.

Great idea but incomplete, released as "finished" too early and they seem to be relying on mod support to fill out what's missing.

Il est triste de voir un studio comme "Double Fine" (Grim Fandango, BrÃ¼tal Legend), avec un ancien de LucasArts Ã  sa tÃªte (Monkey Island, DAy of the tentacles), nous proposer une expÃ©rience de jeu aussi mauvaise : tutoriel approximatif, gameplay Ã  la ramasse, une interface brouillon, des graphismes 'baveux', le tout servis avec le dynamisme d'une tortue narcoleptique sous tranxene. 

Bref ! Je vais jouer Ã  autre chose et mets range ce jeu dans ma catÃ©gorie 'dÃ©sillusion'.
column9:
It's sad to see a studio like Double Fine (Grim Fandango, Brutal Legend), headed by a former LucasArts executive (Monkey Island, Day of the Tentacles), offer us such a poor gaming experience: a sketchy tutorial, lagging gameplay, a clunky interface, sloppy graphics, all delivered with the dynamism of a narcoleptic turtle on tranxene.

Anyway! I'm going to play something else and put this game in my "disillusionment" category.

column8: DO NOT BUY! This game is a disaster in every sense of the word. For those of you who do not know the history of this game it originally was in pre-release phase but due to the failure of that pre-release, Double Fine forced the game to be "fully-released" early. Basically it's a completely unfinished game that is claimed to be fully finished, the games many features include: Very few room options with literally only one object for each room, research that does not allow you to discover any new exciting objects or rooms but instead gives you stat boosts! (Only 7 or so  research techs are even available), incredible glitches that surpass all human understanding and that persist after game restarts! what fun!, In the end you'll have done all the game has to offer in about 30 minutes and then youll slowly fall into depression as you wonder why you shelled out 10 bucks for this when that same money could have been spent on steak fajitas at Chile's...trust me your money is better spent there....or at least on stanely parable....

column8:
This game is great at destroying all of your progress in a single moment. For example: I had a base of around 30 residence and two raiders show up. Then my life support failed so everyone started paniking and running around. by the time I fixed everything, I only had three people left. There are various other issues with this game, but the other reviews should be able to show them.

Don't buy this game, get a different one that is not broken.

column8: The game has been abandoned in the Alpha stages and really it seemed like it had quite a bit going for it. But DoubleFine really screwed the pooch when it decided to do damage control on the disgruntled community. Instead of apologizing and admitting the problems they decided to ban threads, remove forum posts, and keep everything as quiet as possible. I would have been mildly upset with DF-9, but with the way DoubleFine is handling the situation I'm outright refusing to even touch anything else they make. Bad business practices don't deserve support. Vote with your monies and don't support DoubleFine.

column8: I know this game has gotten a lot of flack for being incomplete, but that was to be expected given how it was released, funded and marketed. After quickly dying a few times, I really grew to like this game. It's fun as an occassional small game to play through until you die due to some amusing glitch or something. It has so much potential, I hope someday Double Fine scrapes enough money together to get back to it and make it the wonderful game it was on the way to becoming.

column8: So I have now uninstalled the game, at 1.2 hours I have now seen everything and feel the pain the other earlyer adapors have felt. Dubblefine Did a disservice to us all and should have offered refunds. The game play is basic and its pretty fun on full speed. That is untill you forget to check the incoming ships and get wiped out in a few secounds. the roster is very basic and when people are doing there job's you really don't notice a diffrance besides mining and building. I would give this game a rating of about 4/10 and say unless you want to collect all of dubblefines games, then skip it and save your money.

column8:
The "idea" of the game was really cool so I took a chance on it in early access.  I ended up trying to like it but it ended up being more labor than "fun".  There just wasn't enough to the game.  No help tips or options to make me feel like..."hey I want to play it again tonight."  Nope.  I may give it another installl and try soon to see if it really ever became a fun game but put it this way....it's fun for about the first hour or two then sizzles away.  Oh yeah and the developer has abandoned this game so what does that tell you?

DON'T BUY!!!!!
