column8:
Originally, I had a positive review of this game.  It was an interesting start.  It was basically Dwarf Fortress in space with graphics from the list of planned features, and looked to be quite promising.  Even with what was in the game, it was at least worth playing for a couple dozen hours, even if it lacked any real depth to keep you playing for too long.  

Then, it was cancelled while still in pre-alpha...

The developer abandoned it because, as far as I can tell, they just plain didn't think it was selling well enough to be worth putting money into finishing the game.  It's kind of crushing that a company that had a positive reputation like DoubleFine would just abandon a half-made game like this.  (And for the record, my first real notification of this was that my previous positive early-access review managed to get a near-constant stream of downvotes for the simple fact that it had been a positive review...)  The "consolation prize" was that they handed out free Hack 'n' Slash games to purchasers of this game (limited time, already over), although it raises the question of why players would trust in the next early access game when the last one was abandoned...

That said, I don't have the same bitterness a lot of people seemed to have. (Likely because I don't live in hype of upcoming games when I'm sitting on a mountain of Steam games I've got in reserve.)  

As for the game, itself, it's fairly simple.  Start with nothing but a few resources, build an airlock and air recycler quick to not suffocate when your suits run out of air, build a mining station, and start mining for more resources.  From there, use resources to start making more rooms, and stuffing them full of all the random things in the menu until you have a little of everything.  Then have random visitors stay at your station, and start building MORE of everything.  Then have asteroids slam into your station (just lock everyone out of the threatened rooms), or have some raiders (set everyone to security, and bum rush them all), or have other mystery stations drift nearby (remove their walls from the outside to suck all the likely hostile inhabitants into the vacuum of space instead of letting your guys get killed). By and large, the game just lather, rinses, and repeats from there.  

If you really like managers, I can say you might have fun with it for a few hours, but don't get it unless it's absolutely dirt cheap, because you're probably going to experience everything this game really has to offer in about 6 hours or so, and from there, it's just a matter of building a base larger and larger to cram more and more population in.

column8:
There's a lot of bad blood between gamers and developers here, but all im really reading in regards to the game is that the AI needs tweaking, needs more features and a few other tweaks here and there.

Im recommending it because im developing it. DF gave us the code to edit and mod it, so thats what im doing. Progress is happening in the forums, but im a lone developer with no graphic design skills. But relax, its all coming together!

If you have positive input and would like to see this game succeed, join the forum and send a message in thread and ill see if i can add it in. http://www.doublefine.com/forums/viewforum/58/

Before anyone says it, no im not a shill for DF, I just enjoy this game, found little to no one developing it anymore and want to see it succeed. I want to fix whats broken to play a game that I'd be happy to spend a few hours playing.

-Skenners

column8:
I bought this game way early and it was $20, to this day I wouldn't pay $5 for it. I liked the potential it had, I saw all the planned features it had and it sounded amazing. However most of those features never came. Every now and then I would check up on it, then one day I wake up to Schafer saying this "[Spacebase DF-9] just not something we can afford to do any more." This is a massive dissapointment, and purchasing this would not only be a waste of money, but it would actually be insulting other early access development teams that have more promising games.

My tip: Don't buy it.

column8:
A game that had immense potential. that could be glorious, and in the end it was brought down by greed. It is abandoned by its developers, a babe to be set upon by the wolves. If they'd had any love for the project, they'd finish it. If they had any sort of community awareness, they'd let people finish it and put out unofficial patches on the workshop.

Dont buy it, not even out of sympathy

column8: While I love the potential for this game, it remains largely broken and unfinished. I got a good amount of entertainment out of it, but would not recommend it to a friend (or anyone else) on the grounds that, sooner or later, you will quit out of frustration, not because you 'finished' the game. Very sad, as there doesn't seem to be anything quite like it out there.

column8: Don't get me wrong, I like the game and have played it a bunch when it was in alpha. But unfortunately it's really not finished. It's a failed early release that went from Alpha to Release when the money ran out. Despite that, it's still being sold. On the surface it's not super obvious what happened and there are no real honest announcements from double fine. I had to hunt down forum postings to find out what happened. This is a perfect case demonstarting why it's a bad idea to fund early access, especially when they can abandon production despite the assertions that a fnished game will be delivered to those that paid. And when you have to fulfil that promise but can't, you release a mostly-working title, call it finished and move on to the next project.

column8:
A game with a lot of promise that got abandoned part way through, leaving an late-alpha-quality game labelled as "finished".  Much of the planned content never made it in, or was implemented in a shallow, nearly-negligible way.  Was very unstable and buggy for a long time; they did improve that somewhat before declaring it "finished", so that the early gameplay seems largely stable, but it still starts accumulating problems a few hours in.

A significant dissappointment.

column8: They've stated that they're abandoning the game and yet, Steam and Double Fine are still happy to take our money for an unfinished alpha? Get this shit off the store page if it's never going to be playable. I loved the premise and the gameplay was promising, but it was clearly an alpha with many bugs, poor AI and pathfinding, and a very threadbare amount of content. It could have become something wonderful, but Double Fine screwed the pooch and rather than eating their mistake, they thought they could just abandon everyone and get away with it. Well, I for one, will never purchase another double fine game. Ever. Until they let me get my money back on this shameful turd. DO. NOT. BUY. FOR. ANY. AMOUNT. OF. MONEY.

column8:
dispite everytning ive read about the game and it being ditched and blah blah blah, i actually really enjoyed this game my first attempt at wasnt...the greatest but..well...went a little something like this.

was building my base, things were going great, had a lot of people, plenty of jobs and work, got attacked by 2 raider ships one blew a hole in my wall, sucked out a couple people, the other breached and begun an assault, they killed a couple people before being killed, so I had to switch the survivors job roles to fit the needs, a technician a doctor and a builder, 2 techs 2 builders 1 doc, 1 of the techs got stuck outside the airlock, because 2 of the people went in as he tried to get back in so it liked, glitched, and locked them in, and him out, well during that time the life support went on the fritz, oxygen slowly was depleted, everyone but the tech outside the station died of asphyxiation, he got back in after they were all dead and it stopped being glitched, he fixed life support and I went about repairing damages, got one new resident made him a builder had him working on some stuff, the tech (panya) slowly went insane and he eventually popped, and started beating the shit out fo doors, my new resident (jeff) went to calm him down panya said no, they fought knocked each other out, jeff woke up first, killed panya, went to the medical bay to heal, in stasis basically, more raiders attacked, they found my reactor room my turrents in the reactor room decided shoot THROUGH the walls at the raiders blew up the walls lit the hallway on fire, fire skipped some rooms and lit the life support on fire I booted jeff out of the med bays and turned them off so he didn't just lay back in them he ran around trying to put the fire out did so went ot repair life support died of asphyxiation before needed amout of oxygen was in the room
and so my last resident died

TL;DR everyone dies at the end.

column8: Well as I have had this game for some time, i'm sad to see such... How do I put this, raw Potential in a game go to waste, the game had many features that could have been expanded upon and made to be an over all enjoyable experiance, when I first bought the game I played it and lauged at all the quirks it had, as time went on I grew annoyed by them, the way the Ai isn't polished or how the game handles Raiders and how the frequency of them is not fixed or how the simple air system, I mean the one thing this game could have used is a simple ventilation system. I also was rather upset about how a station could go good to bad in the blink of an eye, one minute my station is doing good the next there falling over dead from parasites because they won't visit the medical lab to have them removed. Over all I wouldn't even tell a person who might be interested to buy this game and support this company.
column9: Well as I have had this game for some time, i'm sad to see such... How do I put this, raw Potential in a game go to waste, the game had many features that could have been expanded upon and made to be an over all enjoyable experiance, when I first bought the game I played it and lauged at all the quirks it had, as time went on I grew annoyed by them, the way the Ai isn't polished or how the game handles Raiders and how the frequency of them is not fixed or how the simple air system, I mean the one thing this game could have used is a simple ventilation system. I also was rather upset about how a station could go good to bad in the blink of an eye, one minute my station is doing good the next there falling over dead from parasites because they won't visit the medical lab to have them removed. Over all I wouldn't even tell a person who might be interested to buy this game and support this company.

column8: A broken and unfinished game, Double Fine has fully released the game and added a mods folder, not even steam workshop support. They expect the community to repair their broken game, I enjoyed the game for the most part, that was until the raider attacks just didn't stop, sometimes it was one or two attacks, others it was five or seven at once making it impossible to survive more than a few weeks in the game. I do not recommend purchasing this game and I strongly suggest you take your money anywhere else that isn't Double Fine's pockets, I think that even EA has better games than this.

column9: I definitely recommend this game, BUT I want to say one thing: just like in the older versions, the artificial intelligence in this game is rubbish! column8:
I'll start by saying that this game has great poential but at the moment it seems imposably hard as the AI is kinda dumb and  even with a utopian sector the raiders are very frequent early on.This would not be a problem if you could direct your people to tasks rather than waiting for them to just figure it out...sometimes they never do. I've also expirenced them sufficating thenselves even when there is a built station. I've never been able to play for more than 30 minutes without everyone being killed as the security just wanders around and does nothing about threats...as I said guys, you need to be able to direct your people to jobs. 

I would reccomend this if these issues are adressed.

column8:
This game looked extremely promising. The idea of building your own space base was extremely cool, I liked the random events, the room zoning, etc, but AI is incredibly stupid, there are tons of game-breaking bugs, and after leaving this game alone for months in the hope that when I came back it would be in much better shape, I find that the devs abandoned it.

So much wasted potential. 4/10, do not buy.

column8:
Spacebase DF9â€™s 2,859 â€œmostly negativeâ€ reviews (at the time of writing) are probably more a testament to Steamâ€™s ubiquity as a content delivery tool than to the gameâ€™s own (very real) problems. And it does have problems, to be sure, but depending on your outlook and how much you pay for it, theyâ€™re not insurmountable.

Its gameplay appears at first to be something along the lines of the legendary Dwarf Fortress, Mucky Footâ€™s 2001 classic Startopia, or Firefly Studiosâ€™  2003 Space Colony, but its flaws â€“ the result of a suddenly-abandoned development process â€“ make it play more like a Roguelike. Your rather nebulous goal is to re-populate the galaxy by building endless space stations, staffing them with an ever-increasing supply of wandering space travellers and keeping them happy and safe from weird diseases, bloodthirsty raiders and each other. Material for building comes from mining asteroids or disassembling passing wrecks and derelicts, and your rooms and corridors are built and then assigned different uses â€“ residential, life support, various social, scientific and utilitarian functions. Thereâ€™s a strong people-management aspect too, as each new arrival at your base can be assigned to one of eight different duties, each of which will make them feel varying degrees of satisfaction or frustration, and each of which theyâ€™ll be good or bad at according to a 1-5 star system. In all respects, the UI is super friendly and makes juggling your people as easy as possible. Which is great, because you can eventually build gigantic structures with literally dozens and dozens and dozens of crewmembers. Crucially though, you have almost zero direct control over your people. You can only order them to report to the infirmary if theyâ€™re injured, and even then it may take them a while to limp their way over.

At first, as you learn the ropes, each new game comes hard and fast. Death comes as a result of being ill-prepared to research a disease cure, or not having sufficient defences against a surprise Raider attack, or for any one of dozens of interestingly unfortunate and unforeseeable reasons (usually often as funny as they are frustrating). But the actual process of making your space stations is so much fun that the urge to immediately try again keeps you clicking, again and again, learning more and more each time, developing and abandoning new ideas and strategies as you go. Spacebase DF 9 is very much one of those Civ/Morrowind-type games that suck the hours out of your life without you realising. Be prepared for some really late nights if you decide to have â€˜just one quick goâ€™ before bedtime.

Adding to this feeling is the gameâ€™s own save system, which by default consists of toggle-able silent autosaves and a Save and Quit menu option. Like a psychopathic lover, Spacebase DF9 doesnâ€™t want you to be anywhere other than inside it, grinding at full speed. Played like this, the feeling is very much of a  Roguelikeâ€™s â€˜one life, one deathâ€™ trip, and all of this helps mitigate the pain of being screwed by one of the gameâ€™s terrible bugs or imbalances.

Yes, they are quite terrible, unfortunately. But in the twenty hours that Iâ€™ve played it so far, the problems have been all about imbalance and lack of tweaking, rather than outright bugs. One of the worst of these is the fact that the guns on enemy ships, once theyâ€™ve boarded you, remain â€˜hostileâ€™ even after youâ€™ve killed or captured the invaders (sometimes they can even be reformed and will join your crew to start a new life), or claimed their ship as your own. Only by eventually disassembling enough of the enemy ship will you be able to cut off power to the gun, thus making it safe. But getting to the bloody thing can be a real game-breaker â€“ these defensive turrets have great range and cut through people in spacesuits like a lightsabre through yogurt. Itâ€™s at times like these that the lack of direct control over your spacemen becomes a real tooth-grinder, and you can end up with piles and piles of floating corpses made up of the Builders who foolishly crossed in front of the guns to get behind them (in space, the AI paths in direct lines from point-to-point), as well as the Doctors who went to retrieve their corpses. 

As far as imbalance in the invisible numbers, the worst offender is the near-constant brawling that goes on. At best this leads to a trip to the brig to cool off for the aggressor and a trip to the infirmary for the victim. At worst, guns will be drawn, and people and facilities start falling. In-fighting is a result of a brilliant system of cabin fever that is determined by various things, including job satisfaction and a host of actual personal feelings and emotions, all of which can be monitored on the crewâ€™s individual profiles. Assigning two people who hate each other to a double cabin is a recipe for disaster, while the sight of bloody corpses littering the place has an obvious impact on depression (especially if the deceased was someoneâ€™s friend). But again, due to the abruptly aborted development process, itâ€™s one of several crucial, glaringly imbalanced systems. Which, unless Double Fine release the source code, as theyâ€™ve promised to but still not yet done, may never be properly sorted out. This is doubly frustrating because a lua-based modding system is present and correct, but so far nobodyâ€™s done anything with it.

Like the similarly blighted and similarly great fun Aliens: Colonial Marines, itâ€™s a game with a bad reputation that in reality is only partially deserved. Early adopters and those who saw the potential for a Dwarf Fortress in space have every right to be annoyed (and to make those thousands of â€œnegativeâ€ Steam reviews). But for those of us coming to the game in its â€˜finishedâ€™ state, and aware of the lingering problems, there is still much fun to be had. Double Fineâ€™s original plan for the game was hugely ambitious, ultimately requiring much more funding than they could successfully raise for it (hence the truncated development). It was only unfortunate that they had already taken it well into the Early Access phase at USD 20 a pop before they realised this. But thatâ€™s one of the risks of public alphas, crowdfunding and transparent game development. Like condoms, no one's happy when they go wrong. 

If weâ€™re looking at it in financial terms, then in my case I bought it in the 2015 Steam summer sale at -50%, or EUR 4.99, and have played it now for nearly 21 hours. My feeling is that Iâ€™ve had at least 20 Euros of fun from it, and thatâ€™s quite important. With some AAA titles costing nearly 60 Euro-dollarpounds and offering dozens of hours of gameplay, but failing to deliver even half as much fun, for a flawed gem like Spacebase DF9 to give you that elusive feeling of true, full-belly satisfaction is, I think, quite a feat.

column8:
This "game" is not worth your time.  The developer and publisher could not be bothered to complete it.  Labelling a game 1.0 does not make it so.  It would be inappropriate for me to speculate where the money that was donated to funding the project went to or what it was actually used for but if the state of the game is an indication it wasn't allocated where it should have been.

The only reason you might consider paying money for this is if you are a skilled modder and want to prove your ability to the gaming industry.  It would be very impressive if you could create a release worthy program out of this monument to mediocrity.  Can you accomplish what $400k+ and a bevy of yesterday's news hipsters could not?

column8:
It is a game with amazing potential, it's really fun when you see past the wealth of bugs and the other mechanics issues, most notably the character AI, who will eat a snack while being shot at, or build instead of fighting raiders. Raiders who appear far to frequently, every 5 minutes it feels as if a raider comes to ruin everything you have just made and due to the derpy ai, you can do little to stop them.

Past all of this it is a really fun building game in space, I would recommend to anyone who likes building and can deal with bugs and setbacks at every corner.

column9:
What can I say about this game? The idea is good, but the application is much less so.
This game is addictive, which is its strong point. Personally, I like the idea, but I deplore the numerous AI issues, the pathfinding, and the over-the-top management.
In short, luckily it was given to me as a gift, otherwise I would have been very upset to lose â‚¬10 for this.

column8:
A grate idea that showed endless promise, up until it was axed my Double Fine after Alpha 6. That's right; the game was released as a 'finished' product before it even went into bata!

I enjoyed my time with the game, even in its unfinished state, but given how it was shamelessly shoved out the door and given a price slash to entice in new players who had yet to see what a half-baked product they were buying into, I cannot recommend this game in good faith, nor can I even say that you should pick up the game if you think it might appeal to you if you don't mind a lack of polish.

As a moral consumer, I strongly advise you to NOT give money to this game! Even on sale, when a 5$ USD price tag might be reasonable, it is an utterly disgusting example of a once grate company using its good name to exploit its fans.

column8:
Saw all the negative press for the game, so I waited until it was less than $5. 

Wow it is really sad to see how AMAZING this could have been with, like, an extra year of indie development. Or, hell, maybe even just a few months more.

The art is great and the mechanics work fine. It's hard at first, but then you get your base starting to work, some hydroponics, a nice little bar, and your colonists go from mildly sad to somewhat happy.

*Then* what?

They added in these achievements but they don't feel worth the effort. The colonists have tons of traits and thoughts and everything, but ... What do they amount to? Why should I care? They don't really affect anything other than how pissy they get over time.

Raiders stomped my first base, but then I realized I just need a turret minding the entrance, and boom, problem almost entirely solved.

There are so few objects, with so little placing options, you can't even really decorate it. The colonists don't even mop up blood from fights that break out.

I understand now why everyone was so disappointed. I just don't understand why they would make such a fantastic foundation, if they weren't gonna build on it.

I give it 4 sad faces out of 4. Couldn't even keep me mildly amused for more than a few hours (the rest was added on when I paused it to get up and go AFK for a bit).

column8:
BUY AT YOUR OWN RISK: UNFINISHED
Such a good concept and game.................for an early access one that is.

It was sadly abandoned by double fine. It will never be finshed.
I bought this game cause it was a great early access concept and game. But its now fully released and its still as it was an alpha.

Its unfinshed other than that.

It plays well, great concept and idea of running your own space station from scratch and watching it crumble cause you let one person in or broke the wrong wall or no fire extingushers. You pick a spot in the galaxy hoping to find a perfect place for mining and saftey.
Its fun but its unfinshed.

Hey its got a 100% mod support cause the devs abandoned it and released the soruce code hopping modders will clean up their unfinshed promises.

So if its cheap ok go ahead have some fun, but its more unfished than rust.
At least rust have a chance of being finshed though, this will never however.

column8:
I don't normally give reviews, But, Ill make an Exception given how terrible this utter waste of Disk space is.

First off, I bought this game about 7 Months ago, (So i can't get a Refund for it), So, I'm now stuck with a Â£19.99 hole in my Wallet.

If like me, You looked at this game and thought, ''Hey, This looks kind of cool'', You were mistaken, What you are buying into, Is a Bug Ridden game with Poorly Designed gameplay, Completely ridden with bugs. All of which, Would be fine, If the Dev team was working on it, But, Oh, Yeah, I forgot, The Dev's have done absolutely nothing on this game since November 2014.

And incase you were wondering, The patch they did back in november, Was not good, It essentially added in loads of broken, Terrible mechanics that completely broke an already not good game, Not its just not playable, Seriously, Do not buy this game, Its terrible.

With the Dev team essentially walking away from this game with all the money of their supportrs, You would only be giving those thieves money if you payed for this, Do yourself a Favour and pick up a Different space game ;).

Gameplay - 3/10
Dev Team - 1/10
Bug Support - 1/10
Waste of money - 11/10

column8:
Spacebase DF-9. Games like this make me sad, it had so much promise. Now? Now it's just buggy and unfinished. I'll happy tell you now dear reader: don't even pirate this game, its not worth the downloads. The only thing this game has got is it's graphics. That's all.

I played less then 30 minutes, i didn't even get passedthe totorial. Not because it was hardbut becuase it wasn't good. It was a window in the bottom left corner telling me what to do. and everything was unloacked in the totorial from the start.

This game also has very little in the way of content. By this I mean there's not much to it. For example i only saw one generator and no alternitives. And everything's really basic too. Life support's just a structure that you put into the life support room.
Also the NPCs aren't great, they randomly do stuff like exercise in the hallways... and doorways. No really, i have someone doing push-ups in the doorway to the generator room. That bring me to another NPC related point: they're annimations. usually when I play games this is never a big problem but with Spacebase I suddenly had many problems. The annimations don't seem one bit natual, or smooth.
Now I know alot of people found this had more bugs than a garden, but the only noticable one i found was when NPCs left the station via the airlock they only went though one door. That door was to get into the airlock, everytime someone left i just had to sit there in horror because the floor kept eating them.

This game work about as well dirty underpants with no elastic. Did i meantion it was $20? this game should be removed from steam altogether. I'm glad this came in an indi bundle.

column8:
[h1]The first 'promising' Early Access game[/h1]
Double Fine had [url=https://archive.is/irRiB]lot's of plans[/url] for Spacebase DF-9. The game those plans outlined would be [b]well[/b] worth the $20â‚¬ price.
As development continued however, more and more of those plans [url=https://archive.is/RBCBP]were laid to rest[/url] and in the end a very select few were ever realized. As such, the game as it stands, is just nowhere close to being worth the price, and should've been priced more like Hack'n'Slash, the game it's being bundled with now, is priced.

Spacebase DF-9 is a perfect example of a phenomenon that continues to this day: wholly unfinished but 'promising' alphas on Early Access.
As Steam's own documentation states, both developers and customers should treat Early Access games as they are know, not as what they might one day become. Devs shouldn't sell promises, and customers shouldn't buy them. But alas, here we are.

I regret buying into Double Fine's promises during Early Access. Because of the few genuinely good games they've put out, it's easy to forget Double Fine's catalogue is more '[i]miss[/i]' than '[i]hit[/i]', Spacebase DF-9 being a prime example of that fact.

[h1]Bottom line[/h1]
Only buy Spacebase DF-9 if you want to support Double Fine. Even then, it might be better to just buy a DF t-shirt or something, rather than to inflate the sales numbers of this mediocre dissapointment.

column8:
This game is quite possibly the worst Pre-Release game I have ever played. I hav eowned it since inception, and the biggest issues were never rectified.

The primary issue i have with this game is the fact that you may queue something up to be done, but nobody may ever get around to doingit. 

Hostile encounters tend to happen early, and often result in losing at least one critical creew member. Diseases are rampant in early game, and controlling your crew is impossible.

I have 10 hours on record playing this gaem, and will never play another minute. You can spend an entire hour on a single session of the game, and end up losing your entire crew to something rediculous. 

DO NOT BUY!

And NEVER PRE-RELEASE BUY ANYTHING.

I never will again.

(Note: The Devs made this game 1.0 while it was still missing about 20-% of the promised features.)

column8: Loved the game.  Really enjoyed it.  Unfortunately it simply quit working.   I'd invest time and effort in building, and it would simply die.  Restart, reboot, re-install, delete saves, nothing returns this pile of garbage software to working order.  Not only will I never buy a double-fine developed game again, but I'll probably never buy another early access game.  Shame, it was a nice game idea and had great potential, and I would have paid MORE for continued development, but alas... jerks up and quit.  Do not buy this game or any early access game, or any game from this game studio.

column8:
I think what hurts the most about this game is the completely wasted potential. When updates were actively coming out it seemed pretty realistic to expect a very well made if modest game. The art assets were there, what had been worked on and put in the game was of a reasonably high quality with some later updates excepted, the sound seemed like time and effort went into making it fit the tone of the overall game. Somewhere, this all fell through at the last minute.

I know Double Fine has to find a way to pay the bills, so cutting the project to work on something more lucrative is the smart thing to do for them. Leaving it on the store and calling it 'finished' to try and squeeze it for cash is simply ridiculous though. They could have easily left it in early access and said something along the lines of "We need to work on some other games to generate revenue. We'll leave the game on Early Access and when we've made enough money on additional early supporters we'll continue development." and I wouldn't have batted an eyelash. There's a pretty distinct line between putting a hold on development and blatantly releasing a mess as a finished product in a crass attempt to get more money.

I'm not mad that you ran out of money. I'm not mad the game is unfinished. I'm mad that you're taking advantage of your audience and lying to them.

column8:
For shame, Double Fine. After Psychonauts I was thrilled to see this release. But after your decision to take your money and tell us all 'Oh-well, so sad'... That was some truly cutthroat business. Sadly, your managers will probably go on to make similar decisions, but it's your name they dragged through the mud, and I will never purchase another Double Fine title.

The game had promise, but the bugs make it practically unplayable. There's no real way to stop rampaging citizens, as the jail system doesnt seem to do anything about their attitudes. Wounded people will lie around on the ground because the Medics cant be directed to go to them and will instead carry on about their daily lives, meanwhile everyone takes a morale hit. 

Would have been fun, but as you can see from the nosedive in reputation the game has taken, "would have been" doesnt sell games.

column9:
An abandoned, unfinished game. With little content. And yet, it could have been good. The developers promised a lot but didn't deliver.

The gameplay doesn't change as you progress. There's nothing engaging about it. There are no complex production chains. No developed combat. No solid tech tree. All it has are basic mechanics, and they work, maybe a bit unstable at times, but they work. But there's simply nothing to do. This game doesn't hold a candle to Dwarf Fortress or even Gnomoria. It has a low development ceiling; once you've established food production, built a bar, a med bay, and a gym, there's not much else to do. Yes, there are raiders, but they're pretty boring, and there's no particularly complex tactics or strategy against them. Yes, with constant population growth due to migration, you'll need to constantly build new living quarters and expand food production, but this is essentially a dull repetition of the previous actions. All subsequent hours of gameplay will be similar to the first, and even easier.

column8: I followed this game during its early access, and I really liked the way it was going. However, I feel that the game was never really completed, and a lot of features were left unpolished. I find the clunky interface to be the games biggest problem. If they had continued to develop it, I'm sure it would have been a marvelous game, but as it stands, I can't recommend it. At least not at that price.

column8:
I played a little of the Beta and enjoyed it, so I though once I waited and tried the game at full release, it'd be even better. And it was, for a time. But I kept getting the feeling that it didn't feel like a finished product. There were plenty of nuances that irked me and I had no control over that often left me starting a new game because my citizens were no better than lemmings as they both walked continuously to their deaths. Combat was pretty poor, as your security rarely won in any fight they got into.

Then came the great raider raid, which killed my measly group(I had only had a few hours to do anything before it came, and the area I chose was supposed to be low in hostility.) So that and finding out it was abandonware was a big slap in the face by the devs.

Hopefully, in a few years, someone will pick this up, fix the bugs and flesh it out and turn it into a game actually worth the money you spent for it. Until then, DO NOT BUY. I already regret it, and I got it on a cheap sale.

The game is unpolished and full of bugs. (For example, if you choose a sector with a very low pirate attack rate, you will actually be constantly attacked by pirates.)

column8:
While there are still many issues in Spacebase DF-9(such as bugs, outdated graphics, and so on), despite the years of production and work, I understand that this is still an incomplete product. Therefore I am not reviewing this game as a complete product, but rather I am reviewing its creative process. As a building management and construction simulator, Spacebase DF-9 fails the most important criterion in any simulation, uniqueness. Uniqueness is a core aspect in simulation games because it is there in which specialties and creativity come together to make an enjoyable and memorable simulation game. Examples of popular simulation games are Goat Simulator, The Sims, and Train Simulator, which all can be easily identified by each of their unique points. That being said, it is hard to find unique points in Spacebase DF-9. As I am writing this review, in trying to remember things that were unique I find myself fixated more on the bugs than actual gameplay. 

Overlooking the bugs, let me break down the gameplay. You build a base, gather resources, and make the base bigger and repeat. You have raiders that attack your base but they donâ€™t present a threat if you properly maintain security. You have asteroid showers that happen every once in a while that start fires and destroy structures such as walls and they need to be patched up. You will get transmissions every once in a while so that people can move in, attack, or attach themselves to the base. The difficulty ramps up as your base becomes larger and more populated; you have to keep track of peopleâ€™s morale, energy consumption, and security.  That is about it. 

As I have stated earlier, it lacks uniqueness. The simulation itself is very basic and there seems to be a large amount of creative work in creating the characters. Unfortunately, the programmers made the characters expandable, having them die very easily and having a lot of them makes the characters feel insignificant and therefore, their uniqueness insignificant. As a simulation, this game will not stand out in sales or reviews unless the creative department decides to do some major reworking. Furthermore if unchanged and published, this game will stand out as one of many examples of morale hazard in pre-release gaming. 

 [u] Note:[/u] As I was about to post this I realized that this game was published a year ago. I could not fathom that a game this unpolished and lacking in content could be deemed complete by anyone who took pride in their work. In the end, it seems that DoubleFine just took everyoneâ€™s money and fled.

It's a waste of money, and that steam is selling this for 20bucks is ridiculous.


EDIT October 8 2015:

An update rolled out and the game now actually works, I'm greatly enjoying this even though it's mostly basic base building with not too much to do other than assign people to mine, food, build and maintenance. 

It's fun but gets kind of dull after a while, I'm now changing my review to positive only due to the fact something has changed and it actually works in an enjoyable way.

This game is a lot of fun! I like the base building, I like all my people walking about and talking and living their own lives, I like being able to 'absorb' docking derelicts.

But I can't reccomend it whole heartedly because ONE defense turret on an attached derelict killed 80% of my crew because they tried to glide past. I had claimed the whole derelict, but there's no easy way to deactivate those turrets. My entire game flushed down the drain because of one turret.

column8:
To put it plainly; I loved this game. "Loved" being the key word. The devs abandoned this game. It had great potential and much promise, but they threw all of that away. I'm deeply disappointed.

If you want to buy this game, by all means, do so. At a discount. Never for full price. Because why should you? It's not finished, and it never will be. So why should you pay full price for something that isn't even finished?

Again, it isn't a shit game. In my opinion anyways. It's just not finished. So expect bugs. Expect crashes. Expect a ton of nasty shit to happy and be there. 

Anyways, I cannot recommend this game because it isn't finished. 

in summary: What was once 4/5 is now 1/5. DO NOT BUY UNLESS IT IS ON A GOOD* SALE. The end.

*A sale being at least 75%+

column8:
Unfortunately this game is a bit of a disaster. DoubleFine supposedly had to cancel this game and release a final version early after finding this game to be uneconomical. A shame.

Time for the good/bad/ugly.

The Good:
[list]
[*]The art style is nice
[*]Oxygen simulation works well
[*]Characters have moods and these change according to what happens
[/list]

The Bad:
[list]
[*]General lack of features; boredom does not take long.
[*]Building a large base is not difficult, merely very time-consuming.
[/list]

The Ugly:
[list]
[*]The AI. DEAR GOD.
[*]Seriously, half of the time people don't do their &!â‚¬$@# jobs.
[*]I'm not kidding. Characters manage to kill themselves REGULARLY.
[/list]

Don't buy this unless you love bad games (also source code is now free according to comments)

column8:
There is nothing more infuriating than an almost good game.  I really like the concept and mostly still had fun playing it.  The game has an annoying tendency for bases to implode (figuratively) for no discernible reason ruining hours of work. The game has no easy ability to save and as far as I can tell no way to have multiple games at the same time.  People are made of tissue paper.  Fights break out and the player has very little control as the denizens pummel each other unconscious.  I have had airlock glitch and deplete the air in the base and suffocate people. I have had people run screaming past fire-extinguishers while their co-worker's burn.  The lack of ability to prioritize building often leaves a room only a single floor tile left to be constructed.

If the issues that make it un-playable were fixed then I would change my recommendation but until then a waste of money.

column8:
Even if you get DF-9 very cheap (like I did) and not expect a lot, you will be disappointed.
It's kind of a space station sim alright, but
1.) the gameplay does not have any depth to it - hardly any resources to balance etc.
2.) it just feels bland and boring after a very short time, there are no goals / challenges
3.) it's bugged. not in a "it crashes" way, but in a "it constantly kills your space station with peculiar mechanics details" way.

What do I mean with that? 2 Examples:
In the tutorial mission, I ordered the removal of a wall. Funny enough, the floor got removed as well (the difference between the 2 available remove/disintegrate commands was not explained", so I had a hull breach in the corridor.  To fix that, one of my builders would have needed to use an airlock - which was on the other side of the corridor. Result: dead end, start a new station.
On the new station, I build the most important new structures (generator room, oxygen source, airlock). Unfortunately, all 3 residents randomly ended up on the outside of the airlock, making it impossible to finish building it. Everybody suffocates. Or maybe the airlock did get finished, but failed to operate because all 3 tried to use it at the same time... I don't know, I will not try to find out. And I will not start a new game.

Funny thing is, from reading comments here, I now know that in the less than 2 hours tutorial play, I have already seen everything there is in this game. The only thing that would have been left for me is build the space station bigger with more of the same kinds of room. I thought I was too stupid to make proper use of the "derelic vessel" parts, but it turns out it's because they are useless.

Well, time to move on.

column8:
This game is probably the most notorious vaporware game in Steam history. The developers at Doublefine were on a roll with a great game, and out of nowhere cancelled the project without finishing the game due to funding issues. Not to mention they didn't even open up Steam workshop support so Steam users could finish it for them. 

The worst part is that it was a fun game a couple versions before Doublefine abandoned the project. However, when they abandoned the project they released a final patch that sends swarms of raiders to attack your base so frequently you can't build, and your citizens are constantly sad or angry. It's unplayable now because you can't send your citizens outside your base to build,mine,explore,etc without them being killed. And I'll point out that this is in the Extremely Low threat areas of the galaxy map. To me this seems like a final insult to all of the people who paid good money for what was a good game. 

I for one will never purchase anything from Doublefine again, and I can't see how this could fix their "funding" issues because the PR nightmare of this game has killed their reputation. My recommendation to Doublefine is to reopen this project and satisfy their customers, as it's the only way they will save their company. 

My recommendation to anyone thinking of purchasing this game in it's current state, is don't!

column8:
I've finally decided to give the "release" version a full go. After completing most of the goals in the game I've come to a conclusion:

DF-9 does not hold up to its promise. Not by a long shot.

Aside from the fact that fact that Double Fine abandoned (I do actually understand their situation) the game long before their planned goals had been implemented, the unfortunate truth is that what we do have isn't finished either.

Most prominently the power system. Without an actual power meter (like we have for O2) your base will just suddenly lose power if you've built too much. You have no useful way of knowing when to build another reactor. The devs expect you to hover your mouse over each and every room and sum up the power consumption in your head each time you want to take inventory.

Next up is the "story" of the game. One of the last versions must have shoehorned this in because I don't remember it from Alpha5. Basically at some point the game will spontaneously throw multiple raider ships and raider astronauts at you in bulk. I've you've managed to build your base accordingly by then: congratulations for figuring out the simple and boring strategy needed. If you haven't? Well, you can start all over again.

Then as you continue to play and expand your base to meet the other goals you'll notice how the game becomes increasingly glitchy.

And speaking of goals: The "build all the things" goal isn't even possible. I tried. I built everything there is and allegedly I'm still missing something.

I've finally decided to give the "release" version a full go. After completing most of the goals in the game I've come to a conclusion:

DF-9 does not hold up to its promise. Not by a long shot.

Aside from the fact that fact that Double Fine abandoned (I do actually understand their situation) the game long before their planned goals had been implemented, the unfortunate truth is that what we do have isn't finished either.

Most prominently the power system. Without an actual power meter (like we have for O2) your base will just suddenly lose power if you've built too much. You have no useful way of knowing when to build another reactor. The devs expect you to hover your mouse over each and every room and sum up the power consumption in your head each time you want to take inventory.

Next up is the "story" of the game. One of the last versions must have shoehorned this in because I don't remember it from Alpha5. Basically at some point the game will spontaneously throw multiple raider ships and raider astronauts at you in bulk. I've you've managed to build your base accordingly by then: congratulations for figuring out the simple and boring strategy needed. If you haven't? Well, you can start all over again.

Then as you continue to play and expand your base to meet the other goals you'll notice how the game becomes increasingly glitchy.

And speaking of goals: The "build all the things" goal isn't even possible. I tried. I built everything there is and allegedly I'm still missing something.

column8:
(I wanted to redo my review for a better viewpoint and whatnot. This review also comes from someone who played early access, and played post realease)

I can say, that the concept for this game was great! A spacebase that half the time acts nicely, and runs like clockwork, then raiders show up and wreck s**t up. I was really excited when I heard this, and boughtit in early access. When I bought the game, I thought it was doing quite well for an early access game, and I enjoyed it!

But, there were some signs that the game development was having problems. Updates, weeks and sometimes months apart. And these updates were adding barely anything to the game, and even bug fixing was quite slow. The AI, was and still is unbearable. And will do stupid things. The variety of things you can build in specific rooms is extremly limited.

And, of course, this game was pushed out the door, being realeased way to early. An example, was that your station's power supply. That was not even a factor until the update before realease. Reasearch was the same story, the update before realease. And the tech tree is pretty much worthless in the game anyway. If you looked at the planned features for this game, they say that they were possible ideas, but some of the content they said were possible are needed in this kind of game!

My last words on this are, Don't buy this piece of shit, in fact, don't buy any sort of thing from Double Fine, unless you can at least make sure that production will finish on the game fully

2/10- Fun for an hour or two, but no storyline, not enought content, and lack of any new things happening after half an hour of gameplay, makes this game awful. Classic example of why you should buy early access games unless they are dirt cheap and you like the idea, or if you have a undying love in your heart for a concept that someone using early access is trying to make. 

Long story short- STAY AWAY!!!

column8:
After reporting a number of bugs during the beta and finding out they "dumped" any and all support for fixing all the issues they created, after all the promises they made regarding contents and then falling short after a year by breaking those promises by lumping all of it on to modders to do their work (and didn't even bother giving a proper source or knowlegebase on modding) and after hearing the huge excuse they ran out of funds and are moving on to other projects...

I suggest people avoid this broken title for what it is. A bunch of promises built on a faulty engine left to the players to fix what they broke. Don't give them your money, you'll simply regret it.

column8:
Now this is the very definition of a disappointment: there it was, a game concept that was absolutely bang on with all the bones to turn it in to a bit of a powerhouse colony building game and then... nothing.
Literally... not a sausage.
They did their final polish, which really wasn't that shiny, and then the whole concept, engine and general U.I. has been entirely ignored and dumped and at the price they were asking for at the time it was a masssive slap in the face.  More so to those of us that have a harrowing love for all that is Double Fine.
It's maddening!
One day they put their love in to games like Psychonauts and Iron Brigade with DLC that's worth a damn and then they drop a clanger like this and without a single explanation why (or at elast none that I can fathom).
But then I pick up Hack 'n' Slash which is some properly INSPIRED gaming.  I loved that.  It's like they got bored and skipped on merrily.

I want to like Spacebase DF-9, and in some ways I really do, but I can't, in good conscience, suggest to another person to purchase this game because it is clearly not finished at all.  Perhaps, in the fullness of time, someone might come back to it, or a fanbase works the source code to turn this game in to something beautiful (and then get Double Fine to publish for them - it's the least they could do, imo...) but until then I'm going to warn players away from this game.

If you're looking for something mildly similar, there's The Spatials on Steam, Rimworld and Sol 0 that, at the time of this review, are still entirely independant.  I'm utterly loving Rimworld.  But not this... :(

column8:
One to Avoid. See Towns /Godus as an example why

It was overfunded by three times its requested KS value, DF development pace was ploddingly slow and then they claimed they had run out of money. This all before they implemented the significant portion of the game (At the time they had barely gotten Oxygen balance working).

The game itself, is basic.

You plop down a square box room, stick a "magical" oxygen generator and a power generator. Oxygen pushes your people out of airlocks if theyre built badly. Combat is buggy and broken, as are the "hidden" space wrecks you can come across.

column8:
Despite not having spent much time playing this game, it was an immediate diappointment from what was originally promised.  I had originally purchased this during Early Access, which of course, always means a certain risk the game will not be completed.  That is exactly what transpired with this particular title.  Essentially, the developers were unable to raise enough money to continue to support the game, so it was rushed into release.

As I enjoy sci-fi sandbox games, this title had tremendous potential, but failed to deliver.  What little time I have spent playing the game have made it obvious it is an incomplete product.  As it appears no additional development will be transpiring, or it will be slowed to a creeping halt, I recommend avoiding this particular title unless something changes.

column8:
Early access should really mean "early access to a finished product".

This was not the case.

It looked nice, had a good vibe, and I was following it pretty keenly. Then the people who made it gave up. I can understand their reasons. Things went wrong, they can't be expected to work at a loss. It's frustrating for all concerned. I can't recommend it, as it's unfinished, but I can understand how everyone, developer and customer lost out here. That's the nature of the beast I guess, it's just pure bad luck and bad planning.

I hope lessons were learned, and wish them the best in the future. Maybe if they have success with something else down the line, they could revisit it and pay back the funders one day?

column8:
The game could have been good but its so broken beyond belief I can't believe it.

So you can't control the citizens in any capacity, so whether or not CRUCIAL jobs get done is based entirely on whether or not the broken clunky AI wants to actually do it.

I cannot tell you how many games I have lost because the AI refused to get back into the station and simply floated aimlessly around in space until they suffocated.

Beyond that, you run out of shit to do absurdly quickly there is no goal, no mission, no midgame, no endgame it's painfully obvious that Double Fine has abandoned the game (saying its finished) as a means to save face and avoid backlash and run away with the Kickstarter and Early Access Cash they got given.

Fuck this game, get Rimworld or Startopia, do not get this game.

If the game were given more content and fewer raiders, the game would actually be good. I only got it as a gift, otherwise I would never have bought it.

column9:
A huge thank you to Rainbow Dash, who's disappeared from my friends list, for this wonderful game!
It's a really hardcore game, especially when you're just starting out: space pirates, meteor showers, famine, and even power outages :D
What I enjoyed most about this game was following the characters, their dialogue, and their personalities (I even lost sometimes because of it :D)
Overall, it's a great game, I recommend it!
10/10 Dead Raiders

column9:
The game's premise: Build a space base and provide its inhabitants with everything they need.
The game's concept is excellent. And the start seems good. But there's glitch after glitch.
It starts with the astronauts being unable to fly into the chamber to enter the station. They're just hanging there, slowly dying. Okay. Somehow they've gotten to the base. We start developing. Building. And then raiders start arriving in droves. And they're killing everything and everyone. Even if I learn to defend myself against them, like setting up turrets everywhere. Then another plague begins. The engineers, who are supposed to maintain the base, simply do nothing. As a result, everything starts falling apart. The power goes out. And the base dies, and it's beyond saving. Okay, we somehow survive and get more than 45 inhabitants. And then, bam! Constant freezes and, ultimately, the game starts crashing every 5 minutes.
Basically, this game can't really be called a release. It's more like a beta.

column8:
This is not what I would expect from Tim Schafer or Doublefine.

There is not enough game here to be worth the money. Many of the features that were originally promised have been dropped.

Developer seems to have just washed their hands of the project and moved on.  Still has some bugs.

column8: To be honest, I was entirely satisifed with it's progress as it was being made. Fairly reguar updates adding lots of new content and improvements... and then out of nowhere they "launched" straight from Alpha. I have to imagine that this was a hard choice on their part, and left a lot of hard working devs sad that they'd never get to see the finished product. It can be fun, but it's not nearly finished and super buggy, so while I apprecate the effort, I couldn't advise spending more than 5 dollars on it max.

column8:
I really wanted to like this game. I saw it featured very early on and picked it up. It was ok, there was a decent core game, but there were some bugs/glitches etc.

This was when the developers were updating the game.

Since that time, there have been very few, limiting updates. To my mind, there is no real point to the game. The whole thing about choosing where to have your base is very cool, but in reality there is little to no difference. There are lots of rooms you can put down, which is great, but I can find nothing to do apart from put all the rooms down and defend myself against the waves of baddies.
Which leads us onto another problem: Combat
If I was to be nice, I would say that the combat was... flawed. The truth of the matter is that even when you assign people to security, and give them a place the have to defend, if they are talking or playing a game or eating etc, they will simply ignore you while the baddies are quite happily blowing the c*** out of your base.

There are many bugs with game, including the priorities problem as outlined above. This was ok when the game was in development, but now that the developers seems to have abandoned it, there are too many for it to be considered a full game. 

That basically sums up my review. It had promise, but there is not enough actual game or polish for it to be considered a complete game. Save some money, go and buy Prison Architect or donate to/download Dwarf Fortress.

I really want them to keep working on it.

column8: It needs to be fixed, updated and it needs a steam workshop, if the creators of this game won't fix it let the modders fix it. I was sadden that this game was not what I hoped for. You have to build fast because your first three 'helpers' run out of oxygen fast. Power and oxygen are the hardest to maintain. People die fast and raiders don't make it any easier, they attack sometimes right off the bat before you even get started.

column8: It's fun, but only for all of a few hours. Maybe it'll be worth a few bucks, if you don't mind trying to micromanage horribly idiotic and suicidal NPCs which aren't designed to be micromanaged. Whatever else I would say has been aid many times over in the other negative reviews. The game was never completed, it was abandoned in development and what you have here are the fragments. It could be a great game if someone were to finish programing it.

column8: The game has a lot of potential and it could be great with few fixes like the raider frequency as they show up way to much and you can lose your whole base within 15 mins, also starting credits is laughable since you need 3 areas to start, and have just enough to make areas small enough to just supply your starting base but make any room too big and you have no way of fixing it. Developers are not working on the game anymore and it shows, seems they want the community to make mods to make their game playable. After playing through and getting to a point where I thought everything would be going well I got attacked by 40 raiders and lost the whole game, and without a save system I wasn't able to save anything and so everything ended because of a useless system and poor programing.

column8:
When I first saw it,  I was amazed. I love Dwarf Fortress. I love Tim Schafer. This game couldn't fail.

In Oct 2013, they released a roadmap for the game. The roadmap was paraphrased by me b/c of word limit in review.

This is the roadmap they gave:

FOOD
deleted the info for review

CARRYABLE OBJECTS
* citizens visibly carry around arbitrary sprite/3D objects
* citizens can stash stuff in an inventory
* when people arrive, they have a suitcase 
* players build shelves for people to put their stuff on
* a single item of stuff can have multiple tags describing it. citizens have affinities for these tags
* citizens trade stuff w/ each other
* roaming traders will visit the base 
* "litter" objects that citizens w/ low neatness personality throw away
* janitors pick up litter
* janitors clean up bloodstains, body parts, other cosmetic damage

POWER SYSTEM
* unpowered rooms go dark (emergency lighting) & objects in them don't function
* reactors only produce X power, then you have to build another
* factor new need for reactors into starting matter allotment

MINIMAP
deleted the info for review

BASE HISTORY SCREEN
* a permanent timestamped list of important base events: citizen joined, citizen died, ship docked, etc
* in-game screenshot key that pops up a "write a caption for this screenshot" box, screenshot + caption is added to the timestamped list
* base history is stored locally in save dir as HTML + linked images, each base has its own dir
* base history is also mirrored on a hosted server

BASE STATS SCREEN
* auto-show stats screen after base fails, ie everyone dies, "game over" state

MULTI-LEVEL BASE CONSTRUCTION
* UI for navigating multiple levels
* rendering tech for showing multiple levels
* build gravshafts to allow citizens to travel between levels
* ability to build railings for safety

TAG SYSTEM FOR LOGS
deleted the info for review

ASSIGN PEOPLE TO ROOMS
* assign a security-duty citizen to a room to have them guard it
* assign any citizen to a residence to have them use it as their quarters
* normally, a citizen will "claim" an unused bed & the area around it
* citizens decorate their living space w/ their stuff (see "stuff" above)
* people protect their spaces / become annoyed when strangers or unfriendly people intrude

"LEARN TO PLAY"
deleted the info for review

TELEPORTERS
* create a functioning teleporter
* UI for selecting which teleporter goes where (dynamically changeable)
* teleporter accidents: could hurt/kill people, scramble their brains, turn them evil (goatee Spock)

METEOR STRIKES
* shield generators generate shielding to repel meteor strikes

MISC UI
deleted the info for review

EMERGENCY DISTRESS SIGNAL
*calls for rescue people / immigrants to show up & save your base

BASE NAMING
*first oxygenated room comes online, base is considered "established" & prompts you for a name

STEAM WORKSHOP
* built in savegame sharing!
* mod support!
* "mods" subdir where user-created scripts patch base game lua files at runtime
* provide uncompiled lua source for gameplay-relevant classes, eg Character.lua, to support modders
* allow PNG sprite sheets - lower performance than tex format in exchange for easy moddability

BARTENDERS
* customers give orders to bartender
* bartenders serve food
* skilled bartenders make people happier
* citizen drunkenness
* drunk citizens make mistakes while doing duty

CITIZEN FIGHTING
* citizens who dislike each other will fight
* risk of injury & deepening mutual hatred
* security can stun violent people
* drunk citizens more likely to fight
* low morale citizens are more likely to fight

SPACE MADNESS
* become violent, grabbing a rifle if available

DOCTORS
* doctor duty & infirmary zone
* doctors unassigned to infirmary patrol the base
* citizens seek out infirmary when hurt/sick 
* doctors use tricorder-like first aid
* better doctors heal people faster, bad doctors have a chance to hurt them
* revivabed object for infirmary: only way to detect parasite infestation or cure some diseases

CONSTRUCTION TOOLS
deleted the info for review

MISC LIFE SIM
* "skill point distribution" for generating skill set on citizen spawn
* citizens can get nicknames
* ability to flag citizens as hostile / suspicious (security will keep an eye on them)
* citizens have to reach a locker to change duty
* citizens become annoyed if environment is noisy while sleeping (low-traffic residences)
* "watch video" activity tied to monitors
* sportsball matches viewable on monitors
* high morale = skills go up more quickly
* citizens put on duty-outfit when they go to do duty, remove it when starting other tasks

SOCIALIZATION / AFFINITY AI
* people prefer to chat w/ friends, unless gregarious personality
* people have +/- affinities for objects/rooms/people w/ certain qualities
* people spread gossip about people they dislike
* trends: popular people influence the affinities of less popular people
* fashion accessories signify social affiliation
* new concepts introduced by immigrants & trade

PERSONALITY TRAITS
* introverted/extroverted
* gregarious/shy
* vindictive/forgiving
* angry/peaceful
* neat/messy
* religious preference

AFFINITY/CONVERSATION TOPICS
deleted the info for review

TECHNOLOGY
* scientist job
* research lab
* blueprints
* scientists can construct blueprints by research
* blueprints can be discovered aboard derelicts or immigrants
* starting conditions determine technologies you have access
* take dead hostiles to research labs to study them
* eventually, how to deactivate killbots & reform them into friendly

VISIT A FRIEND'S BASE
* hangar bay zone where shuttles can dock
* load citizens onto a shuttle
* shuttle leaves, your friend gets a visit request
* if accepted, your citizens disembark inside their base, walk around & have adventures
* return to your base
* travelers preserve any stuff, experience, technology etc that they accrue while visiting another base

BASE DEFENSE
* attackers show up in derelicts, docking ships, etc:
* killbots
* murderslugs
* invaders breach base walls & invade from the outside
* exterior base defenses
* build traps to capture/kill invaders:
* tripwires that can be scripted to doors, other traps, depressurize room, etc
* laser grids/auto-turrets/stun nets
* brig zone
* monster domestication/breeding!
* variety of weapons
* flamethrower
* gravity gun
* plasma cannon

FUNERALS
* will either be recycled at matter recycler or spacecoffin
* small service may be held w/ the citizen's friends
* attending service raises their morale, ie no service, will have a harder time grieving

ROBOTS
* robots join your base as citizens
* normal - subservient to organic life, perform the duty w/out question
* rampant - gained self-awareness but hate all organic life, they produce more killbots
* enlightened sentient -become sentient, develop personalities, change their names, live normal lives

LAWS
* ability to pass ordinances

COMPUTER TERMINALS
* write Lua to script control of environment objects, robots, etc

PLANETFALL
* teleport down to the surface of planet(s) you're orbiting
* discover abandoned bases, alien life, friendly or hostile sentients

HOLODECKS
* build vast zones that can reconfigure their geometry for entertainment/educational scenarios
* costumes for holodeck scenarios
* holodeck malfunctions:
* glitches that partially reconfigure the geometry of your base, eg "half your base is now a medieval castle"
* holo-actors can break free & wreak havok in your base, eg "cavemen & cowboys are attacking everyone"

"HISTORICAL SCENARIO" ADDON PACKS
* props, tiles, costumes for sandbox storytelling in famous sci fi settings: alien, star wars, 2001, etc

TIME TRAVEL
* events deemed timeline-critical 

-----

This never happened. Less than a year later in Sept 2014, they announced they were going from Alpha 6e to v1.0 with way less than 40% of the roadmap in the game. Thumbs down.

If you are interested in a game like this, check out Star Command Galaxies (not on steam yet) or The Spatials.

* skilled bartenders make people happier
* citizen drunkenness
* drunk citizens make mistakes while doing duty

CITIZEN FIGHTING
* citizens who dislike each other will fight
* risk of injury & deepening mutual hatred
* security can stun violent people
* drunk citizens more likely to fight
* low morale citizens are more likely to fight

SPACE MADNESS
* become violent, grabbing a rifle if available

DOCTORS
* doctor duty & infirmary zone
* doctors unassigned to infirmary patrol the base
* citizens seek out infirmary when hurt/sick 
* doctors use tricorder-like first aid
* better doctors heal people faster, bad doctors have a chance to hurt them
* revivabed object for infirmary: only way to detect parasite infestation or cure some diseases

CONSTRUCTION TOOLS
deleted the info for review

MISC LIFE SIM
* "skill point distribution" for generating skill set on citizen spawn
* citizens can get nicknames
* ability to flag citizens as hostile / suspicious (security will keep an eye on them)
* citizens have to reach a locker to change duty
* citizens become annoyed if environment is noisy while sleeping (low-traffic residences)
* "watch video" activity tied to monitors
* sportsball matches viewable on monitors
* high morale = skills go up more quickly
* citizens put on duty-outfit when they go to do duty, remove it when starting other tasks

SOCIALIZATION / AFFINITY AI
* people prefer to chat w/ friends, unless gregarious personality
* people have +/- affinities for objects/rooms/people w/ certain qualities
* people spread gossip about people they dislike
* trends: popular people influence the affinities of less popular people
* fashion accessories signify social affiliation
* new concepts introduced by immigrants & trade

PERSONALITY TRAITS
* introverted/extroverted
* gregarious/shy
* vindictive/forgiving
* angry/peaceful
* neat/messy
* religious preference

AFFINITY/CONVERSATION TOPICS
deleted the info for review

TECHNOLOGY
* scientist job
* research lab
* blueprints
* scientists can construct blueprints by research
* blueprints can be discovered aboard derelicts or immigrants
* starting conditions determine technologies you have access
* take dead hostiles to research labs to study them
* eventually, how to deactivate killbots & reform them into friendly

VISIT A FRIEND'S BASE
* hangar bay zone where shuttles can dock
* load citizens onto a shuttle
* shuttle leaves, your friend gets a visit request
* if accepted, your citizens disembark inside their base, walk around & have adventures
* return to your base
* travelers preserve any stuff, experience, technology etc that they accrue while visiting another base

BASE DEFENSE
* attackers show up in derelicts, docking ships, etc:
* killbots
* murderslugs
* invaders breach base walls & invade from the outside
* exterior base defenses
* build traps to capture/kill invaders:
* tripwires that can be scripted to doors, other traps, depressurize room, etc
* laser grids/auto-turrets/stun nets
* brig zone
* monster domestication/breeding!
* variety of weapons
* flamethrower
* gravity gun
* plasma cannon

FUNERALS
* will either be recycled at matter recycler or spacecoffin
* small service may be held w/ the citizen's friends
* attending service raises their morale, ie no service, will have a harder time grieving

ROBOTS
* robots join your base as citizens
* normal - subservient to organic life, perform the duty w/out question
* rampant - gained self-awareness but hate all organic life, they produce more killbots
* enlightened sentient -become sentient, develop personalities, change their names, live normal lives

LAWS
* ability to pass ordinances

COMPUTER TERMINALS
* write Lua to script control of environment objects, robots, etc

PLANETFALL
* teleport down to the surface of planet(s) you're orbiting
* discover abandoned bases, alien life, friendly or hostile sentients

HOLODECKS
* build vast zones that can reconfigure their geometry for entertainment/educational scenarios
* costumes for holodeck scenarios
* holodeck malfunctions:
* glitches that partially reconfigure the geometry of your base, eg "half your base is now a medieval castle"
* holo-actors can break free & wreak havok in your base, eg "cavemen & cowboys are attacking everyone"

"HISTORICAL SCENARIO" ADDON PACKS
* props, tiles, costumes for sandbox storytelling in famous sci fi settings: alien, star wars, 2001, etc

TIME TRAVEL
* events deemed timeline-critical 

-----

This never happened. Less than a year later in Sept 2014, they announced they were going from Alpha 6e to v1.0 with way less than 40% of the roadmap in the game. Thumbs down.

If you are interested in a game like this, check out Star Command Galaxies (not on steam yet) or The Spatials.

column8:
I would really love this game if it wasn't for the few super annoying bugs .. like e.g. the AI just randomly decides that your perfectly functioning airlock is not going to be used due to a dead body in front of it, and all your builders, miners, new recruits, etc. asphyxiate just because they didn't feel like using the airlock

There have been plenty of changes since the last time I tried this game a few months ago (still in pre-release), but apparently they haven't cared to fix the actual game breaking bugs, instead they've added mainly useless new features.

column8: This game had a lot of promise. They "ran out of money" and it turned out to be barebones after release. This is an example of why buying an early access game is a roll of the dice. You are NEVER guaranteed a complete game. If you are, you're being lied to. The only incentive these people have to complete the game is the promise of more money in the future. If they know their product is crap or they see that no money is in the future, then expect the dev to drop development. If you don't like it, don't buy early access.

column8:
As you can probably tell by my hours played, I was a huge fan of this game while it was in development. I could live with the bugs, knowing it was all an Early Access alpha, and that it was being worked on regularly. Some day, it would be finished and fun.

Except that never happened.

Tim Schaefer himself gave the order to pull the plug on development, claiming that not enough people bought the game during Early Access to fund the development. That's right, the business "plan" was to use Early Access money to fund the actual game (smacks head).

If they'd done a standard crowdfund (like Kickstarter) and said "We need X dollars to make this game", they probably would've gotten the money because, you know, Double Fine -- but, apparently, they completely misunderstood what Early Access is for (hint: it's not for funding the majority of your game's development).

Short version? Same as everyone else has been saying: the developer abandoned the project, but called it finished anyway. It's not finished. Do not buy.

column8:
Wow... Had a lot of potential, but the product that Doublefine crapped out here.. I won't be buying anything else made by that "game" developer.

The project is abandoned and unfinished. The build number claims to be 1.06, but it feels more like a 0.7 beta. Nothing is balanced and I encountered several glitches. This game was made to be modded, which in this case means the dev handed over game development to the players instead of finishing it. I would be happy with some awesome mods that finish the game out, but there is no workshop support.

After four or five failed bases I thought I had got the hang of it. I had beaten every disease and easily defended against 20-30 attacks. Then a wave of attacks hit (they often come in threes within seconds of each other) and I took out the first two no sweat with my five man security team with a combined star rating of ~14 out of 25 (which is quite good). Then the last raider boarded all by himself, and killed my entire crew.

I was boarded by the main antagonist of a space pirate anime apparently.

I would have researched better weapons and armor, but my two man scientific team were busy trying to develop anti-viral air scrubbers to counter the relentless spread of disease.

My entire population was 18. 5 Security, 2 Scientists, 1 Bartender, 2 Doctors, 1 Botanist, 4 Miners and 3 Builders. They were all busy non stop. Also, they were all assigned to professions that made them 'happy' and I had every accommodation in the game available to them in abundance, but they were all still sad/angry. I had only lost one crew member to a sudden chest bursting that I don't think could have been prevented.

I really want to play this game. It is really fun up until that moment that it becomes overwhelmingly unfair and you lose three hours worth of work. Maybe they made the game so hard to compensate for the lack of content. Every so often something comes along and takes out 90% of your crew. Then you have to build back up, thus 'adding' more game play. Not fun.

I give this game a 3/100. I'm going to give it one more try because I am stubborn, but I have no expectations other than a severe cussing fit.

column8: I purchased this as an early-access game, and it was mildly amusing then. I knew it was a pre-Alpha at the time, and so the fact that there was nothing really to do beyond build a few rooms and poke around wasn't a big deal. It never improved, though. The developer simply released the game in its unfinished state. At best, it's simply a bad investment. At worst, it's exploitative abandonware on the part of the developer.

column9:
- Started building a base, ran out of oxygen, everyone died.
- Built a base, didn't provide food, everyone died.
- Meteorites destroyed the oxygen generators, everyone died.
- Meteorites destroyed the power generators, everyone died.
- Meteorites destroyed a wall, while everyone was doing push-ups, everyone died.
- Built everything, 10 raiders arrived, everyone died.

An excellent space death simulator.

And to be honest, absolutely all the characters are suicidal. Raiders attack, the guards are chatting somewhere while the raiders clear the base. Something vital breaks, the technicians are hanging out at the bar. The floor is broken, the builders are messing around. And so on. A game for masochists. This applies to both the early version and the post-release version.

column8: They made a really great prototype for a game, but after selling the idea it seemed like all development stopped. Their "release" is still an unfinished, alpha-quality project, full of bugs and gaps. The world lacks purpose and is obviously still a template for what they were planning to do but never did. Their feature timeline was scrapped at the last second and now this once promising game is a sad letdown of lost potential. Their general treatment of the issue and the game has caused me to regret my purchase and I will no longer be supporting the developer's future work.

column8:
While I've enoyed Double Fine's games in the past, DF9 has left a very bitter taste in my mouth and in the future I will seriously reconsider before purchasing another of their games.  This game was the first time I made an "early access" purchase and it has completely burned me for the whole concept.  I played the game whil it was still being toted in Alpha and it was a clunky mess with no tutorial.  While I was able eventually able to navigate the cumbersome menu setup and get the base setup the game just kinda plateaued at that point and just never got very interesting.

Eventually a tutorial of sorts was added but it had a persistent bug that prevented it from being completed.  No matter what was done the tutorial messages would persist on the screen despite having completed the objective.

Bottom line, avoid this title at all costs.
