column8: Spacebase DF-9 is a really fun game for me to play.  Yes it has aspects that is so unfinish and I wish the development team did not give up so soon on the game as I know that there is lots more that could have been added to the game to complete it. I want to find modders to complete the things in the game to make it no reach the potential it has.   The game is playable up to a certain point then bad things happen and its hard to turn it around.  Is it a long term game? As the game stands now, No, dont know if there is anyway for some other team to come in and finish the game.  I hope so as this game would be oh so much more and was heading in a great direction.  I remembered playing Space Colony and loved it, and this reminds me of that game, but instead of being on land this is set for outer space outside of a planet.  I bought this game knowing, reading all the bad comments knowing that I still like the promise this game had to offer, and the price was really low because of the bad press.  I play it when I am bored, but because of the unfinishness of the game I never last long playing before I quit and move on.  It is a game for other developers to understand what gamers want in these kind of game so that they will make a better product next time as we all looked forwarded to this game but never got 100% of what we were looking for.

I saw this game being played by Scott Manley (a youtuber, really cool guy tho.) so i bought it as well when it was on sale and played it a LOT, i still do play it, just less often....

reason: it gets repetetive real fast, from a certain point you cant really add much more to your base anymore, it starts to lag a little every now and then and lots of other little annoying things.

Also, when i heard they were quitting development of DF9 i was VERY, VEEEEEEEEERY disappointed, or rather, sad. it seemed like such a good game and had a great future if they added in all they promised.


So far, i would not say i would recommend this game, but i wouldnt tell you to avoid it like the plague. it is just a sad example of development stopping on a great game and it being left half finished.

(sadly theres no 'eh' option, i'll just go with the herd and say not recommended)

Like when the game is finished I think it will be a great game! Oh whats that? The game is done? There no more updates? Well shit. The game feels like a buggy demo, and by demo I mean you have to pay 20 dollars AND ONE CENT. If you ask me personally it should just be one cent to buy it, if not free. Would i recomend? No, your gonna like the core ideas and gonna say hey if this was done or if this was added it would be a great game. But saying it wont make it true their just trying to break even on their project. Dont buy this overpriced demo.

column8:
O jogo nÃ£o esta terminado, e n Ã© atualizado com frequencia como dito.
O jogo tem um conceito e ideia bem legal, mas foi feito de maneira ruim, e como a maioria do jogos do genero a I.A. do jogo e bem ruim, n a como vc dar prioridade as tarefas.
Possui bastantes jogos e n escala a dificuldade de forma escalar, vc pode ta com a base recem feita com um comodo e ser atacado por raiders ou estar como 3 pessoas e todas serem pegas por parasitas.


E triste dizer isso mas n compre esse jogo, por mais q alguns amantes digam que a falta de vendas q levou o jogo a ruina, isso so aconteceu por mÃ¡ administraÃ§ao do jogo por parte dos desenvolvedores e a falta de resultados, espero no futuro alguem conseguir criar um jogo com o mesmo pensamento porem com um gameplay mais polido e menos baseado em sorte.
column9:
The game isn't finished, and it's not updated frequently, as mentioned.
The game has a really cool concept and idea, but it was poorly made. Like most games of this genre, the AI â€‹â€‹is pretty bad, making it hard to prioritize tasks.
There are a lot of games, but the difficulty doesn't scale. You could have a newly built base with a room and be attacked by raiders, or you could be with three people and all be taken by parasites.

It's sad to say, but don't buy this game. Even though some fans say the lack of sales led to the game's downfall, this only happened due to the developers' mismanagement and lack of results. I hope someone can create a game with the same mindset in the future, but with more polished gameplay and less luck-based gameplay.

column8:
Going against most of the people here, it seems, I think DF-9 should get a generally positive review.

So you know where my view comes from: I bought this game early in alpha because I had a DF coupon, but I rarely play early EA games.  Aside from a quick try in alpha, I have only played the current 1.06.  I also rarely look in the forums, so perhaps I'm less angry than some.  :)

Bottom line: if you enjoy city/base/island-building sandbox games, you will enjoy this.

I found exploring the game after a minimal tutorial enjoyable.  I had several false-starts and refined my base layout as I went.  Lost one decent early base when I learned the difference between tear down and vaporize: when removing a section of wall, vaporize removes everything including the floor.  Everybody was blown out before it could be repaired.

The graphics and animation quality are quite nice as are most of the sound effects.  The user interface is also easy to use in most cases.  It has a few issues when it comes to placing objects, especially ones that go on walls.  Even though they might be hard to see sometimes, the game does not allow you to use the south-east and -west walls interior (hidden) side for object placement.  Turrets are one of the few items that can face in any direction and it can be difficult to place the turrent as it will jump from wall to wall.  There needs to be a manual method to move the selection tile-by-tile.  It matters where the turret's cone of fire reaches.

The AI is perhaps not superb, but so far I haven't had any serious issues with it.  At least, not yet.  Pathfinding seems okay, as long as your base isn't riddled with paths because of doors everywhere.  Picking/keeping a good crew goes along way towards avoiding frustration.  You should also invest some time in keeping them happy.  It can be difficult sometimes, but all of the information you need it given in their tabs.

Sometimes, though, the AI will do something really stupid or annoying.  Like avoiding the conveniently placed fire extinguisher in the hallway and trying to stamp out the fire.  It seems as though the extinguisher must be within the room on fire.

Of course, sometimes it helps to discover or know the AI's priorities.  With builders, for example, it's rather easy to observe their work, or lack of it, and to figure out what they prioritize.  They tend to prefer building floors before walls, and walls before any indoor work, and so on.  So, if you have a room built and while waiting for it to be filled you plan on a new hallway, the builders will drop their indoor work and go add that new section of hull first.

The game's biggest flaw, by far, then is the lack of depth.  Except for the residence and pub areas, every room has only a very small number of objects that you can place in it.  Researching does not alleviate this problem as you really just get upgraded versions of an object or an upgraded replacement model.  That's not bad, but it would be nice to have a number of topics to research (maybe based on your contact with alien visitors) that would give you new objects to use in rooms or maybe even a new room type.

This lack of depth and seeming lack of forward progression after a point seem to be the primary reasons other posters give for giving the game a thumbs down.  These really impact the length of play and replayability more than they do playability, however.

If the poor description of the game that I've given sounds like a genre that you enjoy, you'll definitely have some fun playing.  For how long I think largerly depends on how much you like exploring the mechanics of the game while you learn to play.  Experimenting with various base layouts for efficiency reasons or asthetics also adds some time and depth.

Whatever the reason for DF ceasing development, it seems pretty clear that what has been delivered is a [b]*platform*[/b] for a game.  But, of course, they were supposed to deliver a game.  Fortunately, the platform seems to be robust and moddable and even as-is provides a good amount of fun.

Judging by DF's last announcement, I doubt we'll be seeing anything more from them.  I choose to be optimistic about the game's future, though.  The quality of what they've open sourced appears good enough that I think the mod community will add a lot to the game in time.  I wish DF hadn't dropped it, but they did and there are far worse states they could have left it in.

The game does provide some long term objectives conveniently located under the "Goals" tab of the main HUD.  They are more like milestones, however, such as getting X number of crew, surviving the Mega Fleet, or killing X number of raiders.

Finally, price:  It's definitely not worth full price given the lack of depth.  I would pay anywhere between $5 and $10 for it and feel that I got my money's worth.

If you're looking for similar games, I would certainly recommend either Startopia or Evil Genius.  Startopia doesn't let you build the base, but you fill it and manage the station.  It came out some years back so it runs great on most any machine and it's a lot of fun.  Evil Genius has you building a base in your island mountain hideout.  You get to design the whole layout, rooms and hallways, similar to base building in DF-9.  Evil Genius has a lot of depth as you take on nefarious missions or as you build booby traps into your base to catch unwitting good guys.

I hope this provides a sufficiently objective view of the game.  Keep in mind that I'm still playing and making ever larger bases, so it's possible that there are some issues I've yet to encounter because my population hasn't been large enough.

column8:
This game had huge potential until Double Fine cut it loose and ran off with the money from the early access. It was a decent start to what could've been a great game, but the devs decided to run off with the money and leave us with a half finished pile of garbage. They keep releasing "patches" that barely fix any of the problems, lied about all of the insanely cool sounding features that were supposed to be added, and then have the gall to charge $20 for a game that's got about $5 worth of content in it.

This game could've been another colossal hit for DF, but instead it turned into a colossal mess. Don't buy it. Pirate a copy if you have to play it, but don't bother buying it. DF doesn't deserve another cent for this train wreck.

column8:
Ok, so this game has been targeted for negative reviews by a bunch of gamergate loons. Free speech and all that, but Tim Schafer and Doublefine make superb, heartfelt games that justify the entire art form, and you should know that he's evidently feminist enough to be able to speak out when the kind of treatment this release is getting is an obvious risk.

So maybe, if you want to piss off some reactionary sexists, you should buy this lovely game. It's not quite everything it was targeted to be, but there is a hidden storyline in there, and it is fun. If you're not interested, then maybe go buy psychonauts or one of their other bigger games as those are superb.

I got it when it was on sale, and my persistent habit of bothering to speak in places where what I have to say has gone unsaid means I am going to get downvoted horribly by those same loons.

Gamergaters, you're on the losing side :)

column8:
This is a game that could have been awesome.
I loved the concept and the gameplay, but this isn't a complete game.
It's a game whose development was stopped half-way through in the process.
If they'd just smooth out the rough edges, and fix all the little problems this game has.
Then it would be playable, but as it is now, it isn't.

It's a Tim Schafer game. In other words, he took a bunch of peoples money off kickstarter, made a half-assed tech demo, and released it as the full product.

Hey Timmy boy, how about you actually ship a full game in the future? That $19 for Spacebase could buy me 2 games each with 10x content. That could get me a whole lot more on a steam sale.

P.S: You probably shouldn't have hired the guys from Enron to take care of your finances

column8:
I had previously enjoyed this title, even in it's unfnished state and as a programmer had enjoyed access to the game's source.

However, that still doesn't excuse the fiasco that was this game's development and release, as well as the essential demand that others finish the title for them, but even that I can just roll my eyes and grumble a bit to myself and opt to be cynical with future purchases.

Than last night happened.
The Game Developer Choice Awards and Tim Schafer single handedly removed agency and the very humanity of thousands of women and minorities in the #NotYourShield hashtag, implying them all nothing but fake accounts and "sockpuppets" on stage, at the GDC.

Part of me died that night seeing that.
That was the tipping point for me, not only can I no longer support double fine or Tim Schafer, but now I genuinely believe their presence is directly harmful to not only game development but the gaming community too.

Go.
And never come back.

column8:
Spacebase DF-9 had high hopes and dreams that were crushed when it was abruptly moved to release due to the game not making enough money to sustain development.  If that's not a kick in the balls then I don't know what is.

In addition, Studio Head Tim Schafer has proved his pig-headedness once more at the Game Developers Conference of 2015, where he flat-out denied the existance of the women and minority gamers who have been calling for improvement in gaming journalism-- so if you fall in one of those two groups (or both), then you should probably think twice about buying any game made by Tim Schafer.  Otherwise you're just fueling the ego of a man who, quite literally, sock-puppets.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eEDCcdjgMNs

column8:
[h1]Full Feature Price, but Still Alpha Gameplay[/h1]

It is with a heavy heart that I give this game a bad review, but when all is said and done I must very emphatically council anyone against paying for this game. I was given this game for free (a Broken Age backer perk) back when it was still in Alpha and I thought it was really fun with it. It was buggy and there really wasn't that much to do, but that's what you expect from a game in alpha and the core mechanics were really quite fun. I followed this game, eager to find out what it could eventually become. 

Sadly, it never grew into anything greater than the alpha version. In fact, I can't even tell the difference between the alpha version and the release version. (Did they ever even have a beta version?) Not only is the game not fully fleshed out, but it's still got some major bugs that have never been fully addressed. I think charging people $20 for this game is just absolute fraud. If you ever manage to pick it up on sale for just a few bucks then I'd say it's worth it and you'll have some fun, but you can't expect a fully realized game. 

Ultimately this is just one more early access dissapointment, slowly destroying my desire to support indie/kickstarter games. What a shame.

column9:
Let's put it this way. I agree with the majority of players of this game. The game showed great promise during the alpha; the developers even wrote about what they wanted to add. However, those hopes were dashed. Everything was abandoned, and unfortunately, the game was abandoned after release. Even during the alpha, there were virtually no updates. My advice to potential buyers: don't buy it. Save your money and find a more worthy projectâ€”one that will truly justify its investment, rather than exploit customers. This game has already been abandoned.
UPDATE: Work on the game has continued, but now it's a modding team. I demand that Double Fine hand over the open source code to them. If you don't want to finish the game, then let others finish it.
Link to the modders: https://www.patreon.com/derelictgames . Support these guys with money; they're doing a great job!

column8:
This game is a bit tedious, but if you're easily endeared by its art and animations, it's worth getting if it's on sale. It has very little replay value and a lot of encounters in the game can be frustrating and tedious. Plus, it's abandonware as far as updates and bugfixes go, so you'd be better off buying something similar with a more attentive dev team.
I can't in good concience recommend it because, even though I adore Double Fine and liked this game at first, the way it's been handled is atrocious and the game itself is extremely shallow.

column8:
[i]"Thanks for the money. I'll need it for my other projects."[/i] - Tim "3.3" Schafer (Not an actual quote he made, meant to be satrical)

Another title that's a stain on the early access program. You'd think a developer like DoubleFine couldn't mess up a PC game like this. Just take everything from Theme Hospital, mix abit of Dwarf Fortress in there add abit of originality and hey presto, you have a game. Not really though, as you've come across the bad reviews/recommendations for this game and there's alot of them.

There's nothing good in this game, it's bare-bones as it comes. Unless a very, [i]very[/i] talented modding crew works relentlessly on this game it's [b]never[/b] going to be worth a purchase.

Oh and one more thing; Recommending your own game through the Curator system isn't ethical. Stop that.

[h1]Edit - 21/07/2015[/h1]
Wow, didn't realise that this 'review' would get so popular.
I'd just like to thank everyone who took the time to click on that good ol' green thumb and bring to light the trash that is early access and greenlight games. Thanks to Steams new refund option, broken, half made games like this will hopefully never come to be.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Fdq8odshMls

column8: Wow what a great... Demo? I finally got around to playing this so called 1.0 and it is totally unfinished to say the least. I'm not really sure how Double Fine can say this is complete. There are still bugs (things not building & researching) and there is almost nothing to do once you build all the rooms. I'm glad I didn't pay full price for this thing, and I'm sorry to all that did. I'm going to steer clear of Double Fine in the future...

column8:
I backed this game when it was still in development.  I was really looking forward to a diet-dwarf-fortess-in-space type experience.  Unfortunately, the game was nixxed before it really got much out of an alpha state. The developers did manage to release a fairly playable game (having gone from ver.6 to 1.0 in under a month) and have since released several patches (on ver 1.06 now.)  

I cannot recommend the game as it stands at this price point.  Maybe if you see it on sale for $5 or so and you want to mess around a bit, but there's no depth of play here.  There are many other sim-type games out there that are worth investing both the time and money in.

column8:
One of the more promising management games I've seen.

To me, it was like Space Colony mixed with a bit of Startopia, both games I absolutely loved.

I was very much looking forward to playing the finished game.

They never finished it.

Midway through alpha development they 'ran out of money'.  This resulted in them slapping a poor excuse for a tutorial onto the game and fixing only a handful of the hundreds of bugs the game had and releasing it.  They stuck around for 6 more patches fixing even more bugs, and the game still has dozens of bugs.

They released the source code expecting modders to finish developing the game and continued to sell it for full price.

It's still being sold, incomplete and extremely buggy.

This is the game that dragged Double Fine's reputation into the dirt, and rightfully so.

If you choose to give them money (or get it elsewhere, as it's essentially abandonware at this point), you will have a few hours of fun, especially if you loved management games of old; but play it longer than that and all you'll experience is complete frustration at the bugs and the general incompleteness of the game.  Every now and again I decide I want to play it again.. and can barely even get a colony started, let alone last more than an hour without crippling bugs breaking the entire thing.

You can pickup Space Colony HD for $2.50 (on sale) on GoG or Steam.  It's a much, much better game.  If you want something a bit different, Startopia is great too, but you'll need to get a widescreen FoV fix to play it properly on modern displays.

---

Update: There's a fan patch for the game that starts to introduce new features and attempts to fix some of the issues with the game.  Unfortunately, it has issues itself and neither experience is a very good one.  Development on it is also very slow as it's by amateur part time modders who seem to have issues every release (including just flat out missing files).

Maybe in the future it'll be well developed enough to actually fix and improve and add to the game, but as of right now, the game is still alpha quality no matter what.

But hey, at least the game only costs $1 now (on sale), right?

column8: Everything you do will be undone right when you start to expand. Once you hit about 20 citizens, raiders start attacking every 5-10 minutes, even in low threat zones, and will kill 2-3 of your citizens. Then, all your citizens will drop into "sad" moods and will start fighting. Security personnel are useless, as are doctors. A person could be injured for 20 minutes (real life) before they end up in the infirmary. Also, they never really fixed the dead bodies issue. They just sit there where they died for 30-40 minutes until they mysteriously vanish. This game feels unfinished, unbalanced, and not really worth investing much time in one base.

column8: The AI in this game is so painfully retarded I get worked into fits of rage when more than 10 people are in the base. I had a base with 33 people, when i was invaded by raiders. they were in a seperate ship from the rest of the place, so i opened the air lock to suffacate them. 7 Flipping people decided to go and check  up on them and died, while oxygen slowly drained through the OPEN AIRLOCK DOOR. Just about every maintanence person, and even the borking scientests went over there for no Kunting reason!!!! That being said it's a fun game, with good music, and the worst AI pathing ive ever seen.

column8: I really wanted to like this game and to a point I did (26 hours worth) but I can not recommend it as it feels unfinished, left out in the cold of space to die and the developers are missing out on a huge potential if they had put more into it. It's quirky, interesting, not very challenging but at best gets old once you've created a few bases and start to notice the patterns. Pick it up if you can get it on sale for $5 or less. Don't be duped like I was into paying a penny more.

column8:
Because my previous review was deleted, I'm re-reviewing this! 

After playing it again recently, I must admit, the game is still horrible and has the feeling of being unfinished. What Double Fine did here was worse than Starbound. Instead of taking money and being incompitint with it, Double Fine instead took the money, released a mediocre game (something you'd see maybe from a sophomore game design class) and said "JOB WELL DONE!" 

To further insult the players who've invested in their early-access game (that looked promising) they've begun censoring forum posts and reviews! 

The good: 
-The game is sandboxxy
-It's goofy
-It had potential 

The bad: 
-It has the feeling of being unfinished
-The AI is retarded, think Dwarf Fortress "The carp stands up" retarded
-The replayability...it's just not there. 
-It's buggy
-The price is goofy.

Overall? Don't buy it. Don't buy it while it's on sale, don't buy it for the goofy price they've given. Don't waste your time, don't waste your money, go buy something else for $20.01. Buy one of the many games that go on sale daily. Buy an older game, buy a damn loli-pop, it'll last longer than you'll want to play this game.

This game still lacks in many crucial areas. The AI is dumb as a post, the mechanics lack any rhyme or reason as to why the function the way they do, and graphical errors still exist (mac version). 
I'm flabbergasted they're still charging $20.01 for a game that doesn't work. 
Go to your nearest sink, toss in a 20$ bill, light in on fire, and you'll have infinitly more fun than playing this game.

column8:
After glancing at the review page for this game, I feel obligated to share my experiences with this game.

Some of the positives:
*You have to actually plan a base and monitor your resources in order to survive
*Every play through is different.  
*You choose what type of game you plan on embarking on from the very start.
   - Do you want a lot of hostiles?
   - Do you want to build your base close to a warp gate so you will have visitors (Friendly & hostile?)
   - Stellar Density: Do you want to have an abundance of "money" or do you want to have to really work for it?

Some of the negatives:
*Yes, the game is no longer being developed
*Yes, there are many things not completed
   -The game is still very much playable
*Yes, there are many features that should have been added in, via the Devâ€™s constant updates, such as:
   -Multi-level base construction
   -Teleporters
   -holodecks

This game started out as an early access game and unfortunately it also ended that way.  The way I see it, anyone on steam, including myself, takes a chance when buying a game that is in early access.  Will it be phenomenal? Will it suck? When will development finish? Will it ever finish? Will this new bug fix crash the entire game? 

The game may not be 100% complete, but at least Double Fine released the source code to their fans to continue development.  Sometimes, it's the fans that understand the game on a much deeper level than the developers ever could.  

With that being said, should you purchase this game at $20?  
In short...NO WAY!!  Should you never play this game though? NO!!! Wait for it to go on sale and purchase once the price drops to a good amount.  You can get HOURS AND HOURS of play time out of this game - and isn't that what you want from any game you decide to sit down and play?!?!

column8:
Spacebase DF-9 is one of the 2 games that taught me to never again invest in either an Early Access of Kickstarter video game. The other was Peter Molyneux's Godus. 

I had a lot of faith in Double Fine's ability to produce this game, and after a long period of slow progress and bland features, Spacebase DF-9 has died in development. It's not an uncommon occurnace in the video game industry for a project to fail while in development and most of the time we players never see this happen. 

The lesson Spacebase DF-9 teaches us is that early access/kickstarter games are not exceptions and are not sacrosanct. If you're foolish enough to give them your money for something that does not exist yet while they are not contractually bound to provide you with a product then you deserve to loose your money.

column8:
I bought this game while Early Access.  The game seemed to have a good foundation for being incomplete.  Every once in a while I scroll down through my games, play ones I have not playing in some time and check out new updates and such.
While I have not had any problems with the game, the game went from Early Access to "Done" with no real change that I could see.  While I do not really have any problems with game play or bugs that I have seen, I have it on "Not Recommended" strickly because of the status change with little to no noticable updates.
About the game itself:
Upon first start of the game, you have to rush to get things started because you have a very limited amount of time before you run out of air. 
General base building is not too bad, can be semi slow on getting materials.
Characters level up and gain more skill in their field which is nice.
Downside to the combat is that when under attack regular workers (non-security) will just run around and die and unless attacker crosses security path or you specifically tell them to go to their location, security just ignores them.
I personally, would have expected a bit more out of the game.  If left as is, then I would say is better worthwhile in the $5 or MAYBE $10 price, but not the $20 unless more work is done for it.  I do not think people really mind spending more money on a game if the effort is put towards it.

column8:
[h1]Perhaps some should tell Double Fine a Tutorial stage is supposed to be easy?[/h1]

The Tutorial stage is actually quite difficult for a newcomer - the 'area' the tutorial station is placed in has a 'high threat' level, and any time I tried to expand my station by adding a new feature, I found myself swarmed with raiders so that any residents I had out in space suits were inevitably killed. I cannot count the number of times my space station found istelf down to a tiny crew due to the rest being killed off. You will have much more satisfaction with the 'New Base' option.

This is a game with  basis, but too many frustrating points. What would help:

- the ability to 'jump' to a location on the map when a message is given, ie, a derelict has appeared, so-and-so is under attack, etc

- the ability to 'jump' to a resident from the roster

- a clearer indication of residents' moods and wants

- more options for decor/entertainment

- a help menu that lists the different features and what they do, instead of a too-difficult tutorial

- more features!!!!

On the whole, I know I will keep playing for the construction aspect, which is why I bought it, but I cannot honestly recommend it to anyone yet. Perhaps Double Fine will come back to it at some point; in light of the negative reviews it's getting, though, I rather doubt it.

column8:
Ugh. All Spacebase needed was time, and that's exactly what ran out. 

This is a great concept for a game. Build and manage a space outpost with a focus on resource & personnel management and design. It has a great, fun art style, and a cheeky sense of humor. 

It's also abandoned, unfinished, and now, unloved. 

Double Fine mismanaged this project from the start, and the result is a "game" that has no goal, no progression, and few failure conditions. A "simulation" where there is little beyond the most basic needs management that can be solved in a few minutes, with no further complexity or depth to ever grow. A "product" that's buggier than The Temple of Doom. 

If you're really curious to look at what happens when a game project gets aborted but somehow thrown at the public, stillborn, then pick this game up and watch as the first few promising minutes of fun fade into unoptimized monotony. 

If not, stay away and check out either Cosmonautica for a similar "Silly Space" atmosphere, or Startopia for a better Spaceport management simulation.

column9:
Spacebase DF9 isn't really a bad game, but it's also far from being a good or even complete game, so let's go through it point by point.

The first point, and very important for many, is the graphics. They may not win any awards, but they're still quite pleasant to look at; for me personally, it's enough. However, I don't have particularly high expectations; I'm just talking about Baldur's Gate 2.

The second point is the content. It's meager, perhaps appropriate for a â‚¬5 title, but not worth â‚¬20. Sure, you can immerse yourself in the game for several hours, not like someone else here suggested, where you'll be done in an hour. But if you want everything to go well and even survive "emergency situations" well, it takes a lot of planning and, unfortunately, luck.

That brings us to point three: the gameplay. It's basically a solid system and easy to use, but also incredibly unfair. For one thing, it could simply happen that your people run amok (preventable) or that a horde of raiders arrives and starts massacring (difficult to prevent). OK, you can build phasor towers, even outside, but you'll initially lack both materials and time. On top of that, events occur at far too short intervals, so you often don't have time to just build something in peace.

Fourth point: the AI. Not as bad as it was at the beginning, but still abysmally bad, nothing more needs to be said.

Conclusion: Due to the game's release policy, it takes a lot of goodwill to accuse the developer of fraudulent or money-grubbing intentions, and I simply lack that goodwill. Does that make Spacebase DF9 a bad game? No, it isn't. Is it worth its 20 euros? NO!
Maybe for 5 euros you could consider getting this unfinished and unfair but still entertaining game, assuming you like the construction genre.

column8: I want to like this game. I really do! Unfortunately it's mostly unplayable in its current form. The AI doesn't know what to do most of the time, so you'll tell someone to build or mine (etc) and they will stand around for ten minutes instead of performing the task. I just played several games in a row where the team you start with wasn't able to build a room fast enough for them to live. You start with 8 minutes of air, and they have to build an airlock and an air recycler. I watched one ai go to a wall that needed to be built, start work, stop, walk away, come back, start work, walk away, and continue on until the entire crew died of asphyxiation! There are some serious bugs to work out if you can't even get far enough to screw up yourself! I'm incredibly dissappointed in Double Fine for making a game that is this shoddy, and it will certainly make me more hesitant to buy their products right away (as has been the case until this game).

For a veteran that was able to keep up a nice base in a "very low threat sector", there are too much raiders coming, and if you go to change some jobs while being invaded, sometimes more raiders come. Ah, and not great news too, the support/bugfixing stopped. My guess is there are so many bugs that it is not worth to realocate a team to fix them.

column8:
Though I purchased in Early Access, I waited until the "1.0" release to really dive in. After ~90 minutes, I felt I had seen basically all I needed. I hope this game gets a cult following that wants to fill in all the missing features. Honestly, just having more stuff to do would make the game interesting enough. I found it ran smooth with a pretty good interface; there just isn't a lot there.

I love Double Fine, but this game is unfortunately lacking. I can feel the nice technical bones about, but there's only a total of, I believe, 34 objects you can ever build in the game. Many of those require research, but I didn't feel any real need to research things. Though things happen (raiders, occasional friendly people, etc.) there doesn't feel like I have much agency which means I don't have any real goals after building one of each room and then letting things go. If the population was easier to expand, at least I would have a reason to build things, but constantly waiting is not a good reason.

I really noticed that I was waiting for more game to happen when I actually reassigned the person I had mining minerals because I had plenty and just didn't need it. Not needing more resources to me implies I don't need to keep playing.

column8:
I loved the concept of the game, so I spent $20 on it thinking it was money well spent on a trusted company. Bad move. This game is the biggest example of why not to buy games in Early Access: it's unfinished, buggy and borderline unplayable. It's also become the reason why in future I'll be avoiding Double FIne games. The fact it's still being sold on Steam for $20 is just thievery. 

Of course, I'm not expecting this review to stay up very long- in a move guaranteed of course to even further please the irate buyers of this game, negative reviews of it are being deleted by the thousands. Because censoring the unfortunate truth is the best way to earn back respect, right, Double Fine?

column8:
This game concept sounded awesome and the graphics look nice enough to rope me into paying $20 when it was in alpha. It was pretty bad and lacked a ton of features. Now that they have moved out of the alpha stage this game is still really hard to play and lackes most of the features that made it interesting.  Not being able to control a persons queue is agravating to no end. The AI is horrible. Normally what happens is I play for 2 hours until everyone in my base gets locked up some how. Either an incopasitated bartender cant serve a security officer and technitian waiting at the bar and those people are stuck their forever. Then a raider comes in and kills everyone while my maininary is slowly destroyed. 

DO NOT BUY THIS GAME. IT IS NOT FINISHED AND NEVER WILL BE.

column8:
Yes, it was abandoned by DoubleFine because they realized that they had over-committed to the game. Yes, it is unfinished and feels a bit rough around the edges. This is, however, not a game worth only a 4/10 rating - people are rating their hurt feelings, not the game itself.

That said, it is not great. It's not bad, but not great. Easily worth a few hours of time, and capable of presenting a moderate challenge. Tentatively recommended for those who need a break between bigger and better titles.

column8:
Spacebase DF-9 is a testament of what happens when a group of people have really great ideas but the managment does not have any business sense or know how to budget themselves. This game had so much potential, it could have been one of the best out there, instead it will be forever known as one of the reasons why you don't buy in Early Access. It's utterly incomplete, you can do and see everything there is to do in the game within 4 hours easily, and even that might be stretching it. Do not waste your money, do not get this game.

The biggest crime this game did though? It made the internet agree with Bobby Kodick.

column9: The game is frankly crude and unfinished. I regretted wasting my money at first, and very much so, but the developers compensated me for my purchase of this trashy game with a free Hack n Slash, for which I am very grateful. They admitted their mistake =) Good company.

column8:
While the game is fun, for an early access title, it's not finished and never will be.

This game was started with a successful kickstarter, with a line of features a mile long.  However since the money raised that way wasn't enough to pay a full studio of developers forever, they worked a short while until the money ran out, then cut losses and ran.

I can't really blame them, but it does leave the game a sorta buggy and unfinished mess.  It had promise, but I can't recommend it if it'll never be done.

column9:
Hello steamers and steamers.

This game disappointed me. I expected a lot from it, but unfortunately the developers stopped updating it and stopped working on it. That was a blow to me. As, at the beginning, everything seems to work normally, but there are small errors that make the game unpleasant for you. Turning the game on and off mostly helped and the graphic artifacts disappeared. Well, sometimes it happens that your whole base full of several dozen people dies because you were ambushed by pirates and no one was able to kill them. Not even a Security Guard at the highest level. He must have had a bad day so he was slacking off and it ended fatally for him. This is the factor I admire in the game, but also the reason I stopped playing it. I had already had the same base for several hours, maybe ten hours, I was looking for it, and suddenly everything went wrong. And she couldn't be saved anymore. I think this type is called a Dwarf TD game. Well, I'm not sure. Although I own the game, I will probably never play it again. Maybe if only because of the video review. So I give him a red card.

column8:
This is a very simplified Dwarf Fortress style game with a sci-fi skin. The graphics are nice, and there's some humor to be found. The interface is clean, and the game is very easy to play. However, the game severely lacks content, was released as "finished" though it was no where near it, and left to the modders.

The only way I could even remotely recommend this game is if it was dirt cheap (I mean like $2 or less) AND you were interested in a colony management type game that lacked the complexity of other similar titles.

I'd recommend RimWorld (currently not on Steam), Gnomoria (I'd recommend checking out a Let's Play to learn the game), or even Prison Architect. These titles are all pretty easy to get in to, can present a good challenge that will help you learn, and actually have active developers.

column8:
In an hour and a half of play I have encountered most everything the game has to offer, as well as 3 major bugs (disappearing tiles, bugged builder AI refusing tasks, and bugged security AI which finally lost me my station). This game was promised to include many basic features of a management game that were never implemented and will never be implemented. All that is left is a very subpar blend of basic features mixed with a hint of bugs that leaves a final product that tastes poor and unfinished. 

Were it 5 dollars and still being worked on I would heartily recommend it as with bugfixing and some addition of actual content it would be a very playable game. However, at the moment there is little to be said for it. 

Additionally, and separate from the review of actual gameplay, I have to express disappointment in Double Fine for letting down their customers like this. I do not support companies that do not live up to their promises and that follow unethical practices like covering up negative reviews, and as such I would like to urge anyone else who does not wish to support these practices to avoid buying this game and to look more closely at Double Fine products in the future.

column8: This game had so much potential to be great. It was a bit like prison architect but in space with parasitic aliens that can burst out of your colonists. There were so many planned features that really made me excited for the game, even in the early stages with the lack of content it kept me entertained for hours on end. Unfortunetly Double Fine has backed out of development and handed over all of the source code to modders. This means the game will most likely never be finished. At it's current state it's not worth the $20.01 USD they are asking for it. It's unfinished and i'm sure it still has bugs. Spacebase DF-9 had to chance to be an excellent game, a fresh take on the base building genre but Double Fine dropped the ball. Now that the game has been handed over to modders 95% of people don't even know whats going on with the game. Is it being updated? Expanded? Abandoned completely? No one is sure. If you don't mind dropping $20 on an unfinished game just to play it and wonder what could have been it's a decent play for 2-3 hours. After that the game just stonewalls as you run out of new things to do. Sure you can keep playing to see how big you can get your base but it simply becomes repetitive and tedious. I suggest you do not buy this game in it's current state. Perhaps one day the community will be able to fix Double Fine's mess but until then, don't buy this game.
column9: This game had so much potential to be great. It was a bit like prison architect but in space with parasitic aliens that can burst out of your colonists. There were so many planned features that really made me excited for the game, even in the early stages with the lack of content it kept me entertained for hours on end. Unfortunetly Double Fine has backed out of development and handed over all of the source code to modders. This means the game will most likely never be finished. At it's current state it's not worth the $20.01 USD they are asking for it. It's unfinished and i'm sure it still has bugs. Spacebase DF-9 had to chance to be an excellent game, a fresh take on the base building genre but Double Fine dropped the ball. Now that the game has been handed over to modders 95% of people don't even know whats going on with the game. Is it being updated? Expanded? Abandoned completely? No one is sure. If you don't mind dropping $20 on an unfinished game just to play it and wonder what could have been it's a decent play for 2-3 hours. After that the game just stonewalls as you run out of new things to do. Sure you can keep playing to see how big you can get your base but it simply becomes repetitive and tedious. I suggest you do not buy this game in it's current state. Perhaps one day the community will be able to fix Double Fine's mess but until then, don't buy this game.

column8:
Unfinished game trying to be something else. Can't see any fun in current gameplay where you can only play until you get set number of colonists in your base, after that you get pirate mega fleet to stomp your base forcing you to start over. That mechanic is just easy way out for lack of content which this unfinished presents as finished game.

Not certain if the last patch that was added sometime last year fixed the issue with starting position where it didn't matter. You got pirates, meteors and other negative events 5 minutes into game which yet again seemed like decision to cover-up lack of gameplay with game being "hard".

column8:
Oh Looks like my old review was deleted... (like about 4000 others)

Unfinished game, and abandoned! DO NOT BUY.

tl;dr

Many people have called this a scam, and while some might say thats a little harsh, you have to consider that people paid money up front for this in good faith - this game has basically been abandoned in a buggy and unfinished state.

Double fine have also gained further bad reputation with another game (possibly others if you look...?) and despite enjoying one of their games (Costume quest) I'll not be buying any of their other games, if they can't be trusted to complete a game, how can they be trusted with even a simple trust like long term maininence.

This sort of abuse of early access, is all too common, and begining to give steam a less than stella name... a crying shame for all concerned.

I shall not even bother to catalogue the bugs and terrible balance issues (there basically is none - balance that is there are pleny of bugs!) this was a great idea completely destroyed by really really terrible implementation and even worse disrespect for customers...

column8:
Today I thought I would write a somewhat higher quality review for this game.
Gameplay is utterly horrible. The interface is very clunky and you will be lucky if you actualy do get a base up to specs. 
To begin with the game is so full of game killing bugs that 9 out of 11 games I played were ended NOT because of a disaster, but because of  a major game killing bug.  I even had to restart the game 6 times in a row one time just because there was a bug that was killing it shortly after launching.. 

Moving on we now go to the general aspects of the game itself: 

Support 0/10

This game was released in an unfinished state and is abandoned yet sold on here for $20 (at the time of posting) 
I can not give a game in this condition or state any kind of rating at all.  Moving on, the devs are not freindly at all and have banned people for expressing their opinions that the game was a piece of vaporware.  You can take a look at the discussion forums for yourself on this and get a good idea of just how much censorship that is going on and make up your own minds on this . 

Graphics 5/10

I am really not impressed with the graphics.  They are not impressive at all and were somewhat below average. 

Sounds and Music 1/10

This is an area that is bare bones.  Obvioiusly this area of the game also did not get fnished.  What little music and sounds that there are  annoying as it is repetitous. 

Gameplay 1/10

I tried. No really I tried and I got 1 decent game out of 30+ hours which yielded  constant frustration from game killing bugs.  So I give gameplay a 1 because it was fun until the game was killed by a bug. 

Fun 2/10
What time I did play that was not killed by a game killing bug was fun so I give it a 2 in this area. 


Price:  due to the bugs, unfinished state, and unfrinedly devs it is my opinion that this is one game that definitely NOT worth more than a few pennies. 

Bugs and Execution:  The interface sucks, the game is full of game crushing bugs. 

I hope this review has been helpful to anyone looking for a new game. Feel free to comment.

Overall :  This game is not just an epic failure but truly IS  vaporware.

Dans le genre dwarf fortress like (ce que Spacebase DF 9 semble essayer de faire dans l'espace), je recommanderais plutÃ´t un Gnomoria, bien plus complet, profond et intÃ©ressant, voir mÃªme un vrai dwarf fortress Ã  l'ancienne avec ses bons vieux graphisme qui piquent (enfin y a des pack de texture aujourd'hui).

column9:
This game isn't finished!!!
So I recommend it if you want an alpha, okay, let's go all the way to the beta, which will never be finished.
In the Dwarf Fortress genre (what Spacebase DF-9 seems to be trying to do in space), I would recommend Gnomoria instead, much more complete, deep, and interesting, or even a real old-school Dwarf Fortress with its good old-fashioned graphics (well, there are texture packs these days).
RUN AWAY FROM SPACE BASE DF-9 like a weekend at your mother-in-law's!!!!! :)

column8: Another unfinished early access game that went "1.0". The concept was great, and the beta showed the skeleton of what could be a great dwarf fortress type game. Too bad it was inconvenient for the developers to finish what they started. Only way I can see DF (developers) saving face is to release the "full" game for modding, not just allow patching.
column9: Another unfinished early access game that went "1.0". The concept was great, and the beta showed the skeleton of what could be a great dwarf fortress type game. Too bad it was inconvenient for the developers to finish what they started. Only way I can see DF (developers) saving face is to release the "full" game for modding, not just allow patching.

column8: Super disapointing. Like many others I purchased this game in alpha with high hopes. A company like Double-Fine wouldn't let us down, would they? Appearantly they would. Because of  the list of features that they  "hoped" to implement, I would jump on every time I saw they had another patch. After a few hours, I'd log off frustrated by repeated raid in a "low threat" area or constant meteors where none should be or a dead guy blocking my airlock. Every patch the game got a little better, but nowhere near what it could have been or what DF implied we were investing in. I understand that they need to make money, but bailing on a game that people invested thier time and money into won't get them any repeat costumers. Not this one anyway.

column8:
A pretty fun, unfinished, Sims-meets-FTL.

Started playing about a year ago, during early access. Have played the game as it developed, up until 'official release'.

The theming and art of this game is excellent. It's cute without being saccharine, the dangers of space are presented realistically, which somehow feels acceptably couched within the hand-drawn avatars and cartoon 3d models. I love it.

The game starts off viciously (excluding the tutorial), dropping your three spacefarers off in the blackness with a small pod of resources and 8 minutes of oxygen. Within those eight minutes, you have to build a small space station that can support a oxygen-producer, and an airlock.

All my astronauts suffocated before I was able to do this, and it was excellent.
The game presented me with such a challenge, I was glued, it was excellent. The first time I successfully got my guys into that little pocket of safety, [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ny2E0BY5s-0#t=108]I felt like that scene from Gravity[/url].

And thus ended the difficulty curve of Spacebase DF-9.
From that point on out, excluding game-breaking bugs (to be addressed later), the game gets easier and easier. Your first foothold allows you to establish resource collection, you invest wisely, and eventually you have a thriving base of about 40 personnel, you've run out of local resources, and are colllecting recycled resources from passing derelicts.

Some playthroughs got to be so easy, I'd just start building massive space-station shrines, or just interior hallways that stretch across space to the next resource deposit, because it was fun.

Sometimes, I'd have enough surplus to just install double-walls around my entire station, so when boarders attempted their namesake, they'd just drill a entrance into the interior bulkhead.

There are some minor issues I have with infrastructure, for instance, for oxygen, the recyclers produce oxygen that free-flows through the station, but aside from that, there's no real way to control it. Usually it's best to center the recyclers in the base, and build the other rooms off as spokes, but if you have say, a long hallway, the oxygen just ceases to flow down the hall, since it's 'range' is too far. The addition of oxygen ventilation, and power conduits, would be a much appreciate increase in control and complexity.

This game had/has such potential, if well balanced and bug-fixed, but there are powers higher-up putting an end to that. Developer Double-Fine has recently seen a round of layoffs, shorty after CEO Tim Schaffer announced that production would cease on Spacebase DF-9. While I've not gone through the process of comparing Spacebase's credits with the current Double-Fine roster, the coincidence is certainly suspiscious. Double Fine, who since Brutal Legend have been relying on Kickstarter and Early Access to fund their products, may have found that charitable funds are not an effective way to bankroll game development.

Regardless, the premature cessation of development on Spacebase has it's noticable effects. Massive, game-breaking bugs still exist, that completely ruin the expierence.

For instance, technicians are tasked with repairing damaged or worn-down equipment around the base. At it's peak, I had around 20 assigned, and I typically ignore them, as they automatically prioritize things to repair.

Instead, I'm focusing on the Marines I've send out to a derelict to clear any threats. Surprise, surprise, there's a xenomorph on this derelict, and I haven't committed enough troops to deal with it. As it chases the final doomed marine around the derelict, it's tail flicks a door, damaging it. I sigh as I watch the marine die to the monster, when I notice that there's movement elsewhere in the derelict.

A conga-line of technicians stroll through the airlock, ready to fix the broken door. As the alien rears it's head on the first, I'm frantically trying to do anything I can to get them back into the main base. But it's too late. They're all panicked, and it's not like the game has any system to give independant commands to a single unit. I lose half of my base's population to bad AI. This is not a one-off; it has ended essentially all of my long-running playthroughs.

Other bugs exist, such as the game having trouble determining what is and isn't space, which leads to things like units being sucked through an interior doorway into a bedroom, only to hover there, trapped, as if it were zero-gravity, until they starve. Or the fact that something about scientists causes them to almost immediately 'go insane' when assigned the position, causing them to run around fighting other crew, and breaking things.

Some of these bugs may have been fixed since, but they were present in the game when it went 'Final', so I am writing about them here.

I really, really like what this game could be, and maybe mods will get it there. You'll noticed I've 'Recommended' it on this review; while it's certainly one of the most ambivalent recommendations I've given for a game, it's entertaining and unique enough to definitely be worth playing.

Get it on sale, though. And don't trust Double-Fine to not release another half-baked product... definitely wait until the next title is complete before putting cash down.

column8:
I started with DF-9 very early on, the updates were consistent and beefy enough that it kept my attention and I didn't feel I wasted too much time with a few new stations every build. 

New problems would of course pop up every Alpha release, but that is to be expected and for the most party they were ignored, yet underlying and game breaking issues never seemed to get fixed that made the end game for the most part pointless while cosmetic and uneeded areas were implemented. 

The game is playable for the most part but feels to have been abandoned after being pushed into release after it seems it ran out of money. I would have even recomended the game had the Devs fixed what is there, I could have forgiven the game missing many of the promised features but as it stands now until it gets some much needed attention the review is going to remain negative and I can't in good faith recommend it to anyone which really is disappointing as it had such promise and I did enjoy it despite being broken and unplayable past certain points.

column9: A very rewarding and addictive game, sometimes too difficult, but occasionally you'll manage to achieve something (high randomness). The graphics are pleasant, and building your space base is very atmospheric. The creators have abandoned development, but the community continues to make patches - http://www.spacebasehub.net/

column8: I was really liking this game but now that they are dropping it.  I just feel pissed off and ripped off.  I will never buy another game from this company and it is sad because I enjoyed alot of their titles.
column9: I was really liking this game but now that they are dropping it.  I just feel pissed off and ripped off.  I will never buy another game from this company and it is sad because I enjoyed alot of their titles.

column8:
This game has more holes in it than a shower head.

Here's an example, your base is breached by raiders, they board your base, you order your security force to engage the intruders, your security force runs in and more often than not they will stand there and let themselves get shot or beaten to death by the intruders.

If your security force decides to work properly and you survive for about an hour, the game will attempt to wipe you out once and for all by sending in raider ship after raider ship to attack your base until there is nobody left alive on the station and raiders destroy everything inside until they suffocate from the lack of oxygen.

These problems are to me the biggest ones with the game, other problems are that parts of the game like research that have an unfinished feel to them and they never fully completed character development.

Best advice is to download the unofficial patches as they bring the game up to a more respectable level such as having better security, more items etc but they can only take it so far as the code isn't user friendly.

column8:
I actually bought this game after reading all the negative reviews because I wanted to see how bad it was. I thought it might be so bad that I'd get a chance to write a funny review and laugh about it with my friends.

I was shocked to discover that I actually liked it. DF-9 has much better graphics than any other dwarf-fortress-lite game I've played, and it's quite challenging while fun. I get the feeling that a lot of the hate directed at this game is due to the fact that the developers promised a lot more than they delivered on, but what's here is still pretty and enjoyable.

The are some weird gameplay decisions - like the fact that when ships dock at your base, they bypass your defenses automatically and essentially becomes a new randomly generated chunk of your base. However, this can be countered by building floor in strips outside your base to keep ships from from interfering with it... so it's a weird mechanic, but it has a counter and doesn't ruin the fun.

A lot of the encounters feel like they were just intended as placeholders - they feel a bit rushed.

I played the game for over 32 hours, enjoyed it, and found it hard to put down... so I'd have to say overall I think I got my money's worth.

I get the feeling that a lot of the hate directed at this game is due to the fact that the developers promised a lot more than they delivered on, but what's here is still pretty and enjoyable.

The are some weird gameplay decisions - like the fact that when ships dock at your base, they bypass your defenses automatically and essentially becomes a new randomly generated chunk of your base. However, this can be countered by building floor in strips outside your base to keep ships from from interfering with it... so it's a weird mechanic, but it has a counter and doesn't ruin the fun.

A lot of the encounters feel like they were just intended as placeholders - they feel a bit rushed.

I played the game for over 32 hours, enjoyed it, and found it hard to put down... so I'd have to say overall I think I got my money's worth.

column8:
This game could had been a great theme game you know like (theme hospital and themepark games) with an awsome survival feal to it.. first off it looked so good what was planned and people started to get there own ideas on how epic this game could turn out to be.. sadly it was left to early its not a finished game by far and alot of stuff people has begged for has not been shown.. Im sad to say i cant recommend this game it has its charm but thats about it, build every room and see people work only take a few hours then your stuck in booredom.

Dont buy this game, i just hope that other developers that see this project will auctully make a game like it thats finished and more polished then this crap. 

3/10 
+ Theme park feel for a bit
+ building system with Air and vacum
+ stupid npc trying to turn them self on fire our jump out of an airlock.. or my favorite get stucked in a door.

Rest of the 7 points is just a angry rant sorry. I dont get why people think its ok to get players dreams up and then blow it out of the airlock as this game did, shame on you.

column8:
Want to watch experienced space fairing adventureres remove thier space-suits to die in a vacuum for no concievable reason? How about repeatedly getting into fist fights with their best buddies over disparate opinions on the subject of foods? Or perhaps you're the type who enjoys how stalwart security agents decide to go completely nanners  while trying to figure out that airlocks also close on derelict space crafts. If these or any other of mindlessly irritating possibilites make you shiver with joy to think of then this is your game!

*Litter your station with thousands of pointless clutter objects that your crew will leave effing everywhere!
*Marvel at stupid AI which seems to go out of its way to piss you off!
*Wonder at clunky building mechanics and counter-intuitive controls!
*Grow food that your bartenders will fill every table with, which your crew inturn will ignore completely while they starve!
*Capture Raiders (or even your own CREW!) who will occasionally just walk right out of thier cells and go totally bonkers!
*Try not to snap your keyboard in two as your crew inexplicably opens the airlock, asphyxiating the entire station!

These and thousands more mind-numbingly stupid bugs (which will never be fixed in this dead game) await you in... SPACEBASE DF-9*ninenine*

column8:
The problem with this game is that it often throws too much at you in too short a time that you can never recover or make progress. I oftentimes wonder what the point of having people set as Security when a boarding party comes and kills 3 people all the while the Security people are sleeping and eating. Even with emergency alarms in every room I feel like the guys just stand around and do nothing.  Technicians rarely seem to repair anything, constantly getting messages telling me that my machines are in poor condition. Even with guys that it shows love the job and have a high star rating I don't seem to ever be able to keep up. 

It a shame really because this is just the kind of game I could sink hours upon hours in. A simulation game in space. Essentially The Sims in space where you build rooms and expand your station. Early on it was so much fun, I really enjoyed it but the bugs and problems mentioned above just suck all that fun right out into space. I hope that the game continues to get updates to make it more playable and allow for the inhabitants to actually feel useful.  Until then it is hard to recommend this title to anyone.

column8: This game has the potential to be a lot of fun but it falls short from the start. I chose a high density area for mining an low density for the raiders. I get raided every 15 minute or so. Then to no surprise the 1 raider is a grandmaster marksmen wile my guys have a board with a nail in it. I have restarted so many times now I can get the base started easy enough. But die out every 15 to 20 minute. NOT FUN.  I will give this game a thumbs up but it needs some patching and balancing between raders skills and your bases retards skill I mean security.

column8: Esta es la primera vez que hago un review... Compre este juego en early access, en un bundle que incluya algunos otros juegos de DF, el concepto me atrapo, y considere que valdria la pena. Estuve al tanto de los updates a traves de las noticias de steam, y en cada vez lo jugue. No creo haber jugado por mas de 1 hora en cada sesion. Â¿Que es lo que Spacebase DF-9 ofreciÃ³ cuando vio la luz como early access? Una idea brillante, un concepto original en un constructor de civilizaciones, con grandes promesas de expansiÃ³n en terminos de jugabilidad, caracteristicas etc. Vamos, es Double Fine, Psyconauts, seguro sera un juegazo - pensÃ© en su momento. Â¿Que es lo que Spacebase DF-9 ofrece en realidad? No mucho. Admito que es entretenido durante un rato, desastres, piratas tratando de abordarte, capsulas extraÃ±as apareciendo cerca de ti, otros astronautas, si si, eso esta bien. 5 horas despues, donde las mismas mecanicas continuan sucediendo, sin materia que extraer, sin un rumbo en especifico, sin siquiera objetivos inmediatos... Es entendible que incluso tu tripulacion quiera cometer suicido porque las maquinas de comida no tienen los sabores que les gustan. Abandone el juego hasta que vi que paso de Alpha a 1.0. Lo jugue nuevamente como 1.0. Y la sorpresa fue, que el juego era exactamente lo mismo. No mas, no menos, lo mismo. Mi conclusiÃ³n fue, que el nuevo negocio de Double Fine no es mas hacer videojuegos, solamente proyectos kickstarter o early access de donde sacar dinero, para despues dejarlos a suerte de modders. NO VALE LA PENA, Y NO LO RECOMIENDO NI SIQUIERA EN REBAJA. Banished, o cualquier otro constructor de civilizaciones supera con creces este proyecto fallido.
column9: This is my first time reviewing... I bought this game in early access, in a bundle that included some other DF games. The concept caught my attention, and I figured it would be worth it. I kept up with updates through the Steam news feed, and I played it each time. I don't think I played for more than an hour in each session. What did Spacebase DF-9 offer when it was released in early access? A brilliant idea, an original concept in a civilization builder, with big promises of expansion in terms of gameplay, features, etc. Come on, it's Double Fine, Psyconauts, it's sure to be a great game - I thought at the time. What does Spacebase DF-9 actually offer? Not much. I admit it's entertaining for a while: disasters, pirates trying to board you, strange capsules appearing near you, other astronauts, yeah, yeah, that's fine. 5 hours later, where the same mechanics continue to happen, with no matter to mine, no specific direction, not even immediate goals... It's understandable that even your crew wants to commit suicide because the vending machines don't have the flavors they like. I abandoned the game until I saw that it went from Alpha to 1.0. I played it again as 1.0. And the surprise was, the game was exactly the same. No more, no less, the same. My conclusion was that Double Fine's new business is no longer making video games, but rather Kickstarter or Early Access projects to raise money from, and then leave them to the luck of modders. IT'S NOT WORTH IT, AND I DO NOT RECOMMEND IT, NOT EVEN ON SALE. Banished, or any other civilization builder, far surpasses this failed project.

column8:
The problem with games that follow the lead of unfinished freeware games with incredibly good ideas is that when the original lacks a definitive purpose, the derivatives tend to as well. As the name suggests, Spacebase DF-9 is derivative of Dwarf Fortress, a city-building ASCII title that has absolutely no purpose outside of building your base and keeping it afloat until that sudden, inevitable downward spiral that brings your civilization to ruins.

It's a decent idea, for sure. I picked this game up as soon as it was available because I'd tried the Amnesia Fortnight prototype and desperately wished that it would be expanded into something great. The premise has a lot of potential, after all, with space being as vast as it is. Unfortunately, DF-9 left Early Access far less than what I'm sure a lot of people hoped it would be.

Spacebase DF-9 is a fairly simplistic base-builder sim. You pick a spot on a big galactic map and then build your fortune on it. Starting with only three people and some meager resources, it's your job to thrive in your little sector, mine up asteroids for more building material, and balance out the health and well-being of all the space grifters you pick up along the way. Sometimes you're attacked by bandits, or a bit of wrecked ship will float by for the taking. Sometimes you'll come across a particularly pushy visitor who insists on joining your roster. Sometimes you'll be stricken by a space disease and need to research the cure before it kills off your crew. That's about it.

The problem I've noticed is that there is really nothing in the way of depth. It's fine to be tossed into the wilds and learn the ways of the land by yourself, but once you've built one of everything you're pretty much done.  The happiness graphs and space social networking tabs might promise more to the individual psychological needs of your people, but there seems to be little to no chance of even the most dour, reclusive person on your base succumbing to space madness and striking out in a hilariously deadly rage. So that's one of my secret space fantasies rendered undoable.

If you want to build a space-base with a little more depth, I'd recommend Startopia. If you want to Dwarf Fortress, just play Dwarf Fortress. Unfortunately, Spacebase DF-9 is relegated to the Horrors of Early Access bin, which is a shame considering all that potential.

column8:
[h1]FIRST:[/h1]
I only played 2 and a half hour at the moment, so this is what I think about this game right now.
The review could change over time.

This game is pretty addicting I have to say, and I encountered no bugs 'till now.
Music is pretty nice, but not the best. Graphics are good.
The price is not the best right now. I only have it 'cause of an humble bundle, I got 7 games or something (including this game) for 10â‚¬, but I won't buy it for 20â‚¬.

[h1]Pro[/h1]
-good graphics
-small social interactions between people (nice to watch)
-there is a tutorial
-this game is moddable
-music is ok
-good GUI

[h1]Contra[/h1]
-no real saving (you can only have one save at the moment, and it gets deleted automatically when loosing)
-not enough content
-community is not that friendly
-bugs
-[b][u]no updates will come, EVER (This game is discontinued)[/u][/b]

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
This game is playable, but not the game everyone would like. Get it for half the price or something, or get it together with other games, but not for 20â‚¬.

[h1]Edit![/h1]
I have to say, by now I'm really angry about myself having bought this game 4 months ago or something. What the game does it does good, but it doesn't have enough content and is not very polished. Do NOT buy this game except you know this game will never get better. I had fun with the game myself, but the price is too high and there is not enough content, so STAY AWAY. Please.

column8:
The game has so much incredible potential, but it is stymied by a lack of development. The many jobs/professions operate fairly well, but ultimately it all comes crashing down by the mid to late game. Once raiders and derelicts inhabited by hostiles become more commonplace, the utter incompetence of your security staff makes exploration and defense near impossible.

The game as a whole is an excellent distraction and I never feel as though I wasted my time, but I do wish your citizens were at least a quarter as competent as the enemy raiders.

column8:
Made new base and my original crew died in the airlock because they were stupid enough not to exit the spacesuits that were running out of oxygen and enter the base that had bunch of oxygen.
My two new crew members who just forced themselves into my base were bit smarter and didn't die in the airlock, but one of them got stuck investigating some spacejunk ,that brought 3 new members to my base, and died eventually after just staying there and running back and forth.

So as the AI of the guys isn't too bright to manage basic survival can't recommend this at all.

column9:
This game could have been Dungeon Keeper in space.

But it wasn't.

I bought it in Early Access.
Tim promised us a lot (most of which never made it to release), I was curious to follow the game's development, I rejoiced at every buggy 0.* version, but even after release, the game still remains a buggy, unplayable mess.

Path Finder doesn't workâ€”in a game with indirect controls, that's unforgivable.

After a few hours of playing on a new base, everything falls apart, and it's not a matter of skill. Believe me, I've played enough to understand the mechanics. All questions should be directed at the game designers.

Terrible optimizationâ€”this game (running on Unity) lags significantly over time. Yes, my hardware isn't the best, but Bioshock Infinite runs smoothly, and then a slideshow starts.

As our foreign comrades say, save your money. And never sponsor games in Early Access.

P.S. The game's development has been abandoned, and there's no hope for improvement.

column9:
Hello everyone.
So, I really like this game. I'm not a huge gaming pro, but I like it from time to time. Coming back to the game itself, I like it because it's calm and at the same time stressful at times.
On the other hand, it's not worth its high price.
So I'm giving it an "up" because I have no choice but to leave it blank, but if I had to rate it, I would give it an 11/20.

column8:
Before you rage at me, yes there are loads of bugs, and yes the development is "finished". I know this, so either take note of my review or shut up.

For those who actually want to read my review, I say in short this game is good if you like base management, but buy it on a ridiculous sale.

The last game I played that could be compared to this is Prison Architect, so I'll compare to that. This game has its ups and downs, but I found that Prison Architect became a bit stale after a while; build fast at the start, expand for new prisoners, work on efficiency. Rinse and Repeat. Not that it wasn't good, but that's the gist of it.

Spacebase Df-9 on the other hand, was a somewhat evolving base management, and a bit of tower defence thrown in when raiders visit too. Once you get the hang of it, you need to constantly adapt your base to make room for new people, keep up with the component decay and so on. One of the hardest bits (albeit interesting) I found was defending against multiple raiders. If you can manage to defeat the raiders, you're then left with a depressed crew (that don't want to work) that needs to repair the remains of the station and hold out until more people show up... or more raiders.

I honestly haven't seen any game breaking bugs yet (touch wood!). Bodies stick around for ages, but with enough doctors they get moved over time. Components decay rapidly, but with the right balance you can keep them in check until you research better things. And yes, research takes ages too, but it's helpful if you're around long enough to finish it.

All in all, it can be problematic, and there are plenty of issues people have talked about, but with patience and taking the time to learn the game, it can be pretty fun. Maybe a 7/10 from me, buy it on a very good sale.

column8:
Spacebase does well enough for what it is - an alpha build rushed to release - but it lacks the strategic depth that a simulation needs in order to keep the player's interest. It doesn't even have enough pretty distractions to make up for the spartan gameplay. This is the kernel of a game that could have been great, but unfortunately that game will never be completed.

On the plus side, Spacebase remarkably stable. I experienced no bugs, glitches, or crashes.

A tip for those frustrated by raiders: build at least one turret in every room and leave them deactivated when not needed. When raiders attack, simply activate the necessary turrets and seal the doors. No muss, no fuss. Don't bother claiming derelicts; they are difficult to defend. Rather, explore them to acquire new crew members or loot and then let them disappear.

In its current and final state, Spacebase is definitely not worth $20; I would not recommend this game at any price other than "free" (I got a complimentary copy with my Hack 'n' Slash purchase).
