column8: Cuando compras este juego tienes que tener claro que se esta comprando, no tiene campaÃ±a ni ninguna clase de progresion, cuando comienzas te dan lo que hay (salvo algunas mejoras de cosas ya existentes que hay que investigar), parece tener el modo de dificultad "pesadilla" por defecto, ya que los asaltos a tu estacion espacial son constantes y permanentes, ademas de otros problemas como los meteoritos y los "aliens". Por todo ello supone un reto cumplir la lista de objetivos que dan para considerar completado todo lo que se puede realizar en la partida en curso. Si pulieran un poco la inteligencia artificial de los ciudadanos y se pudiera tener mas de una partida guardada seria de agradecer, pero parece que habra que esperar a la comunidad de mods para tener una experiencia menos sufrida
column9: When you buy this game you have to be clear about what you are buying, it has no campaign or any kind of progression, when you start you are given what is there (except for some improvements to already existing things that need to be investigated), it seems to have the "nightmare" difficulty mode by default, since the assaults on your space station are constant and permanent, in addition to other problems such as meteorites and "aliens". For all this, it is a challenge to complete the list of objectives they give you to consider everything that can be done in the current game completed. If they polished the artificial intelligence of the citizens a bit and allowed to have more than one saved game it would be appreciated, but it seems that we will have to wait for the modding community to have a less painful experience.

column8: I bought this game for the double fine label. That is a choice I regret. I am careful most of the time with anything that was early access, when I saw double fine's name it give me some hope for a game that would be saw through till the end. I regret my purchase immensly. The game I enjoyed in alpha still lacks many features that where listed and never will be add it leaving it to the modding community to fix up. This is not the practice of a games developer but of a lazy studio who cannot budget.

column8:
I bougth Spacebase DF-9 because it looked very similar to a cool yet repetitive game called Space Colony that I enjoyed playing, but I was however disappointed. I was hoping for an elaborate technology tree, more interesting characters and a cool space-adventure feeling.

Although I haven't played very long, Spacebase is a game that feels somewhat empty from the very beginning and graphicly very neutral. You would think a game with alien creatures could be much more funky as Back to the Futures' 2015 vision. There were good ideas put into this game, but it's definitely not finished.

column8: You can tell painstaking amounts of work went into programming how things could go wrong. You can also tell that not a single thought was given to how to keep thing running. My techs hovering around the research room and refigrerator while a malfunctioning airlock slowly kills everyone on my station is just hohoho funny. Something as simple as the ablity to set priotiries on jobs could have saved this game. As it is, it sucks. It's not hard because it was desgned to be hard, it's hard because the programers are lazy.

column8:
After playing for several hours, all I can conclude about this game is that it's [i]excessively frustrating.[/i]

First off, the tutorial lacks a lot of important information.  No mention that you have to build aesthetic stuff all over to keep up morale, no proper explanation of what most of the structures/objects do or why you should care about them.  I lost three bases to everyone flipping out on each other before I pulled up the (terribly-made) wiki and a starter's guide said to scatter cosmetic stuff everywhere to keep people happy.

The interface, while thematically good at first, gets very old very fast.  Every UI element is oversized, and everything flickers like an old TV set with every interaction, and everything has horizontal lines through it like an old computer monitor.  It gets grating and hard on the eyes rather quickly.  Event warnings on the right side of the screen can be minimized (usually), but not dismissed, even for minor alerts, or ones that no longer apply.

You have no direct control over the citizens of your station, which is fine, but it means that when they're all ignoring your orders - which happens fairly often - you can't do anything about it.  The closest you can get to controlling anyone is setting people to the "security" job and setting a beacon  - they'll jog over and stand near the beacon, but that's all you can do.  You can't prioritize commands, or set a "do this first" type thing on anything, so if you need a room built NOW, you have to go across the entire map and cancel every other build/dismantle task.  If things fall into disrepair, technicians take FOREVER to fix them - each time they work on something, they only improve it by a few percentage points, and then wander off again.  You also can't set anyone to do more than one task - a guy can build things, or repair things, but not both unless you constantly toggle his settings in the roster screen.

Raiders and derelict ships spawn far too often and too regularly - it's not at all random.  If you don't get "security" to respond in time to raiders, your citizens will just wander through and drop one by one.  Seriously, multiple times I've lost almost my entire station's population to single raiders because nobody has the sense to run away when they're being shot at, or security gets there one at a time and just drops.

A known bug (I'd say it's a bug, anyway) with derelict ships is that sometimes they'll just "drift away" with your people still on-board.  What this means is that the derelict despawns - taking your people with it.  This means you have to very quickly "claim" every part of the derelict to prevent that, at which point it's treated like part of your base - including constant alerts that it's not connected to the power grid, and citizens will wander over to it and just hang about, making it impossible to safely dismantle.  This also includes warnings about rooms on the ship not being tended to properly, even if you've already flagged everything to be dismantled for materials.  Heaven forbid you don't tend the garden on that ship you plan to scrap (by the way, it mentions this only in passing in the tutorial, but you NEED a garden - it provides food that doesn't eat through your resources like the food-dispenser does.  And you need a bar with full facilities to serve/store that food properly - also only hinted at).

Researching new technologies/illnesses isn't discussed at all in the tutorial, nor does it say how gardens work, or what to do with incapacitated-but-alive raiders.  It doesn't talk about building a brig, or whether you can ever do anything with these raiders - you only find out on third-party guides that EVENTUALLY these raiders can convert to citizens if they're confined long enough.  And your own citizens will freely wander through the brig, even if occupied, and get injured/killed by captured raiders.

"Passing ships" also happen like clockwork, and get spammy.  The sense of humor in all the dialogue is great and everything, but it wears thin after the 200th ship in a 2-hour session, especially since most of the somewhat-limited encounter types seem to play out the exact same way every single time - either they give you more citizens, or they send raiders.  If you tell them to go away, they either go away, send citizens anyway, or send raiders anyway.  And you almost always know exactly what it'll be the moment it pops up.  Passing ships also turn off timelapse - you'll be going along at 4x speed to get something built, then it pops back to 1x so you can tell some guy to bugger off because you have no more room for more people.  And he may still send more citizens, in which case you have to quickly build beds/rooms for them to stay in or they'll start throwing tantrums and send station morale into the toilet.

I'm sure there are other issues I've forgotten to mention, but I think this gives a decent idea of how obnoxious this game is to play in general.

column8:
The idea behind DF9 is awesome. A City Builder meeting Sims in space. And that's about all I have to say to sell the game to you...

Now why I'd recommend NOT to buy it. Reasons are numerous, and most already mentioned by others and [url=http://wildwoodgeek2.blogspot.nl/2014/12/space-base-df-9.html]this blogpost[/url] explains most of it I think.

In addition to the blogpost I'd like to add an other reason why NOT to buy DF9. Once again the AI, which just plain sucks! My personal experience with the AI sucking balls is that after a debris stike, my oxigen tanks and power supply got hit. Without power and oxigen, the whole crew starts to panic, including the whole technical team. WTF? You guys should run to the power supply and oxigen tanks to fix them instead of running around like headless chickens!

An other problem is the Sims part of the game. The people have a (hidden!) worklist of stuff they have to do. So far so good I'd say. But technical maintenance (yes once again) should have a top priority for lifesupport, but noooo..... Ocigen tanks are about to break down and they fix ...a bar stool... FFS guys get real please! Or at least let me point the Sims where they should go next instead of fully automated.

Bottom line, the idea behind DF9 is real good. Sadly the developer dropped the ball and the project, leaving us with a half-baken, bugged and dumb game :'(

column8:
Like so many have already said, this game was abandoned. They've simply polished the game to look appealing but the game play is downright unpleasant. It's very apparent that some of the decisions that were made in game play should have been better thought out. My advice to the creators: you should have looked to games like Evil Genius to get a better understanding of what's wrong.

Some things that bothered me while playing: 
- no prioritization system in place for construction ( example: watching your workers finish building an empty room before constructing an oxygen recycler can be frustrating, especially when people start asphyxiating)
- I watched a worker box themselves into a sealed room and then remove her suit. Instead of finishing the job and building a door to gain access to the base, she preffered to starve to death. 

In summary, unless you see any news about much more development in this game, don't bother. It's sad to see a game with such potential be abandonned like this.
column9:
Like so many have already said, this game was abandoned. They've simply polished the game to look appealing but the game play is downright unpleasant. It's very apparent that some of the decisions that were made in game play should have been better thought out. My advice to the creators: you should have looked to games like Evil Genius to get a better understanding of what's wrong.

Some things that bothered me while playing: 
- no prioritization system in place for construction ( example: watching your workers finish building an empty room before constructing an oxygen recycler can be frustrating, especially when people start asphyxiating)
- I watched a worker box themselves into a sealed room and then remove her suit. Instead of finishing the job and building a door to gain access to the base, she preffered to starve to death.

column8:
Unfortunately, this game has been abandoned. It was at .5 before being forced to 1.0 and left to the hands of modders. Which is terrible, considering the directions this game was going before it was canned.

The name is misleading, it is less Dwarf Fortress in space, and more The Sims 2 in space with dwarf fortress elements.

Definately needs mods to be in a finished state. Pity.

column8:
DF has already announced they're no longer building out the game, so WYSIWYG.

It's a broad stroke of a space station sim. It's fun at first, but you quickly get frustrated. You ask your residents to do something and they're too busy eating or sleeping to attend to your requests. You also get inundated with people trying to board, faster than you can accomodate them at first. Some of the rooms and objects don't work very well.

column8:
This game is GARBAGE.  PLEASE do NOT buy this game.  Its broken, unfinished and NOT worth the download or space on Steam.  I received this as a gift and gave it a shot, only to find out its so broken that its not worth the time or money.  DO NOT BUY THIS GAME.

I wasted about 90 minutes trying to play this game.  At the very beginning the help hints are quite vague and whats more you cannot meet the requirements due to a bug.  After 5 games my crew always dies when their oxygen runs out, even when there are rooms full of pressurized oxygen.  After multiple attempts and forum search I find out its a bug that has yet to be addressed!  Thanks Steam for putting a broken game on the market.

column8:
So far I've played the game for 44 hours in total. I enjoyed every minute. Now alot of people (and I mean ALOT of people) hated this game and still do. Lack of strategy, no proper ending, horrible AI and mountains of bugs. Some people say Double Fine grabbed the money and ran and that this is discontinued, but Ive been getting game-changing updates at a normal pace. Im not sure if the content isn't being delivered to them or if they are just hating, but this game seems to me as not discontinued.

SpaceBaseDF9 is a relaxing, term long-term game what do I mean by long-term? All your actions are to prevent things in the future that may harm you. The game is slow, but not steady as it shows alot of difficulty. Sometimes it is just luck of the dice. If you aren't a fan of linear games and like management games then I think you should buy it.

This is my opinion you probably won't agree with it, but still If your interested in a game watch gameplay of it and you will know if you want it.

Double Fine decided to abandon development of this game, stamped it with a "Version 1.0" release, released the code "for the community to take over if they want," and that was it. If I were you, I'd spend my money on sandwiches and Coca-Cola.

column8:
Unfinished, abandoned game. Devs did a quick cash grab by putting the game on sale a week before announcing they would stop production and release the game as was. Which was an alpha 6 stage. They went from alpha to release and never even patched it again. 

They actually expected the game to be fully funded on Early Access alone and tried to treat it like a normal release. Meaning they had an overhead of thousands of dollars. A completely unrealistic way of making and funding a game, by a developer that really does not care about their customers.

I will NEVER buy Double Fine games again. They are the lowest of the low when it comes to money hungry developers.

column8:
Nach 10 Studen hatte ich aus Frust erstmal eine negative Bewertung abgegeben, da es schien als kÃ¶nne ich eine Basis nicht wirklich halten oder weiter aufbauen. Frustrierend war, dass man nur ein Spiel spielen kann; ist es verloren,.... fÃ¤ngt man wieder von vorne an. 

Doch nach 20 Stunden Ã¤nderte sich dies und ich war motiviert trotz kurzem Tutorial selbst herausfinden, woran die eigene Spieltaktik nun wieder scheiterte. Toll fand ich den Humor im Spiel, auch wenn dieser leider nur auf Englisch sichbar wird, und das 80iger Jahre Design, welches mich an Babylon 5 erinnerte. 

Wichtig bei diesem Spiel ist es: Srategisch mit Energie und Alien-Skills umzugehen sowie die Medizin und Forschung nicht auf "spÃ¤ter" zu verschieben! Dann klappt es auch mit dem Baseausbau und der Raiderinvasion.

[7/10]
column9:
After 10 hours, I initially gave it a negative review out of frustration because it seemed like I couldn't really hold onto a base or continue building it. It was frustrating that you can only play one game; if you lose, you start all over again.

But after 20 hours, this changed, and despite the short tutorial, I was motivated to figure out for myself why my own game tactics were failing again. I loved the game's humor, even if it's unfortunately only available in English, and the 80s design, which reminded me of Babylon 5.

The key to this game is to use energy and alien skills strategically, and not to put off medicine and research until "later"! Then base expansion and raider invasions will also work.

[7/10]

column8:
Full Review:

Big discussions arose about the Early Access programm and kickstarted games. Leaving that aside I wanna focus purely on the game, that I got bundled in a Humble Bundle when it was still Alpha and played several times until its current version.

The premise and style of the game seemed enticing to me: Build and manage a space station with room for crew and their needs. I like space and sci-fi settings, plus the whole base-management had a Theme Hospital-like feel to it, which was also a great and creative game.

So I started out in space and began building. The game doesnâ€™t offer a campaign, you basically free-build and manage your base from scratch. After a few basic rooms for living quarters, refining asteroids and oxygen supply your base begins to take shape. An intercom window pops up: other space drifters saw my station and want to join my effort. Randomized events like this keep things interesting and challenging. Not all encounters are friendly and you need to be ready for intruders - or pay the costs.

The building and managing is fun and keeps me entertained: There are some fun ideas in Spacebase DF-9 that I really like. Your base-dwellers for example post about their wants and needs in their social media â€œSpacefaceâ€, where you can read how they feel and if they are happy with their occupation. The rooms and objects have good ideas that tie into each other: Plants can not only produce food but also oxygen. The food you produce can be brought into the pub for cooking. When fire breaks out you can not only use fire extinguishers but you can also cut off the oxygen supply to a room - though this usually takes longer and damages your equipment.

All these ideas and concept sound fun - on paper. In the game however they can get buggy and very frustrating. The power management for example can get very messy as the only data I have is a bunch of colorful lines across your base. I donâ€™t see how much reach a generator has and how much power is being drawn. New derelicts appear out of nowhere that are so close to my base that my building plans are screwed. And several times my crewmembers kill themselves by simply staying in space until their oxygen runs out or not fleeing a empty vessel that runs out of oxygen. This is very frustrating and something that doesnâ€™t feel like its the players fault. The build-queue is also not very clear as my crew builds rooms but just doesnâ€™t make time to build the door that would connect them - ordering them useless.
All in all Spacebase DF-9 is a game that had great promise but will never live up to it because bugs ruin the experience. I tried, I spent the time to build a big base and train my crew to fight back an alien invasion - but when the same men later just suffocate by standing in an room without oxygen, I just feel like its not my fault, its the games. And I donâ€™t want to play it any more.

column8:
Don't bother with this game. SBDF-9 a good concept and the game definitely had potential, but it's a flop.

- The game is (and feels) unfinished.
- Bugs and crashes are common even after "release".
- Poor user experience, frustrating character AI.
- As it was left by the developer, the game has a severe lack of depth.

I am extremely disappointed with the developer's choice of abandoning development, but I guess it's a risk one accepts when buying into Early Access.

ADHD Version: DO NOT BUY.

column9:
The game is amazing!
I understand the cries of those people who are now screaming: OH NO, WE'VE BEEN DECEIVED, THEY PROMISED MORE!!! But guys, understand, you need to vote for Early Access games with your rubles if you want them to develop. The developers also need to eat and don't want to work at a loss.

About the game itself, people might say the following:
Remember the classic Dungeon Keeper, where you had to think through every room, separate the creatures so they wouldn't kill each other, make sure everyone was well-fed, etc.? Well, this game is Dungeon Keeper, but in space. But here you also have to monitor the integrity of your base, defend it not only from pirates who attack, but also take care of the base's integrity and the health of the base's inhabitants, otherwise you might get some surprises :3

column8: its a great game to play
column9: its a great game to play

column8:
This is not my review but I thought it should be noted that this game won "Best mod support" from PC Gamer. http://www.pcgamer.com/goty-simulator-2014-the-alternative-pc-gamer-awards/

What does that mean you ask?

"It's always great when games arrive with built-in mod support, but this year Double Fine went a step beyond. Not only did they release the full source code for their Early Access game Spacebase DF-9, but they left hundreds of planned features incomplete, giving modders the exciting challenge of finishing the game themselves. It's rare to see that sort of selfless generosity from a developer, and we salute Double Fine for passing the torch to modders, or at least hurriedly chucking the torch at modders from the window of their limousine as they screeched away from the curb."

So yeah. Buy at your own risk.

column8: While perpetually unfinished (those poor developers), I still got a great deal of playtime enjoyment out of Spacebase DF9. I probably wouldn't buy it at full price, but on sale? Yer damn tootin' I will.

- la partie attaque et dÃ©fense via la sÃ©curitÃ© (pas vu de logique, les ennemis se comportent stupidement, etc)

- une seule partie possible

column9:
Well, at first glance, the game seems interesting, and I hadn't seen the previous reviews at all. It hooked me, and still does, for several hours at a time, and it's quite addictive. However, after all this time playing, you realize its shortcomings:
- Bugs galore (and not just graphical ones)
- Morale management is a trowel (no matter what you do, people end up dying)
- Attack and defense via security (no logic seen, enemies behave stupidly, etc.)
- No objectives
- Only one possible game
- Basic features are "basic" (no fine-grained management of O2 or energy, food, morale, equipment, etc.)
- AI that's completely off the mark (engineer twiddling their thumbs instead of building something essential)
- Horrible pathfinding

So, you can buy the game, but you'll quickly feel the shortcomings.

column8: GOTY. I love playing 'hope the game doesn't break' simulator.
column9: GOTY. I love playing 'hope the game doesn't break' simulator.

column8:
I purchased during the very early days after it was released on Steam and I did truly enjoy the game back then even with its terrible game breaking bugs. Every update added new features that made it both easier to play and easier to get everyone on your entire base dead within minutes.  
I still see a single raider take out 5 of my level 3+ security staff and also win several matches of fisticuffs with civvies... what the F..? 

Also, the AI is strange... SO stange! And possibly sociopathic... with not so subtle rage issues... and a long line of family mental health problems... Someone will freak over something, probably quickly, and go around smashing half of the base until someone else smashes them in the face enough times that they pass out.  If your unlucky, which you usually are, they will have trashed your oxygen recyclers and no one will repair them before the levels get low enough that everyone runs around like chickens with their heads cut off until they asphyxiate instead of solving the issue like a boss.  Sorry, that got dark.

Unfortunately in its broken, unfinished, never to be finished state I cannot recommend this game.  If it goes on sale for $1 or something similar depending on your region it may be nice to pick up to see how good the game could have been eventually, when it was properly finished, but that is just about it.

column9:
This game caused a stir when, amid ongoing alpha development, it was suddenly released as version 1 and declared complete.

It's quite fun to play. I even think it's fun.

But the more you play, the more you'll be hit with unreasonableness due to poor resident password settings and insufficient development.

Even with security enabled to protect against space pirate attacks, residents are killed unilaterally.

What's more, space pirates come at you in a fairly unreasonable manner, all at once. It's frustrating not being able to deal with domestic affairs when you want to.

I think the reason Banished was able to make a smooth landing is because it was focused on domestic affairs and there were no external enemies.

If you haven't played either, I recommend Banished, unless you're a huge fan of sci-fi.

However, one good thing about this game is that the resident's personal diary entries have a wide variety of variations, which makes it quite fun in itself.

I quit the game without saving, or I want to die... etc. The flavor is good. But that's really all there is to it.

Great premise, Had fun for probably the first 5-6 hours. I even recommended it to others in the beginning. I Enjoyed it - game breaking bugs and all. After all, it's what you expect when you knowingly buy an alpha.

But unfortunately it looks like this game will never be finished. It make me feel really sad for people who've been on-board since the Kickstarter (got mine during its first steam sale.)

Always held Doublefine in high regards, never buying from them again unless it's a full release and reviews are out.

Even with bugs, I did enjoy my time with this space station simulator of sorts. Since most users are looking for a finished game I unfortunately cannot recommend this game.

column8:
Lets leave aside the fact that the game isn't finished, shall we? Double fine decided its done, so lets look at this as a finished product

Spacebase DF-9 is The Sims, but in space. I know what youre thinking, I was hyped too. You can assign different jobs to different citizens and theyll like it a certain amount. Your citizens will scurry around and converse with each other about inane things like space mudcrabs. You can select asteroids to be mined, which works kinda. You can get other people to come by and ask to join your space-hovel, and supposedly they might even try to do other things, but that never happened in my playthrough. You can send you citizens to go and explore derelict ships, and they will find things. You can build rooms, and put things in those rooms, and your citizen will use them. You can give those rooms different named functions, and your citizen will use them for those functions. Spacebase DF-9 is The Sims, but in space.

Pros:

-Aesthetic: If you can count on Double Fine for anything, its that their stuff always looks good. The semi-retro looks of the interface and the hand drawn aliens look nice and stylized. Sending your citizens off to investigate a derelict ship is always a harrowing affair, as the ship is completely dark, with red warning lights flashing ominously through the hallways. Even if you have no idea whats coming, the atmosphere of the ship makes you anticipate losing a few citizens. One fult is that the play space looks very flat, even though your citizens, while in space suits, can go under your space-hovel, which was very confusing the first few times.

-Sound: The soundtrack is short but nice. Ambient trance music has a soft spot in my ear canal, but I found the music very nice, even though it will be seen as repetitive to some. If you dont like, it, you can always mute it and play Eminem, or what have you.

-Core gameplay: The game mechanics I described above are very good, and makes the base of a great sim game. I'll elaborate more on this in the negatives.

-Fun alien designs: I like the designs of the aliens. I didnt see two aliens who looked exactly alike in my playthrough, besides the two humans I started with. Reminds me of Star Wars!

Negatives:

-It isn't Psychonauts. Lets all face facts, the main reason we all buy Double Fine games is in hopes of another wacky, fun game like Psychonauts. It doesnt need to be a Psychonauts game, it just needs to have the same spirit (Although, I'm still holding out hope that if I keep buying DF games, they'll eventually make Psychonauts 2). The plain fact of the matter is that this has none of that spirit. Spacebase DF-9 is as sterile a gaming experience as there is to be found. The most funny thing I did was purposefully suffocate my citizens in the bar. Forshame, Double Fine.

-The gameplay is completely flat. As in grossly, sadly, boringly flat. If you have played 30 minutes of DF-9, you have played 30 hours of DF-9. With the exeption of the rare derlict ships, I spent most of my game watching netflix on the other monitor. Even the derelict ships suck in a way, since even with their mystery, it takes too much time and resource to explore and kill the monsters inside for it to be worth it, since all your citizens will be terrible at fighting. In other games, like the Sims 4, this could be remedied with patches and DLC, but Double Fine has no intention to patch or make DLC for this game, and so were tuck with the husk of a potentially great game.

Ending score: 4/10. A passable game that works just fine but because of its pedigree should be a while lot better than it is. If you really need your fix of a Space Station simulation game, try Space Colony on GOG, if you need a Sims-esque game, just go back to the Sims. If you want a fun Double Fine game, just play Psychonauts or Brutal Legend again.

column8:
This game has so much potential, sadly it doesn't even come close to reaching it. Issues I have:

* Controls are not intuitive
* Balance and pacing are way off
* Far too little control over your people
* All sorts of hidden mechanics that should be visible
* Help and tutorial woefully inadequate. 
* Combat is just not fun.

column8:
This game could be so much fun but it needs rebalanced and tweaked a bit.  Raiders attack far too often and are too hard to kill before they decimate your base.  Then after one or two such raider attacks all of the citizens fall into a deep depression from having their friends killed that they go on a rampage and make a bad situation even worse.  When this happens the only solution is to abandon the game and start over again.

I have tried building a decent base 7 or 8 times at varying locations in space and become equally frustrated each and every time.  I'm done playing this game unless a future update makes it more enjoyable.  Perhaps allow doctors to double as psychiatrists or something.

I'm giving this game a conditional postive review. I received the game for free and played it for about 5 hours. At the end of the 5 hours, from what I could tell, I had exhaused the content. I really enjoyed the 5 hours of time, and it is worth a couple of bucks if you realize its only going to be 5 hours tops of play time.  Pick it up on sale for cheap, but I wouldnt pay the $21CND asking price.

It makes me sad that the game is no longer being developed (it is supported and maintained) with new content as it was so fun and had so much potential.

column8:
Here lies a game with so much wasted potential. A skeleton for potentially a great game left to dust. It lacks the meat that really would flesh out and liven it up into something that could easily become a hit. Instead its just a lesson of why we must be careful when backing early access games. 

Heres hoping someone comes out with a mod to make it what it could of been. In the meantime its not even worth the sale price $6.81 I paid for it. And I am in fact sorry that I supported a failure.

column8:
I really want to like this game, despite it's flaws (it's ceased dev, pre-alpha). However the end game is always the same... even if you manage to survive the constant onslaught of raiders, and space diseases, bodies persist long after death... and corpses have a detrimental affect on crew morale which can prevent crew from wanting to enter areas where these bodies are (which can prevent maintenance and production), or crew end up rioting among themselves. 
It's a massive shame because it had a lot of potential. If the community gets behind this game and manage to produce mods to fix major issues, then I'd recommend it, but as it stands atm it's only worth a punt if it's going cheap.

column8: This is a review for people like me who have no context to be angry at this game, and see it on sale and want to know what it is. DON"T buy this game at full price. It is not worth it. It pissed a lot of people off cause the devs decided to pull the plug on it without delivering on what they promised to (for no clear reason), but on sale its a fun, basic sort of Prison Architect/Banished type of deal in space (even though both are much better games). I reconmend it to you wholeheartedly if it's at least half off and this sort of thing interests you.

column8: A lot of reviews for this game are bitter over what happened, and to be honest, I am too. This game had so much potential but something happened and it was abandoned. But, I still find the game fun... until the 'end-game'. Yes, the AI can be downright stupid at times, but I haven't encountered any bugs or glitches, just the AI being poor. I do enjoy the building mechanics (even though there is a lack of variety and functions in the objects and decortations) and oxygen management, and researching, and like any strategy game, it's fun when things are going well and you can expand. It's the Space PIrate Mothership Raid that ruins things but hey, it's fun while the game lasts. It's short and sweet with a bitter finish. Pick it up cheap, it's good to sink a few hours into every now and then.

column8:
Promise a lot -> provide a good prototype -> Take money -> Run

This sums up this "game" development. Don't be fooled by all the sales it got on (seriously, Doufle Fine can't stop milking that unifinished product, it got on a humble bundle, Steam winter sale,... even after the abandon).

It could have been a good game but Double Fine proved once more that they can't handle money correctly (cf Broken Age). It would have been okay if DF just admited the failure (that's the risk with early-access) but no, they just milk, milk and milk.

Avoid at all cost, this is basically a SCAM.

column9:
The game's concept is actually good, but it has a ton of bugs, almost intentional. They're bugs that make the gameplay horrible. The main ones:

- bodies that never disappear and pile up more and more,
- defense turrets that don't hit anything,
- people who run faster than phasers,
- endless waves of enemies until your base is destroyed,
- people are always incredibly unhappy, no matter how perfect your base is,
- things that need maintenance are never fixed by mechanics and keep getting worse until they catch fire, even if everyone in the base is a mechanic,
- mining supplies run out and you can't maintain the base anymore,
- many other minor bugs that make it so horrible to play that you give up.

And don't think they're close to fixing it, it's been like this for a long time and there's no timetable.

I hope they improve this game, because the idea is very good and it would be a shame.

column8:
This is a fun game with a lot of promise. A great atmosphere, a lot of complexity and challenge, and some interesting concepts are present here. The only concern as of now is that it has a brutal difficulty curve (with the beginning of each attempt basically being a mad dash to not die every time) and is quite unpolished in certain areas. With a bit more fine tuning and feedback this game could be a great addition to the city-building games out there.

UPDATE: So having come back to the game, I see that it has been moved out of early access. Unfortunately all of my concerns have not been addressed, and it appears that updates, fixes and overall work on the game have not and will not occurred. From what I have heard elsewhere the game has been abandoned, which for me is troubling because my love for the game was dependent on the developers putting more time and effort into it. It needed more work, more polish, more fixes, and not only was this not done this was a conscious decision by the company to not do. This is the problem of early access epitomized, do not buy this game. My love for the game and what it could be pales to what it is.

column8: The genre of roguelike and city builder probably shouldn't crossover so often. Spending hours building up a little city only to lose half of your population because the game didn't tell you a turret attached to a friendly docking ship isn't friendly (which makes no sense) is infuriating. There's no way to reload the save either because it's a roguelike and losing due to meaningless randomness is part of the 'genre'. It wouldn't be so bad if your citizens weren't seemingly suicidal, preffering to walk right up to the turrets face instead of just swining behind it. And there's no way to force them into doing so.

That being said, if you want a game you don't really need to think about to get through to burn some time, this would be a good one.

column8:
I bought this on sale and am glad I did, it is an excellent game if you can get it cheaply. I have read many of the negative comments and can not se ethe problem, it would appear there was a lot of hype and much of the game did not meet up to what was wanted. Putting that aside, it is a great game as it currently stands at time of this review.

IT is first of all challenging. I highly recommend you play a few games before you go mental becasue much of the difficulty can be a result of small mistakes early on in gameplay. It is possible to correct any mistakes with a lot of work, but it is far easier not to get ot that point.

If I were to pick a negative it is the idiocy of the AI. I am sure it is becasue I am not using alarms and alerts properly to tell my crew what to do, but It could be easier.

column8:
Ive spent most of the day playing this game, and I've found it very fun, I've noticed a lot of people complaining about undelievered promises, but I dont know what any of those promises were, so I dont care. I've also noticed people complaining about instability and crashes, and bugs. but I havent experienced any of those. One thing I do have to say, is its really annoying when a cloaked battle cruiser slams into your station, because it totally screws up your layout and removing it is a bitch.

One thing you need to know about this game, is that you can't win, and its not about winning, its a sandbox game and most of the fun comes from the crazy stories about dying you'll be able to tell.

column8:
Spacebase DF-9 feels like it had so much potential, but very quickly demonstrates that it has failed to achieve it...

I am honestly yet to be able to experience it's full potential as multiple times now, before even getting established, and with a only a handful of people on board, I've been raided in a 'low' threat zone and leaving me to chase my tail, hoping for new residents to come along to replace my losses... This makes even getting your spacebase established, with a reasonable population, an arduous and frustrating task...

Limited resources are just that, limited, even in areas with alot of asteroids to mine, you will find that they are depleted quickly and constructing large bases (like those shown in the screenshots) seems improbable...

If you're a sucker for punishment, and can pick this up on special, Spacebase DF-9 is probably something you'd enjoy, otherwise, this is not for you.

[do not buy] I deeply regret not being able to recommend this game. Having followed it since its inception, it reached gold status 50% of the way through its development (a figure given by the developers themselves).

Promising and full of good ideas, it will likely never be finished. Buying it is like throwing money down a well and hoping for a miracle.

column8:
I just bought this in the bundle with Hack n' Slash during the winter sale. I totally messed up and didn't read the reviews or any of the news behind it because I had seen videos on the gameplay before, and thought they were still relevant.

It's a fun game, I  give it that, and I bought it solely on the features it has now, not what was supposed to be planned for it. I didn't even know what they were planning from it However, the AI in this game is a mess to say the least.

The game is very incomplete in many aspects, but the most infuriating one if the AI. Raiders will raid your base, and there will be 30 or more at one time. Colonists will no build anything for some reason, even if they are happy. They will go into a panic when something goes wrong, and NO ONE will do something to fix they're situation and they usually just end up being killed by a raider or suffocate. That takes hours of making a decent spacebase, and just throws it away.

I DO NOT recommend you buy this game. The developer abandoned this game, and the code is so screwy and amateur, that no one can make mods to fix some of these very basic mechanics that any game in this genre is expected to have.

Several bugs detract from already bad gameplay and bad UI.

There isn't much to say. I bought this game on sale last year when it went one steam sale (had considered paying almost 50$ for the founders shit). The idea behind it is a fasinating one, like sims in space mixed with mining. 
It's good for a few hours, I've experienced a few bugs, and even fewer game breaking ones.

BUT don't pay for this game. When there was hope for it I'd say get it on sale, but now that the developer has left, who'd pay them for it? Even they don't think its worth it.

Its sad to see doublefine as a studio not doing very well in any of there games :(

column8:
Unfortunately for all the potential depth the concept of a Dwarf Fortress style management game in space has this game gives you a very shallow puddle to play in. Also the puddle is full of dirty street water. And the puddle evaporates after 10 minutes.

The fun abrudtly halts when you've completed everything the game has to offer after only a couple hours of play. At that time you've constructed every building and have staff working every job to the happiness of your citizens. Your little humanoids run around your base with a dozen different statistics being tracked that you quickly discover are largely completely meaningless. You are attacked by the same copy paste RNG enemies over and over. It is quite frankly boring and extremely unrewarding.

Do not buy this game. The company Double Fine ran out of money developing this game and forced out an incomplete game.

AI is broken/unfinished, enemy NPC's are OP and impossible to kill. 


DF is a shady, incompetent company who abused the EA (early access), pissed away all the money they made due to horrible planning and development. 

Update: DF is now currently deleting any negative posts/reviews on their forums and perma banning people for giving uninformed customers fair warning about this game.

column8: Double Fine cancelled development of this title due to lack of sales in the Early Access phase. Although they claim to intend to remove the remaining bugs, some of which are game-breaking and require you to restart from the beginning (and still have not been addressed as of mid-December 2014), they will no longer be adding or balancing new or existing features. What's left is a collage of incomplete or broken concepts on an otherwise compelling gaming platform that will never see a proper implementation. Please save your money for more worthy titles.

column8:
I actually enjoyed this game, I got it free when buying Hacknslash so the price was right. 

I think most of the negativity from this game involves the lack of delivery on promises made by the developer. 

I started playing with 0 expectations and after a couple of failed bases built up a huge successful base and pretty much saw everything there was to see in one day. I got 10 hours out of it and while I didnt get all the achievements and there isn't a "win" condition I'm done with it. 

I CERTAINLY wouldn't pay $20 for this but <$5 is ok. If you like base building and character management games like gnomoria this can keep you entertained for a few hours.

Gnomoria is much better than this though, it has far more content and is still being added to.

column8:
Abandoned by its developers while riddled with bugs, Spacebase DF-9 isn't worthwhile in the least. Poor direction and very little finesse to the game's controls make it frustrating from the perspective of the player, and the constant bugs that can block progress and lack of any real story mode make it so that this game has no real playability at all, and anyone who would want to would quickly be dissuaded by the tutorial, which is SO poor that it can outright glitch and block your forward progress.

My rating? 0 inexplicably depressurized stations out of 10. Do not buy.

column9: Spacebase DF-9 is an Early Access game, but despite its considerable development period, it lacks a significant amount of content. Mining rocks and building a few rooms is the only thing you can do. While there are a few events, they're repetitive and tiresome. Ultimately, you can enjoy the game in just two or three hours, but even then, poor balance and frustrating features make for a frustrating experience.

column8:
Nice try ... but not finished.

Playing sims/strategy/rpg genre quite often my expectations of this game have been too high.

It has a nice setup how you interact with your crew, fulfill their demands, but dies under too many random factors. For example, the perfect bartender has as psych attribute "quiet" and "shy". It is not funny and will lead unexperienced player straight to a loss.
The "morale" system is very raw. People will get happy when you built many small rooms filled with monitor/plants. That means long hallways and big rooms are game breaking. You will lose every time cause of low morale. A drawback of many small rooms is the micromanagement in case of emergencies. 


I do love their humor ... A chicken alien beat up a human who was eating because he thought the chicken legs have been from his race/planet.


Conclusio ... 
Play Dwarf Fortress ....  It free but not that fancy and includes all the things Double Fine wanted to realize but didn't finish.

column8:
Moin Leute!

Als ich mir dieses Spiel kaufte (Gott sei Dank als Sale-Angebot) war ich total begeistert. Das Spiel ist so eine Art Sims im Weltraum. Man baut eine Station im Weltall, um dort Bewohnern ein schÃ¶nes Leben zu ermÃ¶glichen. SchlafrÃ¤ume, botanische GÃ¤rten (um Nahrung anzubauen), Krankenstationen, Forschungslabore, uvm. lassen das Herz eines jeden Konstrukteurs hÃ¶her schlagen. Dazu dann noch die Bewohner, die mit ihren verschieden Fertigkeiten und Vorlieben die Station bewohnen. NatÃ¼rlich ist nicht alles Friede, Freude, Eierkuchen. Nein, hin und wieder greifen Piraten an, es brechen Feuer aus oder aber Asteroiden schlagen ein. So weit, so gut.

Aaaaber dann...
... ist DoubleFine der Meinung, dass es sich nicht mehr lohnt, dieses Spiel weiter auszubauen und man macht einfach ein letztes Update - und schwupp ... fertig. WTF?!?

Das Spiel hat noch so (unendlich?) viel Potential, um wirklich was groÃŸes daraus zu basteln. Aber den Entwicklern ist anscheinend daran nicht gelegen ... leider, leider.

Das Spiel - so wie es ist - macht SpaÃŸ, aber alle, die es sich kaufen, sollten sich im Klaren sein, daÃŸ nichts mehr hinzu kommt.

Daher wÃ¼rde ich vorschlagen, die Finger davon zu lassen, wenn man auf mehr hofft. 
Genre Fans sollten im Sale zuschlagen. 
Den vollen Preis wÃ¼rde ich auf jeden Fall nicht zahlen... und wie ich in meinem ersten Satz bereits schrieb: Gott sei Dank im Sale gekauft...

Meine Wertung:
Grafik: 5/10
SpaÃŸ: 8/10
Wiederspielbarkeit: 8/10
Langzeitmotivation: 4/10
Updates: 0/10
column9:
Hey everyone!

When I bought this game (thank goodness it was on sale), I was absolutely thrilled. The game is a kind of Sims in space. You build a station in space to provide residents with a comfortable life. Sleeping quarters, botanical gardens (for growing food), infirmaries, research labs, and much more make any designer's heart beat faster. Then there are the residents who inhabit the station with their different skills and preferences. Of course, not everything is peace and harmony. No, every now and then pirates attack, fires break out, or asteroids strike. So far, so good.

But then...
...DoubleFine decides it's no longer worth expanding this game, so they simply release one last update â€“ and hey presto... it's done. WTF?!?

The game still has so (infinite?) much potential to create something truly great. But the developers apparently don't care about that... unfortunately, unfortunately.

The game - as it is - is fun, but anyone who buys it should be aware that there's nothing more to come.

So I'd suggest staying away if you're hoping for more.
Genre fans should grab it during the sale.
I definitely wouldn't pay full price... and as I wrote in my first sentence: Thank goodness I bought it during the sale...

My rating:
Graphics: 5/10
Fun: 8/10
Replayability: 8/10
Long-term motivation: 4/10
Updates: 0/10

column8: The developer treated this game like a 3 legged dog. It was fun and cute until they tried to play with it, Then it became clear that it's just a crap version of a better thing. So they packed it up and drove it to the forest and let it out "Go on boy, be free" they said. Spacebase just sat at the side of the road watching curiously as the door shut and the car drove away. It wasn't until it's early access collar rotted off that Spacebase realized they were never coming back. But yet it waits.

column8: The project was abandoned and partial scripting made accessible for players to finish the game themselves in a limited fashion. Make sure not to buy early access from these devs on future titles, since they abandoned this one to toss out another one. Its hard to believe the same company made Psychonauts, but that was a decade ago so it might be all new people working there or new ownership. This game looked like it would be pretty cool, so I bought it early on. They scraped together a few last minute patches when everyone was complaining, but they didn't implement any of the missing features.

column8: Was hoping the playerbase would be able to make the game more enjoyable with mods after the devs bailed and launched their pre-alpha as a full release.  I was wrong, it's still lacking in content and the AI is still suicidal.  Get used to watching your crew asphyxiate while hanging out right by the airlock, as this will occur quite frequently.  After trying multiple times to try and get into the game then not being able to get past 30 minutes of gameplay, I can say this game isn't even worth $1 on a steam sale.

column8:
Plays like a prototype for what might one day be a good game, but that game will now never come. Double Fine have called the game finished in order to avoid the appearance of outright fraud, but that doesn't mean it is -- you will see everything the game has to offer in a couple of hours, and then have nothing to look forward to but too-frequent raids (using what appears to be a placeholder combat system) and building the same rooms again and again.

The game is extremely bare, took far too long to get to the point where it is now, and will never go any farther. It should be considered a failure of the early access program. Similar projects like Rimworld and Prison Architect have already gone much further than this on a fraction of the budget.

column9:
I bought this game in Early Access; the premise seemed excellent: managing a space base.

Unfortunately, the developer, Double Fine, abandoned development, deeming it unprofitable.

Double Fine Productions has a habit of biting off more than it can chew, developing multiple games at once.

In its current form, the interface is still very poor; it seems to get in your way more than it helps.
The game has left Early Access; Double Fine Productions considers it finished and will not receive any further updates.

I don't recommend it unless they return to finish the game.

column9:
Rip Off.

Double Fine proves once again how well Early Access can be used for fraud. Launch the game, promote it, and after a year, declare the barely developed beta "finished" with the consolation prize "It's moddable, so you can continue our work."
There are much better Dwarf Fortress clones out there. Craft the World and Rimworld are two examples I'd like to mention. Definitely stay away from this one, but that applies to pretty much every title from Doublefine.

column8:
For formatting and pics go to: http://wildwoodgeek2.blogspot.com/2014/12/space-base-df-9.html


What Space Base DF-9 did right

 -Great visual Appeal

One of the things i love about SBDF-9 is the look and style, they just seem right. And it reminds me of the Sims 4 or Sim City(2013)



-Great idea for a game
lots of people have done building games, city games,etc, but Space Bases are few. The idea for this game is Perfect, now if only the game was...



What Space Base DF-9 did wrong


-Did not deliver
on the Double Fine Games website they had a roadmap (now long gone) of things they said they were going to try to add. It was a big one. And yes i know that even they said it wasn't "set in stone" but it was used to get people to buy the game, and now only about 20 to 40% of those features are in the game, and it kinda feels like they tricked us.

 -Left the Game unfinished
Double Fine Games the dev and publisher has left SBDF-9 to make another game and thereby make more money. They basically blame the community citing that "not enough people bought the game to fund it". Perhaps because the game is in an Alpha state at the most

 -retarded AI
I don't know about you but when i'm in a space base on the far reaches of the milky way, i get pretty damn pissed when i don't have Five Star meals, or Gyms, or bars, or TV. So mad i start trashing my own Oxygen tanks thereby killing myself. What? You wouldn't do that? Well the AI in this game does that. Yep, if they aren't living in luxury they decide life just ain't worth living.

 -Not Worth the price
If Double Fine Games was going to keep working on this, i would say this is worth the price, however they aren't so really there is no point in spending cash on it. Its not going to get better, its not going to get fixed, and its not a good game.

 -bugs and glitches that will never be fixed
Not being able to build, Oxygen not being produced despite the fact i have Oxygen tanks and more, these are bugs and glitches that will never be fixed.

 -Made us pay for their failure
This is more of a issue of Double Fine Games itself. They the whole reason they said the game is being shut down is because one: Not enough people bought it, and two: they ran out of Kickstarter money. If they did run out of kickstarter money then STOP working on another game and spend that money on the game you sold us.

 -This is not the first time Double Fine Game has let people down
Another game by DFG, Broken Age was also misleading. The game is sold as a full game but it is like TellTale games in that there are "Episodes". Right now, a year after the funding for the game ended there is only ONE  episode, with a "promise" that the second one will be coming on "sometime in early 2015"

 Who Space Base DF-9 is for
-People who like wasting money

 -People who don't care about playing an unfinished game

 -People who buy games on sale

 -Idiots


Final Thoughts
The idea behind this game is amazing, and if worked on properly it could be a masterpiece. But it won't and thats a shame. Normally i keep supporting even bad EA games because i figure "eh, they will fix it later" i mean at the point i've already given them money, the best thing to do is hold on to the hope (however pointless) that the game will get better. There is no hope with SBDF-9, not anymore. And yes, modders could make it better, and they could make it a great game, but my belief is that if modders have to fix your game, and i mean Make it playable, then you've already failed.

Il s'agit d'un jeu trÃ¨s joli graphiquement, mais qui manque cruellement de contenus et de dÃ©veloppement. Il manque une histoire au jeu, ou bien une campagne. La simplicitÃ© du systÃ¨me devrait permettre un mode multi-joueur qui est donc absent. 

Il y a extrÃªmement peu d'Ã©volution, et quasiment tout les batiments sont disponibles dÃ¨s le dÃ©but.

Cela est dÃ©jÃ  assez frustrant de jouer en English, mais en plus vous aurez le droit Ã  des mots et des termes trÃ¨s difficiles Ã  traduire.

A la version 1.06, le jeu est toujours plein de bug qui nÃ©cessite souvent de relancer le jeu.

L'Ã©quipage meurt sans arrÃªt, et les personnages se suicident 90% du temps. Le seul moyen d'arriver Ã  tenir c'est par le mÃ©ta-game. Vous Ãªtes obligÃ© de doublÃ©/triplÃ© vos murs, d'encercler votre base par des 10aines de tourelles. A la fin, le jeu ressmeble Ã  un jeu de survie dans un tower defense.

Le jeu ne vos pas son prix, et je plains les joueurs ayant dÃ©pensÃ© plus de 5â‚¬ en prÃ©-release.
column9:
This is a graphically beautiful game, but it's sorely lacking in content and development. It lacks a story, or even a campaign. The simplicity of the system should allow for a multiplayer mode, which is therefore absent.

There's extremely little evolution, and almost all buildings are available from the start.

It's already frustrating enough to play in English, but on top of that, you'll be exposed to words and terms that are very difficult to translate.

As of version 1.06, the game is still riddled with bugs that often require restarting the game.

The crew dies constantly, and characters commit suicide 90% of the time. The only way to survive is through the metagame. You're forced to double/triple your walls and surround your base with dozens of turrets. In the end, the game resembles a survival game within a tower defense.

The game doesn't sell its price, and I feel sorry for the players who spent more than â‚¬5 on pre-release.

column9:
A promising game that turns out to be very disappointing.

THIS GAME IS NOT FINISHED. [b]You'll have a meltdown playing it.[/b]

Reason #1:
[u]The enemy AI will make a fool of you[/u]: an enemy, in 10 seconds flat, will systematically kill everyone, regardless of whether you have guards, closed doors (they can teleport directly into your base), or any other means of progression. The inhabitants won't defend themselves, which is infuriating.

Reason #2:
Someone, every 5 minutes, will ask to join you, even if you don't have the capacity, and often right from the start when your base isn't habitable!

Reason #3:
It doesn't matter whether you accept a new person on board or not, sometimes they automatically accept, without you being able to say anything or stop them.

Other reason:
A multitude of details showing that the game isn't finished. Example: assigning someone to move to the healing bed doesn't work.

In summary: don't buy it, even if it looks good, even if the first 10 minutes are playable; it's just not finished, and 100% of your games are doomed to failure.

column8:
This game, for the asked price, is a complete and utter waste of money. If you want a space simulator, there are lots of others out there ... just do NOT get this one. The updates have ceased and it is not further developed. The AI has a lot of major hiccups, as in your people asphyxiating inside the base with 98% of oxygen in their room while wearing a space suit.

The only events are either pirates, people who join your base even if you want them to stay away and random appearing rooms which can fuck up your building progress.

I only can repeat, if you want a spacebase simulator - not this one.

column8:
its like Rimworld, only terrible.

No form of balence at all, completley random and never lets you have any level of success,not because its hard, but because its buggy.

Hulks appear, but they are death traps, ships dock and ruin the asthetic of your base.

I REALLY WANTED TO LOVE THIS GAME, and gave it a really extensive play, built a functional base and achieved most of the goals, BUT never felt like I was "doing well" 

I'm sure the game is a bit less impossible when you have the research complete, but I've never managed to do more than 3 research projects before my base gets wiped out.

no form of "micro" exists in this game, in fact its totally one dimentional with no real management elements at all.

honestly, save the money and get RimWorld instead. (just as alpha, not classed as "released" virtually no bugs and already has more content than this glorified tech demo)

I'll never buy another DF game again.

I actually can't get over the audacity it took to class this as "finished"

column8:
This game is fun for about 6 hours, then it peaks and I get bored of repetition. I do however think that despite minor functional issues like character pathfinding and a lack of replayability, it is fun if you are really a sci-fi fan. I will recommend this game in hopes that it still has a future of modability if Doublefine has truly stopped adding to the game.

Let the community make it their own!

7/10
Would play again once every 6 months or so...

column8: I bought this game a while ago, and since stopped playing all together. It's unfinished, plain and simple. The game still has AI problems, random event problems, and pretty much a lack of progression, all carried over from it's "Early Access" days (one can argue those days aren't up, even after release). Yeah you can build up a thriving sta... oh wait, no you cant, the game becomes almost unplayable by that point. Oh but you can start the gam... oh wait can't do that either due to your crew not wanting to enter the airlock and subsequently suffocating. Oh and did I mention your populations astounding ability to *Constantly* open airlocks without sealing the station leading to many residents deaths? Yeah that happens too. They also don't like to use fire extinguisers, follow orders, eat, fight, sleep, work, breath, live... yeah they just plain don't work. You ever seen Serenity? The entire planet of people that just laid down and died? Yeah that's what these morons essentially do. DONT BUY THIS GAME!

column9:
The game's premise is very good, and some aspects of it are interesting.
However, the game has many frustrating gameplay flaws.
You have no control over the inhabitants of your space station, and you can easily lose them in single file against a single enemy or fire inside the station.

column8: The stupidity of the NPC AI will enrage you. The game is undeserving of the name 'simulation', as the event controller is designed to be malicious if you get too successful. Don't expect any major updates as the developers have mostly given up on this buggy mess. There are many games that do these genres better, don't settle on this on.

column8:
Playing this game will only frustrate you. This is a management game that is set up in a way that should minimize micro-management of your denizens and let you concentrate on the bigger picture. The citizens of your base are expected to be able to make decisions on their own using their AI. Unfortunately, their AI is nowhere near complete enough to make this feasible. Quite often your entire base will spiral out of control because of events that are set in motion by something a citizen did or did not do because of poor AI. I have had bases fail from one fire because each citizen died one-by-one attempting to stomp the fire out with their feet instead of using a fire extenguisher hung up a few tiles away.

After spending time in the early acess program at alpha-stage and getting rather infrequent updates, this game was suddnely rushed to "completion" and swept out the door. Don't let that fool you, this game was rushed to 1.0 just so that Double-Fine could avoid the game being called "abandoned" based on a techicality.

The game is very much unfinished, and it sorely shows even a couple of hours into gameplay. It's very unfortunate because this game showed a lot of promise and would have done very well if it had just been properly managed.

Double-Fine really soured their brand name with the stunts they pulled here, and I won't buy another one of their products.

column9:
[Do not buy] If you're looking for a fun, comprehensive game, move on; Spacebase DF-9 won't meet your expectations. Double Fine rushed the game out because its early access was starting to run out of steam. The result: a jump from 0.6 to 1.0, very limited content, and mechanics that could be tweaked by the developers if the game weren't left to rot.

Thank you, Double Fine, for this piece of gaming crap.

column8:
You know. A long time ago, a good friend told me about an awesome game, and he shared with me a link to it, and we both agreed that it looked like one of the best Early Access games we had ever seen. And, for the first 5 Major updates, it was.

Then after an age in between each update we grew a little less hopeful about the games future as there was always a few really annoying bugs in it, though we could handle them as they were not always present in our playing, then around update 6 we got some really sad news, this fine game was almost done with development, and that was shocking news.

Lets face it, who doesn't want to buy a game solely on the promise of a fantastic game, then to only have it thrown in your face and given the source code to mod in what they'd promised, I wouldn't really be so pissed about yet another Dev lying to the customers about a game, but the real troubling thing is, that even though they claim to have fixed some of the bugs, there are a mess of other ones that just ruin the enjoyment for me, like the fact that for no other reason that drama, 10+ people will just asphyxiate for no reason at all. That then drags morale down and people don't work as hard, [b]THEN[/b], when the end game comes (not that we really wanted or needed 500 Raiders to fight maybe 50 people IF we get lucky.) we're [b]ROYALLY[/b] screwed, as there are 5-10 people left on our base to fight an onslaught of raiders before we can get Dark-Matter reactors [b]AND OR[/b] Nova Class Turrets (only learnt of those puppies recently) Not that they help much in the scheme of trying to get them researched when everyone is off dying for no reason.

The [b]OTHER[/b] big problem I have, is when I just start a new base because my last one ended as stated I above, is when I only have about 5 people tops, a small base that's barely functioning, [b][u]AND BAM[/u][/b] someones managed to encounter a Face Hugger and now there is a God Damned Parasite on my base killing everyone because they're so damned tired since I couldn't get them any beds yet because I'm only 5 minutes into the base and everyone is busy being Scrubs.

In conclusion: This game was fun once upon a time but now even if offered a refund it would not be worth it since time invested in a failed project.

out of 10 you're owed at least 30 Points, Why 30? because if you were owed 72 Points that would be sus with my Name.

Rating: -30/10

-----Vinditator1972

Full of bugs. Sometimes it is randomly impossible to build a room. Sometimes you'll build an airlock and life support, and they'll pretend it all doesn't exist and all your starting population suffocates in their suits.
Full of imbalance. Start in a "ridiculously low" threat area and before you even have a chance to research better weapons, let alone even build a research area or assign population to it, a ship full of super-powered raiders will kill everyone.

Full of bugs. Sometimes it is randomly impossible to build a room. Sometimes you'll build an airlock and life support, and they'll pretend it all doesn't exist and all your starting population suffocates in their suits.
Full of imbalance. Start in a "ridiculously low" threat area and before you even have a chance to research better weapons, let alone even build a research area or assign population to it, a ship full of super-powered raiders will kill everyone.

it's a fun space base sumulator (hardly gets more niche then that), eventually everything falls apart, things get interresting, and you try to do things diferently.

I got 18 ours of fun out of a 20$ indie title so I say it was well worth the purchase.

column8: Ich habe Spacebase DF-9 schon im Early-Access Ã¼ber 46 Stunden gespielt und fand das Spiel auch im frÃ¼hen Stadium schon sehr unterhaltsam. Mit jedem Update wurde es natÃ¼rlich besser und man kann nun enttÃ¤uscht sein, dass die Entwicklung nicht weiter betrieben wurde und offenbar vorhandene Ideen nicht mehr umgesetzt werden. Das Spiel als unfertig zu bezeichnen finde ich aber unfair. Die Spielmechanik funktioniert. Die Ereignisse sind bisweilen etwas arg zufÃ¤llig, da kann eine nett gebastelte Basis ohne gute Verteidigung schon mal von drei bis vier Raiderschiffen zerstÃ¶rt werden. Wer Aufbausimulationen mag, findet hier sicherlich mehr als eine Stunde SpaÃŸ. Man muss sich eigene Ziele setzen und das Spiel hat kein definiertes Ende, aber das scheint mir so auch konzipiert zu sein. Sicherlich kein Musterbeispiel fÃ¼r Early-Acess aber entgegen der irrefÃ¼hrenden Reviews auch kein schlechtes Spiel.
column9: I played Spacebase DF-9 for over 46 hours in Early Access and found the game very entertaining even in its early stages. It naturally got better with each update, and one might be disappointed that development was halted and that existing ideas were apparently no longer implemented. However, I think it's unfair to call the game unfinished. The game mechanics work. Events are occasionally somewhat random; a nicely constructed base without good defenses can easily be destroyed by three or four raider ships. Anyone who likes building simulations will certainly find more than an hour of fun here. You have to set your own goals, and the game doesn't have a defined ending, but that seems to be how it was designed. Certainly not a prime example of Early Access, but contrary to the misleading reviews, it's not a bad game either.

column8: the primary issue I see with this game is AI.  Builders don't like building out of order, so building interior doors to your starter station before you build the airlocks means they'll voluntarily asphyxiate themselves.  Occasionally your crew & incoming residents will think derelicts are YOUR main ship, causing them to wander off into said derelict (not a problem if it's empty, but I lost a game because I went from 14 crew to 2 because they all charged into a kill bot one at a time).  Sometimes they'll leave airlocks open.  Sometimes security will charge at raiders and stand with fists raised until they're half dead before firing back (and yes, I had "use lethal force" on).  And these are all issues encountered with less than 2 hours of play logged.  Overall I think this game has great potential, but with how awful the AI is at this point it's extremely frustrating and borderline unplayable.  I will keep an eye on this one and I'd be willing to changemy review if these issues get fixed, but as of now I can't recommend it.

column8:
When you pay into an early access game you expect it to be finished to the standards advertised. Especially one by a renowned publisher like Double Fine, and for Â£15. 

What looked to me, and to everyone else, as an excellent idea and promising project turned out to be a ridiculous waste of money due to unfinished development and poor excuses. 

If you wish to rely on mods to make the game interesting and playable, buy it. If you want a complete game from the start, don't.

column8:
Owned it since very early on. It looked interesting and I love space games as well as "theme hospital" type sims so I gave them $50 on Kickstarter. Went to play it but it is literally unplayable. Not just unenjoyable, actually unplayable. But hey, it's early access, I'll open it up in a month.

A month later, almost nothing has changed. Development is slow but yeah, it's early access, I knew what I was getting into. Did this for a few months and again, very little has changed. It eventually becomes playable but very incomplete so extremely unenjoyable.

Left it for 6+ months and recently heard they made it version 1.0. Opened it up again, it's playable but still extremely incomplete, there is very little to do. I ate my $50 and wrote it off as a bad decision and feel that you can't trust DoubleFine. 

I then heard that they ran a sale in September a few days before slapping the 1.0 on it. Brought in a horde of new young hopefuls like myself who believed in the studio and what the game could be. A week later they slapped the 1.0 on it and called it finished in its incomplete state.

In short, don't buy it, it's incomplete. And seriously consider whether you want to support the studio when buying any of their other titles.

column9:
The developers say it was released without the features they promised,
and it's true, there's really nothing to do.
The decorations are minimal, the combat is lacking, and no matter how meticulously the residents' hobbies are described,
when you actually open the game, all you have to worry about is feeding them and managing their oxygen. That's the strong feeling.
It feels like the early days of Arma 3 Early Access?
And yet, this is the official release... Nomoria is much better than this.

column8:
I have to say from day ONE I had very high hopes and expectations for this game.  I looked forward to updates and a continual developing of the dynamics of the game play.

Then one day comes the message that I didn't expect from Double Fine, "We're done, but here is a tiny door to mods."

I enjoyed and still do enjoy the game play, but this and a couple other Early Access games burned me. Left me unwilling to contribute to an uncertain future.

From here on out I will not suggest Early Access to anyone and will not be envolved with any other future products till they are finalized.

column8:
Very promising idea, however, the game is unfinished. It has so many glitches, that it is bound to break after some time of gameplay.

To be honest: I'm sick an tired of constantly being the alpha- or beta-tester!

The game lacks the very basics. You can only save your game by quitting. If you accidentally click on "how to play" or "New Base" you lose everything regardless if you have saved previously or not. You are not even asked "are you sure?" or be warned the your current game will be lost.

In terms of gameplay:
It is quiet unbalanced. Constant attacks don't give you much time to breath if you have not found the right area in the galaxy for building your base.

Sometimes ships dock at your station and there is nothing you can do about it. If these ships happen to have exterior turrets you might as well start from scratch. Because these turret will tear your crew apart and you won't have a chance to disable or even destroy them.

Again. Haven't the developers even played the game? Other players keep having the same problem. There seems to be no answer accoring to the double fine board.

You have to start over several times in the beginning until you have figured out what to do. There is a tutorial, but everything it does is presenting you a half finished base. There is nothing that explains the building items, what to take care of or the basics of managing the station.

Sometimes some of your citizens just stop doing their duties and telling you they are bored. You send security to a place where pirates tried to break into your ship and they just keep patroling the base. On occation citizens refuse to enter a room and do maintainance... which results in suffocation of all citizens on your station.

So, what do you do against those pirates raiding your base? You build some turrets of your own. Then one of your scientists goes mad, usually you would stop him and throw him into the brig until he stops acting up... but the turret has a better idea: it shoots him.

Conclusion:
Under no circumstance is this game in a "release"-state! Beta at most. I feel violated as an alpha-tester again by a company which obviously did not even bother to try and play their own f***ing game! It reminds me a lot of the initial problems of X-Rebirth. But this company does not even show effort in fixing these issues.

column8:
Its a mix between FTL, Banished,  and Prison Architect, but not. Each play through is different and each galaxy is different. With no real difficulty level, its really good endless fun and chance. If you like space, building, and running things, this game will fit your profolio.

I have read other reviews about the game not being complete, the devs dropping everything and running, plus the studio giving this a death sentence. In reality, what game studio doesn't? The game has potential and can be fixed, but its open for modding. I think they set out to make a Minecraft type of game and hope the community would run off with it, which it hasn't so far. Take it for what it is, wait for it to go on sale, to a price your happy with, and enjoy its quirks and misgivings. 

Oh, if you find a great MOD, please let me know.

column8:
This is the framework of a fun game. It's a shame DF decided to murder it suddenly and without warning. Other reviewers are right when they say the game lacks features and has atrociously buggy AI. I would highly recommend skipping this one and maybe try Gnomoria if Dwarf Fortress has too much of a learning curve for you to get into.

Update 10/13/15:

Some modders have set up shop amongs the ruins of this once proud beast. I'll be keeping an eye out for future updates from these guys. While still would not recommend this game in its current state, I can see that these modders are a pretty dedicated bunch. I believe there is still hope and I may have to give this game a proper review in the future.

column8: This game will never be worth $20. While it is fun, it's clearly an incomplete game released in an early alpha state. Little to no depth exists because the feature list is so scant that the only real game is in building a relatively small base. After that, if you expand you're likely to do so at your own detriment not because the game is built that way but because it lacks systems necessary for an endgame. I realize this review is somewhat obtuse, but it's a bit difficult to express just how incomplete this game is. It feels like a demo.

Little to no depth exists because the feature list is so scant that the only real game is in building a relatively small base. After that, if you expand you're likely to do so at your own detriment not because the game is built that way but because it lacks systems necessary for an endgame. I realize this review is somewhat obtuse, but it's a bit difficult to express just how incomplete this game is. It feels like a demo.
