column8:
This game could be fun, but it isn't.
Now if this game were still in development there would still be some hope, but this was abandoned by the Developer and just got the 1.0 sticker slapped on it to be done with it.

I'm not often disappointed with EA and this is actually the first one (for me) that was abandoned. Yes, there are plenty out there where development has slowed to a crawl (Looking at you Starbound) which is disappointing as well.
So just stay away from this, there is really no hope it will get better then it currently is and that's missing a lot of features, buggy AI, clunky UI and lots of broken things.

Just shows that even a big indy developer is not something to give greater chances of EA following through to a featurecomplete game.

As for DF, I'll avoid them like the plaque.

Adding insult to injury with DF-9 getting huge discounts and being in bundles everywhere. "Let's milk even the last penny out of this wreck of a game"

column8:
I poured money into this expecting it to be an ongoing project. It started out interesting for an alpha but then we realised that this was as good as it was going to get.

The developer either mismanaged the money so severely to the point where it should honestly be questioned whether Doublefine has any business in early access or they simply took the money and ran. Not bothering to finish this game as other projects needed more attention.

Either way we are left with a sorry excuse for a game. Horrendously shallow gameplay with barely any of the initially promised features. It is a barren boring game that you will grow weary of in less than half an hour of starting it up.

Do not buy unless it goes for less than a dollar.

column8:
I do not recommend buying this game for the price listed on Steam.
It is in no way worth more than five dollars. I got the shweet Humble Bundle deal, and this game was at the top of the list. Looking back, the other five (unknown and unrated) games show better quality than Double-Fine wishes to attempt. The amount of bugs, flaws, and outright dumb features leave the player wondering if they're actually playing a game, or watching a bad episode of Star Trek: Deep Space-Nine.
If it's on another humble-bundle sale, think about asking someone with a lot of money to buy if for you.
But not for $20.

column8:
I once had a base bustling with 30 highly skilled workers working together in flawless harmony. Then raiders came and killed EVERYONE and destroyed all the oxygen generators, which then led to their death, leaving my base as a graveyard for me to revisit any time. Occasionally being visited by more raiders to add to the body count of suffocated assholes.

The game itself is actually pretty fun, one thing that was never fixed was the AI. The AI will build a base then float around until they die instead of entering the airlock, they take forever to do their jobs or just won't do it entirely. The game also lacks content in general, the bases get bigger but still get filled with the same shit, lots of repetitious dialogue amoung other things. Having a pub doesn't seem to actually do anything, they eat chicken instead of paste and that's really it. My crew was also very depressed and just liked to beat the shit out of each other all of the time, I tried to make it better but no matter how many shelves I put up they just wouldn't be happy. 

The gameplay is fun but it needs work, work that isn't being put into the game anymore.

column8:
Update: All the negative reviews I read for this game were before the November 14 1.06 update, which fixed a lot of the bugs that these reviewers were discussing. I played the game for the first time after this update had already occurred.

Raiders, space debris, nosy passenger ships, quiet derelict vessels, deadly diseases, and parasites that jump out of an empty husk which used to be one of your citizens. That's what you face when you become the Administrator of Spacebase DF-9. You will truly feel like the manager of a tiny oasis, alone in the vastness of a harsh galaxy.

To get a summary of what it's like to play this game, combine the play styles of a small-scope RTS like Age of Mythology with The Sims. Not only do you have to build, maintain, and defend a space station, but you must also make sure you're tending to the needs of your citizens.

Frustrations abound. Just when you have finally constructed a small, functional base, complete with power and air, your citizens will have the gall to ask for a place to sleep. Then, they'll want something to eat. Then they'll need a doctor. Then they'll want someplace to hang out with friends. Then your base needs a maintenance technician, but no one wants the job. Now they want a gym, but you're still trying to build the infirmary because two citizens died in the last Raider attack. But now there aren't enough power reactors! So you've zoned the construction to build a bigger power room, but then some Raider blew holes in your airlock in a firefight and now the whole thing is useless. But hey, at least he suffocated. Pompous jerk. Anyway, you've got to refit another room as an emergency airlock, to fix the airlock, so you can build the next reactor, to build the infirmary, and then ultimately build a gym, but darn it all, your Builder's feeling overworked so they went to bed! And NO, I do NOT want to answer your request to come aboard, random passenger ship!

In many ways, I find this game to be a very realistic depiction of what it would probably be like to lead your own vessel out in space. You have to fight constantly against the threatening, invasive, hostile environment, while not letting your crew's own loneliness overcome them. Think about it. Suppose you were one of your citizens: one of a group of ten people stranded out in, truly, the middle of nowhere, with no chance of ever seeing Earth again. No wonder my overworked builder is having trouble staying motivated, and no wonder most of my crew spends their free time in the pub. We all might want to think that living in space would be cool, but Spacebase DF-9 reminds us of the human element.

Yes, there are still minor graphical bugs, and sometimes your Miner will asphyxiate because they were too stupid to get back inside before their eight minutes of oxygen was up. However, no technical glitch any worse than this has happened to me in the time I've been playing; most of the frustrations are caused by realistic depiction of the situation. But like in Kerbal Space Program or any other pleasantly challenging game, when you overcome the trials of the moment, you will feel an immense sense of reward watching your citizens live the lives you have given them among the stars.

column8:
Wow. Do not buy this game.  I've wanted it for a long time but never bought it due to the god awful reviews. 
It starts out stupid, the first time you try to build a station from scratch.  If you don't know what you are doing you will run out of money befor having all of the life support stuff ready.  So after you create your 5th station and have mastered the exact money(matter) management you need to get a reactor, air cleaners and a matter recycler thing, youre finally good. Then one of your dudes , about 10 minutes in, gets infected by a space parasite.  You only have 3 guys.  No infirmary yet.  He turns into a giant bug and kills your entire crew.  That's really crappy.  Now, you build a new station again and no infection happens.  Good so far.  Everything is great except about 4 hours in and you love your station very much, boom raiders.  3 raiders killed all 22 of my crew, including my two 4-star security guards.  I'll never play this again.  I want this exack game minus the hazards.  I just want to build and manage, not fight parasites.  Also the order the builders build is ridiculous.  There doesn't seem to be a way to actually research things. Screw this game.

column8:
While I do agree with the negative reviews in that the execution of the ideas that could have resulted (and still can result) in a gem of a game is mediocre at best, I still cautiously recommend it.

Below, I list the bad and the good aspects of the game based on my very short experience playing it (one hour is normally enough for me to make my decision, but I leave it up to you to decide whether it is enough to trust my review).

The bad:
- The AI of your colonists is not the best, but is getting better.
- The game becomes repetitive really soon (for me, it has after the first hour playing it)--there is just no hierarchy, almost no gradual development (save the research), and frankly not much to do as of now.
- There is no balance. I am pretty sure the developers got their inspiration in the Dwarf Fortress (where "dying in fun" TM), but I am able to play a game of Dwarf Fortress for days, but here my colonists die horribly within 15-20 minutes (raiders, fire or what not).

The good:

- The graphics are pretty good. I liked them a lot.
- The atmosphere of the game is its best selling point, IMO. Save the frustration of loosing each game I play pretty quickly, I like how the game feels. The colonists have their own characters, interact with each other and the environment, make friends and enemies--and all of this creates a feeling of a growing community in space, which is unfortunately quickly sent to oblivion, heh (see the balance).
- Enabling the support of mods is the best of the developers' decisions, which I think has the potential to save this game. There are mods already that address the balancing issues, and I am sure there will be mods fixing the AI, adding more things to do, and generally, adding depth to the game.

Despite all the drawbacks of the game, I still recommend it for one particular reason: it (still) has an enormous potential to grow into a fantastic game.

I understand the reasons for the negative reviews, but I also know that these reviews can eventually bring the development of the game to a halt. And this would be the most unfortunate turn of events, as the game, as I said, has the potential to become a fantastic game that offers its players countless hours of fun (and not frustration as it is now =) playing experience.

As for now, the price of the game is somewhat high for what it offers, so I suggest you buy this game on sale, and try it (with mods). I also hope more mods will be made for the game to enhance/improve it.

This game grind's to a halt on a 2014 model mid-range notebook which runs CIV 5 with no problems. Havent seen a not quite 3D-Shooter game behaving that resource hungry yet, especially with no way to dial down the effects in the in game menu.

Stay away.

column8: There's likely a playable game in here.  But it needs carved out of the horrible mess of painful murdering it's been left as to date.  Played three games.  By the time I got three rooms built in each, everyone was murderer (to death) by hostiles.   I'm sure you can stick with it and find some fun in it, but I'll save my time for games that don't seem to actively hate the player.

column8:
A great concept completely bungled by developer great on ideas but pretty shoddy on execution.  Never given the support it deserved, slow development and/or bad project management helped to sink this game before it could even be called a "beta".

There is no real game here.  You are presented with a sandbox with no real point or direction except perhaps a rudimentary progress tree tacked on in the end.   Perhaps this is a simulation or perhaps it's a survival game?  The developers never really decided what it was.  

It is a frustrating, stinking mess.  The AI governing the citizens of your spacebase is horrible.  Don't be surprised that in the first 10 minutes of your game all of your budding colonists have died because they can't seem to remove their spacesuits and asphyxiate themselves.  Or, in the very first hour of play, before your base is more than three rooms (one being the airlock) your base is smashed by a meteor shower.

No story.  No middle game.  No endgame. 

Modders may improve Spacebase, but it's unfinished nature means the game will never have a clear focus or direction.  Don't waste your money.

column8:
TLDR: Basically the entire universe either wants to join you or kill you, and you're just trying to finish building your base...

Long version: I bought this as early access, and even though it technically has been released, it still needs a lot of polish. For example, choosing an area to start is simply moving a mouse pointer around a picture until you find a suitable area. When you do find a suitable area, the stats (magnetic interference, proximity to a warpgate and threat level) don't seem to mean anything. I've started in areas with low threat, yet had 8 crewmembers killed in the first 10 minutes. I've started in areas distant from a warpgate with low magnetic interference, however i still get spammed with crewmembers wanting to join my base.

column8:
AWOID THIS GAME.

Game needs serious rework before it will be playable. Which it probably will never get.
Devs decided to leave development and game is maybe interesting concept but realisation just sucks.
AI of aliens in base gliches. Sometimes they stop doing things they are supposed to. Or they forget to come back to base to replenish oxygen supplay and die even if they were idle, without any task to do.
Commanded to tear down relict ship they go inside, take of spacesuits and then they destroy walls just to die of lack of oxygen. 
Even upgraded via laboratory security if not very effective vs hostiles. They also sometiems simply do nothing while getting killed. 
Rooms can loose oxygen without reason. Only solution then is to demolish it and build again.

column8:
Could have been a great game, but was abandoned by the developers. This is not hyperbole or butthurt exaggeration, the developers saw their sales for the game slow down and just threw their hands up, declaring the game completed. Do not buy it. This is one of the games that caused me to abandon purchasing any more Early Access games on Steam (thank you Doublefine -- I hope you're satisfied with the reputation you're purchasing for yourselves. The free "I'm sorry" shovelware game you gave us early access supporters sucks too, by the way). Do not buy this game.

Awesome graphics and sound are ruined by the crippled AI -- your citizens will literally charge past a fire extinguisher hanging on a wall to stomp on a huge room-sized fire to promptly catch on fire and burn to death. Technicians will do pushups in front of a failing oxygen scrubber, then their air will run out and they'll panic and die. Everyone on your station is mind numbingly stupid, but there's no way to directly control them -- you'll just watch them helplessly as their lack of regard for their own safety causes them to die in a variety of ridiculously preventable ways. 
At first it's funny, for a short time. Then it's annoying. Then it's frustrating. Then it becomes infuriating.

Do not buy this game. 

I'm somewhat convinced that it is not actually a game, but an elaborate psychological experiment to determine frustration thresholds. Do not buy it.

column8:
Oh my.



This could have been an awesome game, but they gave up on it, left it half finished, and had to call it done. DF-9 isn't a bad game, the part of it that is finished is pretty awesome and fun to play, until you run into balencing issues that hault the game. I don't know how common of a problem that is, but it seems that all the games I play end up with a negative feed back loop where if enough of the citizens become unhappy, everything on the station starts to not go well, resulting in more unhappyness. what's worse, is no explanation of why. The Wiki for the game is incomplete at best, so there is very little insight into how the game is supposed to be played.


I recommend this game because I owned a copy of space colony, and it was awesome. As it stands, Space Colony is currently better and less frustrating although more than a few generations of gaming old. Spacebase DF-9 is still being worked on, and will hopefully keep improving. All the issues I currently have with the game could be fixed in future patching, and BETTER be fixed or this game will be a hightly polished turd that could have been made of gold.



TLDR: Game needs balencing to be worth buying. Try Space Colony if you want this kind of game.

column8:
Fun, though it doesn't feel finished. If you really like management games, this will probably feel pretty empty to you. Though if you don't regularly play management games, or want something somewhat simpler, this is for you. You may also enjoy this if you like making up stories for your characters, as there is a sort of social network generated for each character that you can kinda use to judge their emotional state.

It has several interesting mechanics, such as raiders which will stop by on their own ship, or derelict ships that will occasionally spawn. These become structures which can be salvaged or incorporated into your own ship, which can be pretty cool. The whole oxygen management thing in general is definitely my favorite part of this game. If you lose a wall of a room to a raider drill, meteors, or anything like that, your guys will be sucked out of that room, and oxygen levels will plumet. Its always fun having to quickly suit up some builders to patch a hole before everyone dies of asphyxiation.

However, once you get going, the game becomes dull. You can expand your base a bit more, make your people happier, defend against the occasional meteor strike or raid, and accomodate new visitors. But there aren't any complex industries to deal with once you get the basics down. I haven't touched modding yet, so hopefully something there will interest me. I'd really like to see this game grow into something bigger, but for now its just enough to keep some people alive. It would be awesome if we could eventually grow our little space station into a massive trade destination, or some kind of space gas station.

Overall, i'd suggest waiting for a sale. There are much more complete games you can be getting for 20$ (And if you want  an AMAZING management game, i'd suggest looking into getting a degree in Dwarf Fortress).


P.S. Anyone else find it hilarious all the positive reviews are from early access?

column8:
Complete garbage. Units get stuck on invisible walls; ships forcefully dock and destroy your build and not in a fun space raider style but an annoying, what the fuck.. kind of way; Your ship travels for 40000+ years carrying a party of 3 but for some reason can only keep them alive for 8 minutes upon arriving, when modern space suits last 1 hour? Not to mention the game is horribly boring after about 40 mins.

From beta: This company is greedy and dishonest, they will start multiple early access games and not completely finish any of them and blame it on "lack of funds" while updating the games once every 2 months. Your lack of funds comes from paying people to not do work! I will never support Double fine ever again.

column8:
A side-project by the venerable Double Fine, Spacebase DF-9 had ambitions of being â€œDwarf Fortress but in SPACE!â€. Itâ€™s in space, that part they finished pretty early on. The entire everything else part, the parts that involve managing a large, complex and interrelated system of many smaller systems all working together and against each other, that part they didnâ€™t quite finish. Much of what was promised for Spacebase DF-9 was dropped just before release (the game had been in Early Access for about a year now). The game was given a half-decent tutorial, opened up so users could modify and â€œfinishâ€ the game themselves, and a few meta-goals were added to give the experience a bit of structure.

So what youâ€™re left with is something that so painfully looks like the start of something great but then never actually goes there.  You can build your base, take on space immigrants, juggle their needs and desires, fend off raiders and explore derelicts that may appear. But it all feels pointless, unless you chase the arbitrary goals the team shoved in at the last minute, like â€œhave a base with X amount of denizensâ€. Itâ€™s a pity the game didnâ€™t get more support in Early Access, as a lack of interest from consumers is why Double Fine claims to have dropped the project.

column8:
So I guess this is what happened:

- Tim Schafer goes to a handful of investors with a prototype for a game. A game that has potential, a game that has that Double Fine sense of humor we all love, and a game that will fill a void in the market that has been left open for far too long.
- The investors love it and give Tim Schafer $400,000 to make this game.
- Tim Schafer gets addicted to cocaine and hookers and completely blows (heh) all of his investors' money, but just about this time Steam early access was hitting its stride and crafty Schafer cooks up a scheme.
- Tim Schafer puts a very early, borderline-developmental build of DF9 up on steam for $25 with a link to a web page promising tons and tons of features - all with a very nebulous timetable attached.
- A few months later (and a few inconsequential updates later) Tim Schafer finally cons enough money from hard-working people to pay back his investors (and get himself into rehab). Unfortunately, Double Fine is now broke.
- Tim Schafer announces the latest development build as the final release, takes down the webpage with the planned content, and releases the source code in a futile attempt to placate his former fans.
- Tim Schafer goes off to further bankrupt Double Fine.

tl;dr, [b]DO NOT BUY[/b].  This game is fundamentally broken and lacking in content.


I realize game development can be expensive, but I think it's pretty obvious from this and the Broken Age debacles that Tim Schafer isn't particularly good with money. Maybe Double Fine's next project should be an Excel spreadsheet so he can keep track of expenses.

Also, I really don't see how releasing the source code, or modding API, or whatever will possibly save this turd.  Modders are not going to want to spend time making a bad game adequate.  I think a complete rewrite of the AI should be the first thing to be done, but by the time they familiarize themselves with the code and rework the game, it'll be months from now. Months of work, just to maybe make the game playable and - best case senario - make Tim Schafer a few more bucks from sales.

Tim Schafer
Tim Shillfer
Tim Pilfer
Tim Tookallyourmoneyfer

column8: I was so excited when I first heard about this game that I bought it immediately. What little there was to the alpha was fun and showed potential, I was just left wanting more as it didn't have much depth; still I was hopeful since it was only Early Access.  Shame that the "finished" product doesn't have a lot more to it than the alpha version I played.  For what there is, it's fun in a temporary diversion sort of way, but on the whole I don't think it's worth it.   I think the fact that the only curator currently recommending the game is Double Fine itself says everything you need to know.

column9: Great idea, has made a halfway decent start to its implementation. Unfortunately, however, this is a very poor example of how a game can be purchased before release. The team was unable to finish this game and has officially abandoned it. This is the first game I have paid money for and have only received a beta, if that. I begrudge the developers making money from this. If it can be purchased for under a euro, however, it is still worth giving it a try. The concept is fun and it is definitely playable. Perhaps there will even be a sequel at some point. Hope dies last.

column8:
A real shame.

This game had some real potential. I love playing it but without finishing the game properly you run into the same issue with every play.

You build, you research, and you run out of things to do. By the time you have researched all functional upgrades your space base is sprawling and you spend your time reassigning all staff to security detail when the multiple raider attacks start happening and then reassigning them back to their positions after the attack.

Eventually you cannot look in all places at all times and "questionable" things begin occurring when your not looking in an  aggravating attempt to "fake" difficulty ala' MarioKart.

The game itself is really not much more completed than what I played when I first purchased the Early Access version.
The AI is shoddy, the dialogue feels very much like placeholder dialogue, and there are items to construct that seem to have no real bearing on game play (can anybody tell me what exactly reactors do or why my turrets don't shoot raider ships out of the sky before they board?).

Feels bad to give this game a negative review, but it's earned it.

column8:
Unless you start your base within 15 seconds, your astronauts die a terribnle death in the vaccum of space. The idea of instruction seems to be so far away as you and your 3 man crew who have somehow managed to warp to the other side of the flippin' galaxy on 10 minutes of oxygen have to try and build a base out of nothing with a very shoddy tutorial. Not to mention, the mechanics are pretty bad. No matter what I do, my citizens of "Probetopia" are never happy, and end up beating each other to a living pulp with nothing more than a broken chair leg. 

It is fun when the train begins to move and your citizens actually function like people. But once one thing goes wrong, controlling everything becomes almost like trying to get a 5 year old with a hand gun to not pretend he's the Sheriff of the town and not to shoot "the bad guys" (who happen to be his siblings). But like the review I'm writing, it gets old very very quickly. 

TL;DR = 2/10 would not recommend.

column8:
Incomplete. Potential never realized. Even the developer abandoned it for no particular reason other than, it seems, the game proved too complex for them.

For a good space builder I was willing to look past terrible animation and shoddy models. I was willing to wait eons for patches through early access. 
Unfortunately nothing was ever, or will ever be, done about any of its problems.
Do not waste your money as I did.

column8:
The game does and did feel incomplete, I enjoyed it/got my moneys worth . There were some realy annoying bugs, but the game hit the mark for what i wanted. I bought the game with no expectations tho, and bought it after the release because the other game looked like it would interest me also (havn't played it yet).

I would not recommend this game to anyone, unless the price is 5 dollars. even then it is a very nich game with tons of flaws.

The problem is this game was supose to be something special, and it isn't. It is very shallow and depends on others to complete what they started. People to tend to make great games better because it is worth more of their time; which this is not. I hope someone out there is making an awesome mod that will make this something special, but i doubt anyone with the skills to do so would even use their time on this.

I hate the lack of content, others hate that they do not quite understand what is going on or how to control it. Which feels valid to me because i spent to the time to understand most of it, and i just felt robbed of time. It all just felt so simple, just tell me how shelves, doing the same jobs, rugs, storage lockers, ect work. I am starting to get annoyed by this tatic of hidding basic information to pad out the game. show me the core game mechanics please.

I should beable to:
-do job rotations because people get annoyed by doing the same jobs.
-save past job selections because the way things are set up now it takes forever to do this.
-easly see and select vancant beds, and people that need them
-select non leathal for my basemates, and lethal for raiders in the security tab.
-set diffrent parts of my base as diffrent work areas for my guys, so i can expand without AI glitches and properly expand my base or even have bases.
-recall workers to a room, or atlease the base when there is an attack.
-have a happyness tab, to show how many people are feeling a certain way.
-to know what the hell a rug/plant does. I am sure it improves happiness, but I dono.

This is not a bad game, but it is just the core of what makes a good game. It needs more, alot more.

column8:
Disclaimer: This review is from someone who played the game STARTING at the most recent version, NOT in the incomplete Early Access version.

As its title suggests, Spacebase DF-9 is essentially a cross between Dwarf Fortress and Star Trek Deep Space 9. Compared to other games of the colony planning genre, the complexity of game content is fairly low, but the visuals are far more detailed and approachable; What I mean is, where in other games you may be struggling to remember what that static @ on the map represents, or which one of your little colored peg people was a particular character, in Spacebases you can tell at a glance what job an individual crew member is assigned to, what they're doing, and even how they're feeling, with an exaggerated moping walk when they're upset or a bounce in their step and head held high when they're happy.

The space setting gives way to elements you won't find in most other colony planning games, such as oxygen management, exploring potentially dangerous derelict vessels, asteroid storms and chest-bursting parasite monsters, but common themes remain such as the importance of high morale and dealing with tantrum-throwing or fighting crew if that morale drops,  dealing with disease outbreaks and fighting off (or capturing and reforming) invading forces.

Despite the amount or complexity of content not being that deep, I've still found fourty-plus hours so far of thorough enjoyment through catastrophic failures and the desire to "build it better the next time", and much like in a Roguelike, I manage to do better, and make a spacebase survive longer, than each previous attempt.

Decide for yourself what price you're willing to pay for a simplistic colony planner, but if you're a fan of them and love anything space-related, I think you'll enjoy this game.

column8:
I was really enjoying this game earlier in the year when I bought it. It was buggy as all hell but I knew it was early access and it had a dedicated team working on every problem. I could see the potential this game had and the creativity it would inspire in the future. Then Double Fine just gave up. They mismanaged their budget for this game and basically said "Here, you finish it." I've never been so insulted by a game company since the last time I bought something made by EA. The game is still a broken, buggy mess despite the patches coming out and that trickle of patches will end soon and it will be up to the community to fix it, mod it, add features and make the most out of a game abandoned by its original creators. Double Fine then tried to quell my outrage with a free game...that I promptly gave away. This ugly event has killed any faith I had in Double Fine. I will never buy their products again and they have no one to blame but themselves.
Oh, and about their new "$20.01" price point...har har har. That's a joke but not for the reason they think it is. If they drop the price by $20 bucks, then you'll get your money's worth.

column8:
This game had incredible promise.. but in the continuing saga of Early Access and Kickstarter, it's another confirmation that developers just can't be trusted to deliver on their promises. They've figured out how to sell half-baked demos as full priced games.

This is a demo... an interesting demo... but not a finished game. Along with Broken Age, I think that Double Fine has successfully burnt all of their credit with the people that have followed them for years. 

Double Fine has become just another games company that views consumer goodwill as a consumable resource.

The available rooms, objects, skills were all limited, but the concepts were clear and the game was fairly enjoyable.

That sadly is where the good news ends.
The game is inomplete as the bugs remain.
The number of rooms, objects and skills is still limited.
The developers have abandoned it.

I would suggest anyone considering buying from this company to give them a wide birth until they've completed the game and then read the reviews, because they seem to have a serious problem with ADHD and fail to complete a project they start.

column8:
Previously I would've recommended it, until the developer announced that they were dropping the game so soon.

I was a backer since the start. Although it had been left in a playable state, with the code made open source for the community to develop on, it's still a kick in the nuts that the game is left at only a fraction of what they promised Spacebase DF-9 was going to be.

Everything works you see, but there are issues:

-----

> AI are still dumb at times. 
I've seen people stand in a corridor when a meteor shower hits the base, or people outside the airlock suffocate because they're waiting in line and their suits run out of oxygen.

> Limited gameplay. 
Once you've built a self-sustaining base thats it. You're done. No more challenge outside of the occassional random events or purposely putting yourself into a situation.

> Limited reply value. 
You get one save file and one base, unless you manually switch them out in folders. Every replay is building the same base again until you come up with an efficient design that always works - its more of a time waster.

> No more official development. 
You'll recieve support, but any further addons are now in the hands of the community.

-----

If you're looking for a time waster with simple space-base building mechanics, then maybe this is for you. Its quick to load, with enough advanced features to keep things interesting while you don't have to micro-manage everything.

If you're looking for a game to compare to Space Engineers however? I'd suggest saving that money. You'll likely make one base or two, learn the mechanics, develop a strategy to quickly 'win' everytime and then get bored quickly.

Its a damn shame this game didn't make enough money so was dropped.

column8:
Double-Fine abandoned this game in a half-finished state.

When I get a refund for this, I'll think about buying something from these developers again, but the fact of the matter is that they have betrayed one of the core tenents of not only early-access game development, but also the free market. Money has changed hands. The consumers have paid for a product with the expectation that it will be finished.

That itsn't happening.

column8:
I'm so sorry - even now with 1.06, read some episodes:

- Tried the new tutorial, how to play; got to the explore derelict task - but the derelict never appeared :-) :-(
- Started a new game and despite in a sector with "low" threats, there were plenty of hostile ships chiming in from time to time.
- I was expanding my base; suddenly I got hails from friendlies. Two new ships/buildings appeared; one docked in the middle of a room building operation leaving it inaccessible; the other docked on a wall that had a ship engine. I could access the latter by cutting a wall and tearing down the engine to free the main entrance, but the former still inaccessible.
- There's a dead raider lying in the room to be the second reactor room. I can not build a power generator since the raider blocks it - seems bodies just don't disappear. I also have a floating dead astronaut in the middle of my bar; he was killed when the room didn't even exist.

I've spent hours in the game but only got frustration out of it - whatever progress I made, disappearing floor tiles, stupid AI, bugs, ... ruined it. Maybe I should finally uninstall it - I'd have had fun with it if it had been more mature.

column8:
While the game in its current state is relatively playable it is sadly unfinished.  

The UI is rather clunky and unfinished.  The AI even more so. 

There doesn't seem to be any dynamic events other than meteor strikes and random raiders which given the basic nature of the AI means that a lot of your personnell will be left dead and dying on the floor.  There was no effort put in to making the Random derelict encounters anything other than a randomly generated set of rooms to be a "starship" or chunk of space station and they pop into exisence randomly on the map sometimes popping in attached to your base.

All in all it is a stable game which is sparse and empty that will hopefully be completed by mod teams into something a little more robust.

However this only serves to prove that Double Fine missed the while point of what utelizing early access is for and clearly started this project with the hopes of funding it exclusively through EA rather than making sure they had the capital to put out a product.

For the price its going for you'll get a better deal by either waiting for Starbound, Planet Explorers, or Space Engineers to get out of alpha and into beta.

column9: I don't recommend this, as sad as it is to admit. As has been said many times, DF9 has enormous potential, but it wasn't even half realized. After the first 3-4 hours, it's simply boring and pointlessâ€”in that time, you'll have seen everything, literally EVERYTHING, there is to see and do. The transition to version 1.0 was extremely unexpected; in my opinion, another year in Early Access would have been better. And the price tag doesn't match the resulting product. It's sad and disappointing.

In fact, despite it being version 1.***, this is not a finished product at all.

I don't recommend buying it, not before a good bunch of patches, and hopefully some future mod.

column8:
This game is based on a really nice idea. It's just not completed yet.

Let's start out with management. Since the tiles you are working with is not directly underneath the stuff you're actually building, it's impossible to know if you're for example deleteing just this room, or also deleting the wall for the next room, which would mean all of the oxygen sucked out of your base.

Another thing is, that you can't move citizens around. This means, that you'll have to wait with (for example) destroying a room, because there are people in it. It can also be annoying, when you know theres a fire in a place, and you just have to wait until somebody discovers it. Even having the rooms alarm on won't help you. People only notices fires (and mostly also intruders), if they accidentally walks into them.

A third thing is bugs. There are bugs everywhere in this game. One bug happens when you have an intruder. You then mark the intruder with an icon saying "kill this man". Even if all of your citizens are security guards, they can just be standing, looking at the intruder destroying all of your reactors, and they will first react, when he actually starts shooting at them.
OMG thats annoying.
Another bugged thing is the airlock, the chamber between the base and space. Here you have two doors, that are never ment to be opened at the same time. Despite that, i've had a whole base killed twice, because the doors sudenly opens at the same time, and everybody is sucked out into space or suffocated. I've also tried people just standing in this room with the outer door opened, waiting until they die, and the door closes again.
AHHHHHHHHH

This is just some of the bugs i have experienced. Tough i've tried several times now, my best game has only been finishing my base, and starting to make research, when some stupid bug happens, or some superior enemies destroy your entire base in seconds.

If DoubleFine made this game 10 times more solid, i would definetely think it was a good game.
But unfortunately for everyone, this game is totally ruined by the crazy amount of bugs and poorly crafted tools in it.

column8: Spacebase DF-9 would have been a great game, but doublefine abandoned their project, as soon as they had enough money to make another game. column8:
The game idea is excellent, but extremely poorly executed.

Where to begin?
- Stupid citizens forever spiralling into madness. No matter what you do thye will become angry and rain a shit storm on the base you just spents hours building. There's no way to make them happy. Even if you give them their own room with tons of shelving and space, an awesome pub with very fancy food, their favorite job and even places to chillax and workout... They will always lack something and then poof! they're angry and destroying the oxygen collectors that keep them alive.
- Dumb techs and builders that don't prioritize. "Oh let's build this wall that serves no purpose yet but hey, that airlock can wait. I just hope I don't sufffocate...... *dies of asphyxiation*" Just terrible AI all around.
- What's the point of building a base in an "extremely low" threat area that is clearly not low at all. Raiders every 5 minutes.
- DId I mention that eveything goes to shit? Oh yeah. remember that awesome base you planned and have been working on for the past 5 hours defending from raiders and citizens and building the greatest space palace you've ever seen? Oh yeah, you can't save it. People died? tough luck. Gotta start again from scratch!
- I'm raging at the many crappy things this game represents.

When I saw videos of this game I was very excited to buy and play it. Now I just feel cheated and extremely dissappointed.

column8:
Game was declared "finished" by Double Fine without actually getting to the point the developers promised. As a make up gesture, they gave people Hack 'n' Slash.

Don't spend your money on this game. It left early access while still being essentially an unfinished product, and Double Fine decided laziness was easier than delivering the promised product.

I'd avoid any future Double Fine games as well; you never know when they'll abruptly be called off.

column8:
Now I let me prefrice this by saying that I did not buy this game, I got it for free at launch with me having bought Hack n' Slash so I don't have as much attachment nor need to justify this purchise. Now with that out of the way I do want to mention that I do enjoy this game, it hits all the same centers as Dwarf fortress did. I will and do recomend this game to anyone who likes Dwarf fortress and Gnomeariea.

Now for anyone who wants some more info on this title and not just a breif blurb. Starbase DF-9 is a take on your Dwarf fortress style game I personaly like it more but this is my byis towards space over fantasy. For those of you who do not know what this game or style of game is let's run this down real quick. In these style of game you take a small group of settlers and build a base having to harvest rescorces, defend your land make everyone happy. This is much harder then you would think, and these games suscribe to the idea that loseing is fun, you either ram your head into it and start to learn how to play it through sevrial fresh runs. 

Double Fine did a great job as usuial with it's sense of humor in a game although for them this is a weaker showing, which is stil better then most "ha ha we're funny" games bring us. The graphics are styleized and rich the artists did a nice job in the 2d art you see in dialoge but I do feel that the models coud use some work, although this still could grow on me and is made to make it easier to tell at a glace who is doing what in your base.

This game has a lot of potential but it did not and is not paying for its devlopement which is a sad thing so that game finalised early and is only a shadow of what they wanted to bring us. I hope that as this game sits on steam and sells they can make more patches to bring us the content they want us to have and make a okay game a stong game for those in this neich of gaming.

column9:
This game is a joke...

I bought it during Early Access. There were only a few buildable items, poor AI, and tons of bugs...

I thought maybe it would be good in a few months. Looking at the list they had, this game would be fun, right?

Guess what?

A few months later, they jumped from the alpha version to the full release. All the promised features are gone.

Now this game is a half-broken joke.

And Double Fine has put a huge dent in the Early Access model...

Look at Massive Chalices. They claimed to have fully funded their Kickstarter campaign,

and yet they're trying to cash in on the Early Access campaign.

People are wondering if this is just another crippled DF-9.

The official claim is, "This game is nearly finished and different from the DF-9."

They say you can't teach an old dog new tricks.

But Double Fine is trying to cash in again.

Damn Tim Schafer... I was fooled by his Kickstarter video!

Maybe Massive Chalices... It will have a completely different fate than the DF-9.

But I absolutely won't buy it until the game is complete. That's what Tim Schafer taught me...

He used to be my hero... damn it.

But the DF-9 gave me a hard time!

column8: Game looked very Promising, but sadly they stoped their development midway. :/
column9: Game looked very Promising, but sadly they stoped their development midway. :/

column8:
When I get a full refund from Double Fine for Spacebase DF-9, then I'll consider buying another DF game. I don't care how great the guys developing Massive Chalice are, they're from the same studio that scamed me out of 25 bucks.

25 dollars, in the grand scheme of things, it isn't much. But there's alot of things I could've done with that 25 dollars, first thing that comes to mind is buy a case of mediocre beer. 

Now when I buy a case of Budwieser I expect certian things; I expect bland taste, I expect to get a mild buzz, sounds like a pretty â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ty use of 25 dollars right? Here's the thing, I was never promised anything more.

Lets expand on the beer analogy: instead of Budweiser, DF is now the brewer. DF promises me a pretty nice brew: nothing amazing, but something well worth my money. Having heard DF has produced some quality brews in the past I buy a case from the affable salesman. I take the case home, eager to try a fresh new flavor from the brewer I've heard so many good things about; then I open the first bottle. â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥, this bottle contains nothing but â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ and â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ fumes; disgusted but still hoping to at least drink my initial disgust away I open another bottle..........more â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥. So the evening rolls on with me opening up bottle after bottle of DF's â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ untill the whole case is gone in the midst of my now pungent apartment I realize: that â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ at DF scamed me.

I storm down to the storefront where I bought the not-brew only to find the signs down, the windows shuttered, and a note on the door: closed due to lack of customers.

That's the best way I can think to describe my one and only transaction with DF, they sold me a case of â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ and said the reason the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ was â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ is because not enough people bought their â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥. So I hope you fine folks at DF can understand why the next time someone asks me to spend my money on one of your products, I'll tell you to shove your product up your â™¥â™¥â™¥.

column8:
Double Fine slapped a "1.0" sticker on this game and abandoned it. Whilst I appreciate that there are times that an Early Access game may not deliver all of the promised features, this game received a small fraction of those features proposed.

But this is a game review, not a review of Double Fine's business practices. So how is the game?

In short, the game is a mess of buggy AI with barely enough gameplay mechanics to sustain more than a couple of hours of play. The character morale system is horribly half-baked, and the game is little more than a series of repetitive busywork tasks.

That Double Fine now has it's greasy mitts out for Early Access funding for Massive Chalice barely a month after abandoning DF-9 is an insult to all of those people who put their faith in the company.

Never again.

column8:
This is fun to play and quite challenging. As I am more the "builder" type of player, I don't like the invasion events - but they are handleable up to a size of 50 inhabitants. Take care afterwards.

It's a lot of micromanagement in here that sums up to a nice game. Unfortunately after a while the resources get short.

column8:
I brought a game in Early Access because it had a promissing development plan and I wished to support the development, unfortunately I got a game full of bugs and incomplete. They removed the early access information, but the game is far from complete and now the only hope of balance and changes are in the hands of modders.
The company gave up in order to stop spending money in the development.
Thank god someone stored the old devplan and is possible to compare the promisses and the real deal.
http://web.archive.org/web/20131018054131/http://spacebasedf9.com/devplans
There are better games like gnomoria, kenshi, etc.

column8:
I had high hopes for this game. It had promise, it had decent enough gameplay, and it was fun to see how your colony gets destroyed. Shame that Double Fine's decision to abandon the game isn't as fun. I loved Psychonauts, so giving the middle finger to them is agonising. I'm sorry, but I can't excuse you for this.

Seriously, spend your money elsewhere. Like feeding starving children.

column8:
Game had loads of promise and even with all its bugs was worth it. Knowing that eventually the bugs would be fixed and more features added. Then, to my horror, they slapped a release update on it and dumped the game.  Never buy a Double Fine product again. This is my first and Last time buying from them. 

After all this time, I have bought many early access and indie games. I have learned more and more from each and can tell a lot better when things will head downhill. There is risk in any indie / early access game, but failures like this will only continue to hurt sales of actually good decent indie companies.

column8:
Buy early access, realize it has problems, but it's okay..,
Come back half year later, to play:

Step1: build my first airlock with a space suit locker. 
Step2: the mentally challenged builders finish the room, except the lockers. 
Step3: game notices me, when all 3 of my crew have less then 20% oxigen left, that my crew can't get in.
Step4: panic&realize the builders can't open the airlocker door, cause it has no no lockers, also can't reach them to build
Step5: the time I get to the tear down the wall, and finish the airlocker, 3 of my 4 crew members dead. (asphyxiation :) )
Step6: last survivor gets into base finally, parasite infection.

This is just so fuckin sad.. :(

column9:
So now the game is out of alpha, and I have to say it's worse than it was at the very beginning.

My Cew constantly beats itself to death, there are way too many raiders (no matter where you start).

Research doesn't work properly.

And there hasn't been nearly as much added as promised at the beginning.

They did give us another game as an apology, but that doesn't make it any better.


If anything changes, I'll edit my review.

column8:
This is a post-release review.  Previously I had recommended it while it was in early Alpha.  In early Alpha, I did recommend it because it showed great promise and looked like it was going to be improved greatly as development continued.  As it was Double Fine - I had high hopes.  Admittedly, I probably shouldn't have gotten my hopes up for any game that is early access.  I highly encourage you to buyer beware for any early access games you may wish to fund in the future.

A note on the current status of Spacebase DF-9: It is considered, by the developers, to be complete enough for a full release.  Currently they're bug squashing and finishing some other small details on their development list.  That's it.  They're done after that.  There will be no future development done to this game for the foreseeable future, according to the developers.  They may not get back to it for at least 2 years, at minimum.  Buyer beware.

On to the review:

I have only played it for about 2 hours since it's official release.  While it still retains the charm and brutal difficulty as most games of this genre (ala Dwarf Fortress), there hasn't been that much added since the last builds of the early access Alpha.  

The graphics are passable, the sounds are passable, the text and artwork definitely has the Double Fine touch that many love and enjoy.  The actual game play and game design is a hollow shell, crying for more.  Should you survive for at least an hour to hour and a half, you will have built everything that is needed.  The rest of the game is simply adding more space for more crew members, taking care of their needs, fighting off the occasional raider/parasite, researching the lack-luster tech tree, and preparing for the â€œend gameâ€ fight with the raider mega-fleet (which also completes the game; I believe).  I'm unsure if the raider mega-fleet actually ends the game or just scores you as I simply got too bored waiting for the mega-fleet to show up.  I built everything I wanted, I raided derelicts for tasty materials, and I threw the troublemakers in my station in a brig or two.  Not to mention dealt with some of my own bugs that are still hanging around since the Alpha builds.

Amongst some of the issues with the game: No varied save slots for more than one base at a time, vague tutorial, unrealized or fully implemented concepts, inability to clean up blood stains (at least no way I have found out), questionable fairness (random spikes in difficulty or events that have no lead up; bad things just happen and they're absolutely devastating), and AI having no way to prioritize important tasks (so they just stand around building the room while they suffocate instead of building the single oxygen recycler they need to survive).

Elaborating on the unrealized/fully implemented concepts: There are a great deal of the beginnings of production chains, rooms, etc. - But they're just lacking.  All those things you would normally build in other games to fully flesh-out a production chain just aren't there.  You just build a room and get the end product immediately.  For example, instead of building a whole bunch of different machines and making an actual factory that takes raw ore, crushes it, purifies it, refines it, and then makes it into usable construction components â€“ You just get a single shot â€œmatterâ€ resource that you use for everything.  The developers didn't want the game to be too bogged down in these systems, but you never need more than one type of room with their setup.  There's not enough dÃ©cor for the rest of your base, so you're just stuck with single blocked out rooms at a minimum size to hold just what you want and that's it.  It just leads to boring designs and an uninteresting base to look at.  It's visually boring.

If you're dying for another Dwarf Fortress game, set in space â€“ I highly recommend checking out Rimworld or even looking into Gnomoria for your Dwarf Fortress needs.  Let this derelict game drift away.

column8: I purchased this game, dispite reviews that suggested it had a lot of bugs and work ahead of it, with the assumption that the game would grow and upgrade as it slowly made its way out of greenlight. Well, that's not the case. Double Fine decides they can't keep working on the game and they leave it filled with bugs and glitches. This is the type of behavior that destroys developers and wrecks the credibility of steam greenlight. I'm so disappointed, this game HAD a lot of potential. I'd only buy completed games now from this developer.

column8:
It's fun if you want to simulate trying to keep a bunch of literal violent retards alive in space.  

Am I joking or exaggerating?  No I am not.  I have never dealt with such mind-crushing stupidity in any game of this sort, ever.  The stupidity of your citizens goes above and beyond funny and delves into the absolutely painful and rage-inducing.  

I'm talking about builders not building airlocks and dying from it, Techs not maintaining their oxygen recyclers, panicing when the lack of oxygen makes them suffocate, and then dies flailing around in circles - going into a raider/monster infested derelict one after another for the sole purpose of greed; the overwhelming desire to pick up some stupid, worthless toy and dying for it in a pile of their greedy dead friends, stamping on a roaring fire the size of a house and burning to death in a huge mass instead of using the fire extinguishers directly outside and in said flaming room - walling themselves into small rooms and dying, refusing to tear down the wall to escape or build a door,   Downright refusing to maintain the station, their lives, their jobs, or anything relating what so ever to order, because they'd rather bash each others brains out in some psychotic fight, or they'd rather have a temper tantrum because they need to keep the oxygen recyclers operational and they can't play with their rubber duckies.

Yes, all of this actually happens, and it happens constantly.  It isn't some stupid trivial issue that appears once in awhile, it's literally fucking constant and it never fucking ends.  Seeing 30 people die one after another because they individually decided to stop working/cooking/sleeping to go steal a fucking trinket from a derelict near-by, and absolutely nothing I try to do can fucking stop them (Making them security and putting the deployment icon elsewhere, making them builders and trying to make them build, ANYTHING BUT DIE IN THAT FUCKING DERELICT ONE AFTER ANOTHER FOR YOUR STUPID BULLSHIT).

Again, this isn't funny.  It goes beyond funny.  It's unplayable.  It's literally fucking unplayable because you're actually trying to manage severely mentally disabled humans and aliens in a fucking space station.  If they don't kill themselves from suffocating, greed, or just random senseless violence and fighting, the almost constant raider attacks (that eventually culminates to a literal raider fleet, for no reason what so ever) will kill them.  

The best part is apparently the developers took the money and ran, haven't been doing anything with the game, ban people who point this out or mention it on their forums, and are making new projects/bullshit with the nonexistant money.

This game could be really, really good if the crew wasn't so fucking retarded and suicidal.  If they were competent and HAD PRIORITIES like ANY LIVING CREATURE WITH SOME SENSE OF SELF-PRESERVATION, the game would be good, REALLY good in fact.  As it is right now?  No it's unplayable bullshit.

Maybe some modders can take it over and fix it, do anything with it, I don't know.  But by default this bullshit is awful.

This game could be really, really good if the crew wasn't so fucking retarded and suicidal.  If they were competent and HAD PRIORITIES like ANY LIVING CREATURE WITH SOME SENSE OF SELF-PRESERVATION, the game would be good, REALLY good in fact.  As it is right now?  No it's unplayable bullshit.

Maybe some modders can take it over and fix it, do anything with it, I don't know.  But by default this bullshit is awful.

column8:
Unplayable and inexcusable


I payed the $25 dollars for a game I cannot play. Graphical glitches and bugs make the game too difficult to make even the most basic bases. 

I have verified and reinstalled the game multiple times, modified the boot config.cfg file (posteffects turned off in windowed mode), but still the issues remain. I have a computer within the required specs and do not have issues with any another games.

DF should provide a full refund because they did not deliver the game as promised. Failing them to do the right thing by their customers, Steam should at least provide store credit since they profited form the sale of game that was never finished in good faith.

column9: I won't write about the game's strengths and weaknesses. I'll just mention something that's guaranteed to drive a player crazy after half an hour of play. The station's incredibly, hopelessly, and endlessly stupid AI. "Why bother repelling the raiders' attack on the base? Let's eat and drink!" "Why bother putting out the fire? Let's do push-ups on the floor instead!" "Why bother cleaning up the corpse? I'd rather stand on it and play on my handheld console!"

column8:
This game is fun, I really enjoy it. This game also has a large amount of game-breaking bugs, which are not fun and will kill everyone in your base. Sadly now that it is officially released these will probably not be fixed.

Things to enjoy: SPAAAAAAAACE. Also base building, planning, and generally keeping everybody happy, fed, and safe.

Things to hate: Terrible AI. This includes having all your technicians/Miners/Scientists/etc go to a raider ship to pick up an item they want... and then being killed by raiders. It's like watching lemmings. Speaking of raiders, they have a tendency to outmatch even the toughest of 5v1 battles with your security forces. Other things to look out for are Builders bothering to install some more flooring, taking a break, and then suffocating to death because they forgot to build some air recyclers before taking said break.

What this game needs: Able to queue up actions, or prioritize building. Being able to tell your citizens to STAY AWAY from scary people in scary spaceships. Or fires. Or vacuums. Theres a lot of room for both necessary, and quality of life AI improvements. Theres a lot of work put into this game, and I happen to think it's fun, but it is clearly not finished yet.

column8:
When I first got the game I loved it and I knew it had a lot of potential but the jump from early alpha build to Final build has just destroyed the game. 

It is still a good game to play every now and then but it defenetly should be Â£2 even Â£4 becasue of the state the left it in.

I bought the game because it looked so promising and had so much potential and I loved the consept of this game, I would say that this is the only early access game I have regreted buying.

After buying this game it made me worry about buying early access games, knowing that at anytime the developers could drop the development of the game.

However the game Prison Architect restored my faith in the Early Access games since the studio that developed the game stuck by the game and cared about the fan base.

Don't Buy This Game !!

column8:
Wasted My money:

Turrets have too short of range
Enemies outside of their ship have just as much health as the ships do...why?
Sometimes the lights of the base do not light up when you come back online

I chose the perfect sector 22-31 where the crime rate was supposed to be extremely low, after a few minutes of playing I get swarmed with raiders.

The game was designed with minimal resources as this game has no goal other than sandbox mode and build until the raiders come to destroy you. And if you do manage to thwart off the ridiculous amount of raiders, when you build a decent sized base I got a raider message saying my base was too large and I got swarmed by soo many raiders that even with my base being completely built with turrets on everyother outside block on my base that even this wasn't enough to kill those raiders.

Eventually the game AI will always destroy you so very un even programming.

There are not many options to customize your base with
There are upgrades but you have to find the plans to them on derelicts

Besides raiders in between those raids you have people parking their so called ships on your base and you eventually have to continually play cleanup where you kill the people aboard, select and highlight their ship and try and dismantle it, and once your done finally clearing away their junk it seems another NPC wants to park their ship on your base where it become permanently attached until you tell again your workers to disasemble it.

It might have had potential if the game designers decided to spend more time polishing it and expanding the way the surfaces interact...as in raider ships come in at some wierd xyz angle that looks goofy and unrefined.

Anyways there is more I can complain about but I would rather throw money at a hole in the wall.

-----Do not buy it unless your addiction to buy stupid games and crossed yet another questionable line.----

column8:
I'm going to focus on the AI aspect here. 

In the beginning, there was Early Access. In its Alpha build, DF9 AI was rudamentary. It made bad, often comically bad decisions, and it was like watching a child grow and interact with a world we knew it would adapt to. Like parents, we told our friends the marginally interesting tales of how the children stopped to chit-chat about Moonbeef and whatever while oxygen recyclers caught fire and firefights happened around them. And it was funny because we assumed that it would improve with time, development, and attention.

Then DF noticed. They thought this is where the charm of the game came from, and they pulled the plug. Our AI children stopped growing, and were now going to stay stupid. "You enjoyed the stupid AI", they say, "and now that's where we decided to leave it." 

We enjoyed the AI because it was temporary and had some amusing quirks in its broken state. Being forced to deal with the game in the shape that it's in is not fun. Building a base for inhabitants who don't know how to live in it is not a sim, it's an exercise in futility.

column8:
A fun game & great concept.
Though the downside is that they pulled out of alpha development way too early.
It seems like they're making more progress now the game is released, rather than when they were developing it.

I recommend it to those who love to sandbox and mess around with building/ simulation games.
But I'd recommend waiting until some more development/content from a thrid party (modders most likely) is released.

column8:
To start off, i'm more neutral towards the gameplay factor, but i have to give this a negative rating for the fact that DF just abandoned the game when they saw it progressed to slow.
But here's the gameplay review, if you're still wondering if you should buy it or not : 

The game's idea is wonderfull imo : build a base in space, maintain it and welcome new colonists into it while fending off raiders and managing the jobs the citizens do. The way they did it was not bad at all, simple drag-build controlls and assigning the different areas by a simple click of a button and design the interior as you like with various props. Easy. Simple.
But the thing that made the game bad is the fact that it's unbalanced, buggy and just unfinished.
The A.I is pretty bad in prioritizing their tasks, and with the new mood system there is just no way of keeping them happy, even if you furnish every room and give them their favourite jobs. they all eventualy get depressed and start fighting over nothing, which screws up the whole base and delays tasks as they recover in the sickbay.
The gameplay is refined for an Alpha at the time, but there was no change in it whatsoever when it went to V1.0 .

I wouldn't recomend the game to someone who disliked game-breaking bugs and dumb A.I , but if you just like building a base and dont mind using mods to fix all of the vanilla game's problems, it is worth buying whenever it gets on sale.
But otherwise, i sadly can'r recommend it, sorry Double Fine, but ya kinda screwed it up here.
4.5/10

column8:
This game was made by an interesting company called Double Fine. The game it self has left early alpha and has became a full game already, now i will emit this game could of been worked on alot more then it currently is. The game many 'preset' areas that you can pick from, but each area is actually randomized as to how it's looked. i played in the same area two times before and the asteriods was layed out different, i had different encounters and much more.

        Now alot of people are non-recommending this game simply because they don't see it being complete. now i do slightly agree there, but there is alot in this game you have to spend time playing to actually find. one example would be there is more research than the ones you can get at the begining once you build a research lab. Random data cores can spawn with derelict ships which have random chances to apear. so you could get a late game research earily on or just get a low grade research.

        When double fine released this into full game, they had said it wasn't to the level they wanted, they wanted to do so much more with this game but they wasn't able to do it. So instead of just scrapping the game entire like some people believe they've done. They have actually given it to us... to the people of the modding community to create things for it that they would like to have seen in it. Many games have been made alot better thanks to the modding community, games that have had more things than this one even. Yet Double Fine has still been doing updates to the game to balance the game and less bugs to the game.

        As for actually gameplay, the game runs fairly smooth and there use to be many annoying things that happened in the game. But the game does have random generation, so you wont have the same game twice. one game you could have an entirely peacefull game, never running into Raiders, or Aliens let alone other things. while one game you could get hit near the begining and get slaughtered, Which this is slightly factored by your chosen start location, for some has more likely hood of one thing than another would. Example: One section has tons of asteriods and rare encounters, while another has medium asteriods and very common encounters. 

        all in all, i actually believe it's a good Space Station Building simulation game, that many people wouldn't of thought to make, the only real bad thing of this game is the Ai i will emit mainy on the builders, if you want to remove spot in a room or anything be prepared for massive pausing and quick selection, for they will try to kill them selves at times, though i have never had to unbuild anything, because i never seen a reason to do so unless i was doubling a room, which was easy to save my builders. If You think when placing security markers that something is wrong and your security isn't going to the location, it's because either 1. their asleep. (you can't wake them up you gotta let them sleep for as long as they wish). 2. you actually don't have any (pay attention to the jobs you assign) or 3. There is no phyiscal way for them to reach the location.

    I will emit this is the first time i've done a review for any game, but i believed i needed to after seeing so many negative reviews that was for reasons that in my opinion didn't fit as a good full on review of the game. This game is still a nice game to play on the side, and in my opinion once the modding community actually starts making mods and more if they haven't already, this game could become even more interesting just like Double Fine is trusting us to do.
i personally would rate the game, but i'm not good at picking right numbers to what i feel it should be, it's not a game you'll want to just spend hours apon hours playing, though sometimes when you start you'll get a bit addicted.. untill your space station is killed and you rage. but you can't live forever.

i personally would rate the game, but i'm not good at picking right numbers to what i feel it should be, it's not a game you'll want to just spend hours apon hours playing, though sometimes when you start you'll get a bit addicted.. untill your space station is killed and you rage. but you can't live forever.

column8:
This is your cautionary tale about Early Access games.

Established studio with a good track record  abandons their game.

Not "some features are missing becuase they were too overzealous"

Not "rough going for a while until we optimize it"

Just "So long, and thanks for all the fish".

Never again Double Fine...never again.

Maybe it'll be a bit borring after more houres, but I'm sure that mods will come out soon.

About the game:
The graphics are realy nice and the musik just awesome. The gameplay is simple but addictiv: You're building a space-base and have to survive attacks and the dangers of space.
 
I know the gam eis a bit expensive, so if you're not able or don't want to pay 20$ for it, wait for a sale.

column8:
Don't be fooled by the trailer or any marketing literature Double Fine put out about this game. It is incomplete, buggy, and a waste of time. Double Fine claims to have run out of funds to develop this title but what they did is squander what sales they did get to fund other initiatives like Amnesia Fortnight and a trip to GDC for the developers (about four weeks of dev time down the toilet).

They then turned around and did an about face, turning this into an abandoned Early Access title.

I can't recommend this. Even the features that are implemented feel somewhat pointless. Where's the design? 

A few examples:
[*]Building and mining are incredibly slow but there were spaceships showing up with new citizens constantly.
[*]The order that jobs are completed is impossible to predict and it doesn't tell you if a job is cancelled.
[*]Every citizen has a constant stream of posts to their social network thing so you quickly start seeing the same stuff.

column8:
It is not finished.  That simple.  

This makes me concerned for all early access games.  To release this with so few features based on what they claimed the feature set was is an affront to their loyal customers.  I do not plan to purchase any further Double Fine Production games and will severly limit my early access purchases based on this fiasco.  The fact that Steam allowed this to happen is even worse.  

If games aren't going to finish, then Steam should not allow for early access.  If they declare this is our probable feature set and then do not release even half of those features, then you are beging cheated.

column8:
Game is not finished, its one of those abandoned early access games that went way over budget and then was never finished. This is of course always a risk with early access games and fair enough; however it is beyond med how it can now be sold as a finished game. 

Im very disapointed that I bought what was sold as a completed product only to  realise its abandonware in alpha. It should have some kind of big warning stickers on the store page or something. 

Of course it feels a bit worse due to the huge potential of the game. It feels like the beginnings on a really good, modern take on old classics and I really want to love it. But it really does need a LOT more polishing and bugfixing to be called a full game. 

TLDR; Its a scam - alpha game sold as finished product.

column8:
I played this game since the Alpha stages.. A few releases before 1.0, a new bug was introduced that DF-9 used 100% of a cpu core, even when the game was idle. Something was changed that caused this,  I filed a bug report, and it's still not fixed. 

This game is incomplete, has a buggy game core that no mod will fix, and DF has dropped all support for it. Don't buy this game.

column9:
Residents are constantly dissatisfied, despite having food/beds/shelves, even if their jobs are changed. That's why technicians don't repair equipment, and that's why oxygen generators are always breaking. It's unclear how to annex the station that's attached to it, so I'm dismantling it.
It seems fine, but the entire gameplay is crammed into an hour. So what, raiders, so what, parasites. What the residents write on Facebook seems irrelevant. Monitor everyone? If this is an attempt to present residents as real individuals and the game as social, then what's with the obsession with micromanagement?

Was a great idea, and I really liked th alpha. Dev's gave up on it and rushed a very very weak 1.0. Extremely buggy, Poor game play. Randomly you are invaded by multiple raiders, which no matter how many security troops you have you always loose. If you manage to survive or wait until you get new people something else happens and destroy's everything or kills everyone again. This is a waste of money. If dev's had any respect they would appoligies to the fan's and either refund some of the price or would realize they are going to loose all creditablitly and loose any fan's they might have had. Very disapointed, first game on steam I have bought that I wish I never did.

When they rushed and released 1.0 last week they gave everyone who had supported the game another one of there games for free. An atempt to sto the outrage by buying us with an additional game. There product should speak for it's self and not have to bribe people to keep or buy the product. Sad and pathetic.

column8:
Bought this expecting a company with a good reputation like Double Fine to deliver a decent game when it was finished. Sadly it never was and what we are left with is a a practically unplayable mess of a game mainly thanks to awful AI and the player having no direct control over their citizens.

Technicians will happily run over dead comrades into a battle zone to fix a door damaged by raiders. A doctor will then happily charge in to recover the technicians dead body. Builders will think it is a good idea to tear down derelicts to recover materials from the inside so when they demolish an external wall they suck themselves out into space and die.

The raiders are equally stupid as claiming a derelict as your own will often lead to them landing a raiding ship on in where they will demolish the airlock doors and the power and air purifiers trapping themselves inside until they suffocate.

Practically unplayable and with no sort of campaign or any sort of end goal to aim for there is no motivation to try and play working around these issues. Avoid.

Experimental Patreon style development was used to create this, under the condition that money continued to flow they would release updates in more or less regular intervals. When income dropped below a threshold they declared it finished.

It was not.

There are still bugs and it has no serious endgame.

column8:
Well I got this game in a Bundle, didn't know much about it and it was not bad, it had potential. I really don't like Early Access and this game painfully reminded me why.
This version is an alpha, broken, unfinished, plagued by bugs and glitches. Nothing wrong with that, it's an alpha right?
Well, not anymore. The whole business plan of DF-9 was to finance it on the way over the whole development process and it bombed. The alpha is now the full version and if you want a full version you have to do it yourself or hope for someone else to do it for free, this is a joke.

Do not support this kind of business, spend your money somewhere else.

column8: Spacebase DF-9 is a space station-building tycoon game with a storied development. Initially conceived during developer Double Fine's Amnesia Fortnight event, Spacebase went on to enter early access with hopes of a long, successful development period which would allow the game to keep expanding for years to come. Despite promising early sales numbers the development couldn't sustain itself and was cut much shorter than everyone expected. Version 1.0 does still offer a full experience, albeit one with quite a few bugs and rough edges. For more, check out the [url=http://youtu.be/ub9lWHFgdX0] VIDEO REVIEW	 [/url] http://youtu.be/ub9lWHFgdX0
