column8:
I want to like this game, I really do. But I just can't.

There are basic bugs and glitches with the AI and a failed priority system for tasks that add up to more frustration than progress - long before you get to the core balance issues. The biggest flaw if I need to point at any is a seemingly over-complicated mood system that is dependant on too many factors that lets it easily sway too far too fast. Early expansion is a difficult grind struggling with a  crew that doesn't work into that mid to what I think is later game starts to drag on far too easily as it gets harder to manage even basic needs with the limited resources income.

I admit it does sound nice, and can have promise - but it just doesn't seem to have enough behind it at the moment to get it there, or at least in the direction the game wants to go without doing something of a major overhault to some key aspects to smoothen the gameplay.

Try it out maybe on a cheap sale, but this is definetly not one I'd be willing to reccomend at a higher price.

column8:
I really don't understand the nerd rage that is going on here about project discontinuation. Like, "give me my money back" and stuff - come on, it's not a catastrophe! Of course, I myself also cannot recommend this game since it's not finished, but it's an interesting idea and it's a limited fun to play. The game has a great soundtrack as well.
It is sad that this project didn't make it. But it's not a reason to go that mad at a company that made it. Yes, they obviously failed, but at least they were honorable enough to admit it and atone for their failure by releasing the source code. 

P.S. BTW, did they make everything on Lua? It's kind of hardcore, IMHO...

column9: Despite the bugs (and remember, this is an alpha version), we liked the game. Adding inventory and relationships between residents would be absolutely fantastic.

column8:
Spacebase DF-9 Version 1 plays like a badly designed tower defense game now it has finally been released. Where you get a limited amount of time to build your station and then have to defend it against attackers. In one game I had a raider visiting by shuttle and 2 other ships attemping to breach my station and right after that pirates appeared. My crew went from 9 down to 1 before the last pirate ship appeared.

During the Alpha this game was about building a space station and whilst that was its main aim, I quite liked it. But the second it was released, it became something else entirely.

Games typically last about 40 minutes before one raider or another wipes you out having magically appeared in a room they did not have access too. 

I liked this game during the Alpha but now, I am afraid I must give it a thumbs down.... they seem to have ruined it in the rush to get version 1 out. 

Pretty Sad... If your looking for tower defense games, look else where, if your looking for space station games, try Startopia.

column8:
EDIT BEFORE YOU EVEN READ

It still broke... So... thanks a REAL lot, christ... I had FAITH IN YOU, GOD DAMN IT. I WROTE THREE PARAGRAPHS PRAISING YOU!!!

Ok so this game gets a LOT of flak. But I'm here to put your minds at ease. Version 1.02 is actually stable. It is actually enjoyable. I don't know why Double-FIne waited until the end of their development to finally fix everything but it's fixed at least.

I've played several hours of spacebse, and that playtime spanned version 1.0 to 1.02. Since the update to 1.02 my game has finally been running stable, though for some reason I do not get random ship encounters anymore.

Conclusion? The game is fairly cheap and enjoyable. It's had a terrible past but seems to have moved on. I recommend modding in the future though, since there are not a whole lot of mechanics in store.

This game needs more development time.

The ai is not very smart:

Security beacons do not work right, colonists will fly around for a while instead of securing areas

Builders will accidently kill themselves tearing down rooms

The entire base will suffocate by building oxygen recyclers last, despite this being an important priority.

column8:
09/11/14 OK. 1.05 and the developers are finally beginning to listen to their customers and are soncentrating on bug fixing. Unfortunately AI continues to be the cripple point that can turn a thriving colony into a pirate laden junkyard. I am very close to giving this game a positive review if they can stop crew from running off to derilicts and asphixiating.

04/11/14: With the release of 1.03 this has fixed up the lack of PROC and the game is now functional. Gameplay is now the issue and the AI acts in ways that will destroy you finely crafted society in minutes (like wandering of to a low oxygen area and dying). Hopefully they will now be able to refine and eliminate these problems. I stil hold out hope for the game, but those who are frustrated by AI stupidity may want to avoid this game.

01/11/14: Those who remember fondly Space Colony will also be fond of this game; at least until the subtle and confusing "bugs" start appearing. In this, the game presently plays like a beta. Playable, but with niggling issues. An example is a continual warning that some sections lack power, yet my base is entirely connected and reactor areas report low energy usage of X/Y. I currently am playing v1.02 and ships (increasing population) just stop coming at about mid game so ending the game at midpoint. Also there is no save games listing: it's one game and perma-death. Hopefully they will address these issues with bug fixes or better in game help. 

Unfortunately, according to the annoucement by Double-Fine (http://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2014/10/29/sad-space-party-spacebase-df-9-leaves-early-access/), they spend too much money on this game and have ceased development and opened it to the community. There will be some critical bug fixes (like ships that stop coming, I hope) but no more content or systems (like changing resolution or rotating isometric view). Perhaps the Steam community can save this game where the developers failed. 

I'd like to see the game succeed, but it is not fully playable just yet. If they can get the ship arrivals bug fixed they might have something here.

column8:
I got Spacebase DF-9 a while back when it was in Early Access.  My hopes were high, as I've enjoyed some of Double Fine's previous games quite a lot, and the game's website gave the impression that the completed product would be rich with gameplay and features.  I suppose it was foolish of me to believe what I read/watched.  

As you probably have already heard, the game was not, and will not be finished.  The released game doesn't come even remotely close to what the website claimed was in production.  I'm actually a little surprised that Double Fine is even releasing what is essentially a demo for sale to the public, rather than just sending its funders an apology letter and a credit for a free game.

It is shameful for Double Fine to call this a finished product, and the fact that they did so says a lot about their business practices as well as their apparent lack of commitment to quality.  I won't be buying their games again, and a free copy of Hack and Slash will not change that.

column8:
This game has so much potential.  Unfortunately, that is all it has.  If I had spent money on this game I would be uspet, however it kind of just "showed up" in my inventory one day.  

There are several small that are annoying, but the biggest, most game breaking part of the game for me is what happens after about 30 minutes of gameplay; total destruction by bandits.  Regardless of where I build my base or how many defences I have in place, my base is always destroyed by several waves of raiders.  A single wave would be manageable, however, the game seems to think that I have played long enough and sends endless waves, ensuring that nothing can live for more than a few moments after arriving.   This by itself makes the game unbearable.

My final thoughts on this game are that this game is dissapointing and someone somewhere should be ashamed.

column8:
[h1]Almost like it was designed to be pay to play... but they forgot to add anything to pay for to make it fun.[/h1]

Although this has promise and I got it free I would not recommend it at all.

It's as though nobody on the dev team st Double Fine actually played this game for more than 30mins. After the first few minutes it just becomes frustrating and annoying. Examples:

[list]
[*] - 7 botanists, all in one small Garden zone totally ignoring two other large zones. Game tells me I need more botanists.
[*] - 15 technicians (meant to repair stuff), EVERYTHING is sparking blowing up and not getting fully repaired. The only way to fix this is the reclaim the damaged equipment and build it again. This is totally STUPID. Game tells me I need more Technicians.
[*] - Sometimes people flip out which is fine, but assigning security to them, trying to cuff them, nothing works. They will destroy half your base, kill as many crew as they can and then eventually hopefully be subdued but some passing person as your whole security team run around them doing nothing.
[*] - Invincible aliens that wipe out your crew, eventually your security team turn up one by one and get killed off. Restart game.
[*] - Space debris damages a reactor and take out the power, nobody repairs it, builders take ages to get to it to reclaim it, will not build a new one as they are freaking out about oxygen. Restart game.
[*] - 7 member security team wiped out down to the last man by raiders. All 5 stars.
[*] - More raiders straight away. Restart game.
[*] - Give the hell up and go back to a decent game.
[/list]

Play this if you want a lesson in total frustration and how to never "finish" a game.

column8:
I promised I wouldn't leave a review until it was finished, as leaving negative feedback on an early access game is just unfair.  I loved this game, and with every patch it got better and better.

So why don't I recommend it?
It's simple.  It's far too unpolished for a finished game.

Missing text, UI errors, and dodgy AI prioritisation.  The AI is good most times, but it has glareing holes where it puts things like "stomping out fire on the other side of the raiders" above "the raiders are shooting at me, run away" and you end up with "look a fire behind those raiders that they just set that doesn't affect anyone, letâ€™s get every civilian to run over to the raiders and stomp out a fire while they shoot us all"

My personal favourite is "the oxygen recyclers are breaking?  No, don't fix them, lets panic for two hours while the oxygen slowly runs out"

Now you can put most people down to blind panic in situations like those, but out of a crew of 64, 52 of them went to stomp out the fire (they ran all the way from a safe section of the base, past security and into the raiders, most of which were assigned to security and tasked with killing the raiders.  You just wouldn't get a situation like that in real life.

I understand the reasons behind it, and the bug fixing is ongoing.  However in its current state it is still very very difficult to play smoothly, and I don't mean that the game is hard, I mean the game visibly holds you back when you want to play it and a single bug can be a game breaker.

If you like the look of this game, feel free to get it, back up your saves MANUALY on a regular basis, and don't be surprised if a sudden bug/glitch wrecks your experience.  However please don't buy this game if you are thinking it will be epic.  It's epic until a bug kills it.

As major bugs are patched I will update this review, but itâ€™s looking like the "patches" will either not continue or be few and far in-between.  There is currently a comminity unofficial patch in the works so I will be interested to see how/if that pans out.

[h1]Update:[/h1]  Over two years later and still no official patches.
Happily there is now a small unofficial team creating patches.  I've not tested it myself but the reviews for it are good.  It took almost two years for this to happen and although I will explore SpacebaseDF9 again sometime, for now there are plenty of other games to play that work out of the box.
column9:
I promised I wouldn't leave a review until it was finished, as leaving negative feedback on an early access game is just unfair.  I loved this game, and with every patch it got better and better.

So why don't I recommend it?
It's simple.  It's far too unpolished for a finished game.

Missing text, UI errors, and dodgy AI prioritisation.  The AI is good most times, but it has glareing holes where it puts things like "stomping out fire on the other side of the raiders" above "the raiders are shooting at me, run away" and you end up with "look a fire behind those raiders that they just set that doesn't affect anyone, letâ€™s get every civilian to run over to the raiders and stomp out a fire while they shoot us all"

My personal favourite is "the oxygen recyclers are breaking?  No, don't fix them, lets panic for two hours while the oxygen slowly runs out"

Now you can put most people down to blind panic in situations like those, but out of a crew of 64, 52 of them went to stomp out the fire (they ran all the way from a safe section of the base, past security and into the raiders, most of which were assigned to security and tasked with killing the raiders.  You just wouldn't get a situation like that in real life.

I understand the reasons behind it, and the bug fixing is ongoing.  However in its current state it is still very very difficult to play smoothly, and I don't mean that the game is hard, I mean the game visibly holds you back when you want to play it and a single bug can be a game breaker.

If you like the look of this game, feel free to get it, back up your saves MANUALY on a regular basis, and don't be surprised if a sudden bug/glitch wrecks your experience.  However please don't buy this game if you are thinking it will be epic.  It's epic until a bug kills it.

As major bugs are patched I will update this review, but itâ€™s looking like the "patches" will either not continue or be few and far in-between.  There is currently a comminity unofficial patch in the works so I will be interested to see how/if that pans out.

[h1]Update:[/h1]  Over two years later and still no official patches.
Happily there is now a small unofficial team creating patches.  I've not tested it myself but the reviews for it are good.  It took almost two years for this to happen and although I will explore SpacebaseDF9 again sometime, for now there are plenty of other games to play that work out of the box.

column8: Incredibly bad AI which frustrates the purpose of the game. Lack of content makes the replay value minimal. Lot's of promise, just another poor Early Access game.

column8: I would not recomend this game, go play Rimworld instead. I got this game on sale just after a new update, I though, it's about time to check this really cool game out! And 2 weeks later they abandoned the project. Should have known it was a bit too good to be true, a DF-like with this kind of graphics would mean that the developers are really meaning serious business, thats what i thought. My guess is that the choice of artstyle is what both got them an early success but then a faliure because its so much work representing all these little details that a game like Dwarf Fortress has. If you're not in it for the long haul, don't do early access. The way I see early access is that you let people play a game while youre making it, meaning you are invested/committed in finishing it since you're selling it to real people for real money. Failing to deliver on that will piss people off and lose you some credibility/trust. Even if you're in early access you shouldnt be relying 100% on that to be able to complete the game if you're selling it for real money.

column8:
DO NOT BUY THIS GAME.

The Game is incomplete and will not be completed. This game was funded via Early Access and because the Early Access version had maybe 40 minutes of gameplay, no one bothered to buy it and Double Fine decided to cut their loses and go straight from mid-alpha to release when it is still full of bugs, and told modders to finish the game for them. They gave out free copies of another game, Hack N Slash, just to be like "We messed up, Whoops sorry!" This game is a scam even at 90% off.

The game still consists of very little to do. The AI people die from suffocation and other stupid reasons all the time due to poor programming. The start of a new base also leaves very little margin for error.

You can find a rant I did about this whole thing in the video below. Avoid Double Fine games in the future.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=334084028

column8:
Fact is, this game is not complete.

That aside it is amusing/fun for a while (2-4 hours) then it just becomes frustrating. There are so many bugs in this game it begins to get on your nerves. On top of that, crew members regularly go on a rampage killing multiple people making it rather difficult to keep your base running. 

On my last playthrough a week or so ago, walls kept randomly disapearing. This wasn't caused by some random event, they just left, gone never to be seen again. When this happens to both your airlocks at the same time, GAME OVER.

column8: While the game starts good and has many interesting aspects, the dificulty simply ramps up too fast. I have been a fan of some of Double Fines games in the past but this one is not worth downloading.

column8:
A lot of people are going to say no to this game because of what happened with the early access. Which for those who don't know, basically backers were promised a lot of features that they later cut in order to push the game to launch due to lack of money.

Politics aside, Spacebase DF-9 is a good game. It has a lot of character, makes you smile at corny jokes, looks pretty good, and in general is a good colony management game. I don't think I can flat out reccommend it at $20, but if you pick it up during a sale I'm sure you'll find it well worth the money.

column8:
It has many bugs and not a lot of content. If you don't have high expectations, there is some fun to be had, but be prepared for potentially game-breaking bugs. 

For example, in my first 1.0 base, one of my first colonists got sucked out of the airlock because it opened for someone else after he had taken his suit off. That left me down a person and made the early game much more difficult. In my second base, the seed pod didn't spawn and one of my colonists spawned stuck in part of an asteroid. I decided to just restart at that point. My third base is going better, but the AI doesn't work very well even when it isn't bugging out completely. My builders will often stand around chatting or working out even though they have a bunch of stuff to do.

Ultimately, it just doesn't feel like a proper release. I can see building a few more bases, but there's just not enough content to keep me coming back.

column8:
Now that the Early Access and broken promises are over, it's time to review this game as what it is. Forget about the development plans for now, and just focus on what was delivered.

Spacebase DF-9 is definitely playable and can keep your attention for a few hours, as you struggle with a not too clever AI to survive the problems the game throws at you.

You start out with next to nothing and your first priority is to build and airlock, a room around the seed pod for power, and a life support room for oxygen generation. From then on you will be constantly trying to expand as new crewmembers arrive all the time, and you will face problems like boarders, raiders, alien parasites, base breaches, and crewmen going crazy and causing damage.

There is no real goal to this game other than survive. Eventually you will figure out how to create a base capable of sustaining 50 people, and the game will have reached the end: there will be nothing left to do except wait for people to die and be replaced.

The game has an unfinished feel about it and that is the main reason I cannot possibly recommend this at full price, but if you can get it at a good discount and do not look at the scrapped plans for the full version, you will probably have at least some fun with it.

column8:
First point I will make is I really enjoy this game and I would recommend that if it was on sale you should pick it up as despite what people are saying about it not being complete it is still a very fun game to play for 30-40 minutes every now and then which is how I play this game.

This game is getting a lot a flack at the moment for being pushed out rather quickly without being completed by the developer. Though this is the case there is still a lot of good content that is in the game as it is and the developers are releasing the code script for this so the community will be able to continue on and mod the game to make it better. I do have to say this is a quite bad thing to do on the developers side, it does mean that at least in the future there is sure to be a lot of content that will make this even more worth while.

TL:DR 
Fun game to play every now and then, buy if in a sale

column9: Despite being version 1.0, there are still so many bugs that publishing it as a "finished game" could be considered fraud. Dead people are thrown around the environment endlessly; ineffective sounds during battleâ€”there are 10, 20, 30 shots and I only hear 10% of them, no matter how I zoom in; the Resolve hatch stops working and the technicians don't fix it, preventing anyone from leaving the base; visual bugs when objects are damagedâ€”I only see the object/wall is damaged when I hover over it. And it stays that way, forever. Horrible. I thought I'd have fun with a Theme Hospital-style game, but I ended up just frustrated. DON'T BUY! Wait for this piece of crap to come out in 1.2 or cost less than $5.

column8:
Another in the recent series of mismanaged games that ran out of budget. Between Hack n Slash being a major disappointment and Broken Age being mysteriously broken in half and the entire budget being blown on the first half, I'm really beginning to doubt Double Fine's ability to publish games these days. I got this for free. FREE. From Double Fine. They sent owners of Hack-n-Slash this game, and the other way 'round, as some sort of twisted joke.

The game itself has been abandoned and the lengthy list of features that would possibly make this into a compelling and enjoyable game was scrapped. It's not even to what I'd call a true beta stage yet (i.e. feature complete, only fixing bugs) and they just slapped a 1.0 on it and left everyone who paid full price holding the bill.

At this rate, I'm seriously concerned about them being able to pull of the HD remake of Grim Fandango.

This could have been a truly amazing game. Instead it is a half finished idea, you can still see the  whiteboard brainstorm session. 

Zones? Incomplete. Progress? Nonexistant. It is a  gesture at dwarf fortress in space but instead of living up to their studios name they just fucked off when the cash grab was done.

Every time I logged into this game I said to myself "okay, still a lot of huge problems, but Double Fine will fix it and eventually this is going to be the next iteration of dwarf fortress. I cant wait to see where this goes."

I said that every time I played this game for a few hours, dealing with horrendous AI was okay because hell, its still alpha. They will fix it.

I logged into steam today, saw that it was 1.0 and was thrilled. Oh my to go to 1.0 the AI must finally be good! They must have fixed all the hilarious behaviour where a guy repairs an oxygen recycler and then freaks out and dies, finally i can play a base that wont just come undone due to insane citizens after a few hours! Great!

I created a new base and was horrified to see the exact same fucking problems that made the alpha quite literally unplayable. The citizen ai will guarantee your base will fall apart after a few hours.

No matter how smart your contstruction, no matter how carefully you manage the base, some collection of events WILL occur and wipe your base out. And it will be because of the shit AI. like telling people to repair a hull breach but instead they all just run around and suffocate. Or when a base adds on to yours and you explore it but then your whole base thinks it would be cool to explore and then they all suffocate and die. My favorite one so far was a guy who refused to build a door to get out of a room even after making him a builder and watching him starve to death, which caused the entire base to become depressed and stop repairing things so the base falls apart.

This is infuriating and flatly unacceptable

I will never buy another game that has Tim Schafer in the building, and I will never purchase another Double Fine game. if this is how they want to play the game, fine. Fuck them.

also the DF = double fine = dwarf fortress?? reference can go eat a dick. These people are the worst.

column8:
I read the negative reviews and backlash against DoubleFine, but I thought that I would be OK even if the game had some bugs and wasn't quite finished, so I picked it up anyway. That was a mistake.

The game is not just unfinished, its in an Alpha state. Which is sad, because I definetly would enjoy the game if it was done. As it is, the game is entertaining for a couple hours, then quickly grows tiresome and frustrating. The bugs are not crippling, but taken as a whole they represent a game that is very unbalanced and grates on you over time. 

If DF-9 ever hits the $5 pile, pick it up. otherwise pass.

column8:
This game is not merely incomplete, not merely flawed, it is magnificently flawed. It is the crack in a marble statue which serves to accentuate the glorious beauty of the whole. It is "the flaw as art". The game it pretends to be, that of building and managing a space station, is a mere cover. What it really is, is a grand commentary on the futility of existence, a plucky crew doomed to be obliterated by the forces of a cruel and uncaring universe, inevitably descending into madness and all-consuming rage, smashing the very machinery that keeps them alive with their bloodied fists in inchoate rebellion against an ethereal tormenter. Your base, which showed such promise, such hope, a seed among the scattered stars, will inevitably become a corpse-choked space necropolis, asphyxiated space pirates drifting, mixed with your own crew's plague-riddled forms in a macabre embrace, a scene of terror and death ruled over by the killbots which inevitably turn up to breach the fragile hull that protects your base from the endless night.

And that is just the tutorial level.

column8:
An incomplete game they slapped a release on to call it complete, so they could make a little bit more money from being on Steam's front page for a while. I got scammed by the developers and will never purchase another product from Double-Fine again. The game went on sale literally 3 days before they announced they were cutting development and just releasing the game as is. I got suckered into that purchase assuming there would be at least another year of EA, and at least most of the features on that list would be completed. Double-Fines horrible calculation of finances and not wanting to dip into their own-pockets for a game not even released yet shows a lot about their business practice. Avoid anything from these guys in the future!

As for the actual gameplay, well it's early alpha still with about 2 hours worth of gameplay before you run out of things to build and at that point you will just get raider after raider attack, meteors, and parasites mutilating your base with no chance for recovery. This game has been the biggest let-down for me since Fable 1 on Xbox back in the day :(.

This game had such potential .... and then Doublefine missmanaged the money entrusted to them by their fans and abandoned this game.

The game is a buggy mess. Key game features don't work. The advertised "research" features do not work at all, so the kit you have at the start is what you have all the way through. Sending security guards to investigate ares doesn't work half the time and citizen are completly incabable of getting back into the station before sofocating unless they are painfull close to the station


The tutoral is not only a joke exsplaning almost nothing (litterally exsplains nothing added after March) but it is hiddiously bug with some parts failing and preventing process.

To put it simply this game is a joke not worth of being a flash game let alone a Â£20 release

column8:
Nothing new to add.  All of the other negative reviews nailed it.  I was singing the praises of Double Fine a year ago, but have since told all of my friends they don't know how to run their company or make a decent game anymore.  Avoid these guys like the plague until they pull their heads out of their asses.

So much promise as a company, but they can't finish anything close to on-time or on-budget.  I'm sure they are decent individuals, but as a collective group, they are utter failures.  Here's hoping this bomb and the recent others are the motivation they need to return to the top of their game.

column8:
Sounds like a lot of these reviews, rather than reviews of the current product, are angry early access people who didn't get all they were hoping for. I bought this from the very first version, but I'm not particularly angry, for some reason. Franky, the game looks a good bit better than it used to, and the features in the trailer are in the game, so if it looks fun, it probably will be regardless of the reviews. And it's $20, even less now that it's on sale, plus they released the source code, so there's a lot of potential for mods. I know some people have said that 20 bucks is too much, but I don't think it is. Standards for game prices have gone waaaay down. Plus you can get Hack'n'Slash cheap, which is a really unique and interesting game. 

My only suggestion for potential buyers is to look up some videos of the game in action and make your decision that way, and not put much stock in the reviews, because many of them are colored by their expectations of early access, rather than focused on the finished product.

column9:
So, you have to like the genre, but personally, I really like it!

It's a strategy/management game like Dwarf Fortress (sorry, that's my only reference), but much more accessible! The direct consequence is a little less depth than DF, but it's still very decent!

That's relative; I've only played the game for an hour, so maybe it'll turn out to be repetitive, or not at all.

In any case, it's far from being a scam, so give it a try!

column8:
I bought this a long time ago, back when it had really just entered the Early Access section.  My play time is more than what's shown as I play offline a lot.  

The idea was sound, and I really enjoyed the game when I first tried it.  Obviously, I expected more as time went on since the game was still in development.  I also understand that development takes a long time, and isn't exactly the smoothest ride, so after a while I uninstalled and just let it sit for a while.  Seeing it just get officially released, I decided to check in on it again and find that, really, not much has changed.  I'm disappointed in the scarcity of things to do - it's a game of "build each facility, bam you're done", when it comes down to it, like the tablet versions of city builders such as SimCity/Metropolis/Anno/etc.  Just not much to it.

I don't recommend it simply because it's not worth playing more than once, and I'm not happy paying for something like that.  Even the most single-player of experiences I tend to come back to after a while, but SpaceBase didn't have anything to it that made me say "yeah, I'll pick it back up after I play this or that".  Not worth a buy, not worth the time, especially given how lackluster the support has been over the period it's been available.

column8:
I'm surprised to see so many bad reviews.  I bought this game a while ago and actually had a weekend of fun with it. 
Didn't follow up on the updates (so many games to play) but apparently they were lacking. 
I meant to pick it up again, but never got to it.  

Now i've been given hack & slash, a game that has been in my wishlist for some time, to make up for the fact that development has been stopped. Yay for me. :)

My recommendation: if you like city builders and exploring new games AND you don't really mind a bug here and there: this game might give you some hours of fun.  Development has stopped, so buy it in promo.

You want to build a digital space station in a way similar to dungeon keeper where not everything is too easy and people die or get attacked by aliens? You want to try it again and again and again till everything is fine and you can be proud about what you've done? Then buy it. You want something that's so easy every newborn gets bored? Well than look out for another game. 

Some people might call it buggy and not finished, I call it challenging. Have a good day,

column8:
Re-edit for Nov 2020 since this is showing up in a sale currently-

This was the game that killed Double Fine for me and ended Tim Schafer's professional career as far as I'm concerned. 

He took one look at the Early Access model and decided it would fund the development of this game- literally put the game up on EA and set the team's salary to be dependent on their continued sales for an unfinished game.

Of course this failed, this was never the intention of the EA model. 

But he stood there with his bald face on within a year, publicly abandoning this game, shocked that *we* didn't fund it's development. The man is a hack.  He's done very little successful since. 

There was a plan to let players salvage this unfinished mess, but that was 2014 and you can see from the top rated reviews they gave up and moved on years ago.

DO NOT PAY for this turd. Shame on Steam for even keeping this on the market, much less putting it on a highlighted sale. 
This is a scam.

On fait tous des erreurs, j'en ai fais une en achetant ce jeu (en solde heureusement et quand le humble store Ã©tait encore en $, donc je vais pas pleurer sur 6euros).

Le jeu est ratÃ© totalement. Les "bases" sont lÃ  mais c'est tout. L'ia est conne au possible, vous pouvez perdre votre partie juste parce que vos premiers constructeurs dÃ©cident de ne jamais rentrer dans la base que vous venez de crÃ©er. Bref, 30sec de jeu, une base construite, des morts qui flottent dans l'espace.

Une brÃªche dans la soute? Tout le monde panique, mÃªme les rÃ©parateurs courent dans tous les sens et crÃªvent d'asphyxie.

Une attaque de pirate? Envoyez donc votre sÃ©curitÃ© s'en occuper, ah pardon les devs ont oubliÃ© de leur donner des flingues, ou du moins ils ont oubliÃ© de coder comment tirer avec.

Vos bots trouveront le luxe de mourrir de faim dans la salle ou vous avez implentÃ© un restaurant, vos mineurs ne rentreront jamais par le sas de votre base, prÃ©ferant tenter leur chance en fracassant un mur, sans succÃ¨s malheureusement. S'en suivra leur mort.

Bref SpaceBase DF-9 partage un point commun avec alien, dans l'espace personne ne vous entend crier.
column9:
We all make mistakes, I made one when I bought this game (luckily on sale and when the humble store was still in $, so I'm not going to cry over 6 euros).

The game is a total failure. The "bases" are there, but that's it. The AI â€‹â€‹is as stupid as can be; you can lose your game simply because your first builders decide never to enter the base you just created. In short, 30 seconds of play, a built base, dead people floating in space.

A breach in the cargo hold? Everyone panics, even the repairers run around and die of asphyxiation.

A pirate attack? Send your security team to take care of it. Oh, sorry, the devs forgot to give them guns, or at least they forgot to code how to shoot them.

Your bots will have the luxury of starving to death in the room where you've set up a restaurant. Your miners will never enter through your base's airlock, preferring to try their luck by smashing through a wall, unfortunately without success. Their death will follow.

In short, SpaceBase DF-9 shares one thing in common with Alien: in space, no one can hear you scream.

This was so promising, which just makes the disappointment that much more bitter.

column8: As good as this game promised to be, Double Fine sadly ruined their chances of making a great game when they chose to fund this game pretty much from their early access sales, which is a perfectly reasonable strategy, if you deliver regular, great content. Sadly this has not occured, and the game sales stagnated. DF have now quickly pushed the game into a half complete, half-featureless husk of what it could have been, and it's still not very fun to play anymore. A lesson for everyone going forwards. Don't buy this.

column8:
This is the game that made me start reading reviews.

I bought this thinking that it would be like a sci-fi version on Towns without the clunky crafting system, also it reminded me of FTL. The game was just released in alpha when I got it, so I overlooked the plethora of bugs and unfinished... everything.

It didn't get better.

I am one of those people who gets angry at videogames, mostly due to something irritating that the devs decided to go with instead of something I think makes sense, and I get over it and come back to the game after a bit. This is the first time I have felt truely cheated by a game dev though. I have put up with the abuse that big companie give their customers like selling DLC that is vital to the game it's being sold for and should come with it stock,(*cough* ea *cough*), and many of you have too, but this is the first time that I have been sold a demo for the price of a full game and then be told that if I want it to be better that I should do it myself. This kind of thing is unacceptable in most other markets.

Yeah sure they gave everyone that bought it Hack 'n Slash, but if I wanted that game I would have bought it. I shelled out a good amount of money for a simple indie style game that was not delivered, in any other market I would be entitled to a refund. There should be a class action suite against Double Fine.

TL;DR

This game is an over priced and incomplete insult to everyone that bought it. They jumped form alpha 6e to 1.0 and I can't help but feel cheated.

column8:
Spacebase DF-9 is a great proof of concept for a colony management sim ala Dwarf Fortress. 

However, as Double Fine has essentially dumped it out hoping that modders will finish it after promising more updates than delivered, I cannot in good conscience recommend it for purchase. It is fun for about an hour before there is nothing else to do and no meaningful ways to interact with the world. Rimworlds or Startopia are suggestions for similar, more full-fledged products.

column8: Got this game for free all of the sudden today. So I said, "why not"? Ive played many isometric strat type games like this and this one is pretty horrible. Right away glitches with people in space suits, glitches with building, glitches glitches glitches. So naturaly I head right to the bugs report / forum for this early access title to report it. Come to find out, its NOT early access. This is it, this is what "shipped". I'm going to give it another try just to make sure I wasn't too far off the mark. But ya, it's pretty horrible. Building anything is a chore, rosters are a nice idea but the UI leaves something lacking, te game "feels" like a poorly made reboot of an old game I ued to play in the late 90's. (It's actually 90%+ desgined like that game, just poorly executed.) In short: If you get this for free, try it so you know what you wont like in a game. If you paid money for this, i'm sorry. I'm so so sorry.

column8: Under normal circumstances this game would have been cancelled in mid production when the devs realised it was not going to be any good. Unfortunately, because it was released as an ALPHA and people paid money for it and the devs can no longer cancel the project without refunding users a LOT of money. This is one of the pitfalls of "Early Access" games. If a company realises the game is fundamentaly flawed they can't just pull the plug and cut their loses. Instead, what we are left with is an unfinished game that doesn't know what sort of game it is supposed to be and is completely uninteresting after the first half-hour of play.

column9:
Despite the premature end of the early access phase, the developer has delivered a fun space station simulation.
As an early access customer, you're understandably disappointed that many of the announced features are missing and can only hope that they'll be added through community mods.

But as an objective player, you have to admit that you can have many fun hours with the game for little money, even if there's unfortunately not enough content to keep you entertained for the long term (20 hours or more). Hopefully, the community will help with that, too.

If you like to build things and enjoy the hustle and bustle on the screen (hello Settlers), you won't go wrong here for under â‚¬20.

column8:
[h1] This game is a scam. [/h1]

Do not touch this game. It has been rushed to "completion" after the developer failed to deliver promised monthly updates and supposedly ran out of cash. They returned their original investor's cash mind you, but they banked on using gamer's (Early Access) cash to subsidize the development, greatly overestimating the monthly sales for an unfinished piece of garbage. Maybe if they had kept up with updates it would have sold better, that seems to have been key in most other successful Early Access titles.

The greatness of the game's concept (found at http://web.archive.org/web/20131018054131/http://spacebasedf9.com/devplans) pales in comparison to the terrible nature in which this games development and budgeting was handled. Avoid at [i] all [/i] costs, developers should receive no incentive to pull these types of moves on fans and consumers.

This game is unfinished, awful, and I'm ashamed to have supported it in any way. The pride with which they present this abysmal product that cashed in on their own fan equity completely turns my stomach.

[i] "Weâ€™ve learned a lot and are proud of what we managed to accomplish, and itâ€™s all thanks to your support." [/i]

Double Fine, I think a lot of your fans can also say they learned something during this escapade and I doubt you'll like what effect that's going to have on future support for any titles bearing your now tainted brand.

TL;DR / What should I play instead? - Don't buy this unless coerced through physical violence. Instead, try Prison Architect or actually try out [url=http://www.bay12games.com/dwarves/] Dwarf Fortress. [/url]

column8:
This game is so unfinished it never even hit Beta. We have 6 Alpha releases and then Surprise! Launch party.

Development ran out of steam (heh) in early access and developers pushed the game out the door instead of completing it.

The citizen simulation is half baked, they arrive on the station with set friends and enemies and then negative or positive interactions with set friends and enemies just serves to increase or lower mood. A few promising features were half implemented but went nowhere. Others, like religion, trading, burial based on religious preferences never materialized.

The bare bones structure is there, but for a game that tried to be Dwarf Fortress (DF-9, heh), it's missing alot. One resource to collect, there won't be any traders or materials to trade for. If you look at it as a tower defense game, it can sort of work, as random waves of boarders and raiders can test your defenses and one bad hull breach can doom your entire base, but that alone isn't worth it.

Exploration and randomly generated content is nonexistant. You get hostile raiders, meteor showers, maybe 12 different canned derelict ships will appear to explore, and immigrants. Features that never materialized: Sending citizens on missions to nearby planets, traders. You'll see it all in ~2 hours.

Overall I mostly enjoyed this game on the potential that it'll get better and seeing the new content in the monthly updates that used to come. It's not really worth it as a finished product.

column8:
Ok, so this is painful for me, but it needs to be said. I got this game in early access, thinking it would be awesome. I didn't just throw money at it, I read everything they wanted to put in, watched a few videos, and then got it to help support the game... and now I don't think I'm going to do early access again.

DF-9 is a basic space station building game that doesn't have any long lasting gameplay. It looks great, it sounds great, it has the base to be great, but as of this review they have stated that Double Fine will not be doing any further updates. That simple statement moves the game from something that can be great to being mediocre at best. If this changes I will take another look at change my review, but as of now, donâ€™t get it, not worth it.

column8:
This game has cute points, but overall it is too shallow to be worth the price. Some examples: You mine "Matter" which you use to build stuff. There are no different types or ores, or complex manufacturing steps. You have two basic paths to feed your colonists: Matter replicators to start with, or a mini-production chain with botanists growing plants which are served by bartenders. A simplistic research chain. There are several types of rooms, but each has just a few types of furnishings. The whole thing is just --- I guess superficial is the word I am looking for.

I started playing during Alpha-3, and through it had a promising beginning. Unfortunately, what I thought was a concept outline which would have a lot more stuff added to it turned out to be it. Space-sim lite. 

Not an awful game, but no where near worth the asking price.

column8:
DO NOT BUY THIS UNFINISHED GAME 

- 

Well, I can say that I will never ever buy a single double fine game again ever.  This is the biggest INTENTIONAL slap in the face to a fanbase that I've ever seen a video game company do.  Move over EA you've got competition for biggest scumbag video game company now.  As someone who bought into the 'early access' scam they were doing for this game, I can't even begin to tell you how far off the 1.0 'release' is from what we were promised a year ago.  To simply say that they're not going to follow through on their development promises because it's not cost effective?  That's sickening.  They had a lot of people give them money based on their development plan.  Are those people getting refunds since they aren't getting the promised product or anything even remotely close to it?

As to reviewing the actual game, it's got the great bones for a game.  It is what it is...  an ALPHA build for an unfinished game.  DO NOT BUY.

column8: Bought this game with high hopes. A dwarf fortress like game in space by Double-Fine? Sounds amazing! What could go wrong? Apparently, being abandoned by the developer is what... The game has a good foundation but its completely unfinished. So many features suggested that would make it an actual GAME instead of a weird space station life simulation. I feel robbed and betrayed. I used to think Double-Fine made well-made and frankly BRILLIANT games and now they do this to me and im completely disillusioned. Dont buy this game. I repeat: DONT BUY THIS GAME. And frankly, dont buy any other early-access Double-Fine games either, they clearly cant deliever on their promises.

column8: Very decent game, is a lot of fun and quite a bit of replay value. There are some bugs, but those will be fixed in time. I suggest you pick it up on a sale. Lots of Sci-Fi factor and it also brings in a pretty new element of managing a space station, which I haven't seen before. Developers are nice and helpful, and dish out updates pretty quickly. The developers also focus on the bugs more, instead of adding useless content when the game is really buggy. Kudos to them for that.

column8:
As of 1.01 This game is a buggy mess*. You can't say still, because prior to 1.0 it was an alpha build. So: alpha -> release. This "release" is just a giant finger for the backers, a disgrace for DF, a disservice to Early Access and alltogether shouldn't even be allowed on Steam. It certainly would not have been greenlit if it had tried.

Besides the buggyness, there are a lot of design-issues which would have needed to be ironed out before release (no building priority, crew-AI, control over security, ridicoulus menus...).

The idea was good and the prototype (not the alpha) fun to play. It is still, more so than this game.

tl/dr: Please don't buy it.

*To give some examples:
-pathing is bugged, making at times airlocks not functional, killing all your crew currently in space
-hostiles appear frequently with mostly no time for you to prepare, decimating 3 out of 4 attampted bases of mine in 5 minutes after start
-builders pop out of their space suits randomly, ending up in rooms connected to nowhere, slowly starving
-bad seed-generation, starts you out with your crew and/or seed-pod encased in astroids and nothing you can do about it

column8: Spacebase DF-9 was a really cool idea, pretty much summed up as "Dwarf Fortress in space! ...with at least a slightly more user-friendly UI." Unfortunately Spacebase DF-9 was also a really bad plan, pretty much summed up as "Hey those Prison Architect and Dwarf Fortress dudes have been making tons of money off their unfinished base building simulations while they're still in production! Base building simulations make tons of money while in production! That's great let's do it!" Well it turns out that wasn't the case, so now Spacebase DF-9 is an unfinished product with no plans to ever be finished. It's for sale, for some reason. You shouldn't buy it.

column8:
Well I have to start with saying that I am really surprised by all the negative comments on this game......but then again I bought this game in alpha, played about an hour, forgot about it after getting into other games and then when I got back to it there were tons of new features. At this point I had a blast playing it (even in its alpha state I could easily get 10+ hours of gameplay) and was sure that small balances and tweaks would add a lot to the games value.

 I guess would sum it all up to I was not really expecting much. So as It is now I really enjoy the game, with no bias of previously reading dev posts of false promises and what could have been. What it is right now is a modern version of a god game where your in space.... think dwarf fortress meets the sims with a dash of spacestation sim. It does have its bugs and it is a shame that they still exist in the full 1.0 release but I am confident they will patch the problems over time.

As for everyone being hurt by how the devs represented themselves, the game, and double fine, (after reading the many reviews on this game) It really does suck. But Hey - At least it's not Infestation. Or any other of those super scamy games.... you got to admit that this game comes out as something pretty decent, even though it might still be a prototype.

column8:
Double Fine has gotten a lot of love from me simply based on the fact that they made Psychonauts, a game I loved.  

I won't go into the specific complaints I have with this game beyond saying it is incomplete and the AI has serious issues since these have been explored more completely in other reviews.

Frankly none of their recent games have really held up to expectations, e.g. Hack'n'Slash, which while clever like Spacebase but failed to impress or the Cave which was fun but had not replay value and was short as hell.

I have a lot of hopes left that Massive Chalice will be decent though to be honest I have not been that impressed by the last few gameplay videos I have seen.

In short, Double Fine you need to redeem yourself by actually finishing a good game.

column8: Despite a promising start, it's unfortunately impossible to recommend SpaceBase when Double Fine has left the game incomplete. Incomplete as is, the developers have my money, but have buggered up their handling of the project, so are bringing it to a premature close. They have released the code to those who bought it, and in effect are saying "Here, we can't be bothered to fix it, so you do it instead". Note, they have not open sourced it, and amazingly still have it for sale!

Double Fine, your ethics leave a lot to be desired. I will actively tell people to avoid your company at all costs.

column8: All this is after Double-Fine gave up on the project is a shadow of what could have been a great game. At the moment, it's little more than say Minecraft in it's first early stages, however this product will never recieve the follow-up that is needed to take a game from what essentially is it's alpha/early beta to the stage of a fully fleshed out game. It's sad to see a company as well respected as Double Fine give up on a highly anticipated project like this. However I've learned my lesson, do not purchase games from Steam Early Access as there is no guarantee of quality on any level.

column9:
No, Spacebase DF-9 is not a good game. While there were chances to be, Double Fine was apparently incapable of doing so.
As other players have already written, the game was released even though it had just been in the middle of the alpha phase.
The reason for this seems simple. Spacebase DF-9 was no longer financially viable for Double Fine. This was less due to sales figures, but much more due to Double Fine's mismanagement, which has unfortunately happened several times before.
I was already an Early Access buyer, and even then, the delayed updates and lack of transparency were a warning sign. It's a shame this adventure ended this way.
I appreciate Double Fine for their creativity, but this time I'm simply disappointed.

column8:
I don't know why so many are complaining. I think it's a great game, better than Starbound. As I mentioned a while back(their forums? steam? can't recall..) I don't think it's worth $30, $15 would be more like it, or rather $14.99 would be about perfect. But I'm a firm believer that developers are getting stupid crazy with pricing just because they see some games doing it and getting away with it.

I found this game a while back, but got a pirated copy to try it out. I liked it and came to buy it, but when I seen the price I decided no, I'd wait. Even if I had to wait for GoG to eventually sell it, for a more appropriate price. But then it went on sale for like 50% off and I was able to get it for about $15. I snapped it up then. I know it shows I've only played for a few hours, but I've got considerably more time in the game than that.

If you like games that set you some where and you have to do research and harvest resources to survive and manage things then this is a great game. Just pick it up on sale for $15 or less and you wont be sorry.

column8:
Do not buy this game.

I bought into it early on, trusting and respecting Double Fine as I enjoyed many previous games from them and I enjoy games like this so I decided to support the project.

It was developed reasonably well from that point, up until recently. 

See they did not finish it.  Nor will they.  They decided to abandon the game in an unfinished state and push the code out and hope some modders are awesome enough to finish it for them.

Not only did this ruin the potential I felt this game had but it has ruined me on double fine.  I will no longer make purchases if it has their name attached. 

This game is a very early state, it is unfinished but they are calling it version 1 and walking away.

Do not buy under any circumstances. 

Sorry double fine, but your handling of this has just poisoned you in my eyes.  I used to love your stuff but I refuse to let this pass.  Maybe in future if I catch wind of you updating this game in major ways like you were meant to I will give it another chance since I already own it but as it stands you guys lost a customer. Probably a lot of them.

column8:
Update - Since writing this. Owners of this or HacknSlash got given the other game (We got given HacknSlash. HacknSlash owners got given DF9) as a peace offering it seems. No. I feel like we are still being cheated.

This is one of the few times i feel like ive been stung by Double Fine and their lack of understanding. They threw themselves head first into this and a lot of us believed we were going to get a full game. The long list of features were what attracted us to the product and we simply wont get that. Double Fine have dumped this game, going from Alpha to 1.0 out of no-where. This game has been left in a state that makes it the most pointless state. It upsets me to even think that i trusted them to do this. If you want a very VERY bare-bones sim game that you have to expect the community to mod into a game worthy of playing? go for it. 

Me? I'm going to go play Clockwork Empire.

column9: Big scam: the game was supposed to be much richer, they stopped it in the middle of development because they couldn't budget properly and they ran out of money. In the state they stopped development, the lifespan is pathetic and the game is not worth more than 3 to 5 euros, and even then, there are free games that are a thousand times better.

column8:
Do not buy this game.

When it was in early access, a lot of features were promised early on. A few months into it, however, things changed. Their unfinished game was not selling like it was the next Minecraft so they decided to cut and run. The features of the game were unceremoniously pared down and a date was given for "1.0". 

There is almost nothing to this game. Don't go into this expecting any sort of depth. You can build a dozen or so different rooms and pirates or derelicts will enter the area every so often. Sometimes your citizens will get angry and go on a rampage. That's about the extent of the interaction in the game. 

This game once had promise but because it didn't sell while UNRELEASED and UNFINISHED every drop of potential was sucked out of it and it was pushed out the door with some bug fixes and a tutorial.

Ich weiÃŸ nicht wieso hier alle negative Rezesionen geben, schlieÃŸlich bewertet man hier nicht das GeschÃ¤ftsmodell oder die Einstellung der Entwickler zu der Finanzierung ihres Spiels, sondern das Spiel an sich!!!

Und auch wenn es jetzt von der Alpha in die Finale Version geht, das Spiel macht nun mal echt viel SpaÃŸ...
Der Humor passt, die Grafik ist auch angemessen und auch die bisherigen MÃ¶glichkeiten sind ganz ok.

column9:
I don't know why all the reviews here are negative. After all, we're not judging the business model or the developers' approach to funding their game, but the game itself!!!

And even though it's now moving from the alpha to the final version, the game is still a lot of fun...
The humor is fitting, the graphics are decent, and the features so far are quite good.
And if the mod community adds more content after the release that was originally planned, then Spacebase DF-9 could still be a success.

All in all, Spacebase DF-9 is only recommended if it's on sale or if you really want it and don't know of any alternatives.

Don't believe the release announcement. Spacebase DF-9 hasn't been really updated in months. The developers messed up the Early Access model with months of no updates and lack of content and this is them saying that they're not going to work on the game anymore.

Features that were originally planned for were scrapped, no real end game or even a mid game and people are still reporting bugs despite them having all this time to "finish it." Avoid this one and for a game that gets Early Access, check out Prison Architect.

Don't believe the release announcement. Spacebase DF-9 hasn't been really updated in months. The developers messed up the Early Access model with months of no updates and lack of content and this is them saying that they're not going to work on the game anymore.

Features that were originally planned for were scrapped, no real end game or even a mid game and people are still reporting bugs despite them having all this time to "finish it." Avoid this one and for a game that gets Early Access, check out Prison Architect.

column8:
I purchased this game when it was still in Early Access for the full price (was $25 when I bought it).  Developers promised a lot of things, new features, customization, and a vast amount of gameplay.  Unfortunately, none of these promises were delivered.  I bought the game because I enjoyed Double Fine's Brutal Legend.  They seemed like a trustworthy developer that could get a fun quirky game done and make it worthwhile. 

After months of no updates and no communication I began to lose heart.  The minimal amount of playtime (logged 0.6 hours) was due to the lack of a tutorial (which they have since added, and it's sub-par) and (I assume) a bug that prevented my characters from entering the base I built.  I started another game, and again they wouldn't enter the base I built and ended up suffocating.  Started another game and I finally got them to enter the base, and that's where more bugs appeared.  Just read the forums to get an idea of how frustrating the bugs are and how broken the game is, despite it getting a full release.  

Very disappointed in Double Fine.  Their lack of communication regarding the game's development, refusal to be honest with people who bought their product (e.g. not letting us know they planned to stop development and leave the game as is), and the fact that they had the gall to release the code and tell the community that if they like the game, then they have to fix it.  Come on.  

To conclude, I'd say avoid this game, it will receive no further updates, and as it stands it's an incomplete mish-mosh of ideas.  Even for $12 I'd say skip it.  Hopefully they update Gang Beast, which I also purchased before this fiasco, although it hasn't received an update since the day I bought it (2 months ago).

Update: Source code has been released...and there are still parts of the code that are hidden, as one person on the forum mentioned, the Oxygen Recycler.  One of the most basic units of the game.  It's used to prevent your base from losing oxygen, thus preventing everyone from suffocating.

Update #2: Price has changed to $20.01 (from the sale price of $12), and that's about it.  Tried playing the game again and it wouldn't let me complete the tutorial (was not allowed to place a second airlock door where it indicated).  Still have yet to build my own base.  They supposedly also fixed some bugs on October 30th.  This is what one user had to say:

 "crlsniper Nov 1 @ 2:30pm 

Glad to see your working on fixes, though the bigest fixes need to be AI fixes, Mostly for doctors and security. I lost an entire base just because none of the doctors would go help people who where incapacitated, neither would soldiers go arrest and move raiders who where incapacitated either."

Multiple counts of the same complaint.  Furthermore, despite where you establish your base, you will have near constant attacks from pirates/raiders.

Some brave souls have attempted to mod the game (essentially having to rebuild the game from the ground up), check this thread out: http://steamcommunity.com/app/246090/discussions/0/613940477963640858/

It outlines a lot of the bugs and problems with the game, such as faulty oxygen recyclers (e.g. too many people in a room would cause dramatic decreases in oxygen no matter how many recyclers you had, thus everyone in that room eventually would suffocate).

Update #3: Free copies of Hack n Slash were provided to buyers of this game (myself and a few others received a copy), however it strikes me as more of a political ploy than a genuine apology.  This is because people who purchased Hack n Slash got a copy of this game.  As far as I know, Hack n Slash purchasers weren't spat upon and kicked to the curb by Double Fine, so this move makes no sense to me.

And of course I'm not eligible for the new refund policy, since I purchased this game over a year ago.  GFY Double Fine.

Like many others, disappointed. Lots of graphical bugs, the game not being finished, I understand, but a major AI issue. You spend an hour building this base only for it to end in a massacre by three raiders or some creature that appeared from who knows where in the base...

Far from recommendable at the moment.

column8:
One of my favourite games from years ago was Theme Hospital, I liked the style and the humour to this end this seemed to scratch a particular itch.

Because of this I bought this game when it first came out, it seemed a little buggy but as an early access I was willing to let it slide as they were promising monthly updates and seemed to have a solid list of achievable goals.

I played the game until the my guys locked themselves out and suffocated. I thought "A bug, I'll come back in a couple of weeks"
I played it a couple of weeks later, I maxed out the building element of the game, built a couple of each room, hired people based on skills, trained them up etc. not that it made any noticable difference and then a similar thing happened. people suit up go outside and wait until o2 runs out, and so on, and so on, apparently I have done this several times in less than 6 hours of total gameplay over the course of 12 months. 

Now it's a year after the release date. they're advertising their 6th alpha which is already less than they previously stated and unless they offer an incredible amount of content in their next release they're offering a game that will let your base be built and let the residents lock them selves out and suffocate to death over the course of about an hour and a half.

So yeah, save your money, go to the cinema, for once it's better value for money.

column8:
DO. NOT. BUY. I bought into this game very early, paying $25 for basically a tech demo, because I loved the concept. I also trusted DoubleFine and Tim Schafer, being a respected studio and developer, to deliver an awesome product in the end. Alas, the development of this game seems to have been mismanaged into the ground. DF is abandoning the project and leaving us gamers with an unfinished buggy mess and calling it 1.0 release. There's about 10 hours of playtime here at most and quite frankly that is just not worth the pricetag.

Update 11/12/14: I tried playing this game again after the 1.0 release. It still feels terribly unfinished. The new tutorial and goals system feel slapped together, lackluster, and unnecessary. I wish they would have spent the time adding more actual game content instead of these "features". Not to mention, the game is still very buggy. My first attempt at a base fell apart rather quickly after a derelict showed up. I set  a beacon to have my security guard check it out, who got killed by a bot. That alone would be fine as a possible risk of exploration, but then my other non-security personnel decided to go to the derelict "picking something up" (presumably the body) even after the beacon was removed. They all subsequently got killed, too. Nothing I could do would send them back to the safety of the base. Basically, I just got too frustrated to want to continue. If you still want to try this game, get it on super sale. It is just not worth the new lower price of $20.01.

column9:
Alpha was barely sketched out after a year and a half of development, yet when you listen to the guys at "Double Fine," here's a game that promised so much and more! Yet the result alternates between bitter regret (for having believed in it) and the deep feeling of having been duped by unscrupulous people.

Because I'm afraid, once funded (and paid), the developers clearly felt that their initial (and I'm being kind here) work was enough to say, "That's it, I've finished it! Buy me, baby!"... in short.

In summary: DON'T BUY IT!!!

P.S.: Unless, of course, you absolutely want to support a "video game charity" and/or don't know what to do with your money.

column8: The developers of this game have effectively abandoned this project. The next and last update will take this game from the alpha stage it is currently in, skip the beta entirely and become version 1.0. The developers stated that they are giving the game over to the modding community. I will back the sentiment of one the reviews below, this game only has a few hours of gameplay until you run out of things to do. A huge amount of features promised will now not make it into the final release. Do not buy this product unless you do not mind having an unfinished game. Perhaps the modding community will make something wonderful out of this, but until that happens, I strongly recommend you stay away. Stay away from DoubleFine(the developer of the game) altogether as this is not the first crowd funded project they have abandoned.

column8:
Hi. 
The game itself is awesome. You run your own space station, and the game is executed with great sense of humour and is a truly fun game. However, at this stage it is not up to par with other management and RTS games. Main problem is the prioritising: if you said you want to build a room and a piece of equipment in another room. The game will build the room first and there is no way of manually prioritising actions. Also if a builder makes a bed and he is tired he will selfishly go to bed instead of finishing other beds, in some cases it is annoying. As a way of fixing the problem the workers should be clickable so that you can assign specific task to a specific worker if you want to. Also clicking on the equipment should show what it affects(i.e. oxygen in surrounding rooms) and how well it does it. Cancelling your actions is very hard, claiming wonky and if you assign a room with reactor to a farm or other type it will destroy the reactor instantly and kill everyone in the station if you have one reactor. Also the research projects seem to be impossible to start at this point. 
All in all the game is very detailed, nicely done, pretty and funny, but it is very unfinished and lacking in some of the most basic features such as prioritisation and control.
Sorry for bad spelling and idea expression.
Danvor

column8:
Bottom line is, never trust Tim Schafer with with your money again.  He put something up here that fleeced the people investing in the game, while taking no financial risk himself.  Calling him an indie developer is an insult to indie development (PS JP, Your not a developer until you develop a finished product).  All they did was take peoples money, determine they weren't going to break even based on pre-sales, returned no ones money and banged out after a year of development.

There are people breaking their backs out there to make a game.  Meanwhile your developing a quarter of a playable game in one of the most expensive cities in the US.  Try a little, or fail at your job and get offended at people for being reasonably upset at your hack job.  I bet if you had venture capital they would have crawled up your ass, but since its just the lonely plebs below they should be ashamed for belittling the pie eyed hacks you have working for you.

Thanks for the code, feel free to disclose your financials if you want to not be called the fly-by-night scum that you are.

If I every see Tim Schafer or JP LeBreton involved in a game, you can be sure I will not purchase it.

column8:
It's probably best to avoid this. The game was apparently reliant on early access funding and didn't sell enough copies to continue development past an extremely barebones set of features. Not sure why Double Fine decided on an extremely risky business model.

It's worth noting that I haven't been able to play for more than about an hour without some kind of show-stopping bug as of the patch before they call the game complete. The AI is dreadful and has a habit of doing the worst thing possible, like suffocating when there's a working airlock and oxygen generators. It's not very likely that all of the issues will be tidied up in the month or so they had left on development.

It's a genuinely great idea and with another year or so of dev time I could really see it shaping up to be worth the money. For now it's not worth the money, and likely won't be once it leaves early access.

column8:
SCAM ALERT

This game is part of Double Fines new buisness model where they rake in a bunch of cash by riding Psychonauts and other older titles coat tails. The idea being that people will buy anything Tim makes as he is a old school developer. However since it did not sell well enough to justify more development and thus more sales it was abanoned in favor of the next take. Going to really have to sit back and do a wait and see on anything further from them. Since if you jump in early you risk the game you invested in early being abandoned.

column8:
If it wasnt for bad optimization on the Pathfinding and other core parts of the game, you would be through with it in aprox. 10 hours max. Comparing the current price (~20 â‚¬-ish) with what you would pay for an Alien Isolation key and the tense action and story telling, well lets just say go for A:I. 

To make this review more helpful, I will shortly tell you what is currently in the game: 
Build a base with oxygen-generators, a simple airlock and some rooms. Create a food source. Mine Asteroids around you and enlarge your base. Upgrade food source and build living and recreation areas. Research stuff. 
This, all the while you are defending against Pirate raids, that wouldnt be a problem, if not for the bad Pathfinding and AI in general, that paralyzes your security officer on duty, unable to shoot at the invaders. 

PLEASE dont buy this game as it is Vaporware and clearly was ment to be a cash scam all along. Though I see little hope, I will try my luck with a refund for my money, as many people here have been scammed into this product. If you dont believe, just watch the forums here. 

Thanks

column8:
just as they promised not to, 
this fly by night dev, 
has rather loudly pulled the plug on Spacebase. 
It has been disastrous to their reputation
and it has killed the games fanbase emotionally.

This game is Early Access AbandonWare

It is DEAD

If I were in Double Fine position, id drop the price to $5 and see if that could help generate sales. 

BUT

This is why you shouldnt buy this game.
NOW as for why you shouldnt even play it. 
Its undercooked and unfinished and will never be finished,
the core gameplay that is here is lacking, and there are much better
management sims available than this, go play SimCity instead, 

The worst thing is, whats here isnt bad, its a fun game ( not Â£18.99 fun however) 
and there clearly was a lot of promise here, but it lacks a cohesive and complete design
a victim of the early access nature of the game, very basic systems were in place here
with no real central mechanics, while it is noticably graphically superior to 
the amnesia fortnight prototype, mechanically it is almost just as under developed and
after 18 months of development, a lot of promised features are completely missing.

While I understand Double Fine has a passion and a penchant for making unique and
interesting games, they absolutely shouldnt not start making a game that they cannot 
gauruntee to finish. Spacebase DF-9 should have never been greenlit, I love the idea but
the project completely failed, and Double Fine didnt gamble their own money on this, or 
even their investors money on this, they gambled OUR money on Spacebase. The game made 
its initial investment back pretty quickly, but due to a high price and lack of features
only a small subset of dedicated fans jumped in. 

Early Access is supposed to be a tool for devs to make a little extra money before a game is 
finished. The game should be planned and financially secure for completion before coming 
to Early Access and in spite of it. It absolutely should NOT be the primary form of financial 
resource for a game, ESPECIALLY for a professional studio like Double Fine that is located 
in a city like San Francisco that has a high cost of living. This game shouldnt even exist
and poor management has cost me and many others about Â£19 and it has cost Double Fine
my trust and future trade.

Im Sorry JP LeBreton, I really wanted Spacebase DF-9 to succeed, but you gambled
with my trust and now Double Fine has lost it.

column8: Kurz gesagt, wie es auch vor mir schon gesagt wurden ist. In der Alpha 6 wird die Entwicklung eingestellt und geht in Full-Releas. Das geht garnicht und sollte nicht unterstÃ¼tzt werden. Deswegen keine Empfehlung und bitte passt auf und kauft es nciht mehr.
column9: In short, as has been said before me. Development will stop in Alpha 6 and move on to full release. That's a disgrace, because so much was promised and not delivered. Now to simply say, "Sorry, we're not continuing because we somehow overpromised!" That's completely unacceptable and shouldn't be supported. Therefore, I don't recommend it, and please be careful and don't buy it anymore.

column8:
Do NOT Buy this. It's been an interesting ride, but Double Fine is already discontinuing development.

After they recouped the 400k investment through the initial Early Access purchases rush, the plan was to pay for the game's development through early access sales.

The lack of an actual game or engaging mechanics left no animo for word of mouth excitement and Spacebase DF-9 is losing them money. Say what you will, perhaps they should focus on not repaying the investment before the game is actually fun to play/worth selling, but let's hope Double Fine learns their lesson on overpromising or underestimating their budget needs.

column9:
A year has passed since the alpha was purchased and launched, and 6-7 updates have been released, along the lines of "We've added a bed!", "We've added a generator; energy no longer comes out of thin air!", "We've added a pirate ship sprite," "We've added a completely empty room called a prison," and so on. Bugs and glitches from the level of "absolutely broken AI" have escalated to the level of "relatively broken AI." Some items still lack a simple description or a non-glitchy sprite that crawls through or under objects... The game mechanics remain at the level of the very first alpha: aimless, awkward construction of empty rooms that perform their functions, often with just one item...

And now, a year later, this very alpha, with updates that are worthless, is being released, officially declaring the game's development complete... Essentially, they released the alpha, waited a year, and now they're saying it's a fully developed game.

Don't buy this product under any circumstances; it's a scam. I've never seen such rude behavior towards customers. Double Fine products are now on my blacklist.

column8: At first glance this game had much potential, asking for a small amount of money on kickstarter the developers recieved 8 and a half time of what they asked for. And everything seemed pretty good so far, they released an alpha version to play and test with, and as it is with alpha versions there were some bugs. But suddenly their money ran out and now they're releasing a game without the hundreds of features they promissed their supporters and in it's currently unfinished alpha stage, presenting it as if it was a full on game. That is a no. Do not buy from double fine. Bad reputation will be worse than doing a little over time, and they have to learn that
