Gameplay Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tE08x3a0x5M
Spacebase DF-9 is a space-based Sim with astronauts. It's a sci-fi, strategy space simulation in the indie style. You don't have much time to expand your base and build rooms to replenish your oxygen supplies. Additionally, astronauts can learn various jobs such as builder, technician, miner, and much more.
More information on my homepage: http://xxxduxy1337xxx.wix.com/pcgameworld#!reviews/

column8: Ask me a few months ago and I would have told you that this game had very interesting ideas and a lot of potential. Ask me today, and I'll tell you about the neglect this game has received and the piss-poor development practices of Double-Fine. This game is no longer being developed, they jumped from beta 6 to "finished" 1.0 release. They now want us, the community, to continue the development of the game through lua script mods. shm

On se prend vite au jeu de construire sa base spatiale depuis zÃ©ro, la faire grandir petit Ã  petit malgrÃ© les obstacles (attaques ennemies, passages d'astÃ©roides, rÃ©sidents qui deviennent fous si on ne leur satisfait pas leur besoins, ...)
Ca peut assez vite mal tourner (incendie gÃ©nÃ©ralisÃ©, robot tueur infiltrÃ©, manque d'oxygene...) et c'est ca qui est fun.
Mais ca reste malgrÃ© tout du early access : beaucoup de bugs dans l'IA (c'est assez frustant de voir ses rÃ©sidents se suicider eux meme), et on en a vite fait le tour (pour le moment).
column9:
Edit: Do not buy since development of the game has been abandoned.
You quickly get caught up in the game of building your space base from scratch, growing it little by little despite the obstacles (enemy attacks, asteroids passing by, residents who go crazy if their needs are not met, etc.).
Things can go wrong pretty quickly (widespread fire, infiltrating killer robots, lack of oxygen, etc.), and that's what's fun.
But it's still early access: there are a lot of bugs in the AI â€‹â€‹(it's quite frustrating to see your residents commit suicide), and you've quickly gotten used to them (for now).

Chicos, no funciona nada de nada, todos los eventos son totalmente aleatorios y desmesurados eso sin contar con la cantidad de veces que pones cosas a construir y simplemente desaparecen como los bancos de pesas... hay mil cosas que no estan bien completas como por ejemplo si alguien de la tripulaciÃ³n baja el animo, es imposible volver a subirlo.
En lineas generales y en pocas palabras,  tras leer tambien los foros en inglÃ©s:
Es un timo. Una estafa dado la gran cantidad de jugadores que han metido pasta en este producto. A este tipo "Tim Shafer" no deberian volver a dejarle acercarse a un ordenador. Ha utilizado el acceso anticipado para financiar su juego, que no vale los 3m de dolares que ha sacado entre quickstarter y steam
No se os ocurra invertir tiempo o dinero, SpaceBase DF-9 es un retal de BUGS.
Espero que os sea de utilidad.
column9:
Guys, nothing works at all. All the events are completely random and excessive, not to mention the number of times you put things to build and they simply disappear, like the weight benches... there are a thousand things that aren't fully realized, like, for example, if a crew member gets down, it's impossible to get them back up.
In general terms and in a nutshell, after reading the English forums as well:
It's a scam. A rip-off, given the large number of players who have invested in this product. This guy "Tim Shafer" shouldn't be allowed near a computer again. He used early access to fund his game, which isn't worth the $3 million he's made between Quickstart and Steam.
Don't even think about investing time or money; SpaceBase DF-9 is a remnant of BUGs.
I hope you find it useful.

column8:
The only thing I like about this game is the concept.
What I don't like about this game?  Where to begin.  I can start with the big problem I noticed right off the bat.  This game has no tutorial.  I still have not figured out how to start building the base so I can get oxygen, power, and refinement up.  The worst thing about this game is that, even with all of the bugs, the full version has been released.  What this means is that the game has basically been abandoned by the developers.  I wish steam offered refunds, if steam did, I would get a refund for this game immediatly.  To sum up: THIS GAME IS A WAIST OF MONEY.

column8:
This game had SO much potential, but the developers - Double Fine - decided that the Early Access sales weren't paying for enough of the production, and they canned it. It is being rushed to 1.0 just to get it out the door and off of their plate.

So disappointing.

I remember back when games made money AFTER they were released, and "it's not making enough money during production" wasn't an excuse...

column9:
Big problem. I don't know if it's my PC or the game that's causing this, but every time I play, the game gives me a black screen, then it restarts the game, then the black screen again, and so on, like an epileptic. On the galaxy map, when I put my mouse in the bottom right corner, some kind of text appears everywhere.
In any case, if it's the game that's having this problem, it should have been fixed a long time ago, and I think it's crap that it hasn't been done.
With the last two updates, there are even more bugs!

I'm wondering more and more if the programmers really know what they're doing!

With each update, the game gets more and more buggy, it makes you wonder if they're doing it on purpose.

column8:
Unfortunately, considering the cost, the game just isnt worth it.  
Double Fine are wrapping up development without a significant portion of the features they intended to include.  The game is "neat" but it isnt deep.  I really wish it was.  I am such a sucker for Sci Fi anything and the game is charming as hell.... It's just not good enough. 

The only people I would recommend this game to are people who are looking for a significantly less intimidating/difficult game than Prison Architect/Dwarf Fortress or any of the other games in that genre..

column8: Imagine you payed someone money to make you a doghouse. They come to your house maybe once a month and d*ck around with the few planks and nails they have brought. Saying their excuse is that they are in "prototype" phase they continue to do this for a year. Rickety and really only an outline the crappy clusterf*uck of wood sits in your yard. To your surprise the guy comes up to you and says it is finished he just need to put another nail in. F*cking useless analogy I know but goddam, DoubleFine took my money and pissed all over it. Not enough content for a Beta phase and the implemented features are too crappy for a 1 year old Alpha. It is now entering "final" release with no further support. Go buy Goat Simulator. Somehow it is better in this situation.

column8:
Even though the developers say that this game is released (up to its full potential, or at the very least in a playable state) the sad fact is that it is not. There are dozens of bugs, issues with the AI, and, unfortunately, you'll find yourself more frustrated with the clunky features that can ruin your carefully-designed space station.

It had such good potential. As it stands, the game is not worth $25, not by a long shot. It's sad to see this game go down the toilet. But with it, so goes a good chunk of Doublefine's Marketing base.

column8:
You too Double Fine? 

An Early Access game falls short again but this time it is a pretty well known developer that decides to under deliver.  DF stated that it simply wasn't making enough money to warrant continued development and from a gamer's perspective, there's not much of a game to warrant purchasing, especially at the $25 price range. What we have here is a stalemate in which both parties lose. Gamer's lose money and the developer loses face.

As it stands, Spacebase DF-9 does let you create a base and manage some resources, it does have some random events to throw at a player so that the game isn't completely boring however, there are no end game type things to work towards, no objectives to ultimately strive towards.  In five hours, a player can pretty much run into everything the game offers and after that, the game will just keep repeating itself.

The lack of gameplay issue is compounded by the fact that the beta phase of game testing is being skipped over entirely.  DF is going to tack on a tutorial, wrap up some issues and then release the code in hopes that modders will run with their..un-game and make it better.

What was supposed to be a game that was to be in continuous development over the next five years with gameplay tweaks and additions is now kicked out the door in its current shape. I guess in space, no one can hear you break promises.

column8:
Avoid at all cost. 

As a big fan of other games like this such as DF and Rimworld - both of which I've played 100s of hours of - I can't recommend this game. Most of the promised features have not been added and the game is being pushed from early alpha to 1.0 release with no mention of future plans to finish the games development. Double Fine has ruined their reputation with this one and I for one will not support any games they develop in the future and would suggest to anyone reading this to do the same.

column8:
This game was boasting that they wanted t odo so much with it and the inspired to be like Dwarf Fortress but in space. I was so happy when I saw this, because I've always wanted a space sim where the main goal was to try and make a space station and survive. Thing is, there was so much they planned on fleshing out and building . Thing is, they didn't have funding so they took an Alpha game, slapped a 1.0 on it and called it finished.

Don't invest in $25 games is the lesson I've learned. Early Access is amazing, if done right and this wasn't done right.
Don't buy this game unless you absolutely love the idea and think this scrap heap will yield results.

column8: This game taught me a 24.99 lesson.  I will never purvhase another doublefine game.  A developer this large should not use the greenlight games as an alternate development strategy.  I am almost embarassed that I purchased this game and the only reason I did is that the green light games I have purchased in the past were KSP and starbound, both excellent purchases.  Remember before buying any greenlight game that you are buying an unpolished and unfinished game as is and the developer, as doublefine affirmed, does not owe you ant future content.  If someone has a game where you can currently jump and play a card game, even if they promise the best RPG of all time, you are buying that game and not what they promise.  I have bought games that have tremendous glitches and that dont start on my laptop through steam and this is the one I am most dissapointed about. This is the one I want my money back for.  I probably own 5 doublefine games on my xbox and I will never buy another game from them due to this experience.  Google this game and read a news article as to why you shouldnt buy it,

column8:
Double Fine are giving Early Access a bad name here, by confusing it with crowd funding. This game is overpriced, unfinished and, worst of all, abandoned. The argument that not enough people bought the title to warrant continued development is a silly one, as most people tend to wait for a title that is at least playable before purchasing, no doubt explaining the poor sales. On top of that, they will not be offering refunds, and complaining about the people who did not purchase, Double Fine are just providing an extra slap in the face to those that did. 

There was so much potential here, but as it stands the AI is a mess & it isn't possible to prioritise tasks so DF-9  becomes an exorcise in frustration.  You may find yourself wanting to create a turret to defend against incoming raiders, but because you can't tell your builders to do so, they'll continue to build a room before the turret and by the time they've finished it's too late and your whole base has been destroyed.

Raiders are also occasionally very overpowered, a raider single handedly killed everybody in my base because all of my crew members seemed to just flap about and let themselves die.

Even if you get round these issues, there simply isn't enough to do to warrant a purchase, especially at the frankly ridiculous price of Â£18.99. I will never buy another Double Fine title again. If you'd like to see an Early Access title that never deserted its backers and continues to get more and more brilliant by the day, try Project Zomboid. It's being made by friendly, helpful developers and is 3 times cheaper than this one for at least 10x the content.

column8: My original review was written under the impression that game development would continue and I gave a yes for my recommendation. Then Double Fine tells us they're releasing the game this month like they're dropping a baby on its head. You just killed it, Double Fine.

column8:
This game was supposed to be one of my favorite games ever, I played and enjoyed throughout early access and looked forward to every single minute of playing. Sadly the dev is rushing out 1.0 and with not even half the promised features.

Spacebase DF-9 tasked you with building a station then maintaining it amongst the stars, with research, raiders, new arrivals, and multiple room types the future of this game looked bright and full of potential. But, everything changed when the fire nation attacked...

SB DF-9 has followed suit of Towns, Starforge, and a few other Early Access titles in that, they made all the promises but only lived up to a few. With the community left with a unfinished product.

Please do not buy this game, developement is mostly finished and it will be abandoned go buy Clockwork Empires, Gnomoria, or Rimworld if you love these types of games. Idk if there will ever be a spacebase sim and, even if there is there will never be one in my opinion that felt as good as SB once did.... Truly tragic.

column8:
Not worth the money.

The game started nearly unplayable. The menu system is hard to use, the citizens would run to their own death, it was impossible to keep things repaired, and there was little to do except wait for the inevitable collapse. Too many people in a room? The oxygen drops low and they become unable to leave the room because the game [i]doesn't distinguish pressure from oxygen[/i]. Some of the issues were fixed; most were not.
Going in, I expected many more features by this point, and for development to continue for at least three years. The game simply did not deliver. Instead of fixing core design issues (like oxygen/pressure not being split, inability to respond to crises, and terrible AI), the developers just added on a few features (like asteroids, which quite simply make the game more annoying) and fixed the easy flaws (like technicians doing lots of damage, flying off to repair derelicts, and taking too long to train).

column8:
Double Fine got the ball rolling for crowdfunding because it was of their use of it for Broken Age that got the media talking about it and it ushered in an explosion of new games that wouldn't have been otherwise, which was awesome,  but after the Broken Age fiasco and now with Double Fine quitting on Spacebase DF-9,  they're pretty much undoing all of that awesomeness by crapping all over it. WTG!

Even after all the sluggish updates that seemed to cause more problems than they fixed, and with all the features that never came to pass, Double Fine is washing its hands of this game and are moving on.  I cannot recommend this game because it's being released unfinished.

Do not buy Double Fine early access titles!!  The risk is too great that they'll pull the plug like they've done with Spacebase DF-9.  Your money will be left in the hands of Tim Schafer, probably the worst businessman in game development today.


DO NOT BUY!

column8:
Here, I made an analogy of this whole situation for you:

What they've basically done is told people about a wonderful mansion they were planning on building for everybody; it would have a waterfall, and monkey butlers, and regular butlers too. If you want to get in on this; drop us some money! You can watch the work come along!

Except, it turns out, they basically have about two walls, and maybe a bit of tarp stretched over a corner or something. Not exactly inspiring stuff; so uh, they're having trouble getting any more people interested in it. 

Time to cut it there, they figured, we've made some money on this; let's wrap this up before we invest any more money into it. It turns out they were only planning on building a mansion. Planning! Obviously what we meant by that and what you thought were different things. Our apologies.

But no worries! You have full use of the two walls and tarp. We never got around to adding plumbing, though, or electricity. Also, there's this hobo who keeps trying to shiv people. Finally, uh, the site is contaminated by deadly radon gas, (interesting, because there isn't even a basement) and some of you may have progressive pulmonary fibrosis.

We'll leave a few nails and boards around, if someone wants to improve on things, though. Also, the president of the company is just as bummed about this as you guys are, except not really, because he's got a bit more money out of this deal!

Bottom line: This company has made some good games in the past, but not recently. Early access might work with small studios, but when you've got 60 plus people to support, it doesn't seem as financially viable... Especially when you repay the investors with the early access sales, before the game's even released!

I accept this risk for early access games, but this is the first time I came across a situation quite like this one. I was treating DF by the reputation they had built long ago, not by what they are now. Double Fine? More like Doesn't Finish! or, uh, Don't Fund, or whatever. Boo this company! Boooo!

column8:
I'm not really sure what to think about this game. It seems that there are still a lot of balancing issues in the game, making it very hard to play a single sustained station, and now that they've mentioned they're going to stop development on the game, after the next update, I don't think these things are going to get fixed.

It was a nice idea, while it lasted, and maybe it's even fun... All the same, I wouldn't recommend it as it seems most people who buy it regret it.

column8:
I have played the game in the last beta, and I have been very disappointed. There were numerous bugs that made entire sections of the space station unusable. I highly doubt they will truly fix all of the bugs in time. The amount of good will this has lost double fine is immeasurable. 

They're releasing the entire source code for the game shortly at which point there will undoubtedly be many fragmented free versions available. 

Absolutely, do not buy this abandonware. I can't even imagine where all the money went for this project. This isn't the first project from double fine where the money came up short. Perhaps this is their strongest trait in action: financial mismanagement. 

I honestly believe if they had continued working on this project for another year it could have been fantastic, but the plug was pulled.

They have posted their sob story on the forums, and now I have posted mine in the reviews.

column8:
Ignore the claims made on this games page: It is NOT version 1.0, it is Alpha 6.

This game WAS going to be glorious! It WAS going to be a testiment to why Early Access works as a promotion system, and the Double Fine let us down by abandoning this title while it was in ALPHA!!

This game had so much potential! It had so many great planned features but now they're probably never going to see the light of day. 
Because of "Funding Problems" Double Fine games has decided to stop production and release a stable version of an unfinished game and claim its a full game, it ISNT.

Double fine have lost a member of their fan-base with this one, I'm going to be steering clear of them in future, and suggest you do too!

column8:
A great concept squandered by mismanagement. The game is buggy and has extremely shallow gameplay.

I played the early prototype of this game that I got with HumbleBundle's Amnesia Fortnight bundle, I liked it the concept but it was clearly in very early stages. Sadly, what we have now is not very different, even though the graphics have been improved.

DoubleFine was looking to cash in on games like Prison Architect. They even said as much themselves. They got investors involved (and successfully paid them off with the huge volume of Steam customers) and then when it wasn't as hot as they wanted, they cut development, did some more sales to lure in a few more suckers and then pulled the plug. In that order.

Most of the people who hadn't bought it yet were waiting for beta or full release, but DoubleFine wanted to make all their money up front. Their business model for this title depended on it, and it is a flawed and presumptuous business model that screws over the consumer.

"Obviously, spending more money than we were making isnâ€™t something we can afford to do forever." - Tim Schafer

Considering that in traditional game development the developer puts in all the work up front, making the investment in themselves to deliver a great product. In this case, we, the consumer took all the risk. And they took none, while they never intended to deliver a full game if it wasn't a pre-release hit with a cult following. Does this sound like a sane sustainable business plan to you? Well, if it does, then congratulations your name is Tim. And Tim, we can't afford to keep spending money on products that never materialize.

I own Prison Architect and its a much more complete game, I recommend getting that instead. It lacks the character and personality of DF-9 and the setting and style is radically different, but its clear that they share the same underlying concept.

column8: Spacebase DF-9 is a fun interesting concept of a game, but unfortinitly that's all it will ever be. While what is in the game is fun the game is far from being a full game and will be released as such relying on modders to finish the game.  If this barely more then a prototype costed more around the $5-10 range then I would say its definitly worth picking up for that price even though it will never be a full game, but at a $25 price point I can not reccomend this game. Hopefully Doublefine doesn't keep with the trend they are on right now between this game being abandoned and who knows how long it will be untill the second half of Broken Age. Hack 'N Slash was pretty good, but I don't want to see Massive Chalice fall to the abandoned development that Doublefine seems to be doing because Massive Chalice looks like a interesting concept of mixing the reboot of XCom with having your soldiers inheirt good and bad traits (possibly just one side or the other depending on hidden dice rolls) from previous soldiers you retire.

column8:
The game has a UI that's pleasing to work with, and it carried big ideas and ambition. But the devs have abandoned it, dumping all the goals and going to 1.0 and asking the modders to carry it. Apparrently they've tried to emulate Dwarf Fortress while forgetting DF is developed by 2 people over the course of years and a major cult following to support them both. 

The best hope is that it goes open source and that modders do in fact save it, like with Cataclysm: DDA. But I don't think that will happen.

The game itself is amusing and fun for about an hour, but it's mired with game breaking bugs, and the difficulty curve is just... An endless swarm of raiders even on peaceful maps? Space junk just constantly hailing down on you? The fact 2 raiders can slaughter an entire base?

The bugs aren't even amusing like many in Dwarf Fortress. They're not ridiculous, they're just frustrating.

column8:
The game itself had so much promise, and due to the mismanagement of the dev team and lack of experience with the Early access model they have essentially decided to early realease the main 1.0 without many of the features promised. It's kind of like buying an all inclusive holiday including hotel and beach views, and then getting there and finding you have a window facing a wall and a room smelling of fish.

I understand where Double fine are coming from but in any other industry, if you preorder something and it doesn't deliver as promised, then trading standards get involved. As a consumer I don't think Early Access is providing enough protection agains fails like this. My question is this...why aren't Double Fine taking the hit for not delivering? Shouldn't they be made to finish this game to the extent of the content they advertised? Surely that is false advertising...and yes, I know they put something like "all features are prospective and not necessarily in the game" but in that case there need to be more rules goeverning Early access so we don't keep getting burned! :S

Still to find a mod that can fix the annoying gameplay in this game. The AI just feels broken and the game becomes unplayable at later stages. Updated Mar 2015.

column8:
I bought this game via greenlight thinking the developers were committed to providing the vision for the game. They stated themselves on their forum before Alpha 6.

"Double Fine is not a random fly-by-night indie dev and we are not going to silently pull the plug on Spacebase or any other in-development project. Doing so would be disastrous for our reputation and it would kill us emotionally" by JP LeBreton @ Double Fine.

Oh wait what has happened going from Alpha 6 to 1.0 Release without a Beta. It looks like the developers didnt realise greenlight didnt mean everyone would buy it pre-release and seemingly they have ran out of money. They are to release 1.0 soon so wait at least until that so you can find out what has actually made it into the game.

It is a shame because this was looking like a very good little game, but now its to be left to modders to finish. As I don't really have time to search for mods as I kind of play games quickly between jobs, this looks like I'll have to write-off this game as a loss.

See TotalBiscuits critique on the matter below.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gAd8Ls8Mwl4

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gAd8Ls8Mwl4

column8:
I was really excited about this game, I always wanted to get into Dwarf Fortress but I can't deal with the obtuse interface, so this looked great. As it is, you should buy Clockwork Empires instead.

I'm really disappointed that devs are abandoning this. I understand why, but they gave no indication that the game was running over budget before they suddenly pulled the plug. If you're going to link a game's development explicitly to sales, tell people, instead of pulling the rug out later from those who have invested in it.

column9:
Warning: Development is discontinued!

Alpha 6 will be turned into a full version, with a few patches and fixes, and that's it.

You can read about the mess again here:
http://steamcommunity.com/games/246090/announcements/detail/216494030200824180

Recommendation: Absolutely not.

For my part, I won't support any "Double Fine" game in the "Early Access" phase, and I don't know if I'll even buy another one from them.

column8:
Before I start. Isn't it a bit disgusting that Double Fine is the curator for their own project? 

Anyway it's a bare bones Space Building game in the vane of Dungeon Keeper, Theme Hospital and Startopia. You build stuff and people rather stupidly suffocate in Space because you can't give people a slight nudge in the right direction to avoid their terrible deaths. The AI is very stupid, and the Building is a very bare. Worse yet is how much DF are asking for, while it's not quite the price of a AAA title, it's by no means cheap either which is yet again is another reason to be critical because what you're buying doesn't add up to Â£20/$30 worth of content. And to add salt to a fatal wound? DF have decided to just straight up ignore Beta stage and release the game into 1.0, that's right a full version from Alpha where there's been a startling lack of updates throughout it's year of development. Poor show.

After the jump into V1.0, my impressions are still disappointing. The game is not fun to play, the citizens now know how to not suffocate stupidly but their prioties are extremely messed up. The UI is counter intuitive and really clumsy and hideous as a result, the game is unimpressive visually and you'll find that the game doesn't do enough to hold your attention. 

This is further signs that money should not be given to DoubleFine, a company who do not deliver on their promises.

column8:
This game is an example of how bad the Early Access model can be. The plan of the developer, Double Fine, was to fund the development from the start with the sales of the (prototype of the) game, reduce drastically their initial investment, and hope that their good name and promises on how they imagined the final game were enough to attract customers. The 'experiment' failed completely because most people interested in the game were holding their purchase to see how the developers were updating the game. It became a self-fulfilling prophecy of failure, in which due to the lack of sales the developers were not able to assign more efforts to the game and, at the same time, exactly that slow development was the reason behind the low amount of sales.

To come to an end to this grotesque scenario, Double Fine decided to stop the development and release the game as it is currently. The game is still in its bare bones and the experience is lacking in many areas, but they will create a tutorial, tools to create mods, and hope for a nonexistent community to continue its development.

About me: I've been a big fan of Double Fine games during the last years. I loved Psychonauts and Monkey Island, funded the Kickstarter of Broken Age and enjoyed other games like Costume Quest, Stacking or The Cave. This is the first dissapointment. It has destroyed the trust that I had in DF and, in the future, I will behave with them as if they are an unknown dev without credentials. I will investigate with caution about their games before buying or I will simply ignore them. Also, I won't buy any Early Access games and advice others to do the same.

column8:
Spacebase had the potential to be a cool game and I liked the concept. As of this writing (and I don't see myself opening it up again) I have 5.7 hours of gameplay over the course of development; that's about as much gameplay as you can squeeze out of it. Truth be told you can run through about all the game has to offer at this point in one two-hour sit down - and that's fine - but definitely not for $25.00. I think the price tag is what really bugs me and, personally, says a lot about the way the higher-ups at Double Fine truly feel about the whole situation. 

Yeah, the whole rush to 1.0 is a bit of a joke and there won't be much to the vanilla full game. But to have the audacity to charge $25.00 [i]in Early Access[/i]! And given that the time between now and its 1.0 release is mainly for bug fixing means you're not getting any more bang for your buck in terms of gameplay (i'm not sure a tutorial counts).

This game was gifted to me nearly a year ago and bought by the giver for about the price of a movie ticket. I got nearly 3 movies-worth out of it, so by that reckoning we're doing alright. That being said, I would be incredibly angry to have bought this for $25.00 only to find what the game holds (and more or less will hold at release). It all seems like "poor sportsmanship" on Double Fine's part. So your game lacks polish and contains less gameplay than some free Flash games; at least be honest about what it's worth. 

In any case, post-"release" sales performance will, over time, likely drive the price to where it should be...somewhere around $5.

column8:
The point this game was abandoned at left it with nothing. They claim they were operating at a loss producing the game, and that we can't expect them to produce a game from their own pockets. That is exactly how every game was made ten years ago. It's shamefull they undertook this with no plan for funding their own undertaking beyond taking our money and falling short.

The game itself is not worth anything. It is to buggy and predictable to play and recieve anything aside from frustration. It had enormous potential.

It may one day be something if dilligent modders shape the gutted husk it is. I feel bitter at the thought of others paying money to double fine for the sweat off the backs of talented modders. Better to donate money to such modders should they arise; and come by a copy in whatever means doesn't pay double fine for their lazy greed built folly.

On a side note pay them for their successes in other games, as they do many good titles.

column8:
Spacebase DF-9 really has great potential. And I cannot say that I squandered 9 hours of my life by playing the game, in fact I even had a good time. However, I have already exhausted all game play possibilites and all the content within that time - twice. Thus, it is highly disappointing that the developers decided to quit developing the game any further and have hitted the emergency exit button as of financial miscalculations by jumping from Alpha to full release by adding a tutorial, objectives and granting access to the source code (which is actually nice but even this cannot whitewash the feeling that I have paid money for a broken promise).

If you like management simulations (and space), I would recommend it only if it is on sale for 5-10â‚¬ / 10$. As for 23â‚¬ [Price of Early Access Version in October '14] I do not recommend buying DF-9.

column9:
As it stands, I can't recommend it.
The basic idea is excellent, but it feels like we're playing an alpha version.
Normally, I'm comfortable with bugs, but the fact that you always end up losing your entire base to three raiders when you have 60 settlers, simply because the settler AI is incapable of defending itself properly and prefers to run around screaming, is simply unbearable (the lack of saves doesn't make things any easier). To solve the problem, we were offered automatic turrets that take up an inordinate amount of space, look completely asthmatic, and are too easily destroyed.
There's still a lot of work to be done to make this game truly interesting; unfortunately, the developers seem to have moved on...

column8:
It was once a very promising pre-release title, great goals, great plans, sadly, thanks to the developer paying himself more than any normal developer earns (significantly more) and the typical miss-management that DoubleFine has become famous for the game ended up being far from what it could have achieved...

The promise was a Dwarf Fortress meets Startopia, a Dungeon Keeper in space with the "fun to fail" attitude that Dwarf Fortress brought to the building genre. What we got was a good and entertaining simulation that grows boring after a few hours, repetetive and chaotic. With too many downsides to really enjoy the game.

Simple things like not being able to rotate items, or not being able to place specific items on two of the four walls (either due to the inability to rotate, the lack of graphics for the other two walls or other design failures are not known). Or like not having a better control over what is done well...

If you like games like this, play Prison Architect instead, it already contains easily three times as much, and their developer is doing a great job. And it costs less... this game would be a nice game for ten bucks, and if it's on sale, pick it up. But for how much they want... hands off.

column8:
This game is a scam and should be removed from steam.

It's sad really, to see the route this game took. It seemed rather fun, even had great potential for what the devs were promoting it to be. However, I do not recommend anyone buys this game. 

Not only is this game overpriced for what you get, but there is no plan to finish the game. (although im not sure they intended to lose faith in the project)

The devs have basically announced they are cutting all funding to it, and are planning to release it as a finished game, even though its not. Why im sure its not intentional to fail in the development of the game, the fact they are gonna still release it as a finished project just screams "I dont care if i scam the uninformed out of there money".

In its current stage, its nothing more then a series of game breaking bugs, and the devs dont care if you throw money at it. None of the money will go into fixing the game. DONT BUY THIS GAME!

column8:
I always enjoyed playing this game.  I joined early access in this game...  

I remember the first Early access Game...  Kerbal Space Program.  I have a beleif that if you don't like the game in the current state the game is in during early access... Don't invest in the game.  If development of the game finished tomorrow and this was the last version of the game... Would you be happy with the current version ?  My answer for every one of the Early access games I have in my library,  Except one. 

Godus -  I bought the game when I was happy with how it looked. Now it is completely different.  Luckily I did not pay much for godus.

The Game has alot of Very good features, Admittedly the game does not have all the features the Developers would have wanted to add if they had the funds and future revenues to develop them.

At the end of the day. This is a very nice little game that works well and has a very nice look and feel.

column8:
Questa Ã¨ la mia prima recensione.Ci tenevo a farla per far sapere ai videogiocatori italiani qualcosa in piÃ¹ su questo titolo.
Un gioco che,almeno sulla carta,avrebbe potuto avere grandissime potenzialitÃ .
PotenzialitÃ  che,purtroppo,non sono state sfruttate a dovere.Anzi,in realtÃ  per niente!
Il gioco Ã¨ rimasto in versione alpha per circa 1 anno e in questo arco di tempo non ci sono stati significativi sviluppi se non piccolissimi miglioramenti,giusto per rendere il titolo un minimo giocabile.
Non esiste un tutorial e nemmeno una "storia"da seguire,cosa che a lungo andare(giÃ  dopo un'ora a dire il vero) rende il tutto veramente noiso.L'assenza di obiettivi rende il tutto davvero snervante ed Ã¨ un vero peccato visto che se la Double Fine avesse fatto almeno un decimo di quello promesso sarebbe stato davvero un titolone!
Ultima nota proprio sulla casa sviluppatrice(per modo di dire)del gioco.
Sono stati davvero una delusione.Io come tanti ho acquistato il gioco appena reso disponibile su steam ed ho speso una bella somma,quindi sentirmi dire a distanza di circa 1 anno che non ci sono fondi e che lasciano il gioco in questo stato mi fÃ  parecchia rabbia e di sicuro non acquisterÃ² altri titoli della DF.
Dovrebbero vergognarsi e restituire i soldi spesi a tutti.Ora come ora questo Ã¨ un gioco da non pagare piÃ¹ di 5 euro.
Vergogna!
Peccato...
column9:
This is my first review. I wanted to write it to let Italian gamers know more about this title.
A game that, at least on paper, could have had enormous potential.
Potential that, unfortunately, wasn't fully exploited. Actually, not at all!
The game remained in alpha version for about a year, and in that time there were no significant developments other than very small improvements, just to make the title at least minimally playable.
There is no tutorial or even a "story" to follow, which in the long run (after an hour, to be honest) makes the whole thing really boring. The lack of objectives makes the whole thing really unnerving, and it's a real shame, since if Double Fine had done even a tenth of what they promised, it would have been a truly great title!
A final note on the game's developer (so to speak).
They were truly a disappointment. Like many others, I bought the game as soon as it was released on Steam and spent a considerable sum, so hearing about a year later that they're out of funds and leaving the game in this state makes me very angry, and I definitely won't be buying any more DF titles.
They should be ashamed and refund everyone's money. Right now, this is a game you shouldn't pay more than 5 euros for.
Shame!
What a shame...

column9:
It has good ideas and is fun for a while; it certainly could have been a good little game.
Unfortunately, development was halted in the middle of Early Access, leaving the game unfinished with many missing features.
It's a shame that a workshop integration wasn't even added as "compensation," so that the game could at least have been "further developed" through mods.

It's a shame, unfortunately.

column8:
The game is going into release 1.0 after only 6 alpha updates. These alpha updates introduced pitifully small features/updates, and in comparision to other early access games like Prision Architect (currently in alpha 26 likely to be more) . Prision Architect updated the game every single month in some way, adding valuable features or spending a whole month working on bugs. 

Double fine claims they recaptured all their initial investment (400K) within two weeks http://indie-fund.com/2013/11/spacebase-df-9-recoups-investment-in-two-weeks/ 

Yet they release this clearly not complete game with a sticker of 1.0 slapped on.

EDIT:

Derelict Games have unofficially edited the original source code to introduce new features bug fixes etc. Go here to download - http://www.spacebasehub.net/download/

column8:
As an early access game, DF9 was decent. There was definable progress. I'll admit it, it was fun. There were bugs, and early access gripes, but the EA rule I use is that "As long I can visualize this being finished, done, and fun, I can consider spending money on it." DF9 met those criteria. However, as the game has moved abruptly to a "release", and with the complete stoppage of new features, Double Fine has fallen far, far short of even approaching their planned development milestones. Further, the lack of believable rationales, detailed explanations, or even breakdowns about why this came about mean that I can't in good faith recommend that you purchase this game, or any future titles from Double Fine productions until some form of publically disclosed management shakeup takes place. 

They reportedly raised approximately half a million dollars to develop this game. They then stopped development, citing financial reasons. They do not appear to have then offered any breakdown of where said money went. They are now confused, as people are angry and asking "WHERE DID THAT MONEY GO!?" The statements I have reviewed do not appear to show that this logical connectoin has been made.

The final nail in the coffin was a "AWESOME DEV PROCESS GREAT JOB" timeline that was issued as a "We're sorry we took your money, but don't pay attention to the archived feature lists we pumped for months about what we were going to do, instead read this sleek graphic that shows what we DID do! JUST DONT COMPARE THE TWO!" Their conduct in this and other products leads me to the following unfortunate conclusion regarding Double Fine Productions:

They simply are not a worthwhile investment for your consumer dollars. This is not the first time this endgame has come about for one of their product. That is not to say Double Fine is an intrinsically bad company, or that they cannot make good games. But I simply cannot justify spending money on early access titles from them now or in the future.

At this point, Double Fine serves as an argument for Valve to more or less micro-audit game development companies, even basic indie ones, for management practices. Whether that is feasible or a correct response is a different matter, but Double Fine's performance definitely elicits that reaction. That or open up a "Developer Review" page to trash talk developers (This would also be a bad idea, but it is my inclination in response). 


A more reasonable option would be for Valve to construct a form of "Warning Stick" that it can publically shake at developers who mis-behave in such a fashion. A "We're reviewing their sales agreement" or "We're considering yanking their priviledge to post on early access" type of statement, to remind developers that Early Access is not a kickstarter equivalent, but is rather an opportunity to generate interest and feedback on your products.

column8: I tried, I really did. It sold me on "Dwarf Fortress in space," and the initial round of bugs were survivable (even if my station did frequently end up knee-deep in my citizens' corpses). But now we're going straight to release with a whole lot of bugs unfixed and features unimplemented, and that isn't what I paid for this game for. Wish I could get my money back on this one.

column8:
Do not buy. Incomplete game that has been abandoned. 

Loved it when I first got it, and was loving the updates (though slow) that were coming in for this game. But now the company has pulled the plug leaving the game far from what they had promised. Double Fine was a developer that I thought I could trust because they had made good games before. I really trusted them, and they let me down big time. I am extremely disappointed with the whole thing, and will not be second guessing everything they put out for a long time coming.

column8: What a joke that they cite not enough initial support as the main cause of abandonment. If you ask me, the outrageously high Early Access price ($25+) was in and of itself the primary deterrent for shoppers. I've learned my lesson now, and don't intend on purchasing any more Early Access games, and certainly never any other DoubleFine products, again unless they offer some kind of partial refund. This game is practically unplayable on a Mac; there are just far too many graphics glitches and various bugs. In the right hands, this could have been a "game-changer," but now it's nothing more than an utter waste of money. If it keeps dropping in price and hits the $1 marker, then MAYBE consider buying it... Maybe.

A sense of unfinished business for this early access game catapulted to a disastrous 1.0 release.
Lemming AI, poor balancing, a lousy interface, and bugs galore. Double fine, double nothing.
Starting projects is good, finishing them is better, and not trusting yourself is a necessity from now on.

column8:
UPDATE: The game is basically "Beta" now. 

From the release of 1.0 there were no new features added. They finally fixed the 3FPS that plagued linux/mac OS, but the game now randomly crashes.  The AI when building will get stuck in walls regularly. Have to close and re-open to fix. This hasn't been fixed from alpha 6. Two months ago.

 The tutorial is complete crap. There is no audio queues and it is VERY uniformitive. All they did was have text on the bottom and hope the random event generator triggers what to do next. 

Crew members will walk back and forth until they die - refusing to either fix/build oxygen supplies.  There is  no way to keep track of power usage.  Just build until you run out of power. THAT WAY when something breaks you'll be completely screwed.

Proximity to the warpgate things don't make any difference on how much spam you have to put up with for people constantly trying to join your base. 

Everything I listed has been a problem since alpha 5/6. No fix. All they did was just plop on some text call it a tutorial and fix the 3FPS issue for linux/mac.

Don't buy. Complete scam.

Below is my original review.




Early access linux backer. (Same review would thereby apply to Mac to some degree)

Game is in last Alpha stage. They are moving to have it be labled as "1.0", aka finished. However. The game is completely unplayable in linux and barely works (from what I understand) in mac. There is no support here for it, and the developer is just claiming "modders will fix it", and we have to rely on the developer to test the game themselves, when, after this lastest aplha stage, TWO platforms that are supposed to be supported do not work. 

Do not buy this game. It is completely unfinished, and will likely not even work on your system due to lack of testing in development. They have completely skipped beta stage of development.

column8:
Game works but is prone to odd glitches like losing oxygen or bad AI for the citizens inhabiting your station. Once you've built everything there is nothing left to do as there are no objectives, its a sand box. It could be better with updates but since the developer is pulling the plug on that, there won't be any more updates. AI doesn't act in a reasonable way and a small group of two or three raiders can wipe out your crew of 50+ guys due to a lack of just being able to effect  AI  citizens to react. It's just not finished, half baked is more appropriate. It looks good, had potential but inside its still a nasty surprise to find out it's not cooked all the way through. 

Production chains are a 1, 2 step process with no real meaningful payoff. Items may or may not build/demolish and random "derelect" spawns clutter up space with unusable nonsense as "salvaging" them is a chore. If there are bugs, the development team is leaving and won't be around to fix them. As a final product this thing is only something an enthusiast of the genre looking specifically for a space station to run would like. Even then, there are better complete games available that will fill that desire. At best this game is average but will likely let you down.

Developers don't do this for the money, they don't get the lions share of it, the investors do. They do it out of a passion and love to create games. Ultimately looking for that big break that garners them adoration and accolades. They won't be getting that here. Unleashing this deformed beast onto the world is a disservice to customers and a cross that will haunt the programmers for years to come unless they really are just the shills forums claim them to be. 

Do not buy unless you want to take a big risk.

column9:
Spacebase DF-9 isn't even a game.

It's barely the bare bones of a game idea.

But here's the thing: the money went on coke and hookers. Doublefine is incapable of managing a project. Doublefine thinks that Early Access, just the sales, allows them to create a miniature Dwarf Fortress from scratch.

And to make sure it's a success and the suckers don't notice anything, they've deleted the feature list from their website, so they can confuse you without anyone noticing.

Surprise, assholes: accounting and the Wayback Machine for dummies.

NO game is capable of going from alpha *6* to release 1.0 in a month. NONE.

Don't buy it; it's so incomplete it's enough to make you cry. In fact, do better than that: avoid Doublefine Early Access like the plague. Invest in Dwarf Fortress. It'll be better for everyone. Really.

column8:
The game is a broken mess right now, and incomplete, and production has been stopped by DoubleFine because it's losing money for them. Which is a good reason, but it doesn't give everyone thir money back, and it doesn't make this a finished product.

Don't buy this. You'll have fun for thirty minutes before the broken shit makes you want to stop playing.

I'd also recommend you never again buy a DoubleFine product, despite their history of putting out good games, because this is an insulting turn of affairs and a slap to the face for their supporters, but that decision is up to you. I know I won't be buying any DoubleFine products ever again.

column8:
Plenty of people have already said this, but more voices never hurt: do not buy this game. It has been pushed from an ALPHA build to 1.0 in ONE UPDATE because the developers ran out of money. The game is mediocre at best - I managed to get almost thirty hours of fun out of it, but I really love this genre. It feels like a hamburger without cheese. You can enjoy it, but the entire time you feel like something essential is missing. 

Paying 25 dollars for a less than half-finished management game that still suffers from issues it had in the first build ever released (people forgetting to get out of their spacesuit in an airlock and suffocating, panicking when there's low oxygen and running until they choke instead of building more oxygen generators, trying to stomp out fires when there are extinguishers nearby) is a joke. Spend your money on the unfortunately-named RimWorld instead.

column8:
Early access brings the unfortunate risk of being burned and this game is the first one to have burned me badly enough to write a negative review. 

First of all, this is practically a demo that absolutely does not capture what makes this genre "fun". Generally the interesting thing about base building games is not about how you can create a utopia where nothing goes wrong, but how your base will eventually come to its inevitable end. 

Spacebase DF-9 fails to spark any continued enjoyment because of how quickly one can create a stable base without having to worry about anything bad ever happening. One playthrough was all it took to figure out all the kinks for the next time, where it is entirely possible to reach a state where everything simply balances itself out. This can be attributed to the fact that the game has a very [b]short[/b] list of features.

The [b]short[/b] list of rooms have an incredibly [b]short[/b] list of items one can add to it, so constructing a base on the second playthrough provides almost the exact same experience. It is not surprising how shallow this game feels compared to other games from the genre, even before you are hit by the realization that the learning curve is really just a horizontal line.

The random events and the citizens "dynamic" behavior do not add a lot of variety, which is something that also quickly realized as you build your base. Understanding the patterns of the [b]short[/b] list of events the game throws at you does not take a lot of figuring out, which is not surprising given the fact that you can count these on one hand. To make things even worse, any negative event that can happen is easily preventable with the aforementioned [b]short[/b] list of items at your disposal. 

The only challenging element this game presents, is the incredibly stupid AI that is set on destroying itself as early as building the very first airlock for the base. God help them if they are apart of your mining crew and there happens to be two airlocks to your base, because they are more likely to asphyxiate in space than they are picking which one is closer so they do not die.

Again, all these negative aspects can be attributed due to the fact that this title is feature [b]INCOMPLETE[/b] and will probably remain so, unless it builds a decent modding community (which is incredibly unlikely to happen given the current state). The keyword here is [b]short[/b], as in the feature list, the amount of time this game was given development time until its "full" release, and any enjoyment you can get out of it.

I would be lying if I said I had never been so disappointed by a game before, but certainly not with a game that I was so excited to see completed. In the end I, and several other hopefuls lost out on $20-25 on a game that will never be finished. And while they did not lie to us about "silently pulling the plug", but they certainly lied about delivering us a "complete" game. With them violating my trust, I will never be purchasing another early access title or Double Fine game ever again.

column8: Do not buy this game. Although the release is technically 1.06, this is actually a facade to disguise the fact that Double Fine added a tutorial and some bugfixes following the release of Alpha 6D. There was never a beta, so the already content-sparce game was never very well optimized or balanced, which becomes extremely clear after a playthrough or two. The artstyle is very interesting and arguably beautiful, reminding me of wonderful games like Bastion, but a pretty paintjob doesn't mask the unfinished nature of the Spacebae DF-9. If you like the look and concept of this game, a group of settlers colonizing  a scifi environment, I reccomed a look at Rimworld by Tynan Sylvester. It is very similar, but obviously has a lot more work put into it. In the interest of full disclosure, I do not have a financial interest in either of these games. The modders with which Double Fine entrusted the game played it and then realized that Rimworld is a (subjectively) better game, which is why I can not find a single mod for DF-9 and the modding community for Rimworld is thriving. But the music is nice.

column8:
DF9 was a disaster waiting to happen. And now it has done just that.

I was surprised by how "polished" this game looked back when I first played it in one of the first alphas. The graphics and animations looked a lot more "expensive" than in similar games (mostly because they seem to be using 3D for everything while other games just use simple 2D sprites often with barely any animation), even the UI felt a bit overengineered.

At the same time the releases rarely addressed game-breaking bugs (e.g. airlocks being death traps) and frequently added seemingly arbitrary features that didn't really improve the gameplay other than giving players more bugs to worry about. I guess the project could be described as ambitious, but then again the same would be true for games like Prison Architect and Rimworld, both of which have been able to maintain some level of consistent narrative over a large number of releases (without needing to re-release every single version several times to provide hotfixes).

Some reviewers have said DF made the mistake of treating a supposedly indie, crowd-funded project as if it were another big team big publisher triple-A title. I don't think anyone but the DF9 team can answer that, but it seems telling that a game that was already funded with half a million dollars within the first weeks of the open alpha and that was intended to be entirely financed by pre-release purchases/"backers" has managed to drain its entire budget within only six major releases. If the game needs more than this kind of cash just to make it to 1.0-as-intended, maybe DF shouldn't have attempted to follow through with this idea. If you're burning money, either find a potent investor who doesn't care, or cut down your development costs to a level where you can bootstrap the project without making f-you money.

To quote Robot Unicorn Attack: "Your dreams did not come true."

column9:
A red card for Double Fine, who is taking us for fools by abruptly cutting off development of the game to announce that it's finished and will be released very soon. Is this a joke?
The game clearly had potential, with a really nice interface for a game of this genre and ideas that have already been seen but are well implemented. However, as it stands, its lack of content is clearly staggering, and it doesn't make for a decent builder. It still needs a lot of work to make it a truly interesting game.
I will no longer back Double Fine games; their way of betraying the trust of the players who supported this game by palming them off with something half-finished is unbearable.
I presented the game here on my channel:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SAKzI-k9n6c&index=49&list=PLE0mBNzs5vu-1o6ng0vQExgR7oI0-LL--

Of course, I could be wrong. Perhaps they have some hidden treasure trove of unreleased code that contains the laundry list of unimplemented features and bug fixes. They never finished this game, instead abandoning it with no support, major bugs and missing features. A very good reason to never trust early access, and to ignore anything Double Fine says.

column8:
After having been in development for over a year and still sitting in alpha state, DoubleFine is about to release this incredibly incomplete game as "complete" and be done with it. This is a slap to the face for anybody that purchased this game and to long fans of DoubleFine in general. Aviod this "game" at all costs and seriously consider all options before purchasing any other DoubleFine title in the future.

UPDATED: Post "release" the game still contains crippling AI bugs and incomplete content. The game is still incomplete at its core. AVOID AT ALL COSTS.

column8:
Never thought I'd not recommend a product from Double Fine Productions. 
Spacebase DF-9 has  a very interesting concept behind it. Even in Early Access I had my 
fun, besides some very screwy bugs. But that's to be expected. Lots of features weren't
implemented, so it only could get better!

But, no big monthly updates as promised. And now suddenly they pull the plug and will
just slap 1.0 on it and 'yeah!' a release has been born!

Which is really a kick in the nuts for every one showing faith in them to give money already
in Early Access stage. 

Early Access isn't supposed to be a risk and isn't supposed to be funding model at all. 
But it was used by DF that way. Gambled and lost. Investors got money back.
We are left behind with an empty shell of a game.

So nope, don't bother with this game at all.

column8:
The game is buggy and the gameplay is weak. I bought it as Early Access to support the developers, but they've just announced that they're going to fix up what bugs remain (which is a lot) and just ship it as version 1.0... then never update it again.

There are base management mechanics in place, but there is no interplay: everything kinda operates as a stand-alone system, so there's very little to do but boring mechanical tasks. You'll run out of content in about 5 hours. The AI is awful: the last time I played (a week ago? 2?) I lost 10 people because they all crowded into a tiny outpost away from my main base and suffocated to death instead of just leaving through the airlock.

It was a mining outpost. There was nothing in there but an incinerator. There was no reason to go there, and even less to stay, but...

Well, that's Spacebase DF-9 in a nutshell. There's no reason for anything.

It's not worth the current price, $24.99. If you can get it for a fiver, then it's probably worth that.

Or hey, maybe I'm wrong and a Christmas Miracle will happen and this game will suddenly become amazing when it hits 1.0.

column8: Cheated. One word to describe how i feel after the deveolpers ended development of this game. It was a fun game i did enjoy it but between the bad AI and the bad deveolpers cheating us out of what we paid for. we was promised many things for this game many of which we never got and now they are ending with an unfinished game for us to finish and they want us to pay 24.99 to play this game thats like paying for a cheeseburger at Mc.donalds and they only give you part of it you have to finish the rest yourself you cant pull something off like that. if it had a cheaper price and didnt rob me of my money for what i was promised i would recomend it for it can be fun at times but definetly not fun enough to justify the money it costs. I will never support another game by Double Fine.

column8:
The biggest waste of potential I've seen in a very long time.  The game itself, while incomplete and a buggy mess was addictive and fun and looked forward to every new update, though they came slowly.  Now that the devs are pushing for a 1.0 release in October then discontinuing production and leaving it up to modders to attempt to 'finish' their game for them is disgraceful.

Do not buy this game and do not support any other/future Double Fine productions; this was the biggest slap in the face to their fans and supporting customers.

column8:
This game is no longer genuinely under active development.

Development over the last year was too slow, and pre-release testing has been very poor with a great many game-breaking bugs on each released alpha - for example, the current build is almost unplayable due to panic spirals.

On the 17th Sept DF said that it's getting a month of bugfixing and that's The End.

Unfortunately I have very little confidence that the 1.0 release will be playable.

column8:
All you need to know:
Double Fine has cut development since the revenue isn't covering the development costs, completely unacceptable. Double Fine is not some small indie developer, they're an established studio which should have no problem spending some money developing the game to then see profit when it's done.
Alpha 7 will be released as 1.0. At this stage the Alpha does show plenty of potential but it is nowhere near a complete game.

If Double Fine gets wisens up and resumes development, great, if not, you should stay away from this 'game' no matter how much you like the genre or what potential you see unless maybe you happen to catch it on sale for at most â‚¬5.

column8: DO NOT BUY. Not worth the Â£19 you'll pay for it, it's unfinished to a huge degree with the AI being brain donors incapable of simple tasks, half of the promised features cut (after a budget over 8 times greater than what they asked for) and other issues regarding polish and gameplay in general, maybe pick it up on sale after a couple years, but not now. DoubleFine did a Towns, and squandered a huge budget barely getting the game halfway through alpha then slapping a "version 1.0" label onto it.

column9:
So, Far Frontier Space Base 9. Welcome!

The game's descriptions often describe it as a space base simulator and a sandbox. Don't believe those people, they haven't played it. DF-9 is The Sims in space.

The game is a bit rough around the edges, looks unfinished, but it doesn't crash. The main drawback is the extremely limited content. Furniture and clothing are missing, you see. :)

The second major drawback is the game's lack of purpose, which is why it's considered a sandbox.

At first, when there are six inhabitants on the base and every raider is trying to hurt you, it seems like there's plenty of room to grow and do something. But after just five hours, you'll have twenty-five people on your team, and life gets a bit boring. Killbots will still be too difficult to kill, and everyone else too easy... However, you can restart the game in a more challenging area, where raiders attack more frequently, and peaceful travelers looking to find a new homeâ€”and a breath of fresh airâ€”arrive less frequently at your base... Okay, so instead of twenty people, you'll have fifty. It won't change anything fundamentally.

The game begins with you having to build a small space house for three people, and you have eight minutes to do it before the characters' air supply runs out. You also have to make do with a fairly limited number of materials. Excessive room space can suddenly give you a hard time... and you'll have to start over. And more than once. In my opinion, this is the game's main challenge, which is disappointing. But I don't recommend reading tutorialsâ€”it'll be completely uninteresting!
It wouldn't hurt to read the wiki on the developers' website (later, after you've built the house), but it's a bit outdated, and that's also disappointing.

It's not all doom and gloom, though. I think the developers will eventually add the missing features. In any case, I liked it.

I have to say I'm disappointed.  I like the concept.  I liked the UI, which is brilliant.  I liked the simplistic challenge with random encounters.  I also like the devolper who is known to make good games with a weird twist.

But there are never updates, the bugs are crash worthy.

Early access is going to be the death of the indie dev scene.

column8:
While it appeared promising on launch to the Early Access register, already having the framework for a novel and engaging space-station based administration/colony game, this Early Access title is now one of many that have failed to achieve even a half of their potential, and is instead being rushed into 'full' release and obscurity.

The game's feature list has been aggresively pruned, and while the ones which remain there are not outright fabrications, they are misleading as to the scope and function the current game has. I'd advise caution towards any of DoubleFine's releases in future, as the end product may be subject to extreme and massive change, or be unduly delayed as development drags on and stagnates in favour of more profitable ventures.

column8:
http://youtu.be/TH_L0-q7jiI

This is a great start on the game so far. It can be a lot of fun, or really frustrating, but overall a satisfying experience if you are into roguelike games... and can handle some bugs that absolutely will kill you when they happen. Development of the game is a bit slow, but it's steady. I'm definitely a supporter of the game, and I definitely recommend it... so long as you're patient enough to deal with such an unforgiving game.

I don't think it will ever be an *easy* game, but due to some current bugs it can be overbearingly hard. The above video is the longest living base I've built so far. I played about an hour longer after the end of this video, and probably could have kept playing indefinitely... but due to some kind of bug my technicians just refused to do any serious work to repairing the base, and I got fed up with it. I've played a few more games since then, but most games don't last longer than an hour. When you do get that one game like this though, it can really make it feel like it's all worth it.

column8: The most expensive abandonware you can buy. An incomplete, uninteresting mess that DF will never finish, but has no issue continuing to charge us for. Hopefully the modding community will make something out of the game, as it has a lot of potential. Check back in a year or so.

column8:
This is a fun, engaging, albeit incredibly incomplete game. I was an early adopter, with high hopes. The premise is fun, and the soundtrack is fantastic. However, Following the recent rushed release as Double fine decided to no longer continue development due to costs, i was incredibly disappointed. While i understand the decision was one driven by financials which is understandable, it does serve to highlight just how much of a failure early access has turned out to be.

Double fine has said they will make the game fully moddable and that they would release the source code, so who knows! The community may step in and polish this rugged gem into something beautiful... Or they might not. Until we see what happens on this front, i cannot recommend this game.

column8:
From the premise, and the fact I love spacegames, I saw about the alpha of this game and got it very early on. It has a generally good idea behind it and an interesting / old isometric look. The first few alpha versions where pretty rough, such as having 9 technitions who refuse to fix anything beyond 20-25% and then eventually the base kills them due to everything breaking at once and four of them just /have/ to play their future ipad as everyone's O2 is used up.

There was a lot of good work that could have been done and if this /had/ a beta phase I'd probably have reccomended it to a good amount of my friends who enjoy spacey like things. However now it's going to be released as 1.0 with no beta, from like 6 updates in alpha for a 25 dollar game of which it's no longer profitable to work on. Another example of Early Access only working as far as the dev wants, and then slaps 1.0 and releases it.

column9:
This game could have been a hit.
Unfortunately, further development was halted beforehand.
I advise everyone not to buy this game; you're throwing your money away.
While the engine is stable, the AI â€‹â€‹is unfortunately only at alpha level, and most of the planned elements haven't been implemented yet.
The game is currently still in alpha (early access), but DF has announced that it will jump from alpha 0.6 to release 1.0 in the next few weeks.
A few bugs will be fixed before release, and that'll be it. DF no longer plans to develop it further.

column8:
Supposed to be like "DF in space", instead you'll get a very simplestic game that you'll be done with after a few hours. It had potential and was only an alpha, but they've announced that this is all there is to it and they're releasing as version 1.0 soon.

There is no game here. There is an incomplete tech demo. 
Avoid it. Unless you enjoy the feeling of regret and buyer's remorse, don't buy or gift this.

And to the people who thought they could finance a game entirely on early access sales. You're a bunch of fools. But hey, if you believed that would work I have shares to a banana plantation at Antarctica I can sell you, just send me a message!

Edit: Yep. Early access is gone. This is now the full version
It's nothing. Don't bother.

column8:
Frankly, avoid this game.

I bought into the Early Access alpha version of this game because at the time I looked forward to the initial concept of the game as advertised and had faith in Double Fine, developers notorious for several well-received cult classics including Psychonauts and Brutal Legend (controversial but in my opinion a very underrated game), to complete it on-schedule and more or less in a finished form of the advertised concept.

It seems apparent, that with the sudden push from 0.6 Alpha to 1.0 Release, that this will not be the case. From my experience, the game as-is is interesting but very buggy and sorely lacking in features. The base-building is somewhat simplistic, which, while partially due to the visual format of the game, is not enough to keep me interested in it. The AI for both friendly and enemy NPCs is very glitchy, hard to control and frankly suicidal at times. The user interface is clunky, incomplete and apparently designed for touchscreen support at the expense of UI size. The game has fullscreen support bugs, occasionally crashes without warning and lacks a tutorial.

Resource management is laughably simplistic, relying simply on the presence of basic station necessities (walls, furniture, life support, matter refineries, etc.) and NPCs in enough of a quantity to satisfy some invisible mysterious ratio (with the exception of oxygen/life support-based crew capacity, this is prominently displayed on the user interface, a very good thing). 

The long-term gameplay suffers when you take into account that there's a very finite amount of natural resources (called matter in-game) with which to build infrastructure and feed NPCs, which means you generally have to rely on proper choice of starting location in order to ultimately dictate how long you'll be able to keep your base going and how much harassment from raiders you'll get. In my opinion there's something wrong with the game when raider attacks are a promising sign of long-term survival after a certain point.

If derelicts are part of your chosen starting location, then, yes, ostensibly I could see you breaking them down for matter for self-preservation, perhaps indefinitely, but I have yet to succeed at this, either due to a lack of experience or simply because it takes too long, I don't actually know personally because it's completely up to the AI-controlled crew NPCs to do this after the order's given. 

NPC deaths (which happen often, due to only security officers being capable of self-defense if I recall correctly, and hardly capable at that) affect nearly the entire crew's morale directly and drastically and how useful they are in performing their tasks. This is apparently impossible to remedy (again, I may be mistaken). 

Even beyond these problems there's just not all that much to do, just survive as long as possible and assign new/current NPCs to station tasks and watch them utterly fail to perform them. Or starve to death because they can't find their way to the cantina because they're depressed and oversleeping. Or open up an interior door into a hallway with an oxygen leak and asphyxiate. Or catch themselves on fire and avoid several nearby, conveniently placed fire extinguishers, relying on other NPCs to actually see that their compadres are on a painful path from the psych ward to the burn ward and put them out. This all creates a bit of a death spiral for the NPCs, which is an interesting but infuriating and uncontrollable part of Dwarf Fortress, a game which Spacebase: DF-9's apparently inspired by.

To Double Fine's benefit, survival was one of the game's main selling points. Sadly, in its current state and potential state when released in 1.0, this may be impossible, or indeed, utterly futile and pointless to attempt from the outset.

Hopefully the game will improve once "mod support" is implemented, but it shouldn't take mod support for basic implementation of features and bugfixes to occur. 

It seems like the general consensus is that the game has been abandoned. I'd disagree with that verdict and give the developers the benefit of the doubt if it weren't so d**n obvious. 

Double Fine, you know better than this. "Big Ambitions, Broken Dreams" indeed.

column9:
Spacebase DF-9 is launching early. Many promised features aren't included. For an Early Access game, this is a slap in the face. For the price of â‚¬22.99, nothing is included. I bought the game back then for 50% off. As it stands, it's not even worth â‚¬11.50. The code will be released, but how many people will build something for this game?

I'm very disappointed. The game's premise is good, but there's just not enough in it at the moment.
For the full price of around â‚¬23, I expect a comprehensive indie game (as in the past), but that's not what you get here.

column8: Originally billed as Dwarf Fortress in space, Devs said"well here is the game engine, have fun" and quit.    As crazy as it sounds, this game is actually LESS complete than Towns, which until now was the poster child for dev abandoned early access game.    External funding + kickstarter + humble bundle + Early access = a ton of money wasted in San Francisco coffee shops and a game 15-20% feature complete being released as a finished product.

column8:
This could have been a fun an interesting game if there was anything to do with your base after the first hour or so. Instead, you will just run out of material to mine and slowly watch your base die.

Or quickly, depending on the raiders.

Unfortunatly, the developers rather surprisingly have seemed to have just given up completely on the game, rushing it to version 1.0 even though there isn't even a reasonable end game experiance. If they actually added everything they were planning, it might have been interesting. However, as is, it's simply not worth the surprisingly high cost. While the gameplay that is there is fairly strong and enjoyable to play, there's simply not enough for $25, and it looks like there never will be.

Long story short, avoid this game at its current price. If you see it on a massive (like, selling for less than $5) sale, maybe try it, but honestly, there's really not much here, and certainly very little replayability. If you want a base building game but aren't neckbearded enough for Dwarf Fortress, try out Gnomoria instead. It controls like a potatoe and is pretty hard to get into, but there's also a lot more gameplay to be had, and for a third the price.

It controls like a potatoe and is pretty hard to get into, but there's also a lot more gameplay to be had, and for a third the price.

column8: DF-9 is a warning against early access.  Priced as a full price game while being a barely functioning early alpha - and when the high price for little content and even less functioning content failed to bring interest and money the project is dropped.  This game is a lot like your initial crew members, suffocated before they had a chance, and their corpses pitifully floating around as a reminder of your failure.
