column8:
"Hey guys, this game we haven't released yet isn't making a profit, I guess we should just stop development on it and cut our losses."

- Double fine

Yes, A sci-fi dungeon builder, an almost spiritual successor to dungeon keeper, a dream come true. Turned to nightmare.

Development was actually coming along nicely, they added some good features over the past year and I was really starting to get excited for this game.

Now, straight from Alpha Early Access to 1.0 and dropped by developers into the "capable hands of modders." Yes, because obviously double fine's attention span leaves them unable to keep a game in development until completion. Now I'm worried about Massive Chalice, and Broken Age is looking badly too.

I would avoid this one with extreme prejudice.

This is something I could had lived with as the game still is in early alpha releases (though they use ages to push out a new update), had it not been for the fact that the alpha version is due to be rebranded as version 1, and development abandoned.

Do not buy this game as it currently sits!

column8: War bisher mit Early Access und Crowdfunding Produkten im grossen und ganzen zufrieden, wahrscheinlich auch durch meine Ã¼berlegte Auswahl was ich nun nehme, beobachte oder abweise. Spacebase DF-9 stellt sich aber als absolute EnttÃ¤uschung raus. Anfangs gabs immer wieder neuen Content und updates. Und nun hÃ¶rt man von den Devs nur noch das mit anderen worten der Hype um das Spiel nicht gross genug war um die BÃ¼ros in San Francisco zu tragen. Bin stolz darauf das mein Geld den Devs sicherlich 10 Minuten aus den BÃ¼rofenstern sehen ermÃ¶glicht hat. Doch in Zukunft, seid kritisch mit Crowdfunding und Early Access titeln. Ein vermeintlicher Diamant kann sich von nah als ein StÃ¼ck Kohle herausstellen.
column9: I've been generally satisfied with Early Access and crowdfunding products so far, probably also due to my careful selection of what I accept, watch, or reject. Spacebase DF-9, however, is turning out to be a complete disappointment. Initially, there was always new content and updates. And now all I hear from the developers is that, in other words, the hype surrounding the game wasn't big enough to support the offices in San Francisco. I'm proud that my money at least gave the devs a 10-minute view out of their office windows. But in the future, be critical of crowdfunding and Early Access titles. A supposed diamond can turn out to be a lump of coal up close.

column8:
A cute little game that had potential to be good. It was basically a small space colony simulator. I'd say it does have potential for some hours of play, but once you've made a well functioning base there's nothing else to do really.

The game has bugs and gameplay issues and has recently been abandoned by the developers; shoved out the nest unable to properly fly. At best the development company is incompetent with time and money, and at the worst they are liars and thieves. Possibly both.

Right now it's $24.99 on Steam. Is it worth the money? Not in the least. Go download Dwarf Fortress for free and you'll be much happier.

Such a shame that this game never lived up to its potential. Jumping from Alpha 0.6 to release because Double Fine ran out of funding was a massive shock, and means a lot of features are not being implemented and the game is rife with bugs. 

I would not recommend buying the game in the state they've decided to release it in (even with promised bug fixes) as it is quite limited in terms of features and gameplay. Personally I would not call this a 'complete' game, and people should be aware of this before buying the final version for a staggering Â£18.99.

column8:
Its impossible to recommend this piece of junk game. in its current state its practically unplayable, no tutorial, no idea what most people are doing and just generally confusing.

Now, however double fine have decided to pull a sneaky one and halt development in a month. The game will be given a tutorial system, thats all. no new content, nothing. The company behind this game are scammers, they take 25 dollars for a game that shouldnt even be 5, promise to keep updating (the store page used to have hundreds of upcoming features, now they're all gone) but then stop at alpha 6, skip beta and say "Heres your final game, but we'll release the source code so you can mod." Whats the point of modding a piece of garbage game like this? It will never be 'finished' and they have broken laws in several countries by releasing it in this state.


TL;DR DONT BUY THIS, IT IS UNFINISHED AND WILL NEVER BE FINISHED (1.0 Releasese next month and then development will stop!)

column8:
This game was billed as Dwarf Fortress in space. It might have been just that, had it not been developed by Double Fine.

Unfortunately, Tim Schafer thinks that Early Access exists to test the waters rather than to operate as a platform for developers without solid capital. They honestly wanted to develop this game for 5 years. 5 years. And Tim says since the game isn't bringing in enough money on early access that they're going to have to push it out as 1.0 with most of the features on the devplan unfinished.

So Tim honestly thought that they were going to make profit on an unfinished game for five years. That, ladies and gentlemen, is the CEO of Double Fine. That's the man that couldn't finish a point and click adventure for 3.3 million.

I've got some advice for you, Tim. And it comes from Gabe Newell.

"Do not focus on anyone but your customers. Your reputation will follow you forever so always be fair to your customers, and certainly one thing you need to always remember is that your customers are not going to be fooled. Some people think they can get away with something and just hope people won't see through the bullshit. The internet is way smarter than any of us."

You've been exchanging your reputation as a game developer in for cash, and given your recent default on Spacebase DF-9 it is with regret that I must inform you that we, the gaming community and responsible consumers, can no longer extend your line of credit.

The next time you want to build a game, like oh, say, Dear Leader, don't come to the community with your hand stuck out and nothing for collateral but promises.

I feel bad for the people who worked on this game. Who wanted it to be something more only to have its legs cut out from under it because it wasn't a profitable Early Access game. To be honest, the updates were too far apart. Of course no one was buying it. It took too long to see progress, and your behavior and glibness on Twitter and other formats has been intolerable.

Sorry, Tim. You can't ride the success of Psychonauts, Day of the Tentacle, and Full Throttle forever. You could have been one of the greats, but instead you're going to end up like John Romero. Only John only screwed his fanbase over once, while you seem determined to make it the remainder of your career.

Do not purchase this game. Do not purchase Dear Leader, an Amnesia Fortnight winner like Spacebase DF-9. Do not buy Costume Quest 2. If Tim Schafer comes onto Kickstarter and is like, "Hey, Psychonauts 2 - I need cash." Do not give him money. Double Fine cannot manage its finances, and has abused a system that was put here to help unestablished developers as a way to decide whether they should bother to finish a game based upon its profitability before launch.

column8:
I hate writing such short reviews but I simply wish to express my opinion after many hours of gameplay (I do get to give a post 36 hour review, regardless):


Post 18 hour review summary (terminated as of release information until 1.0): I would STRONGLY recommend not purchasing this project until you see what comes in at 1.0 release. The ship has sailed, so to speak, on spacebase DF-9. The money brought in for DF-9 was considered insufficient to continue the project and the developers are going to ship the product as is.  You are welcome to receive a product that, with slight and fully justified speculation, will remain permanently as an alpha (it never reached beta) in support of double fine but I would be cautious.


I do recommend to all early access payers, however, to recognize how frequently we receive products that are not even identified as "alpha or beta" and to be kind to double fine. I would suggest most players refer to many battlefield and call of duty releases to see how beta's can be pushed out as "final projects". Double fine has to begin to regain some form of capital from this project and the only way they can is by releasing the game. I commend the team for being open and honest about their decision, as hard as it is. 

Positives:
+ Double Fine was open and honest
+ Graphics are well managed
+ Concept well thought out and fun
+ Obvious love and commitment put into the project

Negative
-Game is being accelerated to final state with obvious, often game ending, bugs
-From the developer: "Spacebase DF9 is still a fun, clever, hilarious, beautiful and complete game."

Leider habe ich das Spiel in der Hoffnung ein wÃ¼rdiger Nachfolger von Startopia zu finden, denn das Spiel hatte mich angesprochen, da es in der ISO-Perspektive, Weltraum und an typischen Basisbaumanagement wie z.B. X-Com erinnerte. Vor allem die Features, die in das Spiel kommen sollte, waren sehr ansprechend.

Allerdings hat Tim Schafer und sein Unternehmen DoubleFine dieses Versprechen gebrochen und will das Spiel nun von Alpha 6e nun als Vollversion 1.0 verÃ¶ffentlichen. Dieses Taktik kann ich nicht billigen und fÃ¼r mich war es wohl letztes Spiel von DoubleFine. Denn das Vergehen lÃ¤sst vielen Spielern in Koma und Wut verfallen...
Beweis: http://steamcommunity.com/games/246090/announcements/detail/216494030200824180
http://www.computerbase.de/2014-09/double-fine-location-early-access-spiel-spacebase-df-9/

FÃ¼r mich ist das Unternehmen wie EA und wird fortan auch nicht mehr von mir unterstÃ¼tzt. Wie Ihr damit umgeht, ist Eure Sache, ich gebe hier nur meine Meinung frei.
column9:
Unfortunately, I bought the game hoping to find a worthy successor to Startopia. The game appealed to me with its ISO perspective, space, and typical base-building management gameplay like X-Com. The features that were supposed to be included in the game were particularly appealing.

However, Tim Schafer and his company DoubleFine have broken this promise and now want to release the game from Alpha 6e as a full version 1.0. I don't approve of this tactic, and for me, this was probably DoubleFine's last game. Because this offense leaves many players in a coma and rage...
Proof: http://steamcommunity.com/games/246090/announcements/detail/216494030200824180
http://www.computerbase.de/2014-09/double-fine-location-early-access-spiel-spacebase-df-9/

For me, the company is like EA, and I will no longer support it. How you deal with it is up to you; I'm just expressing my opinion here.

column8:
When you see a game jump from .6 to 1.0 that can mean 1 of 2 things,
1.That there was a huge patch that added tons of content.
2.That the developer decided to stop working on it because they ran out of money paying back investors to work on the game.

The correct answer for this game is sadly 2, which sucks because the future content that was planned would have made this game great, but as it stands right now its a half assed game that's being polished up a bit to make it look like a full game.  I had fun playing this game but for now, until someone decides to make mods for this game, don't get it unless its on sale for 75% off.

Bemerkenswert ist hierbei, dass das "Spiel" von Version 0.6 (also Alpha 6) mit ein einhalb Jahren Entwicklungszeit dann innerhalb eines Monats den Status 1.0 (Release) erhalten soll. Ebenfalls bemerkenswert ist hierbei die Tatsache, dass eine Beta (inkl. der Ã¼blichen Tests) nicht angekÃ¼ndigt wurde und zum aktuellen Zeitpunkt nicht erfolgt ist.
column9:
Due to a lack of copies sold, development with version 1.0 was discontinued at the end of October 2014 and no longer pursued.
It's worth noting that the "game" of version 0.6 (i.e., Alpha 6), which took a year and a half to develop, is scheduled to reach 1.0 (release) within a month. Also noteworthy is the fact that a beta (including the usual tests) was not announced and hasn't yet taken place.

column8:
Do not buy, it's a Pyramid Scheme. The game is buggy, unfinished, and unstable. You can't play it in its current form, you can only test it, and it has been made clear the issues won't be addressed by DF. DF have paid off their Investors twice their investment, with our Early Access money and then have the nerve to say there's no money to develop the game after only 6 updates. That's right, version 0.6 and they pull the plug.

EDIT: Very little changed in 1.0, other than a tiny price reduction and an offer with Hack N Slash, still unplayable and wouldn't even be worth $5.

column8: Without belaboring the oft mentioned abandonment of this project by Double Fine, the game is not complete. The distance between it's current Alpha 6 state and the 1.0 release version that is scheduled to come out shortly is too great for anything other than a miracle to bridge. Double Fine has burned all Early Access purchasers and will receive no further priviliged consideration from me. *If* I by a DF game, it'll be during a Steam Sale or in a Humble Bundle.

column8: The game was developing slowly, but okay and had great promise but Double Fine have announced that they're stopping development, while the game is severely lacking features.

column8:
I've given this game a lot of time and it has the potential to be a lot of fun. It sufferes from some very serious flaws however. 

There is no real tutorial or guide. I had to go to the Wiki to figure out how to really get started. Part of this is not really knowing what to do and part is many of the things the game asks you to do are hidden about 4 menu layers down without telling you WHICH menu trees they are down. Once you know the trees, they make some sense but it is puzzling for new players.

The menu options need A LOT of work. It is not easy to understand what you need to do or how to do it. After you suffer through a few bad games of learning how to build an airlock, life support and the associated gear it starts to become fun.  Having the bulk of what you need to do hidden under several menu levels makes the trree feel lop sided. If I wasn't building a floor or wall, I was forever going down additional menus. 

Once you get past the start, it gets fun. Until you get a larger crew. Even if you give everyone the job they love to do, build all the comfort items and have everything you possibly can, your crew still gets depressed and sad. The crew want to be assigned their own beds but keeping track of who has what bed for 60+ people is not easy. Add to that the new people who come in and the people who die to raiders (or suicide in space) and you never know who needs what. The interface is increadibly clunky in this aspect. 

There is no way to direct anyone other than security and even then sometimes they just don't respond to a beacon. Critical structures that need building will often be overlooked for unimportant ones, equipment will remian broken while an army of technicians ignore them to chat with each other in the bar. This means the simultaneous building of objects is either best avoided (to direct workers to where you want them) or thrown to chance if something important needs to be done. Maintainence is best done by changin all technicians to builders and then reclaiming (destroying) degrading equipment and rebuilding it. When raiders approach, there is no way to direct non-security personnel away from an area. To be able to direct a worker to a specific task is such a basic tool it is amazing it has been overlooked.

There are some notifications (information) that should be alerts (clickable). What good is it warning me that I have an airlock somewhere I haven't built something in if you won't take me to it? This leaves you hunting down building errors, that may not be your fault, when it should be a simple click and fix. 

The AI is very stupid at times. Workers will starve to death while standing in front of a food dispensor. Builders will build themselves into a room and then suffocate because they can't get out. You can't even pull them out before they finish because you can't direct them. 

There is no screen rotation. Sometimes you will get missing floor tiles hidden behind walls. They may have been missed in construction, they may have come about from damage (fire, space debris). You can drop the walls most of the way but sometimes they can still hide. Being able to rotate the map would help this significantly. 

For something that borrows so much from RTS games, it is a game that fails to learn from lessons RTS games had to learn as they matured. As a result you get a game that could be (and at times is) increadibly fun but is severly hindered by its lack of basic features.

column8:
[h1][b]Abandoned in early development.[/b][/h1]

Extremely sad state of affairs, as the concept was great, early alpha versions demonstrated a load of potential, but development has been killed off long before the game was properly fleshed out.  What you have is an abandoned skeleton which had great potential, but never got any real meat added to the bones.

[h1][b]DO NOT BUY[/b][/h1]

It's simply not worth the extremely high price asked for a forever-incomplete game which has very little substance in its current form.

column8:
I read about the game getting canceled. Saw some youtube videos and game looked awesome. Reminded me of theme hospital a bit. It looks fun even with just its existing feature set. Unfortunetly it is super buggy almost to the point of being unplayable. 

Builders lock themselves in rooms. Cannot place a door until room is built.

In one game got raided every 10 mininutes or so, astroids the same. It's not really fun after first 5 attacks, just annoying. I picked average for density and like almost low for (dont remember wording) for raiders. 

Tells me I dont have any doctors when I do have a doctor assigned. Tells me I dont have a tech when I have one assigned.

A pirate ship "docked" with me. I could not get inside the ship no matter what I did. I endeded up having my builders tear down half way.  The game crapped out on me before I could finish the rest.

I "pacified" a raider instead of killing him. I dont have a brig yet. He is now sitting in the hall way just staring at everyone. Everyone and a while I get an alert saying I am being raided. After this happened everyone started doing stuff even slower than before so I had to restart :(

People spend lots of time doing nothing. Right now I have 6 out of 9 people doing excerises and chatting in hallway. When I need something done in a hurry I just assign everyone. Like when a dude is about to starve because of being locked in a room. 

In the you tube videos people were joining left and right. I just have 7 people and no new people are coming :( I picked near to space gate or whatever when starting. 

Cannot scroll when constructing... This really sucks, literally need to cancel to close construction, scroll, and then start all over :(

The starting area selector thing is no good. Why cant it just be like minecraft where you can just pick easy, hard, flat, etc. Its adds no value whatsover having that picker thing with the map. Just annoying each time you restart and want to experiment with different world type.

The description of magnetic interfernce is caught off, cannot scroll, and I have no idea what it means in the game.	

Wanted to change roll of hallway. Building first generator, room was tool small, knocked down wall, built generator and built new wall that extended one block into hallway. Hallway become "reactor room". Tried to click on and change, instead clicked on unclaim by accident. Couldnt reclaim after that, lost all power and had to restart.

Builders get stuck in rooms behind objects. Need to knock down the wall to free them.

Twice at start of game, I finished my base with working airlock and life support but not everyone comes inside. They die outside.

A weird green line tripod/triangle thing appeared in the middle of base. Save/quit and restart and it went away.

In one game the refiner didnt work? The tech came around and repaired it but miners just came, stood next to it, and then threw there rocks on the ground :( Had to tear down and rebuild.

Twice this has happened, a reactor I built just disappeared. I placed in construction tool and confirmed. Didnt pay attention to see what happened.

It would be nice to have more than one save? Especially with a super buggy game like this.

column8:
This game is completely unfinished and is going into full release without being even close to completion, which is just an attempt to squeeze some money out of an abandoned game.
They also promoted the game on Steam to try and lure people to buy it just before they dumped all the promised features and abandoned development, which in my eyes is sneaky and deceptive and best, and borderline criminal at worst.
After trying repeatedly to start building the base. Just *start* the base that is, I encountered a series of bugs and issues which meant that my crew didn't go into the base I had built, died for no real reason etc etc. There is no guidance to indicate what is wrong, so it is hard to tell when it is a bug or you have made a mistake. The answer is probably both.
Avoid avoid avoid.

column8:
[h1]SPACEBASE DF-9 â€“ HOUSTON, ABBIAMO UN PROBLEMA[/h1]

[i]Spacebase DF-9 Ã¨ un titolo gravemente insufficiente, non perchÃ© quello che c'Ã¨ sia fatto male, ma perchÃ© Ã¨ davvero troppo poco. Si tratta di una vera e propria occasione sprecata e nonostante gli sviluppatori abbiano deciso di rilasciare il codice sorgente del gioco per permettere ai modder di creare nuovi contenuti, tale comportamento non Ã¨ affatto giusto, poichÃ© non Ã¨ compito di chi fa mod aggiungere quello che manca al gioco, ma degli sviluppatori, che continueranno comunque a vendere Spacebase DF-9 all'improponibile prezzo di 19,99 euro, come se fosse un gioco completo; tra l'altro, il prezzo della "versione finale" Ã¨ inferiore di tre euro rispetto a quello pagato da chi ha deciso di supportare questo progetto fin dal suo approdo tra gli Early Access di Steam, e questo fa ben capire quale sia stata la qualitÃ  del lavoro svolto dallo sviluppatore, dato che le versioni ad accesso anticipato sono sempre meno costose di quelle finali.[/i]

column9:
[h1]SPACEBASE DF-9 â€“ HOUSTON, WE HAVE A PROBLEM[/h1]

[i]Spacebase DF-9 is a seriously inadequate title, not because what's there is poorly made, but because it's truly too little. It's a truly wasted opportunity, and although the developers have decided to release the game's source code to allow modders to create new content, this behavior is completely unfair, since it's not the modders' job to add what's missing from the game, but the developers', who will continue to sell Spacebase DF-9 at the unreasonable price of â‚¬19.99, as if it were a complete game; Furthermore, the price of the "final version" is three euros less than the price paid by those who have supported this project since its arrival in Steam Early Access, which clearly demonstrates the quality of the developer's work, given that Early Access versions are always less expensive than the final versions.

[b][url=http://www.z-giochi.com/recensioni/spacebase-df-9-houston-abbiamo-un-problema-133880]You can read the full review on Z-Giochi[/url][/b]

column8:
This game hasn't left Early Access yet and the developers have already gone public with ending support after the 1.0 release.

The game itself was a good idea with a lot of potential but obviously the developers either can't do accounting properly (and can't hire anyone to do it properly for them) or they grossly misunderstood how much money a badly bugged early access title would make. 

An Early Access warning story if there ever was one. 

Do not purchase.

column8:
I can't say anything that hasn't already been said. It's kind of obvious why I can't recommend this!

* Updating my review as this game is out of Early Access now *

In the good old days of games, companies would invest money into developing a game. Sometimes these investments wouldn't pay off and the game would be unceremoniously cancelled. Remember Snake Plissken's First Escape for the PS2? Me neither. How about the next MMO from Blizzard that was recently canned?

With Spacebase, not only do you get the experience of a game cancelled in mid-development but you also get the luxury of paying for it.

Without chasing the rabbit about the dubious nature of the way this game was funded, it's fair to say that I and everyone else who bought this in early access took a risk that didn't pay off. That doesn't mean I can't and shouldn't have expected better from an established development studio.

column8:
If you're looking to get ripped off by a lying, deceptive developer...this is the game for YOU!

DoubleFine's horrible, disingenous business practices aside, this game is just flat out not that good. It's very much like the Sims, but set in space, and with far fewer functioning systems. For example,  NPCs will often stand around, even when all of their "needs" are met, and do absolutely nothing. Usually forever. Sometimes they'll die from starvation while standing right next to an open food source.

You really shouldn't buy this game at all. Even if you're bored, there are plenty of free flash games that offer better and more in-depth gameplay.

column8:
[h1] Â£18.99 For a Cancelled Game [/h1]

This title is broken in its current form. More often than not it is unplayable due to unbalanced mechanics and truly awful ai. There was once promise, promise enough for many people to shed out a lot of money when the game was listed under Early Access, now the developers have declared that no more updates will be coming to the game - that there is not enough funding to warrant the amount of work it would take to deliver the experinece the devs described to us (back when they asked for our money.) The investors who spent 400k on this title have recouped that amount but players who supported this title are receiving a mere token update that hopes to fix a few bugs and add a tutorial. 

Do not waste money on this broken and unfinished game.

column8:
The developers seemed to think that SB DF9 would generate enough money to sustain development costs for "years", yet they neglected to realize that people aren't going to keep buying something that's quite obviously treated like a side project, with slow updates and little content. 
At one time I personally defended the game, because well, it wasn't done yet, and someday it might have been something really good, which I was willing to wait for. However, now that DoubleFine has announced that they're basically just going from alpha 6(!) to 1.0 release (with an added "b-but here's the source code so YOU can finish it"), I cannot recommend the game, as it is unfinished, nor can I recommend any other product from DoubleFine, since they evidently need better management (and PR while they're at it).

column8: A friendly shoutout to the developers: thank you for your honesty. Instead of releasing this game as a "finished product", you apologized and clearly stated your intentions of letting the project go. It was the right thing to do in this situation. If nothing else, this game acts as a cautionary example of the dangers of early access and the hype raised by unrealistic ambitions.

column8:
Having liked Bullfrog's classics (Dungeon Keeper, Theme Hospital) back in the day, I enjoyed what was released of SpaceBase DF-9 during its early access alpha, and the addition of new features gave me a reason to replay it after every update.

I had a lot of fun with the alpha (when not circumventing the game-breaking bugs), and thought that it was a decent concept which had really good potential. While updates were few and far between, I hoped that the game would eventually evolve into something better and deeper. Both the development scope that they posted on their website, and the hard effort which they put into the design of the game reflected that this is what DoubleFine originally envisioned. 

Unfortunately, game development doesn't always go well, and DoubleFine now intend to release a game which when "finished" will be fun to play, but scant on features and not worth it's Â£19/$30 price tag in my opinion, considering there are deeper games (with a bit more content in them) in the same genre as SpaceBase which aren't priced as high, and that people may get more enjoyment from. This is why I can't recommend people buy it.

SpaceBase will hopefully be playable in version 1.0 after much bug fixing, and I can imagine it being a small and decent strategy game which will be quite fun, but unfortunately won't have a lot to do in it. Maybe if you really enjoy the genre then you'll like the finished version of SpaceBase, but don't expect a lot of bang for your buck - I hope DoubleFine reduces the price before final release.

column8:
I sank nearly 50 hours into this shambling mess of a game that had potential to be fun and interesting.

I even tactily believed a team of 4 people could handle developing the game, because the reputation of Double Fine and the People on the team backed up by a firm development timeline, making good but not exceptional progress.

Since my purchase in Alpha 4, a handful of small changes have made it seem to be a good overall investment and a likely turnaround. I even helped other people on the steam forums and DF forums.

And yet, i was hesitant recommending DF9, because Early Access isn't the same as buying a released game, it's not even kickstarter, you can't get a refund or the money back if it fails, you have to accept a shining pile of shit and hope the developer has the stomach to make it better over time when you buy a game through Early Access, 

That's the primary condition Steam sets for you. That all changed on the 19th September, 2014 when they abandoned the game, saying there was no more money in development. If you're going to get this game, wait for a humble bundle and pay $2, that's a little high for what it's worth, definitely  not the $30 i paid to test out a failed experiment.

Fuck you Tim Schafer. Fuck you.

column8:
Update 3/10/18: I fired up DF9 again just to see if the additional patches (including the SBHub patch) made the game any less ****. They did not. Numerous bugs, AI stupidity, UI stupidity, and all the half-***ed game dev garbage you can shake a stick at still abound. My original review stands as follows:

DO NOT BUY.

Investment in an Early Access game may carry some measure of risk, sure. But from an established studio like Double Fine, there's a [i]reasonable[/i] expectation of not only a certain level of quality, but of a [i]completed product[/i]. With Spacebase DF9, we're getting neither of those.

Deciding that pre-release sales aren't up to their expectations, Double Fine has opted to cancel further development of DF9, label the next version 1.0, and [i]abandon[/i] it. Sure, we'll get some bug fixes in 1.0, but the game isn't nearly ready for release. Between miners who refuse to stop working and suffocate before reaching the airlock, doctors who can't be bothered to retrieve dead bodies, construction items that builders ignore, and a notable lack of features and variety, DF9 is an incomplete and outright broken product. That never bothered me much because I kept telling myself, "It's still alpha; it'll get better."

That Double Fine is using sales of an alpha to determine the game isn't promising enough to finish is astonishing. The lack of commitment to invested fans is even more so. [i]Of course[/i] it's not selling well; [i]it's not a good product yet[/i]. This almost makes one miss the old days, when games didn't sell [i]at all[/i] before release. Then no one could complain, "it didn't sell well enough before we finished it."

This is the kind of thing we've come to expect from no-name, fly-by-night indie devs, but from a studio like Double Fine it's all the more shocking, if not more shameful.

A pity all the more because the promise was undeniable.

column8:
Do not buy (unless very, very cheap).

DF-9 was set out in Early Access with an extensive list of planned features. Sadly the dev made the inexcusable decision to cease development. The final rendition of the game is a simple and shallow shadow of what it should have been and is not even remotely worth the $25 asking price. I got it on special, and still feel ripped off.

It's not a terrible game, even as is, but is honestly worth maybe $5 given their choice to stick a bow on it and call it complete. Even then, I'd wait for a sale.

At max you'll get 3-4 hours of fun out of this, DoubleFine mismanged this game so badly that they're throwing it out with hardly any of the features they promised when they first announced their plans for this game. 

It's an unpolished, unfocused mess that doesn't really know what it's trying to do. Does it want you to build the biggest space base ever? Does it want you to build the most efficiant space station ever? I don't know and honestly I don't feel like the developers quite knew either.

column8: For a game that showed so much potential, this one really let me down. I followed development from alpha 1a, and eagerly awaited every patch. But now, DF have decided to end development mid alpha and release the game as a 1.0 full version. I can only hope that the modding community can salvage this game, It has so much potential left. For now though, its not worth $25 to support a game ending development, wait till the price drops or modders expand it enough.

column8:
AVOID AT ALL COSTS.

Based on a paid Indie Jam game of the same name.  I bought that.
They re-released as a seperate game (as apparently it was soooo different to the game jam game) and have done absolutely nothing in a year.  It's still as deep as a puddle and full of bugs.  Now they're going to just release because no one is purchasing it as Early Access.  Erm... maybe they're waiting until it's complete?  It will now never be complete, it's just being badged as 1.0 and abandoned.

Shame on you Double Fine.  You've gone on the list of people I won't purchase from in future.

column8: I must say that despite my disappointment that many of the features that were suggested as possibilities did not make it into the alpha and most likely will not make it into the 1.0 release.  It would be nice if Double Fine Productions were willing to keep this game in a beta state and continue active development of it, but despite this, I still find this to be a very fun game with a lot of potential.  Thankfully, that potential won't be wasted.  Double Fine is including the lua source for developers to mod this game.  While, this would be a very fun project to undertake, unfortunately I don't have the monetary resources to take a year or two off of life to mod this myself.  While this game in its current state is fun and enjoyable, it lacks the depth to justify the price tag in my opinion.  I think with a little more effort to add these features instead of relying on the modding community, a lot of these reviews would be a lot more favorable.  That being said, I love this game for what it is and even more for what it has the potential to be which is the only reason I'm recommending it.

column8:
As a long time fan of Double Fine it hurts me to say that you all should be ashamed of yourself.

Not because you betrayed your word, which you did. Not because you essentially scammed loyal fans out of money, which you did. Not because the game is incomplete, which it is. Not because you botched the project at the expense of your fans, which you did.

You should be ashamed because you have hurt the entire industries trust and faith in early access, small developers, and where to trust developers.

I understand not all early access projects work out, I understand that buying into early access is a risk. This however was pure deception on behalf of the developers.

You don't deserve to be distributed on Steam and you don't deserve my money ever again. Shame on you Double Fine you lost a fan, a supporter and revenue.

-Adding to this review in hopes it will bump it now that it's been released and on sale. I cannot warn anyone off this game thoroughly enough, if you are considering purchasing this now that its been "completed", you are being swindled. Do not purchase this game. Purchase literaly anything else. -

-Adding again, now that 1.0 has been released DF has given a free copy of Hack'N'Slash to people who supported this game. You think we're all going to be bought off that easily? I'm not playing any doublefine games, even free ones. Get it together Double Fine, an apology would go a long way.-

-Adding to this review in hopes it will bump it now that it's been released and on sale. I cannot warn anyone off this game thoroughly enough, if you are considering purchasing this now that its been "completed", you are being swindled. Do not purchase this game. Purchase literaly anything else. -

-Adding again, now that 1.0 has been released DF has given a free copy of Hack'N'Slash to people who supported this game. You think we're all going to be bought off that easily? I'm not playing any doublefine games, even free ones. Get it together Double Fine, an apology would go a long way.-

column8:
I have to change my review on this one.

Double Fine dropped the game without finishing it. I enjoy the game and will keep playing it from time to time but I wish I could put a review up for Double Fine itself. Thanks to how they treated this game and their fans, they are black listed for me. I am more likely to pirate their programs rather than buy them but then again, I don't want anymore of their products in my libary. To aquire their works would only honor them when they don't deserve it.

First Review:

This game is a great time killer. I will fire it up, start playing and when I look at the clock i've lost 3-4 hours with out noticing. I'm not gona lie, this is one of the few games that can get me hopping mad. My tech guys will look at a broken reactor and walk away as the base loses all power. yM builders will go to the air lock get their space suits on, head out and look at the hole in the wall that I told them to fix, go back inside (with out fixing it) get out of their suits head to the pub and get sucked out into space. I'll have a hull breach with out a breach so all the oxygen gets sucked out and by people die. I've been pounded on my space rocks every minute on the dot. My people have lost their minds and started destorying the base. Raiders will bust in and shoot up the place without mercy... Yep. This game can get me really mad, but I still have alot of fun. Its in Alpha, there will be bugs and there will be progaming errors that make ya guys go mad. It all adds to the flavor of the game. While I would like to see the game advance, I do enjoy the mistakes they made. Its a game, just have fun with it.

column8: Was erwartet einen: Im Grunde sollte es ein Dwarfes Fortress im Weltall mit ansehbarer Grafik sein, doch davon ist es weit entfernt. Man baut sich eine Basis im Weltall und wird insbesondere zu Beginn fÃ¼r jeden Fehler hart bestraft - baut man einen Raum zu klein oder zu groÃŸ passen entweder die Lebenserhaltungssysteme nicht hinein oder einem geht das Geld aus ... fÃ¼r Lebenserhaltungssysteme. Hat man es jedoch geschafft, die Lebenserhaltung und eine Raffinerie einzubauen, gehts entspannter zur Sache. Man baut also von Weltraumschrott und Spacepiraten geplagt, nach und nach eine Basis auf und dann? Das wars eigentlich, denn mehr passiert nicht. Hat man alle RÃ¤ume gebaut und mehr als 10 Bewohner, ist so eine Basis fast ein SelbstlÃ¤ufer und man fragt sich, wofÃ¼r man das alles macht. Die Bewohner bei Laune zu halten, sollte zwar ein Ziel sein, das Spiel gibt sich aber keine MÃ¼he, einem zu sagen, was die Bewohner noch brauchen, dass es ihnen besser geht (das Interface ist in dieser Hinsicht auch die HÃ¶lle - um die Moral der Bewohner zu sehen, muss man mÃ¼hsam jeden einzeln anklicken und oft weiÃŸ man danach nur, dass sie traurig sind, nicht aber warum). Klar, mit 1.0 kommen noch Ziele dazu und man kann sich einen schwereren Sektor suchen. Aber im Grunde fehlt dem ganzen Spiel die Tiefe. Da Double Fine ab Oktober die Betreuung des Spiels einstellt, ist auch nicht davon auszugehen, dass da noch Tiefe hinzu kommt. Wer einfach nur eine Spacebase bauen will und sie einfach immer grÃ¶ÃŸer machen will, der kann hier einen Blick riskieren. Alle anderen sollten eher auf Rimworld warten oder sein Geld in Prison Architect oder Startopia investieren.
column9: What to expect: Basically, it's supposed to be a Dwarf Fortress in space with decent graphics, but it's far from that. You build a base in space and are punished harshly for every mistake, especially at the beginning - if you build a room too small or too big, either the life support systems won't fit or you'll run out of money... for life support systems. However, once you've managed to install life support and a refinery, things become more relaxed. So, plagued by space debris and space pirates, you gradually build a base and then? That's it, because nothing more happens. Once you've built all the rooms and have more than 10 inhabitants, a base like this practically runs itself and you wonder why you're doing it all. Keeping the residents happy should be a goal, but the game doesn't make any effort to tell you what the residents still need to feel better (the interface is hell in this regard, too â€“ to see the residents' morale, you have to laboriously click on each one individually, and often all you know afterward is that they're sad, but not why). Sure, with 1.0, objectives are added and you can seek out a more difficult sector. But fundamentally, the entire game lacks depth. Since Double Fine will stop supporting the game in October, it's unlikely that any more depth will be added. If you just want to build a spacebase and keep making it bigger, you can take a look here. Everyone else should wait for Rimworld or invest their money in Prison Architect or Startopia.

column8:
This game is not finished, and it has come out that it never will be.  There are a handful of hours that are enjoyable, but not in the way you think.  It seems to be building up to something.  You gather resources and put together a station, and at no time is your progress ever really threatened.  Then, you have everything built up, you've put lasers on the walls and have a small army of security and... nothing ever happens.  There are no truly challenging random events, there are no barriers that you have to work around to build your base, there's never any challenge at all.  

And then there's no kind of endgame after this, you can just keep expanding and staring at your stable, boring base (that is in itself neither complex nor complicated, with no tough systems to learn or figure out) for eternity.  And Double Fine has come out and said that this is all that there ever will be.

Don't buy this game.  It's all build-up, no climax.  No challenges.  Even the resource gathering and base/population management isn't difficult because it's too simple and easy.

column8:
Post v1.06 Update:
Derlict games (a community team) has picked up the task of fixing what Doublefine left for us.
Progress is slow but allready with v1.07 and v1.071 the game is noticably improved. Many bugs are fixed and there are quite a few new structures avalible.

Unfortunately becuase Doublefine only released the Lua Scripting what can be done is very limited in nature and many aspects of the game are being rewritten from scratch to make them more eaisly worked with.

I dont reccomend buying Spacebase DF-9 [i]yet[/i]. In time that will change but there still are better games out there like Startopia.

Origional Review:
I previously had a negative review of the early access for this game due to various bugs, quicks and gamebreaking issues. I went into 1.0 with the intent of  viewing the game as a clean slate and giving it a fair chance at a positive review.

Unfortunately though nothing has changed.

The AI is terrible, and incapable of even the most basic levels of prioritisation. Crew will get stuck behind objects which is a new issue for the game this sort of thing wasent a problem in previous alpha releases. The initial seed powering system is still buggy. I had to rebuild the room around it 3 times before it registered leaving me with very little resources left to actually continue my station. The predicted resource gains from mining is completely inaccurate. It gave me an estimate of around 1000 or so and i got maby 200. The event system is still stupidly unforgiving and 9 out of 10 new game attemps will fail because of massive ammounts of meteor showers hostile invaders or generally just incompetent AI.

The only thing i can tell they did add was a tutorial that nobody wanted or needed. For all intents and purposes the description of the 1.0 update is nothing more than a lie, there have been no bugfixes, there is no new content.

Do not buy this game. No matter how much of a fan of this genre you are this game is not worth the cost. Dont make the same mistakes myself and the rest of the community that bought into this project.

column9:
Unfinished

Spacebase DF-9 had a lot of potential, but after a good launch, subsequent updates were sparse, and now, unfortunately, the plug is being pulled far too early because the game's revenue no longer makes further development seem worthwhile to the developer. (If one were mean, one could say that the money of the Early Access buyers is spent and they don't want to invest any more.)

The game is now jumping from Alpha 6 to "1.0 Final," which can only go wrong.

A shame.

I wouldn't buy it again, except perhaps as part of a Humble Bundle promotion or a 90% off sale.

I read stuff on their web with long list of planned features and I liked it despite the fact there wasn't much to do in the game itself. I purchased it because of "early" alpha state with only 6 bigger versions and huge planned features list. Not too long from that day, they want to release the game which is still more "prototype" than full game. If I knew about that earlier, I didn't purchase it. It's not worth 22.99â‚¬, heck 10â‚¬ would be still too expensive.

column8:
I purchased this game during a steam sale on september 3 for 50% off early access.
I had been following the progress for a while, and was hoping for a more finished product, but when I watched the Alpha 6 video from Double Fine, it looked like this update finally added some more content and there were also certain assurances from JP, the lead developer, that they would strive for better communication in regards to content and issues in the future. I decided to pay up and try it out. 

Well, it was still very broken. Aside from the known bugs that weren't resolved, the new "mood system" introduced some hugely game breaking bugs and it was hard to progress very far at all in the game without having to restart for one reason or another.
I frustratingly put the game down for the weekend, and only played it a few more times until they ironed out some of the more severe mood bugs by 6e-f. 

Once those game breakers were (pretty much) out of the way, I was able to successfully establish a base and build it to fair size before wondering the inevitable.. "okay, now what?" of an unfinished sandbox game. The derelict ships provide a little interest, but can sometimes be a pain to deal with. The breaches could be a very fun aspect of the game, but instead balance issues make them either ridiculously easy, or painfully hard with no real explanation as to why one way or another.

This lead me to decide (as I have done with other Early Access titles) to "put the game down" for a bit, and come back later when they have added some more content to make the game more interesting and challenging to play. 

It is now two weeks later, and the lead developer has stated that they will be finalizing this game and releasing 1.0 in a month.
This is a woefully unfinished game that is severely lacking in content. While the idea and core features seem real enticing, the truth is there really isn't much at all to do and I dont see the developer adding that much more before actual release.

If you would like a "space base" type game, I would suggest an alternative in Startopia. Yes, it's almost 15 years old, but its funny and entertaining and actually has goals and stuff to do. I guarantee you will get much better gaming enjoyment out of Startopia than this unfinished, yet released product.

column8:
So like many other people I had great hopes for what this game would become in the next year or so.  I bought it late in the year 2013, maybe a month after it was available through early access. Initially the game was fun even though it was still broken in many ways.  However I'd just play a game once every month or so to see what they had added or fixed since my last run. 

I played around the middle of last month for the last time. When I played they had added a total of three new room types into the game since the barebones they had at launch. These rooms were excercise, science and medical. 

Excercise like it sounds was a gym, but it only has one single item you can place in it, a very boring gym machine, literally nothing else can go in there that actually helps your people excercise.
Science was pretty much the same. One big machine that is all you need, and some research projects that are very few in choice, and really don't add anything new to the game once completed.
And finally nmedical. Exact same deal, one structure can be built and only one, and its effect is negligible at best.

Long story short is this game barely had a years worth of development put into it, and is being released for a tag of $25 !?!?

If your thinking about buying a dwarf fortress type game with better UI get Banished or Gnomoria, or even deal with DF's crazy style, but DO NOT BUY THIS GAME! Doing so supports a studio that should know better than to treat customer like this. I learned to never buy an early access title from Double Fine, please don't make the same mistake.

column8:
Avoid this completely!
Double Fine have decided to drop development on this game and, after a little bit of bug fixing, are abandoning any more progress on it!
Once again, Double Fine are screwwing customers who are dumb enough to actually give them money.
They have even removed all their previous statements off their page that stated their aims for this game.
And yet, even though they were abandoning this game, they still had the audacity to put this game on a SALE right before pulling the plug!
This is not the first time that Double Fine have betrayed their customers, they got many hundreds of thousands in funding from us mugs, but gave us the bare bones of a game that doesn't work properly, a few patches over the last year and then abandoning development because they haven't got funds...
A sorry lack of game for such a huge amount of money!

Frankly, it's utterly disgusting that Double Fine STILL are selling this incomplete and failed non-game and STILL conning people out of money!
Yet again putting this shambles of a product on a sale shows just how low Double Fine really are.
They are clearly far more interested in taking people's money than they are in giving their customers a decent product and a worthy game. This disgusting POS and many of their other recent actions have proven that.

Double fine has decided (in their infinite wisdom) that it is acceptable to simply take a 0.6 alpha build, and jump straight to a 1.0 release build and stating that they are ceasing all development on a game that is by no means feature complete, has major bugs and performance issues, as you would expect from an alpha. Simply releasing the source code is not an acceptable remedy for this, they are basically saying they can't be bothered to finish this, so the community should. 

No, that is not acceptable. We invest in an early access title to help ensure the project is complete, and all we expect is a game to be developed to the best of the companies abilities. This is obviously just double fine wanting to cut corners and save money by screwing the consumer out of a finished product. Do not buy! Do not support companies that want to screw the consumer out of their hard earned cash.

column8:
This game was the most feature-bare, bug ridden alpha of an early access game I've ever purchased. Over a year later the updates have been lackluster and far below the minimum standard I'd expect from any early access game. Now the game is being written off, the plug is being pulled, they're taking the money and running. They can call it 1.0, but that's just not true. It'll be Alpha 7, and that will be the final version of this game.

I own dozens of early access games, I love them dearly. This has been my first and only "huge disappointment" out of early access, I straight up feel scammed. Not only does this hurt the reputation of Double Fine, but early access as a whole.

Don't buy this, and don't trust Double Fine with your early access or kickstarter money.

column8:
Nach dem fantastischen Spiel Costume Quest, was mich sehr lange sehr gut unterhalten hatte, war ich darauf gespannt, was Spacebase DF-9 zu bieten hatte. Die Aussichten waren groÃŸartig: Eine Simulation sollte entstehen, in der man irgendwo in den ewigen weiten der Galaxie eine Raumstation bauen, VorrÃ¤te anlegen, Forschung betreiben und sich seine eigene kleine Welt aufbauen kann. GroÃŸe Ziele und viel Content waren versprochen, und das Potenzial war grenzenlos.
So trat auch ich in das Early Access-Programm ein, um den Entwickler zu unterstÃ¼tzen.....ein Fehler?.....

Ich mÃ¶chte ehrlich sein: Ich war von DF-9 begeistert, und bin es im Grunde auch immer noch. FÃ¼r eine EA-Version war es schon ein recht ausgereiftes Spiel, dessen Coresysteme schon gut funktionierten, aber immer noch viel Erweiterungspotenzial boten. Das Anlegen von RÃ¤umen fÃ¼r die verschiedenen BedÃ¼rfnisse geht einfach von der Hand und lÃ¤sst auch viel Platz fÃ¼r auÃŸergewÃ¶hnliche Strukturen. Das Ressourcensystem ist einfach gehalten, funktioniert dafÃ¼r aber auch bei AnfÃ¤ngern. Die zufÃ¤lligen Events wie die Ankuft neuer Crewmitglieder (sowohl freundliche als auf feindlich gesinnte) oder das Erscheinen anderer Raumstrukturen sind einigermaÃŸen balanciert, und auch das Forschungssystem ist mehr Funktional als Schick. Die Bewohner der Station wirken schon einigermaÃŸen intelligent und fÃ¼hren die ihnen aufgetragenen Arbeiten auch meist pflichtbewusst aus.
NatÃ¼rlich, es gibt auch noch viele Balance-Probleme, unausgereifte Mechaniken und zahlreiche Bugs, Aber hey, das hier ist Early Access, da ist das vorprogrammiert und sollte nicht so viel Einfluss auf die Bewertung haben....oder?....

Warum es trotzdem keine Empfehlung von mir gibt? Ganz einfach; weil ich mit dieser Bewertung auch warnen mÃ¶chte. Denn dieses Spiel wird die Alpha leider schneller verlassen, als uns allen lieb ist.
Am 17. September hat Entwickler Double Fine nÃ¤mlich beschlossen, die Community auf den baldigen finalen Release vorzubereiten. Zuerst dachte ich, dass das eine GROÃŸARTIGE Nachricht sei...bis ich endlich realisierte, was das bedeutet:
Es bedeutet nÃ¤mlich, dass ein Spiel, welches zwar funktioniert, aber noch nicht annÃ¤hernd perfekt ist, einfach so abgeschlossen wird, ohne Beta, ohne ausreichende Tests.
Das mag sich zwar nicht so schlimm anhÃ¶ren, es bedeutet aber das entwicklungstechnische AUS fÃ¼r das Spiel. Die komplette Liste der geplanten Features wird verworfen, und auch beim Bugfixing wird man sich wohl nur noch das nÃ¶tigste erledigen. Stattdessen legt man das Spiel lieber in die HÃ¤nde der Community und verÃ¶ffentlicht den Sourcecode.

Man kann lange versuchen, sich diese Enzscheidung irgendwie schÃ¶nzureden, aber am Ende kommt man nicht daran vorbei zu sagen, dass das alles wohl nur eine schÃ¶ne Umschreibung der Aussage "Wir haben keinen Bock mehr, macht ihr mal!" ist. BÃ¶se Zungen gehen aber eher von "Wir haben euer Geld schon, also TschÃ¼ss!" aus.
Dazu kommt, dass diese AnkÃ¼ndigung nach EA-Version 6 kommt, die noch stark fehlerbehaftet und verbuggt ist. In einer Early Access darf sowas passieren; fÃ¼r die Tatsache, dass der Final Release bald bevorsteht, ist das wohl eher ernÃ¼chternd, und hinterlÃ¤sst noch einmal einen stark negativen Eindruck.
Dazu kommt auch noch, dass das Spiel, was ab dahin wohl nur noch von der Community gepflegt wird, trotzdem wohl weiterhin 23 Euro kosten wird, was angesichts dieser Nachricht mehr als ungerechtfertigt erscheint.
So bleibt der Eindruck, dass man auf einen betrÃ¼gerischen Entwickler reingefallen ist.

Ein abschlieÃŸendes Fazit mÃ¶chte ich an der Stelle noch nicht geben; nur soviel sei gesagt:
Double Fine hat sich mit diesem Schritt keinen Gefallen getan. Sie haben mit er Entscheidung, ein Early Access-Spiel so frÃ¼h zu releasen und danach "fallen zu lassen" nicht nur ihren, sondern auch den Ruf des ganzen EA-Programmes nachhaltig geschÃ¤digt.  
Man kann nur hoffen, dass die oft erwÃ¤hnte "Betrugsabsicht" doch nicht so stark beabsichtigt war, wie es sich jetzt fÃ¼r die meisten User anfÃ¼hlt; sonst mÃ¼sste man wirklich fast von Betrugs ausgehen.....trotz Early Access.
column9:
After the fantastic game Costume Quest, which had kept me entertained for a long time, I was excited to see what Spacebase DF-9 had to offer. The prospects were great: a simulation where you could build a space station somewhere in the vastness of the galaxy, store supplies, conduct research, and create your own little world. Big goals and a lot of content were promised, and the potential was limitless.
So I joined the Early Access program to support the developer... a mistake?...

I'll be honest: I was thrilled with DF-9, and basically I still am. For an EA release, it was already a fairly mature game, with core systems that worked well but still offered a lot of potential for expansion. Creating rooms for different needs is easy and leaves plenty of room for unusual structures. The resource system is simple, but works even for beginners. The random events, such as the arrival of new crew members (both friendly and hostile) or the appearance of other spatial structures, are reasonably balanced, and the research system is more functional than fancy. The station's inhabitants seem reasonably intelligent and mostly carry out their assigned tasks dutifully.
Of course, there are still many balance issues, immature mechanics, and numerous bugs. But hey, this is Early Access, so that's inevitable and shouldn't have much of an impact on the rating...or should it?

Why isn't there a recommendation from me? Quite simply; because I also want to warn with this review. Because this game will unfortunately be leaving the alpha sooner than any of us would like.
On September 17, developer Double Fine decided to prepare the community for the imminent final release. At first, I thought this was GREAT news...until I finally realized what it meant:
It means that a game that works but isn't nearly perfect will simply be shut down, without a beta, without adequate testing.
That might not sound so bad, but it means the game's development is over. The entire list of planned features will be scrapped, and bug fixing will likely only be done to the bare minimum. Instead, they'd rather put the game in the hands of the community and release the source code.

You can try for a long time to sugarcoat this decision, but in the end, you can't avoid the conclusion that this is all just a nice way of saying "We're fed up, you do it!" But malicious tongues are more likely to say "We already have your money, so goodbye!"
On top of that, this announcement comes after EA version 6, which is still heavily flawed and buggy. This kind of thing is normal in Early Access; Considering that the final release is imminent, this is rather sobering and leaves a very negative impression.
On top of that, the game, which will likely only be maintained by the community from then on, will still cost â‚¬23, which seems more than unjustified in light of this news.
This leaves the impression that we've been duped by a fraudulent developer.

I don't want to offer a final conclusion at this point; suffice it to say:
Double Fine hasn't done itself any favors with this move. With the decision to release an Early Access game so early and then "abandon" it, they have permanently damaged not only their reputation but also the reputation of the entire EA program.

One can only hope that the often-mentioned "fraudulent intent" wasn't as intentional as it now feels to most users; otherwise, one would almost have to assume fraud...despite Early Access.

column8:
Perhaps, half a prototype.

I'm not upset that I spent the money on this, and I feel I payed for an adequate amount for playing what content there was to play--but I wouldn't recommend the game with the content that is going to be called a 1.0 release. Putting aside what was promised that didn't make it into the game, what's currently there will only get you a few hours in, before you're wondering what there is left to do.

It has a few clever ideas in there, and there is a very lovely amount of polish to the product--which is why it seems like such a waste.

I wish DoubleFine the best of luck for their other projects.

column8:
Since everyone's reviews are solely their views on Double Fine's recent announcement, I'll go ahead and take a look at the game in its current state.

As it is right now, Spacebase DF-9 shouldn't be called anywhere near completed.  I mean, the game works and all but there are a lot of glaring problems with it.  After a few runs through the game, I couldn't help but notice that every space sector you play in has almost zero differences between them.  The astro density determines how much asteroid is in your area to mine from, which is appreciated, but it hardly makes up for everything else.  The threat level has very little difference, as it apparently suggests how often your base gets showered on by meteors and debris, while warpgate proximity indicates how often you get potential new residents passing by.  What is evidently missing is where Raider occurrences would be placed, since they happen fairly regularly.

The Raiders themselves are stupendously overpowered.  The raiding parties vary between one and three Raiders that *will* decimate your population, no matter how well-trained your Security staff is.  The reason for this is because they tank damage like it's nothing while killing a majority (if not all) of your residents in less than five shots each.  The defensive turrets don't offer much by way of defense.  As the camera is locked to only one perspective, you only have the option to face the turrets downward (i.e. towards the bottom of the map) to either the left or right directions.  Seriously, you can't really use them to shoot at the approaching vessels since they have to be *inside* the base.

The base amenities are also a joke as follows:
- Despite having oxygen capacity for X number of people, the second I fill the base to capacity, the oxygen recyclers eventually fail as if I was overbooked (despite each recycler to be working perfectly at roughly 80-85% durability).  This caused my residents to panic and run around, abandoning all jobs and waiting until they either starved to death (because they used up all of the matter in stock) or waited until the next Raider party exterminated them all.
- The bar doesn't offer much, since it's the only thing that works in the Pub zone.  I have seen neither the fridge nor stove used at all so they're essentially useless.
- I set up a Reserch Zone and set a tech to research but my Scientist was busy doing everything else while on duty rather than actually research anything.


Overall, the game pretty much sucks since each playthrough is just the same thing: see how big your base can get before Raiders kill them all.  And given how Double Fine's treating the game now, I'd have to agree with everyone else.  The developers are basically dropping the project and turning the rest of the game's development over to the community after announcing that they're releasing the source code for the scripts and pushing the game out the door with a 1.0 full release version.  Avoid this game and pick up somthing better instead, like the classic StarTopia or even Prison Architect (which I also have). Spacebase DF-9 is simply a waste of time and money.

The reason for this is because they tank damage like it's nothing while killing a majority (if not all) of your residents in less than five shots each.  The defensive turrets don't offer much by way of defense.  As the camera is locked to only one perspective, you only have the option to face the turrets downward (i.e. towards the bottom of the map) to either the left or right directions.  Seriously, you can't really use them to shoot at the approaching vessels since they have to be *inside* the base.

The base amenities are also a joke as follows:
- Despite having oxygen capacity for X number of people, the second I fill the base to capacity, the oxygen recyclers eventually fail as if I was overbooked (despite each recycler to be working perfectly at roughly 80-85% durability).  This caused my residents to panic and run around, abandoning all jobs and waiting until they either starved to death (because they used up all of the matter in stock) or waited until the next Raider party exterminated them all.
- The bar doesn't offer much, since it's the only thing that works in the Pub zone.  I have seen neither the fridge nor stove used at all so they're essentially useless.
- I set up a Reserch Zone and set a tech to research but my Scientist was busy doing everything else while on duty rather than actually research anything.


Overall, the game pretty much sucks since each playthrough is just the same thing: see how big your base can get before Raiders kill them all.  And given how Double Fine's treating the game now, I'd have to agree with everyone else.  The developers are basically dropping the project and turning the rest of the game's development over to the community after announcing that they're releasing the source code for the scripts and pushing the game out the door with a 1.0 full release version.  Avoid this game and pick up somthing better instead, like the classic StarTopia or even Prison Architect (which I also have). Spacebase DF-9 is simply a waste of time and money.

column8:
i have had this game since start of early access and i loved it till the 0.6 update since then i have yet, thru hours of trying, to get a base up and started.
eithe i get multiple space debrie showers, and no im not in a high density zone was actualy using low desity ones, that either destroy my seed pod and i have no power or a raider get a shot on one of my people and he dies in an airlock doorway or some other glitch causes 3-4 colonists to just get stuck in an airlock and suffocate.
this game is FAR from complete and if they do not fix this i can only hope a mod author, God bless this soul, can, the game is far too difficult early on, i cant even imagine late game bases, but now i know why i can't find ANY current videos, lets play or otherwise.
me recomendation to anyone thinking of buying this game... Don't... sad to say cause i loved it when i first got it but now it's just too hard to get started, and thier is no way to adjust difficulty other than what you pick for your zone....

column8:
Since the original Early Access, barely any features have been added, and updates were months apart. The game is far from complete (and even further from what was promised), even though DoubleFine seems to think it will be from just adding a tutorial, wrap up the major bugs, and calling it "1.0".

DF continues to look highly mismanaged, especially financially. E.g. Broken Age was supposed to work with $400k funding. They got six times that and still they "ran out of money" and had to release what they had as "Act 1" (i.e. "Incomplete game, part 1").

This was the last time I trusted DF to make a good game with my money. The only time DF is getting any money from me is if they've actually released the game with all its features, and even then I'll think twice if there's nothing better I can do with my money. Like lighting it on fire. I get more enjoyment out of watching a brief flame than playing this husk of a dream of a game.

column8:
I was initially excited for the game. A sim colony game in space. What's not to like? I used to play Startopia (awesome!) and Space Colony (pretty good!) so I was pumped for another game of the kind. 
I like that the game does not take itself too seriously. You got funny dialogues, weird aliens, and spacebook. It makes for a comfortable feel too it. The colors are vibrant and the interaction between crew members are kinda funny. 
The ability to create your own base and style it the way you want is also very interesting. It makes for a unique base layout each time you make a new game. 

And then there are the things that bother me. First, for a base that supposed to feel like home, there's very little items you can put in a room. A potted plant, a monitor, a dresser, a rug, some shelves, and a couple of neon signs are your ONLY decorations. There isn't even any way you can recolor it so you're stuck with the same items in every room. 
Second, You can only rotate the camera from north to east facing. That will apply to every item too. It's really frustrating as it limits your design option.
Third, There are still a lot of bugs or unfinished issues (that they might address in the future) No matter what you do at the moment, your base will fail either due to depressed crew members that results into raging and destruction of rooms and equipment or raiders killing everybody even if your security personel had all the upgrades available. Some suggested that you put a decorative object almost every other tile to stave off depression but we shouldn't have to do that. You also had that design issue wherein the item looks like it's floating rather than attached to the wall. Crew members can actually go behind it (i.e. Food replicator, monitor)

Ultimately, I felt like I was ripped off. To put more context, Doublefine did say that they 'might' add more based on the development map that they laid out but with the current and future content (1.0) that will come out, it is wholly unreasonable for the 30$ they are asking. It felt like they just gave up midway through.
The worst thing about this is that since they are giving the community access to the source code, they now wash their hands off it. It is now the responsibility of the community to make the game great. Oh sure, they said they'll be sticking around...for bug fixes. 
I knew there were dangers of buying early-access games but I couldn't stop myself. Now I regret it. Don't make the same mistake

column8:
This is not a review of Spacebase DF-9, this is a review of Double Fine and their recent practices.  Below is an exact quote of post I made in the Spacebase DF-9 forums - (I give myself full permission to use my original post):

"Double Fine has lost all of my faith. There is nobody to blame but myself, and I accept that responsibility, but I am also formally stating that I will not be buying any more Double Fine games. I should have seen the problem during the Broken Age development cycle. Even after fleecing thousands of backers on their Kickstarter project and earning an unprecedented amount of money for a single game development (ie. through Kickstarter, making millions of dollars), they failed to deliver a complete game. That was the first and only sign necessary, and I should have known then. 

Then, through their association with The Humble Bundle, they started making numerous other lofty promises - which I did not support based on the fact that they couldn't even finish Broken Age. However, somewhere in between all of that, and before the announcement that Broken Age was going to be released in two parts, I discovered Spacebase DF-9 and I really liked the look of it. Obviously, the folks at Double Fine were giving away keys like candy to every major reviewer and YouTube gamer out there, and the game looked like it would turn into something good. Unfortunately, although the game has evolved over that time since its somewhat buggy beginnings, Spacebase DF-9 still feels unfinished.

In the end, I realize now that I should not have supported Double Fine even though I believed that they were a studio of like-minded game creators and developers who loved games and were passionate about what they do. I was wrong, and spending money on their games is nobody's fault but my own. I do regret it now, but I've also learned from it and I promise never to make the same mistake again. I won't buy any other games made by Double Fine. I have nothing against the individuals at Double Fine, but it's blatantly obvious that Double Fine as a company, a studio, and a publisher, has mismanaged and misappropriated both their time and their money.

To think that Tim Schafer was waving wads of cash around (jokingly) after the first big Kickstarter, leaves me thinking that perhaps it wasn't a joke after all. Perhaps starting projects and then abandoning them, was all part of the plan. Maybe it was naive marketing and projection based on unrealistic sales forecasting. Or maybe it was the millions of dollars that were given, not only through Kickstarter but also The Humble Bundle, and at least a dozen other online gaming portals and retailers (including Steam), by the passionate gamers and hopeful individuals that wanted to see the "small company in a sea of big fish succeed", maybe all of that got to the heads of the people who are behind the decision making at Double Fine. Maybe it's one of those, or maybe it's none of the above. 

Either way, Iesson learned. I'm not going to cry about getting my money back, I'm just never going to buy another Double Fine game. There are too many other "small" games studios that thrive under tight budgets and that could actually use the support of enthusiastic fans and customers."

column8:
This game, like most everything on Steam Early Access, is a total scam. Basically:
1) Start Kickstarter campaign with good idea. Get funding.
2) Write something half-ass, then release it on Steam Early Access with the promise of its ongoing development.
3) When you finally decide to close up shop, ensure the community that development will continue and run a Steam sale.
4) A week later, announce that you've stopped development and give the game away for free.
5) PROFIT!

Steam, you should be ashamed of yourself.

There are other services that people may want to use:
http://www.gamersgate.com
http://www.gog.com
http://www.desura.com
http://www.greenmangaming.com
http://www.indiegamestand.com
http://www.humblebundle.com

column8:
Though this game had its development cut short, which was admittedly disappointing, its is still a solid game and one of the better city sims I have played in a while. So please, before judging solely on the fact that development was cut short, hear me out. If you wanna skip the points i will have a final verdict at the end

Pros
1. No preset rooms, you build how you want

2. Dialogue is rather humorous and reading people's thoughts normally gives me a good laugh.

3. The resource management is just right, not too complex, but not too easy either.

4. Since there are no templates you can really make your base yours. If you want the center of your base to be a nice dorm room thats totally doable. If you want to make it a huge club, all up to you!

5. The game keeps you on your toes and often provides great stories such as when one of my engineers went crazy and caught an oxygen recycler on fire and had to be taken down by security!

6. People interact and all have different opinions of each other. They may become best friends or end up knocking each other out!

7. Passing ships will signal you, you may recruit a bunch of aliens waking from their cryo chambers or tell raiders you're gonna kick their butts!

Cons
1. Raiders get a bit overpowered in later stages of the game

2. Morale is hard to regain after it drops and often leads to the end of your base

3. dialogue, while funny is quite limited. You will definitely see the same phrases more than once.

4. This game had insane potential, unfortunately many concept ideas that would have been great will now never be included

Final verdict: While it isnt a perfect game, spacebase possesses a lot of charm and an amazing amount of freedom. If you are a fan of sim games and think this may interest you, at least grab it on sale. Its a great sim game that has many disappointed fans who look at it for what it could have been rather than what it is

2. Dialogue is rather humorous and reading people's thoughts normally gives me a good laugh.

3. The resource management is just right, not too complex, but not too easy either.

4. Since there are no templates you can really make your base yours. If you want the center of your base to be a nice dorm room thats totally doable. If you want to make it a huge club, all up to you!

5. The game keeps you on your toes and often provides great stories such as when one of my engineers went crazy and caught an oxygen recycler on fire and had to be taken down by security!

6. People interact and all have different opinions of each other. They may become best friends or end up knocking each other out!

7. Passing ships will signal you, you may recruit a bunch of aliens waking from their cryo chambers or tell raiders you're gonna kick their butts!

Cons
1. Raiders get a bit overpowered in later stages of the game

2. Morale is hard to regain after it drops and often leads to the end of your base

3. dialogue, while funny is quite limited. You will definitely see the same phrases more than once.

4. This game had insane potential, unfortunately many concept ideas that would have been great will now never be included

Final verdict: While it isnt a perfect game, spacebase possesses a lot of charm and an amazing amount of freedom. If you are a fan of sim games and think this may interest you, at least grab it on sale. Its a great sim game that has many disappointed fans who look at it for what it could have been rather than what it is

column8:
Pretty sad what happened to this title. I bought it as an early access. It's barely playable, but has potential. The Double Fine cut production and ran with the money. The game went from a half finished Alpha test directly to a code complete product release in a matter of weeks? Sorry. Not buying it. Or, rather, wish I hadn't bought it. Double Fine once had a sterling reputation... it's gonna take a lot for them to recover from this one. I won't be giving them my trust any time soon.

Do not recommend.
