column8:
[h1]This is not [i]Early Access[/i] any more, it's more like [i]Early Abandonment[/i].[/h1]

[h1]At the Time of Writing[/h1]
[b]Game:[/b] Spacebase DF-9
[b]Price:[/b] $21.99*
[b]Genre:[/b] building/simulation
[b]Time Played:[/b] 25 hours
[b]Personal Enjoyment Rating:[/b] â˜ºâ˜»â˜»â˜»â˜»

[b]Links I Found Helpful**[/b]
A YouTube gameplay look by [b]Whole Brain Gaming[/b]. This video gives you a good idea of what the game is actually like to play as the narrator explores it. [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_2G33jDCyc0]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_2G33jDCyc0[/url]

A YouTube discussion by [b]Total Biscuit[/b]. His discussion will not only tell you a bit about all the drama surrounding this game, but youâ€™ll also see some of the gameplay. [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gAd8Ls8Mwl4]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gAd8Ls8Mwl4[/url] 

[h1]General[/h1]
For what little it is now worth, I did enjoy playing the game and exploring the changes in each new Alpha update. This game had a lot of potential and was very exciting. With gorgeous artwork, a decent attempt at UI design, atmospheric music, and an absolutely delightful sense of humour, all of which contributed to an interesting universe of different species and way of life. But the fact remains that this game was abandoned, never finished properly, and at the time of writing can not be considered a complete game.

They did go in and include a tutorial for the game, and I was very impressed with the tutorial until it suddenly ended. Although it felt like it ended abruptly and too soon, I can see why they did limit the information provided. If they donâ€™t leave you to figure out the other rooms and the way the spacebase generally functions then you would have played all there is to play of this game in the tutorial. Ultimately the tutorial just seems to highlight the lack of depth to the game.

Spacebase has a rocky history so far, and I feel I really must include a discussion of this so that you can make an informed decision. However, as you will see with the format of my reviews, there are plenty of sections which allow me to consider the game for itself regardless of the surrounding drama.

In the interests of full disclosure: I was an early access purchaser, and yeah, I did get burned with this game. My experience with Spacebase truly set my mind to never buy an early access game ever again, no matter how wonderful it looks and tempting it seems. Nothing is a sure bet, and I will only be spending my money on finished products from now on. I can accept that I took a risk by purchasing an EA game and that it did not pan out in this case, but the end result is still a bad experience with Spacebase and Double Fine by extension. Things did get very dramatic, but I donâ€™t think the company did a very good job of handling things. Iâ€™m not going to go on about it, so suffice it to say that Iâ€™m not an admirer of Double Fine any more. If you want more information regarding the drama I refer to, please check out TotalBiscuitâ€™s discussion on the subject.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
This is a base building game. You build a space station from basic building blocks (floors and walls) and zone different rooms. You fill those rooms with things like oxygen tanks, plants, beds, exercise equipment, tables, food, defence turrets, fire extinguishers, science labs, and matter converters. Mine asteroids to refine into matter, the basic building block/currency of the game in order to build everything else.

There isnâ€™t exactly a tech tree to this game, and there arenâ€™t any crafting recipes (although there is scientific research). It seems to be more about the simulation of how people interact with one another, but there are so many characters that join your base that itâ€™s impossible to really follow many interactions in a very meaningful way. So I end up concentrating on building the base and trying to see just how big I can make it. Once you get a vast crew though, things start lagging up and the bugs start to get obvious. Ultimately you will find that there is an imposed limit on how big a base you can create and keep running not by design, but because (I'm afraid I must repeat) this game wasn't really completed.

I really desperately wish that there was a blueprint function (like in prison architect) so that one could plan their base out before starting construction.

[h1]Controls[/h1]
Although you can use the mouse to do everything, there are thankfully plenty of hotkeys. Some of them arenâ€™t as intuitive as I might like, but I got used to them over the course of many hours of play. I found the camera controls to be fairly good, with my most appreciated camera functionality being the ability to pan around. Itâ€™s also always a plus to have a simple pause/start button to hit, which is good old spacebar.

[h1]Storyline[/h1]
I canâ€™t say there is much of a storyline. I think the original intention for the game was to immerse yourself in the lives of the different people on the base and sort of imagine your own story. However, there isnâ€™t sufficient depth and breadth to the rest of the game to allow you to direct any sort of imaginary storyline. It was an interesting concept which didnâ€™t really get developed or thought through well enough.

[h1]Sound[/h1]
I really like the sound in this game. The music is quite atmospheric (appropriate to the universe they created) and interesting to listen to. It may get repetitive after a while, but it is more like it fades into the background of your awareness rather than becoming irritating. Meanwhile, the sound effects are pretty much functional, nothing much to warrant remark.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
The artwork in this game is really very good. Itâ€™s certainly got a specific style to it, however that style is stuck to throughout and that consistency helps to establish a weird and wonderful universe. I really only have good things to say about the graphics, itâ€™s a shame that all this creative work is now trapped in the wrapper of the rest of the game. Alas.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[b]+ [/b]huge potential, great concept
[b]+ [/b]easy to read and navigate the UI
[b]+ [/b]gorgeous artwork
[b]+ [/b]interesting universe
[h1]Cons[/h1]
[b]- [/b]EA = Early Abandonment
[b]- [/b]an unfinished game
[b]- [/b]no real end goal
[b]- [/b]not enough depth to make it a decent sandbox
[b]- [/b]still rather buggy

[h1]Help Me Help You[/h1]
[b]If you did not find this review helpful,[/b] I would really appreciate your constructive criticism - tell me why it wasnâ€™t helpful for you. Itâ€™s my hope to make the reviews that I do take the time to write up, as helpful as they possibly can be.

[h1]Rothana's Steam Review Archive[/h1]
For those that are interested in seeing more of my reviews, I have set up an archive of them at an external website. I don't earn anything off of this at all, it's just a little side project that I add to when I can. Steam won't let me create a direct link though, so you'll need to make your own way to the URL I describe now: [b]rothana dot weebly dot com[/b]

[b]Footnotes[/b]
[b]*[/b]Any prices that I mention are in CDN because that is what I see.
[b]**[/b]I will not be keeping an eye on whether the links are up to date, so if they are broken I apologise. Remember that these are external websites and I'm just trying to be helpful - I'm not responsible for the content on the other end.

[b]Edit Log[/b]
1/03/2015 formatting and additional writing

column8:
Sadly, no. I can't recommend it. Probably you've already seen all the info related to the "from alpha to release scandal". Probably you'll see some discussions about "the risk of Early Access" and things like that. Point is: If you pay 25 bucks, you want a full game. Period. It's not a 25-dollar bet, or a 25-dollar donation. We expected good communication. We expected one update a month. Amnesia Fortnight was made public to tell Double Fine which games we wanted. Spacebase came out second on the voting. It seems that wasn't enough.

In short, we feel betrayed. Not the end of the world, okay. We'll move on eventually. But we won't forget. Now we can see Double Fine taking money from Sony to make a remastered version of a 16-year old graphic adventure. That's their line of thought now. Well, they can keep it to themselves.

column8:
It showed potential, but development was slow and lacked any realistic time-table. These hinted at a small team with less than spectacular plan for development which either lacked in the resorces or the drive to produce new content and polish old content.

As a result the game is to be released in a rough and not-quite-ready state which should be avoided.

It has a charming exterior and had the promise to be a game that had a number of interesting interplaying mechanics but the final months of production lacked the feeling of enthusiasm that was present in the games early days of development.

Much like the game itself, realy.

column8:
EDITED: My previous negative review stated it would remain negative until Tim Schafer released a statement of apology. He did so, and although it didn't addrerss every issue I had with the way things were handled, it did address a lot of them and was an apology I felt was sincere. 

The harshness of my previous review was due to anger seeing an early access game come to a sudden halt (Tim Schafer does address the lack of communication and the lessons learned from this experience. He specifically apologizes for the communication issue which was my main problem. Had there been communication about the state of things before hand, I would not have been upset. I would have been sad, but not angry. So I appreciate the fact that Double Fine realized their mistakes and apologized for them.) -- it was not, and I feel bad for not making this clear in my past review, but anger clouded my communication skills... -- it was not a negative review targeting the quality of the game.

In fact, I really enjoy Spacebase, which is why I became angry. It's a game that from the beginning of early access, was getting things right. Yeah, there was rough patches, but the core of the game and vision was there and I was excited. And whether or not the finished game met all the "features we want in the game" dev list or not was not an issue for me. And my anger was not really aimed at the devs of Spacebase, really. I was angry at Tim Schafer. I'm stating this due to the amount of anger that has been directed at the developers. I think they've done a great job developing the game. Communication was not there. But that was an issue with Double Fine as a whole, not just this one development team. 

So, going from a thumbs down to a thumbs up becaue of an apology might seem odd to some people. And that's my fault for not being clear as to why it was getting at thumbs down. It's a good game. As it stands. And I'm sure it will be better when they release the last update. Am I sad that they weren't able to achieve what they wanted to? Yeah. But is the game bad because they weren't able to work on the game actively for a few more years? No. It's a good game.

I'll be curious to see what happens when the community has the ability to create mods and etc and curious to see how if Double Fine keeps an eye on things and maybe works out a way to be there in the form of a helpful guide to the community down the road.

Developers of Spacebase, you made a great game and I'm sorry you were unable to work on it as long as you wanted to. As long as I wanted you to, as well. And thank you, Tim Schafer, for you apology. It wasn't "perfect", but it was an apology I felt was sincere and that's what I needed. And yes, I know that addressing the devs and Tim Schafer in my review is silly (I don't expect them to read this.) It's what I want to include in my review. *shrugs*.

column8:
DO NOT PURCHASE

They pulled a Towns on us.  This game is no where near complete and has tons of bugs.  However, Double Fine has announced they are ceasing development on the game and releasing it with one more fix. 

This game still plays like an Alpha, but Double Fine is just tossing out an incomplete release and washing their hands of it.

Sham on you Double Fine, and especially you Tim Schafer.  You know this is a raw deal.

column8: How does it jump from Alpha 6 too full release in less than a month? It skips beta leaves out all the content they said they would put in. column8:
Barely a game, and about to go into a V1.0 release with no new content to be added other than tutorials and some set goals. They're "generously" releasing the LUA code, meaning you can modify the existing game - but not the engine, and there's barely anything there to tinker with and no real emergent situations.

Yet another KS/EA grab for cash by Double Fine. Between this, the Broken Age management fiasco and the gross misrepresentation of Brutal Legend in the demo version, Schafer is not getting another dollar of my money.

Avoid, do not buy. Not worth $10, let alone $25.

column8:
Review for version 1.01

Its fuckin horrible. Still buggy as hell. Still very little to do. The goals are pointless and more like achievements (get 50 people, kill 50 raiders, build every object).

My 45 minute experience on the new 'release' included such highlights as:

My best tech sufficating because they were outside shooting at nothing, and nothing that I did stopped them (changed role, cuff, send to infirm/brig)

The 'holdables' littering that map from the countless people that just 'died' for bugger all reason.

A part of my station catching fire, and 5 people dying because I locked the room down and opened it to space to clear the O2. What did everyone do? Jump in their suits and go around through the open door, start fighting the fire AND THEN GET OUT OF THEIR SUITS IN A ROOM WITH NO O2.

Fire animation remains after the fire is extingished. Now my base has a bunch of camp fires around it.

In a area with 'Very Low' raiders, had 10 raids between new colonists (not including the potental raids in the form of message that I know the answer to to make them not raid)

Colonists are still stupidly difficult to please. I have to click through 3 or 4 menus to figure out whats wrong with them.

Construction workers die pulling down a wreak because it had a alien in it. The alien attacked and killed a construction worker (who, I would like to point out I cant control to make him run away) dispite that fact that the 'room' the alien was in was open to space along the entire lenght of it. About 15 squares open to space. After killing my construction worker the alien ran FURTHER into the room, and only then was sucked into space.

Raiders still use the airlock, which means to beat them: wait until the raiders desuit in airlock > pause > unzone room > lock door to base > open door to space > they get sucked out. There is no reason at all to ever fight these raiders. This is the single best way to beat them. And it sucks.

Honestly Ive got like 100 more gripes just from the last 45 minutes I've been playing the new update, but I can sum it all up with:

Game sucks. Feel half finished (because it is). Wish I didnt buy it. Dont buy it.

column8:
Full disclosure: I had fun in the ~30 hours I spent on various Alpha builds, but it is by no means a complete game. It's pretty, and looks promising, but is ultimately shallow and lacks replayability.

With Doublefine's decision to go straight from Alpha 6 to 1.0, I don't think I can recommend this game to anyone at it's current pricepoint. 

Save your money and wait for a 90% off sale if you're at all interested in it. $2.50 is about the right price for the features this game will ship with.

So this game is supposedly complete.... I dont see it, I bought it knowing it was incomplete, they added like, 2-3 features and that was it.

its like dwarf fortress, set in space, with nothing to do except build your very limited base, and then let the game play itself, once the base is built, the game is pretty much over.

nothing in terms of adventuring, just wait until something shows up in your neighborhood, and I guess you can react to it if you want, not that it matters.

Double Fine, you guys.... how do you go from psychonauts, to Brutal Legend, to the adventures of 3.3 million dollars, to making a game with less content than other games still in alpha.

column8:
A few months ago I likely would have recommended this game. While development was fairly slow, they were making progress and the game was getting better. I was hopeful for the future as the game had, in my opinion, a very solid foundation.

With the news that this game is now only getting one more major patch; I can no longer in good faith recommend it to anybody. This game was initially touted as a 'Sci-Fi Dwarf Fortress," but make no mistake, it offers nowehere near the complexity or longevity, The feature list is incredibly underwhelming for a sim game of it's type, and you will very quickly lose interest in the little this game has to offer. After a few hours you will have experienced absolutely everything. They could have done so much more with the concept, (and planned to,) but nothing in this game will strike you as particularly unique or groundbreaking. The fact of the matter is this game seriously underdeliverd on the features that were going to distinguish it from other games in the genre. You can go back and look at the archived dev plans to get an idea.

Of course, this was always the danger of early access. There's no guarantee that the game you fund will make it to it's fully realized state. If a game becomes unprofitable; they'll ship it in it's current state regardless of planned features. As far as I know, this is the highest profile early access game that has seriously underdelivered. Let it serve you as a warning when buying other early access titles. After this I don't think I'll be putting money behind any more games that have a chance to be released so woefully unfinished.

column8:
Developer Double Fine has posted that the final release of the game will be version 1.0 and that no more versions will be released.  This comes at a time when the game is still in alpha and lacks considerable depth.  Be warned, if you are buying this game after 9/18/2014 you are potentially buying a dead game.  You can plow through what little content is there in an hour and from Double Fine's last post it seems unlikely much content will be added for the "final" 1.0.

--

Spacebase DF-9 is an interesting play on the Dwarf Fortress formula.  Instead of carving out a kingdom from rock you are inversely adding a "kingdom" to the vacuum of space.  Similar to Dwarf Fortress you are given little control over your citizens.  Instead you play the role of macromanager, assigning citizens to tasks and watching them go about their day.  Certain events will trigger at random times forcing you to deal with raiders, parasites, killbots, and meteorites.

While all of this sounds fun in theory the problem is that Spacebase DF9 is competing with 10 years of Dwarf Fortress development.  As of Alpha version 6 there is still relatively little to do.  You can speed run through an hour of gameplay and basically see all that Double Fine has to offer, afterwards the game offers little reason to continue playing.  Unlike Dwarf Fortress, Spacebase misses the boat on simulated empire building.

Don't let my number of in-game hours sway you, 40 of those hours are from idling the game while I did work.

column8:
Spacebase DF-9 is a fun little rogue-like Dwarf-Fortress-ish game where you build and control a base in space, while fighting off potential invaders. It is a good-looking game filled with potential that is never quite realized and, in the end, it eventually feels very shallow.

It's easy to recommend Spacebase as an amusing little distraction, but not as an in-depth game of strategy or exploration. Unfortunately, it is in a price-range that demands far more of it. I can not recommend this game at or anywhere near its full price of $25 USD. There are numerous similar titles out there that are only a few bucks or even completely free that accomplish far more.

Pretty, but empty.

column8:
Don't buy this game. It is a broken promise and incomplete.

You guys (DOUBLEFINE) say you are not-fly-by-nighters; just last update you said youâ€™d keep us in the loop going forward because there was silence for the weeks prior.

...then you pull the plug completely?

The game is nowhere near finished - itâ€™s potential is untapped. Those of us who bought into early access to support the vision and take part in the development of something special have now had the rug pulled out from under us as you guys cut and run.

I can see this happening with any number of development studios but I would never have thought DoubleFine would join the list. Now Iâ€™ve seen it all.

Have you considered the impact this will have on gamer confidence? On trust? What sort of message do you think it sends that you effectively say â€˜thatâ€™s it guys weâ€™re out - you finish the game yourselves!â€™

The whole Amnesia Fortnight process is undermined - nobody will care now because they will know that whatever is chosen may or may not be finished. The veracity of the process, the thrill of the journey and the move to a final productâ€¦ none of it matters when you donâ€™t deliver.

Disappointed doesnâ€™t begin to describe it. I never post on these forums - but I had to come and say my piece in this instance. And while the mods may desperately fly to your defense - we all know on this oneâ€¦ your conduct is indefensible.

I expected more from DF, from Mr Schafer.

Suffice to say - youâ€™ve lost a fan; and probably a customer. But itâ€™s the former that hurts the most.

column8:
In this game you essenitally layout rooms on a 2d grid made to look like space.  People randomly come up and ask to join your station where you have to keep them alive and happy and also use them to help keep your station running.  Sometimes you get invaders.  The core features to make it a base-building game are there.

While the developers had some good ideas, they did not get fleshed out nearly enough and there is very little content otherwise.

With the announcement of release just a month or two away it's clear that the developer abandoned this title well before it was able to reach it's potential.   Fun for a couple hours but not worth the $25 asking price.  If you can grab it for 5 bucks or less it may be worth it.

column8:
Here's a game that had great potential. Then, after alpha 6, the developers suddenly decided to skip beta, fix the remaining bugs and call it 1.0 and let imaginary coders from the community finish the game by releasing the source code. They'll still take your money, though, thankyouverymuch.
In its current state, the game is bug-ridden, which is understandable since it is (was) still in development, and you'll be lucky if you can play for more than a couple of hours before you encounter a game-breaking bug.
When/if said bugs get fixed in "1.0", you'll get a bug free empty shell of what could have been a great simulation game. It'll be fun for a while and then you'll realize most of the advertised content and features have never been implemented.
There are probably some valid reasons why Double Fine chose to abandon this game, but in the end, it also means that they chose to let down everyone who chipped in to help funding its development. Not a very nice thing to do.

TLDR: Don't waste your money, there are many good simulation games out there that have actually been finished.
column9:
Here's a game that had great potential. Then, after alpha 6, the developers suddenly decided to skip beta, fix the remaining bugs and call it 1.0 and let imaginary coders from the community finish the game by releasing the source code. They'll still take your money, though, thankyouverymuch.
In its current state, the game is bug-ridden, which is understandable since it is (was) still in development, and you'll be lucky if you can play for more than a couple of hours before you encounter a game-breaking bug.
When/if said bugs get fixed in "1.0", you'll get a bug free empty shell of what could have been a great simulation game. It'll be fun for a while and then you'll realize most of the advertised content and features have never been implemented.
There are probably some valid reasons why Double Fine chose to abandon this game, but in the end, it also means that they chose to let down everyone who chipped in to help funding its development. Not a very nice thing to do.

TLDR: Don't waste your money, there are many good simulation games out there that have actually been finished.

column8:
This game is kind of like Dwarf Fortress in space, a little simulator where you design rooms and manage the roster for your space station.  You don't control the citizens directly, but instead you put down work orders, and the citizens will handle it on their own.  You sketch out rooms and order furniture and so on and your citizens place it.

The first few mintues of the game were a lot of fun for me.  You're kicked out of your life support pod drifting in deep space and have to build a little self sustaining environment with an airlock and some life support systems before your citizens run out of air (about 5 mins).  This was an encouraging first glance for me, because it's pretty hard and will probably require a few resets if you don't know what you're doing, and the systems seemed interesting and complex.  Eventually, though, I figured it out and started branching out, putting up a refinery to allow my miners to mine nearby asteroids, using the materials to build a residence and a bar and a garden and a lab and stock it with furniture.

And then the game ended.

I don't mean it dumped me to a "game over" screen or anything, there just wasn't anything left to do.  Once you've got a half dozen rooms down and functioning, which takes maybe an hour, there's nothing else you can do except wait for your science team to sloooooowly research some unnesescary upgrades, or maybe have your security team scrap with some raiders (note that this isn't an RTS, combat in this game is just a matter of setting a point for your security team to defend and maybe they will if they're not on break or hungry or tired or sad).  Sometimes a derelict will show up and you can... well, tear it down, nothing else to do with them really.

If you've ever played Dwarf Fortress, basically imagine that game but with no workshops.  You can make rooms and designate areas and place furniture, but there's no crafting system, no economy, no trade, resources are all boiled down to a single currency which is used to buy everything from walls to furniture.  The game just has no depth at all, and it's competing with some of the most complex and deepest simulations on the market right now.

The devs seem to have responded to this by ramping up the challenge, which makes things a bit frustrating.  Colonies can die from parasites before you get a doctor, waves of raiders can annihilate an underequipped security force, and once things start to fail, it's pretty much a chain reaction to an abandoned base.  Colonists freak out and refuse to do their jobs so vital equipment isn't maintained or repaired so colonists freak out even harder and things just spiral downward.  For example, if the air supply gets low, colonists will freak out rather than do their jobs, so if the area with the life support systems has air problems, you can't ever fix it because whoever goes in there is going to panic instead of fixing the air generator, and the problems get worse.  And this doesn't really do much to fix the problem with the game being short, because once you've got whatever it is you need to counter them, then they're not that big a deal.  

The 1.0 update added a lot of nice features, but the game still has serious issues with longevity.  There are still occasional glitches with draw order and some AI issues, but the game works pretty well mostly.  I've only played a bit, but pathing does seem improved and the interface does make things clearer now.

I don't want to sound excessively negative, this isn't the worst game ever.  I had a lot of fun with it.  It's just really short, and the asking price is kind of high.  On sale, for $5, I'd say this is a good deal.  At full price, I don't think it's worth it.  I'd recommend looking at something like Startopia or Space Colony or grabbing something like Gnomoria or Dwarf Fortress if you're not in love with the sci-fi aesthetic.  All of these games are cheaper, deeper, and more fun in the long term than DF-9.

column8:
This game will never-ever be worth the full price now that DF have announced that they're abandoning development. It MIGHT be worth a quater of the price IF the community gets into modding it to fix serious issues and add much needed content.

[b]MIGHT
IF[/b]


---
I guess i should update this review now that the game has been released and has been updated to 1.05.

I still play this game, and at the time of the edit to this review, i've invested about 70 hours into countless new games. 

The updates have helped a whole lot, but the game still has some playability issues: 
Doctors will often ignore corpses, which leads to bad morale, which leads to violence which leads to drastic crew loss.

Raider events are too randomised, and can often lead to base failure in the very early game, or general drastic crew loss.

The added raider mega-fleet event is a good idea in principal, but is vastly over-powered.

Construction crew often take huge detors to the next block to be built when in space, which can lead to a new base failing, or causing unrecoverable crew loss in the very early game.

Even with my reasonable system spec and the relative simplicity of the game, it tends to lag-out far too much.

Generally; Base failure seems to be down to chance rather than skill.

[b]There are positives, however[/b]
There are mods appearing now, which is great. The community is addressing balence issues and adding reaseatch and similar. 

Workshop support is still very much missing, sadly.

[b]Overall:[/b]
Has the potential to be a reasonable casual game, but really isn't worth the full price at all. Perhaps at a quater the price, it woulnd't be so bad.

column8:
I payed $25.00 CAD for an Early Access game. More than most EA games but not something I have a problem with so long as they stick to their goals and finish the game. I excpected that since it was a known company, Double Fine, I would be safe from cash grab type marketing.
It has already been stated they have NO INTENTIONS of finishing the game. They have cut development with what features they have in at the moment. They WILL NOT finish their planned features listed here: http://web.archive.org/web/20131018054131/http://spacebasedf9.com/devplans

The game is horribly broken, incomplete, buggy, and they have no intentions of finishing it. 
I expected more from double fine. Do not purchase.

Edit: To this day I have not purchased another Double Fine game, and I suggest you follow the same path. Vote with your wallet.

column8: Stay away at all cost. This game is now set to release in October 2014, going from alpha 6e to full release. This is the prime example of why you should think twice before throwing your money away at early access games. There is hardly anything to do in the game other than mine asteroids, build a few room types and research a few things. There is no mid-game and no end-game. Definitely not worth the asking price.

column8: From the first day up until weeks before the end I was assured that my apprehension about this game was unwarranted. Doublefine has quickly gained a reputation for not satisfying the end consumer and creating products that are merely designed to appear flashy and draw sales and this game is no exception. Billed as Dwarf Fortress in space, with the lofty promises of away team missions and much much more. This game is now being released with barely any content and over a year spent making it barely playable and none of the interesting promises of the roadmap. On top of that they managed to cash in on it not once, not twice but three times. With the Amnesia Fortnight Bundle people actually paid money for the concept to be developed. Then with the kickstarter, people paid the money for the game to be developed. And with early access on steam, people actually paid for these devs to lead extravangant lifestyles. They're software designers in San Fransisco. THey are geniuses. You've gotta tease that genius out with sweet tens of thousands of dollars. It isn't their fauilt the money dried up, and besides they are needed more elswhere. On the next flashy soon to flop Double Fine project. Look out for it!

column8:
This game is lacking tons of content. Which is understandable for an early access title. During early access they rarely put out new content. Plus rumor has it that they want to go straight from Alpha 6 to version "1.0" and release it as complete. Which is more than a little odd. They even stripped their roadmap page of planned features to go with this.

Edit 28th October 2014: Double Fine started giving out free copies of their other game "Hack 'n' Slash" to owners of Space Base DF-9, as some sort of apology I would assume. That doesn't change my opinion that this game is unfinished, but at least they did something to appease their customers.

column9: For a R$45.99 game, you get a game that should have cost R$10.00. This high price is due to the developers wanting to implement a lot of things, and everyone who bought it was thinking about this, about the game's future. It really seemed good, but the developer just announced that they will stop development and release it as is, with only bug fixes. I feel ripped off. I'm sure they wouldn't have done this if it weren't for an early access game that has already sold well, or at least they would have priced the game correctly. But honestly, even for a R$10.00 game, it doesn't have much. You build the infrastructure, get a bunch of people in, and that's it, there's nothing left to do. I'll never buy an early access game again, and I think Steam should remove this type of sales model. If even Double Fine, who are supposed to be the "good guys," did this...

column8:
AVOID AT ALL COSTS!

This game is unfinished, buggy and has just had the plug pulled with no explanation whatsoever. All this after a couple of weeks ago they stated they would never do that and would ensure the game is finished and done well.

In its current state it has minimal content that may keep you busy for a couple of hours or until you crash. There are major bugs and missing features that leaves this game a mere outline of what could have been a decent game.

Its overpriced and there are far more value for money buys to be had on mobiles let alone the PC.

Stay clear!

column8:
Unfortunately, the game is being released WAY before it's ready.

The worst part is DoubleFine is playing it off like it's such a wonderful thing, and aren't we all so lucky. Why not just tell us "Sorry, we didn't get enough money to continue development, but here's what we'll do - giant bugfix/polish patch, release sourcecode. We hope you guys can make the game we couldn't afford to!" That would at least have had the respect for the players and Early Access supporters that seems "right" to me. Deleting the old "roadmap" seems particularly dishonest at this point as well.

However, that's just me with my silly morals and standards and respect and honesty. I don't have to run a business and make decisions like "let's pretend this is great when it's actually crap." Sorry, DoubleFine, but you've managed to massively damage my opinion of you with the way you're handling this. I know you're just publishing GangBeasts, but there's now NO WAY I'm putting money into that until it's actually finished. And if too many people feel that way, will it stagnate and suffer the same fate as DF-9?

-----

I'll try to make an update to this review once the so-called-1.0 version comes out, and see if it's actually some working skeleton of a game.

[b]As it is now, DO NOT PURCHASE THIS GAME AT ANY PRICE.[/b]

It simply does not work as a game. Stuff happens and your base will die, and there's nothing you can do about it. Just after the latest patch version, I lost an entire base to one raider, because the security team was either standing around and getting shot, or running away (and getting shot). None of them ever bothered to attack the intruder. Not even once. Your base will catch fire from asteroid impacts and your inhabitants will gleefully panic-run right into the flames and die, instead of grabbing the fire extinguishers you've placed across the base and actually doing something constructive. Someone will decide that they absolutely need to do floor pushups right in your airlock door, and then everybody will suffocate to death.

These things are quite forgivable in an alpha game. Frustrating, but understandable. It's alpha, I get it. Things might be broken or unfinished. I'm fine with that. But if ANY of this crap manages to slip into the 1.0 release? That's just garbage.

(Edit: Apparently The S-Word is too raunchy for a review. Sigh.)

----

[b]1.01 Update[/b]

It has improved nothing at all.

No. I absolutely do not recommend. It continues to just [i]not work[/i]. I started two bases today after the 1.01 patch, the one designed to "finish" the game. I see no significant improvements. Build orders are randomly followed, regardless of importance. Citizens start "running away" for no obvious reason. Random station boarding parties still utterly annihilate you base regardless of the number of security personnell you have assigned. Security teams clearing derelicts still seem to think that actually shooting the hostiles is a silly concept.

But hey, at least now there's a tutorial! A rather unnecessary one, since the game mechanics are not at all complicated, and I felt were very obviously conveyed through normal play. The problem isn't the players misunderstanding the game mechanics - it's that the game simply [i]doesn't f-ing work.[/i]

----

[b][i]Final[/i] Final recommendation:[/b]

DO NOT PURCHASE THIS. EVER.

[b]Secondary recommendation:[/b]

Never trust DoubleFine again. Only buy a product once it has been actually released, and you've tried it, and it actually works, and the community is being treated well. Do not give support (either financial or social) to companies that make bad decisions. And especially not companies that make bad decisions, then try to tell you how great their decisions actually were.
column9:
Unfortunately, the game is being released WAY before it's ready.

The worst part is DoubleFine is playing it off like it's such a wonderful thing, and aren't we all so lucky. Why not just tell us "Sorry, we didn't get enough money to continue development, but here's what we'll do - giant bugfix/polish patch, release sourcecode. We hope you guys can make the game we couldn't afford to!" That would at least have had the respect for the players and Early Access supporters that seems "right" to me. Deleting the old "roadmap" seems particularly dishonest at this point as well.

However, that's just me with my silly morals and standards and respect and honesty. I don't have to run a business and make decisions like "let's pretend this is great when it's actually crap." Sorry, DoubleFine, but you've managed to massively damage my opinion of you with the way you're handling this. I know you're just publishing GangBeasts, but there's now NO WAY I'm putting money into that until it's actually finished. And if too many people feel that way, will it stagnate and suffer the same fate as DF-9?

-----

I'll try to make an update to this review once the so-called-1.0 version comes out, and see if it's actually some working skeleton of a game.

[b]As it is now, DO NOT PURCHASE THIS GAME AT ANY PRICE.[/b]

It simply does not work as a game. Stuff happens and your base will die, and there's nothing you can do about it. Just after the latest patch version, I lost an entire base to one raider, because the security team was either standing around and getting shot, or running away (and getting shot). None of them ever bothered to attack the intruder. Not even once. Your base will catch fire from asteroid impacts and your inhabitants will gleefully panic-run right into the flames and die, instead of grabbing the fire extinguishers you've placed across the base and actually doing something constructive. Someone will decide that they absolutely need to do floor pushups right in your airlock door, and then everybody will suffocate to death.

These things are quite forgivable in an alpha game. Frustrating, but understandable. It's alpha, I get it. Things might be broken or unfinished. I'm fine with that. But if ANY of this crap manages to slip into the 1.0 release? That's just garbage.

(Edit: Apparently The S-Word is too raunchy for a review. Sigh.)

----

[b]1.01 Update[/b]

It has improved nothing at all.

No. I absolutely do not recommend. It continues to just [i]not work[/i]. I started two bases today after the 1.01 patch, the one designed to "finish" the game. I see no significant improvements. Build orders are randomly followed, regardless of importance. Citizens start "running away" for no obvious reason. Random station boarding parties still utterly annihilate you base regardless of the number of security personnell you have assigned. Security teams clearing derelicts still seem to think that actually shooting the hostiles is a silly concept.

But hey, at least now there's a tutorial! A rather unnecessary one, since the game mechanics are not at all complicated, and I felt were very obviously conveyed through normal play. The problem isn't the players misunderstanding the game mechanics - it's that the game simply [i]doesn't f-ing work.[/i]

----

[b][i]Final[/i] Final recommendation:[/b]

DO NOT PURCHASE THIS. EVER.

[b]Secondary recommendation:[/b]

Never trust DoubleFine again. Only buy a product once it has been actually released, and you've tried it, and it actually works, and the community is being treated well. Do not give support (either financial or social) to companies that make bad decisions. And especially not companies that make bad decisions, then try to tell you how great their decisions actually were.

column8:
UPDATE: So Double Fine finally pushed the '1.0 launch' and at least props to them for trying to repair some goodwill damage by offering up Hack N Slash (their recently launched game) for free to previous supporters (prior to 1.0) of this game. It takes a bit of the sting away though unfortunately I still wouldn't recommend this game at it's current price of 20 bucks.

In summary, Double Fine made a lot of faithful customers lose a lot of trust in them and I strongly advise anyone to carefully re-consider throwing money towards Double Fine for any of their future Early Access games.

ORIGINAL REVIEW: DO NOT buy this game and DO NOT buy from Double Fine until they can prove that they aren't an immature developer that renege on promises made by exploiting the community's goodwill.

You don't just go to v1.0 after sparse alpha updates and lack of any real content. Terrible planning, terrible cop out, and terrible damage to their reputation. I would rather recommend buying a $1 dollar completed Flash game 20 times instead of buying this.

column8:
I feel like I am jumping on a bandwagon, but whatever. 

The devs just bailed on the game, leaving me with mixed feelings. Releasing the source code is kind of nice, and at the same time is quite useless in itself.

This is a game which was "prototyped" in a fortnight. Which meant it was written on a language enabling quick prototyping. In this particular case, Lua, which I don't think is precisely the best programming language to develop a project so ambitious as this one was sold to us as being. What sold me the early alpha back in October 2013 was the vision. If I knew the vision was backed by that, ehm, [i]questionable[/i] technological foundations, well, certainly my scepticism about the whole enterprise would have been higher.

On the other hand, the writing was on the wall for all of us to see. The development team promised monthly major updates and a continuous stream of bug fixes between updates. That development wasn't going quite right for this title was obvious when those updates started to lack regularity, at some point after February 2014, right after the "Amnesia Fortnight". 

Indeed, Double Fine seemed to forget about this one, since the fortnight turned out to be a couple months. Since then there have been "major updates", but to be honest, I am not sure that the new features added since May are that interesting, well thought out or functional, as the "backbone" of the game. Which I now reckon hadn't changed much between February 2013 and February 2014.

I'll look forward to the source code release. It will be good to see how things were implemented, and probably will inspire others to take up the concept. It will also, to be blunt, allow to rewrite the f*cking thing using tools actually meant for this kind of job (say Unity and C#, or Unreal/Cry Engines and C++). In that sense, hats off to the devs of Spacebase DF-9 and to Double Fine for putting this into the public domain. 

Of course, this last paragraph will only make sense to people like me, who understand and appreciate the real hackers' ethics. 

What I don't appreciate [i]at all[/i] is that this comes out of the blue, without saying a "we're sorry but the early access revenue wasn't enough to support development". Which would have been a very a straight way to approach the community, without giving excuse to people to think that they have been duped. I also see some astroturfing going on: it seems like some community management person is trying very hard to spray a giant smiling emoji on top this. And failures like this one are sad.

So I'd say that Double Fine doesn't deserve a sale of this title unless 

[list]
[*] You appreciate the release of the source code to the public domain as an inherently good thing.
[*] You look forward to someone to take up the torch and actually take this ball all the way to the touchdown line.
[/list]

If you're just interested in a game that you can play now and you can get value for money, just stay away, and look out for that rewrite I mention above.

DISCLAIMER: if the source code turns out to come out with a very restrictive license, i.e. one that prevents people from doing what I suggest above, then I'll be sure to come back to this review and use very different terms.

column8:
devs announced they are gona finish it soon with 1.0 and that's it. I guess games go from Alpha to finished game now, no Beta needed :P No new stuff, no nothing.. horrable.. complete waste of money.
Instead of making the game better, after finishing the engine and ironing the whole game out, you were supposed to start adding lots more content. They just said it's up to modding community to add new stuff from now on and that's it..
But they should have improved it and added more content to draw in more players, especially ones that were undecided before they saw this scamm.. It had potential to be a really good game and would have become more popular with a bigger fan base and more money, but devs decided to be jerks..

they even changed the dev plan they had on their website, you can compare them here:

promising and cool plan - http://web.archive.org/web/20131018054131/http://spacebasedf9.com/devplans

cheaty scamming money grab plan they made last minute - http://spacebasedf9.com/devplans

I can't recommend spending money on this.. 
I'm glad I bought it on a discount, I learned more about early access and to not trust even devs that seemed ok..

column8:
Warning: AVOID.

Very sad to say this, but it seems that the developer is cutting this title loose. The store page says this is in Alpha. It is not. It is in final beta stages since they have just announced that after a round of bug fixes they will release version 1.0 in october and content updates will stop. 

The game had huge potential and I was under the impression this still had at LEAST a year left of updates, but sadly it seems like they are ditching it. What exsists today is the shell of a full title, a scant promise of something it could be after a lot longer in development, but Â£19 for this? Forget it. 

This is the first time I have been badly stung by Early Access and it has shaken my faith in it completely. I have huge respect for Double Fine, but I will NEVER buy any of their Early Access titles again (and I was so close to getting Gang Beasts). 

Just have to put this one behind me I suppose. Can't see how this won't hurt the developers Early Access reputation however.

Very disappointed.

For this price you will get 2h of playtime and after that there is NOTHING to do anymore exept getting a larger base...without any goal...just building more rooms. I`m deeply dissapointed right now. How this could happen out of nothing puzzles my mind. Especialy since Double Fine is developing this so no...they didnt run out of money.
Edit: http://web.archive.org/web/20131018054131/http://spacebasedf9.com/devplans
That was the plan. I know "nothing carved in stone" but half of it was not "worth it"? Seriously? 23â‚¬ for this?

Konnte es kurzzeitig auf meinem Mac spielen, bis ein Update es zerrissen hat. Die PC-Version zeigte seit je her einen openGL-Fehler an, obwohl alle Specs die empfohlenen Leistungen Ã¼bertreffen.
Auf dem Mac lief es ganz gut und hatte Ã„hnlichkeiten mit dem von mir geliebten Theme-Hospital. Da es angeblich nÃ¤chsten Monat als 1.0 rauskommen soll, werden die Entwickler wohl Rekordarbeit verrichten mÃ¼ssen, denn die Unspielbarkeit auf zwei Systemen (zumindest bei mir), spricht nicht unbedingt fÃ¼r einen ausgereiften Code. Zudem sind viele versprochene Inhalte noch nicht geliefert worden.
Wer sein GlÃ¼ck versuchen mÃ¶chte kann es tun, bis es aber (ich rede wieder von mir) Ã¼berhaupt spielbar ist, muss ich leider klar abraten...
column9:
I was able to play it briefly on my Mac until an update broke it. The PC version always showed an OpenGL error, even though all specs exceeded the recommended performance.
On the Mac, it ran quite well and bore similarities to my beloved Theme Hospital. Since it's supposedly coming out as version 1.0 next month, the developers will probably have to work hard, because the unplayability on two systems (at least on me) doesn't exactly speak for mature code. Furthermore, much of the promised content hasn't been delivered yet.
Anyone who wants to try their luck can do so, but until it's even playable (I'm talking about myself again), I'd unfortunately have to strongly advise against it...

column8: A great game that can be played casually or hours on end. Looking forward to future updates.

column9:
Quite a difficult game. He was banging his head against the wall a little too often. The game would have a lot of room for development. Unfortunately, the development of the game has been stopped. The latest supported version is 1.0, after which the game is finished and development ends. At the same time, the list of planned features disappeared from the internet, and of course not even a fraction of its features were ever made into the game. 

You should think twice about supporting Double Fine anymore.

Well, to tell the truth: Have they had to fix some programming errors. So there are still updates to the game. I don't think new features will be added to the game.

column8: The game is in alpha but a high alpha and is completely playable as is. There are a few bugs still being worked out and a great deal of content that is waiting to be added but it is still a good game now, with nothing game breaking after my long play times.

column9: The game is great, you can happily spend a few hours, but even if you don't get killed by invaders or asteroids, after 4-5 hours of play, the "locals" will kill each other. :) And by the way, a tip for those who play: when you run out of asteroids, you can earn resources by dismantling other people's ships. :)

column8:
This "game" is basically unplayable because you can't control the people in any direct way, and they're too stupid to do anything right. Also everything is broken far beyond the usual early access glitches.

EDIT: well I guess now they want to release the game without adding any of the features it should have had and still with worthless ai. They could have at least added micro-management so that we could make up for the ai issues, but NOPE.

column9:
[i]This part of the review was written after the game's official release:[/i]

It's a shame, but the developers decided to abandon their creation and released the game as unpolished as it was when it entered Early Access. I have nothing to add to the review I wrote back then. I would strongly advise against purchasing it after its release â€“ it's a complete waste of money.

[i]This part of the review was written before the game's official release:[/i]

Unfortunately, the game is still very rough. The core and concept are interesting (naturally, for those who enjoy this genre of games), but there are too many small but annoying flaws. There's no detailed tutorial to help you understand the basics; otherwise, you'll have to start over several times and try different approaches before you find a stable development model.

Citizens assigned to a particular job sooner or later stop doing it, even when absolutely necessary. Pieces of fabric thrown on the floor by miners, which are then welded to the floor and cannot be removed, becoming part of the interior. Guards who, when invaders appear, are the first to run, leaving the peaceful doctors and botanists a fighting chance (who, incidentally, manage to win!).

There are many more to list. Overall, the game is highly recommended, but I think it's best to wait for at least the Beta version, as the urge to play kicks in almost immediately after a couple of hours of play.

column8: If you are a fan of the Dungeon Keeper series, Theme Hospital or Evil Genius, then you will probably fall in love with Spacebase DF-9.
column9: If you are a fan of the Dungeon Keeper series, Theme Hospital or Evil Genius, then you will probably fall in love with Spacebase DF-9.

column8:
This is a potentially really good game. It does have the feeling of the old "Theme XYZ" games, and it has an overal oldschool feel, which is greatly appreciated.

The graphics are neat, gameplay is potentially superb and endless, there even is some subtle, underlying humour which makes life in space more tolerable. The audio is also fairly standard, but fitting and nice.

Unfortunately, at this early stage of development, the game is nigh unplayable. The AI is just, well, close to non-existant. "Events" are a tad too catastrophic and can easily lead to total failure (usually because AI doesn't do what it's supposed to, though). There is very little control over the space station's inhabitants' actions, there is no way to prioritize tasks. Occasional bugs will result in a lot of citizens dying for random reasons (eg, can't open a perfectly functioning door, or they won't come back from space when low on oxygen, and so on), whose corpses nobody will remove (again, AI failure). I'd say the AI  is what really needs some tweaking, right now.

All in all, the game has a very nice backbone and quite some flesh, along with a few interesting quirks, but needs a lot (A LOT) of polishing yet. I recommend you try this game with this in mind.

column9:
We built... built... and finally built it.
So, you're the "god of the space station." Your job is to look after the health and well-being of your citizens... But all your citizens are nuts! Suffocate in space with a piece of mined ore in their hands? Easy! Kill astronauts while doing push-ups in an airlock? Easy peasy! Burn to death through your own stupidity? Pfft...
And just how many idiot guards there are, armed with phaser rifles and clad in the best armor, who will run around the pirates and shout "help!"!!!
So what was I talking about...
The project has high potential; it's a bit rough around the edges, but overall, it's not bad. 9 out of 10, with ample room for future development.

October 1, 2014
P.S. Review update... greedy developers said, "We're releasing the game... screw the beta... And they'll cut out a lot of the promised features... Don't buy this game in that case, because the developers are pigs, and since further improvements to the game have been transferred to modders, they don't deserve your money.

column8:
Edit: I just found this amazing game Space Haven that has the potential to be everything SpaceBase DF9 should've been, and more! Sooo hyped!! http://bugbyte.fi/

It was really hard deciding whether to recommend it or not. Here's why I decided not to (followed by what I like):

At its current state (Alpha 6e) there are a few bugs I consider gamebreaking.
1. When exploring a derelict that for various reasons doesn't refill it's oxygen, citizens will walk around and even go there (!) - like technicians wanting to fix something, botanists if there is a garden, etc - until the oxygen is low at which point they start running around panicked. With no way to add oxygen, they do this until they die, often wiping out most or all of my security crew, along with a couple of other idiots who went there.

2. I can't seem to get them to calm down after throwing a tantrum. Most of the time, they wake up (or when they're released from the brig) and throw another. Rinse and repeat until someone kills them.

3. Technicians are quite useless at their work (which goes for all citizens, really, but it's most noticeable with the technicians). It takes forever to fix something.

4. (Related to 2) It's too damn hard keeping your crew happy. I just can't seem to do it, at all! 

Ok, so that's why I would not recommend the game at this point. If these things are fixed in a coming update, however, I would definitely recommend it! Here's why:

I really like the challenge it is to build a base in space. Things like broken or incomplete walls are suddenly a major deal. It's fun with the research letting you get better and I like that there are derelicts appearing that you can explore. I see much promise in this game and think it can get really good once the team has had a chance to develope it a bit further.

column8:
At this time the game has gone from being pretty fun to annoying:

*  Derelicts attach to your base which is annoying for those who like to plan.  Yes you can remove them by de-zoning, and if your builders follow instructions....
*  Citizens fight each other far too early into the base development.
*  Citizens become depressed over anything meaning they don't do their job.
*  Citizens stand about in airlocks meaning people can't come and go.
*  Raiders appear too often in low risk zones.
*  Security teams run off when you are being raided leaving citizens to fight and die.
*  Security just orbit around a derelict when you place a beacon on it.
*  Security don't always go into a derelict attached to your base when the beacon is on it and just stand outside.
*  Updates are slow in coming.

Is the developer more focussed on their other new game now they have the money from this one?

column8:
I really want to like this game, because it seems to want to have so many elements that I like in games - however it is ultimately so frustrating and hard (not difficult) that I inevitably put it down after a short while.  

One of the very basic problems is that the 'dangers' feel too contrived.  One starts playing and within a period of time there will be a 'space debris strike' aimed at your balls.  This doesn't feel like randomness, it feels like designers clutching at introducing adversity.  

The other problem is that the AI in the game is suicidal at best.  While building structures they will seal themselves into rooms with no air, or no exits.  They will do stupid things such as ignore danger when someone is shooting at them while building or destroying structures.    

Also and finally the game's biggest problem of all is that there is no 'border.'  Enemies enter anywhere on the base by attacking in the faux-3d of the game's world.  This means that there is no safe area, no main gate or wall.  The bigger your base gets, the more likely you are to suffer an attack or air leak where you can't contain it and you'll lose half of your crew to something utterly stupid.

All in all, I keep starting the game but then I quit in disgust and frustration,  I see what they are trying to do, but it just feels very unsatisfying and annoying to me.  I'll try again later and report back with the new builds.

column8: Great concept, awful game right now. having no ability to control your units means relying on a crummy ai code to put out fires and repair very critical systems on the ship. Instead of repairing oxygen systems, the technicians decided to play games and chat, resulting in my whole base being wiped out.

column9:
If you remember and love the game Evil Genius, you'll love this one!
The principle is simple. Build your space base, populate it with creatures, assign them to specific positions, and keep them all alive and entertained. Sounds simple. In reality, you need to screw up at least four bases to understand how everything works. Then, develop a bit, and screw everything up again.
It's very easy to lose in this game. You always have a ton of problems.
Just because you think assigning a human, or a chicken, or anyone else to a security position doesn't mean they won't run in panic from the evil pirates who've broken into your station and are shooting everyone (yes, another screwed up base)...
Or maybe half your crew has gone crazy and are starting fights? Everything's fine until they get into the life support module and wreck everything (yes, another reboot).
Even though it's still in alpha, it's already generating tons of funny stories and never lets you get bored.
I'd also like to point out the developers' good sense of humor (it's Double Fine, of course) and the game's pleasing graphics.
I'm looking forward to the full version.
I think the game is totally worth the money!
By the way, if you thought Banished was difficult, you'll find this game completely hardcore ;-)

column8:
Thought i'd love it, was correct...Just enough randomness to keep my attention. Can't wait to see finished product.

EDIT
I was cool with the bugs as it was in alpha. I was okay with the suffocating crew refusing to build more o2 recyclers...I was cool with the refinery breaking every 30 minutes (no not technician fix it broke) they forget how to use the reactor and go around dropping asteroid chunks on the ground broke...I was remotely cool with the raiders breaching my perfectly constructed shit every 2.4 minutes and walking through the hall with 4 turrets while brutally butchering my 6 person security detail with body armor and upgraded weapons... That was because it was in alpha...but now giving up and just dropping it...

NEVER AGAIN

column8:
Update on 19. of September 2014:

Double Fine decided to move the game from Alpha to general availability and open the source code to the public. To me that seems like throwing the towel and this is not how early access should be played. Thumbs therefore went from up to down.


Very entertaining for us old guys (like 35+), who enjoyed "Theme *something*" in the past. Perhaps for those willing to spend more than reflexes, this will turn out intersting as well. Remember that the game is currently in ALPHA stage and is still kind of unbalanced. Like, a single raider plowing through a base where 16 people have been assigned to "alert" security duty and beaconed to the intruders - each and every one of them pushing the daisies after. I have no doubt that after some further balancing and polishing this game will turn out to be something of retro goodness.

Remember that the game is currently in ALPHA stage and is still kind of unbalanced. Like, a single raider plowing through a base where 16 people have been assigned to "alert" security duty and beaconed to the intruders - each and every one of them pushing the daisies after. I have no doubt that after some further balancing and polishing this game will turn out to be something of retro goodness.

column8:
Interesting ideas, but poor executions, which, sadly enough, tends to be the case with Double Fine's products in the last few years, even to the point at which one Tim Schafer had to beg for crowd-funding in order to continue.

The Game focuses on a "Sims in Space" gameplay environment, where you must manage a number of statistics for your group fo interstellar residents, including their happiness and morale, in order to keep them alive, all while dealing with events suddenly popping up and digging for materials.

The problem with this approach is that it is completely uninspired. There's very little content and agency for the player to address the issues that appear, and largely the game loses its luster within the hour.

I really cannot recommend this game. It is just... bad. Step it up, Tim.

column9:
I initially downloaded a pirated version, then bought it. The game is cool, but no matter how hard you try, sooner or later everyone will die. There will be countless reasons, and nothing can help you. The team simply goes crazy over time, and there's no escape from this, for now.
Of course, the alpha is still raw, there are tons of bugs, ridiculous ones at that, like the script isn't finished, and there's no Russian language.
For those who buy it, I'll tell you how to start playing, because I managed to build something viable on the 10th try.
As soon as the screen appears, immediately hit pause, put everyone in builders. Your goal is to build two 3x5 oxygen generators, a minimum 3x3 airlock, and the building you're given for the room, and of course, a 4x4 resource processing factory. Don't forget the doors.

column8:
EDIT:  This was my review before they announced they were releasing before schedule:

Fun so far.  Encountered a few AI bugs and the such, but it is in alpha.  Know what you are getting into, it's not finished, hence the Early Access and fact it is currently in Alpha 6.  If you are looking for a finished game, wait till later.  If you like this sort of game and want to help the development then buy it.


EDIT:  My review was thumbs up before they announced they were stopping development for a full release.  I will change my review back to a positive one if it actually is decent.

As things stand right now, this game is not worth it. Security personel rarely do anthing but flee or try to start a fist fight with a raider holding a rifle, the needs of the colonists shrink so fast that they go on a rampage before you can meet their basic needs, and just too much bad stuff happens to fast.

With time and re-balancing it could be better, but I'll stick to RimWorld for a colony sim.

It seems alot of people dislike the game at its current states, but even with all the bugs I still have fun. And now with the new undate, the game just keeps getting better! I'm pretty sure I got this for like $4 anyway. Money well spent!

But I do have some problems. Not bugs but suggestions. 

1.All the women in this game look like buff dudes. I'm not saying make them look like sluts or anything but having them a little womenly would be nice.
2. I think it would be nice to be able to chose who are the starting people you get. Their likes, dislikes, starting skills and want jobs they want, race ect ect.
3. I find it hard to believe that everyone who contacts your Space Base is either someone who wants to join or just bandits. I think that traders, slavers, Cosmic Government Agents ect ect, should show up and help or mess with you from time to time.

*-Edit-*
Nevermind what I said, don't buy this piece of shit. The makers have abandon it. I was willing to forgive all the bugs because its a early access game, but now the creators have basically said "Thanks for the money, faggots.", I highly recommend you don't buy this.

column8:
When I bought the game I figured I'd love the vast base-building. I'd hoped it would resemble something like Prison Architect, and to an extent; Banished. But it seems more appropriate to say it's like Age Of Empires, as, with limited build time, I'm forced to hapazardly prepare for an attack from raiders, parasites, or one of my own crew. Taking into account this was in the easiest area of the game I could find.

After multiple restarts (I've barely played a single playthrough for more than 30 minutes), I gave up. This kind of game could steal hundreds of hours from me, but with the trouble I'm having constructing a fuctioning populace, and a decent-looking spacebase, that's not going to happen.

column8:
SEPTEMBER 22 EDIT: Do not buy this game. The game is going into "1.0" release next month and is being left to modders to finish it up. They claim they're going to fix bugs, but as I made clear in the review below, they couldn't even finish the A.I. during thier "Alpha" stage.

This game is like an incredibly dumbed-down Dwarf Fortress in space. Key word being dumb. 

The AI has incredibly complex inabilities to solve their problems. They would rather let themselves asphyxiate in the cold of space than finish constructing the airlock that is filled with oxygen. Why? Because the unfinished part is a space suit locker. They were in space suits already.

In a previous run, the builders refused to add onto the life support section because oxygen was running low (for some unknown reason) and so the whole crew suffocated. 

Another run, I had to tear down a door I placed. That destroyed the wall and converted the next room from an airlock into a reactor, and while trying to fix that, the builder simply never finished construction. The crew died because they had no airlock to exit and expand and there was a hole into space.

The security have no sense of uniformity and would rather walk one at a time into a derelict and die continuously to the same thing.

You can't place objects in 4 directions, only two. I don't know why 4-view camera controls aren't implemented yet, but its frustrating to deal with as you have so much unused space. 

It's a neat concept and can become a good game, but it is not at all worth your time or money. It is bug-ridden. It has very stupid AI. If the developers can create useful viewing controls and decent AI that you don't have to play around in a nit-picky manner, it'll be a fun, hard game of balance between many facets of every characters' needs and wants, and management of a space station.

column8:
I remember first encountering this game during Amnesia Fortnight 2012, Double Fine's crowdfunded event in which they put out a series of rapid prototypes to test out a bunch of different game ideas.

I'm going to bottom line this for you: the game hasn't evolved significantly beyond what was originally shown off as a rapid development prototype nearly two years ago. Updates are slow and add to the backend with new features that increase complexity, but don't actually add content or meaningful gameplay in any way. Worse, the developers have completely removed the "Future development plans" backlog from their website with no explanation. This is to say nothing of the numerous game breaking bugs and brick-dumb AI which have survived for release after release.

And yet I could deal with all of that if the game were fun to play... but it's not. Games like its inspiration, Dwarf Fortress, are fun because of their emergent gameplay - the stories and situations which unfold around you are completely unique to each playthrough, creating a different experience every time you play. This frankly isn't true in DF-9, at least in its current state. Fire up the game and start on a random map and you'll have built and encountered everything there is to see in around an hour; there's no point in starting a new game since the same story unfolds every time.

column9:
I'm having fun with the game on PC!
I wanted to play it on my MacBook for a bit during the night shift, but
I was unfortunately disappointed.

-There are tons of graphic glitches. No door is displayed correctly. Materials marked for mining are displayed very crookedly. Sometimes I can see the "power lines" leading from the reactor to the rooms.

-The reactor and seed sometimes don't provide power. I've started the game several times now and almost always had the problem that the station didn't have power, and my people were suffocating. The seed was tied up, I even built a separate reactor, but it didn't help. Once I had power, and then it suddenly disappeared (without me doing anything) and wouldn't start again...

-No save game works! After every "save and exit," I have to start completely from the beginning. I finally managed to get power to the base and continue building, but it just won't save.

These issues only affect MacOS gaming. I've played a lot on a friend's PC before
and never had these issues on Windows.

This isn't MacOS support! If I'd known this beforehand, I wouldn't have bought it...

column8:
I like this game. Yes it's got flaws but it's an alpha so I expect them. I would like some further options, like a 'safe world' mode where I can build without dangers. But I hope that comes in time. It's hard to start, taking me at least 5 tries to get something happening without all my men dying. But once I did the game started to take hold and I'm slowly learning how to play.

Dont get this if you don't like alphas because you will be dissapointed. But do get this if you like the idea of building your own space station from scratch and don't mind a few bugs here and there.

column9:
I bought it hoping that someone would once again manage to copy the (of course, greatly simplified) gameplay of Dwarf Fortress, especially since it had renowned developers, stylish art, and graphics.
But. But. But, things turned out not to be so rosy.

In fact, the controls in this game, in an isometric view, are, to put it mildly, not very user-friendly. The game's content turned out to be negligibleâ€”this was a drag when the engine and basic control aspects were released for demo.
And now, ALMOST A YEAR HAS PASSED...
During this time, only six minor updates have been released. The gameplay hasn't been updated at all. There's basically nothing to do in the game :(

I don't recommend it yet, I have a feeling it'll be abandoned :(

PS: Play the magnificent RimWorld instead â€“ the progress is obvious, and it's already fun to play, even though it's still alpha 6.

PS: They've finally abandoned the game, announced version 1.0, followed by a modding toolkit, and off we go... Oh, DoubleFine, that's not good... And at the very beginning, they promised to at least add a third z-dimension to the beta...

column8:
First let me say this: I have a very deep love for Dwarf Fortress. I absolutely adore that game so I have bought almost every dwarf fortressesque game on early access.

However, this game: Spacebase DF-9 is not a good game. Why? Several reasons, but most relate to really bad controls. To build stuff or select or anything is really fiddily because it has a hard time registrating where the mouse is pointing on the grid - so you have a really hard game just controlling the damn game. Also the UI is hard to understand sometimes. The citizens all have their own individual "twitter feeds" where they write what the think of your space station, but the problem is that it's hard to understand exactly what their problems are. The game is also very unbalanced so it's hard to get a space base running and the nature of space means that it's important to make sure that you build correctly the first time. More so than in dwarf fortress where you can occasionally correct mistakes or convert rooms. Here your items often take more than 1 space on a grid so you'll find that its harder to convert rooms to other things. Also the rooms needs to be substantially bigger and you cannot put stuff like beds beside walls because they need all of the bed's adjacent squares to be free.

EDIT: It has been a long time since the developers decided to abandon this project. I think I speak for all of us who bought this game when I say that we're all deeply disappointed in them. We all think it's a scam, and that it was not finished like it should have been. They never fixed the interface or the controlling problems. Stay away from this scam if  you  know what's good for you.

column8:
UPDATE -- from the many years ago i made this. They gave up on the game a long time ago. its great that people are out there finishing the game for them, after they happily took our money then didn't even come close to a finished product. Anyway i really can't belive that is game is still on steam and it costs Â£6.99! you cant even call it a game without the mod... 

So they are still charging people for a game that they didn't finish but will be happy to take your money... and have left it upto the community to finish it for them. Which is great for everyone that owns this game already but i do think its wrong because its an insentive for people to buy the game and give there money to crappy company. 

Really good game, i enjoy playing it a lot, but... there are atm a fair few bugs that dont just ruin the game, they will destroy your save! saying that there have been 3 updates from when i bought it 3 days ago (04/09/14) and they have all fixed some big bugs that made the game very hard to play, due to these fixes i would recomend you to buy this game, it is a lot better and a lot more fun then the pictures may portray it to be!
