Ich habe das Spiel nun schon seit langer zeit und bin die entwicklungssschirtte mitgegangen. Und eines muss ich mal sagen. DAS HIER IST EINE ALPHA!!! Alles an negativen Kritikpunkten kann schon wenige tage nach verÃ¶ffentlichen der Kritik hinfÃ¤llig sein. Bedenkt das also.

Nun zum spiel. Es ist ein bissel wie Dungen keeper mit dem ganzen rÃ¤ume bauen. Es hat viel potenzial und ich finde bisher es war kein fehlkauf. NatÃ¼rlich gibt es nach einen update wie aktuell mit version 6 viele probleme. vieles muss eingestellt werden und ausbalanciert werden. aber die Entwickler sind dran und arbeiten sichtbar dran. Also nicht gleich aufregen wenn nach einen updatet mal alles mist ist. Einfach einige tage warten und das meiste gibt sich schon. 
Ich persÃ¶nlich sehe nicht das ich hier geld mit  einen schlechten spiel verschwendet hab.
column9:
I've had the game for a long time now and have followed the development steps. And I have to say one thing: THIS IS AN ALPHA!!! Any negative criticism can be invalidated just a few days after the review is published. So keep that in mind.

Now, about the game. It's a bit like Dungeon Keeper with all the room-building. It has a lot of potential, and so far I don't think it's been a bad purchase. Of course, there are a lot of problems after an update like the current one with version 6. A lot of things need to be adjusted and balanced. But the developers are working on it and are clearly working on it. So don't get upset if everything is crap after an update. Just wait a few days, and most things will improve.

Personally, I don't see that I wasted money on a bad game.

column8:
Die Idee des Spiels ist super, aber die Umsetzung...wo fÃ¤ngt man da nur an.
Ich mÃ¶chte gar nichts Ã¼ber die Grafik, Musik, Soundeffekte oder die Steuerrung schreiben, denn alle diese Punkte sind ganz gut umgesetzt. Das Problem ist die Spielmechanik! 

Ein paar Beispiele (aus der getesteten Alpha 6c - Version):

* FÃ¼r die Sauerstoffproduktion muss man Sauerstoffaufbereitungsanlagen bauen. Pro drei Bewohner eine. Diese gehen mit der Zeit kaputt (alles geht viel zu schnell kaputt) oder werden von den Eindringlingen beschÃ¤digt und mÃ¼ssen von Technikern repariert werden. Die machen aber praktisch nie etwas, sind immer sauer, depressiv, traurig oder reden und essen den ganzen Tag. Kommt es dazu, dass der Sauerstoffpegel unter 50 % sinkt, laufen die Bewohner der Station hysterisch herum bis sie am Sauerstoffmangel sterben. Auch die Techniker. Keiner kommt auf die Idee eine Anlage zu reparieren. Zudem sterben sie alle gleichzeitig. Spielende.

* Eine Speicherfunktion gibt es nicht bzw. sie funktioniert nicht. 

* Angreifen sind Ã¼berstark. Zwei Angreifer kÃ¶nnen 20 Bewohner und damit die ganze Basis (3 Stunden Spielzeit) in 2 Minuten auslÃ¶schen. Das Problem ist, dass die Bewohner dumm sind und einfach panisch durch die Gegend laufen und sich nacheinander abknallen lassen. 

* Eine monstermÃ¤ÃŸige Kanone mit drei LÃ¤ufen als Verteidigunsanlage kann keinen Angreifer oder verrÃ¼ckt gewordenen Bewohner stoppen. Die Kanonen gehen nach ein paar Treffern oder SchlÃ¤gen kaputt. 

* Einige Bewohner infizieren sich mit Krankheiten und kÃ¶nnen sich in Monster verwandeln, die alles zerstÃ¶ren. Das gleiche wie mit Anfreifern - kaum zu tÃ¶ten. 

* Alle paar Minuten gibt es ein Meteoriteneinschlag auf der Station. Mehrere RÃ¤ume fangen Feuer oder der Boden wird zerstÃ¶rt. Die meisten Bewohner laufen panisch umher, einige greifen aber zum GlÃ¼ck zum FeuerlÃ¶scher. Oft bleiben sie dann aber irgendwie stehen und sterben trotzdem.

* Das GefÃ¤ngnis funktioniert Ã¼berhaupt nicht. Das Sicherheitspersonal macht nichts, auÃŸer essen, reden und schlafen. VerrÃ¼ckt gewordene Einwohner laufen in Ruhe um zerstÃ¶ren die Einrichtung oder sie werden von anderen Bewohnern getÃ¶tet. 

* Allgemein macht auf der Basis kaum jemand etwas. Geregelte ArbeitslÃ¤ufe sind nicht zu erkennen. 

Das waren nur ein paar Punkte, die mir schnell eingefallen sind. Man kÃ¶nnte diese Liste noch mindestens doppelt so lang machen. WÃ¼rde das Spiel 5â‚¬ kosten, kÃ¶nnte man das ganze noch verkraften, denn das Spielprinzip ist echt fesseld. 

Meine Empfehlung fÃ¼r alle Leute, die Ã¼berlegen sich dieses Spiel zu kaufen: Wartet auf eine spielbare Version und spielt in der Zwischenzeit Startopia! Gibt es auf Steam fÃ¼r 5,99 â‚¬. DF-9 ist bis jetzt in weiten Teilen nur ein schlechter Klon von Startopia.

Sollten die Entwickler sich mehr antrengen und doch ein spielbares Spiel abliefern, werde ich meine Bewertung natÃ¼rlich Ã¤ndern.
column9:
The idea of â€‹â€‹the game is great, but the execution...where do you even begin?
I don't want to write anything about the graphics, music, sound effects, or controls, because all of these aspects are implemented quite well. The problem is the game mechanics!

A few examples (from the tested Alpha 6c version):

* To produce oxygen, you have to build oxygen processing plants. One for every three residents. These break down over time (everything breaks down far too quickly) or are damaged by the invaders and have to be repaired by technicians. However, they practically never do anything; they're always angry, depressed, sad, or talk and eat all day. If the oxygen level drops below 50%, the station's residents run around hysterically until they die from lack of oxygen. The technicians too. Nobody thinks of repairing a plant. Moreover, they all die at the same time. The game is over.

* There is no save function, or it doesn't work.

* Attacks are extremely powerful. Two attackers can wipe out 20 residents, and thus the entire base (3 hours of gameplay), in 2 minutes. The problem is that the residents are stupid and just run around in a panic, getting shot one after the other.

* A monstrous three-barreled cannon used as a defense system can't stop an attacker or a resident who has gone mad. The cannons break after a few hits or blows.

* Some residents become infected with diseases and can transform into monsters that destroy everything. The same as with attackers - almost impossible to kill.

* Every few minutes, a meteorite strikes the station. Several rooms catch fire or the floor is destroyed. Most residents run around in a panic, but luckily some grab the fire extinguisher. Often, however, they somehow stop and die anyway.

* The prison doesn't function at all. The security personnel do nothing except eat, talk, and sleep. Residents who have gone mad wander around quietly, destroying the facility, or they are killed by other residents.

* In general, hardly anyone is doing anything on the base. There are no discernible regulated workflows.

Those were just a few points that quickly occurred to me. This list could be at least twice as long. If the game cost â‚¬5, it would still be bearable, because the gameplay is truly captivating.

My recommendation for anyone considering buying this game: Wait for a playable version and play Startopia in the meantime! It's available on Steam for â‚¬5.99. DF-9 is largely just a poor clone of Startopia so far.

If the developers put more effort into it and deliver a playable game, I will of course revise my rating.

The AI in this game is horrible at best and down right imbread retarded on good days, i'v lost count how many people have died on me because of buggy AI, My fav one is when someone gets pacified in the airlock and instead of the AI telling him to move or even when i tell him to go to the brig/escort him to the brig he will just stand there in the airlock as my miners and workers on the outside die, and to top it off even if I have multi airlocks they will keep waiting at the one that doesn't open, then there is teh fact that enemys particular parasits get incompacitated in doorways leaving them open and i have no way of removing said blockage because there is no "Cap in the head" option so i wait for it heal on its own to get back up and continue to attack my base workers or and the one i love the most for part of the floor to give way under a meterior shower and have half my base sucked into the vacumme of space.

column8:
At the moment, don't buy the game. That doesn't mean don't pay attention to it, just don't put your money into it at this juncture.  The AI pathing is questionable at best (space requirments for individuals to navigate around larger items within the base is different considering the dimensions available). AI would rather sleep then do a job you have assigned them to; AI get's stuck within a structure with no doors or other forms of escape after you ask them to build it. 

Way too many individuals ask to your base than you are obviously ready for (I had over 10 within the first 15-20 minutes in one play attempt). The mechanics are fantastic. I will personaly be continuing to attempt playing this game, but can't recommend it to others that haven't already paid for the alpha.

column8:
Unfortunately the final release of this game is not an improvement on the earliest alpha at all. Throughout the alpha the gameplay did not change at all. Instead each alpha update added some tacked on crap that contributed very little to the game. 

Good
The characters you construct a base for seem to have depth. They have feelings and thoughts and you can read about them and so on. The basic gameplay elements for a base builder are there and function.

Bad
The game seems to be caught somewhere between Dungeon Keeper and the Sims. Unfortunately, the emphasis seems to be on Sims gameplay. The station inhabitants have clearly had more effort put into them than the actual gameplay. This could have been a positive thing, as it is in the Sims which is a great game, except without a base and proper neccessities all your inhabitants will die. So you find yourself in a panic to build a base early, made all the harder by the fact that your workers spend more time socializing and posting to their "spacebook" than building things essential to survival. This is made even more frustrating by the single most terrible UI I've seen in a modern game ever. 

In conclusion, the game isn't finished. The gameplay in Spacebase is incredibly underdeveloped and clunky. There isn't even anything to do. You build a small base and then there's nothing. You could make a bigger base, but there's no reason to. There's no challenge. Despite a year and a half of development this still plays like a terrible demo.
column9:
Unfortunately the final release of this game is not an improvement on the earliest alpha at all. Throughout the alpha the gameplay did not change at all. Instead each alpha update added some tacked on crap that contributed very little to the game. 

Good
The characters you construct a base for seem to have depth. They have feelings and thoughts and you can read about them and so on. The basic gameplay elements for a base builder are there and function.

Bad
The game seems to be caught somewhere between Dungeon Keeper and the Sims. Unfortunately, the emphasis seems to be on Sims gameplay. The station inhabitants have clearly had more effort put into them than the actual gameplay. This could have been a positive thing, as it is in the Sims which is a great game, except without a base and proper neccessities all your inhabitants will die. So you find yourself in a panic to build a base early, made all the harder by the fact that your workers spend more time socializing and posting to their "spacebook" than building things essential to survival. This is made even more frustrating by the single most terrible UI I've seen in a modern game ever. 

In conclusion, the game isn't finished. The gameplay in Spacebase is incredibly underdeveloped and clunky. There isn't even anything to do. You build a small base and then there's nothing. You could make a bigger base, but there's no reason to. There's no challenge. Despite a year and a half of development this still plays like a terrible demo.

column8:
As Of update 6c this game still needs ALOT of work. it has gone from a nice space sim that needed to be a bit harder and more long term goals to a game that will leave you alone if you keep the starting 3 people but after that Raiders, debris and other disasters happen way too often and undo all the work you have just done. as it stands this game has promise but i doubt many people have the patients to stay with it if these problems are not further addressed.
If you like big challenges and space sims this game will be something to look at, but not yet.

column8:
My crew. My team. My group. The space station. The brotherhood and love. Space is a void and we all return to it sooner or later. 

You may sit sobbing in a corner, lamenting over the death of your brother. Tears hit a cold hard metal floor. You've been appointed the new doctor. As part of your duties you'll be disposing of your brother and his killers. Soon their bodies will make up the walls of your station.

You may bravely be the subordinate who is sent aboard the abandoned station. You may bravely be the new meal of the creature within. Maybe you'll kill it. Maybe you'll be stranded there, running out of oxygen as a hail of distress signals come from your station.

This game has so much potential. Even now it is the creator of a great many stories I can tell.

column9:
A really good game, even though it's still in early access.
I recommend it to anyone who likes Theme Hospital or Prison Tycoon.
Its interface is very easy to use, and you practically don't need to know English to progress in the game.
The only downside I see is that it has little content, but that will be fixed over time.
What surprises me is that even though it's in early access, it has no bugs.
So there's no problem with losing games or the game crashing.

First off you should be able to assign crew to stay in certain ships so that repair crew don't go and fix stuff at empty ships because to be honest t's probably better you just scrap the ship unless it's really cloes to your base and you can make a pathway.  Second there's a bunch of issues with the bar, people always go there when no one is working and just sit there instead of doing there jobs which causes tones of issues. Also everyone wants to go to the bar and this completely emtyss the oxeygon out of the room. This one time I lost half my crew due to these issues. Besids that  great game and I can't wait to see what you guys add next.

â˜°â˜°â˜°â˜°â˜°â˜°â˜°â˜°â˜°â˜°â˜°â˜°â˜°â˜°â˜°â˜°â˜°â˜°â˜°â˜°
â˜ â˜ â˜   Avoid, avoid, avoid, avoid!  â˜ â˜ â˜ 
â˜°â˜°â˜°â˜°â˜°â˜°â˜°â˜°â˜°â˜°â˜°â˜°â˜°â˜°â˜°â˜°â˜°â˜°â˜°â˜°

This game has been classified as hazardous space debris.  Set your navicomps to avoid this sector at all costs, lest you find yourself wasting space credits.

UPDATE: Developer has released the game as "done."  Oh, but we'll get the source code so we can finish it ourselves, right?  Right??  Well, let me say this:  Tim Schafer is the new Peter Molyneux.  *drops mic and walks away from Double Fine forever*

UPDATE 2:  Just played 1.05, the "release" version of the game.  Some of the bugs I've mentioned have been addressed, but only a few.  Now features a "tutorial" level that is basically just a pre-built base with some lame text overlays telling you to perform a few tasks.  I played the level after the tutorials were complete, and was immediately swamped by a continous stream of raider vessels.  Base went from 12 occupants to just 1, and when I saw that last "Raider breach vessel incoming!" message I just quit the game and un-installed it again.

Pros:

â˜‘  Er.  I wish it were a good game that had potential?  Cuz I would love me a Sim Starbase game.

Cons:

â˜’  Very buggy user interface.  I commonly had to "trick" the game to build an item by building another and then canceling it before completing it in order to get it to build the second item (which is the item I wanted in the first place).  If items overlap, then it is impossible to click on one or more of the overlapped items.  (Say if you have a claim-territory flag that is overlapped by an oxygen generator.)

â˜’  Obtuse needs and wants system.  My crew fights and kills each other, and I am never sure why without carefully inspecting each cluttered needs/wants screen for each crew member.

â˜’  I've lost dozens of crew without even really knowing why.  The notification bar fills up with tons of "XXXX needs medical attention" and "XXXX is dead" messages before I can even react to whatever is putting my crew in danger.

â˜’  Your first base is going to result in dead astronauts.  So will your second, third, fourth and likely fifth.  Margins are extremely thin at the beginning of the game, so if you screw up in the least (such as build a room too small to hold a refinery, without knowing how big that refinery is) you have to start over.  There is no way to undo or fix a build mistake, so if you make any at the critical first few minutes of the game, then kiss your space-butt goodbye.

â˜’  Zoning system is clunky and requires you to build a special-purpose room to simply place one item.

â˜’  Annoying fixed view that cannot be rotated, nor is there a "fade behind" effect when someone or something is behind another object, so it's easy to lose people or things.  This will likely never change either, because while the crew are rendered as 3D models, it's clear the walls and objects are static sprites, and if the devs didn't account for rotating views at this point in the dev cycle, they probably never will.

â˜’  Overall quite buggy.  UI elements end up becoming corrupt, crew get stuck in rampaging loops and can never be subdued, miners will drop ore in the middle of space during a crisis and never pick it back up, etc.

â˜’  Feels very unpolished, and like an early WIP.  Expected more progress for this game since the last time I looked at it (about a year ago).

column8:
I used to like this game. Post version 6 release, it now totally sucks.

Why?
Specifically the AI doesn't seem capable of managing the new functionality. Also the threat system is totally broken. For some reason in my "extreme low" hostility sector I get constant pirate raids (and I do mean constant. Like... 30 seconds after beating the last one there's another).  Or a meteor impact. The "game" (if one can call it that anymore) has gone from a space colony sim to a constant crisis. 

But more fundamentally... the brig system doesn't work right, nor the tantrum system. So first the brig system: enemies can often get "subdued" where they just stand there endlessly until they starve. If you have a brig, you can store them there instead. There doesn't appear to be any reason to do this that I can see. There is no benefit. Its preferable to let enemies starve, especially because sometimes captured enemies lose their "subdued" flag and simply walk out of the brig to shoot up your base again. Seriously... WHAT IS THE POINT? Also... did you guys even test this release?? Its almost entirely unplayable.

Okay so now to the tantrum system. Colonists can get freaked out, wreck the place up, and fight with fellow colonists. Yet for some reason this happens to happy colonists sometimes. I suppose one could say they "just snap" or something but... once again, what is the point of happiness if it doesn't do anything? Bigger problem is after a tantrumed colonist is subdued they lay there and nothing happens. Even if you have doctors on staff, they don't seem to treat the person like... laying there in the hallway injured. It appears that the primary role of doctors is simply corpse disposal, rather than anything doctor-y.

If steam had a numeric rating system, I'd give this 1 of 5 stars. Its really abysmal and should never have been released with the numerous game-breaking bugs. At least it was playable before.

column8:
Before I've bought this game I've read the reviews and they were horrible, but still decided to give it a chance because its idea seemed really cool. I'm really glad I didn't give in to the negative hype. Game has it's bugs as any EA but at the moment (Alpha 6c) none of them make it unplayable. Building and running your own space station is tons of fun the way theese guys did it. Lots of ways to let your creative side run free and strategizing for those who like some action. It's always exciting to send a security detail to scout out a derelict ship, or prepare for boarding by pirates. Really like the idea of inhabitants personalities where they make friends and enemies amongs each other and situations it creates. 
I definately reccomend this tittle, don't believe all the bad things you hear, sometimes it's good to try stuff out on your own.

column8:
So the producers decided to just go "Eh, close enough, release it, move on". Shame that is simply isn't done at all. I leave my original early access review below, but the character AI is still atrocious, there is no way to prioritize building, the security is still slow to respond to threats, the characters are just too dumb to live (Hey, this robot killed this guy, so I'll just go over and grab his body while the robot is still around), it is finicky to find a starting spot as there is no rhyme or reason to the colony select screen, the tutorial doesn't tell you jack, the construction controls are non-intuitive, you can't rotate the screen so placement of some objects is difficult, the builders build things in a random fashion (see point about prioritizing above), the aliens are only different in appearance, no trading available with ships, I could go on and on. I was hoping for a better version of Startopia, but this game is nowhere near that level. Indeed, it still plays pretty much like an alpha, and can not seriously be considered a finished game. Especially a game with no on-going support. Do not buy. 


________________________________________________________________________________
Spacebase DF-9 is a very very alpha game. The AI just simply is broken. Having your characters die because they are all standing around in one room instead of doing tasks is not fun at all, and watching one lone raider knock out/off half your station plus all your oxygen recyclers with no security moving to do jack about it is just infuriating. Add in very dumb things like your crew deciding the airlock is a great place to hang out, and yeah, needs much more work before it's in a state worthy to play.

column8:
Honestly one of the better early access games I've played in a while. The way I see games is simple, has it consistently entertained me throughout, can I get an hour out of the game for every pound Iâ€™ve paid. Is the games content easily exhausted after a few hours? Answer yes'ish, more than! and lastly yes/no. These are my main questions after aesthetics, story ect.

Story is non-existent it relies on your attachment to your base inhabitants which at this moment is little to none but the game is constantly being updated, new AI and character interactions are making your inhabitants a little bit more entertaining or quirky and eventually you wouldn't be able to live without 'randomly generated name' for fear they maybe sucked out into the coldness of space. Random encounters become more of a tedious burden after the many hours I have played this game however more and more events, new interactions, content, game dynamics are constantly being updated and worked on, to keep me coming back each time to test out all the new content.

Conclusion is I loved games like Theme Hospital, Space Colony, Startopia and I love this game! There is enough to work with to classify it as a functioning game now and it constantly gets better. It has incredible potential and I can see the vision the Dev has in mind, its very bright.

Also JP if you're reading this please add some much needed new random events, dialog and a little bit of story/intrigue in here.. I'm spending my "I've conquered research, disasters and people management' time just tearing down derelicts and watching people eat Killbot corpses en masse in the pub.. I need more challenge which would be nice to have when one reaches a 50 population :).

column8:
This game feels like it's going to be extremely good.  But right now it's more like a horror game.  The whole time you're playing, you have this horrific, sinking feeling that something is going to happen that makes absolutely no sense, and you'll have to restart (or, more likely, quit).
I've played several times on earlier versions, and I just played 3 games on the latest alpha (6b).  First game, I ran out of minerals before I built my refinery.  Whoops.  Second game my guys finished the building, but then wouldn't enter it, despite everything being apparently in order.  They all died of asphyxiation.  Third game, I got the base up and running, things were looking great, but then meteors came and smashed into my base.  While no walls or floor were visibly damaged, the oxygen dropped to 0% and everyone died.
I can't say the game is just flat out broken, but it sure feels like it.
That being said, the potential is there... they just need to get this out of alpha.  I really wish they hadn't made it early access so darn early.  This latest update does not fix the game enough to warrant being released as early access yet.
I think I'll love this game eventually, but it pains me to say that I think they released this so early in order to fund other projects. 

The developers may love this game, deep down.  "But it's not who you are underneath, it's what you do that defines you."

Edit: Is it any surprise that people disliked this negative review, and yet, I feel I hit the nail on the head now that the game has been "released".

I recommend this game because I believe in Double Fine and really want it to work out. I played the super early super basic demo a long time ago and it's came a long way from that, but still has a lot to go. At this point in early access, you're paying to help support the game's creation as well as beta testing it. There's a lot that needs work, but you can see where it's going.

Some very weird things that happened:
-A room got hit with a meteor, caught on fire, and they would just kind of use the room normally. I thought ok, I'll put a fire extinguisher in there. The guy walks into the fire, builds the extinguisher, walks out, room stayed ablaze until I quit for the night. They would seriously walk in, use the console to research something, and walk out. Hilarious, but buggy.
-Ships would dock with mine, then nothing would happen. Nobody would come from the ship, nobody would go into the ship. Nothing. One time one of my people had a panic attack and ran into all the rooms of the docked ship that allowed me to claim them, but there was nothing in there. 
-I had to rezone the Brig to something else so prisoners would maybe leave there and get food instead of starving to death. 
-I had an incapacitated invader just kind of chill out in my main room doing nothing. I eventually forced the cop to put him in the brig where he slowly converted to being a member of society, but couldn't figure out how to unbrig him so he also slowly starved to death. Added food processor in the brig, they kind of just decided death was better, and died. 

I mean really? Those are bugs, but they're also pretty hilarious. I'm backing this game because it's fun, even in it's buggy state, and I believe Double Fine will hammer this stuff out.

column8:
Ist noch eine Alpha und derzeit auch noch arg buggy, was sehr frustrierend sein kann/ist.
Zum Beispiel ist die Besatzung in etwa so intelligent wie kopflose HÃ¼hner.

Dennoch ist's eine interessante Spielidee. Durch weitere Patches und Verbesserungen kann hieraus sicherlich irgendwann ein brauchbares Spiel herauskommen.

Im Moment muss man noch damit rechnen, dass die Basis durch ein unglÃ¼ckliches Ereignis komplett ruiniert wird und alle Arbeit umsonst war. Dann hilft nur noch ein Neuanfang.

Trotzdem fange ich immer wieder gern eine neue Basis an, auch wenn ich weiss, dass das schnell wieder im Chaos endet. ;)
column9:
It's still an alpha and currently quite buggy, which can be/is very frustrating.
For example, the crew is about as intelligent as headless chickens.

Still, it's an interesting game idea. With further patches and improvements, this could surely become a viable game at some point.

At the moment, you still have to expect that the base will be completely ruined by an unfortunate event, and all your work will have been in vain. Then the only thing that helps is a fresh start.

Still, I always enjoy starting a new base, even though I know it will quickly end in chaos again. ;)

don't get this game, maybe wait till the full release, if there ever is.

column8: Bearing in mind the game is still early access, DF9 has some great idea's, interesting mechanics and the possibility of becoming something very fun to play. However, it's current lack of depth combined with the developers lack of updates make this a difficult purchase to warrant. I personally feel like the latest updates have ripped idea's directly from Rimworld as well. Nevertheless, it may be one to watch, as there are plenty of interesting ways the game could go. As it stands, it's not worth buying right now, you will get perhaps 1-2 hours of content, and even that is very basic.

column9:
Let me start by saying I'm a fan of this genre of games and bought the game for that reason. But after playing it for two hours, I realized I'd already done everything possible at that point. The idea is certainly not bad, but it's irresponsible and insulting to release a game that's not just not ready... I first saw it in alpha about six months ago!!! And it's still in alpha! But if you're being honest about this review, the game is full of bugs! The models are laggy! The map generator is completely unconfigurable! 
In short, if you do buy it, do so only after the official release and only with a minimum 50% discount!

column8:
I called Spacebase DF-9 vaporware on September 3rd and got banned off the forums.

http://steamcommunity.com/app/246090/discussions/0/613935403965867988/

Double Fine announces that they're abandoning Spacebase DF-9 just 15 days later, thereby making it vaporware.

Banned for telling the truth.

Double Fine, you're an embarrassment. You are <insert whatever explitive you want, they deserve it>


~-~-~-~-~-~-~-~-~ PROOF BELOW ~-~-~-~-~-~-~-~-~
My Forum Post:
Clearly Vaporware
A person on the Spacebase DF-9 forums asked if this game was abandoned back on August 17th. It took over two days for a person NOT on the Spacebase DF-9 team to even notice the post and say 

'Hey - heck yeah Spacebase is still in development!
Iâ€™m not on the team, but JP and co are working hard on the next update and I think youâ€™ll hear more about it soon. "

Clearly this game is vaporware, another developer abusing the early access system. Go spend your money on Prison Architect, RimWorld or another game that has proper monthly updates. Even if they release an update, it'll be four months since the last one. Prison Architect and RimWorld and a dozen other proper indie games have got monthly updates of ACTUAL content, not the tiny micro-updates of Spacebase where gameplay is not affected at all.
 

JP's Reply (A developer)
You're making some incorrect assumptions about how Double Fine functions. No developers at Double Fine are working on Gang Beasts. Boneloaf is its own studio; Double Fine is just publishing it.

Your tone is nasty, unconstructive, and presumptuous. Locking this thread for the same reasons described here:

http://steamcommunity.com/app/246090/discussions/0/540738050855160345/#c540738051589496942

Ban:
You have been banned from all Spacebase DF-9 discussions until Oct 3 @ 9:26am.
You were banned by a Spacebase DF-9 developer.
Reason: "See my post in this thread."

column8: A lot of people seem to be complaining about bugs, which, when you're buying into an Alpha I'm not sure what you expect, but it's by no means "unplayably buggy."  There are some pretty severe issues, but they're getting whole swaths of them corected with each pass, which is what you get in an Alpha.  As far as "seeing all the game has to offer in an hour," the same can more or less be said of Minecraft, especially the earlier builds.  I've happily invested hours at a time into various stations only to have them go to hell sooner or later, and then started over again.  I guess maybe it's just a YMMV situation, but to me it's hard, it's buggy, but it's also fun and full of potential and very addictive.

column8:
UPDATE: According to the update posts, this is maybe becoming abandonware, Double Fine are leaving new features to the community and are only fixing bugs, and will stop bugfixing sometime. 
Please consider this before buying.

This game is a little tricky to recommend, the idea and the way the game plays is good, but it's quite buggy.
For example, one of my ''citizens'' was stuck in the door of the airlock that lead to space, and he died because of suffocation.
TL;DR, this is a good game, but it's buggy. If you can get over that, this would be a great game.

column8:
I can't recommend this game.

It has a lot of potential and I'd really love to see it done. I also really like the ideas the devs have.

BUT and that is a huge but...

... I purchased this game like a trillion years ago and hoped for updates. But there are just minor ones like nothing happened.
I feel a bit ripped off, because in the state it is, it is not really playable. The AI is just dumb as hell and it gets really frustrating (the citizens are like lemmings).
And after a short time you have done everything there is to do. I'd say after a 100 minutes you have seen everything and it gets to the point where you are just tweaking your base or you are eager to fight the trials caused by bugs. I really tried to befriend with this game the way it is but it just gets worse, because the unfinished state and slow development starts to aggravate me more and more.

Also there are a lot of known bugs, but they fix them really late or never. Who knows? The devs prefer to remain silent about nearly everything. I just read something about â€œWeâ€™re nearing our goals and the complete state of the game is not far awayâ€, so I decided to write this and warn everyone about this. The way it is, this game could be a free to play iPad thing. I'd pay about 4-7$ for this max, given that I wouldn't know what I know now.

For all the people, who think I'm just being pessimistic:
Look at their Website, or the updates here at Steam. It seems like they are releasing updates labeled as huge success, which are little more than some minor bug-fixes (or sometimes a bunch of new ones adding to the old ones).  
And you can't know whats to come, because the devs decided to delete the "Future developement plans"-website, which is a huge issue for me and just another indicator, that this game is dead and light years from being finished.
column9:
I can't recommend this game.

It has a lot of potential and I'd really love to see it done. I also really like the ideas the devs have.

BUT and that is a huge but...

... I purchased this game like a trillion years ago and hoped for updates. But there are just minor ones like nothing happened.
I feel a bit ripped off, because in the state it is, it is not really playable. The AI is just dumb as hell and it gets really frustrating (the citizens are like lemmings).
And after a short time you have done everything there is to do. I'd say after a 100 minutes you have seen everything and it gets to the point where you are just tweaking your base or you are eager to fight the trials caused by bugs. I really tried to befriend with this game the way it is but it just gets worse, because the unfinished state and slow development starts to aggravate me more and more.

Also there are a lot of known bugs, but they fix them really late or never. Who knows? The devs prefer to remain silent about nearly everything. column8: This game is so far from being anything that I don't understand why they're selling it. It's everything wrong with early access. It's not a playable game, crashes a lot, and generally isn't fun. There are numerous game-breaking bugs and bad ai behaviors that don't seem to be getting fixed, and a number of systems that might do something on day (power generation, happiness, etc), but are useless at the moment. Given how long it's been out, and the ammount of development actually happening, this one's probaly just a cash-grab by the developers.

column8: *NOT A LASTING NO, JUST SHOULD WAIT* A great idea and so far so good! However, develpoment has slowed down greatly since Alpha 1, or atleast news. Game breaking bugs with the AI, along with a small starting set of features really muddies this games ability to shine. I want this game to grow and strive, but as of now, it is far to early to tell. I have owned this game since the beginning and i truly love it, but it has far too many issues to be worth the $25 AT THIS MOMENT. If they fix the AI bugs, such as pathfinding issues, idiotic passengers, etc, I will rewrite this be recommended. Away from the negatives, the art style is quirky and really pops, the creativity with the Space Face logs is lovely and the "Choosing a Sector to Live In" menu is amazing, creatice, unique, and gorgeous. My opinion is to wait for the beta or release before you purchase, and pray this game makes it.

column9:
Warning!

I think this game has potential, which is exactly why I got into it.
Unfortunately, there's almost no development, and at this stage, the game is nothing more than a nice idea...

Now this unfinished "garbage" is being dumped on the market as a final release...
For my part, when I look at Double Fine's roadmap, I feel absolutely BETRAYED!

Twice in Early Access... SpaceBase DF-9 (Rating: Unsatisfactory) and Prison Architect (good, leaning towards very good)

Play Double Fine again?
NO, never again...

column8:
Builders build rooms so that they will be left inside without means to escape.
Citizens move to live in derelict ships in masses, run out of oxygen and don't know how to evacuate, and die.
Raiders have invisibility cloaks that lets them kill 3-5 civilians before security staff reacts to them.
5/5

column8: I've never really played this game for more than 10 minutes because all my guys keep dying, despite following the game's helpful suggestions. Build a room - check. Build oxygen things - check. Build an airlock with lockers - check. At this point my guys just hang around asphixiating before promptly die. It seems they don't have the intelligence to go inside where there's air. On the odd occasion they do, they run around in 'running for cover' mode for some random reason.

column8:
I love the concept of the game. I love what it could be but quite frankly, the devs either need more resources or more dedication. They claim this is "their baby" but all I see them doing is adding fancy backgrounds, fixing 2 or 3 relatively minor or non-gamebreaking bugs, and adding a new half-finished feature every 1.5 months or so. This is unacceptable and this is exactly why I am absolutely DONE supporting early access titles.

I don't believe early access reviews anymore unless they look honest and there's enough of them. Too many people review a game and say they love it despite its flaws simply because of the premise (Kinetic Void is a good example). I love the concept of Spacebase DF9, but if I still had a choice whether to back it, I wouldn't. The devs are pathetically slow on this and I see no excuse for a 4 or 5-man team to take this long especially if it's their "baby." Yes, they did say that in an update a while back. Claimed something to the effect of, 'oh we reallllly are working on this game we promise. This is our baby" <paraphrased>

I'm sorry DoubleFine. you have my money but I can assure you I will be attempting to convince anyone I know interested in it to hold off until you get your act together.  You've had close to a year and you have barely made any progress.

column8:
EDIT: (12/24/14) This game still has very annoying bugs. The door graphics still has a bug where the doors are other graphics instead of doors. The way the power usage on base works is unblanced, hostiles can plow through your whole base in nothing flat, the illnesses are unblanced; frankly everything is unblanced. For a supposedly finished game it is terrible. Don't waste your money.


EDIT: (9/23/14) Don't buy it. Just don't waste your money on it. The bugs are still there and pathfinding is still horrible, possibly worse than ever. I can't play more than 30 mins before I rage quit over some stupid bug that is seemingly never going to be fixed.

I was very hopeful when I reviewed originally, but with the annoucement the game is leaving Early Access still as broken as it currently stands is extremely dissapointing. I will not be buying from this developer in Early Access ever again.

Original (8/23/14):

Each update it gets better, but it has some bad bugs in it. I play on Mac and for me the most annoying bug is that the door images are never doors sometimes they blink between a chickenhead in the shape of the door that should be there and nothing at all. 

In this game you run a spacebase that's constantly falling apart around your ears. If the workers aren't killing themselves the raiders will do it for them.

Currently you can only play one game at a time. If you start over you lose the base you were building. You usually lose the base to something stupid before you get to the point you would want to start over anyway.

Everything needs worked on. AI, pathfinding, how the spacewalkers handle their oxygen timelimits (they ignore them and die last I played), how often metors strike, how the bartender wants to eat which jams up everybody as they wait on the bartender to be served who can't serve himself (only fix I know is to change the bartender's job to nothing which unsticks everyone and then change him back until the next time), how the builders decide what to build next, just everything.

The game looks promising and when it decides not to kill me within the first 15 mins of gameplay I usually can have fun until the door images being wrong get to me or raiders invade while the turrents do nothing and I get mad. I open it after an update, start a new base, play until I rage quit, and wait for the next update to try again.

My suggestion is to put it on your wishlist and check it early next year. See if the bugs have been fixed and even then only buy on sale.

column8:
This game is in ALPHA. You should expect bugs.
If you are surprised by the fact that there are bugs, I honestly don't know how you're breathing right now.

Spacebase DF-9 is an excellent concept for a game. It's like a space-themed Prison Architect: you micro-manage the needs of your crew, build/destroy sections, new world events happen, etc.

But that concept has been poorly executed. The updates seem to be coming fewer and farther between, with not much added to keep your interest. It seems Double Fine have put this game on the back burner.

And as I said, it contains bugs. The AI of characters is still a bit dumb, but it has improved since I started playing.

All in all, if you're very patient, and don't mind waiting around for updates and waiting for the game to figure out what you want, it has potential. Whether that potential is worth 25 USD is a personal choice.

column8:
[b]Solltet ihr Interesse an Spacebase DF-9 haben, schlagt ihr am besten erst zu, wenn das Spiel deutlich reduziert angeboten wird.[/b] 
Leider hat Double Fine beschlossen von der Alpha 6 direkt zum Full-Release Ã¼berzugehen. Seit der Alpha 5e wurden noch ein paar Bugs gefixed und ein paar ErgÃ¤nzungen gemacht, fÃ¼r einen Full-Release ist es jedoch noch viel zu frÃ¼h. Ein paar Stunden SpielspaÃŸ bleiben garantiert, mehr aber nicht. Angebracht ist also der deutliche Hinweis, dass in Punkto Potential, Spieltiefe und Features vieles vieles unentwickelt bleibt. Hunderte angedachte Features wurden vor dem Full-Release gestrichen und das Spiel durch die VerÃ¶ffentlichung des Quellcodes in die HÃ¤nde der Community gelegt. KÃ¼nftige Community-Mods werden die vielen LÃ¼cken, die die Entwickler hinterlassen, vermutlich nicht auffangen. 

Double Fine hat dem Ruf der Early-Access Spiele hiermit keinen Gefallen getan. Schade um die 23 Euro die in der Hoffnung auf ein "groÃŸes" Spiel investiert wurden. Viele Spieler dÃ¼rften sich zurecht "abgezockt" vorkommen. Ich werde diese Spiele-Schmiede kÃ¼nftig meiden!
column9:
[b]If you're interested in Spacebase DF-9, it's best to wait until the game is significantly discounted.[/b]
Unfortunately, Double Fine has decided to go straight from Alpha 6 to the full release. Since Alpha 5e, a few bugs have been fixed and a few additions made, but it's still far too early for a full release. A few hours of gameplay are guaranteed, but nothing more. It's therefore appropriate to clearly point out that much remains undeveloped in terms of potential, depth, and features. Hundreds of planned features were removed before the full release, and the game was placed in the hands of the community with the release of the source code. Future community mods will likely not fill in the many gaps left by the developers.

Double Fine hasn't done the reputation of Early Access games any favors with this. It's a shame about the â‚¬23 invested in the hope of a "big" game. Many players may rightly feel ripped off. I will avoid this game developer in the future!

column8: Sympatoche mais j'ai bien peur d'etre a la retraite le jour de la release ^^
column9: Nice but I'm afraid I'll be retired on release day ^^

column8:
I loved this game. I supported it in early access, gave it a glowing review. Double Fine had a ton of really cool features planned, then they announced the games official release. All development stopped. None of the features they were talking about were added, or would be added. Double FIne had gamed the Early Access system, they used sales from this game to pay for another they were developing. Double Fine had the potential to be a great company, with a great series of games under their belt to be proud of. 

This developer has seriously soured me on Early Access. 

Never buy a game from Double Fine..... Ever. 

Save your money, buy a game that works ( this one only loosely fits the definition of complete and functional) and support a company that finishes its products.

column9:
Managing a space station populated by a crowd of suicidal, sadistic, and maniac people.

Dismantle the station's outer wall while the crew is inside? Easy! Close the door in the face of the injured during a depressurization? Of course! Someone's fallen and bleeding? Let's go sit at the bar! Is it on fire? Then to the gym for some weight training! Replace the door between the compartments so slowly that the people inside suffocate? Yes, sir!

column8:
When I bought the game and reviewed positive, I anticipated that Double Fine would decide to "finish" their game an actually add more than just the basics and bare bones. To buy Spacebase now, is to buy a game engine then go hunting for mods for it.
Unfortunately, I do not see much of any mods for it at this time.

This review is negative for the very fact that Spacebase is now the base engine, and no longer a fitting or complete "Game." It has just barely got enough polish to pass off to be ready for sales.

Despite all the annoying bugs, and odd annoyances, Spacebase DF-9 is worth it imo for early access.

column8:
I really love the idea, but I'm not totally in love with the execution â€” yet. I still recommend playing it, but I feel like at this point, any new games I start will play out pretty much identically to what I'm doing.

It seems like there's a good structure for a game, but it doesn't take much time at all to get a pretty decent, stable population (until raiders or parasites come along and decimate you). Medicine could be fleshed out more. Science and technology need to be fleshed out more. Facilities should be upgradeable in some capacity â€” better entertainment facilities, better food replicators, whatever. A bit more of a personality to the citizens would be interesting. Maybe they form groups to make demands of you?

Even in the premise (story?) of the game, who IS the player?

I look forward to seeing what is tweaked and added to this game, though! The graphics are a lot of fun. There's a ton of potential here.

UPDATE: After Spacebase was unceremoniously shoved out of early access, I have to change my review from a thumbs up to a thumbs down. It was a promising game, but decidedly incomplete. Knowing that the developers have basically given up on it changes things: my thumbs-up review before was based on its potential. This thumbs down review is based on what it actually IS -- a half-finished game with a lot of interesting ideas and nothing much for the player to do with them.

column9:
The game is over, so I'm changing my review:

You start with 3 astronauts.
Using your starting materials, you must build a makeshift shelter in space (not on a planet, mind you, I'm talking about outer space, the void, the nothingness).

A pressurization compartment, doors, an oxygenation room, a food dispenser, and an indoor or outdoor walkway to house an ore processing machine.

Once that's done, you'll have to:

- mine
- build bigger
- check your oxygen
- survive pirate attacks
- welcome other survivors
- choose each one's specialty (among miner, scientist, engineer, doctor, bartender (cook), guard, etc.)

Your creativity will be put to the test... and your patience will be tested!

I loved playing this game (check out some screenshots).

You have to build airtight rooms, produce oxygen, defend your base against unscrupulous pirates, get rid of the parasites that unfortunately came along with your colonists, whom you saved from a stranded ship. Passing stellar debris can set your base on fire, or breach your beautiful station...

Game entirely in English, forum in English.

!!! Warning: no further development planned!!!

Graphics: 15/20
Music: 15/20

Gameplay: Tough at first, hard to put down afterward <3

I would recommend it if you don't blame the developers for abandoning the game...

I'm sad... but it's still a good little game (try it).

Management - construction (Sims-like) - survival

column8:
UPDATE: Game left early access in an unfinished state and letting down many players. I wish it had been different but it wasn't. The game promised a lot but was short from delivering even the bare miniums. Modding options were released but I think it was too late. The game is now most likely dead. Keep searching, there are other options for fans of base building and space.

Original review:

Many good things and many promises, it just needs time to grow. It is playable and enjoyable already, but if you get it consider it an investment for something that will surely be much better and polished. I have great faith in Double Fine's uniqueness to tackle their games though for now what you see mostly are the mechanics and some glimpses of geniality. It reminded me of Startopia, which is a good sign.

column8:
Abandoned by the developers, because they relied on the early access funding to continue developing their game.

Quote from DoubleFine:
|||||"We started Spacebase with an open ended-production plan, hoping that it would find similar |||||success      (and therefore funding) to the alpha-funded games that inspired it. Some of its early sales |||||numbers indicated this might be the case, but slowly things changed, and it became clear that this |||||was looking like a year and a half of production instead of five or so."

Don't buy this game in its current state.

column9:
I have mixed feelings about this game. On the one hand, I think it has a very good design and good ideas to implement, but on the other, it lacks a lot of content, and the much-discussed bug problem can ruin a game and make you have to start over.

Special mention to the soundtrack; I think it's spectacular.

If you like science fiction and construction games, and you can buy it on sale, then it's not bad.

For now, I'll give it a vote of confidence. Let's hope they continue adding content and improving those catastrophic bugs.

A space station simulation game. Control four astronauts who initially volunteer to accompany you. Build your own space base in space. Prevent alien invasions and manage the supply of supplies within your base. Sometimes, you'll also have to keep an eye on the astronauts' friendships.

Unfortunately, this game is still under development, but it's actually quite exciting. As for whether this company will work hard to complete the development...
Let's wait and see...

column9:
It's difficult at first. But once you get the hang of it and you've gotten used to the menu controls, which are a bit cumbersome here and there, it's a very exciting experience that demands a lot of planning, etc. the further you go.

Last but not least, you're constantly being attacked by pirates!
Which can be quite intense at times. You barely think, wow, the station is finally up and running.
Pirates are already coming. If you're not careful, they'll slaughter all your residents, and you can only hope that new residents will appear after a while. ^^

Here you have to decide for yourself whether you can get the hang of it or whether you should just start over.
The attacks are easy at the beginning but become more difficult as the game progresses.

There are also exploration phases.
Suddenly, another station appears not far from yours, or perhaps docks next to yours. This really puts you in a certain mood of discovery. I wonder what's on the other stationâ€”are they enemies or new crew members?

What I struggled with was mining raw materials. At the beginning, there was quite a lot near the station.
Once they were mined, my guys went off to the nearest fields. The problem is the air in the spacesuits. If you're not careful! They fly there but never come back and end up,
first deliberately leaving and then even dead at the mining site. =)

Summary:

I really liked that you can build a station however you want and it doesn't get boring.
I have to say, it would be nice if more options were introduced soon. Because once you've researched everything and built all the modules, the game only feels half-baked.
I miss the fact that I can't do much.
All you have to do then is watch out for your residents and fend off pirates.

I think if you add more options for station expansion, like decorating, etc., the game will become even more intense.

A few possible quests. ^^
Visiting merchants to buy and sell.
Space artifacts, etc.
A bio module where you can create park landscapes. (With a change of season: summer, winter, spring, autumn)
A shop for the residents where you can dress them, maybe an editor.
A weapons shop so your security forces can also buy black market weapons.
And so on.

But since it's not finished yet, I think the price is too high,
because you have to pay. Too expensive for a game that isn't finished.

You have to say that.

Otherwise, I had a lot of fun and even got briefly caught white until I reached the point where I had researched everything and there weren't enough mining fields.

In the end, everything was researched and everything was mined. The only source of income was collecting the bodies of dead pirates and turning them into money, but it's a long process, etc.

It's a good game, but it should offer more options. As it is, it's only a short-term pleasure of, say, 2 to 8 cities.

A game for in between.

Thank you."

Best regards, Cap.

column9:
For now, the few graphical bugs aren't too bothersome. Sometimes some explanations are missing, so you're not always sure what to do, but overall, it's a good game.

It's extremely frustrating that the entire scientific research part isn't finished! You can just... build a station... and that's it. A few meteorites, a few enemies, but I think the event management system will probably evolve, hopefully incorporating a story... We'll see.

In any case, it's looking really good: if you like management games, buy it with your eyes closed when it's finished! :)

column8:
Given the current state and price tag of the game, I would wait until more features, bug fixes, and content arrive.  Having said that, I played for almost 3 hours straight and cannot wait to see this game grow.  I picked it up during the summer sale for 10 bucks and do not regret that it all!

If you're a fan of sim games like Towns and Dwarf Fortress then you'll love this too.

column8:
This one's quite a puzzle to review because it's got a relentlessly compelling 'one more turn' allure to its moment-to-moment of construction and management, but there are no over-arching goals or rewards for anything you do or 'achieve'.  It's very sandboxy in that way.  It's more pointless than Civilization, Sim City, or any 4X game, but I still just love collecting resources, assigning roles, salvaging shit, and building more base.  

It's buggy as hell.  A lot of shit straight-up doesn't work and the game's greatest weakness is its AI behaviours and pathing which will have you losing so many crew to senselessly suicidal idiocy (eg: "Suffocating due to area with no air!  Air-lock's right next to me, but I'd rather just asphyxiate than get into a space suit and live, thanks.") which kind of takes any joy out of nurturing your higher-skilled crew or paying any attention to their needs, especially when you rapidly replace them without any effort whatsoever.

This is going to be a really fantastic game if it ever gets finished and if they can ever fix the AI.  That level of frustration is the only reason I'll ever turn the thing off, most times.  If you get easily frustrated by outright broken shit, watch this one and wait til it's actually released.

POST-'RELEASE' EDIT: 

It did not get finished.   Shame on the developers for giving up and writing it off.  

This is an Early Access cautionary tale.  No matter what assurances you read on the store page for an Early Access game, it can always be abandoned in a shitty state.

column8:
[EDIT] I wrote this review when I assumed (hoped!) funding would continue and the game would reach its promising potential. With version 1.0 on the way and a general air of abandonment from DF, I'm less keen to recommend this. I still load it up now and again and lament the missed opportunity...
================

I'm offering up a cautious recommendation here. This game is very promising, while still being far from a complete experience in its current state (Alpha 5d). I bought it on the strength of it being made by Double Fine, who I think have a habit of putting out some really fun games. The recommendation is partially based on their reputation.

As other reviewers have mentioned, the UI is great and the overall aesthetic brings to mind 70s/ 80s SF such as Hitchhikers Guide to the Galaxy or Dark Star. Having said that, the devs should really set about implementing some goal-based gameplay soon enough. It seems an odd move to put it out in its current state since there's not the level of freedom for it to act simply as a light space survival sim. There isn't really enough depth at the moment for the player to come up with their own objectives beyond not dying for long enough to build a space-pub. In its current state it looks like you can try out all the space- decor and experience the space- mining and space- pirates in a fairly short stretch of time. Basically, I love the content so far and I'd like there to be more. 

I really hope there is continued support and funding on this project. There have been a few negative reviews on Steam but most people acknowledge the potential here. I look forward to seeing the updates and in the meantime, I can set about building my Silent Running style interstellar greenhouse.
column9:
[EDIT] I wrote this review when I assumed (hoped!) funding would continue and the game would reach its promising potential. With version 1.0 on the way and a general air of abandonment from DF, I'm less keen to recommend this. I still load it up now and again and lament the missed opportunity...
================

I'm offering up a cautious recommendation here. This game is very promising, while still being far from a complete experience in its current state (Alpha 5d). I bought it on the strength of it being made by Double Fine, who I think have a habit of putting out some really fun games. The recommendation is partially based on their reputation.

As other reviewers have mentioned, the UI is great and the overall aesthetic brings to mind 70s/ 80s SF such as Hitchhikers Guide to the Galaxy or Dark Star. Having said that, the devs should really set about implementing some goal-based gameplay soon enough. It seems an odd move to put it out in its current state since there's not the level of freedom for it to act simply as a light space survival sim. There isn't really enough depth at the moment for the player to come up with their own objectives beyond not dying for long enough to build a space-pub. In its current state it looks like you can try out all the space- decor and experience the space- mining and space- pirates in a fairly short stretch of time. Basically, I love the content so far and I'd like there to be more. 

I really hope there is continued support and funding on this project. There have been a few negative reviews on Steam but most people acknowledge the potential here. I look forward to seeing the updates and in the meantime, I can set about building my Silent Running style interstellar greenhouse.

column8:
Great game with much potential.. Sure I struggled a bit at first, lost many crews, but all in all they've done a nice job.. I do have a couple of gripes that I'll post here, but I'm sure it's already on their to-do list of stuff to fix:

My biggest complaint is the fact that it looks like Iâ€™m commander of some of the stupidest aliens in the entire galaxy.  I had a derelict ship enter my sector, so I sent some guards to check it out. Well as soon as they did, they decided to take brief naps afterwards.  It wasnâ€™t so bad trying to get them to leave, but when the oxygen generators failed, they started running around like chickens with their heads cut off.  My genius repair technicians decided to head over there and fix the problem, but their first step was take off their life giving suits and join the orgy of morons by running around with them.  Why they didnâ€™t just keep their suit on, fix the unit and then take off those stinky suits is beyond me.  My only option was to destroy the ship with all the morons on board.

All in all the game is addicting, even with all its flaws.. Hereâ€™s hoping they fix this craziness with some better AI or at least more logical ones.

The game is a new twist on simulations I believe. It has the old look of a late 90's early 2000's game while still catching that modern feel and playing style. It's a truthly immersive game, even for what little the developers have done, that can keep you playing for hours on end. Even when you have the occasional crash, you have no problem wiht starting a new base!

Fantastic game, I cannot wait for each new update.

EDIT: Since they dropped the game unfinished, refusing to work on it, I cannot support the game...

column8: I want to preface this review by saying it is about the update schedule, or lack there of, not the game play itself. Knowning this game is early access, I bought it back in January expecting that it would have bugs, lack of content and be a work in progress. I also expected steady progression on the games development. In half a year of owning it I have seen two full alpha revisions and maybe seven or so minor patch/bug fix updates. There is no posted schedule or hint at when updates can be expected. It feels like this game is on the back burner and a one man team is working on it. All the while the rest of company is putting time and effort into they 5-6 other games listed for release this year from DoubleFine. In short, if you are looking for a game with a set alpha release time frame and/or constant status updates this is not for you. Paying the money I did I was hoping to see progress more like Prison Architect and Space Engineers and that is just not the case.

The game has enormous potential, which unfortunately hasn't been fully exploited yet; it's easy to get bored.
And there are still too many bugs:
- Display issues (impossible to see the entire character list, for example)
- When you assign a job to a character, it often takes ages for them to complete their task
-...
I'll be following the game's progress, hoping to be able to give it a positive review. For now, it's a shame...

column8:
Quite fun. Still needs a lot of work, but it's definitely looking promising. There's nothing that's truly broken, just a general lack of variety that further development will undoubtedly fill out. Even so it's difficult enough that even when you think you're strong enough to take on some of the pirates you might just be deluding yourself. Only issue is that there doesn't seem to be a significant benefit to taking on raiders yet. Would also be nice to see a progression route where YOU could send out raiding parties and take other bases' supplies and/or dock your station to another's to merge it with yours.

Definitely

column8:
What can be said ?...: Spacebase DF-9.
 [ An Early Access Preview ]


*Uninterested exhale/grunt.*
*Leaves to get coffee.*
*Returns, sips coffee.*
*Writes this prologue in a way, that hopefully delivers the feeling of indifference.*

This, is exactly why. You cannot properly review an Early Access game, since most of the games content is not present. It is like Minecraft in Alpha, its a proof of concept with not much context, polish or content.

And thats why, i cannot write a review about it...

What ? Dont look at me like that, when you think about it properly. You'l see exactly what i mean, it would be like reviewing something just based on its trailer. [spoiler] *Cough* Colonial Marines [/spoiler].

But allright... 

Spacebase DF-9 is a game, where you try to build a working Deep Space outpost. 

This is only hampered by the AI and its questionable prioritisation. Multiple times, my only technician thought it would be more important to talk to Johny the SpaceSlug than to, lets say, repair the Life Support systems.

And this is one of those games where there is a certain build plan. And deviating from it will just result in failure.
That is, if you can get the builders to do everything in time.

And speaking of "doing stuff on time". That is an ironic statement/joke, that i hope several of you will get. The citizen of your station are complete and utter lazybones.. 'ses.

Most of their life consist of eating food and talking to others. And this they will do even if they have other, more important stuff they need to do. Like maintenance to make sure the station wont disintegrate like a clown car.  Another rather ironic thing to say about this...


So to compress that all:

Spacebase DF-9  is like Minecraft in Alpha, very lacking in content. But the concept is easy to get, now it just needs some care and attention to make it a full game. And for gods sake, repair the AI.

column8:
It was fun for a while, until you start noticing the stupidity of the AIs: 
- Miners don't use the nearest airlocks and suffocate. 
- The techs spend their day getting fat instead of repairing equipment (especially the turrets outside the station). 
- Doctors don't always grab the bodies floating in space. 
- Everyone runs around panicking when the station loses air instead of suiting up and repairing the hole. 

There are also graphical glitches: 
- Sometimes phantom fires stay lit in the floor if the crew put the fire out without a fire extinguisher.
- Airlock LED indicators often stay floating in space after the doors are removed. 

There are more problems, and the game features don't feel fleshed out enough. I would recommend trying this game later in its life.

Edit: Now that the developers have stopped, well, developing, the game isn't a worthy investment unless you want to cry tears of sadness.

column9:
It's a fun space station building game. The core elements of the game are station expansion, resource management, maintenance, and defense against catastrophic events. The main ones are pirate attacks and asteroid bombardment.

The main problem, however, is the AI â€‹â€‹system's sluggishness. It gets stuck here and there. Sometimes, when building a substation outside, it gets stuck in some kind of quagmire, unable to move and suffocating. Sometimes, it can't even return to base in time, dying of suffocation.

And the cool thing is, the gun turrets inside the station can shoot through the floor and walls, attacking enemies outside.

column8: In its current state this game is a fantastic mix of FTL and Theme Hospital, I highly recommend this to anyone that likes either of those titles. Really looking forward to the future developments, easily a game i've enjoyed a lot recently.
column9: In its current state this game is a fantastic mix of FTL and Theme Hospital, I highly recommend this to anyone that likes either of those titles. Really looking forward to the future developments, easily a game i've enjoyed a lot recently.

column8:
This game is a great base building space game.

At the moment it is still in alpha and still has bugs. So far I haven't met a bug that has broken the game for me.

I do feel that the percentage of spawns doesn't equal the area in which you have placed your base. Low, Semi-Low and so forth all seem to spawn things at roughly the same rate reguardless.

Early Raiders are a little tuff and can take over your entire base.

It can be unpredictable - just when I thought all was going well a seres of events meant the lost of my base!
Overall it is fun, and it makes you think when it comes to how you place and build your base.

column8: This game had great potential when they launched it back in October. And now, 9 months later, it is still solidly stuck at potential. They add a new room about once every other month or so, and that's about it. There are still really rudimentary bugs that they have shown no progress toward fixing, and it still feels incredibly unpolished, and they still have yet to add any fun. For the amount of time this has been in development, this little progress on it is really unforgivable. I can't recommend it unless someone actually takes its development seriously.

Leider ist die Alpha (stand 2.07.14) vom Umfang her viel zu gering. Nach etwa 2 Stunden ist das Spiel vollstÃ¤ndig erfasst und bietet keine Ãœberraschungen mehr. NatÃ¼rlich ist das nicht ganz richtig denn die noch zahlreich vorhandenen Bugs und Kinderkrankheiten zwingen die eigene Sternenbasis schnell in die Knie und beenden das Spiel vorzeitig. Wirklicher SpielspaÃŸ kommt bei DF9 daher leider noch nicht auf â€“ obwohl das Potential gegeben ist.

column9:
First of all: Spacebase DF9 isn't a bad game, and it's not a complete failure either.

Unfortunately, the alpha (as of July 2, 2014) is far too small in scope. After about two hours, the game is completely grasped and offers no more surprises. Of course, that's not entirely true, as the numerous bugs and teething issues still present quickly bring your own starbase to its knees and end the game prematurely. Therefore, DF9 is unfortunately not yet truly fun to play â€“ although the potential is there.

Recommendation to buy?: Unfortunately, not; I strongly recommend waiting.

column8: Spacebase DF-9 is a space colony building game by Double Fine. One moment you will go from peace across your colony with 20 citizens and then a meteor strike hits and kills 19 of your people leaving a lone survivor who is left to wallow in sadness. In this comedy with a twist starring Adam Sandler you play as Adam Sandler. The lone surviving drunkard who must rebuild his space colony 350,000 years in the future he is then attacked by giant space slugs as he uses his classic comedic timing in mutiple jokes about them. This game brings you back to the golden days of Adam Sandler when he only played a single character in the movie, rather then 2, this twist makes you remember the time where Adam Sandler had made a good movie in 10 years. Everything goes alright until Adam Sandler finally is asphyxiated by his lack of oxygen in his space suit thus ending his comedic golden age. This game is likely the movie of the century. 5 stars.

column8:
Sims in space lite with permadeath and poor pacing.  Please fix entire game.



...Okay, it's actually very addicting, which is WHY the permadeath (no save points) make it that much more brutal.  IT TAKES SOOOO LONG to have a decent base, and then boop, everyone dead.
The mechanics are pretty good, but the placing of objects is off sometimes, and the interface could use a lot of work.  But it's fun to see your little colony doing well!  And so so brutally frustrating after crew have been given the "builder" job yet refuse to install the air reclaimers, asphyxiating your entire base.  The entire crew apparently has mono because all they ever do is eat and sleep, it seems.  For a game that's been in development this long it's kind of surprising how not nearly done it is.  But I love this company and when it IS done, this game will likely be awesome.

It IS Alpha! People who like this say it's similar to play Prison Architect.  So I'm going to go play that now.  Too bad it's not in space. :(

column8:
I've been playing the alpha 5b ([i]Doctors with Boarders[/i]) build, and the game definitely has promise.

Not everything works yet (e.g. power reactors don't seem to serve a purpose), and some things work when they probably shouldn't (e.g. the wall mounted turrets inside the base seem to be able to shoot raider ships that are outside).  The game also currently lacks any tutorial content, so you'll need to learn by playing or look for outside information.  There is enough there to enjoy, although after a few hours you'll probably reach the end of what's available and need to restart keep it from getting boring.

There is minimal micro-management options available in the game (you can assign jobs to people and tell them to go to the infirmary), so you need to be careful how much work you queue up since there is no way to prioritise it.  There are other mechanics that don't work so well, such as sending security personel to derelict bases to investigate: the bases always seemed to be hostile and I would end up with some of my people dying.  I found it easier to deal with these bases by getting a builder to knock holes in a few walls to vent the atmosphere first.

You can already see some of the humour that Double Fine is known for.  Each person has a SpaceFace feed where they make notes about their day.  There is humour in some of the game mechanics, such as doctors getting rid of the dead bodies in the same matter refineries used by the miners.

It'll be interesting to see how the game develops.

There is minimal micro-management options available in the game (you can assign jobs to people and tell them to go to the infirmary), so you need to be careful how much work you queue up since there is no way to prioritise it.  There are other mechanics that don't work so well, such as sending security personel to derelict bases to investigate: the bases always seemed to be hostile and I would end up with some of my people dying.  I found it easier to deal with these bases by getting a builder to knock holes in a few walls to vent the atmosphere first.

You can already see some of the humour that Double Fine is known for.  Each person has a SpaceFace feed where they make notes about their day.  There is humour in some of the game mechanics, such as doctors getting rid of the dead bodies in the same matter refineries used by the miners.

It'll be interesting to see how the game develops.

column8: Its a fun game with promise though it still has various gamebreaking bugs.

column8:
I'm a fan of Star Trek and Science Fiction in general and I love base building games.

So this game was a no brainer for me to support and I've sunk many hours into it and I highly recommend it.

It's challenging and it's fun and the developers never disapoint so I'm going to say this is going to be one of the better games when it comes out.

column8:
1.0 review update:
I don't recommend this game anymore. The developer decided to quit working on it simply because its alpha release did not net them the money they were hoping to get. Not everyone goes for an alpha release. Some want to see the finished product.

Considering the developer thinks of the 1.0 release as the finished product, let me say that I'm thoroughly disappointed in the product. I would not have bought it in this state.

Instead of complaining about the lack of funds they received for their in-progress game, the developers could have simply hammered on the bugs, made a well-rounded game, and then the 1.0 release could have brought so many more people in. People who would have paid them.

This is yet another example of why Early Access fails; developers pulling the plug on projects because their expectations were impossible to realize.

column8:
Has much potential but to be honest progress is painfully slow. There is often no update from the devs for weeks at a time and the 'monthly' updates when they do come, late, are small.

I have totally given up playing the game as after a couple of hours you've been through the same repetative cycle of building, loosing everything and starting again twice or more. There are very few item/rooms to build. One of the things I really have a problem with at the moment is the rediculous way it handles breaches. I can remove a section of wall then watch the O2 level in the room slowly drop off over a minute or so. This makes dealing with raiders hard as the security are next to useless and you best option is decompression which doesn't work.

I hope they get all this sorted, there is so much potential here for a great game. But its not worth buying now while even the very basics don't work. For now save your money, there are more bugs than working componants it seems and every belated update just introduces more.

I'm going back to prison architect for now, if you want an alpha builder, thats where to invest your money right now.

I have heard the team is only 3 people, considering the funding sales in this game has already brought it I have to wonder if this is true, then how much they really are behind it. It has certianly made me reconsider my feelings about buying early access in the future.

PS I have much more than 8 hours outside the steam time as of writing this.
