column8:
This game has some real promist. In its current state I found that I had "completed" it.   

Suggestions for the devs:

1.  Update the roster to make it smaller in UI space.  Add features like health, needs and other important info
2. There seems to be no real objective except have a larger base.. Once you build the rooms that are availabe you are done.  Add goals:  Build a docking station to get an economy going, Build warp gates/black holes for travel and trade. Add a goal to colonize a nearby planet. 
3. Research is painfully slow and cumbersome.  Add options to speed it up by spending Matter or sience points. 
4. Random Debris fields are not really a challenge.  Add a couple of fire extenguishers and you can over come them.  
5. Infirmary is useless.  Needs a serious look to make it a worth while room
6. add action menus to the right click of a resident.  example:  Right Click > take corpse to refinery/dispose etc. 

I am anxious to see what this game can become. You are on the right track!

column8:
I cannot recommend at this time. The two biggest problems are the citizen AI and zoning. The citizens do the dumbest things and there is no way to micro-manage them to do what they really need to do. On more than one occasion I have had people die because they wouldn't build a door or they'd take off their spacesuit in the unoxygenated. The zone system limits what you can do with your base. You can only put certain types of objects in certain zones. This means you can put a life support system in the same room as the bedroom or pub. This is a pain when you are just starting out and can't really afford to layout an entire space station.

A lack of content is to be expected but these issues harm the gameplay.

column8:
Spacebase alpha

The best part about this is learning how things work by failing. The AI is hit or miss, but that's the best part. Accidently commanding your crew to dismantle a machine, but instead telling them to vaporize the floor beneath it too, and having your crew get sucked out into space is hilarious. I can see how It may get boring after "winning" and being able to withstand raiders and meteor showers, but it'll take a good while before that happens. Even then, you just restart and do it again.

Also, my bartender, Tim Schafer died of suffocation, after I accidently destroyed a wall seperating the bar and the life support systems, and the builder crews started dismantaling oxygen recyclers. Whoops... BEST GAME EVER

column8: I don't understand the negative user reviews.  I had several hours of fun with it in its current sandbox state.  It is certainly not too difficult or "unplayable".  Once you get the hang of some common errors when constructing, the AI handles things fairly well, and the pop-up clues for events and problems are adequate.  It has potential to be a good replacement for Mucky Foot's Startopia.

column9:
It's a bit raw and unbalanced. It's fun to play, but for the first three hours, it gets boring. The most frustrating thing is when you have 10 guys in your base, each with their own skill level up to 5, and then two raiders show up and shoot down two-thirds of the staff. There's no tutorial; I ruined five bases before I learned how to control everything.

Regarding intelligence:
Raiders arrived, turrets and security shot them down. One raider was wounded, lying on the ground writhing in pain. A doctor came and healed him! The raider got up and killed the doctor, and then broke all the equipment in the room. A technician came running to fix it, and the raider killed him.
Here's another situation. I started building a base with three workers, built an air production thing. Two more guys showed up, and the thing was designed for three. I ordered a second one to be built for air, but instead they ran around the base in a panic that they were running out of air, and they ran like that for about 3 minutes until they all died.

column8: Sehr geiles Spiel! Ich glaube aber, dass es auf Dauer etwas langweilig werden kann, da bisher viel zu wenig Content eingebaut wurde. Dennoch mÃ¶chte ich dieses Spiel jedem empfehlen, der ein Spiel dieser Art sucht.
column9: A really cool game! However, I think it might get a bit boring in the long run, as there's far too little content added so far. Nevertheless, I would recommend this game to anyone looking for a game of this type.

column8:
Out the airlock!
This game combines two elements I usually enjoy: building game and scifi. Unfortunately it tryies so very hard to be cute and fluffy that I want to barf. I REALLY don't care what fictional bands my colonists enjoy and I certainly don't want to read through their mental diharrea to find out what exactly displeases them. The worst part are the conversations with ships arriving at your spacebase. I had more meaningful conversations with my cat...

Can not recommend this game at any price. I tried to like it but it's really just a waste of time.

Get Dwarf Fortress, Prison Architect, RimWorld or Banished instead.

column8:
I've played this game only a couple hours and so far I really enjoy it.  You can create rooms for your guys to sleep in, tell them to mine asteroids so you can make your place bigger, put in a pub.  Just don't forget to put in enough oxygen recyclers, otherwise, you'll have a lot of dead guys just floating around.  
The only issue I found so far, is that when I started out one of my guys was stuck in an asteroid.  He wouldn't move or anything, just sat there in space and suffocated.  After I got situated, I was able to mine his body out of the asteroid.  The good doctor was then able to turn his body into materials for me to continue my construction.

column8:
Its promising.

While yes, the AI is buggy almost to the point of hilarity and yes, your success or failure seems to hinge on wether or not you get a certain bug (my favourite was the security member who floated outside an airlock and waited until they suffocated), the game certainly has promise.

I can't wait to play it as its closer to being complete. I look forward to taking the chance that a derilict station that has just shown up will in fact contain raiders, and having my builders knock out a wall section to make them all suffocate first. Of course I also did that to a station containing friendlies and felt a little guilty :)

column8: This game has some promise but currently is a little dull. It is standard resource collection, building, and some disaster management. I think they are aiming for something like The Sims in space, but there isn't really a spark to make this game interesting, and also it is full of bugs. There is a difference between an early access game and an alpha game. I'd expect early access to have the features, but minimal bugs, like most other early access games (E.g. Godus). This game falls short of the marketing and I think there are other more interesting, more engaging games on Steam to try first, e.g. Craft The World.
column9: This game has some promise but currently is a little dull. It is standard resource collection, building, and some disaster management. I think they are aiming for something like The Sims in space, but there isn't really a spark to make this game interesting, and also it is full of bugs. There is a difference between an early access game and an alpha game. I'd expect early access to have the features, but minimal bugs, like most other early access games (E.g. Godus). This game falls short of the marketing and I think there are other more interesting, more engaging games on Steam to try first, e.g. Craft The World.

column8:
Spacebase DF-9 looked quite interesting, from the Dwarf Fortress-esque room management to the quirky characters and random event system.  Unfortunately, it hasn't had a significant content upgrade since I initially saw it months ago on an Evening with Sips episode or short series.  What is in this game is a wide gamut of bugs combined with sheer stupidity when it comes to the AI, arguably the most important part of the game, and they screwed it up.

Not being able to build rooms, place objects, or cancel construction orders without having to move the camera around until the game sees fit to finally let your commands go through was the most common bug, and it persisted in being terrible from the moment I tried to start building a base to my eventual giving up on the game.  Random events seem to pull from a pool of maybe 5 different things, the most frequent of which was a ship encounter that featured a squeal along the lines of "EEEEEEEEEEEEEEEE!!!!! WE FINALLY FOUND YOU!!!!!!!!  WE'RE COMING ABOARD THIS INSTANT!" to which no matter whether you select to allow them on or not, you are forced to take on additional crew members, all of which will be more of a liability than a help due to their universally crap skills.  This will culminate in your base having to constantly expand its oxygen suppliers and eventually even building a second reactor, just to provide for these new idiots while avoiding losing your valuable crew members to oxygen deprivation as the wastes of space use it all up.

Oh, and if you want to expand your oxygen room to make space for more recyclers, or any room in fact, make sure you set the entire station to become builders.  Because when you have four builders dismantle a wall, immediately head back into the base to go to sleep, and refuse to build the floor in place of the wall you just tore down, your entire base will asphyxiate and your builders will sleep themselves to death, dooming the entire station.  Absolute rubbish prioritizing and programming.

Do not buy this game.  Do not buy Early Access games.  Early Access games are a plague on Steam and should not be allowed a store page or a sale until they have a finished product.

WE FINALLY FOUND YOU!!!!!!!!  WE'RE COMING ABOARD THIS INSTANT!" to which no matter whether you select to allow them on or not, you are forced to take on additional crew members, all of which will be more of a liability than a help due to their universally crap skills.  This will culminate in your base having to constantly expand its oxygen suppliers and eventually even building a second reactor, just to provide for these new idiots while avoiding losing your valuable crew members to oxygen deprivation as the wastes of space use it all up.

Oh, and if you want to expand your oxygen room to make space for more recyclers, or any room in fact, make sure you set the entire station to become builders.  Because when you have four builders dismantle a wall, immediately head back into the base to go to sleep, and refuse to build the floor in place of the wall you just tore down, your entire base will asphyxiate and your builders will sleep themselves to death, dooming the entire station.  Absolute rubbish prioritizing and programming.

Do not buy this game.  Do not buy Early Access games.  Early Access games are a plague on Steam and should not be allowed a store page or a sale until they have a finished product.

column8:
Alright, I enjoy aspects of this game very much, but the A.I. is, quite frankly, awful. Disasters like space debris and raider invasions happen fairly often, but your civilians have almost no way of actually responding to them, unless you make them a security guard and give them a beacon. And even then, only about half of them will do what you say. Then sometimes they'll start suffocating in space, but they won't even attempt to head back inside the station. And if you order them back in (by sending them either to the infirmary or to a beacon), they'll take the most roundabout route possible and still die. Once, I sent a worker to tear apart a derelict for extra scrap, but when he got on, he took off his space suit, so when he removed the walls, he suffocated.

I really want to like this game, I really, really do, but the A.I. needs to be fixed desperately. I'm talking priority 1, above all else. Either that or give the player some sort of option to order any worker (not just security guards) to different parts of the station at will. Honestly, I was enjoying it for the first 2 hours, but the last hour I was tearing my hair out as the terrible AI constantly killed off my best people.

I realize this is still alpha, and I expected some bugs. But my gosh, I expected the AI to at least be somewhat competent. If you're going to release an alpha, DoubleFine, at least have the game be somewhat playable.

I'm sure my feelings for this game will change later down the line, but honestly this alpha has left a bit of a bad taste in my mouth. There's so much here that I really like, but the AI ruins it for me.

column8:
I've played 7 stations so far, 2 lost because I had no clue what I was doing, 5 more lost because the game's AI makes some pretty terrible decisions (for instance 3 security guards opted to just sit and chit chat with eachother while 2 bandits entered the base and killed everyone else in the room with them - then they all died while still chatting away) or because the game decided I didn't need to keep playing and suffered from one of its many game breaking bugs.  Needless to say this game needs an extraordinary amount of work before I would even have classified it as Early Access.  For now, stay away.

Update:  Many of these bugs still exist and production of the game has ceased.  So I would strongly suggest you spend your money elsewhere.  If you want a good game with similar style (though not in space) then look at Gnomoria.

column8:
There are quite a few bad reviews for the game. Most people seem concered about the current state of the game. While the game is a long way from finished, maybe I can put a couple of concerns to rest.

This game is a double fine game. Double Fine are an experience developer, who have made games such as Brutal Legend, The Cave and Phychonauts. They have built up quite a reputation and are very unlikely to leave thish game unifinished.

Also, this game is being developed on Linux from the get-go. On the off chance someone from Double Fine actually reads this, let me just say this was really awesome of you guys! I have recently stopped using windows and am very happy to see all my Double Fine games not only run on linux. But run better on linux. (Seriously, I get like double FPS on Brutal Legend!)

Really great linux support, really fun even while it's no where near complete. Also planning to do an LP of it soon :D

column8:
Game went like this...

Built a small spacebase
Randoms wanted to join the crew
Said "No"
They joined anyway
Built more life support, becuase new crew were breathing up all the air
More randoms wanted to join the crew
Said "No"
Turns out they were raiders and slaughter the crew
Spacebase drifted silently through space for the rest of eternity

Amazing game, loads of fun! :)

column8:
First, I would like to point out that this review was made on 15.06.2014, early stage of game.

I liked this game, it has a lot of potencial, but so far, there is not much to do in it. Space pirates are lazy and not that dangerous as they try to sound in vidcom, so there is no much of a challange to start with. Just be sure to build airlock and airsupport at the begginning and you are good to go, you will be fine untill you bore yourself to death and quit the game. In my personal opinion there should be more random events, like sickness, rogue settlers, dangerous aliens, neutral events that could turn out favorable or agressive, problems with neighbour bases (So they won't just hang out nearby, but they could request for your help or attack you), etc. Lack of danger is kinda killing the survival vibe in this game, you just build, chill out. Build some more, kill occasion pirate and it's what else? Nothing. This game need a challange, something for a player to fight for. This would make it way much interesting, in my opinion.

Update... Nope... They didn't delivered.

3/10.

column8:
Spacebase DF-9 â€“ Preview
By GMCamulos

Genre: Simulation, Indie, Strategy
Platform: PC / Mac / Linux 
Publisher / Developer: Double Fine Productions

From the Devs:
â€œSpacebase DF-9 is a simulation game in ongoing development at Double Fine Productions. Alpha 3b version is available right now for Windows, Mac, and Linux.â€

Gameplay:
So the first simulation strategy game I ever played was Theme Hospital, and I am SO glad that the basics have stayed the same.
Spacebase DF-9 still being in early access alpha stages at the moment means there are still some bugs that need fixing, but that is not to say that the game is not engaging and fun right now, because it very much is! 
From the get go you start where you want to. You pick the location to start from the galaxy map which has different indicators as to how that area will play. From how many minerals will be there for you to mine when you arrive, how close you are to warp gates for new visitors (good and bad) and even the areas magnetic field levels. 
Once you find an area you like the looks of, you travel to that area in your trusty SEED Capsule with your three starting inhabitants in your roster.

You start off with 6 minutes of air in their space suits so itâ€™s a good idea to build your beginning base as quickly as possible.

From there the game progresses with new rooms to build onto your ship, the need for food and clean air. Refineries to turn your mined resources into useable material and the delight of new people arriving at your station and the pain of having raiders try to destroy your base.
The main issue I currently have with the alpha (which I assume will be fixed pretty soon) is that half the time I need something built quickly to stop bad things happeningâ€¦ my builders decide that they have other more important things to do (which has resulted in everyone on my base dying from starvation about four times now).
But if you have played any simulation game in the past, itâ€™s a quick pickup to learn how the game mechanics work and no trouble from there on in.

Graphics:
For an early access Alpha release, the game clearly shows it has had some graphical polish sought early in development. 
The rich backgrounds and effects used in the game provide a very crisp and clean alpha. Not much variation once you start building, but you never know, the developers at Double Fine may add some randomisation when building rooms in a later release?

Sound:
The game does have a nice background track playing and there are some audio assets in the game, but nothing that really stood out or shocked me. I look forward to more sound assets being added in the future, but in alpha development that is not something you really wait with baited breath for.

Skill Levels and Controls:
As I stated at the start, I have been playing simulation games for a while now. And most gamers would be able to tell you the jist of what happens in The Sims. 
So its not hard to understand that the game runs pretty smoothly for most gamers. 
Each hotkey is listed on the action in your GUI menu for building and assignment of rosters, so no trouble there. Camera is a quick to grasp control setup as well. You basically zoom in and out and use the W,S,A,D keys to move around the map.
I think a veteran simulation player would have the best bet of survival in their first base run. But it is not 100% clear at first what is needed when and how much of something is a good idea to start with. 
So expect a bit of restarting as you work things out. Which leads to:

Replayability:
Like most simulation and strategy games, there is a metric tonne of replayability, even at this alpha stage. 
The maps are randomly generated when you start based on the map level indicators when you pick your base local from the galaxy map, BUT you get to choose where on the map you build your first room, and from that first room, the choice is all up to you how you want to build. 
The random encounters of new inhabitants and raiders also helps determine what to build next. 
But I dare say, no two bases will ever be the same!
At the moment though you can only have one base saved at a time. You start a base, then save and exit. If you start a new one and then save and exit it DOES overwrite the old base, so be careful.

Last thoughts:
I spent a bit during the last STEAM sales, but I am very very glad I picked up this little gem. Itâ€™s a fun take on space base simulation, and holds a lot of potential.
I will be keeping an eye out for future dev plans for this one and recommend that if you have the $24.99 then you should pick this one up for your library.

column8:
One of the games I honestly wanted to love, to play for days...
I must say, the fact that the devlopers ignored a lot of feedback of the Community is very true.

Even I tried to help out, finding bugs, bringing feedback how to make specific core mechanics more fun... but most of them got ignored.

Alpha 5 should have shown us, that it goes down:
Even the Healthsystem didn't work in the beginning!
The game has three parts connected to health, Injuries, Illnesses and "HEALTHPOINTS".

So Doctors were able to heal everything except the later, permanently injure personnel.
Another critical aspect were bodies which never got cleaned up.

After all: The new Sickbay went completely redundant due to the simple fact that firefights always ended up deadly. "Phazer Rifles" shoot several projectiles at one person and even in the case the intruders got killed, all those bolts hit the Character, killing them immediately.


The feeling of building a Spacebase with a social structure also failed massively.
Morale is a simple factor that drops and raises just because of silly things (How much nice "Stuff" is around a character... seriously?) and while the Death of your Crew also drops the morale, you can be sure they will always be depressed.

Content that makes the Spacestation feel more alive is fully missing, useless content got applied to the game as much as the developers could.

So brawls happen very often, incapacitating (yes, only here people get not killed) the other ones and in the end you are struggling to hold up with tons of angry, depressed people which get slowly killed by raiders.

The last update (that included a push from Double fine onto the Steam Mainpage), was probably the most frustrating. As stated above the brawls.
It also implemented Items, that get dropped by raiders and personnel, which in the end is rotting on the floor for eternity.
While some stuff sounds like weapons, some are armours, some are absolutely useless objects.

In the case of low morale, people go now insane, making them aggressive and destorying property... and get them brigged or killed in most cases.
While the brig was actually a nice Idea, it was the same like the medbay.

Double Fine's Devs or Conceptors didn't really think about the gameplay, they just kicked another Update out with features that are less then half working and this all under the cloak of Early Access.
While EACC-Games are indeed not finished and can have bugs, they gave us mostly core features that are buggy, imbalanced and never fixed them, going on with a silly routine until they canceled the Project.
While the Community always brought up Bugs, they automatically produced even the most obvious bugs without fixing it before a release.

In general: I am disappointed with Double Fine and their product. It is still very expensive (22â‚¬) on Steam and therefore I absolutely do not advice buying it unless you are ready for a buggy game that has barely potential for fun.

The only hope I can see is, that the community mods the game once it reaches 1.0, making it a much better experience.

column8:
This game is fun to play, see how long you can hold till your base is destroyed or all crew members are killed by raiders or die from lack of oxygen! 

Even tho its still in alpha it is still playable. 

Devs release updates reasonably often and listen to the community on the DoubleFine Forums. They have delievered what they said they would, but i think pateince is required for alpha games from small (ish) developers. 

However i do not think its worth Â£18.99 yet... 11.99 maybe. The AI needs a lot of work still and after a few games it can become repetitative. Not much changes from base to base. You will encounter the same problems again and again.  

5/10 @ Alpha 5a

column8:
Would not recommend this game as it is now, wait until that shiny bright blue box that says "alpha" is gone. This game runs so well, it provided me with countless hours of fun, but as soon as they "fixed" it things started to break big time. I can't hail ships, I crash periodically for no reason whatsoever, my station members wait outside airlocks until they die of suffocation, the list would go on but these are just the things I've experienced until I decided to stop putting up with it.

Game is wonderful, just not right now.

column8:
I really try to like this game, I really do. But between the horrible AI, UI, and overall game meta, not to mention lackluster developer support over the course of the last year I cannot with good conscience recommend this to anybody. Wait at least until beta to buy this, and only if they significantly alter the meta-game.

As it stands the AI are imbecilic, the gameplay progression borders on unfair or unplayable even at low difficulty, and the game has a daisy chain of progressive bugs and glitches that functionally cripple your base the longer you play. Invisible raiders? Yes. Unhealable citizens? Got that too. Ludicrous pathing? Sure! Lack of transparency in regards to what you're placing into the game? Oh hell yes, have to rely on an oft-incomplete wiki full of speculations.

You would be better off looking to ancient games like Space Colony, or Startopia for a game of this genre that works. (More in the case of Startopia) This is what bugs me the most, since I normally would expect good things from a Double Fine game, if only because I enjoyed Brutal Legend. But it is obvious to me that Double Fine isn't investing many resources in this game, and probably have no intention of doing so either.

My prediction? A halt in development by Fall of 2014 when the dev team gets recalled to work on what is seen as more 'profitable' ventures. But maybe I'm just pessimistic because I've played games like this in the past with far higher levels of development from studios most people have never even heard of. (Okay, it's moving up into fall 2014 when I edited this and still no halt.. I can only hope that alpha 6 is some sort of incredible improvement.. But I won't hold my breath.) 

Spacebase DF-9 - 24.99
Startopia - 6.99 (Space Base DF-9 could learn something about meta from this)
Space Colony - Available on GOG for 9.99 (Again, something Spacebase DF-9 could learn about creating at least tolerably realistic social interactions in somewhat of a fun fashion.)

column8:
Even though it may still be in Alpha, Spacebase DF-9 is one of the funnest Sim type games i've had the pleasure of playing recently and another stellar title produced by Double FIne. The game slowly progresses from 3 crew members and a hastily constructed base that barely has the essentials to a thriving community of around 100 members that provides all the comforts of home. Each charecter in the game has their own little quirks as well, which certainly makes you feel a little more attatched to your charcters. You'll find yourself mourning the death of your favorite miner who got locked out of the base because of an airlock malfunction. 

Although it can get a little tedious during long play sessions, it is great to hop in for a half an hour or so, tweak your base up, and leave to return to it later. If your into sci-fi themes, or are just looking for a bit of fun, you can do far worse than this game.

column8:
Less 'Dwarf Fortress in space' and more 'The Sims meets Dungeon Keeper in space'. Not that that's a bad thing... just don't get your hopes up about interactive complexity or emergent gameplay... they're not to be found here. In fact, the only point of the game at present seems to be to keep your base operating---this might be seen as somewhat lacking in comparison with any of the above precedents--SBDF9 dosn't have the world building of DF, the customizability of The Sims, or the naughtiness and design of DK. However, it does look to aspire to all three, eventually.

As of v5, it's still buggy as hell, so I would wait a while before purchasing. Get your fix from Timber and Stone or Prison Architect for the being (or check out RimWorld, which I haven't done yet).

column8:
Despite what the nay-sayers say...

Yes, the game is Alpha. Yes, it's full of bugs, some of them fairly major. 

What it also has is a good bit of fun. It's not an action adventure, it's not a shoot-em-up... it's a Sim. If you play other sims, you'll probably like what this game is turning into. It has a good ways to go, no question, but with the regular updates the author has been doing (every month and a half or so) plus his response in fixing the major bugs themselves, the game is obviously being supported and actively developed.

In short - if you can sit and watch an ant-farm (yes, I can... dunno why, but I can) like any other sim game, you'll be OK with this. Heck, my pre-teen kids sit and watch me play this... even ASK me to play it. Give it some time to get where the author intends it to go, and you'll see some magic, I think.

column8:
Like many Double Fine games, this has a great premise, but terrible execution.  T=DF has a track record of fantastic concepts, but they really need people who can turn great ideas into complete games.

The graphics are well-done and polished.
The first 20 minutes of the game are fun, building the first few rooms and mining and managing people. However, it quickly gets boring with a non-intuitive interface, and not much beyond the very basics to manage the station.  

Because it's early access, I have no problem with some of the room types not working, but I would expect more features that are "coming soon" and they just aren't there.

Unless there's a radical shift to make the game a more fun game, I cannot recommend it.

column9:
A great space exploration simulation game. Recommended!
- Explore and develop your space base
- Expand your base by building bars, refineries, life support, laboratories, or take over enemy assets.
- Hire more crew members
- Mine meteors or spaceship debris to expand your buildings.
- Check each crew member's individual profile, with access to Facebook ;)
Great game, very sandbox-like.

column8:
This game is going to be amazing!  Note, however, that it's currently far from finished and their release schedule seems to be...  extremely sparse.   Right now, it's buggy and has several game-breaking bugs (anyone else find that all their citizens become uncontrollably depressed and technicians stop fixing things when they reach about a population of 50?)

If they get this under control and fix the bugs, it's going to be incredible.  Right now, though, I can only recommend it to the patient.

column9: ok at the beginning the concept and the game seemed great to me but with a lot of hours played more than meh, you build a station but there is no goal! after with the problem of the size everything is messed up no more maintenance with 20 technicians on a population of 35 everything is disintegrating! once finished the few ores finished bringing in money then you wait for someone to attack you to deplore the ships that appear, at the beginning from time to time they appear but after nothing more in a general way the first hour of play is great everything works and then arrive at the 10 rooms built everything but EVERYTHING detracts, no more food harvests, no more maintenance, the oxygen disappears from your station in a second and everyone dies whereas before you had for 110 people for a pop of 35 people and especially no missions, no goal so we get bored very quickly and very repetitive! Oh yes, they are all more than stupid, most of them lock themselves in rooms alone and then die, they can't open the external airlocks (3 next to each other) and then die of suffocation. In short, if this is space exploration, I prefer to stay at home!!

column8:
As a fan of Space Station 13, this game piqued my interest.  Although it is a singleplayer game and lacks a lot of content in comparison to SS13, it is a good start for an Early Access game.  I'm glad it isn't a pixel or block based game like most of the Early Access junk.

This game is also compared to Dwarf Fortress, which I absolutely love.  I wouldn't compare it to DF except for the fact that it is singleplayer compared to SS13.

I would love to see Spacebase DF-9 be as fully featured as Space Station 13.  If I could turn SS13 into a singleplayer game I would enjoy many hours of crazy spacestation activities and mayhem.

Current state of the game is minimal.  It is in a beginning stage of content/development from what I can see.  There's a lot of room for improvement.  I'm sure it will get there if the developers stick with it.  But that's always a risk you run with Early Access.  The developers don't actually have to finish the game.

All that said, it was fun to try it out.

column8:
ATTENZIONE: SCORRERE LA RECENSIONE PER UNA RETTIFICA A SEGUITO INTERRUZIONE SVILUPPO DA PARTE DI DOUBLE FINE

Sebbene sia ancora una versione alpha (allo stato attuale alpha 4d) ho trovato questo piccolo gioiello ipnotizzante.
Sono ancora presenti alcuni bug, alcuni grafici, altri di gameplay, ma il potenziale Ã¨ enorme.
Consigliato ai fan del genere, della Doublefine e a tutti quelli che possono guardare oltre quallche piccolo bug di gioventÃ¹.
Sconsigliato a chi cerca un gameplay privo di bug o con poca pazienza. In tal caso meglio aspettare.
Giudizio comunque molto positivo.

AGGIORNAMENTO:
A seguito della decisione incomprensibile di DoubleFine di interrompere lo sviluppo del gioco, non posso che cambiare il giudizio della recensione. Rimangono validi i punti espressi precedentemente, ma pubblicare un gioco in stato di alpha (attualmente alpha 6e), aggiustando qualche bug e scartando tutte le feature che avrebbero potuto rendere il gioco un ottimo prodotto, a mio avviso Ã¨ un colpo davvero basso nei confronti degli utenti che hanno pagato in anticipo, dando fiducia ad una software house del calibro di Double Fine. Questo puÃ² solo insegnare quanto segue: diffidate dai prodotti Early Access di software house blasonate. Le politiche interne prevalgono sempre sui desideri dell'utente finale. Meglio finanziare le produzioni Indie. Non vi Ã¨ certezza nemmeno in quel caso che il prodotto venga completato, ma almeno lo sviluppatore ci mette la faccia.
Evitate pertanto di acquistarlo, se non ad un prezzo inferiore di â‚¬8. Una grossa delusione.
column9:
WARNING: PLEASE SCROLL DOWN FOR A CORRECTION FOLLOWING DOUBLE FINE'S DEVELOPMENT CEASE.

Although it's still an alpha version (currently a 4D alpha), I found this little gem mesmerizing.
There are still some bugs, some graphical, some gameplay-related, but the potential is enormous.
Recommended for fans of the genre, DoubleFine, and anyone who can look past a few minor early bugs.
Not recommended for those looking for bug-free gameplay or those with limited patience. In that case, it's best to wait.
Overall, a very positive review.

UPDATE:
Following DoubleFine's incomprehensible decision to cease development of the game, I can only change my review. The points made above remain valid, but releasing a game in alpha (currently alpha 6e), fixing a few bugs, and discarding all the features that could have made the game a great product, in my opinion, is a truly low blow to the users who paid in advance, placing their trust in a software house of Double Fine's caliber. This can only teach us the following: be wary of Early Access products from well-known software houses. Internal politics always prevail over the wishes of the end user. It's better to fund indie productions. Even then, there's no guarantee that the product will be completed, but at least the developer is putting their face forward.
Therefore, avoid purchasing it unless it's under â‚¬8. A huge disappointment.

column8: Don't buy this game until at least 5d.  Bought the 4d version of the game on sale yesterday, but it wasn't worth it.  Sadly the game does not work.  You do what the tutorials tell you to do.  Building an airlock, lockers and life support, sealing the rooms, but the oxygen levels stay at 0% and your workers all die after eight minutes.  Too bad.  They have a great concept and graphics.  The current execution earns it a big fat goose egg though.

column8:
I was hopeful this would be a build, conquer, research game. And it is all that; I love this concept: Build and survive, personnel management, with a twist of exploration thrown in.

However, all of the positives this game has to offer is decisively destroyed by its horrible, horrible AI.

The technicians should have an editable queue. That would make life better.
Security should have a route display that is editable.
And if there is no door (only a wall) why am I still supplying it with oxygen? Maybe I want to decompress the room. And that takes waaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaay too long.
And where are my multiple saved games?

Devs, please consider my suggestions.
At this time, I can no longer play due to these issues; the game is almost unplayable for any extended period.

column8: Not much to do yet. After a while you got little to do. Less to explore than Gnomoria or Towns. It would be fun if you could move the base around to a different part of the sector or dock to a moon or a planet. The little guys have a lot of data attached to them, but seems redudant and its hard to make them happy. Hard to monitor food, and what you need to produce more. There is a counter for minerals and oxygen but food is not as clear. Right now all engagements are options. You have to choices, if you want to fight or not, and you can select either. Characters are not memorable and also many wait too long to go back to the airlock and die. I wish I could send them back to the base earlier. They shouldn't die in routine jobs because they went to the airlock too late too often.

column8: Idea carina, soprattutto per gli amanti del genere spaziale. Lo scopo e' costruire una base spaziale sperduta nel nulla, possiamo gestire le attivita' tramite una schermata intuitiva, possiamo costruire diversi tipi di stanze e "arrendarle" con oggetti piu' o meno utili. Purtropo il gioco e' ancora molto indietro, non c'e' varieta' nella costruzione, poco intuitiva la gestione delle stanze, eventi ripetitivi e non c'e' alcuno scopo end-game se non resiste piu' che si puo' prima che la comunita' muoia, senza ossigeno (capita spesso), uccisa da sciacalli, bruciata ecc. Attualmente dopo le prime 2 ore di gioco, ci si annoia. Se non volete buttare via soldi aspettate la relese finale, altrimenti acquistate il gioco se volete aiutare una casa indie con una buona idea\, ma sappiate che non giocherete piu' di qualche ora.
column9: A nice idea, especially for space genre fans. The goal is to build a space base in the middle of nowhere. We can manage activities through an intuitive screen, build different types of rooms and "surrender" them with more or less useful items. Unfortunately, the game is still far behind; there's no variety in construction, room management isn't intuitive, events are repetitive, and there's no end-game purpose unless you can last as long as possible before the community dies, either out of oxygen (which happens often), killed by looters, burned, etc. Currently, after the first two hours of play, it's boring. If you don't want to waste money, wait for the final release; otherwise, buy the game if you want to support an indie studio with a good idea, but be aware that you won't play more than a few hours.

column8:
Great UI, some good ideas, but current feature set is exremely small, leading to a shallow game where you'll have seen everything it has to offer within an hour.   It's also riddled with severe, game-breaking bugs; your station's success usually has more to do with whether or not the game decides to malfunction, and less with the environmental hazards. 

Down the road I could see this evolving into something excellent, but in it's current state it's falling short of playable.  I would only reccomend purchasing at this stage as a means of supporting the project, don't expect a fully playable game at this point.

column8: This is a fantastic brilliantly awesome Space game! It is cheesy, and it is beautifull! Space game! I reccomend this to all Sci-Fi fans!

The current state of this EA game is lacking in content and stability. At the time of this writing it is in Alpha 4. Currently the AI is quite problematic and often results in very stupid behavior that will cause crew members to become stuck in loops or stop functioning altogether. The game also tries to emulate air pressure, this while a very exciting feature can cause problems in larger spaces/ bars. The game I suspect will be one of my favorites once it's development is further along, and I am sure my review will change. However, in its current state I can not suggest picking it up.

column8:
This is quite a fun game but even when all the problems are fixed it will still be a failure.

Current issues: The game A.I. is broken which means everything else is currently broken too. Every type of crewmember forgets how to do their job every now.. builders wont build, botanists ignore plants etc (restarting the game every 15 mins helps).  Game settings (all 6 of them) dont always work. Some features are unfinished (which is understandable). There are a lot of graphical glitches & bugs.

Game issues: There is very little to do. You can research everything and build a fully functional space station in 30 mins.  Then you just sit and wait for the RNG to do its thing and thats it. Even if the A.I. & everything else is fixed it'll still be broken the same way most god/build/sandbox games are. Every game will end the same way, you'll keep building until some RNG event inevitably breaks things ruining your game.

column8:
[b]Spacebase DF-9 Video and Review[/b]

[url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=251392153] Click Here For Video [/url]
This charming little strategy sim is easy to play, but does have its own pitfalls.
The first few times you play you'll most probably end up dead before you get the chance to do much, this is because if you don't follow the set pattern required to survive your poor little space men will suffocate and there is no warning about this, yet! (remember were still in early access here).

To start out ensure you get your room setup, airlock (which requires doors form object menu not the airlock menu?!)
and some oxygen generators and do this asasp as this is the only thing that can save you from dying before you begin.

Once your past that you can actually begin to play, your space men all have their own skills and personalities and require a variety of elements to keep them from going space crazy, but in addition to this issue you will have to deal with invaders, meteor storms and rogue stations that appear, so make sure to get some technicians, security and fire extinguishers.

The gameplay currently is pretty limiting but the constant influx of travellers does make it last as long as your willing to keep playing for, in a constant struggle to feed, water and generate oxygen to keep them all alive.

The graphics are a great deal better than the original alpha released in the amensia fornight 2012 but still is nothing head turning.

As far as value for money currently to play alpha I would say no but then theres a long road infront of the devs between now and final release, so lets hope it improves.

For now I think this is one to watch but don't buy until its much further down the road.

Want more reviews? check out my website [url=http://www.idedonline.com]IDEDOnline.com[/url]

column8: It has potential and and if you're not afraid of an Early Access game go for it but as it is now I'd say wait. The game is in alpha still and it's pretty short since after you build a base with one of everything there's not really anything to do. The AI is not too bright when it comes to pathfinding and has a tendancy to act like lemmings. Combat is meh. It's just too early.

column9:
Spacebase DF-9 reminds us of the old days when we played Bullfrog's Theme Hospital or Startopia.
Here, however, it's all with better graphics. Check out our review.
We provide an insight into the game and explain the first base building and the most important events.

http://gameplane.de/2014/04/spacebase-df-9-preview-theme-hospital-im-weltall/

Update: Unfortunately, a lot has changed for the worse since the early alpha review. The developers released the game too early and declared the unfinished game "finished." The enormous number of bugs simply makes it less fun to play. It's a real shame for the game's many loyal fans, as real potential was wasted here.

column8:
So leid es mir bei dem Potential, das hinter dem Spiel steckt, auch tut, doch aktuell kann man keine Empfehlung aussprechen, dieser Entwicklung im Sinne des Crowdfundings (Early Access) noch mehr Geld voraus zu strecken. Seit Ende 2012 (Prototyp) in der Entwicklung, steckt das Spiel immer noch in einer Alpha-Phase, die man ihr auch ansieht, da immer noch einige elemenatare Funktionen nicht richtig funktionieren. Die Entwicklung lÃ¤uft so schleppend, dass man den Eindruck gewinnt, die Entwickler ruhen sich auf den bereits eingesammelten Einnahmen und ihren Lorbeeren aus der Vergangenheit (hinter Double Fine Productions stecken immerhin so klangvolle Namen wie Tim Schafer etc.) aus. Schaut vielleicht nochmal in einem Jahr rein, vielleicht gibt es dann eine anstÃ¤ndige Beta, die man prÃ¤sentieren kann, denn wie schon erwÃ¤hnt: es KÃ–NNTE ein richtig tolles Spiel werden. Aktuell werden jedoch hÃ¶chstens Leute damit glÃ¼cklich, die gerne Tester spielen. SpÃ¤testens nach einer gewissen Spielzeit/GrÃ¶ÃŸe der Raumbasis wird es unspielbar.

Bis dahin empfehle ich euch das grandiose und sehr Ã¤hnliche Spiel "Space Colony HD" von Firefly Studios und hoffe instÃ¤ndig, dass dieses Machwerk hier irgendwann eines Tages an diese Vorlage herankommt (oder gar Ã¼bertrifft), dann gibt es auch wieder eine Empfehlung. :)
column9:
As much as I'm sorry about the potential behind the game, at this point, I can't recommend putting any more money into this development through crowdfunding (Early Access). In development since the end of 2012 (prototype), the game is still in an alpha phase, which is clearly evident, as some basic functions still don't work properly. Development is so slow that one gets the impression that the developers are resting on their laurels from the revenue they've already collected and their past laurels (after all, Double Fine Productions is backed by such renowned names as Tim Schafer, etc.). Maybe check back in a year; maybe there'll be a decent beta to present, because as I mentioned before: it COULD be a really great game. Currently, however, it's only going to be fun for people who enjoy playing testers. After a certain amount of play time/size of the space base, it becomes unplayable.

Until then, I recommend the terrific and very similar game "Space Colony HD" by Firefly Studios and sincerely hope that this creation will one day come close to (or even surpass) the original. Then I'll give it another recommendation. :)

column9:
Good ideas that will hopefully be expanded with much more complexity.

Update:

I liked what I was able to play in the alpha. I had a lot of fun and was really looking forward to the game's further development. Now Double Fine has released this game unfinished, which is a huge disgrace, and right now Steam needs a money-back guarantee for fraudulent developers.... I actually really like Double Fine and their games... but this is simply unacceptable. 1. It damages Double Fine's reputation, 2. It's very unfair to the customer who trusts the developer.... Sorry, Double Fine, but I will never support another game from you that's still in its infancy. I'll wait for a hopefully proper full release.

column8:
Vorsicht! Ich empfehle zwar dieses Game, aber mit der Voraussicht, das es erweitert wird. Vorallem das alle Bugs beseitigt werden.
Im Moment ist es noch nicht durchgÃ¤ngig Spielbar. Es sind sehr viele Detailfehler vorhanden, Optisch sowie in technischer Hinsicht.
Das schlimmste was mir Heute passiert ist, das ab einem Punkt das Spiel immer abgestÃ¼rzt ist und ich komplett von vorne anfangen musste.
Gruselig finde ich die MenÃ¼-Tasten. Warum nicht einfach eine MenÃ¼leiste machen, wo die Hauptkategorien abgebildet sind. Darunter klappen dann die UntermenÃ¼s fÃ¼r die Objekte auf. Aber vieleicht wird das noch verbessert.
Die Wegfindung ist auch manchmal eher merkwÃ¼rdig. Vorallem wenn die Ausserhalb gebaut wird, da fliegen die einfach durch die WÃ¤nde.
Man kann auch nur auf einen Spielstand zurÃ¼ck greifen. Zwischenspeichern und evtl. wieder laden, wenn was schief geht ist nicht mÃ¶glich.
Ja es muss noch sehr viel gemacht werden.
Aber ansonsten machte es mir wirklich Spass und hoffe auf mehr.

TIP: Wer ein vergleichbares Spiel sucht und mit weniger Fehlern kÃ¤mpfen mÃ¶chte, sollte sich Rimworld mal anschauen!
column9:
Caution! I recommend this game, but with the expectation that it will be expanded. Especially so that all the bugs are fixed.
At the moment, it's not fully playable. There are many minor errors, both visually and technically.
The worst thing that happened to me today was that the game kept crashing at one point, and I had to start all over again.
I find the menu buttons creepy. Why not just create a menu bar with the main categories? The submenus for the objects then open underneath. But maybe that will be improved.
The pathfinding is also rather strange at times. Especially when building outside, they just fly through the walls.
You can only access one save game. Saving and possibly reloading if something goes wrong isn't possible.
Yes, there's still a lot to be done.
But otherwise, I really enjoyed it and hope for more.

TIP: If you're looking for a comparable game with fewer bugs, you should check out Rimworld!

column8:
Do you like resource management type games? Do you like simulation type games? Do you like science fiction? If you answered yes to two of the previous questions you should check out Spacebase DF-9. Even though this is an Early Access Game there is still enough playability and fun in it to occupy hours of your life. 

Basically you build a space station or as the name suggests a Spacebase. You do this by laying out rooms and zoning them for specific tasks. At first you'll need an airlock and a life support system so that your virtual Spacebase residents can breath. As you play, you'll discover that you need to expand, and that takes resources. You'll need to build more rooms and different types of zones to make your Spacebase function. Things like refineries, sleeping quarters and pubs. Yes, they have pubs in space.

To add to the gameplay each of your Spacebase residents has his or her special skill set. You need to assign them tasks based on their individual skills or train them in new ones, if you wish. As they get better at their tasks the station starts to hum along nicely. As you progress, you'll discover that the natives get restless and you'll need to attend to their complaints and unhappiness by building new rooms or maybe mixing up their work routine. 

All that is enough to keep you busy, but there is more. Every now and again a spaceship will pass by. They can be friendly folk and join your Spacebase or they can be your worst day in space. Sometimes you can weasel your way out of sticky situations but eventually something is going to rain on your Spacebase. You'll need to prepare for that eventuality and defend your Spacebase if you want to hold onto it. 

This is an Early Access Game and itâ€™s in Alpha 4b as of this writing. Even so, there is plenty of fun to be had with this game. Double Fine Productions, the developer, is actively releasing updates. They are shooting for updates on a monthly basis and thatâ€™s good. 

Now I donâ€™t want to mislead you. Iâ€™m having a ton of fun with this game, but it is and Early Access Game and itâ€™s still in Alpha. That means itâ€™s not for everyone. The game isnâ€™t finished. Itâ€™s not even close to finished. Itâ€™s Alpha. Donâ€™t buy this game expecting a polished game. Even if you have Beta tested before, keep in mind that this is pre-beta. 

That said, this game promises to be something extremely fun to play. If you want to be in on the ground floor and watch, as well as give feedback, as the game develops then you should definitely pick up a copy of Spacebase DF-9. Itâ€™s okay, the waters warm, jump in. You will have fun.

column9:
The game's premise is quite promising, but for now, it's very, very raw. It's definitely not worth buying right now if you're looking for fun, unless you're more interested in helping the developers than playing the game. This is because there's practically nothing to do other than build rooms and rooms repeatedly, with very few options, do some small exploration, and add new members to your crew.

Beyond the current cost-benefit issue, the game has a mechanic that's quite annoying and can ruin the game if the AI â€‹â€‹isn't well-designed: you don't control the crew! Always keep this in mind when considering purchasing the game; it's not a space-based FTL. The gameplay assumes you assign crew members to specific roles, and as you build or mine something, they'll obey the AI's instructions. If they're tired, hungry, or sad, they'll take longer to complete the tasks.

For now, this is catastrophic for base security. You don't control the security guards or the boarding team of other stations that appear; the only thing you can do is select a location to patrol. This works very, very poorly. It's impossible, for example, to extract the crew from a threat they can't handle, or if a base depressurizes, they'll die. At least for now, it's catastrophic.

Furthermore, there are roles like technician, bartender, botanist, and scientist (and security, practically) where you have no control over their actions. The equipment is there, and they act according to the AI.

In principle, this is interesting; it's a different kind of gameplay, but for now, it's working poorly, very poorly.

column8:
**Updated Review**
I get that putting down cash for a Beta is a chance that we take... but to put down cash and then  Double-Fine literally stopped doing updates after that "Beta release sale" is fraud. Valve should look into it. The fact that at the same time, this dev went around boasting how much money they made off their kickstarter... it's a disgrace.

 If you think that your game is a struggle: wrap it up, and then take it off Steam. Give it back to Humble Bundle as abandonware assets. Open-Source it and let the community finish it for you. Don't commit fraud. We thought you were supposed to be one of the good guys.

**Original review: **
It's pretty cool, unfortunately DoubleFine had to completely ignore it whilst their "amnesia fortnight" game jam was on... except instead of a fortnight it was about 8 weeks since an update. It goes to show, the success of Broken age still wasn't enough for them to hire back many staff. Leave it for a couple more months, don't fall for their "sales" like I did

column8:
This game was promising. And then the devs just dumped 1.0 on the community and bounced. Don't reward that behavior. 

[i]My previous review[/i]

This game is strangely and frustratingly addicting.

It's by no means finished; at time of writing, Alpha 4b is the current release. Some major and glaring pieces of the game are missing. There are no doctors or infirmies to heal people from injuries, and bugs abound. AI pathing is a work in progress. 

The difficulty curve needs to be balanced more, and base immigration is hit or miss. Right now, the game is crying out for some sort of debug mode or option. It'd be nice to force events or otherwise peak under the hood right now to see what's going on. Adding some hints to improve morale would be welcome, too.

Overall, the game is more than promising. It shows a proper spark of fun and creativity, with tons of good ideas and some solid concepts to build off of.

column8:
An addicting space station creation-simulation reminscent of Dwarf Fortress, Spacebase throws you alone into the cold, deep darkness of space with nothing but 8 minutes of oxygen and a recommendation to quickly build a life support zone. The rest is up to you, as you are left to quickly build a functioning space station and hopefully turn your tiny crew of three space colonists into a fully functioning space outpost.

If you're a fan of Gnomoria, Banished, or Towns, then definitely pick this one up. I'm very excited to see what future updates offer, and I hope they come soon!

column8:
Can't recommend this game as it stands...

The idea behind it is great and I was looking forward to playing. However the game gets repetative far too quickly.
There's also some annoying issues, like security not responding to intruders whilst the rest of your crew gets blasted to death. Sure you can reasign everyone to security until the attack is repelled, but after a while gets annoying. Amongst others (Will write more in depth review in the near future)

I'm fully aware the game is in alpha and issues are part of the course, that said even with this in mind I'd suggest waiting a little longer before buying. Unless you're happy to assist the developer with feedback and enjoy seeing how games progress, from Alpha to the full package. 

I'll update my review as time goes on.... Watch this space (pardon the pun)

*** UPDATE **

Played the game recently and there have been some updates, the game is more enjoyable now. But for me there's still something missing. More of a middle of the road game in my opinion. Still not able to give it a thumbs up at the moment,

column9:
Hello,
now after a few hours of playing... it's hard to believe it's so addictive,
but the whole thing still has that slimy aftertaste of the alpha.

Those prone to frustration should definitely stay away from it,
as there are still extreme bugs in many places that can drive frustration levels to unimaginable heights ^^

Examples:
In a moment of inattention, the entire crew suddenly finds themselves
sitting in the bar, waiting for food that never arrives, because the bartenders are all
standing at a table, also waiting for food :)
To complete the chaos, the mechanics don't work (because they're the ones waiting for food), and all the equipment goes to pieces... air filters fail... panic, and ultimately, the final gasp from the crew :(

Firefighting is also quite frustrating... fire extinguishers are hanging around in abundance in the room, but people want to put out the fires... they catch fire as a result, and run wildly into the next fire... well, death is happy ^^

The AI's pathfinding also needs a lot of fine-tuning... it happens at corners near the airlocks of the Often, people glitch through the wall and end up in an infinite vacuum ^^

All in all, the game is absolutely hilarious and a lot of fun as long as the bugs don't bring you back down to earth...

A few patches later, this could definitely become a fun game to play in between.

Have fun and don't forget to hold your breath in space ;)

column8:
UPDATE http://steamcommunity.com/gid/103582791434732506/announcements/detail/216494030200824180
Game is being pushed out the door half finished. DO NOT BUY. Most promised features never  materialized and game is shallow and broken as of 9/19/2014

Slow dev, NO communication now, and after nearly a year and maybe 5 updates a complete waste of your time, money, and sanity.

This game will never ship - it'll just drag on at a third of the pace of any other game (with a pro studio, I might add) while the devs make excuses like some kid who lost their homework.

I'm done screwing around with this - Doublefine may be a good studio but this team is a bunch of slow, excuse making hacks who are in absolutely no rush to make this game (and I suspect the money for it is going to other projects.)

Don't buy this game, even on sale. It's not worth it - there are MANY better Dwarf Fortress style games out there who's devs are actually engaged in their craft/jobs. 

Doublefine screwed the pooch on this one, hard.

column9: Nice game, for early access it already runs well. Some bugs though: floors that stay black after creation, small graphical glitches, the exploration of the "derelicts" is quite messed up (the soldiers stay in the airlock and it's impossible to place the "Bacon" where you want in it, or the soldiers turn around the wreck). I should point out that these minor bugs don't prevent you from playing it ;). There's potential and even in its current version it's enjoyable. I hope the developers will add the ability to save multiple space bases. The list of things to develop (posted on their forum) looks interesting, hopefully they can do it...

column8:
It's tough to give a recommendation to an Early Access game. The current version shows promise, but definitely requires more work to be a finished game. Granted, this is the point of Early Access, so I can't exactly fault it for not being a finished game yet.

The game play is fun for a while, but the unpolished pathfinding and job queueing makes a decent obstacle to large bases. At some point in every game I've played, the oxygen recyclers break down nearly simultaneously and the technicians are either asleep or fixing other, non-broken (but still slightly damaged) systems.

column8:
Still in development, this game is really addictive so far. Looking forward to more content as they work along makes coming back to this game once in a while enjoyable to discover new things. Lot's of bugs still exist and can ruin a run pretty easily such as oxygen not filling rooms right. This causes your people to get stuck due to air pressure differences, or recently one I found with making large bars. I made a bar large enough to hold a good proportion of my population only to find that all my people will wait for ages to get served. Even if the bartenders are asleep, they can wait up to two minutes or longer at max speed, neglecting their duties of building and maintenance. Eventually they all died because the oxygen recyclers all broke down causing them all to panic instead of fixing the issue. The A.I. really needs to be updated to react better to situations like this where they need to get their job done over waiting for dinner and schedule who does what and when they are on duty.

Edit: As of recently, this game which was updating at a steady pace has now entered 1.0. Unfortuantly the company running it decided it was not making anymore money, and was not worth it in the long run. Buyer beware, what you pay for now is what you get, and that is a game with many features mentioned during develpoment left out.

column8: The game seems like it has a TON of potential. The only problem is there is no tutorial for this extremely complicated beginning. TERRIBLE beginning to the game. Almost made me write the company and ask for a refund, but I'm giving it a chance because it seems like, once in the game, it could be very fun.

column8:
I am really excited by the potential of this game and it is for this reason I purchased at this early stage expecting to get a discounted future AA purchase.

This game at this stage all told should not be selling for anymore than Â£4.99. Yes I do enjoy it, yes I see the potential and yes I do understand this is a Alpha release. This game is good but it seems to be nothing more than the best of genres from decade past - not a bad thing but a thing that retails at Â£12.99 as a complete package.

This feels like a game from experienced developers going back to their roots and as such I believe they should have the courage of conviction by offering a discounted Alpha and not a inflated overpriced one. I should not be expected to pay a premium for their mid life crises.

Edit 3 years later - I still keep coming back to this game. It had so much potential and I keep hoping for an official uptake. Yes I've tried the mods and hats off to the community.......but it needs an end story.

Based on the hours I've played, the feel overall; i'm changing my negative to a one of hopeful. I do enjoy the game.

It is still missing a lot of rythm and items, rooms, objectives etc. so far. But it is already fine to play it and it is not  buggy  for an early beta.

column8:
Developers at Double Fine are consistently updating the game because it IS an Early Access/Beta. I am glad I got SpaceBase DF-9 on sale for about ten bucks, but it is definitely not worth twenty. I suggest waiting for it to go on sale if you want to try it out.

In SpaceBase DF-9, there's no micro-managing. The A.I. take on a life of their own once you give them a task so it can get rather frustrating. And most of them are very, very moody, which affect their work ethic severely (ugh). They're fairly stupid at their current stage of development, so you can expect to lose a base very quickly - regardless of whether you're playing the game correctly or not. And if your base doesn't fall apart right away, it will eventually. It takes quite a while to understand how each A.I. functions (due to their personalities) and how to work around them. 

Even with all that said, it's a very fun game. I have fun, anyway. It helps that I enjoy simulator games. It's space sims! Sorta.

column8:
At this point in time, this game is not worth buying the developing seems slow as it is and you cant seem start a new seed so I am stuck in choices of low of all stats. Not only that, but the biggest problem is it is extremely buggy I have constant cadets either standing still in space or dieing of oxygen when its nearly 100% oxygen full. The worst comes from the fact that the starting part of the game is the most annoying. 8 minutes of oxygen fly really fast and with the current bugs it makes it more of a stressful panic to ensure that you just build an oxygen recycler then instantly a refinery. The game doesnt exactly explain all of this so it is up to the player to figure it out all which, if you are experienced with a game like Dwarf fortress you will be able to adapt quite well however, if you are not then this game will just make you want to unistall it and think of how much you wasted on it. 

In short, Do not get this game until they decide to speed up its development and fix its issues or bring out new things that will make the game more enjoyable in its current state it is not exactly enjoyable and in my opinion, I bought this during a hype and they are using the alpha business model excuse which I do not like. Right now waste of money for me

Spacedate 9153: Nach fast 400.000 Jahren Kryoschlaf erwache ich mit meiner Crew. Uns wurde Reichtum und GlÃ¼ck im Vorpulonquadranten versprochen, doch stattdessen befinden wir uns in der endlosen EinÃ¶de des Weltalls. Ein paar Asteroiden schweben in unsrer NÃ¤he... ihre Materie kÃ¶nnte sich spÃ¤ter noch als nÃ¼tzlich erweisen. Die Sauerstoffanzeige meines Anzugs weist mich darauf hin, dass uns nur 7 Stunden bleiben, um uns hier ein Zuhause zu erschaffen... keine Zeit fÃ¼r Pausen also.

Spacedate 9155: Cheeseness und die anderen sind gerade dabei nahegelegene Asteroiden zu varporisieren, um genug Materie fÃ¼r den Weiterbau zu beschaffen. Eine Raffinerie, sowie 3 Sauerstoffrecycler und ein Essensreplikator sind schon konstruiert. Als NÃ¤chstes planen wir ein Schlafzimmer, da der kalte Boden unserer Basis nichts im Vergleich zu einem echten Bett ist.

Spacedate 9158: Das Schlafzimmer steht. Endlich schlafen! Der Bordcomputer zeigt an, dass sich ein unbekanntes Flugobjekt nÃ¤hert, aber das ist mir egal... ich will mich nur kurz ausruhen.

Spacedate 9159: Cheeseness und die anderen sind tot. Ich habe mich im Schlafzimmer versteckt und die TÃ¼ren aus Panik abgebaut. Das Flugobjekt war das Schiff dreier Weltraumpiraten. Oh mein Gott... das wird mein Ende.

Spacedate 9160: Als die Piraten mit ihrem Raubzug fertig waren und sich in die LuftschlÃ¤use begeben hatten, habe ich diese sowie die TÃ¼r zu den Sauerstoffrecyclern geÃ¶ffnet und sie ins All geblasen, noch bevor diese ihre RaumanzÃ¼ge anziehen konnten. Cheeseness, das ist fÃ¼r dich. MÃ¶gest du in Frieden ruhen.

Spacedate 9173: Sato ist tot. Parasiteninfektion. Der Parasit lÃ¤uft gerade Amok. Unser Sicherheitsmann wurde im Schlaf ermordet und die anderen Crewmitglieder haben keinerlei Kampferfahrung. Alles hinÃ¼ber. Ich sitze mal wieder im Schlafzimmer und demontiere die TÃ¼ren. Vielleicht gehe ich danach in die LuftschlÃ¤use und lass mich einfach ins All treiben...
column9:
Spacedate 9153: After almost 400,000 years of cryosleep, I awaken with my crew. We were promised wealth and happiness in the Vorpulon Quadrant, but instead we find ourselves in the endless wilderness of space. A few asteroids are hovering nearby... their matter might prove useful later. My suit's oxygen gauge tells me we only have seven hours to make a home here... no time for breaks, then.

Spacedate 9155: Cheeseness and the others are currently vaporizing nearby asteroids to acquire enough matter for further construction. A refinery, as well as three oxygen recyclers and a food replicator, have already been constructed. Next, we'll plan a bedroom, since the cold floor of our base is nothing compared to a real bed.

Spacedate 9158: The bedroom is finished. Finally, sleep! The onboard computer indicates that an unidentified flying object is approaching, but I don't care... I just want to rest for a bit.

Spacedate 9159: Cheeseness and the others are dead. I hid in the bedroom and dismantled the doors in a panic. The flying object was the ship of three space pirates. Oh my God... this will be the end of me.

Spacedate 9160: When the pirates finished their raid and went into the airlocks, I opened them and the door to the oxygen recyclers and blew them into space before they could put on their spacesuits. Cheeseness, this is for you. May you rest in peace.

Spacedate 9161: I'm lonely. The matter is running out, and I don't have time to get more because I have to take care of the engines. The onboard computer shows another approaching flying object. If they're pirates again, I'll probably join them. Better than starving here.

Spacedate 9164: The craft was a SEED! Just like the one we came here with. The occupants were very friendly and immediately wanted to join my base! They even called their friends to join us. I think this space station is going to be a real home after all.

Spacedate 9166: There are already 21 of us... Amazing. And the best part is: We even have our own bar! I can hardly believe my luck.

Spacedate 9167: An asteroid storm destroyed our bar and sucked seven crew members into space. The whole crew is mourning.

Spacedate 9169: Pirates successfully repelled.

Spacedate 9171: Things are looking up again. We've taken in a Terran named Sato, who seems to be a gifted scientist. He's currently researching pirate-proof doors.

Spacedate 9173: Sato is dead. Parasite infection. The parasite is currently running amok. Our security guard was murdered in his sleep, and the other crew members have no combat experience whatsoever. Everything's ruined. I'm sitting in the bedroom again, dismantling the doors. Maybe afterward I'll go into the airlocks and just let myself drift into space...

column8: Another brilliant game. Build a space station and let it thrive, but careful of the mishaps as they could destroy the hard work you create. Not often I review a game, but this has given me enjoyment and frustration in equal amounts, but I keep on playing more and more. Still buggy with being a Early Access, but damn is it good when things turn out right for your little people.

column8: Dwarf fortress, IN SPACE!!!!!
column9: Dwarf fortress, IN SPACE!!!!!

column8:
Absolutely fantastic fun to play. The only frustrations come not from gameplay, but the little glitches etc. that are to be expected at an alpha stage of development. 

Two concerns right now are that your citizens can be doomed to eternally eating at the pub, never to leave until you quit and reload the game. I have had excess food and yet had many crew members die of starvation. It's frustrating to see someone starving and scream "THE FRIDGE IS RIGHT THERE, JAMES." and then have James say "no, there are people eating in the bar right now, I'll wait my turn". Meanwhile, in the timelocked existence that is the bar, 9 citizens stand at tables, frozen, looking ahead as if they've seen something I haven't. The food is long gone, but they're still eating. Forever eating. 

Basically, the timer freezes and stops going down.

Also, when mining matter, crew members have an unexplicable urge to return from whence they came. When you have to venture away from your base in order to continue mining operations elsewhere, you think to yourself 'I'll just place another airlock and refinery here. That'll be convenient.' Nope. Instead, miners will ignore that airlock, deciding instead to head for the MOST DISTANT AIRLOCK IN THE QUADRENT. I have a silent dialogue in my head with them.
"Bill. I built you this airlock and refinery. I even built a long path down from the original base so you don't waste oxygen getting out here, see?"
"Ahh thank you sir, I appreciate that"
"Bill....you're going out of the far away airlock."
"I know."
"...why?"
"fuck it, it was closer"
"........."
"dum dee dum dee dum"
"Bill?"
"yes sir?"
"why did you go PAST the airlock that's right next to the mining field"
"I'm heading home?"
"I know that Bill. I know. But you could have gone through there and just...WALKED up."
"Nah I'm good."
"BILL."
"WHAT."
"YOUR OXYGEN IS ON 30 SECONDS GO TO THE GODDAM CLOSE AIRLOCK"
"Nah man, YOLO"
*Bill has died from asphyxiation*
"...fuck you, Bill."

I don't know if you're starting to notice some slight frustration I feel towards my dear citizens, but they will be patched soon and hell, I'm still playing aren't I? In all, though, such a good game, and it'll only get better.

column8:
Do you like games that have a hilarious oxygen glitch that causes your crew to run around and then jettison themselves into space one by one? 
What about when your builder builds himself into a room and refuses to build the door to get himself out? Then through some stroke of hilarious luck being the only survivor in a derelict raid because he refused to build said door? Then building said door when he wanted some food?
 

Spacebase even as an early access looks stylish and well designed, it's easy to grasp (after restarting your base about twice then looking up a guide) camera controls can be slightly frustrating as you can't rotate around your base to fill every nook and hallways are a pain. 

But it has a fair amount of difficulty depending on the type of system you choose, crippling asteroids, monster filled derelicts and varying hostility of ships passing by are choices for different play-styles every time everyone is murdered horribly and you have to start a new base.

column8:
A fun time waster at the moment, probably not worth the money however. I was able to spend about an hour trying and failing miserably to start up a basic base, as this is the hardest part of the game so far.m After your functional base is set up it's just kind of a sandbox without any real goals other than to not have all your crew members killed by the occasional parasite.
There is massive potential connected with this game, however that is all it is, potential. I enjoyed my short playthrough, and will definitely return to explore the game further when more features are added.

AI is rather stupid sometimes, having a pub with three bartenders but nobody is working there for example. But it's al part of the alpha. Lovely game with some nice potential! Wondering how this game is going to be when it's done.

As for the other reviews, don't mind them to much. Just remember your buying an alpha version of this game! It's not complete so don't expect a game that is working flawlesly ;)

column8:
Spacebase DF-9 is turning out to be an epic sandbox game.  A friend of mine once quipped, "It's like the SIMs, right?"  It's so much more.  From the humor to the researching of new technologies (thanks latest patch) to forced management of a ever increasing population, this game keeps you hooked from your first experience until your carpal-tunnel kicks in.  

I highly recommend it.  [i](It's still in alpha?  Beta?  Pre-release in any case, but it really is playable!)[/i]

column8:
Meteors destroying your base every 3 minutes Simulator.

Update: A.I. is more stupid than previous updates.
I know it's an alpha, but seriously, on Alpha 4 A.I should be better and not worst than A.2/3.

Today I did 10 bases, and I couldn't play with these more than 30 minutes (the shortest is 8 minutes because oxygen spread bug...)
Reasons: -Frequent attacks of meteorites on "Extremely low Stellar Density"
- NPC blocked in construction wall, so infinite construction and stuck.
- Oxygen doesn't go on other rooms and NPC A.I. too stupid to build 1 Oxygen recyclers, they prefer to eat or workout.
- Builders construct 1-2 things, then eat, chat, build again 1-2 things etc.
- Bartenders wait other bartenders serve them, if there is no more bartender, they wait and don't move until they have food.
And what happens if Bartenders wait for food? ALL NPCs have to wait for food, but no one can serve them, so you have to get more bartenders... Because Bartenders can't cook their own food.
- Lost 2 Builders and 4 technicians because they are stupid, so they are stuck in the doors in space, while Builders destroy derelicts.

I loved this game before the Alpha 4, but now, there are too much bugs to enjoy it.

To avoid until official release. (or Beta?)

[b]Update & TL;DR: do not buy[/b]

Really enjoying this game hopefully more and more features will be added to make it a contender with the current ones out there ... it has the potential to be a great space sim. L<ooking forward to more additions and tweaks.

column8:
As of 2-13-2014 it plays, but after getting established it loses any sense of direction or challenge.
-It is very difficult in the beginning due to limeted intelligence of your crew and the need to spend all of your resources on very specific things.  After getting started it is fairly easy to just grow and grow with the only challenges being to decide who you let on your base to grow your crew and the occasional meteor shower setting fires.  If you can accept these limitations it is still fun to build.  I look forward to seeing how this one ends up.
