column9: When I actually tried to build a space city, there were restrictions on buildings, so it was boring, stressful, and not recommended.

column8:
In it's current Alpha state, the foundation of the game are there and they work very well. It shows how you can assing characters to specific jobs and accumulate ressources, manage characters mood, set up different rooms that serve different functions and so on.  There is only so much you can do for now and once you've set up a good base, you can pretty much wait it out forever so there's no real interest.

But the alpha game does an excellent job at demonstrating how rock solid the core elements are. Everything is intuitive, characters do what they're told, unexpected roguelike events come to break the monotony and the game already has a certain charm to it. Given how the basic elements are so well done and so stable, it's easy to see the potential of the game, they can add layers upon layers of features in futur updates and their roadmap is in fact already impressive. 

I can see that game becomming very complex in the future and each base you build could be very different from one another. Here's an interesting idea, at some point, why not give each base you build some kind of purpose or mission to accomplish and give members of the crew some kind of personnality system od background stories and random events. That way players could make their own little stories with character having romance or hatred or jealousy or mutiny or aliance and friendship and brotherhood and so on.

A game with a lot of potential, but unfortunately way too overpriced in early alpha access! The game currently contains 2-3 hours of gameplay, nothing more. I'm looking forward to updates. The final version will definitely be great! But as I said, it's simply not worth the approximately â‚¬20 at the moment. There are definitely other DF games that are more worthwhile for the price!
Game bugs not yet mentioned:
- Beacon doesn't work quite right
- Space Airlock Doors are sometimes very odd (the display just goes up and down without the door being used)
- AI is still a bit silly :)

column8:
Even at this early stage, Spacebase DF-9 can offer hours of fun. It offers interesting design options, and while it's not exactly a simulation of a 'DS-9' type base, it is certainly an interesting simulation with a great deal of potential.

This is still early Alpha, however, so there is no harm in waiting for the game to get fleshed out before making a purchase. On the other hand, you can invest and support this very exciting developer.

column8:
I would really recommend this game.

You get to build your answer to Deep Space 9, what more is there to say?

The game is very simplistic and very fun. There are the odd thing that can get on your nerves (why did that derelict appear to destroy my only large asteroid?), but the vast majorirty of the game is well done.

Although the features are a bit basic at the moment (i.e. no need for a power generators), this game is well supportted and a major new feature is added every month.

column8:
Though a number of reviewers quite zealously insist that this game is more like Dwarf Fortress than Prison Architect, I have never played Dwarf Fortress and would say that it is quite similar to Prison Architect from what I know.  The game is in early Alpha right now, so there is a limited depth of play, but it shows enormous potential.  For those that enjoy it there are a number of advantages to owning a game in Alpha, a large part of which is getting to see it grow and develop, along with being able to give feedback before everything is finalized.
  
In essence the game is a space station sim.  You make a station, try to keep your people alive an happy, screen potential immigrants, explore derelicts, and get attacked by raiders.  Of course thatâ€™s a gross oversimplification, and trust me itâ€™s much funnier and ridiculous as you play.  If youâ€™re interested at all, youâ€™ll probably like it.  At this stage itâ€™ll likely leave you hungering for more once you stop accidentally suffocating your crew members or getting them killed by raiders.  But if you can be patient itâ€™s very much worth your time.

column8: I can't recomend the game right now as it has many game breaking bugs which can make the game unplayable. Just a note pay for the game if you want to support a promise but don't expect a working game, this is truely an Alpha build.

column8:
Current recommendation for this game: Wait at *least* a year before purchase.
As it stands this game requires MAJOR changes to even make it playable, let alone entertaining. I have been waiting since relase for this to happen, but so far it simply hasn't been done. Patches seem to be few and far between, and the current gameplay is broken so badly that even when starting a new base I have had a 90% failure rate inside of ten minutes, due mainly to minions lack of oxygen... even when my whole base consists of an oxygen recycler, and an airlock...

column8:
This game has a lot of promise as a building / management / simulator for space stations but right now it's more of a tech demo. I will definitely take another look once it gets further along in its development cycle but as of right now it doesn't have much that you can really do in it yet.

It has various props that could do something in the future (like a reactor) but currently the only real bit of management you have to do is mining and a little building (plus the occassional raider). You can't fortify your defenses really nor can you customize the space station as much as I would expect from a building management game. 

I'd pass on this game until it gets more content and substance.

column8:
Spacebase DF-9, or as I like to call it â€œThe one game where I want to throw everyone out the airlock and watch them all dieâ€ is in my opinion one of the reasons early access games should not be on steam. While the page fully warns people that this is still in its alpha stages it should not have been allowed to until at least a better running beta. As of right now the game is computer destroyingly broken as there are multiple problems with the game.
The Intro: As of right now there is not even a full bare bones intro to this game. While when first picking the area you will settle in you see multiple aspects in the upper right corner which mean nothing to you. However it does give the player some heads up after picking it what everything means. That is the only good thing I can say about the intro as is. The next second you are placed in space with three aliens and a pod which can be broken down for scrap and a few minutes of oxygen for each to try and figure out how to build a base. While I understand people hate the idea of tutorials that really drag on I would have preferred at least something to give me more information. My first time playing my entire crew died because instead of building as I instructed they mostly floated around space and then began to panic when their oxygen got low because no one worked.
The AI: Okâ€¦ Day One: Garryâ€™s Incident I feel is one of the best examples of bad AIâ€¦ this nearly reaches the same level of incompetence. In order for a crew member to do anything you must assign a job and where they will be in regards to some of the jobs like mining and building. While thatâ€™s fine by itself the AI doesnâ€™t know what to do often times. They will lounge about the base or flat out ignore build orders or security beacons for when intruders come in guns blazing or fires becauseâ€¦ I have absolutely no idea. The AI is unresponsive and more lazy than helpful and I feel like this would have been aided greatly by being able to tell them what to do The Sims style but the AI of course has free willâ€¦ the free will to walk around doing nothing while I have set up a build order for oxygen recyclers which they need to live while their oxygen quickly is used up.
Building: There is barely any direction as to what to build when starting but common sense plays a part here. Of course they need oxygen, food, and a way for more resources and while all those work when the AI actually does their jobâ€¦ the rest is very lacking. There is no explanation as to why a pub, or a reactor, or really anything is important beyond just common sense guiding my actions to make me build them because, they are there so they must be useful. After all if they can make their own food they stop eating the same stuff from the food replicators. But again things donâ€™t seem to need reactors for power or crew quarters, or fitness rooms, or a pub since things work without them. Again direction would be nice here and even diversity since for example there is only one air recycler, no better one.
There is more I could go on about and while I love Double Fineâ€¦ I cannot in good conscience recommend this game to anyone until at EARLIEST its full release. But even then I would wait a few months if this is any indication of what the full game will be like.

column8:
UPDATE:
Scratch that, they've jumped ship. So much wasted potential and failed expectations make this
completely inadvisable for play. Too expensive for what equates to about 30-40 minutes of play.

Just bad.

------------------------------------ end of update ------------------------------------

Has a lot of potential and there is fun to be had in its current state (alpha 3b).

However, there is only about 30 minutes worth of game before you start repeating
yourself and several features are missing. 

Also, due to a high number of bugs (which Double Fine are great at finding and eliminating
by the way) the game can be frustrating as you'll often find yourself waiting 10-15 minutes
for the A.I to complete what should be simple tasks.

Definitely worth looking into later on as it goes through further development. Right now, it's
too expensive for what it is.

column8: Okay, so after quickly starting the game for a quick play whilst waiting for stuff, I was expecting an infuriating play again as usual. Surprisingly though, it was fun this time, getting stuff done relatively easily, until about 30 minutes in, where, because the technicians are absolutely, positively retarded, all my oxygen recyclers died and a colony of about 37 died within seconds. I'm currently fuming because I've been working on this specific colony for close to a month. The game's fun, no doubt, but it's at times like this where I'd throw my computer out of a window. Needs more polish and an ability to send people to specific places ASAP.

column8:
Currently in early access, it's not hard to see the potential of this game. Running your own spacebase can be challenging and frustrating depending on your luck and knowledge initially, but it's quite satisfying to see your crew improve as they grow your station from a simple airlock to a sprawling hub for interstellar travel. 

Currently lacks a lot of features, so expect not to get much out of it until more is added, but the initial few hours are very entertaining if not buggy.

column8:
Spacebase DF-9 is a "Space Station Simulator" from the people at Double Fine. The game starts out on a map screen letting you pick the best spot for your Seed Pod and every pixel has a different variable ranging from, Stellar Density, Warpgate Proximity, Threat Factor and Magnetic Interferance and all change how you game will play out. Once you have your Seed placed you will go into the space base part where you will have 3 crew and 2000 matter (Currency) to start out with, but be warned as your crew only have a limited ammount of time until there oxygen runs out so you have to be quick building a simple foundation and a good amount of oxygen genorators. Now getting more crew is as simple as waiting for a ship to come by but be warned as it could be pirates who will latch onto your ship and try to kill your crew one by one unless you have a good defence, but it could be just people wanting to be crew of your station. Mining is also a main thing that you have to be checking as if you don't mine you will slowly runout of matter and have no more.

Your crew has needs such as; sleep, food and morale if any of these get low it can cause them to do their job slower, sleep longer of worse die so you do have to farm and have food replicaotrs to counter act this. Apart from the pirates being a thret  meteors can also hit the station and kill your crew so you have to be on the ball if you have a large station and have emergancy alert systems in place to get your crew out of danger.

Now This game does look good but on slower machines can be slow so always check for the latest drivers and be sure that you can run this before buying, as for anything.

I am going to give this game a 6.5/10 as in this is still in alpha and is nowhere finished yet, but has a good amount of features.
column9:
Spacebase DF-9 is a "Space Station Simulator" from the people at Double Fine. The game starts out on a map screen letting you pick the best spot for your Seed Pod and every pixel has a different variable ranging from, Stellar Density, Warpgate Proximity, Threat Factor and Magnetic Interferance and all change how you game will play out. Once you have your Seed placed you will go into the space base part where you will have 3 crew and 2000 matter (Currency) to start out with, but be warned as your crew only have a limited ammount of time until there oxygen runs out so you have to be quick building a simple foundation and a good amount of oxygen genorators. Now getting more crew is as simple as waiting for a ship to come by but be warned as it could be pirates who will latch onto your ship and try to kill your crew one by one unless you have a good defence, but it could be just people wanting to be crew of your station. Mining is also a main thing that you have to be checking as if you don't mine you will slowly runout of matter and have no more.

Your crew has needs such as; sleep, food and morale if any of these get low it can cause them to do their job slower, sleep longer of worse die so you do have to farm and have food replicaotrs to counter act this. Apart from the pirates being a thret  meteors can also hit the station and kill your crew so you have to be on the ball if you have a large station and have emergancy alert systems in place to get your crew out of danger.

Now This game does look good but on slower machines can be slow so always check for the latest drivers and be sure that you can run this before buying, as for anything.

I am going to give this game a 6.5/10 as in this is still in alpha and is nowhere finished yet, but has a good amount of features.

column9: Personally, I feel it's missing a trading system, as well as a way to better train and upgrade troops. Furthermore, there are too few professions. For example, there's no doctor to ensure health at the stadium. The game itself is already quite good; with a bit more content, it would be even better than it is now.

column8:
My first experience with this game involved scrambling to build an airlock and life support structure so my poor crew could breathe that sweet sweet air before asphyxiation ended their greatest adventure.  Sadly I was too late and my workers did not understand the importance of building that suit locker which would allow the air lock to operate properly.  So I watched as my worker scrambled to build the suit locker that would save his life only to be a few seconds too late.  He and the rest of my crew succumbed to the cruelest of fates; I can only hope it was painless.  Armed with new experience and a greater understanding of the fragility of life in space I took another bold step forward and my second base was born.  Things went much better for much longer.  The basics were established with ease and in a very timely fashion.  Mining operations were going smoothly and I was about to establish a pub for recreation and relaxation.  My builder was ordered to remove some interior walls in order to expand a room and it was hoped that he would finish the exterior walls first (you know the ones keeping the cold empty death void that is space outside of my lovely base.)  Alas this was not to be and as the second crew member was pulled into the blackness of both death and the cosmos I knew I had learned another valuable lesson in the fragility of life in space.  

With just these few experiences I must say that Spacebase DF-9 has a lot to offer even as an early release.  It is a little rough around the edges and your workers will tend to aggravate you with poor decision making, but stick with it and you will be proud of your accomplishments in time.  Failure and loss is a part of this game so donâ€™t be too frustrated when you need to start over from scratch.  If you enjoy building and management games you should at least give this a shot.

column8:
A great game that suffers from AI issues, the mechanics are great and remind me of Dwarf Fortress, without the ASCII issues.
The AI issues are minor if you don't mind builders taking forever to finish their ques while the bartenders play games and sleep before they serve people food, and the miners sufforcating because someone else as using the airlock. A patch to make people return to the nearest airlock and get pressurised before the suit oxygen lvl get to 1% would be nice, not as many people would asphyxiate that way. Overall it's a good game with endless construction possibilities and a lot of functional props.

column8:
Noble effort, very polished for an Alpha, but simply not enough content or player feedback at this time.

It's like feeding space fish right now.  You give them food, you clean the filter, and they do stupid sh** like poop on everything and then eat each other.    Your pH instruments say everything is perfect and yet they die, doomed to float for all eternity at the top of their little aquarium in the universe.

As of Alpha, several rooms don't do anything, customization of your base is extremely limited, the UX is uninformative, and your "Sims" do random, stupid stuff instead of fixing the life-threatening oxygen pump (despite being assigned to do exactly that).

Good luck devs!   Get some more people on the team (I think I saw a blog post that there were 3?!?), and this may be worth the buy in.

column9:
It appears development has ceased.

First of all, there's very little you can do at the moment.
Build and maintain a space base.
And that's it.
And it quickly collapses.

You can't safely increase your population, and those you lose can only be replaced by tramp ships.
Once you reach about 30 people, you'll have more leeway, but until then, each person is extremely important.

There's no way to defend against meteorite (or debris or asteroid belt) impacts.
If a hole opens, anyone approaching will easily be sucked in and lost.

As for enemies, if they enter, everyone except the guards is completely defenseless and has no chance of escape, so they'll just be killed.
You basically have no advantage, and if you don't defeat them, everyone will be killed.

Because it's still in Alpha mode, it's safe to say the gameplay isn't quite there yet.
It's unclear how many additional features will be added in the future,
but I think preferences will be divided on whether you want to prioritize base operation and maintenance or strategy for dealing with enemies.

column8:
This is game is about building a Spacebase (duh). Through mining and finding debris from other stations, you can make your own station bigger and bigger. Also you need to be preoccupied with Security, Air, Food and so goes on.
PROS:
For an Alpha, I was really impressed, the game worked really well and I had my share of fun. There is some odd things like the power generator being useless or two raiders wiping out all my base, but nevertheless, I was REALLY impressed with this Alpha. The soundtrack reminded me FTL (which is really good) and the graphs do their jobs.
CONS:
The gameplay for know it's really shallow, you can only grow your station and nothing more, but this is an Alpha! Probably it's going to get deeper.

Final Word:
Good investment, and I am hoping to play the final version of this game as soon as possible.

column8:
An enjoyable diversion, Spacebase DF-9 is currently a bit limited in scope. Of course, the game is still in development and is only available as an early access, but it only takes a few hours at most to fully explore every aspect that is currently developed. As a sandbox game, the limited number of objects and tasks detracts from the overall enjoyment and replayability.

That said, it is still in development and I would recommend it if nothing else to see how it develops and expands over time.

column8:
Let me start off by stating this game is very early in the development stages. It is short on features so you will probably build many stations instead of creating a long running one.

But these shortcomings are overcome by how tight the game feels. The menus are slick and easy to use, the graphics are great for the type of game you are playing, and the flavor text that accompanies contacts with your station inhabitants, and others wishing to join your rag tag group of explorers, are top notch. I am very excited to see where this game goes in the future and plan on putting countless hours into it.

column8:
This game feels like Startopia and Tiny Tower went and had an adorable funny baby.  It is important to point out that Startopia is my most favorite game ever made, and I'd still be playing it today, despite having owned it for ten years, if I could find where I put the disc.

I would still be immersed in this Spacebase DF-9 if I hadn't hit the bottom of the alpha content after a few hours of playing it.  I am so looking forward to future releases. Everybody buy this game, it is going to be magical.

column8: Dang it.  Like I have time for one more addictive game, but this is pretty fun.  Each play through is obviously different. column8:
This is an excellent start to what the developers hope to eventually achieve with the game. At the moment you can build your base (including multiple rooms), take on new residents (meaning you'll soon need to expand your base to cope with the extra people), fight off hostile enemies, claim "derelict" bases nearby as an expansion of your main base, and assign each resident to a job, which they progressively get better at.

Eventually, you'll have a well-run base that is looked after by a team of highly trained staff, but to get to that point, you might have to survive a couple of scares near the beginning of the game (a meteor strike which leaves your base on fire when your technicians aren't well-trained to deal with it, or raiders when your security forces aren't trained up, etc).

In the future, the devs want to add depth to the game with a research system, job zoning, and so on. Once those are implemented, the game will really be something. I think there's enough for more than a few hours of enjoyment here already. Definitely recommended.

column8: I was hesitant at first with all the alpha games on steam. The game is great, a blast to play and pleasnt to learn. The soundtrack is enchating as space scenes are. You start with 3 characters you can only lightly influence. Each one can be assigned a task within the spacebase, they are: botanist, bartender, builder, technician, security, miner. (Botanist grow food for the bartender to serve in a pub, the others shouldn't need explanation). Each person can perform each task at a level granted by skill. So it allows an opportunity to manage your labor resources as well as material resources. After while you will slowly build a  base of up to 100 or so people if you can survive impacting debris and pirate raiders. Opportunities to plunder derelict ships will give you bonus space or resources. While definitely a playable alpha build, you can probably do just about everything in eight hours, more content would make replay value more substantial. Overall impressive game, can't wait for the finished build. *Edit I have to change my opinion to negative because the game was not finished. It never really progressed out of the alpha stage of development. I'm not mad about it, they almost had something cool. Its my recommendation you do not trade anything of value to purchase this game.

column8:
I'm leaving my past review up for whoever wants to read it, but I can no longer recommend this game, the developers abandoned it during alpha, rather than refunding money or at least "slowly" fixing the bugs, they announced full releases of a game with so many bugs it's borderline unplayable.

Game has a lot of potential! However it is still lacking. The base building is a little hard to get used to but works well, there are no clear markings for what does what when you try to build an item. No way to move items you place. Lots of bugs including: engineers don't like to repair things. all your oxygen recyclers can be at 0% and they wont bother with it (same with doors) until it explodes half the time. For so reason security officers wont move to the beacons you place, but when they do they usually go outside under the base at the spot the beacon was placed instead of inside so it's VERY hard to defend your base. Works wont work half the time. Lastly in regards to bugs my middle room for no reason what so ever went down to 40% O2 and all my guys got stuck in the room next to the air lock (which had 70% O2). So I quite and came back hoping that would fix the bug, and every single room suddenly went to 0% O2 and half the people were already dead. the other 98% suffocated. saved and went back now my rooms are back to 98% O2 and 2 people survived. then one became a parasite and everyone died can't retake.

Now that's a lot of bugs and problems yes. BUT I had a lot of fun playing the game none the less. I hope these bugs get fixed and I hope the game does great. Also This game needs more rooms (i.e. Security room, Med Bay (no idea how you heal units yet) and the like)

column8:
There's something very engaging about this little base building sim.  The character of your citizens, the flavor of the room types and furnishings, the banter with incoming vessels.

Bugginess aside, the game is still very incomplete.  It serves to give you a taste of what the finished game will be, but it wont satisfy.  For Alpha 3 though, it's in a pretty good place.

But even ignoring it's alpha state, there are some issues with the design I find a bit lacking.  Issues I'm not sure will be resolved by the official launch.  For instance, there is no vertical building.  Your citizens can space walk in 3D, but you can only build in 2D.  There is also only one material to mine and build with.  Some of the other issues I could list off are relatively minor, or things that they're likely to address for RC.  But these two core design points are things that fundumentally narrow the experience, and it's not clear if they'll be resolved.

Ultimatley I say wait, unless you want this sitting in your library and eyeing you until it's finished (and I'll probably update my review at that point just to be fair),

column8:
I bought this game because I support the idea.  Long time sci-fi fan, I'd love to build my own Babylon 5 or Deep Space 9.

Much like the premise of this game being in the FAR future, I think the game will reach a playable state in the FAR future as well.

Spacebase DF-9, right now, is a buggy mess of a prototype.  It's what I expect a team of developers might show their boss or a publisher and be like "See, with a year or two and a truck full of money, we can turn this into something amazing!"

On the other hand, the bugs can be hilarious, and I'm trying to make the best of it.

If you want an actual GAME to PLAY - do not buy.

column8: Despite being quite a ways from finished, Double Fine's Spacebase DF9 is still an incredibly compelling experience. Build your ideal base, fit out the rooms with equipment and furniture and watch as your new space citizens go about their lives. You'll have to keep the needs and wants of your people in mind, as well as ensuring that your base is correctly staffed and maintained. A great game that promises to be an excellent one upon completion.

column8:
This game has potential, but in its current state, there is about 3 hours worth of somewhat buggy gameplay.   Simple things like citizens of your base being unable to figure out how to navigate through/around other citizens, or to the place where they need to do their assigned jobs.

It's easy to imagine this could turn into something great (with more tech and numerous path finding bugs worked out).   Let's hope it does.

At the moment, it is not a recommend for what I paid (around $15 USD).  Hope to change this in the future as the game improves and sometimes very frustrating kinks get worked out.

column8:
I'll make a list of pros of this games and cons simple enough right?
PROS
1.Quite challenging at times to build up your base but good for those who seek it
2.Great job system
3.Overall very fun
4.Alot of potential with the game mechanics
5.good to invest in early so you cn watch it rise up from were it is now
CONS
1.You have to individually select floors to delte them
2.kinda short because you run out of things to do
3.Does not have as much control over your crew as i hoped for
4.They usually don't do there jobs especially builders
5.It's a alpha so i guess that kinda rules out the most of the cons

column8: This game has potential, at the moment there is great deal to do and can get boring quickly, however it is still in development and the devs seem to be active. If you are the kind of person who likes to play games in their infancy and support the devs at an early stage, then I can recommend this game. If however you are looking for game to kill a few hours, this is not for you yet.

column9:
Unfortunately, there isn't much going on in SPACEBASE yet, but the direction is right! Something is being developed here that could become a truly great game. Until then, however, I advise anyone expecting a complete game not to purchase the game in Early Access at this point! It's still very unfinished!

Those of you who want to support the development of SPACEBASE and also enjoy sandbox games without a specific goal or missions will find what you're looking for here!

column8:
Great game, yes it is an alpha so there are still a few bugs around, my main bug is when I ask my builders to build new objects, at times it takes them quite a while before they get round to do it, even if they have not got anything else in the build que.
The updates are regular and informative, and with the new fitness room/objects your people have another place to build their happiness up.
Overall a great game, with a few bugs to iron out nothing game breaking.

column8:
An excellent time sink already that has a lot of potential.  Invest now and help them make this great!  

Definitely for fans of Theme Hospital and its sim ilk (which I devoted many hours to).  If you haven't heard of Theme Hospital (or Roller Coaster Tycoon, or several other games with Theme, Sim, and/or Tycoon in the name), then maybe you'd be familiar with FTL, which this also shares some DNA with.

You can tell this is an alpha build, as it is a little clunky and buggy -- but you can immediately sense the charm.  I have high hopes.

column8: Cooley Station was unfortunately designed to have a disastrously small selection of toilet facilities. The stationâ€™s industrial architect, Adolf Riker (a given name only recently returning to a brief but immense popularity after an extremely long hiatus) had studied under the Europan architectural school famous for its brief merger with the Plutonic school of Folk-Industrial psychology. At the time, a study of the Plutonic school had shown that workplace efficiency increased seven-fold where employees were unable to utilise the bathroom facilities and had to spend long periods yearning to pass fluids. Unfortunately it was only later discovered that the study had taken its entire sample from a pool of specially bred accountants genetically engineered to only excrete small unscented pellets every five to six years. The disposition of toilets on Cooley Station was one of the more famous and catastrophic results of the merger of the two schools, the other major notable example being the Plutonic embassy in Basra, which was constructed entirely out of fresh spring water and shaped into an immense cock.

column8:
Update:

This is definitely a promising alpha, and many of the issues I'd mentioned in the previous version of my review have been fixed or improved.

- The technician AI is very much improved.
- I haven't run into issues with bartenders holding up people at the bar, except when I didn't have enough bartenders assigned, which seems reasonable
- Intruder defense seems more manageable now, though the actual mechanics don't seem to have changed.
- Haven't seen any more accidental depressurizations in a while

The only part that is still somewhat frustrating is the builder sequencing. While building walls and floors still seems to be prioritized above everything else, tear down or vaporizing unused areas is still prioritized above building other objects. I'd love to see a queue that I can prioritize, but failing that, at least making tear down/vaporizing last in the priority list would be an improvement. Even better than that would be only deprioritizing those tasks if they're part of unclaimed structures.

Some other issues I've noticed:
- Occasionally people will get stuck in airlocks and eventually suffocate
- There are sometimes odd placement issues with room objects randomly getting removed from the building queue, or sometimes not being able to place an object in a place that you should. I've had this happen with research consoles, beds, and rugs

--------------------------------------
Original Review
--------------------------------------

This looks promising, but in its current state, is not very fun to play. Most of the issues center around not-very-effective AI:

- In order to keep your base functioning, you need technicians to keep all the systems in repair. However, the technician AI is TERRIBLE, and there's no way to force a technician to repair a specific machine. The only way I've been able to play is to keep my base relatively small. Once a hostile docks with my station and as a result, adds more machines, it's an unrecoverable downhill slide to all machines eventually breaking down, no matter how many technicians I add. I've also seen my technicians attempting to repair broken machinery in areas I'm deconstructing, which is a huge waste of time.

- Your citizens need to eat. They also need to sleep. If they go to the bar to eat or drink, and the bartender isn't on duty, they'll wait until he is. Even if the bartender is, himself, waiting to eat or drink. The bartenders will not serve themselves, nor is there any sort of timer that allows them to give up and move on to do something else. There's also no way to force a bartender to go on duty. When your citizens get stuck waiting on food, it makes it very easy to start a downward spiral (especially for technicians) since they obviously aren't doing their jobs if they're waiting for food.

- Defending against intruders is incredibly unreliable. From what I can tell, you're supposed to assign citizens to security duty, and use a beacon to make them congregate in a specific area, either to explore or defend against intruders. In practice, they seem to take an "I'll get to it when I'll get to it" attitude, even when their comrades are getting gunned down around them.

- Sequencing building instructions is irritating - things seem to happen only in the order you enter them in - once you put in a request, there's no way to prioritize it against other requests, except to erase it and do it again, effectively putting it at the end of the queue. The exception seems to be building walls - those seem to get built before anything else.

- Citizens coming in and out of airlocks will occasionally kill their comrades by an ill-timed depressurization

Given this is an alpha, I'm guessing/hoping these issues will be smoothed out, but as it stands, it is more frustrating to play than enjoyable.

column8:
Dec 8th 2013 - Excited to see this game continue to evolve. 

Feb 19-2015 - Well final review and I am disappointed. This game could have been so much better. I got it cheap on sale during early access. Please do not waste your money here.  Game can be compared to Towns.  Honestly it is a little bit better but not much.  Sooooo many bugs.

June 15th 2019 - Double Fine I am dubbing you doubly fucked.  I will never buy another one of your products ever again.  6 years and you still haven't even patched this game.  You guys are a fucking joke.

column9:
In its current form, the game lasts a couple of hours at most. The only good thing about the game is its initial atmosphere. If it holds up and the gameplay improves in a more enjoyable way by the actual release, I might have to revise my rating. I like sandboxes; this game is currently being advertised as such. But right now, the current "sandbox" doesn't feel like it serves any purpose other than being decorative.

You're given a small starting resource and tasked with building a base. The main resource is construction units, which can be obtained by dismantling existing structures or assembled from deposits located throughout the location. You can build several types of rooms in your base, in which you can place objects compatible with the room type. You can assign roles to maintain these objects in your team roster.

Random events occur at regular intervals, but so far only one type is "someone wants to join you or someone wants to attack you." While initially these will simply be new astronauts, later on, aliens will likely cripple your base by placing theirs next to or docking with yours.

I'm not discussing balance; it would be strange to expect it in alpha. What's the problem with the gameplay? The whole game is essentially reacting to random events. Your base development curve takes a couple of heartbeats and then dies forever after 20 minutes of play. Judging by the updates, they promise to extend it to several hours. Later, there will be reactions to random events. In a flat, two-dimensional space, infinity is limited by the small width of the playing field. And the spirit of countless adventure scenarios is limited to notifications about new scenarios (currently, there's only one).

This isn't Terraria with its multitude of resources, enemies, and crafting. It's not Minecraft with its free-form mode. This is a Sim where you can only furnish a room with a cactus and a TV on the wall, and you can't change the characters' clothes.

column8:
Still very rough around the edges as of writing this review, Spacebase DF-9 shows us a lot of promise. For those of you who ever thought about building your own Deep Space 9, this is the game for you. You start with virtually nothing and carve your existence out of space rock and the broken backs of your colonists. Fend off boarding parties of pirates and rampaging killbots, help fellow travelers in need and maybe they will even join your crew!

As I stated it's still a work in progress but it's something you might want to look into.

EDIT: Sadly I can no longer recommend SpaceBaseDF9 due to Double Fine cutting and running on the project. It's quite sad considering just how much potential it had but in it's current state it's unfinished and not worth your time.

column8: Great, Fun, and immersive. Although since it is still in early access as im writing this, it does have major problems.The AI screws up immensley at sometimes, and my crew dies because of their stupid mistakes. Also one major flaw that annoys me too much, is that SHIPS DOCK TOO OFTEN. i would rather have it as a really rare opportunity, or not happen at all because in games like this, the whole point is to expand your ship yourself, not have it be expanded upon by random occurances.

column8:
So I picked up this game after it was featured by Sips of the Yogscast.
It's pretty fun and it kept my attention for about an hour or 2 until I managed to create a stable base on my second or third attempt.
But remember, this is an Alpha.
I'm sure as the complexity and opportunity for mayhem ramps up this game will suck away days of time. Certainly one to watch, though maybe wait for the price/content ratio to balance out a bit if you're on the fence.

column8: Excellent simulation game! I love the interaction level among the residents of the spacestations. Only a few noticable bugs in the alpha.
column9: Excellent simulation game! I love the interaction level among the residents of the spacestations. Only a few noticable bugs in the alpha.

column8: Double Fine present us with our own little slice of space in this pick up and play spacebase builder. Fun, interesting and while yes it is in Alpha, it promises to be something quite fun. In its current state it is playable and enjoyable, with a few random bugs here and there. Features are a little thin on the ground at the minute but it is an Alpha so it is to be expected. The roguelike elements add to the game rather that detract, its always dishearting to see your beloved crew dying starvation and with no reload function you really do miss the little guys. All in all give it a go, its fun to take up a few hours at the moment and hopefully will shape up to be a great wee game.

column9:
The game is great, but there are a lot, or rather, a LOT of bugs!!! It's clear they're working on the game, BUT there aren't enough rooms and things you can build yet. Moreover, when your base gets too big, the engineers give up on everything and don't repair the oxygen modules. Then you're 100% lost.
So, the rating:
Idea - 9 out of 10
Execution - 5 out of 10
I recommend waiting; there are too many bugs and not enough rooms right now.

column8:
Beta access is cool, but it ruins the game experience. I'm really pretty much over playing unfinished games.

Spacebase DF-9 has a lot of potential as a fairly simple sim-space world builder game, but there is too much that isn't working well yet for me to give this a wholly positive recommendation. Not worth the buy-in price unless you like playing betas.

Having said all this, I'll be more than happy to review this game again once it gets closer to completion.

If you found this review helpful, please have a look at [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/essidus/recommended/][u]my other reviews.[/u][/url]

column8: Some people may be thrown off by the idea of buying a game in its alpha stage, but I have so much fun playing this. No matter how glitchy or buggy it may be (I have only encountered two bugs, while some people have encountered a bunch), it is all about the setting and the experience that this game creates. I started to play this game, and 4 hours later realized I had memorized patterns, and adapted my strategy, adapting to chaos and catastrophe. There is a sense of accomplishment when you get all of your crew members to an emotional state above just "Happy" and reading their logs to see what is going on in their lives. This space simulator is addicting and engaging, and I am very impressed by the amount of detail and development behind such a broken masterpiece.

column8: It's an alpha, so you aren't really getting much right now. However, the developers are quite up front (and accurate) about what is currently in the game and have posted their near-future plans as well as those that are a bit further out. In particular, keeping morale up is very important (and not something you are really going to notice at this stage unless you check the forums) and isn't the easiest to do. I'm also not a huge fan of the fact that objects only have 2 orientation choices right now (as opposed to 4). However, all in all it has kept me amused for a good amount of time and offers a lot of promise for the future.

column8:
I have a penchant for space sims and decided to give this a go. My immediate advice to those considering purchasing would be: wait. The game's fairly expensive at the moment and I sort of ran out of things to do after only playing it for a hour or two.

The game shows a lot of promise however. I enjoyed it and I look forward to playing it properly when it's more complete, but this is one of those early access titles that when it says it's an alpha, it really means it.

In the meantime why not enjoy Startopia? It's been done for ten years and isn't gonna get any less awesome while you wait for Double Fine to finish this fine morsel.

column8:
This comes off more like Dwarf Fortress than some of the flashier me-too versions. Though, if you like DF you will find this unbearably simple. There is not much to see or do in the world right now but its a fun time waster. If the devs continue to deepen the possible interactions without changing the core mechanics I could see this being one of my favorite games.

Unfortunately the devs decided to end development on this game leaving a lot of promises on the table.   I really hope the studio does a better job with Massive Chalice.

....yet.


I figured it would be alpha as in full of bugs. Turns out it's a mostly bug free extremely short demo.

There is some promise here. If this turns out to be Dwarf Fortress in space that would be fantastic but it's feeling more like a theme park game at this point. Babby mode easy and when it is "hard" it's because your sims are pants-on-head retarded and can't follow a basic command.

I'm hoping against hope that is actually a bug but I get the feeling it's going to be one of those games where you are infuriated with retarded sims not doing the most basic task and you have no direct controll over them so you're just stuck yelling at the screen.

Just wait. I don't plan to play it again until it's finished. Gameplay issues aside there is almost no content here. I'm not going to boot it up again every time they add a new sprite.

column8:
A space colony game, in the very beggining of the early access, it was buggy as hell and dull after half an hour, currently they are adding more features, which makes the game more interesting, I think Spacebase is going in a good direction, it's nothing superb atm, but it might be later on. 

I'll give it a 5/10 for those who like numbers. Don't buy now, check how it will go later, instead I recommend checking Rimworld and Maia, they look a much better option then Spacebase atm.

column8:
I must reiterate what's been said by practically every other reviewer.

This game was a great idea and was coming along nicely. Then the dev decided they didn't want to make it any more (for whatever reason) and put a "finished" sticker on it. Right up until they stopped developing it, it truly was evolving into a great game. It's certainly worth checking out if you can get it FOR FREE. DO NOT pay any money for this game but there are some really cool ideas and features here (that are almost all thoroughly incomplete but it's nice to see what they were going for).

column8:
So Double Fine is a bad developer. They didn't really fix any of the major problems with the alpha. Barely did any work on the game. Then just abandoned it. If you're going to do early access you need to have a plan to finish the game. Instead they released a good idea, with the intension of getting back to it. Then realized it would take too much work to actually make it a good game; so they abandoned it. WTF Double Fine!  

Please stop supporting this developer.

-----

*Inital Alpha review*

This game is fun to play. However, right now, at the very beginning of alpha stages it's not worth the price. There isn't a lot of content at this time. Plus the crew's AI amounts to a lemming mentality. One wrong event could send your whole crew blindly walking towards their deaths. That said, there is a lot of fun to be had. People have personalities and some of the events can really get hectic. I'll update as this game develops.

column8:
This game is litterally unplayable.

There's nothing more here other then some nice graphic on an existing engin. The mechanics that have been made in-house are obvious. The path-finding via open Space is buggy and sufocates the crew. The mechanic that lets you repair structurs, like the oxygen generator, is buggy and sufocates the crew.

I tried to get my money back, but Steam said they wanted to keep it.
